The Chinese people stepped into the 20th century carrying the national humiliation of the occupation of China's capital, Beijing, by the Eight-Nation Alliance. At that time, the outlook appearing before the Chinese nation seemed to be a gloomy and tragic prospect on the brink of destruction. Since the Opium War in 1840, foreign capitalism has invaded China, causing significant changes in Chinese society and gradually turning it into a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society. To achieve the goal of enslaving and eliminating China, imperialists adopted military, political, economic, cultural, and other means to invade China. And the feudal rulers in China, in order to maintain their own rule, even stooped to rely on imperialism, becoming the agents of Western powers. The 1911 Revolution led by Sun Yat-sen overthrew the monarchical system that had ruled China for thousands of years, initiating a modern democratic revolution in a more complete sense, opening the gate to China's progress, but failed to change the social nature of old China and the miserable plight of the people. After Yuan Shikai seized power in the Republic of China, the political environment in China dramatically deteriorated. Yuan Shikai completely wiped out the small amount of democracy obtained formally through the 1911 Revolution, publically instigating a farce of restoring monarchy. After Yuan Shikai fell from power, China sank into a situation of warlords carving up the country and fighting. Under the manipulation of imperialism, powerful warlords advocated "unification through force", while smaller ones described their actions as “maintaining territorial integrity and ensuring people's safety”. In fact, they were all fighting for power and oppressing the people. Continuous wars between the warlords over the years brought severe destruction and endless disasters to society and people's lives. Around 1915, China experienced several major famines, which brought even more suffering to the people’s lives. 

The invasion of imperialism also forced China to gradually adopt capitalist methods of production. Since the 1860s, China has developed its own national industries. After the Sino-Japanese War, China's national economy grew significantly. From 1895 to 1913, 548 new factories and mines were established across the country, with a total capital of 120.297 million yuan, including 463 entirely commercially managed factories and mines with a total capital of 90.821 million yuan. With the development of China's national economy, the Chinese proletariat grew and strengthened. In 1894, there were approximately 100,000 workers in China's modern industries; by 1914, on the eve of World War I, this number had grown to over 1 million. This demonstrates that imperialism, although massively profiting in China, had also contributed to the creation of revolutionary forces against it.

The dual development threads of national oppression and the rise of modern industry constitute the overall trend of modern Chinese society. Imperialism and feudal forces combined, pushing China into a dark abyss; yet, the emergence of national industry and new social forces brought hope to China's future. Looking over the 110 years of China being a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, modern China indeed experienced its deepest downfall in the early 20th century (1901-1915).

The First World War accelerated the evolution of Chinese society, triggering a cultural awakening in the intellectual community that was unprecedented. During the war, on September 15, 1915, Chen Duxiu founded the "Youth Magazine" (later renamed to "New Youth" from the second volume), using evolutionism as a weapon to initiate a new cultural movement against Confucianism and the old traditions. The thoughts of the fighters for the new culture were very radical, not recognizing traditional authority and various dogmas, demanding the breaking of spiritual shackles, and using "reason" to critically scrutinize everything. People usually refer to this cultural movement as the "Enlightenment Movement". It has a consistency in nature and content compared to the Enlightenment movement in the West since the 15th century, that is, both are critiques of feudal thought and culture, paving the way for the development of capitalism. However, there are some differences in timing between the two. The Western Enlightenment prepared the ideological groundwork for the outbreak of the European bourgeois revolution, whereas the new cultural movement in China made up for the ideological deficiency after the outbreak of the bourgeois revolution. The movement broke out amidst the backdrop of the world imperialistic great war and domestic warlord chaos, inevitably strengthening the initiators’ resistance against imperialism and feudalism, thereby infusing the movement with new historical content to a certain extent. It prepared the ideological premise and necessary conditions for the subsequent spread of Marxism in China and the outbreak of the May 4th patriotic movement.

The war also exposed the flaws of Western civilization, destroying the idols in the hearts of the Chinese people. The brutal war not only resulted in over ten million deaths and over twenty million injured and disabled, but also almost completely annihilated the material civilization that had been accumulated for many years within a few short years. Liang Qichao arrived in Europe just as the war ended, traveling through the UK, France, Belgium, and other countries. In "Records of a Traveller's Heartfelt Impressions in Europe", he described the scenes he saw of production destruction, faith crisis, social chaos, and public poverty in Europe, sighing that there "the whole society has fallen into a state of despair and fear, like a ship that has lost its compass in a foggy wind, not knowing what to do." This couldn't help but shock the Chinese who were always fond of learning from the West.

It was at this time that many intellectuals began to recognize that Chinese society had to be reformed, and moreover, it needed to be reformed in a direction completely different from Western capitalism. The conclusion Liang Qichao drew after traveling through Europe was: social revolution, perhaps the only characteristic of the 20th century, no country can escape, it is only a matter of sooner or later. Zheng Zhenduo's conclusion after analyzing the various evils of capitalism was: "The society under the domination of capitalism has no room for existence." The concepts of advanced Chinese intellectuals began to undergo profound changes, from longing for Western parliamentary democracy to disappointment, from pursuing capitalism to denial. The "Minxing" magazine at the time wrote: "Republican democracy is not our end, the world revolution is inevitable.”

The idol in the heart has collapsed, but the journey must still continue. Amidst the turbulence of world politics, the First World War and the Russian October Revolution brought new changes to the world, prompting a group of Chinese who cared about the future and destiny of their homeland to start re-exploring the plan to transform society.



At this moment, Marxism caught the attention of progressive Chinese, triggering a wave of enthusiastic propaganda for socialism. At the time, out of the hundreds of publications advocating for "social transformation", the vast majority expressed varying degrees of positive sentiment and longing for socialism. Many publications featured articles introducing and promoting socialism almost in every issue. Some young authors hailed socialism as the "lucky star of humanity", and believed that if China were to "undertake construction, it must follow the principles of socialism", which was seen as the "common ideal of humanity now and in the future".
Socialism became the most popular ideology. However, it should be acknowledged that the "socialism" discussed during this period was quite diverse. In addition to Marx's scientific socialism, it included various factions known as "socialism", such as Stirner's "anarchist individualism", Proudhon's "social anarchism", Bakunin's "collective anarchism", Kropotkin's "mutual aid", Mutsukado's "new village", etc. But one thing was certain: the widespread dissemination of socialist ideals in China at this time was strongly influenced by the crisis of Western capitalism after World War I. When the monthly magazine "Communist Party" was established in Shanghai in 1920, it pointed out: "The economic transformation naturally occupies a major position in humanity's changes. Our production methods, other than capitalism and socialism, have no other way. Capitalism in the West has already developed and is on the verge of collapse ... What naturally follows it is the socialist production method.”

A harmonious socialist society is desirable, but what is this society like, and how can it be achieved? At this point, news of the successful Russian October Revolution reached China. The success of the October Revolution in Russia, led by Lenin, turned socialism from a theory in textbooks into a vivid reality. Marxism was the intellectual weapon of this change. After the October Revolution, despite civil war and armed foreign interference, Russia still held its ground on the world stage and showed vitality, forming a stark contrast with the declining Western capitalism. Consequently, advanced Chinese intellectuals began to turn their attention to the Soviet Union, and to Marxism.

Chinese people came into contact very early with Marx and his teachings. Between September 1902 and 1906, Liang Qichao published several articles in the "New People's Miscellany", introducing Marx and his doctrines. Zhu Zhixin, a bourgeois revolutionary democrat, published an article in the November 1905 issue of "People's Daily", introducing Marx, Engels, their lives, and their teachings. In addition, Sun Yat-sen, Song Jiaoren, and Liao Zhongkai mentioned Marxism in their speeches and articles. Some anarchists mentioned Marx and Engels in their publications and translated their works. However, these introductions were fragmentary, scattered, some even distorted, and the introducers did not adhere to Marxism, with some even criticizing it.




These introductions had, and could not have, a significant impact on the transformation of Chinese society at the time. By the May Fourth period, under the propaganda and instigation of new-style intellectuals in China, introducing Marxism became an unstoppable intellectual trend.

Among the disseminators of Marxism during the May Fourth period, the most influential were Li Dazhao and Chen Duxiu. Both of them had a great influence on a generation of Chinese people, both in thought and politics.
Li Dazhao was the first person to propagate Marxism in China, playing a leading role in the early Marxist propagation movement. From July to November 1918, he successively published articles such as "Comparative View of the French and Russian Revolutions", "Victory of the Common People", and "Victory of Bolshevism", lauding the value and significance of the October Revolution with profound historical insight. After the May Fourth movement, he compiled volume six, issue five of the "New Youth" magazine, which he edited, into the "Marx Research Issue", and published an article "My View of Marxism", for the first time systematically expounding Marxist economic doctrine, historical materialism, and socialist theory in China. Li Dazhao fully affirmed Marxism's historical position, calling it "the doctrine of world transformation". He said, Marx's socialist theory can be roughly divided into three parts: a theory about the past, which is his historical theory, also known as the theory of social organization evolution; a theory about the present, which is his economic theory, also known as the theory of capitalism; and a theory about the future, which is his policy theory, also known as the theory of socialist movement, which is social democracy. "His theory is a completely self-contained, systematic organization." Among them, Marx's historical theory reveals the material causes of social development and class relations, elaborates on the theories of productive forces and relations, economic foundation and superstructure, classes and class struggle; Marx's economic theory elaborates on the "theory of surplus labour and surplus value", reveals the "secret of modern capitalism" and the "capitalist exploitation of labour production mode", which is the fundamental idea of Marx's economic theory. Marx observed the economic condition of modern society with the viewpoints of historical materialism and surplus value principle, analysed and studied the economic organization of capitalism, foresaw that the capitalist system will inevitably be replaced by the socialist system, and then stated that "the means and methods of realizing socialism are still in the ultimate class competition." Hence, Li Dazhao emphasized, Marx's "these three theories are inseparable, and class competition is like a golden thread, linking these three principles fundamentally."
Later, Li Dazhao also published articles such as "Marx's Historical Philosophy" to promote historical materialism. He also taught courses on historical materialism, socialism and social movements at Peking University and Beijing Women's High School. In the theoretical system of Marxism, he took historical materialism as a focus, fully reflecting his urgent desire to find theoretical guidance to solve China's problems.
Unlike Li Dazhao, Chen Duxiu transitioned from a radical democrat to a Marxist slightly later. But because Chen Duxiu had long been the editor of "New Youth", and already had a certain reputation in the New Culture Movement, he quickly became the most influential propagator of Marxism in China. In March 1920, in his article "Malthus's Population Theory and China's Population Problem", he began to contact Marxist views, and made some criticisms of Malthus's theory, while holding a reserved attitude towards Marx's historical materialism. In his subsequent speech "The Awakening of the Laborer", Chen Duxiu expressed the Marxist viewpoint that "labor creates the world", "the worker is the most useful and valuable". He emphasized that the old saying, "those who work with their minds govern people, those who work with their bodies are governed by people", should be reversed to "those who work with their bodies govern people, those who work with their minds are governed by people", which is the correct principle.



Of course, the real change in Chen Duxiu's thought, that is, from critical commentary and agreement, towards endorsing and propagating socialism, started with the article "On Politics" published in September 1920. In this article, Chen Duxiu criticized the anarchist opposition to politics, law, power, and the state, pointing out that the root of global inequality lies in the existence of the bourgeoisie. He stated, "To sweep away this inequality, this suffering, the oppressed productive working class must create new forces themselves, stand on the position of the state, utilize political and legal agencies to completely conquer the oppressive bourgeoisie, and only then can we hope to abolish private property, wage labor and other systems, and eliminate the overly unequal economic conditions." This suggests that he endorses the Marxist attitude and position, clearly approving of the Marxist view of "building a labor (i.e., productive) class state by revolutionary means, creating politics and law that prohibits all forms of plunder, both domestically and internationally, for the primary need of modern society." Chen Duxiu has a historical mission and ideal pursuit of opposing warlords and seeking public happiness. As a revolutionary with a strong action temperament, he has a special fondness for the Marxist theory of social revolution. He created publications, organized groups, and wrote articles to expose the evils of the capitalist system, propagate socialist thought, and effectively pushed for the spread of Marxism in China.

Compared with Chen Duxiu, the outstanding characteristic of Li Dazhao is that he established a firm historical materialism, believed in the great role of the masses in the historical process, recognized that the power of social development could only be sought in the nature of the people themselves, and never in any external forces. Based on this understanding, Li Dazhao emphasized the combination of theory and practice and actively involved himself among the masses.

In addition to Li Dazhao and Chen Duxiu, those who studied and studied Marxism during their studies in Japan, such as Li Da, Yang Kuan, and Li Hanjun, also promoted and expanded the propaganda of Marxism through publishing articles and translating works. Li Da returned to China after translating the books "Explanation of Historical Materialism", "Marx's Economics", and "Social Problems Overview". Among them, "Marx's Economics" was included in the reading list by the Marx Doctrine Research Society established by Li Dazhao at Peking University. After returning to China, Yang Kan published articles such as "Socialism" and "Marxism... Scientific Socialism" on Guangdong's "Zhonghua Xinbao" from October to December 1919. The former praised Marx's "Capital" as a "socialist classic"; the latter systematically introduced Marxism's historical materialism, class struggle theory, and surplus value theory. Li Hanjun translated and wrote about sixty articles related to Marxism in just over two years before the founding of the Chinese Communist Party. In addition, progressive journalist Shao Piaoping also contributed to the spread of Marxism.



During the May Fourth Movement, among those who introduced and studied Marxism, some not only believed that Marxism was the truth but also believed it was a weapon to transform China; some just used it as a Western theory to explore, without connecting it to the actual situation in China; some were studying it to prevent China from following the path guided by Marxism. In terms of class attributes, Marxism is the doctrine for the working class seeking liberation, and it will not be accepted by representatives of other classes. Thus, when the early Chinese Marxists linked Marxism with China's fate, debates were inevitable. Marxism is an ideology that paves the way forward in struggles.



The first debate revolved around the cultural choice of China, i.e., whether the solution to the China issue should be guided by Marxism. In July 1919, Hu Shi, one of the proponents of the May Fourth New Culture Movement, published an article called "Study More Problems, Talk Less about Isms," which sparked a heated debate in the intellectual realm from July to September. Hu Shi's theoretical foundation was experimentalism. He believed that "the greatest danger currently in the public opinion sphere is to incline towards doctrines on paper, without actually investigating what Chinese society needs today", and “it should be known that the first duty of a public opinion leader is to carefully study the real situation of society. All academic theories, all isms, are just tools for such investigations.” He was very opposed to the popular "empty talk of isms."

After Hu Shi's article was published, Li Dazhao and Lan Gongwu wrote articles expressing their dissent. In Li Dazhao and Lan Gongwu's view, all problems are intertwined in an all-encompassing social structure, and the notion or ism to solve these problems needs to be verified through social experiments. People need to use isms as criteria to judge the situation and problems, and also as tools to solve these interconnected issues. Li Dazhao agreed with Hu Shi's view that actual problems should be seriously studied, and that various theories should not be discussed in a vague and unclear manner. However, he did not believe that there was any fundamental contradiction between studying problems and discussing isms. He pointed out that "the solution to a social problem must rely on the joint movement of the majority of people in society", and to "make a social problem the common problem of the majority of people in society," we must "first have a common ideal, an ism." "Our social movement, on the one hand, must indeed study practical issues, and on the other hand, it must also advocate ideal isms. These two aspects are interdependent and compatible." He also pointed out that the study of problems should be based on academic theories; before the study of various problems, there must be a study of various isms. The debate on "problem and ism" was actually a discussion within the progressive intellectuals at that time on the development of Chinese thought and the fate of modern Chinese history. Hu Shi advised people to talk less about isms, advocating that China did not need a profound revolution to solve the problems he mentioned. Li Dazhao pointed out that the popularity of Bolshevism was a major shift in world culture, the theory of class struggle was an important component of historical materialism, and if we did not pay attention to class struggle and did not use this academic theory as a tool to guide the practical movement of workers' union, then the economic revolution may never be realized. In this debate, Li Dazhao and young Marxists from all over the country, based on their understanding at the time, proved that Marxism suits the needs of China, which had a positive effect on the spread of Marxism.

The debate surrounding "problems and isms" further aroused intellectual reflections on China's future. In September 1920, Zhang Dongfu published an article in Shanghai titled "Another Lesson from Travel in the Mainland," arguing that there was only one way to save China, and that was to increase wealth and develop industry. He later stated that the quickest method to develop industry was none other than capitalism. The early Marxists seriously criticized this argument, leading to the debate about the "problem of socialism" during the spread of Marxism.




In May 1921, Li Da pointed out in his article published in "New Youth" that China is the marketplace for all nations. The economic power cultivated by various capitalist countries in China has taken root and is unbreakable. China, under the heavy forces of politics and economics in the era of nascent industries, may face extreme difficulties should it wish to develop capitalism and wage an economic war against other capitalist countries. In the dispute with Zhang Dongfu and others, early Marxists, through comparative analysis of the advantages and disadvantages of both socialist and capitalist systems, essentially proposed the idea that only socialism can develop China's productive forces. Li Dazhao pointed out, "If we want to develop industries in China today, it is essential to have a government organized by pure producers to eliminate the exploiting class within the country and resist world capitalism by managing industries according to socialist organization." Chen Duxiu also emphasized, "To enable all Chinese to acquire a humanly life, it is necessary to abolish the capitalist production system and adopt the socialist production system. At this time, it is both possible and necessary for us in China to talk about socialism." Thus, walking on the socialist path was the common system choice revealed by early communists in China during the dispute, and this choice represents the demands for the advanced productive force development in China.

The third dispute was carried out against anarchists. During the May Fourth Movement, anarchism was widely spread among young intellectuals. It played a constructive role against the monarchical autocratic system and raised people's awakening. However, it advocated for absolute individual freedom, opposition to any organized discipline, all authorities, all nations, and anarchic society and emphasized absolute equality. This opposition to Marxist state doctrine and proletarian dictatorship became a major obstacle to the spread of Marxism. Therefore, another ideological clash began with anarchists like Huang Lingshuang while the debate on socialism with Zhang Dongmi was not yet over. During the debate, "New Youth," "Communist Party" monthly, and others published articles critically attacking anarchism. In January 1922, the "Vanguard," magazine of the Chinese Socialist Youth League, made criticism of anarchism one of its significant tasks.

The Marxist criticism of anarchism was mainly about the form of revolution, essence of the state, and necessity of the dictatorship of the proletariat. They pointed out on one hand that under the exploitation of imperialism and capitalists, the Chinese proletariat had been enduring intolerable pain and had a strong demand for seizing state power through violent revolution. On the other hand, they pointed out that only by establishing the dictatorship of the proletariat can the interests of the laborers be protected. Therefore, the state of the feudal nobility and the bourgeoisie must be completely overthrown, while the state power of the proletariat must be consolidated and enhanced. This represents the right path from capitalism to communism. In addition, Marxists criticized the egalitarianism of anarchists over distribution, emphasizing the refutation of their "absolute freedom" fallacy, pointing out that in human society freedom is always relative, and so-called "absolute freedom" doesn't exist. This conflict criticizing anarchist thought was grand in scale.

The argument between Marxism and non-Marxism was the first confrontation in the spread of Marxism, which had significant and profound influence on China's intellectual field. During this dispute, early Marxists, with unwavering faith, bravely wielded Marxism as a theoretical weapon, refuting various erroneous ideas of the bourgeoisie and petty bourgeoisie. A group of progressive youths dedicated to saving the people and remaking Chinese society began to appreciate the scientific and truthful nature of Marxist theory after this conflict, recognizing that only scientific socialism can achieve the goal of saving people and fundamentally transforming Chinese society.



In the process of establishing their life beliefs and choosing what "ism" to use to transform Chinese society, they ultimately chose scientific socialism, became Marxists, and swiftly become involved in the action of propagating Marxism, associating with the working class, and establishing early Chinese Communist Party (CCP) organizations.

After accepting Marxism, advanced Chinese intellectuals immediately applied it to studying Chinese issues and situation. This practical-oriented value orientation reflected the thought situation of the Chinese intellectual community at that time. After the May Fourth Movement, social reform thinking was widely surging. The "Work-Study Mutual Aid Group" established in 1919, whose initiators included well-known figures like Chen Duxiu, Li Dazhao, and Cai Yuanpei. This trend drove a large number of youths to society, prompting them to understand the reality of social life in China. At the same time, debates with non-Marxist ideologies also promoted early Chinese Marxists to study practical problems. Shortly after Hu Shi proposed "to study more problems", many socialists and their followers began to approach workers and peasants, studying their living conditions, while Hu Shi and his followers rarely engaged in this kind of social investigation and labor movement.

Li Dazhao made significant contributions to the development of practical-oriented value orientation. Long before the May Fourth Movement, he published such articles and encouraged young people to integrate with the public and delve into the reality of Chinese society. Under Li Dazhao's influence, in March 1919, young students such as Deng Zhongxia organized the People's Education Lecture Group of Peking University and carried out organized education and propaganda activities among the people. After the May Fourth Movement, Li Dazhao organized revolutionary elements in Beijing to investigate the living conditions of rickshaw workers on the one hand and sent Deng Zhongxia, Zhang Guozhu and others to propagate among the railway workers in Changxindian, set up labor tutoring schools, established worker clubs, and organized workers. In March 1920, in addition to lectures in the city, the People's Education Lecture Group of Peking University also gave speeches in factories and villages in Lugou Bridge, Changxindian, Tong County, etc., conducted social surveys, and understood the lower classes. Through the lecture activities, these young intellectuals initially perceived the hardships of workers and peasants and the backwardness of education, and understood that rural people are easy to understand the truth and easy to instill new thoughts. Deng Zhongxia was trained through lectures in Changxindian, which laid the foundation for his later leadership of the workers' movement.
Another important method of Marxists' practical orientation is to establish worker’s tutoring schools, worker’s night schools and literacy classes, and establish worker’s clubs. In this way, on the one hand, it is possible to instill the thoughts of scientific socialism into the working masses and discover and cultivate backbone members among the working masses. Through them, organize a large number of workers, laying the foundation for the establishment of unions and the leadership of workers' struggles. On the other hand, it is also conducive to the Marxists establishing close ties with their own class and participating in the actual struggle of workers. This method of running schools among workers is a form often used by the later party in leading the workers' movement. The 1920 International Labor Day commemoration is an important start for Chinese Marxists to move towards the workers' movement...



They took advantage of the situation to promote to workers the values of labor and the great role of the working class, exposing the evils of the capitalist system and calling on the working class to unite and struggle. In Shanghai, Chen Duxiu personally participated in and guided the joint meeting composed of seven industry groups such as the Chinese Industrial Association and the Chinese Trade Union Federation to jointly initiate the preparation of a May Day commemoration. At the commemoration, the speakers spoke about the sanctity of labor and the audience's emotions ran high. The resolutions made at the meeting were as follows: ① demand for an eight-hour workday; ② organization of real unions for workers; ③ union of workers from all industries. After the meeting, the seven groups issued a "Response to the Soviet Peasant Government", proposing "we will strive to create a new, beautiful, and eternally peaceful world for mankind, deciding to cooperate with you and bear this responsibility".
At the same time, similar commemorative events were also held in Beijing. On May 1, Peking University suspended classes for one day. More than 500 school workers and students held a commemorative meeting at Peking University. Li Dazhao attended the meeting and gave a speech. The Work-Study Mutual Aid Group took two cars for a parade in the east and west cities. Banner flying in front of the car, with the red words "labor is sacred" and "long live May 1", attracted particular attention. They chanted slogans such as "long live the workers", and distributed leaflets with "Declaration of Beijing Workers on May 1".
In addition to Shanghai and Beijing, workers and students in other places like Tangshan, Harbin, Jiujiang, Guangzhou, Shantou, and Zhangzhou also held commemorative activities. This was a large-scale movement combining Marxism with the Chinese labor movement. Cai Hesen commented: "The first May Day propaganda in China was very huge; the 'New Youth' issued up to 10,000 copies, so it had a great influence at the time and had spread all over the country."
Among early Marxists, Mao Zedong was also a model of practical attention and action. As early as the autumn of 1919, he established the Problem Research Association in Changsha. This society proposed to research topics on politics, economy, society, education, labor, and international affairs, as well as issues like how to unite people, the possibility of socialism, and the teachings of Confucius, totaling over 140. He often went deep into the lives of railway workers, construction workers, and porters to understand the situation, make friends, and establish workers' night schools and trade unions. To blend in with workers, Mao often discarded his long robe for short shirts, learned the language of the workers, understood their demands, and felt their lives.
Intellectuals promoting Marxism turned to practicality and went deep into the worker and peasant communities to carry out propaganda and organize work, promoting the integration of Marxism and the Chinese labor movement.



At the same time, their thoughts and feelings have also changed, gradually forming into vanguard soldiers with communist consciousness. The working and farming masses began to accept Marxism, from which emerged a group of advanced elements with communist ideals. In China, the conditions for establishing a Communist Party organization have matured. 



The spread of Marxism, its selection and gradual integration with the Chinese labor movement, and the emergence of a group of advanced communists naturally brought the issue of organizing a Chinese working-class party onto the agenda. Li Dazhao pointed out: "China currently lacks a group that truly represents the people's power, (If one faction of friends can establish a strong and rigorous organization and pay attention to promoting the training of its members, then China's thorough reform will have a reference point!" Cai Hesen clearly pointed out at the Montargney meeting of the New People's Society members studying in France: The proletarian revolutionary movement must "first organize the party - the Communist Party"; because the party "is the initiator, propagator, vanguard, and combat unit of the revolutionary movement"; with the party, the revolutionary movement and labor movement have a nerve center. This shows that the consensus of the Chinese avant-garde with communist beliefs has been established at that time.

Under the promotion of Li Dazhao, the Beijing University Marxist Research Society, established in March 1920, was the earliest Chinese group with the purpose of learning and researching Marxism. Most of its members were students from Peking University, mainly including Deng Zhongxia, Gao Junyu, Huang Rikui, Fan Hongjie, He Mengxiong, Li Jun, Zhu Wushan, Zhang Guozhu, Liu Renjing, and Luo Zhanglong, etc. The union of Marxist intellectuals aimed to establish the Communist Party. It was at this time that Voitinsky, a representative of the Communist International, came to China. His task was to understand the situation in China, establish contact with progressive forces in China, and investigate the possibility of establishing a Communist International East Asia Secretariat in Shanghai. After several talks with Li Dazhao and others, he expressed that he wanted to support and help the work of building a Communist Party in China. Introduced by Li Dazhao, Voitinsky met Chen Duxiu in Shanghai. Based on his investigations in Beijing and Shanghai, Voitinsky thought that the timing for establishing the party in China was ripe and suggested Chen Duxiu organize the Communist Party of China. This was in line with Chen Duxiu's intention. Chen Duxiu then introduced Voitinsky to meet Li Hanjun, the editor of the socialist propagating "Weekly Review". After several discussions, it was decided to establish a secret organization to prepare for the official establishment of the party. The Shanghai Marxist Research Society was established the same year in May, with Chen Duxiu as the person in charge, and members included Li Hanjun, Shen Xuanlu, Shao Lizhi, Chen Wangdao, Shi Cuntong, Yu Xiusong, Shen Yanbing, and Yang Mingzhai, etc.

Meanwhile, The Communist International also planned to establish an East Asian secretariat in Shanghai, including China, Korea, and Japan sectors, to guide the party building work in East Asian countries. Under Voitinsky's efforts, "the work of the China sector progressed smoothly. Relying on worker and student organizations, the sector has laid the groundwork for communist organizations in Beijing, Shanghai, Tianjin, Guangzhou, Hankou, Nanjing, and other places".



In August 1920, the Shanghai Communist Party organization was formally established, initiated by Chen Duxiu, Li Hanjun, Shen Xuanlu, Chen Wangdao, Yu Xiusong, Shi Cuntong (then in Japan), Yang Mingzhai, Li Da, and others. Upon its inception, this organization took on the task of establishing party organizations nationwide. Shortly after the establishment of the Shanghai party organization, Zhang Shenfu, a lecturer from Beijing Normal University, came to Shanghai to prepare for the arrival of British philosopher Bertrand Russell. In Chen Duxiu's home, they widely discussed issues about party establishment. They believed that those eligible to join the party should be absorbed into the party, and a Communist Party organization should be established in Beijing, headed by Li Dazhao. In late September, Zhang Shenfu returned to Beijing with Chen Duxiu's suggestions and discussed with Li Dazhao about party establishment. They unanimously agreed to promptly develop party members. At the beginning of October, Zhang Guozhu, who attended the National Student Federation's fund-raising activities, returned to Beijing and conveyed Chen Duxiu's views on party establishment in Beijing to Li Dazhao. Therefore, Li Dazhao, Zhang Shenfu, and Zhang Guozhu formally established the Beijing Communist Party organization in Li Dazhao's office. The Beijing Communist Party organization was the main base for propagating Marxism and cultivating revolutionary talents in northern China.

With the impetus of party organizations in Shanghai and Beijing, local Communist Party organizations sprung up everywhere. From the autumn and winter of 1920 to the first half of 1921, early Communist Party organizations were established successively by Dong Biwu, Chen Tanqiu and others in Wuhan; Chen Gongbo, Tan Pingshan and others in Guangzhou; Mao Zedong, He Shuheng and others in Changsha; Wang Jinmei, Deng Enming and others in Jinan; Shi Cuntong, Zhou Fohai and others in Japan; Zhang Shenfu, Zhao Shiyan, Chen Gongpei, Zhou Enlai and others in France. Different terms were used as the names of these early organizations in China. The organization in Shanghai was called the Communist Party of China from the very beginning, and that in Beijing was referred to as the "Beijing Branch of the Communist Party of China". All of them served as local organizations of the unified Communist Party of China that was subsequently formed, and they were then conventionally referred to as "communist groups". The members of these organizations were mostly advanced intellectuals who had grown up through the May Fourth Movement. Their understanding of Marxism and their observation of practical issues in China were deeper than that of other contemporary Chinese people. These local Communist Party organizations directly paved the way for the formal establishment of the Communist Party of China.

Under the guidance of the Communist International, the scattered local Communist Party organizations gradually came together to establish a unified Communist Party organization in China. In June 1921, the Secretary Bureau of the Irkutsk Communist International sent Maring and Nikolsky to Shanghai successively, suggesting early convening of a national congress to formally establish the Communist Party of China. Thereafter, Li Da notified party organizations nationwide to each select two representatives to attend the congress. On July 23, the first national congress of the Communist Party of China was officially held in Shanghai. Li Da, Li Hanjun, Zhang Guozhu, Liu Renjing, Mao Zedong, He Shuheng, Dong Biwu, Chen Tanqiu, Wang Jinmei, Deng Enming, Chen Gongbo, Zhou Fohai, Bao Huiseng and others, representing over fifty party members nationwide, attended the congress. Maring and Nikolsky also participated in the congress. Li Dazhao was unable to attend due to reasons. Chen Duxiu did not attend either, but he entrusted Bao Huiseng to propose a program stating that "the Communist Party should adhere to democratic centralism, believe in communism, realize the dictatorship of the proletariat and implement communism" to be discussed at the congress.



The convention passed the "First Program of the Communist Party of China," which stipulates: "The party is named the Communist Party of China. The party's program is: "Overthrow the power of the capitalist class," "Recognise the proletariat dictatorship," "Eliminate capitalist private ownership," and "Unite the Third International." The essence of the party's program is to carry out a socialist revolution and replace capitalism with communism.

As for the work arrangement after the party's establishment, there was fierce debate at the meeting. Li Hanjun and others believed that China's proletariat was too naive and did not understand Marxism. They advocated for uniting with advanced intellectuals to engage in research and promotion of Marxism. Most representatives disagreed with this opinion, believing that the party must focus its energy on social struggle and practical work. The first National Congress of the CPC decided to focus its work on the labor movement and made specific arrangements for all aspects of the party's work. This was reflected in the "First Resolution of the Communist Party of China" (hereinafter referred to as the "Resolution"). The "Resolution" stipulates that the basic task of the party is to establish trade unions, "wherever there is more than one industrial sector, a trade union should be organised," and "the party should instil the spirit of class struggle in the union." It emphasized the establishment of worker schools to increase worker awareness. In order to guide and promote the labor movement, due to the small number of party members and the lack of organization, the convention decided not to establish a central committee of the party temporarily and instead set up a central bureau to lead all party work. The meeting elected Chen Duxiu, Li Da, and Zhang Guozhu to form the Central Bureau, with Chen Duxiu as secretary of the Central Bureau, Li Da as propaganda commissioner, and Zhang Guozhu as organization commissioner.

The establishment of the Communist Party of China was a groundbreaking event in Chinese history. It demonstrated that China now had a new type of unified workers' party with communism as its goal and Marxism as its guide of action. Although the party was weak when it was founded, it actually represented the development requirements of China's advanced productive forces, represented the direction of China's advanced culture, and could become the most trusted leadership force and strong core of the Chinese people.

The party's program formulated by the First National Congress of the Communist Party of China, although it still lacks understanding of the particularities of Chinese society and the Chinese revolution, generally copied the articles of the party's program of the proletariat party in capitalist countries. However, its essence reflects the basic principles of Marxism on the proletariat revolution, which signifies that the Communist Party of China has established the guiding position of Marxism in the entire party's work as soon as it was established. Theoretically speaking, the basic principles of Marxism must be combined with Chinese reality, which was also recognised among early Marxists in China. As previously stated, in Li Dazhao's article "On the Issue and Doctrine Again" published in August 1919, he pointed out: "A socialist must study how his ideas can be applied to the surrounding reality to make his doctrine have some impact in the world." Liu Renjing stated in a letter to Zuo Daying in December 1920: our current task is to "find a policy that is suitable for the national conditions and can achieve communism." Although the idea is clear, to truly achieve the combination of "doctrine" and "reality," to find a "policy that is suitable for the national conditions and can achieve communism," is not something that the First National Congress of the Communist Party of China could achieve. It must go through a long period of struggle and repeated victories and failures, continuously summing up the experience and lessons of practical struggle, in order to achieve this.



Within a year of the founding of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), through studying and mastering Marxism and carrying out revolutionary struggles, they began to develop a deeper understanding of the international and domestic situations, the condition of Chinese society, and the fundamental issues of the Chinese revolution.
At that time, the key features of international and domestic situations were: imperialist nations were intensifying their aggression towards China, seeking further domination; conflicts and struggles among domestic warlords were becoming increasingly severe. Under such circumstances, various political forces proposed different solutions for China's way out. Among the ruling classes, the Beiyang warlords in control of the central government advocated "military unification", while local warlords in various provinces demanded "autonomy" or "provincial autonomy". These two opposing views both sought to protect the self-interests of various warlords, and could not solve any of China's problems. Among the bourgeoisie, some reformers represented by Hu Shi advocated establishing a "good person government", thinking that it was not necessary to oppose imperialism or overthrow warlord rule; as long as there were so-called "good person" entering the government, China could be saved. As for how these "good person" could enter the government, and whether they could make a difference after entering, were questions they could not answer. Although Sun Yat-sen still adhered to the revolutionary position of democracy, he could not propose a revolutionary program capable of mobilizing mass struggles. In November 1920, after the KMT forces expelled the Guangxi clique from Guangdong, Sun Yat-sen returned to Guangzhou from Shanghai and raised the banner of the "Constitution Protection". In April 1921, Sun Yat-sen was elected as the Extraordinary President of the Republic of China by the extraordinary congress held in Guangdong. He planned to launch the Northern Expedition based in Guangdong with the military support of Chen Jiongming. Despite Chen being a KMT member who outwardly supported Sun's initiative and claimed to follow socialism, he secretly accepted the provocation of imperialists, colluding with the Beiyang warlords, and launched an armed rebellion in June 1922, ultimately revealing his reactionary nature as a tool of imperialism. Sun was forced to leave Guangzhou and his Constitution Protection Movement completely failed. 
Where is China going? What's the future of the Chinese nation? Many patriotic individuals were distressed, bewildered, and worried about these questions. It was at this time that the young Communist Party of China, initially combining the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism with the reality of the Chinese revolution, proposed a program for the Chinese democratic revolution. 
When the Chinese Communists, with the belief of overthrowing the dark rule of reactionary classes and striving for socialism, plunged themselves into actual struggles, they quickly found that, under semi-colonial and semi-feudal conditions, what the Chinese people urgently required was not the immediate transformation to a socialist revolution. Because foreign capital controlled most of China's modern industry, whether it was the increasingly intense strikes in Shanghai, Changsha, and Hong Kong, or the workers' movements in other cities, it all inevitably clashed with imperialism and, to varying degrees, opposed imperialism.



Even the economic struggle of workers demanding improved living conditions can easily transform into a political struggle against imperialism and the warlord government. Imperialist forces and feudal warlords always collude, going to great lengths to destroy and suppress these mass struggles with violent means. The Chinese Communists came to understand in the course of actual struggles that if the Chinese Revolution did not first wage a struggle against imperialist aggression and the rule of feudal warlords, the country could not be independent, the people could not be liberated, and there would be no discussion of realizing the ideals of socialism and communism. Therefore, the Chinese Communist Party and the Chinese Bourgeoisie Democrats share some common points in the goals of the revolutionary struggle. This further understanding of the basic problems of the Chinese Revolution, which arises from practical experience, propels the Chinese Communist Party to establish realistic struggle objectives and corresponding strategies in order to realize the socialist ideal.

During the exploration and establishment of a revolutionary program suitable to China's national conditions, the Chinese Communist Party received help and guidance from Lenin and the Communist International. This was of great importance in helping the party correctly grasp the direction of the Chinese Revolution.

During this period, on the one hand, the party explored the basic problems of the Chinese Revolution through revolutionary practice, and on the other hand, accepted Lenin’s theories on national and colonial issues. These two facets were gradually being integrated, leading to the development of a revolutionary program that was largely consistent with China's national conditions.

The party first advocated for anti-imperialist and anti-feudal political views to labor unions and youth organizations. The first national labor conference held in May 1922 and the first representative assembly of the Chinese Socialist Youth League accepted the political slogan proposed by the Chinese Communist Party to "overthrow imperialism" and "overthrow the warlords". On June 15, 1922, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued "The Standpoint of the Communist Party of China on the Current Situation". These documents emphasized the post-Xinhai Revolution period, analyzing the history and current status of the international imperialist and Chinese feudal military clique colluding to oppress the Chinese people, pointing out that imperialist aggression and warlord politics are the root causes of China's external and internal troubles, as well as the root cause of people's suffering. They criticized the reactionary propositions spread by the feudal military cliques on the question of the current situation and the erroneous ideas held by bourgeois reformists, pointing out that the key to solving the problem of the current situation is to overthrow imperialism and the feudal military clique with revolutionary measures and establish democratic politics. The documents also pointed out that in order to fulfill the proletariat's most urgent tasks, the Chinese Communist Party advocates the establishment of a democratic united front with revolutionary parties such as the Kuomintang and other revolutionary groups, opposing common enemies, and freeing the Chinese people from the dual oppression of imperialism and the feudal military clique.

This was the first time that the Chinese Communist Party announced its political views on major issues of the Chinese Democratic Revolution to all walks of life. It was also a new starting point for the party to use Marxism-Leninism to analyze the social conditions in China and solve the problems of the Chinese Revolution. It laid the foundation for completing the party’s historical mission to formulate the party's democratic revolutionary program at the party's second national congress. From July 16th to July 23rd, 1922, the Chinese Communist Party held its second national congress in Shanghai. The "Declaration of the Second National Congress of the Communist Party of China" passed by the Second National Congress of the Communist Party is a document of great historical significance. It analyzes the history of capitalist, imperialist powers' invasion of China and China's evolution into a semi-colonial, semi-feudal society. It emphasizes that "Various facts prove that the greatest pain inflicted on the Chinese people (whether bourgeois workers or peasants) is the feudal forces of capitalist imperialism and warlord bureaucrats. Therefore, the democratic revolutionary movement against those two forces is of great significance. That is to say, with the success of the democratic revolution, independence and comparative freedom can be achieved." Based on the analysis of the international and domestic situation and the nature of Chinese society, the declaration proposed that under current historical conditions, the party's struggle goal is: to eliminate civil war, overthrow warlords, and build domestic peace; overthrow the oppression of international imperialism and achieve complete independence of the Chinese nation; unify China into a truly democratic republic.



This actually lays out the Party's current stage of the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal democratic revolutionary program, i.e., the Party's minimum program. The declaration also pointed out: The purpose of the Party is to "organize the proletariat, use the means of class struggle, establish the dictatorship of the proletariat, eradicate the private property system, and gradually achieve a communist society". This shows that the second declaration of the CCP has adhered to the ultimate struggle goal of the Party as stipulated by the first program, that is, the Party's maximum program.
The second declaration of the CCP initially clarifies the nature, object, dynamics, strategy, tasks, and goals of the current stage of the Chinese revolution, indicating the future of the Chinese revolution. This is: the nature of the revolution is a democratic revolution; the object of the revolution is imperialism and feudal warlords; the power of the revolution is the workers, peasants, and small bourgeoisie, and the national bourgeoisie is also one of the forces of the revolution; the strategy is to form a united front of all classes. The tasks and goals are to overthrow the warlords, overthrow the oppression of international imperialism, realize the independence and unification of the Chinese nation; the future of the revolution is to transition to socialist revolution.
The second party congress for the first time linked the Party's goals in the democratic revolution with the long-term goals of the future socialist revolution, not only clearly put forward the tasks of the democratic revolution against imperialism and feudalism, and pointed out that it is necessary to further create conditions through the democratic revolution. Realize socialism and communism. This is a deepening of the understanding of the situation in China and the problem of the Chinese revolution by the Chinese Communists. It is an important result of the Party's combination of the basic principles of Marxism with the reality of the Chinese revolution. It points the way for the heavily afflicted Chinese nation to obtain independence and liberation and for the correct conduct of the Chinese revolution. From the First National Congress of the Party deciding to directly carry out the socialist revolution, to the Second National Congress of the CPC deciding to first carry out the democratic revolution and then carry out the socialist revolution, this is a major change in the Party's strategic policy.
The Second National Congress of the Party made a preliminary analysis of the specific connection between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution. The second declaration of the CCP pointed out: "If the democratic revolution succeeds, the proletariat only obtains some freedom and rights, and cannot be fully liberated. Moreover, the success of democracy, the naïve bourgeoisie will quickly develop and be in opposition to the proletariat. Therefore, the proletariat must deal with the bourgeoisie and implement the 'dictatorship of the proletariat in alliance with the poor peasants' as the second step of struggle. If the organizational power and fighting power of the proletariat are strong, this second step of struggle can succeed immediately after the victory of the democratic revolution." There are two possibilities for the future of the democratic revolution as estimated by the Chinese Communists: one is that if the power of the proletariat is greatly developed in the democratic revolution, the socialist revolution of the dictatorship of the proletariat can be implemented immediately after the victory of the democratic revolution; the other is that after the victory of the democratic revolution, the bourgeoisie "seized power from the feudal lords", and the proletariat can implement the second step of struggle after a long period of strengthening its own power. At that time, the young Chinese Communists had just launched the labour movement and lacked revolutionary experience. Some people, influenced by the historical experience of bourgeois revolutions in Europe and America, consider more the latter possibility for the future of the democratic revolution. Some people, starting from the historical experience of the February Revolution to the October Revolution in Russia, are considering the former possibility of developing quickly from the democratic revolution to the socialist revolution. However, in China, a semi-colonial and semi-feudal country with complex national conditions, they do not yet have a clear understanding of how to reach this future through what path.
The program of a political party is its banner...



The revolutionary program proposed at the Second Party Congress embodies the ultimate aspiration of the proletarian party in its struggle towards communism, while also for the first time explicitly articulates the party's current tactical policy and revolutionary mission, namely to carry out a democratic revolution against imperialism and feudalism. A mere year after the founding of the Chinese Communist Party, it was able to start to grasp the relationship between the minimum and maximum program, emerging from the specific conditions in China. This demonstrates that only the Chinese Communist Party, led by Marxism and aligning it with the realities of the Chinese revolution, can scientifically analyze the current state of Chinese society, reflect the desires and demands of Chinese people, point out the correct direction for the Chinese revolution, and shoulder the historical responsibility of leading it. 

To implement the party's democratic revolutionary program, nine resolutions were passed at the Second Party Congress. The Assembly passed a resolution on a "Democratic United Front," calling for workers and peasants across the country to struggle under the banner of the Communist Party. At the same time, it proposed to unite with all revolutionary parties in the country, join forces with the bourgeoisie democrats, and arrange a democratic united front. It also decided to invite revolutionary groups such as the Kuomintang to hold joint meetings to discuss specific methods. This thus changed the provisions in the Party’s first Congress documents about not establishing any connections with other parties, thereby proposing for the first time the party's thoughts and assertions on a united front. This has significant implications for advancing the development of the Chinese revolution. 

Second, the basic ideas of the Chinese revolution have begun to form. The May Thirtieth Movement that erupted in 925 marked the coming of a high tide in the revolution. The political attitudes of all classes in Chinese society also fully manifested during the movement, and contradictions over power struggle within the revolutionary united front became increasingly evident. The vivid and rich revolutionary practice provided communists with many new experiences, and the complex revolutionary struggles raised many new problems without ready answers to the communists: What is the nature and future development of the Chinese revolution? How should the proletariat treat its allies—the national bourgeoisie, urban petty bourgeoisie, peasants, etc? How can the proletariat achieve its leadership in the national revolution? Before and after the May Thirtieth Movement, party leaders such as Chen Duxiu, Li Dazhao, Qu Qiubai, Mao Zedong, Cai Hesen, Deng Zhongxia, Zhou Enlai, and Xing Daiying, based on timely summarizing the experiences of revolutionary practices, made wide-ranging discussions on these issues, thereby elevating the party's understanding of key issues of the Chinese Revolution to a new level.

The party's understanding of the nature and future of the Chinese revolution has undergone a gradual process of intensification. The second party congress clearly stated that the nature of the Chinese revolution is a bourgeois democratic revolution against imperialism and feudal warlords, and its future is socialism. In May 1923, Cai Hesen wrote that the nature of the Chinese revolutionary movement was different from the bourgeois democratic revolution in Europe and America, "It is no longer purely a problem of bourgeois democratic revolution, in fact, it has become a problem of national revolution (also called a national revolution)."

After the May Thirtieth Movement, Communists made further discussions on the issue of the nature of the revolution. Mao Zedong pointed out that the bourgeois revolutions in Europe, America and Japan "are revolutions of the bourgeoisie class," "their purpose is to build a nationalistic state or a state governed by the bourgeoisie," while the national revolution in China "is a revolution collaborated by the petty bourgeoisie, semi-proletariat, and proletariat," "its purpose is to build a state governed by cooperative revolutionary masses." Qu Qiubai believed that during the era of imperialism, or the beginning of the social revolution, the so-called national revolution among the weak nationalities in the colonies, "must contain the seeds of the proletariat revolution." Because this kind of revolution "internationally, is just a part of the world proletariat revolution; within a country, although it is still bourgeoisie in nature, the revolutionary forces are largely supported by the proletariat."



Although the communists had not yet proposed the concept of the New Democratic Revolution at that time, they had begun to distinguish this revolution from past democratic revolutions based on fundamental issues such as the conditions of the times, the leading forces of the revolution, and the goals of the struggle. This provided the ideological conditions for the party to later explicitly propose the theory of the New Democratic Revolution.

On the issue of the future of the Chinese revolution, mainly the relationship between democratic revolution and socialist revolution, the party's Fourth Congress believed that after the October Revolution, the "Chinese national revolution movement" was a "part of the broad world revolution" and was associated with the "movement to overthrow world capitalism to establish communism." After the May 30th movement, Qu Qiubai pointed out: although the democratic revolution is bourgeois, its victory will not belong to the bourgeoisie. If the revolution is led by the bourgeoisie, it will soon compromise with the enemy. He further pointed out: It is now the era of imperialism and the beginning of the socialist revolution, therefore, "naive private capitalism in the colonies of weak nations has no need or possibility for further development." It can plan and develop the economy through the state organized by working workers, progressing gradually towards socialism. He repeatedly proposed that China's democratic revolution is the "first step towards communism." While Qu Qiubai correctly emphasized the proletariat's leadership responsibility for China's revolution and its non-capitalist future, he made two mistakes: one was to deny the strategic thought that the Chinese revolution takes two steps, thus confusing the boundaries between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution; the other was to interpret the non-capitalist future as the immediate abolition of the private capitalist economic component, proposing anti-bourgeois tasks during the democratic revolution stage.

In the democratic revolution, how to understand and treat the bourgeoisie is a complex issue. Communists' understanding of this issue gradually improved and deepened. The party's First Congress believed that all bourgeoisie was the object of revolution; the party's Second Congress believed that the democratic bourgeoisie was a force that could be united; the party's Third Congress to some extent recognized the ambivalent nature of most of China's bourgeoisie; by the party's Fourth Congress it clearly pointed out that China's bourgeoisie was divided into the counter-revolutionary "big commercial comprador class" and the "emerging national industrial bourgeoisie." During the May 30th movement, the national bourgeoisie initially played an important role in the anti-imperialist struggle, but later it wavered and compromised, fully demonstrating its dual nature in politics, thus providing objective conditions for Communists to carry out a more in-depth analysis of this class.

On this issue, Mao Zedong made an excellent exposition in his Analysis of All classes in Chinese Society published on December 1, 1925. He pointed out in the article that the middle class held a "contradictory attitude" towards the revolution. They needed and supported a revolutionary movement against imperialism and the warlords when they felt the pain inflicted by foreign capital and military oppression. However, when they felt threatened by the emerging bravery of the domestic proletarians and the active support of the international proletariat, which could hinder their desire to reach the status of the big bourgeoisie, they began to doubt the revolution. Their right wing would soon side with the imperialists and the warlords when the revolutionary struggle was intensified and would become excellent partners with the comprador class. The left wing of the middle class could be somewhat revolutionary at times, but it was prone to compromise and could not last. Therefore, we can treat them as our friends, but "we must always guard against them and not allow them to disrupt our front."

Having such an understanding is crucial. In the situation of the Kuomintang-Communist cooperation in launching the Great Revolution, it is necessary to actively unite the national bourgeoisie to join the revolution and also to fight against the possible waver and compromise of the national bourgeoisie. For the young Communist Party of China, this is an insoluble contradiction. Many communists do not understand that as long as the proletariat firmly holds the political leadership of the national revolutionary movement, it can push a part, or even most, of the national bourgeoisie to persist in joining the revolution, but one must always be on guard against possible disturbances that can disrupt the front of the revolution.




Mao Zedong's analysis of the national bourgeoisie objectively reflected the actual situation of class struggle at that time, providing an important theoretical basis for the party to later deepen its understanding and correctly handle relations with the national bourgeoisie.

The peasant issue is another important issue in the Chinese revolution. Even before the Fourth Communist Party Congress, the party had recognized the important role of peasants in the revolution. The Fourth Congress of the Party affirmed that peasants are allies of the proletariat. The "Resolution on the Unification of Workers and Peasants" passed at the Second National Labor Conference in May 1925 viewed guiding peasants to participate in the democratic revolution and establishing a solid alliance with them as a guarantee for the success of the democratic revolution. The painful experience of the working class being isolated due to the wavering and compromising of the national bourgeoisie in the later period of the May 30th Movement further proves that the rise of the peasant struggle is an indispensable condition for the success of the National Revolution, and peasants are the most reliable allies of the working class.

The May 30 Movement furthered many communists' understanding of the role of peasants in the democratic revolution and the importance of establishing a worker-peasant alliance. In October 1925, the enlarged meeting of the Central Executive Committee of the Chinese Communist Party proposed to include the solution of the peasant land issue in the political platform, believing that "the Chinese Communist Party should make the general democrats know that the expropriation of land is an inevitable policy and an important duty to complete the Xinhai Revolution." The meeting emphasized that only by forming a solid alliance with the peasants can the party fulfill its historical mission. After examining the economic conditions of Chinese peasants, Li Dazhao pointed out: “If the vast masses of Chinese peasants can be organized to participate in the National Revolution, the success of the Chinese National Revolution is not far off.” Chen Duxiu emphasized: Not only do Chinese workers need to expand and consolidate their own class face, but also urgently need the establishment of worker-peasant alliance... only in this way can they achieve preliminary victories in political and economic struggles.

From 1925, Mao Zedong led the peasant movement with his main energy and paid attention to the study of Chinese peasants. After the "Analysis of Various Classes in Chinese Society," he published "Analysis of Various Classes in Chinese Peasantry and their Attitude Towards Revolution" in the first issue of "Chinese Peasants" in January 1926, using Marxist class analysis for the first time. The rural inhabitants were divided into eight classes including large landlords, small landlords, tenant farmers, partial tenant farmers, beneficial farmers, poor peasants, hired peasants, rural artisans, and vagrants, and gave a more in-depth scientific analysis of the attitudes of each class towards revolution, initially forming a theory about rural class analysis. This lays an important foundation for the Chinese Communist Party to correctly understand the position and role of peasants in the democratic revolution and formulate correct policies towards peasants. In May 1926, the party led the convening of the second peasant representative conference in Guangdong Province, which specifically put forward the “Resolution on the Position of the Peasant Movement in the National Revolution,” pointing out: “The semi-colonial Chinese National Revolution is a peasant revolution,” “The peasant problem is a central issue in the national revolution. Whether the national revolution can progress and succeed must be transformed according to whether the peasant movement can progress and succeed.” Making the peasant issue the core issue of the National Revolution shows that the party has a deeper understanding of the important position of peasants in the Chinese revolution.

Before the Fourth Congress of the Party, Communists had discussed the issue of proletarian leadership to varying degrees. The Fourth Congress of the Party clearly raised the issue of proletariat leadership in the democratic revolution, but there was still a lack of understanding of the seriousness of the struggle for leadership between the bourgeoisie and the proletariat and the way to achieve proletariat leadership.

During the May 30 Movement, the Chinese working class once again fully demonstrated its power, while the bourgeoisie fully demonstrated its dual nature in the May 30 Movement. Subsequently, the right-wing of the Kuomintang intensified its attack on revolutionary forces.




These facts have led communists to further understand the importance of the proletariat vying for leadership with the bourgeoisie. Chen Duxiu pointed out when summarizing the experience of the May 30th Movement: The May 30th Movement was indeed a national struggle of all classes in unity, but the actual direct confrontations with imperialism took place among the striking workers in Shanghai, Hong Kong, Hankou, Jiujiang, Nanjing, Qingdao, Tianjin, Jiaozuo, and other places. Other members of society simply provided support to the workers, so while we cannot exaggerate and say that Chinese workers are the only force present in the Chinese Revolution, we must admit that they are an important and reliable power. The compromising and hesitant attitude of the bourgeoisie allowed the imperialists and warlords to take advantage of the situation. Liu Shaoqi pointed out: "The working class made the greatest sacrifice in the 'May 30th' anti-imperialist movement, advocated the most radical, fought the most persistently, and their power was also very strong. In various struggles, It proves that the leading role of the working class in the National Revolutionary Movement is unshakable. The Chinese bourgeoisie were originally oppressed by imperialism and warlords. They could potentially participate in the National Revolution, but the participation of the bourgeoisie in the National Revolution is ultimately compromising and can't be thorough." Qu Qiubai believed that the weakness and concession of the bourgeoisie during the May 30th Movement led to the setback of the strike struggle. The compromise of the bourgeoisie and the hesitation of the petty bourgeoisie were enough to prove the necessity of the proletariat to take the leading role in the National Revolution.

On the issue of the proletariat vying for leadership with the bourgeoisie, the communists put forward an important point of view: This vying can't be limited to mass movements, the question of political power should also be valued. Deng Zhongxia clearly pointed out: "We join the National Revolution to seize power..." but "political power is not flown into the hands of workers from outside, we have to gradually obtain it from practical political struggle." He particularly emphasized: "If we don't take political power, the bourgeoisie will"; only if the proletariat's political status and power grow and strengthen every day can we "prevent the compromise and softening of the bourgeoisie in the revolution and prevent them from monopolizing power after the revolution", and prepare for the future establishment of a workers' government. Zhou Enlai pointed out: "Workers are the leaders of the National Revolution and should lead farmers and soldiers in a grand union to overthrow imperialism.” In July 1926, under the severe situation of the intensified anti-communism of the new and old right-wing of the Kuomintang, the expanded meeting of the Central Committee of the Party pointed out in the "Resolution on the Relationship Between the Communist Party of China and the Kuomintang": "Our strategy in the National Revolution should be more clearly defined: On the one hand, our party should intensify its political independence and establish its power among the workers and the majority of peasants, and gain political influence among the revolutionary general public; on the other hand, it should organize these revolutionary currents of the petty bourgeoisie and gather them in the Kuomintang, to enrich its left-wing, and influence the Kuomintang with the revolutionary power of the proletariat and the peasants—this way we can form a strong struggle alliance with the leftist Kuomintang to compete with the bourgeoisie for the leadership of the national movement. Only this can guarantee the proletarian party's struggle for leadership in the National Revolution." These statements show that under the education of facts, the understanding of the leadership of the proletariat by the Chinese Communists has deepened compared to the past, and has moved from generally discussing the struggle for leadership with the bourgeoisie, to how to capture the political guiding position within the Kuomintang.

Regarding the issue of armed struggle, which is the main form of struggle in the Chinese Revolution, the party also made new progress in understanding at this time. Previously, the communists criticized the Kuomintang for focusing solely on military work and neglecting the mass movement, but they often focused solely on the mass movement and neglected military work. In the process of unifying the revolutionary base in Guangdong, the Party began to focus on carrying out soldiers' movements and strengthening propaganda work for warlord troops in order to promote their division and attract a portion to lean towards the revolution.



In June 1925, Zhou Enlai pointed out during his return journey from the Eastern Expedition that the army is a tool, "the oppressors use this tool to oppress people," and the oppressed class "can also use this tool to resist their oppressors and overthrow the power of the oppressors". In terms of overthrowing imperialism and feudal warlords, "the army is the vanguard to implement our theory."

The Party also began to realize the importance of arming the workers and peasants. After the start of the Guangdong-Hong Kong strike, the communists saw the important role of the workers' patrol team in the struggle to consolidate the Guangdong revolutionary base, and regarded it as the vanguard of the Chinese nation against imperialism. In October 1925, the enlarged meeting of the Central Executive Committee of the Communist Party of China discussed the issue of arming the working class, proposing to organize and prepare the bravest and most loyal members of the armed working class.

On the importance of armed struggle and the revolutionary army during the National Revolution, Qu Qiubai provided a systematic explanation in his article "The Issue of Armed Struggle in the Chinese Revolution". He pointed out that the Chinese people have been fighting in forms of demonstration, boycott, and strike, "however, starting from the 'May 4th', 'February 27th', 'May 30th', 'March 18th' and the Guangzhou War, the revolutionary turbulence has been spiraling and advancing, using various forms of struggle, it has come to the prepared period of armed direct warfare, and it is approaching the time of a desperate war." "Especially in this period, revolutionary war is the main form," all other forms are directly or indirectly preparing for the revolutionary war. Qu Qiubai pointed out: "The Chinese national revolution is extremely in need of a formal revolutionary army," grassroots civilian armed forces and armed uprisings, are always difficult to defeat powerful enemies, the workers, peasants, and petty bourgeoisie must be organized and trained to form a formal revolutionary army. He said: "Politically, with the revolutionary party of the people as the main body, and militarily, with the formal revolutionary army as the main body, engaged in revolutionary combat...only then will the Chinese common people have the hope of thorough liberation."
