This early party article specifically addresses the issue of armed struggle, and has not only served as a propaganda for the forthcoming Northern Expedition, but also made a pioneering theoretical contribution to the party's exploration of the Chinese revolutionary road.

The above discussions have initially formed the basic thinking of the Chinese Communist Party on the Chinese revolution, which is: the proletariat leads the peasants and other petty bourgeoisie, wins over a part of the national bourgeoisie, carries out democratic revolutionary struggles against imperialism and feudalism, overturns the reactionary rule of imperialism and the big landlord class represented by the warlord regime, and establishes a joint dictatorship of all revolutionary classes; under the international and domestic historical conditions in China, the national bourgeoisie's attempt to lead this revolution to victory and establish a bourgeois dictatorship is not feasible; this revolution, as a part of the world proletarian revolution, will prepare conditions for China to move towards a socialist revolution. These ideas were proposed by many important members of the Chinese Communist Party at that time in their individual explorations. Although there are still uncertain and incomplete aspects, and the understanding between each other is not completely consistent, they are the precious results of the Chinese Communists' efforts to apply Marxism to Chinese conditions, and have a significant pioneering significance for the later formation of the theory of the New Democratic Revolution.



The victorious advance of the Northern Expedition and the vigorous development of the workers' and peasants' movement led to a sharp intensification of contradictions and struggles within the revolutionary camp, bringing great changes to the political and military situation in the South and even the whole country. During this period, The Communist International, The United Communist Party (Bolshevik) and their representatives in China put forward some principles which were correct in principle, which provided a lot of useful guidance for the Chinese Communist Party. However, due to their lack of vigilance about the danger of people like Chiang Kai-shek betraying the revolution, they adopted a wrong policy in handling their relations with Chiang Kai-shek, Wang Jingwei and Tang Shengzhi, which had a negative impact on the decision-making of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. The most concentrated expression of this was the formation and development of Chen Duxiu's rightist mistake.




In the context of the revolution making great strides forward, the issue of revolutionary power prominently emerged in front of the party. The deepening of urban and rural worker-peasant movements has prompted changes in the power of many counties. In Hunan Province, some counties established county affairs meetings or public law group joint meetings, with participants including representatives from county farmers' associations, county unions, and other revolutionary mass organizations. Although they did not elect the county leader themselves, the existing county leaders had to listen to the opinions of the various mass organizations, effectively creating a situation where mass organizations jointly held power. In some counties in Jiangxi Province, due to the support of the masses, communists were serving as county leaders. In terms of provincial power, Communists Dong Biwu participated in the leadership of the Hubei provincial government, Lin Zuhang and Li Fuchun participated in the Jiangxi Provincial Political Committee. Communist members and worker-peasant representatives' participation in revolutionary power is a new development in the victorious advancement of the Northern Expedition.

Although the participation of communists in the revolutionary power has become a necessity for further development of the revolution, the Central Party's understanding of this issue was behind the situation, and there were misunderstandings. In September 1926, Tan Pingshan, delegated by the Communist Party of China Central Committee to attend the 7th enlarged session of the Comintern Executive Committee, asked the Comintern: Can communists participate in the government? However, before the Comintern responded, the Central Committee issued directives within the Party, severely criticizing and stopping local communists from participating in the government, emphasizing that at the stage of the national revolution, the Communist Party must stand in the position of the opposition party, and should thoroughly maintain an independent opposition attitude.

The policy of maintaining the status of the opposition party adopted by the Central Committee, on one hand, is directly related to the erroneous idea that has always existed in the party that regards the mass movement as higher than everything and regards participation in the government as a hunt for official positions. Influenced by this idea, the central government proposed to strictly ban the tendency to seize official positions in the party, and ordered communist members who served as county chiefs in Jiujiang, Yongxiu, etc. to resign immediately, emphasizing that "From now on, our manpower should all be used on the masses, do not join the government work." On the other hand, more importantly, the Party as a whole, especially the main leader Chen Duxiu, did not have a clear understanding of how to transition from the democratic revolution to socialism. 

In July 1926, the second enlarged meeting of the Central Executive Committee passed the "Central Political Report", which defined the "construction of national capitalism" as the "future" that the "National Revolutionary Movement" should strive for. In September, Chen Duxiu's article "Why Are We Fighting Now?" stated that this future would be achieved when the victory "belonged to the national government, the national army", and "Only by then, the real Capitalism in China can develop freely." The article made it clear that during the National Revolutionary period, there would be no situation where the Communist Party would strive for power, and thought that "the Communist Party gaining power is a matter of the proletarian revolution era." At the end of 1926, the Chinese Communist Central Committee initially understood the meaning of participating in power and decided that Communist members "should strive to join the provincial governments". After the 7th enlarged meeting of the Comintern Executive Committee explicitly proposed the requirement for communist members to join government agencies, the Chinese Communist Central Committee further understood the necessity and urgency of participating in power, and successively dispatched Tan Pingshan and Su Zhaozheng to join the work of the Nationalist Government and local governments. However, due to the rapid deterioration of the situation, they actually did not play a significant role.

Chen Duxiu and the majority of leaders of the Chinese Communist Central Committee did not give enough attention to the establishment of armed forces directly led by the Communist Party. Before the start of the Northern Expedition, there were about 2,000 Communist Party members and Communist Youth League members among the graduates of the Huangpu Military Academy; a large number of workers and farmers in Hunan, Hubei, and Jiangxi obtained a large number of guns and ammunition from the defeated enemy forces and urgently requested to arm themselves; many officers of the National Revolutionary Army also invited the Communist Party to send people to assist in their work. However, Chen Duxiu opposed taking advantage of these favorable conditions to strive to develop the revolutionary armed forces directly controlled by the party.



After the start of the Northern Expedition, the Communist Party of China Central Committee decided to send fewer Communists to study at the Whampoa Military Academy, and comrades who were engaged in labor and peasant movements "absolutely should not be allowed to abandon their work to go to" the military academy. The Central Committee also required Communist Party members and Communist Youth League members who were engaged in political work in the National Army to "only pay attention to political propaganda matters, and not to interfere in military and administrative affairs." Therefore, not only did the party not establish more directly controlled regular armed forces during the Northern Expedition, but it also did not consolidate and develop the considerable amount of existing worker-peasant armed forces.

As the Northern Expedition progressed, the dangerous tendencies within the National Revolutionary United Front became increasingly apparent. Facing a complex and volatile situation, the Chinese Communist Party faced difficulties: on one hand, the task of overthrowing the Beiyang warlords was still not fully completed; on the other hand, contradictions within the revolutionary camp began to stand out. How to handle these complex external and internal contradictions, deal with betrayals and surprise attacks from allies, has become an urgent problem to be solved. For the inexperienced Communist Party members, this was indeed a big challenge.

In order to analyze the various dangerous tendencies that emerged within the National Revolutionary United Front and to formulate the party's strategic struggle, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China convened a special meeting in Hankou in mid-December 1926. Representatives from the Communist International, Vevyensky and Borodin, attended the meeting. In Chen Duxiu's political report, he pointed out that since the victory on the Jiangxi battlefield, our relationship with the Kuomintang has undergone many new changes and revealed many dangerous tendencies, which may cause the united front to rupture at any time. 

While the report analyzes the causes of this danger and acknowledges the rightist tendencies of the KMT and Chiang Kai-shek’s rightist actions despite leftist rhetoric, it does not provide any effective solutions to the problem. Instead, it focuses on criticizing the so-called "left-leaning" within the party, such as looking down on the Kuomintang, taking control of the KMT, monopolizing the mass movement, denying the existence of the left, misunderstanding the independence of the party, and being unwelcoming towards small and medium-sized merchants, etc. 

The settlement for the "Resolution on the Kuomintang Left-Wing Issue" passed at the conference stipulates that we should assist the KMT left-wing from all aspects, make it a strong political force, and fight against the reactionary tendencies of the right-wing forces. The resolution believes that although the KMT's left is weak and wavering, we should still unite with them and support them. This is actually placing all hopes of fighting the right wing on the KMT's left-wing, not only advocating for the party and political power of the Kuomintang to be handed over to them, but even the mass movement that has always been under the leadership of the Communist Party should also be given to them.

The policies proposed by this meeting to save the crisis are not based on the foundation of consolidating and strengthening the power of the Communist Party itself, and are not well-prepared for sudden changes in both spirit and actual work. Instead, they place all hope on Wang Jingwei and other Kuomintang military generals, hoping to seek unity by conceding. This inevitably led to serious consequences at the crucial moment when the situation was suddenly reversed in the future.




This policy has objectively resulted in two consequences: On one hand, it has spread harmful illusions among the masses, giving the impression that Chiang Kai-shek, who seems well-prepared for battle, may have a change of heart and shift from right to left; it also seems that Wang Jingwei, who is notably weak and opportunistic, could form a powerful left-wing group and undertake the significant task of completing the National Revolutionary. On the other hand, it poured cold water on the raging worker-peasant revolutionary movement, dampening the enthusiasm of the masses and suppressing mass movements. This policy, in essence, sacrifices the fundamental interests of the working and peasant masses to accommodate the right-wing of the Kuomintang, providing convenience for Chiang Kai-shek and Wang Jingwei to seize the leadership of the Kuomintang.
 
The Hankou Special Conference failed to solve the extremely important issue of how the Party could survive and continue to fight in the imminent crisis; instead, it guided the party in the wrong direction, and gradually developed the right-leaning errors within the party into right opportunism. The decisions of this conference were approved by the Central Political Bureau and the Joint Meeting of Representatives of the Communist International. This is an important subjective factor leading to the failure of the great revolution.


First, a significant progress in understanding the basic problems of the Chinese Revolution

After the failure of the Great Revolution, the domestic political situation underwent a huge reversal. The counter-revolutionary forces have far surpassed the organized revolutionary forces led by the Communist Party. The nationwide revolutionary climax has passed, and the revolutionary situation has entered a low ebb.

The failure of the Great Revolution showed that the leadership of the party, the united front, and armed struggle are the basic issues of the Chinese Revolution. Only by correctly understanding and solving these problems can we promote the development of the revolutionary cause and achieve final success. The harsh reality has deeply educated the Chinese Communist Party.

In order to review and correct the serious mistakes of the party during the late period of the Great Revolution, and determine the new line and policy, the CPC Central Committee convened an emergency meeting in Hankou, Hubei on August 7, 1927 (the "August 7th Meeting"). At the conference, Communist International Representative Romagniaz made reports and conclusions on the past mistakes of the party and the new line. Qu Qiubai, representing the Standing Committee of the Central Committee, reported on the future work guidelines. Many party members criticized the right-leaning mistakes the Central Committee made in dealing with the Kuomintang issues, peasant land issues, armed struggle issues, and other aspects. Some party members also criticized some mistakes made by the Soviet advisors and representatives of the Communist International.

The meeting adopted papers such as "A Letter to All Party Members from the Executive Committee of the Communist Party of China", demanding resolute correction of past mistakes by the party and calling on a large number of party members and revolutionary masses to continue the fight. The meeting pointed out that during the late period of the Great Revolution, the Central Committee, led by Chen Duxiu, made grave errors of right opportunism and other mistakes, such as fully abandoning the independent political stance of the Communist Party in dealing with the Kuomintang, implementing a policy of compromise and concessions; in terms of the revolutionary armed forces, the Central Committee never thought about the necessity of arming the workers and peasants, and creating a truly revolutionary worker-peasant army, and even actively ordered the dissolution of the Worker's Patrol Team; the Central Committee did not actively support and lead the peasant revolutionary movement, and was influenced by the fear of the leaders of the Kuomintang and could not put forward a revolutionary action plan to solve the land issue; the Central Committee was not subject to the supervision of the masses and lacked democratic life within the party. The letter to all party members announced: "Our party openly admits and corrects mistakes, without ambiguity or concealment, this is not a sign of weakness, but a proof of the strength of the Chinese Communist movement."



The conference summarized the lessons from the failure of the Great Revolution, discussed the tasks of the Party, and established the approach to implement the Land Revolution and Armed Uprising. 
On the Land Revolution, according to the instructions of the Communist International and in line with the spirit of "the Chinese Revolution steps into a new stage - the stage of Land Revolution" made explicit in the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party's July 20, 1927, announcement, the conference explicitly pointed out that the Land Revolution was the central issue of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution, and the main socio-economic content of the new stage of the Chinese revolution. The conference pointed out: practically, the main task is to solve the land problem with "civic" revolutionary means, to confiscate the lands of large and medium landlords, and to confiscate lands of so-called public properties such as ancestral halls and temples, and distribute them to tenant farmers or landless peasants. The small landlords should be given a rent reduction. This decision answered the critical issue of the Chinese revolution at that time. In China, the feudal land system is the important foundation of the reactionary rule of imperialism and feudal comprador forces. Therefore, resolving the peasant land problem has always been the fundamental issue of the revolution. 

Regarding the Armed Uprising, the conference clearly stated: the most primary task of the party is to systematically, planfully, and as possible prepare the total uprising of peasants in large areas. The conference believes that the main force of the peasant movement is the poor peasant, and decided to dispatch the most active, strong, and struggle-experienced party members to lead and initiate peasant uproar, organize the revolutionary army of workers and peasants, and establish the revolutionary government of workers and peasants, to resolve the peasant land issue. 

The Conference passed the "Decision on Party Organization". The decision stipulates that prior to the sixth national congress of the party, the acting politburo of the Central Committee shall exercise all powers of the Central Committee. It pointed out the main task now is to create strong and capable secret organizations, and all party organizations should reinforce secret party work; at the same time, the conference also calls for making use of all public opportunities to expand the influence of the party. 

When summarizing the lessons of the party's mistakes in the late period of the Great Revolution, the conference considered as an important reason that the majority of the party's leading organ was represented by intellectuals and representatives of the petty bourgeoisie, so it requested to promote worker comrades to take major responsibilities in the party's committee. Influenced by this view, the Central Announcement issued shortly after the conference pointed out that the party's political opportunism inevitably affected the party's organization. To change this situation, the announcement proposed to proletarianize the composition of the leading organs of the party, promote active worker-peasant members to take responsibility in the leading organs at all levels of the party; also proletarianize the membership of the party, and resolutely and quickly absorb a large number of worker-peasant members. Unfortunately, this guiding idea of improperly emphasizing the pure worker-peasant composition of leading organs and party members departed from the actual state of Chinese society and the party, resulting in a negative effect on the party's construction thereafter.



Especially during the period when the 'left' error occupied a dominant position in the central government, the emphasis on 'composition theory' was repeatedly emphasized, which seriously hindered the healthy development of the party's organization.
In addition to criticizing Chen Duxiu's right-leaning mistakes in his speech, Mao Zedong raised two very important issues. One is about the issue of military struggle. He criticized the party's past inclination to "do mass movements instead of military movements", suggesting that "we must pay great attention to the military in the future as we must know that political power is obtained from the barrel of a gun". This judgment was derived from the bloody lesson of the failure of the great revolution. It pointed out the characteristics of the Chinese revolution, and actually raised the issue of military struggle as the focus of the party's work. The other is about the issue of peasant land. He proposed that standards for large and medium landowners should be set and that confiscation should be applied to all landholdings over 50 acres, regardless of the quality of the land. The issue of small landowners is the central issue of land. If the lands of small landowners are not confiscated, "then there will be many places without large landlords, and the Peasant Association will have to stop working, so the landlord system should be fundamentally eliminated, and certain measures should be taken for small landlords. Rich and middle-class self-cultivating farmers have different land rights, and peasants want to attack the rich, so they must set a direction. This suggestion, which is in line with the landholding situation in Hunan, Hubei, Jiangxi, and Guangdong, laid the ideological foundation for the future launch of the land revolution and the formulation of the correct route for the land revolution. However, the Comintern representative did not accept Mao Zedong's correct opinion, but proposed that the fundamental solution to the land problem is to implement state ownership of land.
In the face of a serious crisis in the Chinese Revolution, the timely convening of the August 7th Conference and the formulation of the correct guideline to continue the revolutionary struggle prevented the entire party from panicking in the face of the extremely serious white terror, refueled the courage to fight against the Kuomintang reactionaries, and made a significant contribution to saving the party and the revolution. The Chinese revolution thus began a historic shift from the failure of the great revolution to the rise of the land revolution war.
However, due to the influence of the "leftist" ideas of the Comintern and its representatives and the "leftist" sentiment within the party, the August 7th Conference did not pay attention to preventing and correcting "left" errors while opposing right-leaning errors. There was a lack of understanding that the party should organize necessary retreats when the revolution was in a low-ebb situation, and there was a tendency to blindly instigate workers' strikes and organize urban riots. The conference did not invite Chen Duxiu to attend, only accused the erroneous leading persons, did not seriously summarize the lessons of the mistakes made from a theoretical and ideological perspective. The conference also inappropriately emphasized the importance of the pure worker composition of the party's leading organs and members. The conference believed that the completion of the anti-feudal bourgeois democratic revolution (including the land revolution), especially the completion of the anti-imperialist struggle, must be realized in the struggle against the already reactionary bourgeois. This understanding provided a theoretical basis for the development of later "left" errors, causing great harm to the Chinese revolution.
After the August 7th Conference, armed uprisings took place one after another. After the armed uprising, what kind of regime to establish was an urgent issue that needed to be addressed by the Chinese Communist Party. In the "Resolution on Recent Peasants' Struggle" and "Resolution on Recent Workers' Movement" passed by the August 7th Conference, it was proposed that "rural power belongs to the Peasant Association" and the goal of "dictatorship of workers and peasants" was to be achieved. On August 9th, the Temporary Politburo of the Central Committee clearly stated in a directive letter to the Hunan Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party that it was necessary to establish a revolutionary government of proletarian dictatorship, specifically: all power in the countryside belongs to the Peasant Association; all power in the city belongs to the Revolutionary Committee; it should be propagated that the Revolutionary Committee should convene a meeting of representatives of labor unions, peasant associations, and revolutionary small businessmen to set up a regular "government of people's rights".



As for when to organize such a "civil rights government", the letter of instruction believes it should be decided after the local revolutionary committee's power is consolidated. At this time, although the CPC Central Committee had determined the policy of establishing a worker-peasant democratic government, it still proposed to organize the worker-peasant uprising under the banner of the left wing of the Kuomintang in the revolution. 

The CPC Central Committee believes that the Kuomintang is a special banner of the national liberation movement, and Communist Party members have joined the Kuomintang and have always been the center of the left wing of the Kuomintang. The actions and propaganda of the grassroots organizations and members of the Communist Party have made the Kuomintang have a revolutionary prestige among the petty bourgeoisie in cities and even some working masses. The Communist Party should not abandon this banner now. 

At the same time, organizing uprisings under the banner of the Kuomintang can attract revolutionary elements of the petty bourgeoisie. Therefore, the slogan of organizing the Soviet should not be raised at this moment. More than a month later, on September 19, the Central Temporary Political Bureau meeting passed a resolution based on the change of the situation, abandoned the banner of the "left-wing Kuomintang", and proposed the slogan of propaganda and establishment of the Soviet.

Two, the issue of China's revolutionary nature and revolutionary road. At the time of the failure of the national revolution and the unfolding of the land revolution, the Chinese Communist Party, while summarizing the lessons of the failure of the revolution, re-recognized and re-explored various basic issues of the Chinese revolution, including social nature, revolutionary nature, revolutionary power and class relations, the central content and main methods of the revolution, revolutionary power, revolutionary prospects, revolutionary road, etc. This is a necessary part of the work to be carried out after the climax of the revolution. The core of these issues is the issue of revolutionary nature and revolutionary path.

About the social nature. To understand the semi-colonial and semi-feudal social nature of China is the basis for understanding the basic problems of the Chinese revolution. Among Chinese Communists and early Marxists, the first to specifically use "semi-colonial" to describe the social nature of China was Cai Hesen. In September 1922, he stated in his article "Unification, Borrowing and the Kuomintang" that "China has long been in a semi-colonial position in international status." 

After the Fourth Congress of the Communist International reaffirmed in November 1922 that China was a "semi-colonial country", concepts such as "semi-colonial China", "semi-colonial society", and "semi-colonial Chinese society" played a wide role in the documents of the Chinese Communist Party and the works of Marxist theoreticians. The earliest use of the concept of "semi-feudal" among Chinese Communists and early Marxists was also Cai Hesen. In September 1922, in his article "Force Unification and Provincial Autonomy - Military Dictatorship and Military Separatism", he pointed out that China at that time belonged to a "semi-feudal and semi-democratic situation". In September 1924, Cai Hesen, in his article "Anatomy of Feng's Free-Revolutionary Movement", had mentioned the term "semi-bourgeois and semi-feudal society", but did not give a specific argument and explanation. 

The clear point of China's economic and social "semi-feudal" nature is the "Sixth National Congress" of the Chinese Communist Party. The "Resolution on the Land Issue" passed by the "Sixth National Congress" unambiguously pointed out: "The characteristics of China's economy, the characteristics of land relations, are clearly semi-feudal", "The current economic and political system of China should indeed be determined as semi-feudal" ...



Based on a clear understanding of the aspects of "semi-colonial" and "semi-feudal", in February 1929, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) used the full concept of "semi-colonial and semi-feudal" for the first time in its "Twenty-eighth Central Announcement on the strategy of the peasant movement". The document pointed out: "The Sixth Congress, based on the semi-colonial semi-feudal social-economic relations in China as well as years of precious experience gained by the peasants, set out the course for the peasant movement. It highlights the struggle to establish a united front against the landlord class in rural areas and consolidate the leadership of the proletariat in the peasant revolution, ensuring the victory of the land revolution and its transition towards a socialist future." Although the Sixth Congress of the CPC had a clear understanding of the semi-colonial and semi-feudal nature of Chinese society, it had not yet employed the concept of "semi-colonial semi-feudal". 

Previous articles seldom mentioned this document, which led to much disagreement about when the concept of "semi-colonial semi-feudal" was first proposed. After the major debate began in the 1930s, various different opinions on the nature of Chinese society were proposed again. After deliberation, Su Hua and Zhang Wentian were the first to reaffirm that Chinese society was semi-colonial and semi-feudal. In September 1933, Su Hua pointed out in his article "The Development of Chinese Capitalist Economy", that current Chinese society is a "semi-colonial semi-feudal society". This statement is centered on "semi-feudal society", and "semi-colonial" is used to modify "semi-feudal society". In January 1934, Zhang Wentian's article "The Socio-economic Foundation of Chinese Revolution" persuasively concluded that the economic characteristics of Chinese society were "semi-colonial and semi-feudal" and further pointed out: "This economy determines the tasks and nature of the Chinese revolution, the relationships between different classes in the Chinese revolution, and the dynamics of the Chinese revolution." 

About the nature of the revolution, Stalin pointed out in his speech to the joint meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist Party and the Central Control Commission on August 1, 1927 that the Chinese revolution has three stages. The first stage is a revolution of a national united front, mainly attacking foreign imperialism, and the national bourgeoisie is supportive of the revolutionary movement; The second stage is the bourgeois democratic revolution, which began when the National Revolutionary Army reached the Yangtze River. In this stage, the national bourgeoisie withdrew from the revolution, and the land movement developed into a powerful revolution involving millions of peasants (China is currently in the developing second stage); The third stage is the Soviet revolution, which has not yet arrived, but is impending. In the resolutions adopted by the Executive Committee of the Communist International on February 25, 1928, it is clearly pointed out: "The present stage of China's revolution is the stage of bourgeois democratic revolution." The 1927 meeting of the CPC pointed out: "China's revolution is still at the stage of bourgeois democratic revolution, which is against the oppression of imperialism and all social, economic and political vestiges of the feudal system."



"On April 30, 1928, the 'Announcement by the Central Bureau of the Communist Party of China on the Resolution of the Comintern' stated: 'The Central Political Bureau has always clearly understood that the Chinese revolution is still a bourgeois democratic revolution.' The 'Sixth Party Congress' further pointed out: 'The current stage of the Chinese revolution is a bourgeois democratic revolution,' because 'the goal of the current revolution' is to 'expel the imperialists, complete the true unity of China. Thoroughly overthrow the landowner's private land system in a civilian manner, carry out land reform... completely destroy all semi-feudal bindings in the land system.' In the articles of many Communists such as Mao Zedong, Cai Hesen, Qu Qiubai, Li Lisan, they clearly pointed out: 'The current stage of the Chinese revolution is a bourgeois democratic revolution.' The Communists recognized that the Chinese revolution still belongs to the bourgeois democratic revolution, while also pointing out that the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution has its own 'particularities'. 

First, the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution not only opposes imperialism and feudalism, but also opposes the national bourgeoisie. The political resolution of the 'Sixth Party Congress' pointed out: 'The current bourgeois democratic revolution in China must oppose the national bourgeoisie in order to be successful', 'because the national bourgeoisie is one of the most dangerous enemies hindering the success of the revolution.' The decision of the Sixth Comintern on political issues also pointed out: 'With the expansion of the scope of mass mobilization and the deepening of the land revolution, the national bourgeoisie gradually enters counter-revolution. Therefore, China's anti-imperialist struggle cannot be separated from opposition to the bourgeoisie and the land revolution.'

Communists believe that: 'China's national bourgeoisie is connected to the feudal land ownership of the landlord in a flesh-and-blood way. At the same time shamelessly surrendered to imperialism.' Although 'the economy of the Chinese national bourgeoisie is in conflict with imperialism, it fundamentally contradicts the interests of the vast majority of Chinese workers and peasants.' 'The Chinese bourgeoisie suffered economic aggression from imperialism, but it is unable to resist imperialism for compensation. He can only further exploit the Chinese workers and peasants for compensation'. Therefore, the Chinese revolution must oppose the national bourgeoisie. For a relatively long period of time after the failure of the great revolution, the Communists, based on the class standpoint, held hatred towards the betrayal of the revolution by the national bourgeoisie. According to the political attitude of the national bourgeoisie's hostility to the land revolution led by the Communist Party, they shouted slogans against the national bourgeoisie. However, most communists still understand: to oppose the bourgeoisie 'not because the national bourgeoisie is the representative of capitalism that should be opposed, but because the national bourgeoisie has become a tool of imperialism and an ally of the landlord class, betraying the revolution and becoming the leader of the counter-revolution against the democratic revolution. Therefore, this new task does not exceed the nature of the bourgeois democratic revolution, and it will not destroy the capitalist method of production, which is rather the starting point for the development of capitalism.'

Second, China's bourgeois democratic revolution is part of the world's proletarian socialist revolution. Cai Hesen once pointed out that China's bourgeois democratic revolution 'opposes international imperialism and forms part of the world revolution.' The 'Sixth Comintern' believes that 'the Chinese revolution has great world significance'. The political resolution of the Sixth Party Congress of the Communist Party of China pointed out: the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution, 'oppose imperialism', 'weaken its power', 'which also reduces the violence of the imperialist oppression on the Soviet Union and the working class of various countries, which helps the world proletarian revolution's future.' 'It is a help to the world socialist revolution and is also a major part.'

Third, China's bourgeois democratic revolution must be led by the proletariat and unite the vast majority of people mainly composed of peasants. The 'Ordinance 87' Meeting Announcement to All Party Members of the Communist Party of China' pointed out: 'The Chinese working class, due to the relationship of objective conditions, is the most determined, thorough and uncompromising class struggling for China's national liberation. This situation enables the Chinese proletariat to have the right to lead the national liberation movement...



In "Why Can the Red Political Power Exist in China?", Mao Zedong pointed out: "China urgently needs a bourgeois democratic revolution, and this revolution must be led by the proletariat to be completed." Qu Qiubai stated: "The development of the Chinese revolution, based on its class basis, is inevitably a revolution of the proletariat leading the peasant soldiers and poor masses to overthrow the bourgeoisie of the gentry, landlords, domestic bourgeoisie and international imperialism." Cai Hesen emphasized that China's bourgeois democratic revolution, due to the betrayal of the national bourgeoisie, further established the "leadership of the proletariat". The "central issue of the Chinese revolution" can only be completely victorious under the condition of "union with the peasants".

Fourth, China's bourgeois democratic revolution has a non-capitalist future. In February 1927, the seventh expanded meeting of the Executive Committee of the Communist International made a resolution on the Chinese revolution issue, pointing out that the Chinese revolution has a non-capitalist (socialist) development. The Sixth Congress of the Communist Party also clearly pointed out this. Some Communist Party members pointed out: "The special feature of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution lies in the fact that its victory will open the way for socialist development." Why does the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution have a non-capitalist future? Communists have answered from different angles. 

"The driving force of the Chinese revolution is now only the proletariat and the peasants, and the leadership of the proletariat can be established in the stage of the bourgeois democratic revolution (the proletariat can assist and guide the peasants to carry out the land revolution and lead the anti-imperialist struggle). Therefore, it can open the way for the future development of the Chinese revolution, giving it a non-capitalist future, which is also a socialist future. The world capitalism is now in a period of panic. The socialist construction of the Soviet Union, a proletarian dictatorship, has been going on for ten years, and its political and economic power is growing. This can assist the Chinese proletariat to strive for the socialist future of the revolution and ensure the possibility of victory."

"The crisis of China's industrial and agricultural economy requires socially transitional measures," namely, the confiscation of foreign capital by the Soviet government, "and then the confiscation of all large enterprises in the country to organize and command the national economic life." In addition, because "agricultural productivity is very weak, when the land revolution is completely successful, and can begin to develop towards capitalism, it will inevitably encounter a huge obstacle, this obstacle is the stubborn resistance of imperialism and the domestic landlord bourgeoisie and rich peasants who have been hit by the revolution". To overcome these obstacles, for the farmers (except for the rich peasants), the only choice is to "quickly prepare to transition to socialist revolution conditions, that is, to eliminate the capitalist market economy and replace it with an organized rural collective economy under the leadership of national urban industry. At such a turning point, it is no longer the starting point for capitalist development, but the preliminary stage of socialist construction."

The future of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution is non-capitalist, which is the consensus of the majority of Communists. However, there are serious disagreements about when the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution will transition to the socialist revolution. The Communist Party's understanding of this issue took a detour. 

The enlarged meeting of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China in November 1927 believed that the Chinese revolution was an "uninterrupted revolution" that "necessarily completely solves the democratic tasks and quickly moves towards the socialist road". Qu Qiubai further argued for this "uninterrupted revolution" that "it can't help but go beyond the scope of bourgeois democracy", even believing that "the current stage of the Chinese revolution has grown into a socialist revolution."

The Communist International, the "Sixth Communist Congress", and some Communists criticized this view, pointing out that only "under the condition of the complete victory of the democratic revolution, can the transition to the socialist revolution begin", and it is absolutely impossible to "jump over the stage of the democratic revolution". At the same time, it also emphasizes: "The end of the democratic revolution is also the beginning of the decisive struggle for the socialist revolution", and between these two, neither the development of capitalism is allowed nor possible.




After the August 7th Conference, the Communist Party of China led the uprising, launched armed struggle, and realized the transformation of the form of struggle. However, the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee at that time did not realize that the revolutionary situation had turned into a low ebb, but instead wrongly estimated the situation, disregarding the objective and subjective conditions, and blindly demanded armed uprisings in some areas. As a result, the "leftist" sentiment in the party gradually grew. 

In the twists and turns of exploring the basic issues of the Chinese revolution, many comrades still focused the central task of the party on preparing for urban uprisings and work in white areas during a long period after 927. The same mistake was repeatedly made on this issue in each "Leftist" error. The historical lesson of their mistakes is not to start from the reality of the Chinese revolution, not to investigate and research the historical and social situation of China, sit in big cities, rigidly adhere to doctrines, mechanically apply foreign experiences, so although they have some partial knowledge, they eventually cannot become wisdom that connects theory with practice and suits the specific situation of China, thereby underestimating the importance of military struggle, especially the peasant guerrilla warfare and rural bases, attacking the theory of "encircling the city from the countryside" as the so-called "local and conservative consciousness of peasant consciousness", and always dreaming that the workers' struggle in the city and other mass struggles can suddenly break through the enemy's high pressure and flourish, always wanting to launch armed uprisings in central cities, to achieve the so-called first victory in one province or several provinces, forming the so-called national revolutionary climax and national victory, and using this dream as the center of all work arrangements. 

This "leftist" mistake was blindly copying the experience of the Russian Revolution. Under the guidance of the "leftist" error theory of the Communist International, from the 9th to the 10th of 1927, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China convened an extended meeting of the temporary Political Bureau in Shanghai. The meeting was chaired by Xu Qiubai, with Romina, the representative of the Communist International, participating. The meeting passed Romina's draft resolution on "The Current Situation in China and the Tasks of the Party", as well as resolutions on organizational issues and political discipline. On the one hand, the resolution correctly called on all revolutionary forces to resolutely oppose imperialism and overthrow the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang under the leadership of the Communist Party, resolutely lead peasant uprisings, implement rural separatism, confiscate the land of the landlord class for peasant farming, organize the Revolutionary Army of workers and peasants, launch guerrilla warfare, etc. On the other hand, it considered the Chinese revolution to be the so-called "uninterrupted revolution", "the current revolutionary struggle, which must inevitably go beyond the scope of democracy and progress rapidly," and that it must be thoroughly resolved and quickly entered the path of socialism. In this way, the boundaries between democratic revolution and socialist revolution were confused. The meeting accepted Romina's "leftist" perspective, believed that Chiang Kai-shek's betrayal was the betrayal of the entire national bourgeoisie, Wang Jingwei's betrayal was the betrayal of the petty bourgeoisie, and therefore proposed that while opposing imperialism and feudalism, it would also oppose the national bourgeoisie and the upper petty bourgeoisie. The conference did not admit that the revolutionary situation was at a low ebb, believed that the rule of the new warlords of the Kuomintang was on the verge of collapse, and that the current situation in China was a direct revolution. The conference accordingly determined the overall strategy of launching a national armed uprising, and required the combination of rural uprising and urban uprising, with the urban uprising as the "center and guide", to form a nationwide armed uprising, until a revolutionary victory situation in one province or several provinces. The meeting also laid down a series of over-"leftist" policies, such as advocating the expropriation of enterprises of Chinese and foreign big capitalists, "factories owned by workers", and demanding "extremely severe and ruthless killing of all the nobles and anti-revolutionaries" in times of peasant uprising, and so on.



According to the proposal by Romine, the meeting did not specifically analyze the failures and frustrations suffered by the armed uprisings in various places after the August 7th Conference, but unilaterally blamed the uprising leaders for "hesitation", "violating the central policy" and making "opportunistic" mistakes. The meeting decided to impose different political disciplinary punishments on the leaders of the Nanchang Uprising and the Autumn Harvest Uprising in the Hunan-Jiangxi border region, and on the responsible persons of the relevant provincial committees, such as Zhou Enlai, Tan Pingshan, Mao Zedong, Peng Gongda, etc. While affirming the organizational progress of the Party since the August 7th Conference, the expanded meeting also concretized the guiding ideology of the Party's guiding organs and party members becoming worker-peasant-focussed. The "Resolution on Important Tasks in Recent Organizational Issues" passed by the meeting believed that one of the main shortcomings of the party's organization was that the leading cadres of the party were not workers, or even poor peasants, but representatives of the petty-bourgeois intellectuals. This was considered a source of opportunism within the Party. Therefore, the resolution proposed that the party's most important organizational task is to replace the non-proletarian intellectual cadres with new worker-peasant cadre, and to make the proletarian and poor elements occupy the majority in the party's guiding cadre. The meeting required that the guiding organs of the party be thoroughly reformed before the 6th Party Congress. 

From mid-November to mid-December, the spirit of the expanded meeting of the Temporary Politburo began to be implemented everywhere. In some areas, there were forced strikes among the workers, peasant uprisings, blind burnings, and killings, causing the party in these areas to be temporarily severely disconnected from the mass base. There were a few armed peasant uprisings that achieved certain victories, most were not successful, or did not get started at all. The strikes carried out by a few workers and activists in big cities like Wuhan, Changsha, and Shanghai were also quickly suppressed. 

In late December, the CCCP, led by Qu Qiubai, concluded that rebellion was hard to provoke in every region, and subsequently issued notices in succession, instructing some areas not to call for immediate rebellion if the conditions were not met. They decided to stop the planned New Year's Rebellion in Hunan and Hubei, thus avoiding some losses, which had some effect in correcting rash errors. However, at this time, the CCCP had not yet fully recognized its "leftist" errors from the guiding ideology and overall strategy, so it was impossible to thoroughly correct the global rash errors. 

The "Leftist" rash errors occurred during the historical turning period from the failure of the Great Revolution to the rise of the Land Revolution. The reasons were the rage at the Kuomintang's massacre policy; within the party, there was a general impatient desperation. Meanwhile, some people who had previously committed rightist errors were afraid to recommit them, thinking that "left is better than right", which provided the hotbed for the development of "leftist" errors. At this time, it was impossible for the party to provide correct analysis and solutions to various pressing issues faced by the Chinese revolution after the failure of the Great Revolution, and it also lacked the experience of internal party struggles, failing to know that while countering the right, it must also protect against the "left". 

The Comintern representative, Romine, bore significant responsibility for the emergence of this "leftist" error. He was the major proponent and implementer of political spontaneousness, organizational punishment, and other "leftist" policies. The temporary Politburo led by Qu Qiubai also bore direct responsibility for this "leftist" error.

The Li Lisan line is also the "urban-centric theory". On January 11, 1930, the CCP Politburo passed the "Resolution to Accept the Directive Letter of the International October 26th, 1929". On February 26th, the CCP Central Committee issued the 70th announcement, making an excessive estimation of the revolutionary situation, believing that "the current national crisis is deepening and the new wave of revolution is in progress", and the mass struggle nationwide is "moving towards a balanced development path". In accordance with this estimate, the announcement set out the party's "current overall political line" to be to merge all kinds of struggles, "move towards 'transforming the warlords' war into a domestic class war' to overthrow the KMT's rule, and establish Soviet power".




The announcement points out: the Party is not to continue the strategy of accumulating power during the downturn of the revolution, but to implement a strategy of actively concentrating power for attack. Each area is to organize workers' political strikes, local uprisings, and military mutinies, and concentrate the Red Army to attack major cities. In April and May, the CPC Central Committee and the Central Military Commission made specific plans and deployments for this. During this process, Li Lisan published several articles such as "Questions in Front of the New Revolutionary Climax" on the Party's official publications such as "Red Flag" and "Bolshevik", proposing a series of "left" views on the Chinese revolution. After the outbreak of the Central Plains War and the Hunan-Guangdong-Guangxi Border War, Li and others believed that the revolutionary situation had matured nationwide. Therefore, at the Central Political Bureau meeting convened in June 1930, a resolution was passed drafted by Li called "Resolution on Current Political Tasks" (or "The New Revolutionary High Tide and the First Victory of One Province or Several Provinces"). The resolution made an erroneous estimation of the revolutionary situation, believing that "the fundamental economic and political crisis in China continues to sharpen everywhere in the country, with no fundamental difference"; "the general situation indicates that the new revolutionary high tide in China has come close to us", and "there is a great possibility of becoming a nationwide revolutionary victory". The resolution also believes that "the unprecedented world events and the time of the world revolution are approaching us", once the Chinese revolution breaks out it will "set off a world revolution", and the Chinese Revolution will achieve complete victory in this final battle. Based on such an erroneous estimations of the revolutionary situation, the resolution believes that the current Party no longer needs to gradually accumulate and prepare the forces for revolution, because the masses no longer want small fights, only big fights, that is, only armed revolts, and this is a nationwide armed revolt. The resolution mechanically applied the experience of the Russian October Revolution, believing that as long as a great workers' struggle suddenly breaks out in industrial areas or political centers, immediate success can be achieved through an armed uprising in one or several provinces, a nationwide revolutionary government can be established, and then victory can be won in all provinces nationwide. Although the resolution acknowledges that it is necessary to organize the Red Army in the rural areas, it believes that the task of the Red Army is "to cooperate with the armed riots in major cities to seize power and establish a nationwide revolutionary government." Therefore, the "past guerrilla tactics" must be fundamentally changed. It calls for the Red Army to be concentrated, under unified command, and to carry out large-scale offensive warfare. The resolution's views on the nature of the Chinese revolution and the problem of revolutionary transition also return to the erroneous understanding of the "uninterrupted revolution" that was criticised by the Party's Sixth Congress. Although the resolution recognizes that the current stage of the Chinese revolution is still a bourgeois democratic revolution with the main tasks of anti-imperialism and anti-feudalism, it also determines that "the bourgeoisie has already become a part of the reactionary alliance". If the revolution is first successful in one province or several provinces, not only will the banks, enterprises, and factories of imperialism in China be confiscated, "but also the factories, enterprises, and banks of the Chinese bourgeoisie" will be confiscated; politically, it will "necessarily need to transfer from a worker-peasant dictatorship to a proletarian dictatorship". The resolution points out: "The beginning of the revolutionary victory, the beginning of the establishment of the revolutionary government represent the beginning of the revolutionary transition"; "If you think that the revolution must win nationwide before the revolutionary transition can begin, this is a serious mistake"; the phased theory of revolutionary transition is "undoubtedly an extremely dangerous right-wing conception". Under the guidance of the aforementioned erroneous thoughts, Li et al. formulated a risky plan centered on Wuhan to instigate uprisings in all central cities nationwide and to concentrate the nationwide Red Army to attack central cities. In July, preparations for uprisings in cities such as Nanjing, Shanghai, and Wuhan were prioritized. At the same time, it was stipulated: the Red Third Army Corps was to cut off the Wuhan-Changsha railway and press on Wuhan; the Red First Army Corps was to take Nanchang and Jiujiang to cut off the Yangtze River and cover the success in Wuhan; the Red Second and First Army Corps were to cooperate and press on Wuhan. The Red Seventh Army Corps was to attack Liuzhou, Guilin, and Guangzhou. All local Red Armies, in accordance with the directives of the Central Committee and the Military Commission, immediately took military actions.




In late July, under the victorious momentum of the counter-offensive operation in Pingjiang, the Red Third Army occupied Changsha on the 27th while it was unguarded. Upon hearing this news, Li Lisan and others believed more strongly that the goals of "meeting in Wuhan", "drinking horses in the Yangtze River", and even achieving national victory could be realized soon. The "left-leaning" error has thus developed further from this point. From early to mid-August, under the slogan of "militarization" needed by the entire party organization, Li Lisan and others established the Central General Action Committee to serve as the highest command for leading armed uprisings; they merged various leadership institutions of the Communist Party, Communist Youth League, and unions at all levels into action committees (abbreviated as Xingwei), halting normal activities of the Party, League, and unions; they further proposed preparing for Wuhan uprisings, Nanjing uprisings, general strikes in Shanghai, and detailed plans for establishing the Central Soviet Government in Wuhan and national uprisings; they proposed that "the Soviet Union must actively prepare for war", hundreds of thousands of Chinese workers in Siberia should quickly arm themselves, and "prepare to fight against Japanese imperialism"; they also proposed that Mongolia should also launch large-scale troops attacking the reactionary forces in northern China when the Chinese uprising succeeded. Li Lisan and others called for the entire party to "be brave, braver, and advance bravely". Up to this point, Li Lisan's "left-leaning" adventurous error had developed to its climax.

The Wang Ming line is a typical dogmatism. This is very clearly reflected in the pamphlet “Two Lines” he wrote. This pamphlet, although criticizes some of Li Lisan's "left-leaning" adventurous errors, but he believes that Li Lisan's error overall is right-leaning, and is a right-opportunistic line that is masked by "left-leaning" words. Why does Wang Ming believe Li Lisan’s clearly "left-leaning" error to be right-leaning? This is mainly because Wang Ming's views are even more "left" than those of Li Lisan and others. He maintains that the driving force of the Chinese revolution is only the workers, peasants, and the lower petty bourgeoisie, all other classes and strata "have turned to the reactionary camp", so there is no "third force" and "middle camp". He equates the bourgeoisie and the upper petty bourgeoisie with imperialism and feudalism, all viewed as objects of the revolution, claiming: The current stage of China’s democratic revolution will only thoroughly succeed with resolute struggle against the bourgeoisie. He emphasizes that a national revolution is underway, with a strategy of offense across the country. He argues: "At present, we do not have a direct revolutionary situation in the entire China, but under the growing new highs of the nationwide revolutionary movement and the conditions of unbalanced development, the direct revolutionary situation may soon be included in one or more of the main provinces." He advocates real victory in one or several provinces such as Hunan, Hubei, and Jiangxi, and then strive for and win victory across the country. Both Li Lisan and Wang Ming insist that the Chinese revolution should focus on urban workers' uprisings, but Wang Ming, according to the decision of the Communist International, proposes: "New revolutionary movements are maturing in China, the most reliable sign of a new climax is the high tide of workers' strike struggles"; organizing and leading workers' economic struggles, truly preparing for general strikes and even armed uprisings, is the most important task of the Communist Party. Although Wang Ming also emphasizes the importance of the Red Army's power, he does not understand the rules of the Red Army's operation and the development of revolutionary bases under the strong-enemy and weak-ours situation. He criticized the party and the Red Army for "still not being able to establish a true revolutionary base that can truly be the most reliable revolutionary center by the winter of 1930", and considers that resistance to right-leaning is essential. On the issue of land revolution, Wang Ming proposed "left-leaning" ideas such as "resolutely cracking down on rich peasants" and "making rich peasants get worse land". In organization, he requested to "enhance and replenish leadership institutions at all levels with proactive and executive international line struggle cadres — particularly worker cadres".

The pamphlet "Two Lines" is essentially the political manifesto of Wang Ming's "left-leaning" dogmatism.



From the winter of 1927 to January 1935, the Chinese Communist Party made three "left" leaning mistakes in more than seven years, one of their common characteristics being urban centrism. Why was it that they weren't fundamentally corrected, making repeated mistakes? One of the fundamental reasons lies in the skewed orientation of the ideology. The ideological line forms the political foundation. If the ideological line is skewed, it is impossible to formulate a correct political line. Particularly, Wang Ming did not start from the actual conditions of China, regarded dogma as a sacred treasure that could not be violated, and implemented policies based on dogma, with instructions from the Communist International as the only guide. Given that the international communist movement has no experience of rural areas surrounding cities for revolution, there is no discussion of this aspect in their directives or textbooks. They believed that the Chinese revolution must also focus on the city. Their logic was that foreign experience shows the proletariat achieves victory through armed uprisings in the cities. Since the Chinese revolution is also led by the proletariat, which is always tied to the cities, placing the focus of party work on rural areas and not on cities would be tantamount to denying the Communist Party is a party of the proletariat and denying the leadership of the proletariat over the peasants; in the end, they feared that the party would only become a petty bourgeois peasant party. They were always worried that if the rural areas were made the focus, it would be too far from the cities, which would lack leadership by the proletariat. Based on this erroneous understanding, they one-sidedly emphasized that urban armed uprisings were the main sign of the national revolutionary climax. There was a repeated demand that work in all Soviet districts "should shift from rural simplicity to important cities,” placing the focus of work in cities. This disregard of rural areas as revolutionary bases is clearly unsuitable for the situation in China.

Marxism believes that there are common basic laws in the development of human society, and it is wrong to deny these basic laws. However, among different countries and ethnic groups, there are also different historical conditions and characteristics. If we do not proceed from the actual conditions of our own country, and from the characteristics of our own revolution, to practically apply the universal truths of Marxism-Leninism, we cannot guide the revolution towards victory. This is the most fundamental historical lesson from the three "left" leaning lines. The entire historical experience of the Chinese Communist Party repeatedly proves one truth: whenever the dialectical materialistic ideological line deviates, the political line becomes incorrect, leading to harm to the revolutionary cause; whenever the dialectical materialistic ideological line is adhered to, we can formulate a political line suitable for the actual conditions in China, leading to the constant development of the revolutionary cause.


During the Great Revolution period and the Land Revolution War period, the Chinese Communist Party, guided by the principles of Marxism-Leninism and with the help of the Communist International, led the Chinese revolution to significant victories; however, at the same time, on the issue of integrating the principles of Marxism-Leninism with the actual conditions of the Chinese revolution, they made significant mistakes. Especially from 1931 to 1934, the extreme "leftist" dogmatists represented by Wang Ming committed more serious errors in terms of severing the relationships between theory and reality. They didn't apply the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism based on the specific conditions of the Chinese Revolution, but adapted the actual situation of the Chinese Revolution to apply pre-existing formulas. They, especially regarding the instructions of the Communist International, exhibited blind obedience and revered the so-called international line as the golden rule, using it as the criteria to assess all theories and practical work.



As a result, it first ruined the party's work in the white areas, and then incurred the failure of the Red Army's war, causing the Chinese revolution to suffer another severe setback. The ups and downs of the revolutionary cause made the Chinese Communist Party profoundly realize the importance of linking theory with practice, applying foreign experience and Comintern directives according to the country's circumstances. Mao Zedong's works such as "On the Strategic Problems of Chinese Revolutionary War", "On Practice", and "On Contradiction" have shown the re-establishment of the correct ideological line in the Party Central Committee. However, after the outbreak of the Anti-Japanese War, Wang Ming, who returned from the Soviet Union, made the same mistake of divorcing from Chinese realities, copying foreign experience and Comintern directives indiscriminately. What's different is that he shifted from "left" bias to right tendency.

At that time, the Communist International and the Soviet Union actively supported the Chinese people's anti-Japanese war cause. But they once again overestimated the strength of the Kuomintang and underestimated the strength of the Chinese Communist Party. They mistakenly believed that only Chiang Kai-shek's army could restrain and hit Japanese imperialism on the Chinese battlefield. They advocated that the Communist Party should make more concessions to the Kuomintang, not in agreement with the Communist Party's principle of independence and the policy of both unity and struggle in the united front. They suggested "unconditional obedience to the Anti-Japanese National United Front" and "all through the Anti-Japanese National United Front". They only focused on the regular war and position war of the Kuomintang army, ignoring the role of the anti-Japanese guerrilla warfare led by the Communist Party. Wang Ming took these views as his basis for observing China's Anti-Japanese problems, and tried his best to develop them, thus forming a new right-leaning mistake in new historical conditions. Wang Ming claimed that both the Communist Party and the Nationalist Party were "a gathering of the progressive youth of a large part of China," and that Chiang Kai-shek "will become China's immortal national hero". He advocated "all through the united front", "all obedience to the united front", did not agree with emphasizing the principle of "independence and autonomy", and opposed raising the issue of leadership in the united front. He belittled the people's army and guerrilla warfare led by the Communist Party, ignored the work of the anti-Japanese base areas behind enemy lines, put the hope of victory in the regular war of the Nationalist Army, and advocated the strategic principle of "taking mobile warfare as the main with guerrilla warfare and supplemented by positional warfare". He even proposed that the armies led by the Communist Party and the Nationalist Party should be unified in organization, armament, discipline, treatment, command, operation plans, and actions. As Wang Ming continued to use the flag of the "Communist International", his misguided views still had some misleading power, were implemented in some areas, and caused some damage to the cause of the Anti-Japanese War and the development of the people's revolutionary forces. The Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, convened from the end of September to the first half of November in 1938, basically overcome Wang Ming's rightist mistakes. It was at this meeting that the Chinese Communist Party, based on 17 years of experience since its establishment, clearly put forward the task of "concretizing Marxism in China".

In "On the New Stage," a keynote report made by Mao Zedong for the meeting, there is a section devoted to the issue of "learning". He pointed out: "A political party that guides a great revolutionary movement, if it doesn't have revolutionary theories, doesn't have historical knowledge, and doesn't have a deep understanding of the actual movement, it will be impossible to win." For this, he put forward three corresponding learning tasks: learning Marxist theory, learning historical heritage, and studying the current actual movement. Regarding the first task, he said: We are leading a large nation with tens of millions of people, and we are going through a struggle like never before. Therefore, the task of universally and deeply studying the theory of Marxism-Leninism, for us, is a major issue that urgently needs to be solved and needs to be focused on in order to solve. Mao Zedong called for "a learning competition for the whole party, to see who really learned something, and who learned more and better".

However, to study Marxist theory, one must solve a question of attitude...



What is the correct attitude to adopt? Mao Zedong believed that Marxisms and Leninist theories should not be regarded as dogmas, but rather as guides to action. People should not only learn the words and phrases, but also study them as the science of revolution. They should not only understand the general laws, but also learn the perspectives and methods for identifying and solving problems. It is particularly important to "learn to apply the theories of Marxism-Leninism to China's specific environment", "to use it according to China's characteristics", because "Marxism must be combined with the specific characteristics of our country and realized through certain national forms". "Talking about Marxism without considering China's characteristics is empty abstract Marxism". "Therefore, to make Marxism specific to China, to make it carry the necessary Chinese characteristics in each manifestation", is the "issue that the entire Party urgently needs to understand and resolve". Mao Zedong pointedly and harshly said: "The eight-legged essays must be abolished, empty abstract chants must be reduced, dogma must rest, and to replace them with fresh and lively Chinese style and Chinese character." These statements by Mao Zedong, following On Practice and On Contradiction, more clearly point out the attitude that Chinese Communists should have towards Marxism and the instructions of the Communist International. Only by "making Marxism specific to China" can it conform to the essence of Marxism.
In the report on the issue of the Anti-Japanese National United Front and the party's organization, Zhang Wentian expressed the same view as Mao Zedong. He believes that: "The principles and methods of Marxism are international, but we are carrying out organizational work in China. We must strictly take into account the characteristics of China's politics, economy, culture, thoughts, and customs and correctly understand these characteristics before we decide on our forms of struggle, organization, and methods." He calls for "making organizational work more local to China," and for implementing the principles of Marxism "in a national environment." "Transplanting foreign party decisions to China is bound to fail." The resolution of the Sixth Plenary Session of the party calls on the whole party to "learn how to apply Marxism-Leninism and international experience flexibly to every practical struggle in China."
Implementing Marxist principles according to China's characteristics, and making Marxism concrete in China, represents an elevation in understanding that Mao Zedong and other Chinese Communists came to after experiencing rough and torturous path. This elevation goes beyond the summary of general revolutionary experience, and instead puts forward a basic principle guiding the Chinese revolution. The clarification of this principle throughout the Party signifies the Communist Party of China's maturing development and the maturation of the Party's theoretical thinking, which provides an ideal internal condition for the eventual formation of the New Democracy theory system. During this process, the external conditions were also gradually met.

After the outbreak of the Anti-Japanese War, the Chinese Communist Party emerged from an arena that had previously been tightly blocked, becoming a major national party, openly appearing on the national political stage, and gaining increasingly closer scrutiny from the public. They are eager to understand the Chinese Communist Party's views on the current situation and the future of China. In order to maintain its independence and autonomy in the Anti-Japanese National United Front, the Chinese Communist Party needs to clearly put forward its own political positions that are distinct from other parties before the national populace and attract people to its banner.
After the start of the national Anti-Japanese War, the Nationalist Party and the Communist Party engaged in a fierce debate on the issue of the Three People's Principles.



Just as the KMT and the CCP had reached a cooperation agreement, Chiang Kai-shek proposed in his talk on "Conversation on the Declaration to the Communist Party" that the Three Principles of the People are the "foundation of China", and "There is only one direction for China to strive today", which is the Three Principles of the People. In early 1938, the conservative faction of the KMT launched a propaganda campaign in Wuhan advocating "one doctrine", "one party", and "one leader". KMT-controlled newspapers, such as the Sweep Revolution Report, continuously published articles attacking the Chinese Communist Party and Marxism. The KMT's hired writers clamored: "The KMT is the pet among all parties, and parties beyond it cannot talk about equality with it. There is "no reason for independent existence" either today or in the future.

After the Anti-Japanese War entered a stalemate phase, this kind of propaganda became more intensified. In December 1938, Zhang Junli of the National Social Party published an open letter to Mr. Mao Zedong, while advocating the abolition of the border area, the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army, he also wanted to discuss with Mao Zedong "the theory of the Communist Party". He sternly wrote: "In the current stage, since you are working hard in foreign wars of nationality, why not temporarily put aside Marxism and let the peoples' thoughts go on clearly right or wrong, without the need to obscure with grey words and covers. If this can be achieved, the ideologies of various factions in the country, taking the salvation of the nation and the country as the starting point, their approach to each other will be easy." Ye Qing, a defector from the Chinese Communist Party, known as the "theorist" of the KMT, even openly advocated: "The Three Principles of the People can meet all of China's current and future requirements. Once it is realized, China will no longer need socialism, and there will be no need for a party to struggle for socialism."

He also said: All parties outside of the KMT have no reason to exist independently, not only today, but also in the future. In January 1939, Chiang Kai-shek made a report titled "Awakening Party Spirit, Promoting Party Virtue, Consolidating Party Foundation" at the fifth plenary session of the fifth session of the KMT, and delivered a speech titled "Essentials of Party Affairs Consolidation". The so-called "awake party spirit" and "promote party virtue" are to implement the authoritarianism of "one doctrine", "one party", and "one leader". In September, he published another long article titled "The System of Three Principles of People and Its Implementation Procedures", advocating the so-called "Governing the Country by the Party" and "Building the Country by the Party", "to make the day of victory in the anti-Japanese war the time of completion of the construction of the country". 

Consequently, answering the question of where China is going has become a major theoretical issue. Mao Zedong, Zhang Wentian, Zhou Enlai, and other leaders of the Central Communist Party, as well as the theoretical circles in Yan'an, responded to the stubborn faction of the Kuomintang's attack on Marxism and the Communist Party of China by publishing a series of articles and speeches. They strongly exposed and criticized various false three people's principles, discussed the difference between Sun Yat-sen's new three people's principles and the old three people's principles, and the relationship between the three people's principles and communism.

Mao Zedong strongly refuted the fallacy that "recognizing the Three Principles of People means giving up communism". He analyzed the history of the development of the Three Principles of the People, compared the Three Principles of the People with communism, and pointed out that the revolutionary Three Principles of the People reinterpreted by Sun Yat-sen are the same as the basic points of the Communist Party's minimum program, that is, the New Democracy. Therefore, the Communist Party recognizes the Three Principles of the People as the political basis of the Anti-Japanese National United Front.



However, there are differences between the two. They are two thinking systems guided by different worldviews, and their specific policies at this stage are not exactly the same. The thoroughness of the revolution and the prospects of the revolution are different, that is, after the completion of the New Democratic Revolution, there is a highest program to establish a socialist and communist social system, while the Three People's Principles does not have. Ignoring this difference is wrong. The diehards are not only unreasonable in asking the Communist Party to "hold back" Communism, but they also show that the Three People's Principles they talk about are not Sun Yat-sen's Revolutionary Three People's Principles, but counterfeit ones. Their shout, "One principle," actually denies the united front and negates the status of the Communist Party and the working and peasant masses, insisting on the despotism of "one-party dictatorial rule". Such practices are fundamentally unfeasible. Mao Zedong stated that Communists will always cooperate with all sincere supporters of the Three Peoples Principles, and will never abandon any friends.

The debate between the KMT and the Communist Party on the Three People's Principles further clarified the nature of Chinese society and the characteristics of historical development from a theoretical perspective.
