It clarified major issues such as the nature, tasks, and basic strategic tactics of the Chinese revolution, and promoted the establishment of the new democratic theory system of the Communist Party of China.

The Communist Party of China regards the Anti-Japanese War as a stage of the Chinese New Democratic Revolution. To carry out the Anti-Japanese War, it is necessary not only to drive out Japanese aggressors but also to create conditions for the construction of New China. In order to explain to the whole party and the people of the whole country the party's views on the Chinese revolution and the construction of New China, Mao Zedong conducted a large amount of theoretical research work in Yan'an, and concentrated the wisdom of the entire party collective to systematically summarize the experience of the Chinese revolution.

In the "May 4th Movement" article published on May 1, 1939, Mao Zedong already said: "The May 4th Movement 20 years ago showed that China's anti-imperialist and anti-feudal bourgeois democratic revolution has developed to a new stage." "The completion of China's democratic revolution depends on certain social forces. These social forces are: the working class, the peasant class, intellectuals and progressive bourgeoisie, that is, revolutionary workers, peasants, soldiers, academics, and businessmen, and the fundamental revolutionary force is the proletariat and peasants, and the leading class of the revolution is the working class. It is impossible to complete the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal democratic revolution without this fundamental revolutionary force and without the leadership of the working class." In his speech on the direction of the youth movement on May 4, he called the ongoing Chinese revolution "Our Chinese People's Democratic Revolution against Imperialism and Feudalism". He said, "This revolution, the bourgeoisie is incapable of completing, and it must be completed by the proletariat and the vast majority of people." It must "establish a people's democratic republic" and "establish a people's democratic system" after overthrowing imperialism and feudalism. "It is different from the current semi-colonial and semi-feudal state, and it is also different from the future socialist system." But undoubtedly, "China will certainly develop to socialism in the future, and such a rule cannot be overturned by anyone."

In these two articles, Mao Zedong has clearly stated: The anti-imperialist and anti-feudal democratic revolution in China has developed to a new stage since the May 4th Movement, led by the working class; it aims to establish a People's Democratic Republic that is neither a semi-colonial nor a semi-feudal state, nor a future socialist system, and will develop into Socialism in the future.



Clearly, Mao Zedong's New Democracy theory was already brewing, pondering, and forming at this time, but the clear concept of "New Democracy" had not yet been proposed, nor had there been time for systematic argumentation and explanation.
The earliest proposal of the scientific concept of New Democracy was made in "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party," written in December 1939. This was a textbook co-authored by Mao Zedong and several other comrades in Yan'an, with Chapter 2 "The Chinese Revolution" written by Mao himself, and Chapter 1 "Chinese Society" drafted by others and finalized by him. "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party" was first published in the Yan'an publication "Communist." After the establishment of New China, this work was included in "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" after his review. In this article, Mao Zedong distinguished the bourgeois democracy revolution into the old democratic revolution and the new democratic revolution for the first time, and explicitly stipulated: "The so-called new democratic revolution is the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal revolution of the masses under the leadership of the proletariat."
Why can the bourgeois democratic revolution at this stage in China only be a new democratic revolution? This is determined by China's actual national conditions.
Mao Zedong wrote: "To understand the nature of Chinese society is to understand China's national conditions, which is the basic basis for understanding all revolutionary issues." For this reason, "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party," first started by analyzing Chinese society and, based on this, detailed the objects, tasks, dynamics, nature, and prospects of the Chinese revolution.
He pointed out: Chinese society at present is a colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal society. This kind of social nature determines that the main targets or main enemies of the Chinese revolution at this stage are imperialism and feudalism. Among them, the national oppression of imperialism is the greatest oppression, so imperialism is the first and most vicious enemy of the Chinese people. After Japan's military invasion of China, the main enemies of the Chinese revolution are Japanese imperialism and all traitors and reactionaries who collude with Japan openly surrender or prepare to surrender. The task of the Chinese revolution is to overthrow the national revolution oppressed by imperialism abroad and the democratic revolution oppressed by feudal landlords at home, with the most important task being to overthrow the national revolution of imperialism. These two revolutionary tasks are interrelated.
The enemies of the Chinese revolution are extremely powerful. Who can complete the arduous task of the Chinese revolution? This is the issue of the driving force of the Chinese revolution. After analyzing the economic status and political conditions of all classes in Chinese society one by one, Mao Zedong concluded: The Chinese proletariat has many outstanding advantages, so it can become the basic driving force of the Chinese revolution. "If the Chinese revolution does not have the leadership of the proletariat, it is bound to fail." But if it relies solely on the power of this class, it cannot succeed. To succeed, it is necessary to unite all possible revolutionary classes and strata under various circumstances and organize a united front of the revolution.



Among different classes in Chinese society, peasants are the firm allies of the working class, the petty bourgeoisie in cities are also reliable allies, and the national bourgeoisie are allies to certain extents and in certain periods. 
The bourgeoisie in China is a complex issue. Mao Zedong clearly pointed out: "There is a distinction between the big bourgeoisie with a comprador - nature and the national bourgeoisie". This is a very important distinction. Mao Zedong pointed out that the national bourgeoisie is a class with a dual nature: on the one hand, they are subject to oppression from imperialism and feudalism, hence they can be one of the forces of revolution; on the other hand, due to their economic and political weaknesses, and their failure to completely sever ties with imperialism and feudalism, they lack the courage to oppose imperialism and feudalism thoroughly, which becomes evident when the power of the masses rises. Mao also mentioned that this dualistic nature of the national bourgeoisie allows them to participate in the revolution against imperialism and the bureaucratic-military government in certain periods and to some extent, becoming a force in the revolution. Yet, there is also a risk of their becoming reactionary accomplices of the comprador bourgeoisie at other times. During the Anti-Japanese War, differences existed not only between them and the surrenderists of the big landlords and bourgeoisie, but also the diehards among the big bourgeoisie. To date, they remain relatively good allies so "it is entirely necessary to adopt a cautious policy towards the national bourgeoisie." However, the comprador big bourgeoisie in China is divided among several imperialist countries, and during the Anti-Japanese War, a distinction should be made between the pro-Japanese bourgeoisie and the pro-British and American bourgeoisie. The former is surrenderist and must be overthrown. The latter is stubborn and has two faces in the revolution. In addition, many enlightened gentlemen of medium and small landlord backgrounds, i.e., landlords with some capitalist characteristics, still have the enthusiasm to resist Japan, and it is still necessary to unite with them in the resistance against Japan.

The colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal nature of Chinese society, or China's unique national condition, determines that "the nature of China's revolution at this stage is not proletarian socialism, but bourgeois democracy." However, "the bourgeois democratic revolution in China today is no longer the old-fashioned, general bourgeois democratic revolution, which is now outdated, but a new, special bourgeois democratic revolution. This revolution is developing in China and all other colonial and semi-colonial countries, and we call this revolution the New Democratic revolution." This New Democratic Revolution is "the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal revolution of the people led by the proletariat." "Chinese society must go through this revolution to further progress towards a socialist society, otherwise it is impossible." This is the most important conclusion drawn by Mao Zedong in this article.

Mao Zedong further pointed out: the New Democratic Revolution inevitably brings about two results: on one hand, it clears the obstacles on the path of capitalist development, allowing capitalism to develop to a certain extent. On the other hand, there is also the development of socialist factors. These socialist factors include: the growth of the proletariat and the Communist Party in national political power; the peasants, intellectuals, and urban petty bourgeoisie either have admitted or are likely to admit the leadership of the proletariat and the Communist Party; the state-run economy of the Democratic Republic and the cooperative economy of the working people.



With the advantageous international environment, the future of the Chinese revolution can be directed towards socialism, rather than capitalism. The publication of Mao Zedong's work "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party" has greatly opened people's eyes. It makes such a systematic and clear explanation of the nature of Chinese society and a series of fundamental issues of the Chinese Revolution, making the formerly dazzling and complex social phenomena look so orderly and easy to understand. It enables people to stay soberly grasp the basic direction and maintain a consistent pace in the face of complex and changing situations. Its enormous impact at the time and for a long time afterwards is hard to estimate.

The banner of "New Democracy" was raised high. So, what is the specific content of the politics, economy, and culture of New Democracy? What are their characteristics? There are many other issues that need to be further elaborated and explained. In January 1940, the First Representative Assembly of the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia Border Region Cultural Association was held in Yan'an. Mao Tse-tung gave a lengthy lecture at the meeting, entitled "The Politics and Culture of New Democracy." This long lecture was given from afternoon until the lights were lit at night. The five to six hundred spectators crammed into the venue were inspired and attracted by his sharp insights and vivid words, concentrating and listening quietly with fervent emotions, and burst into applause from time to time. A month later, this lecture was first published in the inaugural issue of Chinese Culture and then a few days later in the combined issue 98 and 99 of Liberation, it was retitled as "The Theory of New Democracy". Mao Tse-tung himself said that the main purpose of this speech was "to refute the die-hards", but its significance far exceeded this scope.

In his speech, Mao Tse-tung straightforwardly raised the question of "Where is China heading?", to which he clearly responded: "We want to establish a new China.” He stated: “We Communists, for many years, have strived not only for China's political and economic revolution, but also for China's cultural revolution; the purpose of all these is to build a new society and new nation for the Chinese nation."

In his speech, Mao Zedong systematically explained the theory and program of New Democracy and once again discussed the issue of Sinicisation of Marxism. He stated: "Formalistically absorbing foreign things has caused a lot of harm in China's past. Chinese Communists' application of Marxism in China is the same. It is necessary to perfectly and appropriately unify Marxism's universal truths with the concrete practice of China's revolution. That is to say, it should be combined with national characteristics and passed through a certain national form. It is useless to subjectively and formulaically apply it.”

This way, Mao Zedong outlined the basic characteristics and specific content of the politics, economy, and culture of the New Democratic state, picturing a clear and complete outline of what kind of state the Chinese Communist Party wants to establish.

In this article, Mao Zedong refuted a rhetoric spread by the die-hards: Since you Communists have put the socialist social system to the next stage, and since you have also asserted that "three democracies are necessary for China today, this party is willing to strive for their full realization", then, it's better to temporarily put communism aside.



Mao Zedong wrote: "Communism is the entire ideological system of the proletariat and also a new social system." "The democratic revolution in China cannot succeed without the guidance of communism, let alone the next stage of the revolution." He also specifically analyzed what commonalities and differences exist between the Three Principles of The People and Communism. 
"New Democracy" is an article with a rigorous theoretical system and also a highly polemical article. Mao Zedong took a long time to prepare for this article, repeatedly revised it during the writing process, and sought the opinions of some comrades. More than twenty years later, he once said: "When the first draft of 'New Democracy' was half-written, the idea that the first eighty years is one stage and the last twenty years is another stage in China's nearly a century-long history gradually became clear, so I started rewriting it, and it was only after repeated revisions that the final draft was determined." Even reactionary writers like Ye Qing who always attacked the Communist Party for having no theory of its own had to admit that since he read "New Democracy," "I have since then regarded Mao Zedong as a theoretical scholar of the Communist Party." The article had a significant impact both within and outside the party, giving many people a clear understanding of the current goals of struggle and the future direction of China, attracting more and more people to the banner of New Democracy.
The fundamental difference between the New Democracy revolution and the Old Democracy revolution lies in whether the proletariat has taken the lead. The issue of proletarian leadership has long been raised within the Chinese Communist Party. However, in such a complex environment in China, how can the proletariat achieve leadership? This question, Mao Zedong also went through a long period of thinking and exploration, and made a comprehensive discussion in the article "For the Publication of The Communist." He pointed out: "Eighteen years of experience has taught us that: the united front, armed struggle, and party building are the three magic weapons, the three main magic weapons for the Chinese Communist Party to defeat the enemy in the Chinese revolution." Regarding the relationship among these three, Mao Zedong wrote: "The united front and armed struggle are the two basic weapons to defeat the enemy. The united front is the united front to carry out armed struggle. And the party organization is the brave fighter who takes the united front and the armed struggle as two weapons to charge against the enemy." "Correct understanding of these three issues and their interrelations is equal to correct leadership of the entire Chinese revolution." And now, "we can correctly handle the united front issue, correctly handle the armed struggle issue, and correctly handle the party building issue." This is his important summary of the eighteen-year struggle course of the Chinese Communist Party.
Why was Mao Zedong able to make such great theoretical creations? On the one hand, because he always bases himself in the infinitely rich practice of the Chinese revolutionary struggle, every step of his understanding comes from careful observation and deep thinking about various new situations and new issues in objective actual life, from repeatedly exchanging views with people who understand actual conditions, collecting a wide range of opinions, and never making those out-of-touch personal meditations; on the other hand, because he diligently and strenuously studies Marxist works. His method is: to read Marxist theory is to apply it, to apply it requires frequent reading, focused reading, reading some classic Marxist works, can also understand the development process of Marxism, in the debate and criticism of various theoretical views, deepen the understanding of the universal truth of Marxism. He once said to Zeng Zhi: I flipped through the 'Communist Manifesto' many times when I wrote 'New Democracy'.



Mao Zedong always believed that it was very important to point out the direction and future of the revolution, but having these alone was not enough. It also required the determination of the policies and strategies to achieve these goals. He said: only when the theory and the actual policies are made clear can the problem be comprehensively solved. Of course, what attracted Mao Zedong's attention more at that time was the actual policy issues in the Anti-Japanese National United Front, rather than the specific policies of all aspects of the new China later. However, there are many connections between the two.

By the end of 1940, on the eve of the Southern Anhui Incident, the situation was very serious, and Mao Zedong was very busy. But he did not relax at all in summarizing the party's historical experience, especially the new experience in the strategy of the united front. On February 4th and 13th, the Politburo meeting held serious discussions on these issues. Mao Zedong pointed out at the meeting that summarizing past experiences and lessons generally divided into three periods: the Great Revolution, the Soviet period, and the Anti-Japanese War. The overall mistake was not understanding the long-term and unbalanced nature of the Chinese revolution. Many "left-wing" mistakes were made in the later stage of the Soviet period, because Marxism-Leninism was not linked to reality. He proposed to form a committee to summarize all the policy issues of the party, and some even needed to formulate regulations.

On February 25, based on the comprehensive summary of the Chinese Communist Party's experience in this area, Mao Zedong drafted a party directive on the current situation and policy (the policy part of the directive is included in "On Policy" in Mao Zedong's Selected Works). The directive explicitly pointed out: "Under the current situation of the anti-communist climax, our policy has decisive significance." "In the entire Anti-Japanese War, no matter under what circumstances, our party's policy of the Anti-Japanese National United Front will never change; many policies during the past ten years of the land revolution should not be simply quoted now." The directive criticized some "left-wing" opportunist mistakes that occurred during the period of land revolution, and pointed out: "The current policy of the Anti-Japanese National United Front is not all union denial of struggle, nor all struggle denial of union. It is a policy that combines both union and struggle."

The directive emphasized and stipulated a series of policies for the Anti-Japanese National United Front, including: independent policies under the United Front, which must be unified and independent; independent guerrilla warfare under the unified military strategy, mainly guerrilla warfare, but not giving up mobile warfare under advantageous conditions; "Use contradictions, strive for the majority, oppose the minority, defeat each", adhere to the principle of "reasonable, beneficial, and restrained"; in the enemy-occupied area and the Nationalist Government-controlled area, adopt the policy of "sheltering the elite, long-term ambush, accumulating strength, waiting for opportunities"; develop progressive forces in domestic relations, strive for middle forces, isolate stubborn forces; and so on.

The directive, based on specific class analysis, especially emphasized the need to make various distinctions, such as differentiating big landlords and bourgeoisie who opposed the Anti-Japanese War from those who advocated for it; distinguishing between the big landlords and bourgeois who were in favour of the Anti-Japanese War but wavering, advocating unity but anti-communist, and the lesser dual-natured national bourgeoisie, small and medium landlords, and enlightened gentry. Internationally, different imperialist countries also need to be distinguished. And so on. And it clearly pointed out: "Establish our policies on these differences. The above various different policies are all derived from these differences in class relations."

Regarding various specific policies, the directive also stipulated clear specific policies on power organization, labor, land, taxation, counter-espionage, people's rights, economy, culture, education, military and other aspects according to the strategic principles in the United Front.



Final Instruction: "The strategic principles outlined above and the many specific policies stipulated by these principles within the united front must be resolutely implemented by the entire Party. At the time when Japan intensified its invasion of China and the domestic large landlords and bourgeoisie were implementing high-pressure policies and military attacks against the Communists and the people, it is only by implementing the aforementioned strategic principles and specific policies that we can persist in resisting Japan, develop the united front, gain the sympathy of the Chinese people, and strive for an improvement in the situation."

The establishment of the theory of New Democracy and the determination of a series of guidelines and policies for the Anti-Japanese National United Front marked the maturity of Mao Zedong Thought, the combination of Marxism with the practice of the Chinese revolution. After eighteen years of trials and tribulations, Mao Zedong finally pointed out the correct path for the Chinese people to achieve the victory of the democratic revolution and build a New China suitable for China's national conditions.

As Mao Zedong once said in his early years, "Doctrine is like a flag. Only when the flag is raised can everyone have hope and know where to go". This flag should be distinctive in color, simple and clear, and should have very rich and definite connotations, so that it is easier for more people to understand and accept. Since the Chinese people began to accept Marxism from around the May Fourth Movement, it took twenty years of hard exploration and twisting experiences to nicely combine Marxism with the practice of the Chinese revolution. During the Anti-Japanese war, the flag of "New Democracy" was independently raised, thus giving more people "hope" and "knowledge on where to go". This is a major event in Chinese history. Not only did it have a significant impact during and after the Anti-Japanese war, but it also played a huge guiding role in the subsequent Chinese revolution and construction.


On the New Democracy theory, the Chinese Communist Party's thoughts on the theory of the revolutionary road, the construction of people's armed forces, the strategy and tactics of the people's war, the strategy of the united front, economic thoughts and cultural work have been enriched and gradually completed. This shows that after the party's failure from the great revolution to the rise of the land war, from the defeat of the fifth "encirclement and suppression" to the rise of the anti-Japanese war, it accumulated rich revolutionary experience. During the Anti-Japanese War, the party faced a complicated international situation and domestic environment. Correctly answering new problems that arose in the national and class struggle accumulated many new experiences, which further helped us understand the laws of the Chinese revolution. As stated by Mao Zedong: "During the Anti-Japanese period, we only established a comprehensive line and a complete set of specific policies based on the situation. It was only then that we recognized the Kingdom of the Chinese Democratic Revolution and that we gained freedom." Obviously, during the Anti-Japanese War, Mao Zedong evolved the theory of Marxism-Leninism with the practice of the Chinese revolution into a new stage, forming the theoretical system of the New Democratic Revolution. It expanded in many aspects and levels such as politics, economy, military, culture, and party building. The significance of the tested ideas and theories of New Democracy is as follows:
First, it systematically summarized the historical experience of constructing White Areas and rural revolutionary bases, and correctly formulated the party's struggle strategy in Japanese-occupied areas, the Kuomintang-ruled areas, and the guidelines and policies for economic, political, and cultural construction in liberated areas.

The struggle of encircling cities from rural areas, with rural revolutionary bases as the main base, and armed struggle as the main form of struggle. "But just because we focus on the armed struggle, doesn't mean we can abandon other forms of struggle; on the contrary, without the cooperation of various forms of struggle apart from the armed struggle, the armed struggle cannot win. Emphasizing work on rural bases does not mean we can abandon urban work and work in other large rural areas still under enemy control. On the contrary, without urban work and other rural work, rural bases would be isolated, and the revolution would fail.


For this reason, under the leadership of Mao Zedong, the central party systematically summarized the lessons and experience of the party's work in the White-controlled areas since its foundation. Based on the semi-colonial and semi-feudal characteristics of Chinese society, it creatively formulated a complete set of struggle strategies suitable for the Japanese-controlled areas and Kuomintang-controlled areas; and systematically summarized the experience and lessons of the construction of rural revolutionary bases since 1927 to the full outbreak of the Anti-Japanese War. They formulated policies suitable for the actual conditions of economic, political, and cultural construction in the liberated areas during the Anti-Japanese War. The implementation of these struggle strategies and policies, combined directly and indirectly with the massive anti-Japanese guerrilla warfare launched by hundreds of millions of soldiers and civilians in the enemy rear, made the Anti-Japanese War a great revolution nationwide. 

Secondly, the party's construction problems were systematically summarized and the rectification movement was created, which unified the understanding of the entire party based on Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought. 

On the eve of the Anti-Japanese War and during the War, under the leadership of Mao Zedong, the party central committee systematically summarized the experience and lessons of the party's construction issues and strengthened the party's construction ideologically. It was proposed to summarize the experience and lessons of the Chinese revolution based on the basic principles of dialectical materialism and to strengthen the party's construction by rectifying the party's ideological line; to strengthen the party's construction by linking the united front, armed struggle, and other political lines with Chinese characteristics; and to creatively launch the rectification movement against subjectivism, sectarianism, and the party's eight legs, unifying the entire party's understanding based on the universal principles of Marxism-Leninism and the specific practice of the Chinese revolution.

Thirdly, Mao Zedong Thought was officially recognized as the guiding ideology of the entire party. The Seventh National Congress of the Party was the most important representative congress of the Chinese Communist Party in the period of democratic revolution after the founding of the Party. The Congress summarized the historical experience of the tortuous development of China's democratic revolution over more than 20 years, formulated the correct program and strategy, overcame the wrong thoughts within the party, and unified the whole party's understanding based on Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, achieving unprecedented unity within the party. That congress laid the foundation for the victory of the new democratic revolution nationwide. The new party constitution adopted by the Congress solemnly stipulated: The Chinese Communist Party, with Mao Zedong Thought, the unity of Marxist-Leninist theory and the practice of the Chinese revolution, serves as the pointer for all its work. This means that Mao Zedong Thought had then developed and matured into the guiding ideology recognized by the entire party, and the entire party had achieved unprecedented unity and unity based on Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought. From the Zunyi Conference to the Anti-Japanese War, the entire party's understanding gradually unified until it was completely unified, and finally completely unified in Mao Zedong Thought, which reflects the objective laws of the Chinese democratic revolution. It is precisely because the entire party operates according to Mao Zedong Thought, that is, according to the objective laws of the Chinese democratic revolution, that the party's team is tidy, the pace is consistent, and it can lead hundreds of millions of people to persist in anti-Japanese aggression for eight years, under the conditions where the comparison of enemy and our forces is extremely disparate. This made the Chinese Communist Party and the people's revolutionary forces achieve unprecedented development, and combined with the anti-fascist war of the Soviet Union and the people of other countries, finally defeated the Japanese aggressor. If it can be said that all the revolutionary struggles of the Chinese people for nearly a hundred years have suffered failures or setbacks, then the Anti-Japanese War is different, the Chinese people finally achieved the ultimate victory. This is related to the fact that there are much more favorable conditions internationally and domestically than in the past, but more importantly, the entire party, under the guidance of Mao Zedong Thought, correctly used these favorable conditions and overcame unfavorable conditions. Mao Zedong Thought led the Anti-Japanese War to achieve a great victory and laid a solid foundation for the victory of New Democracy throughout China.




During the Liberation War and after the establishment of New China, under the guidance of Mao Zedong's Thought, the people all over the country carried out a large-scale, intense Liberation War, overthrowing the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang, establishing the People's Democratic Dictatorship in New China, and smoothly transitioning from New Democracy to socialism. This led to significant achievements in the socialist transformation and construction, opening new areas of development for Mao Zedong's ideology.

After the victory of the Anti-Japanese War, the Chinese Communist Party anticipated two possible scenarios influenced by various domestic and international factors. The first possibility was a peaceful social and political reform, while the other was a civil war led by the Kuomintang, following the peaceful negotiations initiated by the Chinese Communist Party. The party presented a strategy of using both 'hands of revolution' to overcome both 'hands of counter-revolution'. This ensured that the party could timely engage in peaceful and legal struggles, gain public support and sympathy from the moderates in the first scenario, and effectively fight against the military attacks from the Kuomintang in the latter scenario. They aimed to expose the Chiang Kai-shek government for sabotaging peace and launching a civil war, proving the necessity of overthrowing it and establishing New China.

This strategy of using both 'hands of revolution' not only ensured readiness for self-defence without compromising on the desire for peace but also made the struggle more flexible, keeping the party in a politically proactive position and winning over potential moderate supporters, to thoroughly isolate a tiny reactionary clique led by Chiang Kai-shek. This strategic transformation from defense to offense and the development of ten military principles, answered how the People's Liberation Army could defeat Chiang's Army's attacks under unfavorable odds. Mao Zedong explicitly stated: "We not only must defeat Chiang Kai-shek, but we are also capable of defeating him."

By late December 1947, at a meeting called by the Central Committee of the Communist Party, Mao Zedong highlighted that the main force of the People's Liberation Army had already moved into the Kuomintang-ruled areas. This was a historical turning point. To utterly eliminate Chiang Kai-shek's reactionary army and finally secure a nationwide victory, Mao Zedong systematically proposed the ten military principles for the People's Liberation Army. These principles predicted the development trend of the war and summarized the long-term combat experience of the army. Following these principles, the People's Liberation Army not only thwarted the frenzied invasion of Chiang Kai-shek's army into the liberated areas but also successfully transitioned from strategic defense to strategic offense, ultimately leading to the decisive battle.




The launch of the land reform movement and the consolidation and expansion of the people's democratic united front, during the national liberation war, the party central committee led by Mao Zedong initiated an unprecedented land reform movement, further consolidating the worker-peasant alliance; At the same time, on the basis of the worker-peasant alliance led by the working class, all people who could be united and strived for were united, not only the national bourgeoisie, but also patriots who had split from the Kuomintang ruling group, and enlightened gentlemen who had split from the feudal landlord class. This made the people's democratic united front unprecedentedly consolidated and strengthened, making the Chiang Kai-shek group completely isolated and helpless. In May 1948, the Communist Party of China proposed to convene a political consultative conference without reactionary elements to discuss the establishment of a democratic coalition government. The call immediately received enthusiastic responses from various democratic parties, people's organizations, and non-partisan democrats. They sent representatives to the liberated areas one after another to prepare for the new CCP with the Communist Party of China. In the climax of the strategic decisive victory of the People's Liberation Army, various democratic parties declared their agreement with the Communist Party of China's industrial and commercial policies and land reform policies; recognized that the Kuomintang's reactionary rule was the source of the reactionary civil war and the main obstacle to domestic peace and democracy; pointed out that American imperialism was the enemy of the Chinese people. They jointly issued a statement, publicly declaring that they have abandoned the middle road and accepted the leadership of the Communist Party of China. This is a major victory for the Communist Party of China in effectively managing its relationship with the bourgeois. In September 1949, the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference officially opened. The Communist Party of China, various democratic parties, various people's organizations, various departments of the People's Liberation Army, various regions, various ethnic minorities, overseas Chinese and other patriots all sent representatives to the meeting. They respectively represent the working class, the peasant class, the urban petty bourgeoisie, the national bourgeoisie, and all other patriots, in fact they have the nature of representing the Chinese people. Therefore, the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference was formally established as a concrete organizational form of the people's democratic united front. Through this meeting, the Communist Party of China formulated a common program, uniting all the democratic classes and people of all ethnic groups in the country into this organization, in order to complete the great historical task of finally overthrowing the Kuomintang's reactionary rule and establishing the People's Republic of China. By this time, the people's democratic united front opposing imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism had "developed into the establishment of a people's democratic dictatorship led by the working class and based on the worker-peasant alliance." The reorganization of the party's troops, the strengthening and improvement of the party's leadership, the party central committee led by Mao Zedong during the entire liberation war, always took party building as a central link related to the success or failure of the revolution and took effective measures. On the one hand, a campaign to rectify the party and reorganize the party's rural grassroots organizations has been carried out; On the one hand, the central and unified leadership of the party central committee has been strengthened, making the party, government, and military leadership organs highly unified in the implementation of policies and disciplines, while paying attention to perfecting the party committee system, promoting the democratic tradition within the party, and launching a democratic movement within the party and the army. In this way, the work of the party's grassroots organizations and leading organs at all levels has been strengthened and improved, further consolidating and developing the ideological, political, and organizational unity and solidarity achieved at the seventh national congress of the party, and effectively ensuring the victory of the national revolution from the leadership of the party. The party's struggle strategy in the Kuomintang ruled area and the principle and policy of receiving and managing the city during the national liberation war, the mass struggle in the Kuomintang ruled area led by the Communist Party of China achieved unprecedented development, truly forming an important front behind the Chiang Kai-shek group. The opening and development of the second front first effectively coordinated the People's Liberation Army to crush the Jiang army's invasion of the liberated areas; With the strategic offensive, strategic decisive battle and strategic pursuit of the People's Liberation Army successively unfolding, they effectively coordinated with the Communist Party and the People's Liberation Army to protect and take over the central cities that the enemy had been entrenched for a long time.



This is the continuous development of the New Democracy theory on the policies and strategies for the work in white areas. Regarding the People's Democratic Dictatorship and the theory and policy of transition from New Democracy to Socialism, the People's Democratic Dictatorship is the bond linking the minimum and maximum program of the Chinese Communist Party, and is the political condition for the transition from New Democracy to Socialism. It is both a government of New Democratic nature and a government that can smoothly transition to proletarian dictatorship. This transition can be fully achieved under peaceful conditions, and there is no need for a violent revolution to overthrow a reactionary regime like Russia from the February Revolution to the October Revolution. The reactionary regime of the Kuomintang has been destroyed by the revolutionary war. The newly established People's Democratic Dictatorship in China, whether during the New Democratic Revolution or the Socialist Revolution, is a people's government led by the working class and based on the alliance of workers and peasants. When transitioning to the socialist revolution, the working and peasant masses would not overthrow their own government. This is another new development of the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism on armed seizure of power by Chinese Communists represented by Mao Zedong. Mao Zedong emphasized: Summarizing our experience, focus on one point, that is, the People's Democratic Dictatorship based on the alliance of workers and peasants led by the working class (through the Communist Party). This dictatorship must unite with international revolutionary forces. This is our formula, our main experience, and our main program. We can rely entirely on the weapon of People's Democratic Dictatorship, unite all people in the country except the reactionaries, and steadily reach our destination.


In modern China, the country is in a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society which is the basic national situation, and it determines that the revolution must go in two steps, take the route of armed struggle, and surround the cities from the countryside. Mao Zedong said: "Only by understanding the nature of Chinese society can one recognize the nature of the Chinese revolution, the tasks of the Chinese revolution, the motive force of the Chinese revolution, and the future and transition of the Chinese revolution." Therefore, "recognizing the nature of Chinese society means understanding China's national conditions is the basis of understanding all revolutionary issues." The main task of the first Party Congress in 921 was to establish the Chinese Communist Party and determine the nature of the Chinese Communist Party. At this time, China's communists had not yet deeply understood the national conditions of China and the special characteristics of China's revolution. They only started from the world's overall situation after the victory of the October Revolution, and concluded that China's revolution was bound to be a socialist revolution led by the proletariat. During the year after the founding of the Chinese Communist Party, through learning and mastering Marxism, and through the practice of revolutionary struggle, it had a further understanding of the international and domestic situation and the social conditions of China. In early 1922, the Chinese Communists participated in the first congress of the Communist Parties and national revolutionary groups of the Far East called by the Comintern and accepted Lenin's theory on the problem of national colonies. On June 15, 1922, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued "The Views of the Chinese Communist Party on the Current Situation". This document focuses on analyzing the history and current situation of international imperialism and China's feudal warlords colluding with each other to oppress the Chinese people after the Xinhai Revolution, pointing out that China is a "semi-independent feudal country" under the rule of international imperialism and its local feudal warlords and bureaucrats; the declaration of the second Congress of the Communist Party of China, based on a further analysis of the social nature of China, for the first time put forward the democratic revolutionary program of anti-imperialism and anti-feudalism. After the Second Congress of the Communist Party of China, Chinese communists continued to discuss the nature of Chinese society.



In 1923, Chen Duxiu used the concept of "semi-colony" in his article "Chinese National Revolution and Various Social Classes". He believed that the revolution of a semi-colonial country had a dual significance for foreign nationalist revolution and domestic democratic revolution. The aim was to seek economic independence from foreign intervention and political freedom internally. This is a unique characteristic of the national revolution in semi-colonial countries. The declaration of the third congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC) had referred to China's democratic revolution as the "national revolution", emphasizing that "semi-colonial China" should center its work around the national revolution, distinguishing it from the bourgeois democratic revolutions in European countries. In the same summer, Mao Zedong also used the term "semi-colony" in his political essay "Beijing Coup and Merchants". He pointed out that the semi-colonial Chinese politics is a dual political oppression in which domestic warlords and foreign imperialism collude against the entire national population. The historical mission of the Chinese National Revolution is to use the power of the people to overthrow the warlords and foreign imperialism. 

In 1926, Cai Hesen used the concept of "semi-colonial and semi-feudal China" in "The Development of the History of the Communist Party of China". It was precisely on the basis of a relatively accurate understanding of the nature of modern Chinese society and revolution that young Chinese Communists established a revolutionary united front with Sun Yat-sen's Chinese Nationalist Party, spearheading a fervent climax of the national revolution. However, at this time, the Chinese Communist Party's understanding of the laws governing Chinese society and the development of the Chinese revolution was not fully conscious. In the summer of 1927, the national revolution ultimately failed. Chiang Kai-shek, representing the new rightists of the Nationalist Party, established a new regime in Nanjing.

What kind of regime is the Nationalist government represented by Chiang Kai-shek? What kind of society exists under this regime? Has the semi-colonial and semi-feudal nature of China fundamentally changed? This is a question that must be resolved first in the revival of the revolution by Chinese communists. At the time, people had different understandings of this issue. Some said that Chinese society was still a feudal society, others said that China had become a capitalist society, or a pre-capitalist society; and of course, there were still those who insisted that China was still a semi-colonial society, etc. The sixth congress of the Chinese Communist Party, convened in June and July of 928, analyzed the political and economic situation in China after the failure of the national revolution. It pointed out: on one hand, the real unification of China was not completed, China had not been liberated from the iron heel of imperialism, and the Chinese revolution was still a semi-colonial revolution; on the other hand, the private land ownership system of the landlord class was not overthrown, and all semi-feudal remnants were not cleared, so the nature of the current stage of the Chinese revolution was still the bourgeois democratic revolution. In February 1929, the Chinese Communist Party officially put forward the complete concept of "semi-colonial and semi-feudal" in its own documents. However, not long after the sixth congress of the Chinese Communist Party, a dispute arose within the party over this issue, which had basically been settled. Chen Duxiu and others accepted Trotsky's erroneous position on the China issue, believing that the failure of the national revolution showed that the bourgeoisie had won and that the remnants of feudalism had been hit for the last time. The Nationalist government in Nanjing was a regime centered on and led by the bourgeoisie, and Chinese society had become a society where capitalism prevails and is expected to develop peacefully. The proletariat should only carry out the socialist revolution after capitalism has fully developed, currently it can only conduct legitimate activities centered on the slogan "National Assembly". This essentially denied that Chinese society is still a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, denied the necessity of continuing anti-imperialist and anti-feudal democratic revolution, and became the right-wing erroneous view of canceling the revolution.



At the same time, influenced by Stalin and the Communist International, some leaders in the Chinese Communist Party believed that the betrayal of the revolution by Chiang Kai-shek and the right-wing of the Kuomintang represented the entirety of China's bourgeoisie, and the Kuomintang regime was essentially a bourgeois government. They advocated that the Chinese revolution should completely oppose not only the bourgeoisie but also the petty bourgeoisie, conflating the opposition to capitalism with to imperialism and feudalism, thus blurring the definite boundaries between democratic revolution and socialist revolution. This adventurous "leftist" perspective was viewed as an error. Whether it was the right view or the "left" one, they all exaggerated the capitalist components of Chinese society under the rule of the Kuomintang, misjudging Chiang Kai-shek's regime as representing bourgeois interests, showing a misunderstanding of the fundamental nature of Chinese society. Importantly, their mistaken understanding on the question of societal nature, led to two totally different conclusions concerning the nature of the Chinese revolution- one advocating to cancel the national democratic revolution, the other pushing to outstrip it. Thus, understanding the true nature of Chinese society is extremely significant for a revolutionary party.



Just as the Chinese Communists were seeking new understanding on the nature of Chinese society and revolution, intellectuals of the KMT were also frequently publishing articles, discussing the nature of Chinese society. Tao Xisheng was one of them. Between 1928 and 1929, Tao wrote numerous articles. Sometimes he described modern Chinese society as a feudal society under imperialistic rule. At other times, he argued that China was no longer a feudal state but a society primarily shaped by literati and peasants before the rise of capitalism after the collapse of feudalism. In other instances, he defined Chinese society as late feudalism from a feudal perspective, and as pre-capitalism from the capitalistic view. His contradictory and vague statements about the nature of Chinese society were an attempt to sow confusion and oppose the thriving peasant revolution under communist leadership.

In that context, a debate about the nature of Chinese society ensued, lasting from the late 1920s to the mid-1930s, a period of nearly ten years. The discussion shifted from the nature of Chinese society to the nature of its rural society and expanded to its social history. Marxist theorists and progressive social scientists actively engaged in the debate under the direct influence of the Chinese Communist Party. They analyzed modern Chinese society and revolution from the standpoint of Marxism-Leninism, refuting erroneous perspectives, particularly those held by Tao Xisheng and the Trotskyists, and preliminarily demonstrating the semi-colonial, semi-feudal nature of Chinese society. They argued that the nature of the Chinese revolution could only be understood by distinguishing the unique economic structure of Chinese society. They pointed out that China was a semi-colony of imperialist countries. Imperialist aggression had dealt severe blows to China's feudal natural economy thereby initiating capitalist development. Simultaneously, imperialism colluded with Chinese feudal forces to impede the development of national capital and the bankruptcy of national industry was widespread. In China, semi-feudal relations still prevailed. At the time, their arguments were preliminary but helped clarify amidst the plurality of opinions about China's social situation that Chinese society was semi-colonial and semi-feudal. The Chinese Communist Party successfully disseminated this scientific judgment beginning with this debate, and its impact was huge. The document "Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party", written cooperatively by Mao Zedong, Zhang Wentian, and Li Weihan in December 1939, represents the Party's highest level of understanding on these issues.



"The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party" analyzes the roughly three thousand years of feudal society that lasted from the Zhou and Qin dynasties. It points out: "Since the Opium War in 1840, China has gradually turned into a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society. Since the Japanese imperialist armed invasion of China after the 918 Incident in 1931, China again turned into a colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal society." Mao Zedong further explained in "On New Democracy" written in January 1940: "Since the foreign capitalist invasion of China, and as capitalist elements gradually grew in Chinese society, China has gradually turned into a colonial, semi-colonial, semi-feudal society. Today's China, in areas occupied by Japan, is a colonial society; in areas ruled by the Kuomintang, it is essentially a semi-colonial society; whether in areas occupied by Japan or the Kuomintang, feudal and semi-feudal systems predominate. This is the nature of current Chinese society, this is the current situation in China."

The evolution of modern Chinese society from being entirely feudal to colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal is not accidental. This societal transition went through a long, slow, and complicated process. Recognizing this helps us to deeply understand the nature of modern Chinese society, and correctly evaluate and understand the role of foreign capitalism in China in the past century.

"The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party" analyzes the evolution of modern Chinese society from two aspects: one is China's evolution from a fully feudal society to a semi-feudal one; the other is China's evolution from an independent sovereign nation to a semi-colonial, colonial nation. These are two historical processes that occurred in the same space and time. The book believes that the main cause of these changes is the invasion of foreign capitalism. "When the imperialist powers invaded China, they prompted the disintegration of Chinese feudal society and the emergence of capitalist elements, turning a feudal society into a semi-feudal one. But on the other hand, they cruelly ruled China, transforming an independent China into a semi-colonial and colonial China."

So, what role did foreign capitalism play in promoting China's evolution from a fully feudal society to a semi-feudal one? The book states: "Foreign capitalism had a great disintegrating influence on China's socioeconomic conditions. On the one hand, it destroyed the basis of China's self-sufficient natural economy, devastating urban handicrafts and peasant home-based handicrafts. On the other hand, it promoted the development of China's urban and rural commodity economies." Both the destruction of the natural economy's foundations and the development of urban and rural commodity economies created the conditions for the emergence and growth of the Chinese bourgeoisie. But since imperialism controlled China's economic lifelines and politics, the Chinese national capital that emerged in the middle of the last century was in extremely difficult conditions and could not normally develop and grow. It never "became the main form of China's socioeconomic structure", and it did not lead China into a capitalist society.

Not only was it squeezed out by foreign capital with various privileges, but it was also powerless to resist the pre-capitalist exploitative regimens that still dominated Chinese society. Thus, modern China changed the historical direction it should have followed, gradually evolving into a semi-feudal society where a "weak capitalist economy existed simultaneously with a severe semi-feudal economy, and some modern industries and commercial cities existed simultaneously with the stagnant vast rural areas".

However, the aforementioned changes are only one aspect of the transitions in modern Chinese society. The book further points out: "The goal of the imperial powers invading China is certainly not to transform feudal China into capitalist China. The goals of the imperialist powers are contrary, they want to turn China into their semi-colonies and colonies..."



If it's said that promoting the development of capitalist buds in China and making China a semi-feudal society was not the original intention and consciousness of imperialist powers, then turning China into their colony, putting China in a position of arbitrary humiliation and slaughter, is determined by the nature of imperialism. Marx and Engels pointed out in "The Communist Manifesto" that the need to constantly expand product sales drives the bourgeoisie around the world. "It must settle everywhere, start businesses everywhere, and establish contacts everywhere." It destroys "all long walls" with cheap goods. Just as it subordinates the countryside to the city, it subordinates uncivilized and semi-civilized countries to civilized countries, nationalities of farmers to the bourgeoisie, and the East to the West. In order to conquer the vast and hollow-strong China, the imperialist powers have exhausted all means and adopted various methods and ways in the last hundred years. "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party" combines the history of Chinese and foreign relations in the past century, summarizing imperialism's ten ways and means of aggressing and oppressing China from military, political, economic, cultural, and diplomatic aspects, vividly depicting the bloody picture of turning a feudal China into a semi-feudal, semi-colonial, and colonial China.

From this we can understand that the invasion of China by imperialist powers, on one hand, promoted the disintegration of Chinese feudal society, stimulated the occurrence of capitalist elements in China, and transformed a feudal society into a semi-feudal society; on the other hand, they ruled China brutally, turning an independent China into a semi-colonial and colonial China. Combining the situation in these two aspects, our colony, semi-colony, semi-feudal society has the following characteristics:

Firstly, the natural economic foundation of self-sufficiency in the feudal era was destroyed; however, the foundation of the feudal exploitation system—the exploitation of the landlord class on peasants—not only remains, but also combines with the exploitation of comprador capital and usurious capital, taking a clear advantage in China's socio-economic life.

Secondly, national capitalism has developed to some extent and played a significant role in China's political and cultural life; however, it has not become the main form of China's social economy, its power is very weak, and most of it has more or less connection with foreign imperialism and domestic feudalism.

Thirdly, the autocratic regime of emperors and nobles was overthrown, first replaced by the rule of the warlord bureaucracy of the landlord class, followed by the dictatorship of a coalition of the landlord class and the large bourgeoisie. In the occupied areas, it was the rule of Japanese imperialism and its puppets.

Fourthly, imperialism not only manipulates China's financial and economic lifelines but also controls China's political and military power. In the occupied areas, all are monopolized by Japanese imperialism.

Fifth, because China is under the rule or semi-rule of many imperialist countries, because China is actually in a long-term state of disunity, and because China's land is vast, China's economic, political, and cultural development show extreme imbalance.

Sixth, due to the double oppression of imperialism and feudalism, especially due to Japan's large-scale aggression, the vast majority of Chinese people, especially peasants, are becoming increasingly impoverished and even bankrupt, living in dire poverty and without political rights. The degree of poverty and lack of freedom among the Chinese people is rare in the world.



These are the characteristics of the colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal Chinese society. It is determined mainly by the forces of Japanese imperialism and other imperialisms, a result of the combination between foreign imperialism and domestic feudalism. 

Mao Zedong repeatedly emphasized that only by clarifying the nature of Chinese society, can the nature and tasks of the Chinese revolution be clearly recognized, the targets and motivation of the revolution be understood, and the future and changes of the revolution be predicted. In short, only by recognizing the social nature of China can we scientifically grasp the basic laws of the development of modern Chinese society and correctly solve a series of basic problems in the Chinese revolution. Following this, Mao Zedong repeatedly discussed the semi-colonial and semi-feudal nature of modern Chinese society in his works such as "On New Democracy". 



The so-called revolution in two steps refers to dividing the Chinese revolution into democratic revolution and socialist revolution. "The first step is to change this colonial, semi-colonial and semi-feudal social form and transform it into an independent democratic society. The second step is to advance the revolution and establish a socialist society." In the history of the Chinese Communist Party, this thought of strategic significance had undergone a very tortuous process from its proposition to its finalization. In fact, whether this strategic thought can be correctly understood and interpreted not only affects the practice of the Chinese revolution but also directly influences the development of the revolutionary theory of the Chinese Communist Party. 

After the establishment of the Chinese Communist Party, it used the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism as a weapon to observe the fate of the nation and initially answered the problems encountered in the Chinese revolution. In July 1922, the second grand assembly of the party scientifically analyzed the international and domestic situation and the social nature of China. It considered imperialism and feudalism as the main enemies at that time. The Chinese revolution must first overthrow the rule of imperialism and feudalism to achieve victory in the democratic revolution, then carry out the socialist revolution. Therefore, the grand assembly for the first time put forward the thorough anti-imperialist and anti-feudal democratic revolution program in its declaration, that is to eliminate civil strife, overthrow warlords, and build domestic peace; overthrow the oppression of international imperialism to achieve complete independence of the Chinese nation; unify China (including the three eastern provinces) into a genuine democratic republic. The grand assembly reiterated the Party's highest program: "Organize the proletariat, use class struggle means, establish a dictatorship of the workers and peasants, eradicate the private property system, and gradually achieve a communist society." Closely related to the formulation of the democratic revolution program is the idea proposed by the second grand assembly of the party that the Chinese revolution should be divided into two steps. The declaration of the grand assembly pointed out: the struggle of the proletariat must be divided into two steps, the first is "to assist the democratic revolutionary movement", and the second is "to implement 'the dictatorship of the proletariat in alliance with poor peasants'". "If the organization strength and combat capability of the proletariat are strong, this second step of struggle can be immediately successful after the victory of the democratic revolution." The second grand assembly of the party determined that the Chinese revolution should be carried out in two stages, and the proletariat should first strive to complete the bourgeois democratic revolution. Compared with the claim of directly carrying out a socialist revolution in China, this is a significant progress, which has played a role in promoting the party and the workers' class to participate in the democratic revolution. However, the second assembly of the party did not clarify the relationship between the democratic revolution and the proletariat revolution.



Although the Party's two major documents pointed out that "Workers are under the extreme oppression of Chinese and foreign capitalists, and the revolutionary movement will develop on its own. The result of this development will turn into the revolutionary leader army that overturns world capitalist imperialism in China," the basic understanding of the Second Congress of the Communist Party of China is that the proletariat is merely "assisting" and "helping" the democratic revolutionary movement, of course, this "assistance" and "help", is not "the proletariat subjugating the bourgeoisie", but is "a necessary step to not prolong the life of feudalism and cultivate the real power of the proletariat". The Second Congress also believes that: "After the democratic revolution succeeds, the proletariat only gains some freedoms and rights", and "the naive bourgeoisie will rapidly develop and be in a confrontational position with the proletariat". At this point, the proletariat must carry out the "second step struggle". For this issue, Chen Duxiu made further elaborations in 1923. He believes, "The proletariat clearly knows that the success of such a democratic revolution is indeed a victory for the bourgeoisie, but the naive proletariat currently only has the opportunity to gain some freedom and expand its capabilities in the struggle of this victory, so cooperation with the revolutionary bourgeoisie is also the necessary path for the Chinese proletariat at present. ""Under normal circumstances, the victory of the national revolution is naturally the victory of the bourgeoisie; it is naturally the bourgeoisie that seizes power". The deficiencies of the Second Congress were later developed by Chen Duxiu into the "second revolution theory", which became the theoretical root of the right-leaning mistake within the party.

Regarding the relationship between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution, or the question of the future of the Chinese revolution, the Fourth Congress of the Party from January 11 to January 22, 1925, also touched upon it. The fourth congress of the party stated that the future of the Chinese revolution is a non-capitalist future (originally there was a draft resolution, which was removed after discussion). However, compared with the understanding of the second congress of the party, the fourth congress deepened its proposition on the issue that the Chinese revolution must take two steps. First, it basically clarified the idea that the proletariat must bear the responsibility of leading the Chinese revolution, pointing out that: "The Chinese national revolutionary movement, must have the strongest participation of the most revolutionary proletariat, and take on a leading position in order to achieve victory." Second, it questions whether the bourgeoisie will seize power after the victory of the democratic revolution. These two points are interconnected. If we think about these two points together, we would have reached a clear conclusion: the future of the proletariat-led democratic revolution is not capitalism. But the documents of the Fourth Congress of the Party show that its understanding is still unclear. The resolution points out: "After the victory of the national revolution, whether it will be followed by the worker's revolution, whether it must go through the bourgeois democratic system, depends on the extent of the proletariat's own class revolutionary preparation at that time and the objective conditions of society at that time, as well as the political situation in the world at that time, which will all have a great impact." Here, it raises the question of how the success of the democratic revolution and the proletarian revolution are linked, which is obviously different from the "Second revolution theory" that separates the two. But this statement only questions the insertion of a capitalist stage between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution, "whether it must go through the bourgeoisie's democratic system" still depends on the situation. In other words, it does not rule out the possibility of a capitalist future. At the same time, the Fourth Congress did not provide specific answers to how to achieve the leadership of the proletariat, especially how to deal with various complex issues in the struggle for leadership with the bourgeoisie; and it still lacks sufficient understanding of the extreme importance of the issue of power and arms. These weaknesses have gradually become evident in the development of the revolutionary movement afterward.



Despite the Fourth Congress of the Party, where some Marxists within the Party, such as Deng Zhongxia, Zhou Enlai, Li Dazhao, Mao Zedong, Liu Shaoqi, Qu Qiubai, etc., published articles one after another. Using Marxism as guidance, they criticized the erroneous theories of the right wing of the Kuomintang and Chen Duxiu from different perspectives, analyzed the economic status and political attitudes of various classes in Chinese society, studied the practical issues and characteristics of the Chinese revolution, and actively explored the basic laws of the Chinese revolution. For example, Deng Zhongxia pointed out in "Several Important Issues in the Renaissance of Labor" published in May 1925: "The proletariat participates in the National Revolution, not as a subordinate of any bourgeoisie, but with their own class purposes; in the National Revolution we should prioritize our class interests." Mao Zedong published "Analysis of Different Classes in Chinese Society" in "Revolution" in October 1925, "Analysis of Different Classes in Chinese Farmers and Their Attitudes Towards Revolution" in "Chinese Farmers" in January 1926, "Reasons for the Separation of the Right Wing of the Kuomintang and Its Impact on the Revolutionary Future" in "Political Weekly", and in March, "Analysis of Different Classes in Chinese Society" was published in "China Youth". Employing the class analysis method of Marxism, it analyzed the various classes in Chinese society, expounded on the tasks, objectives, leadership, motive force, and prospects of the Chinese revolution, and put forward the basic ideas of the New Democratic Revolution. However, these correct views did not dominate the party's leadership until the end of 1926, the "Two Revolutions Theory" was still the majority and formal opinion of the Communist Party's leadership. The fatal mistake of the "Two Revolutions Theory" was to voluntarily give up or not strive for leadership in the revolution by the proletariat and the Communist Party, committing a right-leaning mistake at a critical moment in the revolution, leading the first major revolution to failure.

Second, the systematic formation of the "Two Steps" strategic conception. At the end of 1926, the resolution on the issue of the Chinese situation passed by the Seventh Enlarged Meeting of the Executive Committee of the Communist International stated: "Although the current stage of the development of the Chinese revolution, historically speaking, is of the nature of a bourgeois democratic revolution, it must be characterized by a broad social movement. The outcome of the Chinese revolution does not necessarily create a social and political environment that promotes the development of capitalism. The process of the Chinese revolution is taking place in the era of capitalism decline, it is part of the overall struggle to eliminate capitalism and build socialism. The structure of the revolutionary state will be determined by its class basis. This revolutionary state will not be a purely bourgeois democratic state, but will become a dictatorship of workers, peasants and other exploited classes. It will be a revolutionary anti-imperialist government in the transitional period to non-capitalist (socialist) development. The Chinese Communist Party has decided to make every effort to realize the revolutionary future of transition to non-capitalist development. The Communist International brought the issue of the "non-capitalist future" of the Chinese revolution prominently before the Chinese Communist Party. From the end of 1926 to the beginning of 1927, the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee discussed the issue of the linkage between the two stages of the Chinese revolution and formed a party document "Explanation of the Central Political Bureau on the Seventh Expanded International Chinese Issue Resolution". The Central Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China accepted the instructions of the Executive Committee of the Communist International, reviewed the errors of the "Two Revolutions Theory", and interpreted the international instructions. The Central Political Bureau believes that the Party Central Committee’s past understanding of the Chinese revolution has a fundamental error, that is, it has drawn a huge "natural insurmountable" gap between the national revolution and the proletariat revolution. If the national revolution and the proletarian revolution are completely divided into two disconnected periods, and stick to the old framework to carry out the national revolution, and self-depict with this, it will "ruin the national revolution". According to the instructions of the International and China's internal and external conditions, "the development of the future of the Chinese National Revolution will exceed the bourgeois democratic revolution.



The successful national revolution led by the proletariat does not need to create a political environment conducive to the development of capitalism, but rather, transitions from capitalism to a non-capitalistic (socialist) political environment... to smoothly move towards socialism”. We should "view the national revolution and the proletarian revolution as the entirety of the Chinese revolution," "seize the connection between these two revolutions and make them inseparable," "and should not subjectively determine that our destiny must have a second revolution, and prepare to have a second revolution."
The explanation given by the Central Political Bureau officially rejects the previous erroneous belief of the "Twice Revolution theory" which separates the democratic revolution and socialist revolution, combines the issue of proletarian leadership with the two stages of revolution organically, treats the democratic revolution and socialist revolution as a whole, and considers how to cause non-capitalistic development. This is its correctness. However, the explanation of considering the democratic revolution and socialist revolution as "seamlessly one" and no need for "preparing for the second revolution" is wrong. It indicates that the Chinese Communist Party had not yet cleared the difference and connection between the two stages of the Chinese revolution, and had not found the correct path to a non-capitalistic turn.
The view of "single revolution" confuses the nature and stage boundary of the democratic revolution and socialist revolution, tries to complete the tasks of the two revolutions in one step, which reflects a "leftist" impatience. But at the same time, it also contains valuable ideas that were later confirmed by facts, that is: the proletariat will establish a democratic government of workers and peasants after the democratic revolution and take the supreme economic right from the hands of imperialism, warlords, bureaucrats, and compradors; the revolution in which the proletariat seize power has only one time, and the Chinese democratic revolution will not see the bourgeoisie control the power like the French Revolution. In short, the future of the Chinese revolution is socialism, not capitalism. These marks the theoretical progress of the members of the Chinese Communist Party. However, at the time, the mistakes in the "single revolution theory" became increasingly prominent and continued to develop, forming a "left-leaning" mistake of eliminating the bourgeoisie during the democratic revolution phase. After 1927, Qu Qiubai, Li Lisan, and Wang Ming all made mistakes in understanding the relationship between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution, which led to the "leftist" thought to dominate the central leadership of the party three times and cause serious harm to the revolutionary cause.
During the Land Revolution War, in response to the erroneous "uninterrupted revolution" theory in the party that wants to "skip the stage of the bourgeois civil rights revolution", Mao Zedong pointed out in "The Struggle in Jinggang Mountains" that: "China is indeed currently in the stage of the bourgeois civil rights revolution. The program of China's thorough civil rightist revolution includes overthrowing imperialism externally and completely achieving national liberation; cleansing the influence of the comprador class in the cities internally, completing the land revolution, eliminating the feudal relationship in the rural areas, and overthrowing the warlord government. Only after such a civil rightist revolution can a genuine foundation be built for a transition to socialism."  Later, Mao Zedong discussed the economic policy of the Red Zone at the Second National Worker-Peasant-Soilder Representatives Conference in January 1934. He pointed out: "The principle of our economic policy is to carry out all possible and necessary economic constructions, concentrate on economic power to supply war and to rectify the living standards of the people, strengthen the unity of workers, peasants and economics, ensure the proletarian-led peasants, strive for national-run economy to lead private economy, and lay the groundwork for future development to socialism." However, these thoughts of Mao Zedong at that time were mostly aroused under the correct guidance of the Communist International, which are the initial results of the combination of Marxism-Leninism and the concrete reality of the Chinese Revolution. The thought of Mao Zedong about "two steps" Chinese revolution was still in its infancy and early formation stages.
However, in order to "push our work forwards", we need to "advance our great cause of combining the universal truth of Marxism-Leninism with the concrete practice of the Chinese revolution". After the Anti-Japanese War entered a stalemate stage, the tasks of the Chinese Communist Party's ideological struggle were significant.



The stubborn wing of the Kuomintang (KMT) advocates: if Three Principles of The People are to be accepted, communism must be set aside. While some representatives of the national bourgeoisie display dissatisfaction with the dictatorial rule of the KMT and their weak resistance in the war, they remain skeptical about the propositions of the Communist Party and the prospects of the Sino-Japanese War. They attempt to seek a political path beyond the political positions of both the KMT and Communist Party, hoping to establish a bourgeois republic in China similar to those in Europe and America.
