Even within the Communist Party and revolutionary ranks, some lack understanding of the theory and policy of the Chinese revolution. Thus, the task of explaining to the entire party and the people of the country the party's full understanding of the Chinese revolution gravely lies ahead of the Chinese Communists. Against such backdrop, Mao Zedong’s systematic study and exposition on the "two-step" problem of the Chinese revolution is carried out in depth. In Yan'an, Mao conducted extensive theoretical research on this issue, systematically summarized the pros and cons of the Chinese revolution, pooled the wisdom of the whole party and successively wrote the "No Idle Talk about The Communist" and "The Chinese Revolution and The Chinese Communist Party" and "On New Democracy" and other works. The introduction of these works marked the systematic formation of the strategy of the Chinese revolution progressing “in two steps”.


Colonial and semi-colonial countries must go through a difficult and complex path of proletarian revolution from democracy to socialism. The democratic revolution, in terms of its social nature, is a bourgeois revolution. Why is this the first step of the proletarian revolutionary movement in these countries? After the victory of the proletarian-led democratic revolution, it is not possible to enter socialism, then what is its immediate future? If the immediate future is not socialism, why is it said that the socialist revolution is the inevitable trend of the new democratic revolution? These are exactly some of the problems that the New Democratic theory seeks to answer and solve. The scientific elucidation of these issues constitutes the basic principles of New Democracy. 


The nature of the New Democratic revolution is a bourgeois democratic revolution, not a proletarian socialist revolution. In “The Chinese Revolution and The Chinese Communist Party,” Mao Zedong pointed out that what kind of revolution is the current stage of the Chinese revolution? Is it a bourgeois democratic revolution or a proletarian socialist revolution? Obviously, it is not the latter, but the former. Based on a complete understanding of the special nature of Chinese society, Mao pointed out that since Chinese society remains a colonial, semi-colonial and semi-feudal one, the primary enemies of the Chinese revolution are imperialism and feudal forces. Furthermore, the tasks of Chinese revolution are the national revolution and the democratic revolution aimed at overthrowing these two primary enemies. Sometimes the bourgeoisie also participates in this revolution against these two enemies. Even if the big bourgeoisie betrays the revolution and turns into an enemy of revolution, the brunt of the revolution is not directed towards general capitalism and its private property, but towards imperialism and feudalism. Hence, the nature of the Chinese revolution at its current phase is not proletarian socialism, but bourgeois democracy. But the bourgeois democratic revolution of China at present is no longer of the old-fashioned and general type - such revolution is already outdated but is a special type of bourgeois democratic revolution. This revolution is developing in China and all other colonial and semi-colonial countries. We call this revolution "the New Democratic revolution." This new democratic revolution is a part of the world proletarian socialist revolution, and it is resolutely against imperialism i.e., international capitalism. Politically, it combines several revolutionary classes against the dictatorship of imperialists and traitors. It opposes turning Chinese society into a bourgeois dictatorship. Economically, it puts the big capital and big business of imperialists and traitors under state operation, redistributes the land of the landowner class to farmers, preserves the general private capitalist enterprises, and does not abolish the rich farmer economy.



Therefore, this new form of democratic revolution, while on the one hand is paving the way for capitalism, it is, on the other hand, creating a prerequisite for socialism. The current stage of revolution in China is a transitional stage between ending the colonial, semi-colonial, semi-feudal society and establishing a socialist society; it is a process of New Democracy Revolution.

So when did this process begin? Mao Zedong stated that this process started after the First World War and the October Revolution in Russia, and in China, it started with the May Fourth Movement in 1919. The so-called New Democratic Revolution is a revolution against imperialism and feudalism led by the proletariat of the masses. It is essential for China's society to pass through this revolution to further develop into a socialist society; otherwise, it would not be possible. Mao Zedong elaborately pointed out that China's New Democratic Revolution greatly differs from the historic democratic revolution in European and American countries. It does not lead to bourgeois dictatorship but rather a dictatorship of a united front of several revolutionary classes under the leadership of the proletariat. During the Anti-Japanese War, the Anti-Japanese Democratic Government established by the Communist Party of China within the various anti-Japanese bases was a government of the Anti-Japanese National United Front. It neither represents the dictatorship of the bourgeoisie nor the dictatorship of the proletariat, but a dictatorship of a combination of revolutionary classes led by the proletariat. As long as people endorse opposing Japan and support democracy, regardless of their affiliation, they qualify to participate in this government. On the other hand, this New Democratic Revolution also differs from the Socialist Revolution. It only overthrows the rule of imperialists and treacherous reactionaries in China, without destroying any capitalist element that can still contribute to the anti-imperial and anti-feudal struggle.

Mao Zedong stressed that this New Democracy Revolution aligns fundamentally with the revolution of the Three People's Principles advocated by Sun Yat-sen in 1924. Sun Yat-sen stated in the "Manifesto of the First National Congress of the Kuomintang" published that year: "The so-called system of civil rights in modern countries is often monopolized by the bourgeoisie and has become a tool to oppress the common people. If the KMT's democracy, then it is common to all civilians, not a few who get it. He also said: "As for the businesses of both Chinese and foreigners that are monopolistic in nature, or too large to handle by private power, such as banks, railways, and airlines, must be operated and managed by the state, so that the private capitalist system cannot manipulate the people's livelihood, which is the essence of restraining capital." Sun Yat-sen also pointed out in his will the basic principles regarding domestic and foreign affairs that "we must arouse the masses and unite with nations in the world that treat me equally to struggle together." All these have transformed the old Three People's Principles that adapt to the old international and domestic environment into the New Three People's Principles that adapt to the new international and domestic environment. The Communist Party of China issued a proclamation on September 22, 1937, declaring that "The Three People's Principles are a necessity for China today, and our party is willing to struggle for its thorough realization," which refers to these Three People's Principles, not any other. This Three People's Principle is Sun Yat-sen's three major policies, namely, alliance with Russia, alliance with the Communist Party, and assistance to workers and peasants. Under the new international and domestic conditions, the Three People's Principles without the three major policies would not be a revolutionary Three People's Principles. Thus, China's bourgeois democratic revolution, whether in terms of its battlefront (United Front) or its state structure, cannot disregard the position of the proletariat, the peasant class, and other petty bourgeois. Whoever intends to discard the proletariat, the peasant class, and other petty bourgeois in China will, in no way, be able to solve the fate of the Chinese nation or any problem in China. The democratic republic that China's present stage of revolution aims to build must be a democratic republic that sees workers, peasants, and other petty bourgeois assuming a certain position and playing a certain role. In other words, it is a democratic republic of a revolutionary alliance of workers, peasants, petty bourgeois, and all other anti-imperialist and anti-feudal forces. The thorough establishment of this republic is only possible under the leadership of the proletariat.



Fully understanding the nature of the New Democracy Revolution, the party systematically summarized its basic characteristics, deepening the understanding of this revolution. The New Democratic Revolution is "a part of the proletarian socialist world revolution" and is "an ally on the front line of the world socialist revolution". The Communist Party of China pointed out in a deep analysis of the historical characteristics of the New Democratic Revolution that if one studies the historical development of China and the world, they would know that these historical characteristics of the New Democratic Revolution did not exist since the Opium War, but were formed later, after the First World War and the October Revolution in Russia. Mao Zedong once again emphasized clearly that the current nature of Chinese society, being of colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal character, determines that the Chinese revolution must be divided into two steps: 

The first step is to change the colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal society and turn it into an independent democratic society; the second step is to advance the revolution and establish a socialist society. The present revolution in China is taking the first step. This first step, the preparatory stage, has also been ongoing since the Opium War in 1840 when Chinese society began to change from a feudal society to a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society. Through the Taiping Heavenly Rebellion, the Sino-French War, the Sino-Japanese War, the Hundred Days' Reform, the Xinhai Revolution, the May Fourth Movement, the Northern Expedition, and the Land Revolution War, up until today's Anti-Japanese War, many individual stages lasting about one hundred years, they are all implementing this first step. The Chinese people are taking different steps at different times and to different degrees against imperialism and feudal forces, striving to establish an independent democratic society and complete the first revolution. The revolution that truly began in a more complete sense was the Xinhai Revolution. This revolution, in terms of its social nature, is a bourgeois democratic revolution, not a proletarian socialist revolution. This revolution is still not complete, and much effort is needed because the enemies of this revolution are still very powerful. Sun Yat-sen's statement, "the revolution has not yet succeeded, comrades still need to work hard," refers to this bourgeois democratic revolution. 

However, since the outbreak of the First World War in 1914 and the establishment of a socialist state on one-sixth of the world's land by the October Revolution in 1917, China's bourgeois democratic revolution has changed. Before this, China's bourgeois democratic revolution belonged to the category of the old world bourgeois democratic revolution, and was a part of it. After this, China's bourgeois democratic revolution has changed to be within the category of the new bourgeois democratic revolution, and on the front line of the revolution, it became part of the world proletarian socialist revolution. The direct cause of this change, as Mao Zedong pointed out, was the First World War and the victorious socialist October Revolution, which changed the direction of world history and divided the era of world history.



In the era when the global capitalist front has collapsed in one corner of the earth (this corner occupying one-sixth of the world's land), and in the other corners, its decadence has been fully revealed, any colony or semi-colony countries, if a revolution against imperialism, against the international bourgeoisie, and against international capitalism occur, will no longer belong to the category of the old-world bourgeois democratic revolution, but belong to the new category. It is no longer part of the old bourgeois and capitalist world revolution, but part of the new world revolution, namely, part of the proletarian socialist world revolution. 

The colony and the semi-colony of this kind of revolution can no longer be allied forces of the world capitalist anti-revolutionary front but has become allied forces of the world socialist revolutionary front. The first stage, the first step, of this kind of colony and semi-colony revolution, although basically bourgeois-democratic in nature according to its social nature and its objective requirement is to clear the way for the development of capitalism, it is no longer the old, bourgeois-led revolution aiming at establishing a capitalist society and a bourgeois dictatorship, but a new, proletarian-led revolution, aiming at setting up a new democratic society and establishing a dictatorship of revolutionary classes in the first stage.

Therefore, this kind of revolution exactly clears a broader way for the development of socialism. This kind of revolution, in its process, divides into several stages due to changes in the enemy situation and allies, yet its basic nature does not change. This kind of revolution strikes imperialism thoroughly and thus is not permitted by imperialism, but is opposed to imperialism. However, it is permitted by socialism and aided by socialist countries and the international proletariat of socialism. Therefore, this kind of revolution inevitably becomes part of the proletarian socialist world revolution.

Mao Zedong reflects on the proposal process of "the Chinese Revolution is part of the world revolution" in "On New Democracy". He pointed out that "the Chinese Revolution is part of the world revolution", this correct proposition, was proposed as early as 1924 to 1927 during the first great revolution in China. This was proposed by Chinese Communists, and was approved by all those who participated in the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal struggle at that time. However, the significance of this theory was not yet brought into play at that time, causing people to only vaguely understand this issue. Mao Zedong said that this kind of "world revolution" is no longer the old world revolution, the old bourgeois world revolution has ended; it is the new world revolution, it is the socialist world revolution. Similarly, this kind of "part" is no longer part of the old bourgeois revolution, but part of the new socialist revolution. This is a great change, this is an unparalleled great change since the world history and Chinese history.

Mao Zedong also particularly mentioned that the correct proposition of "the Chinese Revolution is part of the world revolution" proposed by the Chinese Communists "is based on Stalin's theory."



In 1918, to commemorate the first anniversary of the October Revolution, Stalin said in "The October Revolution and the National Question", “The great global significance of the October Revolution, lies mainly in: First, it broadened the scope of the national problem, transforming it from a local issue of struggle against national oppression in Europe, into a general issue of liberation from imperialism for all oppressed nations, colonies, and semi-colonial regions. Second, it opened up vast possibilities and practical paths for their liberation, significantly promoting the liberation cause of oppressed nations in the West and East, and drawing them into the immense tide of victorious anti-imperialist struggle. Third, it thereby built a bridge between socialist West and enslaved East, and established a new revolutionary front against world imperialism, extending from the western proletariat, through the Russian revolution, to the oppressed nations of the East." Following this article, Stalin frequently elaborated on the theory that the revolution of colonial and semi-colonial regions had broken away from its old confines, and had become part of the proletariat socialist revolution. The clearest explanation is found in Stalin’s article "On the National Question Again", published on June 30, 1925, arguing with the nationalists of Yugoslavia at the time. From this, it can be seen that there are two types of world revolution. The first is the world revolution belonging to the bourgeois and capitalist categories. This period of world revolution has long passed, ending with the outbreak of the first imperialist world war in 1914, and particularly with the Russian October Revolution in 1917. Since then, the second type of world revolution has begun, namely the proletariat socialist world revolution. This revolution is led by the proletariat of capitalist countries, with oppressed nations in colonial and semi-colonial regions as its allies. Regardless of the class, party, or individuals participating in the revolution from among the oppressed nations – and whether they consciously understand this or not – as long as they oppose imperialism, their revolution becomes part of the proletariat socialist world revolution, and they themselves become allies of this world revolution. Faced with the rapid development of the Chinese revolution, Mao Zedong said: "Today, as the economic and political crisis of capitalism increasingly leads the world into the second world war; as the Soviet Union has reached the transitional period from socialism to communism, and is able to lead and assist the world proletariat and oppressed nations to fight against imperialist war and strike against capitalist reaction; as the proletariat in various capitalist countries is preparing to overthrow capitalism and realize socialism; as the Chinese proletariat, peasant class, intellectuals and other petty bourgeoisie, under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party, have already formed a great and independent political force. Should we expect the world significance of the Chinese Revolution to increase in such a period? I think we should. The Chinese Revolution is a great part of the world revolution. The first stage (which is divided into many small stages) of the Chinese Revolution, its social nature is a new type of bourgeois democratic revolution, not the proletariat socialist revolution, but it has long become a part of the proletariat socialist world revolution, and now it has become an even greater part of this world revolution, a great ally of this global revolution. The first step, the first stage of this revolution, will not and cannot establish a capitalist society dominated by the Chinese bourgeoisie, but will establish a new democratic society with the Chinese proletariat at the forefront and the combined dictatorship of various revolutionary classes in China, to complete its first stage. Then, it will develop into the second stage, to establish a socialist society in China. This is the most fundamental characteristic of the current Chinese revolution, this is the new revolutionary process of the past twenty years (starting from the May Fourth Movement in 1919), this is the vivid and specific content of the current Chinese revolution."



Since the May Fourth Movement in 1919, the leaders of the Chinese Revolution have been the proletariat.
Mao Zedong pointed out that before the May Fourth Movement in 1919, the political leaders of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution were the petty bourgeoisie and bourgeoisie of China (their intellectuals). After the May Fourth Movement, although the Chinese national bourgeoisie continued to participate in the revolution, the political leaders of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution no longer belonged to the Chinese bourgeoisie, but belonged to the Chinese proletariat. There are two aspects to the reasons: firstly, the preparatory stage of the Chinese democratic revolution has been underway since the Opium War. Secondly, the bourgeois-led Xinhai Revolution "marked the start of this revolution in a more complete sense". The Xinhai Revolution overthrew the monarchy, established the Republic, and made great contributions. However, it only ousted an emperor and hung a sign of "Republic", China remained under the oppression of imperialism and feudalism, and the revolutionary tasks of anti-imperialism and anti-feudalism had not been completed. The reason why China's bourgeoisie could not, like the bourgeoisie of Western Europe in history, especially the bourgeoisie of France, complete the mission given to them by history is mainly because "they were extremely weak economically and politically". This weakness was formed in the process of China becoming a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society. It is an "old problem brought from the mother's womb", a deficiency that is hard to overcome. Because of their weakness, they often compromise with the enemies of the revolution. The Chinese national bourgeoisie, "even in times of revolution, are unwilling to completely break away from imperialism, and they have close ties with rural rent exploitation. Therefore, they are unwilling and unable to completely overthrow imperialism, and are even less willing and less able to completely overthrow feudal forces." "Thus, the Chinese national bourgeoisie cannot solve the two basic issues and the two major fundamental tasks of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution." As for China's big bourgeoisie, represented by the Kuomintang, throughout the long period from 1927 to 1937, they colluded with imperialism and feudalism against the revolutionary people. During the Anti-Japanese War, some of them, represented by Wang Jingwei, openly surrendered to the Japanese invaders, "signifying a new betrayal by the big bourgeoisie". In summary, "on the one hand, the possibility of participating in the revolution, and on the other hand, the tendency to compromise with the enemies of the revolution, these are the dual aspects of the Chinese bourgeoisie". This dual nature is the fundamental reason why the Chinese bourgeoisie cannot lead the Chinese revolution to victory. However, on the other hand, the development of the revolutionary movement requires and always finds new leaders. Just as the Chinese bourgeois revolutionaries were defeated, the grown Chinese working class finally took the stage of Chinese political struggle after the May Fourth Movement. Although the Chinese working class is small in number and has its shortcomings, it is the most progressive, promising, and combative class in Chinese society. Relying on its organizational discipline, natural connection with the peasants, and especially the leadership of its vanguard—the Chinese Communist Party, the Chinese working class unhesitatingly undertook the heavy responsibility of leading the Chinese democratic revolution. Therefore, Mao Zedong said: "After the May Fourth Movement, although the Chinese national bourgeoisie continued to participate in the revolution, the political leaders of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution no longer belonged to the Chinese bourgeoisie, but belonged to the Chinese proletariat." It can be seen from this that the change of the leading class in the course of the Chinese democratic revolution is an inevitable development of history, and a choice made by history. In this way, the revolutions before and after the May Fourth Movement, although they were still bourgeois democratic revolutions, showed "important differences". After the May Fourth Movement, under the leadership of the Chinese proletariat and its party, and guided by Marxism-Leninism, the Chinese democratic revolution quickly displayed a new look. Not only in the breadth and depth of the revolution, but especially in the completeness and thoroughness of the revolution, it far surpassed that before the May Fourth Movement. Its political program, economic program, and cultural program all showed great differences from the former.



Not only does it accomplish the established tasks of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution, but it is also creating prerequisites and conditions for the next socialist revolution. In this sense, Mao Zedong referred to the democratic revolution before the May Fourth Movement as the "old general bourgeois democratic revolution," or the Old Democratic Revolution. The democratic revolution after the May Fourth Movement, he called the "new special bourgeois democratic revolution," or the New Democratic Revolution. Therefore, the change in dominant class is the most important change in the development of China's democratic revolution. Proletarian leadership becomes the main characteristic of the Chinese New Democratic Revolution. "The ultimate destiny of the Chinese revolution is not capitalism but socialism and communism. The question of the future of the Chinese revolution is also a question of the relationship between the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution and the proletarian socialist revolution, and the relationship between the current stage and future stage of the revolution. At the Chinese Communist Party's National Representatives Congress held in Yan'an in May 1937, Mao Zedong said in response to a question about the future of the Chinese revolution that the bourgeois democratic revolution and the socialist revolution were like "two essays, the first and the second, Only when the first part is done properly can the second part be done well. Determined leadership of the democratic revolution is a prerequisite for the victory of socialism." "We advocate for the transformation of the democratic revolution in the direction of socialism," but this must be when conditions are ripe. Mao Zedong refuted Trotskyism's theory of "permanent revolution" and tailism, adventurism, and revolutionary impetuousness, which had once caused harm to the Chinese revolution, and required CCP members to both recognize the future of the revolution and struggle hard for the tasks at hand. He said: "Today's efforts are aimed at the future's great goal. Without this great goal, one is not a Communist. However, if today's efforts slacken, one is not a Communist, either." Later, Mao Zedong further expounded this concept comprehensively and systematically in "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party" and "On New Democracy," brilliantly summarizing the relationship between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution, and providing a clear answer to the question of China's future.

Mao Zedong pointed out: Since the bourgeois democratic revolution in China at the present stage is not a general old-fashioned bourgeois democratic revolution, but a special new-style democratic revolution, a new democratic revolution, and China's revolution is taking place in the new international environment of the 1930s and 1940s, namely an international environment where socialism is surging and capitalism is declining, occurring during the Second World War and the era of revolution, then there is no doubt that the ultimate destination of China's revolution is not capitalism, but socialism and communism. Mao Zedong believed that since the Chinese revolution at the present stage is to change the current status of semi-colonial and semi-feudal societies, namely to struggle to complete a new democratic revolution, then after the victory of the revolution, due to the elimination of obstacles on the road to capitalist development, it is conceivable and not surprising that a capitalist economy would develop to a certain extent in Chinese society. The development of capitalism to a certain extent is the inevitable result of economically backward China after the victory of the democratic revolution. But this is only one aspect of the result of the Chinese revolution, not its whole. The complete result of the Chinese revolution is that on the one hand, there is the development of capitalist factors, and on the other hand, there is the development of socialist factors. What are these socialist factors? They are the growth of the weight of the proletariat and the Communist Party in national politics, the peasants, intellectuals, and petty bourgeoisie who either acknowledge or may acknowledge the leadership of the proletariat and the Communist Party. They are the state-owned economy of the Democratic Republic and the cooperative economy of the working people. All of this constitutes socialist factors. With favorable international conditions, the final outcome of China's bourgeois democratic revolution, avoiding the path of capitalism and realizing the path of socialism, would have great potential.



This shows that the relationship between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution, is also the relationship between the present and the future. Their differences reflect the particularity of contradictions, while their connections reflect the unity of contradictions. The Chinese revolution is composed of such complex contradictory phases. Faced with this situation, the Chinese Communist Party can "properly lead the Chinese revolution only by clearly recognizing the differences and connections between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution."
In short, in terms of the international front, the New Democratic Revolution is an ally of the socialist revolution of the world proletariat, not an ally of the world bourgeois revolution; in terms of revolutionary leadership, the New Democratic Revolution is led by the proletariat, not by the bourgeoisie; in terms of the future development of the revolution, the future of the New Democratic Revolution is socialism, not capitalism. These are the main characteristics of the Chinese New Democratic Revolution.

After the First Congress of the Party, both national crises and domestic political crises were deepening. The Party mobilized and led the workers’ movement to actively carry out anti-imperialist and anti-feudal struggles, leading to rapid development of the revolution. However, with divergent social views, and varying perspectives on "forceful unification," "Provincial autonomy," and "good person governance," it became urgent to clarify the basic issues such as the enemies, drivers, tasks and nature of the revolution. All of which are built on the correct understanding and analysis of the various classes in Chinese society.
The "Declaration of the Second National Congress of the Communist Party of China" by the Second Congress of the Party (hereinafter referred to as the "Declaration") preliminarily analyzed the bourgeoisie, peasants, petty bourgeoisie, and the proletariat.  
It pointed out that the bourgeoisie, in order to avoid economic oppression from imperialism and feudal military forces, will surely rise up against imperialism. Among the peasants, there are three parts: the affluent peasant landlords, small farmers who farm independently, and tenant farmers and farm workers. The first type is the minority. While the second and the third types constitute at least 95%. They are oppressed and exploited, so they must rise up in revolution—the “most important factor” of the revolution.
The Second Congress of the Party identified the feudal warlords and imperialism as enemies of the revolution, and drew the proletariat, peasants, petty bourgeoisie, and bourgeoisie to the side of the revolutionary forces. It clearly proposed to overthrow the oppression of imperialism and put down the political rule of the warlords, thereby formulating the Party's democratic revolutionary program. Therefore, for the first time, it clearly defined the objects, power, task, and nature of the revolution among various divergent views.
The Third Congress of the Party made important decisions about cooperation between the national and communist parties in the form of the "Resolution of the Third National Congress of the Communist Party of China" (hereinafter referred to as the "Resolution"). Based on the analysis of the economic and political conditions of society and the analysis of peasants and the working class, it focused on analyzing the bourgeoisie and the Kuomintang: First, it believed that there is a contradiction between the bourgeoisie and imperialism and warlords. In the “Resolution”, the bourgeoisie was divided into big businessmen (financial magnates) and the middle class, pointing out that big businessmen and bureaucrats are also looting by taking advantage of the fire. On the other hand, the middle class has been robbed by imperialism, occupying the market, taking away raw materials, and almost cutting off the "possibility of development" of large industries in China, and has caused its business to "develop anomalously"...



The rule over China is by "feudal warlords, not the bourgeoisie," and, "most of the middle class" suffer from political oppression. Therefore, "there must be inevitable conflicts with international imperialism and warlordism." Secondly, among the existing parties in China, only the Kuomintang can relatively be considered a party of national revolution. Given the current status of various social classes, it is difficult to establish a larger and more revolutionary party than the Kuomintang. Thirdly, however, the bourgeoisie tends to "live in peace with their situation" and "depends on the imperialist powers or warlords, easily compromising and betraying the common people." The Kuomintang also harbors illusions about imperialism and warlords, focusing all its efforts on military actions and disconnecting from the masses. The "Resolution" analyzes not only the revolutionary side of the bourgeoisie and the Kuomintang, but also the initial analysis of their compromise and non-revolution. Based on this, a decision is made to cooperate with the Kuomintang, thus defining the party's basic strategic policy for the Democratic Revolution. Although the "Resolution" was influenced by the Rightist thinking of the Communist International and Chen Duxiu, considering the Kuomintang as the "central force" and "leader" of revolution, there was a right-leaning misconception on the issue of revolutionary leaders, but the third congress of the Chinese Communist Party established the strategic policy of the united front for revolution, indicating that the party has made a new leap in understanding.

During this stage, Chen Duxiu wrote "On State-building" (September 1922), "Bourgeois Revolution and Revolutionary Bourgeoisie" (April 1923), "Chinese National Revolution and Various Social Classes" (December 1923), which are important components of the party's class analysis and understanding during this period. These three articles have three characteristics in their analysis of different social classes: Firstly, they point out that imperialism and feudal warlords are always the enemies of revolution. Secondly, the bourgeoisie is divided into three parts: the revolutionary bourgeoisie, the counter-revolutionary bourgeoisie, and the non-revolutionary bourgeoisie. It states that the emerging entrepreneurs support the revolution because the development of their businesses is hindered by imperialism and warlords; the bureaucratic bourgeoisie are against the revolution because they are dependent on imperialism and warlords; small business owners, due to their small scale, are destabilized by competition, have an unstable living situation, and tend to be neutral or lean towards revolution. This is the second characteristic. Analysis of farmers and the working class includes both advantages and disadvantages. It is pointed out that peasants account for the majority of the Chinese population, suffer from the plundering of imperialism and the exploitation of feudal gentry, and are potentially a great force for revolution. Without the participation of the peasants, the Democratic Revolution cannot be successful. However, peasants are dispersed, unorganized, culturally backward, and conservative. They are against landlords, "but cannot exceed the psychology of transferring private ownership from landlords to their own," which is a major reason why peasants find it difficult to join the revolution. The working class in the democratic revolution is an "important element," their "revolutionary tendency is greater than the bourgeoisie," and the few workers who truly have political consciousness are the bravest vanguards of the revolution. But a portion of the workers' thoughts are still immersed in clan society, with heavy regional ideas and superstitions. The number of politically conscious workers are "really too small." If the working class only conducts simple economic struggles, "there is no significant meaning," only the direct political struggle against imperialism and warlords has serious implications. This is the third characteristic. Chen Duxiu's analyses have played a certain positive role in the party's analysis of various social classes.

However, Chen Duxiu's class analysis contains some rightist errors.



This mainly shows the wavering, compromise, non-revolutionary and even counter-revolutionary side of the emerging bourgeoisie, with insufficient analysis and extremely insufficient affirmation of the advantages and role of the working class. Therefore, from a general estimate, it is mistakenly believed that the power of the bourgeoisie is greater than that of the proletariat, and the working class and peasants are not as revolutionary as the bourgeoisie. The leaders of the National Revolution are not the proletariat but the bourgeoisie, hence there is an erroneous conclusion of the "second revolution theory". This has led to a significant ideological root of the error of rightist opportunism committed by Chen Duxiu and others.

From the above, we can see that the party has begun to analyze all classes of society. On the basis of preliminary understanding of the economic status and political attitudes of each class, it has clearly defined the boundaries of the revolutionary object and the revolutionary force, and defined the party's democratic revolutionary program and strategic guidelines. However, it underestimated the working class and the peasants, and overestimated the bourgeoisie. Therefore, it still did not fully understand the problem of friends, and there was a right-wing view on the issue of revolutionary leaders.

Secondly, the preliminary development of the Party's class analysis

The establishment of cooperation between the KMT and the Communist Party has pushed the revolution into a new stage of development. In the united front, the class relationship between the proletariats and the bourgeoisie has come to the fore. The fundamental issue of this relationship lies in who is the leader of the revolution. On this issue, the Chinese Communist Party had not had a correct understanding in the past, and there are now two erroneous tendencies: the "left" tendency believes that the proletarian party should carry out a Soviet-style proletarian revolution and it is not necessary to lead the bourgeois democratic revolution. The "right" tendency believes that the bourgeois democratic revolution should be led by the bourgeoisie. In fact, both of them recognize the bourgeoisie as the leader of the National Revolution. To correct these two erroneous understandings, define the leading position of the proletariat in the democratic revolution, and the party has conducted a large amount of class analysis.

Deng Zhongxia wrote two articles in December 26, 1923 and November 1924 respectively, "China's Workers Condition and the Policy of Our Movement" and "The Power of China's Working Class", which focused on the analysis of the working class. The articles point out that the emergence and development of modern industry in China and the growth of the working class demonstrate the historical position of the working class and new methods of production. "China's proletariat has, due to the progress of industry in the past thirty to forty years, formed a strong and great team. It turned its head and 'betrayed' imperialism and counterattacked". The power of the proletariat, can now be "tested", and it will not be difficult to "predict" in the future, "it is ultimately the greatest force in the Chinese revolution." No one can deny its "leadership position". This is the first point. The advantages of the working class are pointed out, as well as its disadvantages, but the revolutionary nature of the working class is emphasized. Deng Zhongxia pointed out: Chinese workers are cheap labor for foreign capital, work for long hours, "cannot see the sun", low wages, average income "just a few cents", "work like a horse" for others. Therefore, the awakening of the working class is determined by its oppressed and plundered status, "and it certainly cannot be prevented from awakening because of its kinship and reasoning." This is the second point. The historical role of the working class is fully affirmed by summing up the lessons from the failure of the "2.7" big strike. Deng Zhongxia pointed out: "After the failure of the '2.7' strike, I have said this 'no matter in the democratic revolution or the social revolution, the working masses occupy the position of the main force', 'we should be very optimistic.'"



He criticized those who excessively doubt the power of the working class, pointing out: "You think this path is impassable due to minor setbacks, and seek other ways. I fear that you may not succeed even if you revolutionize for ten thousand years." This was his third point. 
Through an analysis of the proletariat, Deng Zhongxia clearly raised the issue of the proletarian's leadership position in the revolution, arguing: "The leader of China's future social revolution will undoubtedly be the proletariat, as is the leader of the present Nationalist Revolution. Only it is fit to be the leader of the Nationalist Revolution." In December 1924, Peng Shuzhi published an article titled "Who is the leader of the Chinese Nationalist Revolution?" The essay divides the bourgeoisie into three sections: banking bourgeoisie, commercial bourgeoisie, and industrial bourgeoisie. He pointed out that the banking bourgeoisie are "naturally reactionary." Among the commercial bourgeoisie, the comprador class is "a fascist against the nationalist revolution," and the native bourgeoisie, under various oppressions of imperialism and various devastations of the military, need revolution, but "absolutely cannot lead other classes." 
The industrial bourgeoisie clashes significantly with imperialist interests economically and is hindered in its development by the military, which "necessitates revolution”, but has a "weak economic base," and is "too weak." Therefore, "the reactionary element predominates among the Chinese bourgeoisie." "It would indeed be a difficult task to expect the bourgeoisie to participate in a nationalist revolution, let alone hope them to lead one. It's a pipe dream." Next, the working class and the peasants were analyzed. The article asserted that the working class, more directly oppressed and exploited by imperialism and the military than any other class, therefore, has a clearer and deeper understanding of imperialism and the military forces. This is the only realistic condition and the underlying reason why the working class “can take up the leadership of the Nationalist Revolution in China." "The Chinese working class is the natural leader of the national revolution." 
The peasants need a revolution, but they can only be led by other classes. The article believes that the proletariat, not the bourgeoisie, is the leader of the National Revolution, which is correct. However, it is a mistake to automatically assume that the working class naturally occupies a leading position in the revolution and that the bourgeoisie cannot naturally become revolutionary leaders, negating the struggle between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie for the leadership and easing vigilance against the bourgeoisie's attempt to take over the leadership of the revolution, reveling in blind optimism. Such “natural theory” in the issue of revolutionary leadership is erroneous. In December 1924, Chen Duxiu also published an article titled "The Lessons Learned from the National Movement in the Past 27 Years," pointing out: the proletariat is the most uncompromising revolutionary class; not only in the social revolution is it the main force, but also in the nationalist revolution, it also plays a role as a "supervisor of the war". 
The articles by Deng Zhongxia, Peng Shuzhi, Chen Duxiu, and others, indicate that more people in the Chinese Communist Party are carrying out class analysis. Moreover, their articles have one thing in common, that is, it is clearly posited that the leader of the democratic revolution is not the bourgeoisie, but the proletariat. This provides a broad ideological basis for the Fourth Congress of the Party to clearly put forward the "leadership position of the proletariat." In January 1925, the Fourth Congress of the Party made a "decision on the national revolutionary movement," and through an analysis of all classes in society, for the first time in the party's resolution, it clearly raised the key issue of "the leading position of the proletariat." Thus, it clarified the leading role in the revolution that was not clarified by the second and third congresses of the party, and corrected the wrong understanding of the third congress of the Communist Party on this issue.
During this stage of development, the party, through an analysis of all classes in society, clarified the issue of who is the leader of the revolution. This is another significant development based on the clear identification of the objects and dynamics of the revolution, indicating the initial formation of the party's basic ideas of the New Democratic Revolution. However, at this time, the party has not yet analyzed the peasant issue as the central issue of the revolution.



At the same time, there is no correct understanding of the bourgeoisie. In the initial stage, the entire bourgeoisie is considered revolutionary, but at this stage, the bourgeoisie is generally considered unable to revolutionize. For instance, Deng Zhongxia's article believes that "the bourgeoisie cannot revolutionize," and Peng Shuzhi's article finds it difficult for the bourgeoisie to participate in the revolution. The "Fourth Resolution" considers that the bourgeoisie still cannot join the revolution. This indicates that the Party does not yet have a correct understanding of the revolutionary friends.



After the Party's Fourth Congress, the revolution developed rapidly, and the peasant movement in Hunan and Guangdong rose quickly, which was inspiring. However, following the death of Sun Yat-sen, the Kuomintang was divided, and the right-wing began to plot to seize the revolutionary leadership. This urgently required the Party to clarify the situation of friends and adhere to the spirit of the proletariat's revolutionary leadership at the Fourth Congress. The Party's analysis of all social classes has entered a more complete and scientific stage. From February to June 925, Qu Qiubai published three articles, further clarifying the problems of the proletarian leadership position in the democratic revolution and implementing the spirit of the Fourth Congress. In May 925, Deng Zhongxia made a speech and "answers" at the Chinese National General Workers' Welcome Nationalist Party's Second National Representative Conference. Deng's articles and speeches raised the issue of "worker-peasant alliance". He pointed out that the peasants were the workers' "natural allies", and without the unity with the peasants, it would be impossible to achieve the leading role in the national revolution. In December 925, Li Dazhao released an article analyzing the reasons for the oppression and exploitation of the peasants, pointing out that the peasants and workers must unite to overthrow the rule of imperialism and the warlord government.

The articles of Qu Qiubai, Deng Zhongxia, Li Dazhao et al., while emphasizing the proletarian leadership position's concept, initially acknowledged the basic problem of "peasants are the central issue in realizing the proletarian revolutionary leadership". This is a new beginning for the Party's understanding of revolutionary friends. However, in March 1926, Mao Zedong's analysis of all social classes in China developed this understanding to a new level. The main features are: firstly, the bourgeoisie is clearly divided into the comprador class and the middle class, clarifying the past ambiguous concepts and views. The article lists the comprador class, warlords, bureaucrats, and landlord class as the representatives of the most reactionary and backward production relations, and the comprador class is an undeniable reactionary. For the first time, the article clarified that the middle class is the national bourgeoisie. 

Secondly, it conducted an extremely detailed analysis of the petty bourgeoisie. The article pointed out that the petty bourgeoisie includes owner cultivators, handicraft masters, the small intellectual class, and small businessmen. This small private owner class, which is large in number and revolutionary, is the closest friend of the proletariat, and it is necessary to unite with them and lead them to revolution.

Thirdly, it made a scientific analysis of the peasants.



The article classifies semi-self-sufficient farmers, poor farmers, small artisans, shop assistants, and peddlers as the semi-proletariat. It conducts a profound analysis of the economic status and political attitudes of semi-subsistence and poor farmers, pointing out that "the so-called peasant problem is mainly their problem." This is because poor farmers and semi-self-sufficient farmers are the largest group in rural areas. Considering the issue of peasants, their problems must be considered first, they are the main targets of the feudal rent and usury exploitation of the landlord class. Hence, they are the main force in rural areas opposing feudal forces. Their revolutionary nature is superior to that of self-sufficient farmers. Especially the poor farmers, who are extremely receptive to revolutionary propaganda. They constitute the most basic force to realize the leadership of the proletariat revolution. Mao Zedong's analysis of semi-self-sufficient and poor farmers, pointing out that they are the closest friends, actually indicated the center of the party's consideration of the peasant issue, mainly the issue of poor and semi-self farmers. Mao Zedong's high degree of observation and scientific analysis methods for the peasant issue are a remarkable embodiment of his combination of Marxism-Leninism and the actual situation of China's revolution.

Once the issues concerning the bourgeoisie, the petty bourgeoisie, and the peasants have been clarified, the revolutionary friend problem can be readily understood. This is a new contribution after the party's Second and Fourth National Congresses clearly identified revolutionary enemies and leaders.

During the Land Revolution War, faced with a more complex class struggle situation and context, the Chinese Communists represented by Mao Zedong made further divisions on the class relationships in Chinese society. In October 1933, in the document "How to Analyze Rural Classes," Mao Zedong set scientific division criteria for five classes: landlords, rich peasants, middle peasants, poor peasants, and workers (including farm workers). After arriving in northern Shaanxi, the Chinese Communist Party summarized historical lessons and conducted a more systematic analysis of the class relationships in Chinese society. In the article "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party," Mao Zedong conducted a comprehensive analysis of various types of petty bourgeoisie, the peasant class, the proletariat, and the lumpen proletariat beyond the landlord class and the bourgeoisie. These scientific analyses provide a scientific basis for formulating the party's line, policy, and tactics, and elevate the party's analysis of Chinese social classes to a new, scientific level.



The general line is a concentrated summary of the party's strategic goals, main tasks and the ways and means to achieve these goals and tasks during a certain historical stage, that is, the basic line. It embodies the party's stance and is the basic principle of the party's actions. It overlooks the whole situation and determines the direction, goals and course of all the party's work. Therefore, the general line is the lifeblood of the party and plays a major role in unifying the thoughts and actions of the whole party and uniting all ethnic groups across the country. Formulating the party's general line according to the features of the era and the tasks of the party in each stage is an important method of leading the revolution by the Chinese Communists represented by Mao Zedong.



The general line and overall policy of the Communist Party of China in the democratic revolution stage is: "A revolution led by the proletariat, for the masses, against imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism." This general line was formed after long-term theoretical exploration and continuous practice of revolutionary struggles, and it essentially took shape during the War of Resistance Against Japan. It was finally fully formed after further supplementation and development during the period of the Liberation War. It could be said that the process of the formation of the party's general line of democratic revolution was an understanding of the three elements of the general line of democratic revolution - revolutionary leadership, revolutionary dynamics, and revolutionary targets. It was also a process where the Communist Party of China went from knowing very little to knowing more about China's national conditions and Marxist-Leninist theories, until they had a complete and unified understanding in theory and practice. This process also reflected the difficult development of the democratic revolution in China until it achieved national victory.

At the founding of the Party and the National Revolution period, the members of the Communist Party of China had already made preliminary exploration of the basic issues of China's modern national democratic revolution, forming the basic ideas of a new democratic revolution. During the Land Revolution War, the Party continued to explore the fundamental questions of what kind of revolution the Chinese Revolution is and how to carry out this revolution, achieving significant progress, and enriched the theory of the New Democratic Revolution with the revolutionary path theory of "surrounding cities from the rural areas, and seizing power by armed force." During the War of Resistance Against Japan, the Party summarized and expanded upon the theory of New Democratic Revolution in a comprehensive and multi-faceted several ways, on the basis of systematically summarizing the experiences and lessons since its founding. In many of his works during this period, Mao Zedong analyzed deeply basic issues like the domestic and international environment of the Chinese revolution, the nature of Chinese society, and more. He also comprehensively detailed on the basis of this the distinctive historical characteristics of the New Democratic Revolution and the developmental laws of Chinese revolution, proposing the theory, program, line, and set of principles and policies of the New Democratic Revolution. He answered creatively and completely major questions like what kind of revolution the Chinese revolution is and how to carry out the revolution.

In "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party", Mao Zedong provided a comprehensive and deep discussion of the objectives, tasks, nature, and prospects of the New Democratic Revolution, from both theoretical and practical perspectives, and definitively stated: "The so-called New Democratic Revolution is the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal mass revolution under proletarian leadership." This is the first expression of the overall line of the New Democratic Revolution. After the victory of the War of Resistance Against Japan, the domestic class contradictions rose to become the main contradiction, and correctly understanding the nature of Chiang Kai-shek's government and its economic foundation became an urgent question for the Party to resolve. After deep analysis of its political nature and economic foundation, Mao Zedong referred to the colossal capital burgeoning under the state power of Chiang Kai-shek and the "Four Big Families" as "bureaucrat capital," and the class in control of bureaucrat capital as "bureaucrat bourgeoisie." As bureaucrat capitalism is characterized by sophistication, feudal nature, and monopoly, hence, "The task of the New Democratic Revolution is not only to abolish the special privileges of imperialism in China, but also to eradicate the exploitation and oppression of the landlord class and bureaucrat bourgeoisie (big bourgeoisie) domestically." In April 1948, in his "Speech at the Cadre Meeting in Jin-Sui", Mao Zedong clearly included bureaucrat capitalism, along with imperialism and feudalism, as targets of the Chinese revolution, stating: "The New Democratic Revolution is not any other revolution, it can only and must be a revolution led by the proletariat, for the masses, against imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism." This is the current historical stage's general line and overall policy of the Communist Party of China. This general line properly resolved a series of basic questions about the new democratic revolution, such as the right to leadership, the dynamics of the revolution, the targets of the revolution, the tasks of the revolution, the nature of the revolution, and the future of the revolution. It enriched and developed the revolutionary theory of Marxism-Leninism.



Why does the Communist Party of China lead the people in a democratic revolution against imperialism and feudalism? What is the fundamental purpose of the New Democratic Revolution led by the Party? This is another important question that must be correctly answered while resolving what kind of revolution the Chinese revolution is, and how the revolution takes place. As the vanguard of the Chinese working class, the birth of the Communist Party of China is the requirement of the development of China's advanced productive forces, and it took to the historical stage in the capacity of representing China's advanced productive forces. The New Democratic Revolution led by the Communist Party of China aims to change the feudal production relationships of compradors, as well as the corrupt superstructure in politics, fundamentally liberating the restrained productive forces. To this end, Mao Zedong has made many insightful discussions.

In March 1944, when Mao Zedong spoke at a propaganda work meeting held by the Propaganda Committee of the CPC Central Committee, he emphasized to cadres that they must have a correct understanding of the purpose of the revolution. He pointed out that many comrades put politics and military first, which is correct, because without defeating the enemy, there is no room for negotiation. However, we must not forget that the purpose of political and military affairs is to liberate and develop productive forces. Mao Zedong said: The power of politics and military is to overthrow the forces that hinder the development of productive forces; the purpose of overthrowing the forces that hinder the development of productive forces is to liberate productive forces and develop the economy. The economy is the basis of politics and military, and politics and military are the superstructure. The foundation is the economy, and the fundamental purpose is also to develop the economy. Politics and military are put first because without them, productive forces cannot be liberated, and there is no possibility to discuss other issues. Here, Mao Zedong deeply analyzed the relationship between politics, military, and economy, and clarified the fundamental purpose of the New Democratic Revolution led by the Communist Party of China.

In April 1945, in the political report of the Seventh National Congress of the Communist Party of China, Mao Zedong clearly proposed that the fundamental criterion for judging the quality of a political party is the criterion of productive forces. He pointed out: "The good or bad of the policy and practice of all political parties in China, and their role among the Chinese people, ultimately depends on whether they are helpful to the development of the people's productive forces and the size of their help. It depends on whether they are restraining productive forces or liberating productive forces. To eliminate Japanese invaders, implement land reforms, liberate farmers, develop modern industry, and establish an independent, free, democratic, united, and strong New China, only all of these can liberate China's social productive forces and be welcomed by the Chinese people."

In December 1947, Mao Zedong made it clearer in "The Current Situation and Our Tasks" that the purpose of the revolution is to liberate productive forces. He said that the most fundamental task of the New Democratic Revolution is to "change the feudal production relationships of compradors and liberate the restrained productive forces".

In summary, during the New Democratic Revolution, the understanding and handling of the relationship between politics, military, and economy, the purpose of the revolution, and the standard for judging the quality of political parties by the Communist Party of China was correct. In semi-colonial and semi-feudal China, only by first carrying out the New Democratic Revolution, overthrowing the rule of imperialism and feudalism, can the restrained productive forces be fundamentally liberated and production be developed. Throughout the New Democratic Revolution, the Communist Party of China embodied and practiced the requirements of the development of advanced productive forces with such a concept.



The victory of the revolution depends on the correctness of the revolutionary line and strategy. The basis of the general line lies in a clear understanding of the national conditions, and the basis of the strategy lies in distinguishing friends from enemies. To distinguish friends from enemies is the primary issue of the Chinese revolution. Who is the object of the Chinese revolution? This is determined by the nature, characteristics, and main contradictions of modern Chinese society.



Since modern China was a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, the main contradictions in this society were those between imperialism and the Chinese nation and between feudalism and the masses. Therefore, the targets of the Chinese revolution were "imperialism and feudalism," along with bureaucratic capitalism. 

Mao Zedong pointed out: who are our enemies? Who are our friends? If one cannot distinguish between enemies and friends, they cannot be a revolutionary. However, distinguishing between enemies and friends is not straightforward. The limited success of the Chinese revolution after thirty years was not due to a wrong purpose, but a faulty strategy. This wrong strategy was the inability to unite real friends for the assault on real enemies. This was because the revolutionaries had not identified who their enemies and friends were. After the Opium War, the Chinese people's struggle against imperialism and feudalism never ceased. The fundamental reasons for repeated failures within these struggles were the lack of scientific theory, the failure to mobilize masses, particularly the workers and peasants, and the failure to identify the objects of revolution, the friends of the revolution, and to formulate correct strategies.

Even though the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom had a dual nature of being anti-feudal and anti-invasion, it could not theoretically justify this, so it ultimately fell deeply into the mire of feudalism. The slogan and actions of the Boxers "Support the Qing, Destroy the foreigners" show that the peasants didn't understand the relationship between the local feudalists and foreign invaders. The fact that the bourgeois reformers attempted to promote reform by relying on the feudal emperor, with the assistance and support of British and American imperialism, demonstrates the reformers' lack of understanding of the nature of feudalism and the Western powers. The 1911 Revolution overthrew the Qing government, but the fruits of the revolution ultimately fell into the hands of Yuan Shikai. The bourgeois revolutionaries lacked both a clear stance against imperialism and a thorough stance against feudalism, often deliberately aligning with warlords to oppose other warlords; they could not articulate the real targets of struggle for the Chinese people.

After the establishment of the Communist Party of China, the second congress of the Communist Party based on its understanding of the current situation in China, for the first time clearly stated the minimum program of the party is against imperialism, against feudal warlord rule, and to carry out a democratic revolution. This defined the goals of revolution that had not been clarified since the modern era, leading the way for the Chinese revolution. This clear stance against imperialism and feudalism marked the first valuable step that the Communist Party of China took in the course of integrating Marxism into Chinese contexts.

Firstly, imperialism was the primary target of modern China's national democratic revolution. Why was imperialism the main target of the Chinese revolution?

Firstly, imperialism directly hindered China's economic development and political progress. Modern China was bullied by all the imperialist nations of different sizes in the world. Several powerful countries carved spheres of influence in China, and some even attempted to monopolize China. China was subject to insult, harm, and dismemberment. The objective of the imperial powers invading China was not to change feudal China into capitalist China, but to turn China into their colony or semi-colony.



Although imperialism did not annihilate China, and China remained semi-independent, imperialism was essentially the ruler of China. Secondly, imperialism colluded with Chinese feudalism to oppress the Chinese people. When imperialism comes to a backward country, it always preserves the backward forces of this country, unwilling to casually discard it, change it, in order to facilitate its aggression and oppression. The seventy years before modern China was ruled by the Qing Dynasty, imperialism turned the Qing Dynasty into a tamed tool utilised by it. After the demise of the Qing Dynasty, it supported one military bureaucrat after another representing the interest of the landlord class and comprador bureaucratic capital. The feudal forces and their superstructure could continue to exist due to the maintenance of imperialism.

Lastly, the Chinese people's opposition to imperialism is also to rid the power behind Chinese feudalism, to complete the democratic revolution. In modern China, there is a relationship of interdependence and tight connection between imperialism and feudalism. Imperialism uses the Chinese feudal forces as the foundation for its bullying and oppression of China, and the Chinese feudal forces use imperialism as their backing. Thus, on the political stage of China, those who often perform in the foreground are the reactionary warlords and politicians, and those who manipulate behind the scenes are the imperialist powers. Under such circumstances, only by undergoing an anti-imperialist national revolution can the Chinese people finally rid themselves of the shackles of the feudal system, and the democratic revolution can be thorough.

Opposing imperialism and striving for the independence of the Chinese nation is the fundamental premise to solve the "salvation" and "development" issues of modern China, as well as the primary task. It will not be an easy task to defeat the already ruling imperialist forces in China on a very backward social foundation. But history has proven that only through such means can China's miserable fate be changed. That is to say, only by first striving for the liberation of the nation and the independence of the country, can we talk about the construction of modern political, economic, and cultural systems.

Opposing imperialism is also a long-term task throughout the whole process of the New Democratic Revolution. However, due to different situations and main objects of struggle at different stages, the main opposition to which imperialism differs as well. Also, because of the different forms of imperialist aggression and oppression of China at various stages, the form of the Chinese people's opposition to imperialism is also different. When imperialism launches an invasion of China, the Chinese people would oppose imperialism in the form of a national war, such as the Anti-Japanese War. When imperialism invades China by non-armed methods such as politics, economics, and culture, domestic feudal warlords and reactionary politicians often form an alliance with imperialism to oppress the people together. In such a situation, the Chinese revolution generally adopts the form of a civil war to oppose the alliance of imperialism and the feudal class, and indirectly opposes imperialism while struggling against feudal forces, such as the National Revolution, the Land Revolution, and the National Liberation War, etc.

Secondly, feudalism is another main target of the modern Chinese democratic revolution. The reason why feudalism is another main target of the Chinese revolution is that the feudal exploitation system is the main pillar of imperialist rule in China and the social basis for the autocratic rule by feudal warlords. Feudal rule is the main obstacle to the economic modernization and political democratization of modern China and a roadblock on the way forward for the Chinese nation.



In modern China, the landlord class controlled the grassroots government in the vast rural areas, acting as officials at all levels of government. Many officials, after exploiting the people, went to the countryside to buy land and became emerging landlords. Imperialism stabilized its footing in China by supporting and nurturing feudal reactionary regimes, gaining maximum benefits. The feudal reactionary regime, in turn, depended on the landlord class for nationwide rule. This was true for both the Beiyang warlords and the newly emerging KMT warlords.

In China's modern economic life, feudal economy dominated. The feudal exploitation system was premised on landlords owning land and exploiting peasants' surplus and even necessary labor. In old China, landlords and wealthy farmers, who made up less than 10% of the rural population, owned 70% to 80% of the land. In contrast, the poor peasants, farm laborers, middle peasants, and other laborers, who made up over 90% of the rural population, only owned 20% to 30% of the total land. The feudal landlord class exploited by renting land to peasants and charging high rents. This rent exploitation not only occupied all the peasants' surplus labor but also a large part of their necessary labor. In addition to the cruel exploitation of rents, peasants were also oppressed by commercial capital, usury, and excessive taxes levied by reactionary governments at all levels. These conditions led to a very low level of productive forces in China and extremely poor living conditions for the people. Therefore, to achieve economic modernization and political democratization in China, feudalism must be opposed. To oppose feudalism fundamentally means to eliminate the feudal exploitation system with the primary characteristic of landlord land ownership economically and to overthrow the autocratic rule of feudal warlords —— the concentrated representatives of imperialism's proxies and landlord comprador forces, politically. 

Like opposing imperialism, opposing feudalism also runs through the entire course of the New Democratic Revolution, although it has different specific content and forms in different periods. During the Great Revolution, people opposed the rule of the Beiyang warlords, and the party mobilized peasants to fight against landlords and divide the land. After the failure of the Great Revolution, the party raised the banner of land revolution, launched a vigorous land revolution war, and addressed the core and substantive issues of feudalism —— abolishing the land ownership system of the feudal landlord class. During the Anti-Japanese War, the party timely changed the policy of confiscating the land of the landlord class to a policy of reducing rent and interest, in accordance with the changes in the primary contradictions within the country and the needs of the united front. After the Liberation War, the party implemented a land system that abolished feudal and semi-feudal exploitation and allowed those who work the land to own it, and it ultimately overthrew the feudal superstructure in China, achieving a decisive victory against feudalism.

In short, the modern Chinese revolution has dual characteristics of anti-imperialism and anti-feudalism. The two aspects are interlinked. If the rule of imperialism is not overthrown, the rule of the feudal landlord class cannot be eliminated; conversely, if the rule of the feudal landlord class is not eliminated, the foundation of imperialistic rule in China is not uprooted, the broad masses of peasants cannot be mobilized to form a powerful force for the Chinese revolution to overthrow imperialistic rule. Therefore, "the two basic tasks of national revolution and democratic revolution are distinct yet unified."



Thirdly, bureaucratic capitalism is also the target of China's New Democratic Revolution. Since modern times, the development of capitalism in China has presented two parts with both strict distinctions and certain connections: one is bureaucratic capitalism; the other is national capitalism. Correspondingly, the bourgeoisie in modern China is also divided into two parts: one is the bureaucratic bourgeoisie (also known as the big bourgeoisie, comprador class); the other is the national bourgeoisie (also known as the middle bourgeoisie, middle class). Bureaucratic capitalism and the bureaucratic bourgeoisie are the targets of the New Democratic Revolution, national capitalism has always been protected in the process of the New Democratic Revolution, and the national bourgeoisie is one of the driving forces of the New Democratic Revolution. Therefore, the Chinese New Democratic Revolution does not generally oppose capitalism and the bourgeoisie. Conversely, it allows and encourages the development of national capitalism, and the capitalism it opposes is only bureaucratic capitalism. The presence of two parts in modern Chinese capitalism and bourgeoisie is entirely a result of imperialist aggression against China, a phenomenon unique to a semi-colonial semi-feudal society.
Opposing bureaucratic capitalism is not because it is capitalism, but because bureaucratic capitalism is an amalgamation of imperialism with the Chinese feudal landlord class and the old rich peasantry, relying on state power to develop into a comprador, feudal state monopoly capitalism. This kind of state monopoly capitalism is not developed on the basis of free capitalism, but is created by the political representatives of large landlords and compradors through super-economic plundering, characterized by comprador, feudal, and state monopolistic traits. It is the economic foundation of the reactionary regime of Chiang Kai-shek, an important factor impeding the development of productive forces in modern China. Therefore, confiscating bureaucratic capital and eliminating the bureaucratic bourgeoisie has become one of the basic content of the New Democratic Revolution.

The core issue of the New Democratic Revolution is the issue of proletarian leadership. Whether the leadership of the revolution is in the hands of the bourgeoisie or in the hands of the proletariat is the fundamental sign distinguishing the new and old democratic revolutions, and the touchstone to measure the correctness of the Party's line. Right-leaning is to give up leadership, "left-leaning" is empty-headed leadership. Whether it is "left-leaning" or right-leaning, there are mistakes in leadership. Therefore, this issue is very important, it relates to the future of the revolution, and determines the success or failure of the revolution.
Generally speaking, the bourgeois democratic revolution should be led by the bourgeoisie. However, the Chinese revolution has taken place in a special era and under special societal national conditions, so who should lead the revolution has become a new problem. 
As the historical facts show, the leadership of the Chinese revolution has undergone a transformation process. Since the emergence and development of Chinese national capitalism in the 1870s, representatives of the bourgeoisie have indeed initiated waves of revolution and led significant struggles such as the Xinhai Revolution.



At that time, the proletariat was small in number and politically immature, and had not yet formed an independent class force, participating in revolution only as followers of the bourgeoisie. This situation changed with the May Fourth Movement. In this movement, the working class demonstrated enormous political enthusiasm and maturity, played a very important role, and began to appear on China's political stage as an independent class force. After the birth of the Communist Party of China, the leadership of the Chinese revolution gradually transferred from the bourgeoisie to the proletariat.

From the perspective of ideological understanding, the issue of leadership in the Chinese revolution also underwent a process of development. In articles published between 1923 and 1924, both Qu Qiubai and Deng Zhongxia emphasized that the proletariat must occupy a prominent position in the National Revolution and increasingly assume leadership of the revolution. The Fourth National Congress of the CPC also raised the issue of the proletariat's leadership in the democratic revolution. However, the praxis of the next few years showed that the CPC's understanding of the leadership of the revolution had not really been resolved. In 1925, Mao Zedong, in his analysis of the social classes in China, proposed that the proletariat was the leading class of the revolution; by the Autumn Harvest Uprising in 1927, Mao Zedong's thought on the leadership of the proletariat in the Chinese revolution was further solidified; and by the late 1930s, in the New Democratic Revolution theory, Mao Zedong's theoretical elaboration on the proletariat's leadership in revolution became a significant part.

The Chinese bourgeoisie could not lead the bourgeois democratic revolution in China because the changes in the era and China's nationality had determined that the Chinese bourgeoisie lacks the capability to lead a bourgeois democratic revolution. The Chinese bourgeoisie is not like the Western bourgeoisie and does not have a thorough anti-feudalist character - it has a dual nature. This characteristic determines that the bourgeoisie's attitude toward the revolution is not stable or resolute.
