Even in times of revolution, they are not willing to fully sever their ties with imperialism and they have close connections with the land rent exploitation in rural areas. As a result, they are neither willing nor capable of overthrowing imperialism or feudal forces. Hence, the two fundamental issues and two major tasks of the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution could not be solved by the Chinese national bourgeoisie. This claim is proven by the failure of the Hundred Days' Reform and the Xinhai Revolution. The Chinese revolution objectively required a new leading class and a new path.

The Chinese proletariat, due to its inherent characteristics, was able to shoulder the responsibility of leading the revolution in China. Although the Chinese proletariat was less numerous compared to peasants, younger than the proletariat in capitalist countries, and had a lower cultural standard than the bourgeoisie - with prevalent small producer consciousness - it represented the advanced productive forces of modern China. It was the most progressive, promising and combative class, with an organized, disciplined nature linked to advanced economic forms.
 
In addition to having the general virtues of the world proletariat, the Chinese proletariat also had many special attributes. Firstly, the Chinese proletariat was deeply oppressed by imperialism, feudalism, and capitalism in ways that few other nations have experienced. This severe and brutal oppression meant that not only is the entire class highly revolutionary, but it also took a more resolute and thorough approach in revolutionary struggle than any other class. Secondly, although the numbers of the Chinese working class were small, they were highly concentrated in big cities and large enterprises, making them easy to organize into a powerful force conducive to the widespread dissemination of Marxism.



Thirdly, the majority of Chinese industrial workers come from bankrupt farmers and have a natural connection with the vast number of farmers, making it easy to form a solid alliance with the peasant class. These unique advantages of the Chinese proletariat have determined that only it can become the leading class of the revolution. Without the leadership of the proletariat and the Chinese Communist Party, the Chinese revolution cannot succeed, as proven by the entire history of the Chinese revolution.
Recognizing that the proletariat should lead and can lead the Chinese revolution does not mean that the question of leadership has been resolved. Leadership will not naturally fall into the hands of the proletariat, and it must be fought for. To this end, the Chinese communists, represented by Mao Zedong, have gradually developed a set of policies and strategies for striving for and seizing leadership of the revolution through long-term revolutionary practice. Mainly include: First, establishing a broad revolutionary united front based on the worker-peasant alliance is the key to realizing proletariat's leadership. Mao Zedong once pointed out: "The Chinese proletariat should understand that although they themselves are a class with the highest level of consciousness and organization, but if they rely solely on their own class strength, they cannot win. To win, they must unite all possible revolutionary classes and classes under various conditions and organize a revolutionary united front." Without the revolutionary united front, there is essentially no leadership of the proletariat. This united front must be based on the worker-peasant alliance, because the "proletariat is the most thorough revolutionary democrat" , "The peasants are the largest revolutionary democrats", the peasants who make up about 80% of the total population, are the basic force determining the success or failure of the Chinese revolution. Therefore, the key to realizing the proletariat's revolutionary leadership is to unite the peasants and form a solid worker-peasant alliance.
Secondly, when establishing a united front with the bourgeoisie, the implementation of the principle of independence and both unity and struggle is the basic strategy to maintain the leadership of the proletariat. Although the bourgeoisie, due to its economic and political weakness, cannot lead the Chinese revolution to victory, it does not mean that it will automatically give up leadership. They not only strive to influence the petty bourgeoisie and peasants, but also strive to influence the proletariat and the Communist Party, striving to eliminate the independence of the proletariat and the Communist Party in thought, politics, and organization, and strive to turn the proletariat and the Communist Party into the tail of the bourgeoisie and its party, striving to make the fruits of the revolution to a group and a party of the bourgeoisie. Therefore, the proletariat and its party must maintain a clear mind, adhere to the principle of independence, and implement a flexible strategy of both unity and struggle when establishing a united front with the bourgeoisie. Only in this way can both maintain the united front with the bourgeoisie without losing the leadership of the proletariat.
Again, establishing a powerful revolutionary armed force is a solid pillar to ensure the leadership of the proletariat. In the semi-colonial and semi-feudal China, where there is no national independence externally and no democracy and freedom internally, the main form of revolutionary struggle is war, and the main form of organization is the army. "Political power comes from the barrel of a gun", without a strong revolutionary armed force, there is no place for the proletariat and the Communist Party in China, let alone the so-called leadership of the proletariat. Therefore, if the proletariat wants to maintain their leadership in a democratic revolution, they must establish a strong revolutionary armed force.
Finally, strengthening the construction of the proletariat party is the fundamental guarantee for realizing the leadership of the proletariat.



The leadership of the proletariat in the Chinese revolution is realized through their own party - the Communist Party. The leadership of the proletariat is essentially the leadership of the Communist Party. The Communist Party is the initiator and organizer of the proletarian revolutionary cause. Only under the leadership of the Communist Party can the proletariat fulfill its historical mission and realize the cause of human liberation. As the political representative of the proletariat, the Communist Party mainly relies on its correctly formulated programs, routes, and policies, by the role model of the members of the Communist Party, by the proper relationship established with its allies, and by the conditions of development, ideological unity, strict discipline of the Communist Party, etc., to realize and guarantee its political leadership. For this, the Communist Party must strengthen itself comprehensively in thought, politics, and organization.
Four, the driving force for the new democratic revolution. The driving force for the new democratic revolution, as mentioned in the general line of the new democratic revolution, is the "masses", mainly including the proletariat, the peasant class, the petty bourgeoisie, and the national bourgeoisie.
First, the proletariat is not only the most basic driving force for the Chinese revolution, but also the leading force of the Chinese revolution. We have made a detailed analysis of this issue when talking about the leading forces of the New Democratic Revolution.
Second, the peasant class is the main force of the Chinese revolution and the major part of the "masses". Peasants account for about 80% of the total population, and 4 out of 5 Chinese are peasants. The so-called "masses" mainly refer to peasants. The main content of the democratic revolution is anti-feudalism, fundamentally eliminating the landlord's feudal land ownership. The main force against feudalism is peasants, who are the most heavily oppressed by feudalism. Therefore, the issue of peasants is "the basic subject of the Chinese revolution, and the power of peasants is the main force of the Chinese revolution". The characteristic of the Chinese revolution is the armed revolution against armed anti-revolution, and peasants are the main source of Chinese troops. Soldiers are just peasants in uniform. Therefore, in 1936, Mao Zedong pointed out sharply during his conversation with Snow in Shaanxi that whoever wins the peasants in China will win the revolution. How to lead the peasant revolution? Mao Zedong pointed out that we must liberate the peasants, take land revolution as the central content of the democratic revolution, completely eradicate the feudal landlord land ownership, and implement "those who cultivate shall have their fields". We must also educate the peasants, arm the advanced part of the peasants with Marxist theory, arouse the peasants' awareness, and overcome their own weaknesses. The Chinese revolution mainly rely on the power of workers and peasants.
Chinese peasants include the rich, middle, and poor peasants. The rich peasants, who account for about 5% of the rural population, are the rural bourgeoisie. They have semi-feudal characteristics, but they may remain neutral in the land revolution against landlords. Middle peasants, who make up about 20% of the rural population, are economically self-sufficient and politically powerless. They can participate in the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal struggle, can accept socialism, can become a reliable ally of the proletariat, and are an important part of the revolutionary force. The poor peasants and tenant farmers, who constitute about 70% of the rural population, are the semi-proletariat in the countryside, and the broadest driving force for the Chinese revolution, and the proletariat's natural and most reliable allies. Even though Chinese peasants are divided into three classes, the main forces leading the Chinese revolution are the poor and middle peasants. Only by forming a solid alliance with the poor and middle peasants can the proletariat lead the revolution to victory.
Third, the petty bourgeoisie is one of the basic driving forces for the Chinese revolution.



During the period of the New Democratic Revolution, the petty bourgeoisie other than peasants includes the majority of intellectuals, small traders, artisans, and freelancers. Their status was somewhat similar to that of middle peasants, oppressed by imperialism, feudalism, and the bourgeoisie, and gradually heading towards bankruptcy and decline. Therefore, these petty bourgeois groups served as one of the driving forces for the Chinese revolution and were reliable allies of the proletariat. Among them, intellectuals and young students often played a pioneering and bridging role in the Chinese revolution. Especially the relatively impoverished intellectuals, who were capable of joining and supporting the revolution alongside workers and peasants. The propagation and acceptance of Marxism-Leninism in China primarily occurred among intellectuals and young students. The development of revolutionary forces and the establishment of the revolutionary cause would not have been successful without the participation of these revolutionary intellectuals. Some among them were easily influenced by the bourgeoisie and often had a tendency towards subjectivity and individualism, hence it was necessary to carry out revolutionary propaganda and organization work among them.
  
Fourthly, the national bourgeoisie was one of the driving forces in the Chinese revolution. The Chinese national bourgeoisie emerged in the 1870s, later than the Chinese proletariat, and mainly originated from two sources: firstly, they were transformed from landlords, bureaucrats, and traders who directly invested in modern enterprises run by the government, joint ventures between the government and merchants, and businesses run solely by merchants. Secondly, they were transformed from owners of hand-made workshops that adopted machine production. Therefore, the Chinese national bourgeoisie can be further divided into the upper and middle-lower classes. The upper class owned large-scale enterprises and substantial economic strength and had close connections with foreign capitalism and national feudalism, often holding dual positions in both government and business. In contrast, middle-lower class enterprises and capital were generally smaller in scale, had fewer connections with foreign capitalism and national feudalism, and more contradictions.

In general, the Chinese national bourgeoisie is a dual-natured class, having both revolutionary demands and wavering traits. On the one hand, they had been oppressed by imperialism and restricted by feudalism, had conflicts with imperialism and feudalism, and thus they possessed anti-feudal revolutionary traits, forming one of the forces of revolution. On the other hand, they were weak in both economic and political terms, had not completely severed economic ties with imperialism and feudalism, lacked the courage to thoroughly oppose imperialism and feudalism, and were prone to wavering and compromise during the revolution.

The ambivalence of the Chinese national bourgeoisie is not related to the timidity during the period of original capital accumulation, nor is it a "new problem" occurring when their interests are threatened after the rise of the proletariat and the peasantry. This was an "old problem" they have carried since birth. The ambivalence of the national bourgeoisie is inherent and always present. When their revolutionary nature dominates, there are also tendencies to compromise with enemies, and they are unwilling to completely oppose imperialism and feudalism in their revolutionary agenda, which initially defined the democratic nature of the Chinese revolution. But for a long time afterwards, understanding of this issue was not profound. After the failure of the Great Revolution, the perception within the Chinese Communist Party of the nature of the revolution once fell into a mess. The 6th National Congress of the Communist Party of China made a correct judgment on the nature of the Chinese revolution, but afterwards, there was the occurrence of "left-leaning" opportunism, and the mistake of confusing the boundaries between democratic revolution and socialist revolution. The nature of the Chinese revolution was truly understood from the combination of theory and practice, and scientifically explained by Mao Zedong's works, including "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party," and "On New Democracy," among others.




Connected with the revolutionary nature is the question of the revolutionary future. Generally speaking, the future of the bourgeois democratic revolution lies in establishing a capitalist system under the dictatorship of the bourgeoisie, which is not the case for the China revolution. The China revolution no longer aims to develop capitalism as its ultimate goal, but instead, follows a new path of New Democratic revolution. Under the leadership of the proletariat, it aims to establish a state under the people's democratic dictatorship, and through the New Democracy revolution, it eventually aims to reach the goal of socialism. The issue of the future of the New Democratic revolution is essentially a question of how to deal with the relationship between the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution. For this, Mao Zedong clearly proposed the idea of China's revolution taking "two steps". He pointed out: the China revolution must be divided into two steps: the first step is to change the semi-colonial and semi-feudal social form, making China an "independent New Democratic country, the second step is to advance the revolution to establish a socialist society. In short, the first step is democracy, and the second step is socialism. “The Chinese Communist Party-led entire Chinese revolutionary movement includes both the democratic revolution and the socialist revolution phases; these are two revolutions of different nature, and only after completing the previous revolutionary process can the next revolutionary process be possible.”
Strictly distinguishing between the nature of the New Democratic revolution and the socialist revolution does not mean severing the connection between these two revolutions. The relationship between the two is like the relationship between the first and second part of an article; only when the first part is well done, can the second part be done well. In general, “the democratic revolution is the necessary preparation for the socialist revolution, and the socialist revolution is the inevitable trend of the democratic revolution. And the ultimate goal of all communists is to strive for the final completion of socialist society and communist society”. There were two wrong tendencies within the Chinese Communist Party regarding the future of the revolution: one was to separate the two closely connected stages of the revolution, only seeing the differences between the two without recognizing their connection, and inserting a stage of bourgeois dictatorship and capitalist development between the two stages; the other was to advocate that the democratic and socialist revolutions “accomplish their tasks in one stroke", attempting to combine the two revolutionary stages of different nature into one step, thereby blurring the boundary between the democratic and socialist revolutions. Both of these wrong tendencies violate the laws of China's revolution development. Therefore, Mao Zedong profoundly concluded that only by recognizing the difference between the New Democratic revolution and the socialist revolution, and also recognizing their connection, can the Chinese revolution be led correctly.

After the failure of the Grand Revolution, when the Chinese Communist Party decided to resist the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang through armed force, how to achieve victory in the armed struggle? What should the revolution path be? This is another problem that the Chinese Communist Party encountered in leading the Chinese revolution. Establishing armed struggle as the primary form of revolutionary struggle was a historic progress. However, for a while, the party fell into the pitfall of "Urban Center Theory" in its exploration of China's revolutionary path.
In the Soviet Union, the proletariat carried out the violent revolution by directly arming the working class and seizing revolutionary victories through uprisings in central cities.



Lenin developed Marxism in the process of leading the Russian Revolution, proposing that the proletariat must seize power with the city as the center. Lenin believed that only the proletariat concentrated in the central cities of capitalist countries could completely smash the bourgeoisie. "Cities must inevitably lead the countryside. The countryside must inevitably follow the city." Therefore, seizing power in the central city has strategic significance for seizing national power. At the same time, Lenin pointed out that once the proletariat launches an uprising, it must courageously continue to attack. The basic principles of Marxism-Leninism are undoubtedly correct, but revolutions in various countries have their own characteristics. Therefore, when the Communist International guided the Chinese revolution according to the Soviet model, and the Chinese Communists sanctified the instructions of the Communist International, a "left-leaning" dogmatic line guiding the Chinese revolution evolved.

After the October Revolution in Russia, the theory of city centrism was introduced to China with Marxism. After the Chinese Communist Party joined the Communist International after the Second Congress of the Party in 1922 and became a branch of the Communist International in China, the theory and policies of the Communist International had a profound impact on the formulation of major policies of the Chinese Communist Party. During the Great Revolution, the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party followed the instructions of the Communist International and took the "city center" path. At that time, because the first Kuomintang-Communist cooperation was realized, the revolutionary Kuomintang not only had a unified revolutionary base in Guangdong, but also had an army of tens of thousands of national revolutionary army; And the target of the revolution, the Beiyang warlords, was divided and cut, without a unified central government. Therefore, the Northern Expedition initiated from Guangzhou jointly led by the Kuomintang and the Communist Party once achieved great victories. This shows that the path of the Northern Expedition to seize the center city is fundamentally correct. This is determined by the special historical conditions at that time. After the failure of the Great Revolution, China's political situation has undergone a drastic change. The former allies have become fierce enemies. They have established a unified government, have a powerful army, occupy the central city, and carry out a bloody slaughter policy against communists and revolutionary people. In this situation, the experience of foreign urban centralism is obviously not suitable for China's national conditions. Mao Zedong later pointed out: "If the revolutionary ranks are unwilling to compromise with imperialism and its running dogs, but want to persist in fighting, and if the revolutionary ranks are to prepare to accumulate and exercise their own strength and avoid decisive battles with powerful enemies when they are not strong enough", they must resolutely change their line, namely, leaving the center city and moving towards the rural areas in the mountains. There, they can rebuild a solid base to "counter the brutal enemy attacking the rural areas from the city and gradually win the entire victory in the long-term battle." This change in the revolutionary line not only allows Marxism but also is the most essential requirement and expression of Marxism. However, at that time, due to the lack of a unified understanding of Marxist theory and Chinese revolutionary practice, the Chinese Communist Party was still unable to get rid of the influence of the theory of the city center, and still insisted on the view that the city was the center of the revolutionary struggle. Therefore, the influence of the theory of the city center has become a prominent obstacle encountered by the Chinese Communist Party in exploring a new path for the Chinese revolution during the period of the Land Revolution War.

The influence of the "urban center theory" on the Chinese Communist Party can be divided into several stages...

The first stage was from the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) Central Committee's August 1927 Eighth Seventh Meeting to June 1928's Sixth CCP Congress. In this stage, the influence of the city center theory mainly manifested in several uprisings led by the CCP Central Committee around the time of the Eighth Seventh Meeting, attempting to advance the revolution through initiating uprisings in cities. For example, in the Autumnal Uprising in Hunan, both the Central and Hunan Provincial Committee advocated for initiating the uprising in Changsha city. The Hunan Provincial Committee mentioned in a letter to the Central Committee, "The Changsha Uprising and the Autumnal Uprising are one and the same. The Changsha Uprising is the starting point of the Autumnal Uprising." The Central Committee agreed with this "in principle.” Similarly, in the case of the Guangzhou Uprising, the Central Committee believed it "is the beginning of the general uprising in Guangdong and a signal for workers and farmers' uprisings nationwide.” As such, the Central's idea of initiating the uprising in the city is fully reflected in the uprisings after the failure of the great revolution. Starting from October 1927, instructions from the Central to provinces such as Hunan, Hubei, Jiangxi, Guangdong, and Fujian also proposed to launching widespread guerrilla warfare and land revolution, creating "an independent and separate situation” and "establishing a basis for the peasant revolution". However, this did not mean that the Central had given up on the city center theory; on the contrary, the Central still advocated for "the city of the uprising to become the center and guide of spontaneous peasant uprisings”.

Under this ideological guidance, the Central required Hunan to "plan the overall uprising around Changsha". The Central Committee mentioned in a letter to the Guangdong Provincial Committee that although the Chinese revolution has formed a special method of "peasant separatism", the development of this separatism "must obtain" the larger cities in each region, and the leadership of the working class should be demonstrated "on this basis". This shows that regardless of the Central's changes in the specific form of the uprising, as well as some degree of attention to rural separatism, the idea centered on the city has not changed.

The situation of the Party Central Committee was largely due to the influence of the Comintern. On February 25, 1928, the ninth expanded meeting of the Communist International Executive Committee made a "Resolution on the Chinese issue", emphasizing that the Chinese revolution should continue to follow the "city center" route and criticized the rural guerrilla warfare led by the CCP Central Committee. This resolution points out that the rural uprisings must be connected with the climax of the city revolution, to "become the starting point for the national uprising", and the Party's primary task is to prepare for the coordination of the city and the countryside in the upcoming provinces, and not focus only on armed uprisings and guerrilla warfare in the countryside, neglecting to make the city the center. In this way, guerrilla warfare is bound to fail. It also proposed that "we must oppose the indulgence with guerrilla warfare, against sinking into disorganized, unrelated, and inevitable failed guerrilla warfare". Clearly, the Russian revolution model centered on the city was used to guide the Chinese revolution. This subjective idealism, without considering China's actual conditions, brought serious impacts to the Chinese revolution.

The second stage was from the Sixth CCP Congress to the September 1930 Sixth Plenary Session of the Three Central Committees. In this stage, the CCP Central Committee emphasized the need to focus work in the cities and, under the rule of "left-leaning" adventurousness, arranged city uprisings and actions to attack large cities.



At the 6th National Congress of the Communist Party of China held between June and July 1928, the Communist International still guided the Chinese revolution with the theory of urban centrality. In the report made by Communist International representative Bukharin at the beginning of the congress, he did not acknowledge that the guerrilla warfare led by the Chinese Party was a positive exploration to accumulate and develop revolutionary forces based on China's reality, and to seek new paths for the Chinese revolution. He criticized the armed uprisings of peasants initiated by the Chinese Communist Party in some places and the establishment of revolutionary bases as "valuing peasants more than workers". In his conclusion to the congress, he also opposed the founding principle of the Chinese Red Army, believing that the Chinese Red Army were "non-productive masses" with only a single task of fighting wars; he proposed that the Red Army should be "dispersed to various places", roaming around and engaging in guerrilla warfare, playing the role of a peasant self-defense force.

After the 6th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, the Communist International expressed such concern, that is, fearing that the Chinese Communist Party's long-term development in rural areas would turn into a "peasant party". They believed that the party's work should be centered in cities and carry out worker movements to reflect the leadership of the proletarian party; if the work was centered in rural areas and there were many peasant party members, it would not be a proletarian party, but a peasant party instead. This essentially emphasized that the Chinese Communist Party must walk the path of "urban centrality". On October 26, 1929, the letter from the Communist International Executive Committee to the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee on the reorganization of the Kuomintang and the tasks of the Chinese Communist Party emphasized that the Chinese Communist Party "must exert all its strength to develop political strikes and prepare for a general political strike."

By October 1930, although the Communist International recognized the imbalance between the Chinese labor movement and the peasant movement, they still emphasized to the Chinese Communist Party that "establishing the Soviet government means that the Chinese Communist Party intends to launch an armed uprising in the largest industrial centers." They essentially guided the Chinese Communist Party's actions using the specific model of the typical October Revolution.

On April 28, 1928, when the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee Political Bureau discussed the "February Resolutions" issued by the Communist International, whether it was intimidated by the criticism of the Communist International or to demonstrate loyalty to the international line, most of the people spoke out in support of the international instructions. They believed that since the August 7 Conference, our party had underrated the power of urban working class, which led to a comparatively passive or even abandoned urban work, "which is not right". They believed that not focusing on urban worker movements was a reflection of "peasant leadership", and they introduced the notion of "opposing peasant consciousness". Based on this discussion, on the 30th, the Central Political Bureau issued the "Notice Regarding the Resolutions of the Communist International", which pointed out that the failure of armed uprisings in the countryside was "due to the lack of urban leadership, and inappropriate coordination and contact". It criticized the provincial committees in Hunan and Hubei for calling for "rural unrest but not city" since the autumn harvest uprising, and "indulging in" guerrilla warfare. It called for party organizations everywhere to "restore urban work and establish the leadership of urban workers to the countryside", emphasizing that "cities are the leaders of rural areas".

Under the above-mentioned guiding spirit, the theme of urban centrality still deeply influenced the Chinese Communist Party after the 6th National Congress. Firstly, the work of the party should be centered in cities. The Chinese Communist Party Central Committee believed that after the Great Revolution failed, many party organizations moved to rural areas. The peasant consciousness made the Chinese Communist Party "at risk of deviating from the proletariat". To ensure the nature of the party and create a proletarian base for the party, the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee suggested selecting industrial areas and important cities as the "centers of work". Because "the city is the center of all political and economic activities, it can lead the countryside. Once we seize the city, the countryside can quickly follow... we must change the overall work spirit from purely rural to focus on the city". Even when carrying out work in the countryside, "we should pay special attention to the rural areas close to the city", and should never lean towards the development in remote rural areas. This city-centric perspective severely hindered the shift in the focus of the party's work.

Secondly, it ignored the peasant war and Soviet base areas. At that time, the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee believed that in the new height of the revolution, the peasant war was a major tributary, and the primary symbol of the revolutionary climax was still the revival of the worker movement.



Therefore, in the work of the party, it should be firmly believed that the establishment of a number of branches in every heavy industry is even more valuable than our division of a village with hundreds of comrades in rural areas. During Li Lisan's "leftist" adventurous error period, this tendency became even more severe. The central government emphasizes that the uprising in the central city is of decisive significance, criticizing the surround the cities with rural areas as "an illusion", "an absolutely erroneous concept", and criticizing focus on rural work as a "peasant consciousness". Thus, the idea of rural rule, which had been agreed upon before the Sixth Congress of the Communist Party, was criticized as a mistake. This perception is undoubtedly a regression.

Third, propose the adventurous plan of attacking central cities. In early 1930, due to the certain degree of recovery of revolutionary forces, the warlord melee provided a good opportunity for the development of the revolutionary struggle, the central government made a wrong estimation of the situation, thinking that the revolutionary situation was mature and heading to a climax. Under this circumstance, preparing for one or several provinces to unite and establish the national revolutionary government became the general guideline for the party's current strategy, emphasizing that the first area to be captured should be "a place of significance in politics and economy for national leadership", like Shanghai or Wuhan. In this way, the capture of large cities was put forward as the main task. The Central Committee emphasizes that to capture large cities, there must be armed uprisings of workers. This is the "most important" condition for a successful uprising. Therefore, the military work should put "arming workers" in the first place on the agenda. The central government asked for a total strike and even armed rebellion in Shanghai, and a soldier rebellion in Nanjing, in order to suit the early victory of Wuhan and its neighboring provinces. At the same time, the Red Army was also given the task of attacking large cities, requiring the Red Army "to develop towards the central cities of important transportation routes in strategy and tactics". Obviously, at that time, the CPC Central Committee aimed to seize the central city by coordinating the urban workers' rebellion and the Red Army's attack, and achieve the initial victory of one or several provinces centered on Wuhan.

Fourth, deny the imbalance of revolutionary development. At that time, the central government overestimated the development of the revolutionary situation, exaggerated the instability of enemy rule, and denied the imbalance of revolutionary development, believing that "the fundamental crisis of Chinese economy and politics is sharpening in the same way everywhere in the country without any fundamental difference." The revolutionary situation is "most obviously the balanced development of the Red Army of workers, peasants, and soldiers". Under this circumstance, "any issue is possible to spark a revolutionary climax". When the national revolutionary climax comes, "the beginning of a province or several provinces' uprising is the beginning of a national uprising", "the initial victory of one province or several provinces is the beginning of national victory". This estimate actually denies the possibility of one or several provinces' initial success.

It cannot be denied that the Central Committee of the Party after the Sixth Congress also paid more attention to the development of the Red Army in rural areas and the conduct of rural guerrilla warfare. However, the Central Committee of the Party raised this issue from the perspective of winning over the masses and preparing for urban uprising. The development of the Red Army and rural guerrilla warfare has always been included in the track of city uprisings. As the "leftist" adventurers pursued the policy of seizing large cities, the work of the Party was greatly damaged.



Despite the Party's primary focus being on urban work, the outcome did not meet the Central Committee's expectations, and instead, there were significant losses. In just over two months, 11 provincial committee offices were destroyed by enemies, the number of party members in large enterprises was scant, and the fluctuating status of urban branches were all beyond unacceptable. Simultaneously, the Central Committee's decision to mobilize the Red Army to attack central cities away from their base resulted in varying degrees of losses for both the Red Army and their base. The overemphasis on urban centrism negatively impacted the development of rural revolutionary struggles.

The third phase started from the Third Plenary Session of the Sixth Congress of the Communist Party of China in September 1930 to the failure of the Fifth Counter "Encirclement" Campaign. During this phase, the urban-centric theory further harmed the Chinese Revolution and was practically declared bankrupt.

The Third Plenary Session of the Sixth Party Congress ended Li Li-san's “Left” adventurous error (known as the "Li-san Line"), and there was a cessation of urban riots and large city attacks, yet the influence of the urban-centric theory still lingered. After the failure of the Li-san Line, under the direct direction of the Communist International, the even more "leftist" "Left" dogmatic error orchestrated by Wang Ming once again dominated the Party Central Committee. The Wang Ming Line reintroduced the risky mistake of seizing central cities and primarily advocated for the Red Army to attack central cities and decisively battle with enemy troops. The urban-centric theory brought serious losses to the revolution in its new manifestation.

During this period, the revolutionary situation underwent some changes. On the one hand, the Red Army and their base made significant progress in the revolutionary war. On the other hand, the Party's work in the White-controlled areas suffered severe setbacks. Party organizations at all levels were continually destroyed, and city workers' strikes, fly-in rallies, and even armed uprisings mostly ended in failure. This situation made it necessary for the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China to shift its guiding ideology, placing more focus on the Red Army warfare and rural revolutionary bases. In the spring of 1933, the Provisional Central Committee moved from Shanghai to the Central Soviet Area, which objectively was a progressive change. However, this change was forced and unconscious. Despite the Provisional Central Committee moving to rural areas, the essential idea of urban centrality persisted. This was mainly manifested in the belief of achieving initial victories in one or several provinces via the Red Army seizing central cities. Under the dominion of Wang Ming's "Left" dogmatic error, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China did not understand the long-term and tortuous nature of the Chinese Revolution. Although they criticized Li Li-san's premature risk-taking command for the Red Army to attack major cities, their divergence with Li was not about whether to capture central cities in order to achieve initial victories in a few provinces, but about the estimation of the situation and when such captures can be carried out. Therefore, as soon as there were any shifts in the situation, the Central Committee would repeat the mistake of attacking major cities. And this was exactly what happened. Shortly after the 918 Incident, the Central Committee proposed: "The previously correct strategy of not occupying major cities is now different," "Taking advantage of the current favorable political and military conditions to occupy one or two major central cities to start the revolution's initial victory in several provinces is now on the party's overall work and Soviet movement Agenda".



"From then on, the overall strategy of our central operations became to seize the central cities and achieve initial victories in several provinces. Even when we faced consistent setbacks during the fifth "encirclement" campaign, when the Red Army was in a very passive situation, the central authority still repeatedly emphasized the need to seize the central cities and achieve the first victory in multiple provinces. Under this strategy, the central authority criticized the theoretical line of Mao Zedong and others who advised consolidating and expanding the revolutionary base in rural areas as the "theory of the Soviet on the mountain". They also disdained the assertion made by Deng Xiaoping, Mao Zeqin, Xie Weijun, and Gu Bo that "developing Soviets towards central cities and important traffic routes is impossible". The central authority instead advocated developing large rural areas where enemy forces were relatively weak and condemned this as "the pessimistic disappointment" of "advocating the abandonment of the Soviet base area" and tried to push out Mao Zedong and strike against Deng, Mao, Xie, and Gu.

Regarding the strategy to seize the central cities and achieve the first victory in multiple provinces, this stage differs from the previous two stages. Although the central sometimes also mentioned the armed uprising of cities, the main emphasis was on using the military offensive of the Red Army to seize central cities and achieve the first victory in multiple provinces. The main reason for this different approach was due to severe losses in city work and the gradual increase in Red Army's strength, the Central was forced by the situation and insisted on the thesis of city center with a new method.

Second, the Red Army war was commanded with an "active offensive" route and regular war strategy. The "left-leaning" central misunderstood Marx's principle of continuous attack after the armed uprising and proposed that the "primary key" of all strategic tactics is to "eliminate the enemy under the attack line" and to carry out the so-called "total offensive", "capture of central cities" and "two fists hitting the enemy" strategic tactics. In order to implement the active offensive tactic, the central authority unilaterally emphasized the regular war and proposed to oppose the "conservative guerrilla war strategy". They required the Red Army to become regularized, and that "the main force of the Red Army must be concentrated, and must act as quickly as possible", and to enable the Red Army to "make full effort in the decisive battle".

The Central denied that the form of China's revolutionary warfare was a long-term repetition of "encirclement" and anti-"encirclement". They considered the fifth anti-"encirclement" as a "class decisive battle", and believed that crushing the fifth "encirclement" would resolve the question of "who wins between the Soviet road and the colonial road". Under this misguided thinking, the Central Command led the fifth anti-"encirclement" war with the principle of so-called regular warfare, opposing "guerrillaism", opposing enticing the enemy to go deeper, advocating "guarding the enemy outside the country's gate", and promoting the defensive tactics of the inner line and fortress, which directly led to the failure of the fifth anti-"encirclement".

The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China during the Wang Ming dictatorship period guided the work of the Red Army and base areas with erroneous city views, which caused great damage to the Chinese revolution. The failure of the fifth anti-"encirclement" proved that the city-centric theory, in whatever form it appears, does not conform to China's national conditions and can only bring losses to the Chinese Revolution. The failure of the fifth anti-"encirclement" declared the end of the city-centric theory in China's history.

The failure of the fifth anti-"encirclement" led to a crisis in the Chinese revolution. In this critical juncture, in January 1935, the Central Committee held the Zunyi Conference during the Long March. The meeting focused on correcting the military mistakes that were decisive at the time, summarized the lessons from the failure of the fifth anti-"encirclement", and ended the rule of Wang Ming’s "Left" dogmatism in the party central committee. The meeting made a resolution based on the Mao Zedong's speech, "On the Summary of The Opposition to the Enemy's Five 'Encirclements'", it pointed out: "The civil war in China is not a short-term war, but a protracted and enduring war. The Soviet revolution developed and consolidated through continuously crushing the enemy's 'encirclement'." Under the principle of protracted warfare, we must oppose conservatism, as well as "adventurism produced by overestimating our own victories and underestimating enemy forces."."



The resolution specifically pointed out: The adventurism of such "uncertain and unnecessary attacks on the central city at the time" has caused serious damage to the Red Army and the revolutionary war. In fact, it criticized the theory of the urban center and thus truly began the shift of the entire party's focus.

After the Red Army's Long March reached northern Shaanxi, although the party central committee deployed extensive work to expand into the five provinces of Shanxi, Shaanxi, Gansu, Sui, and Ning, it was no longer centered on the victory in several provinces with cities as the center. The CCP Central Committee believes: "The Chinese Soviet revolution has already achieved preliminary victories in some provinces", the kind of view that it is necessary to occupy central cities and provincial capitals for a province or several provinces to achieve preliminary victories is "unfactual". After the Wa Yao Bu meeting, Mao Zedong wrote in the article "On the Strategy against Japanese Imperialism", describing the uneven development of China's political and economic development and corresponding uneven characteristics of the revolution, as well as the long-term characteristics of the revolution caused by the enemy's strength and our weakness, the conclusion was drawn that "the victory of the revolution always starts, develops, and achieves initial success first in places where counter-revolutionary forces are relatively weak." Thus, the CCP Central Committee replaced and denied the view of the initial victory in one or several provinces centered on cities with the idea of initial victory in areas where enemy rule is weak with rural areas as the center, completing a major change in the issue of the Chinese revolution road. This is the result of a group of Chinese Communists, represented mainly by Mao Zedong, persisting in long-term rural revolutionary warfare, constantly summarizing experience and lessons, and struggling against "left" errors.

Third, the party's summary of the "urban center theory" practice
The Communist Party of China is good at summarizing experience and lessons from failures and setbacks. The painful results of the practice of the urban center theory made the Communist Party of China deeply realize: First, the urban center theory has a profound influence on the Communist Party of China, no matter what form it takes, it can only bring harm to the revolutionary cause. Firstly, it made the CCP Central Committee persist in the idea of revolution centered on cities for a long time, first with the city as the center of the uprising, then with the city as the center of daily work, and even under the circumstance of the central government moving into rural areas, it still called for the seizure of central cities, and guided the work of the Red Army and the base areas with this idea for a long time; secondly, it made the party central committee regard the armed uprising of workers as the decisive force for a long time, and could not recognize the extreme importance of peasant wars; thirdly, it made the party central committee command the Red Army war with the principle of the armed uprising of the European proletariat revolution, and could not recognize the laws and characteristics of the Chinese revolutionary war. In summary, the urban center theory has seriously affected the shift of the work focus of the Communist Party of China, resulting in the Communist Party of China not being able to accept the correct revolutionary road represented by Mao Zedong for a considerable period of time, and the revolutionary cause has suffered setbacks repeatedly. Of course, in the practice of leading the Chinese revolution by the CCP Central Committee, their ideological understanding also changed. For example, the view of the first victory in a province or several provinces gave the urban center theory a Chinese color, which was in line with the actual situation in China, so it was accepted when people did not deeply understand the characteristics of the Chinese revolution. In this sense, the idea of first victory in a province or several provinces played a transitional role in the process of the party shaking off the influence of the urban center theory. But essentially, it is the product of the urban center theory. However, the CCP Central Committee at that time always failed to comprehend that the seizure of the central city is the last stage of the Chinese democratic revolution, and regarded the seizure of the central city in the short term as a prerequisite for achieving the first victory in a province or several provinces. Here, the influence of the urban center theory is prominently displayed, becoming a kind of barrier hindering the Communist Party of China from deepening its understanding of the problems of the Chinese revolution. Facts have proved that no matter what form the urban center theory manifests in China, it can only bring harm to the revolution.

Second, the reason why the urban center theory cannot lead the Chinese revolution to victory is that it is not a product of China's social, political, and economic development and does not conform to China's actual situation.



The soil from which the theory of central cities arose is the European capitalist society, reflecting the laws and characteristics of the European proletarian revolution. However, China's national conditions are different from those of Europe and have great specificity. Looking at the development of China's social economy: due to the invasion of imperialism, China lost the opportunity to develop capitalism independently. The social economy of China did not follow the usual laws of capitalist economic development to form a unified urban and rural market, nor did the city gain economic control over the countryside. China's big cities can be divided into two types. One is cities that have continued from history, such as Beijing. They are mainly the centers of feudal political power and consumption, not production. Economically, these cities cannot control the countryside. The other type is emerging economic and political centers, such as Shanghai. However, the economic lifeline of these cities is in the hands of imperialism. This kind of urban economy can only be the economy of a semi-colonial society and cannot compare with the economic centers of the West. Regarding rural economy, in most parts of China, the feudal mode of production still dominates, so it is hard to say that industrial cities have a decisive influence on the vast rural areas. During the development of capitalism in China, farmers near commercial ports would undoubtedly be impacted by the commodity economy, speeding up the process of separating laborers from the means of production. However, this separation process was primarily not caused by the prosperity of industry and commerce but by feudal factors such as feudal land ownership and super-economic coercive exploitation. In the vast areas far from commercial ports where transportation is inconvenient, the natural economy still predominates. In China, not only is the economic development between urban and rural areas uneven, but the economic development between rural and rural areas is also uneven. Therefore, Chinese cities and villages are not under a unified economic form. Cities cannot control the vast rural areas, and rural areas can be self-sufficient without cities. Under these conditions, cities can play an important role in the revolution, but they cannot have the absolute authority role like European cities. Looking at the comparison of class forces: the absolute number of the Chinese proletariat is no less than the number of Russian workers during the October Revolution. However, due to China's large population, the relative number of the working class is very small. During the October Revolution, Russian workers accounted for 1/6 of the total population, but at this time Chinese workers only accounted for 1/200 of the total population. Therefore, the main force of the revolution is not the workers but the peasants. The leading role of the proletariat cannot be reflected in actions such as city strikes and riots, but is reflected in sending their vanguards to the countryside to lead the peasants in land revolutions and revolutionary wars. The proletariat leads the peasants, it cannot be like Europe where urban workers participate in the fight first to mobilize peasants. 
Looking at China's political situation: China has been a feudal centralized authoritarian state for thousands of years and has no democratic tradition. Since the Revolution of 1911, there has been some democratic propaganda, but this propaganda is very shallow due to a short time, deep-rooted old ideas, and other reasons. After Chiang Kai-shek came to power, he still continued the tradition of feudal autocracy and added fascist methods. The more centralized the city, the stricter the reactionary rule, and the more likely the revolutionary activities are to be suppressed.



In this circumstance, with no parliament available for exploitation and no room for open activities in cities, power cannot be accumulated. Therefore, the Chinese revolution could not use the cities as a base to directly seize supreme power, but could only use the rural areas as bases for revolution, attacking the cities from the rural areas and finally gaining national power. 
The aforementioned socio-historical conditions determined that the Chinese revolution could not follow the path of European revolutions, urban-centric theories simply did not work in China.
Thirdly, it took the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee a winding and long process to rid the influence of the urban-centric theory. This illustrates that correctly combining Marxism with the practices of the Chinese revolution is a daunting and complicated task. Objectively,China is an extremely complex large country. At the turning point after the failure of the great revolution, it was impossible for the Party Central Committee to fully understand the national conditions of the revolutionary country and the laws and characteristics of the revolutionary movement in a short period of time, and to discover the correct path for revolution. In addition, the influence of the Communist International also added difficulties to the Chinese Communist Party's exploration of the revolutionary path. Subjectively, a major reason is to dogmatically treat Marxism and merely copy foreign experiences. Marx, Engels, and Lenin all greatly emphasized the leading role of cities in revolutions. As Marx and Engels see it, the leading role of cities is the proletariat's leadership over the peasants. Lenin has also said, "The bigger the city, the greater the proletariat's role in the struggle.” Of course,Marx, Engels, and Lenin never neglected the role of peasants, but they all discussed the issue from the perspective of winning over peasant allies, and they never mentioned that the proletariat's political parties should focus their work on the countryside from the perspective of the revolutionary road. Based on the Marx-Lenin doctrine,  Chinese Communists who are not adept at combining the principles of Marx and Lenin with the realities of the Chinese revolution would naturally take these principles of Marxism as a guide for action, and the city would naturally become the center of the party's work. This kind of thinking has been the orthodox view for quite a long time, and new ideas arising out of China's reality were regarded as "heresies" against Marxism. At that time, the domination of the party with the sanctification of Marx's doctrine as well as the resolutions of the Communist International and Soviet experiences, it was not easy to creatively apply the principles of Marxism. This is also a profound lesson that the retrospective of this history has left us.

In the arduous struggle of the whole Party to save the revolution and to find a new path for the revolution, a large number of Communists, represented mainly by Mao Zedong, through the practice of creating and developing the Red Army and the rural revolutionary base areas, began to gradually find a way to revive the Chinese revolution. This formed a theory that guided the Chinese revolution to victory. The proposal of the thought of "the armed enclaves of workers and peasants" signifies the beginning of the construction of this great theory.



Although the "urban centralist theory" still dominates within the Communist Party of China, faced with the difficult situation of the Chinese Revolution and the complex national conditions, the entire Party is also striving to explore and think about future prospects and ways forward. 

Because the speed and degree of revolutionary struggles vary across different regions, this prompted the CPC Central Committee to recognize the imbalance in China's socio-political and economic development, resulting in an uneven development of the revolution: 

Firstly, there is a disparity in the development of the worker-peasant movement, rural struggles have developed into guerrilla warfare, some areas have begun to establish separate regimes and established Soviets, while most cities have not developed to this extent. 

Secondly, there is an uneven development of revolutionary movements in different regions, some provinces have progressed to the point of seizing provincial government power through uprisings, but many provinces have not yet reached this level. 

Accordingly, at this stage, the CPC Central Committee proposed some arguments that differ from the Russian October Revolution model. 

Firstly, the proposition of the strategic objective of "first victory in one province or several provinces" was put forward. During the early stages of the Land Revolution War, the CPC Central Committee primarily deployed the armed uprisings in provinces like Hunan, Hubei, Jiangxi, and Guangdong. In fact, the uprisings led by the Party were mostly concentrated in these provinces, and the uprisings in the north did not flourish like they did in the southern provinces. This suggests that the Central Committee did not adopt the "one-strike" tactic used in the French Revolution and the Russian October Revolution to seize the capital. 

In November 1927, the Party Central Committee explicitly proposed to "unite the power of workers and farmers' uprisings, merge spontaneous workers and farmers' uprisings from all places, seize political power, ... until a revolutionary victory situation is created in one or several provinces". The Central Committee believed that under the situation of a general revolutionary upsurge, victories could first be achieved in areas where the enemy was weak, the revolutionary tide of workers and farmers was high, and the leadership of the Party was strongest. This initial victory would be the first step towards a nationwide victory; through establishing Soviet power to safeguard this victory, and then "expand the Soviet power to other regions and the whole of China with a population of 400 million". The Sixth National Congress of the CPC confirmed the strategic goal of striving for the first victory in one or several provinces, pointed out that under the condition of a revolutionary upsurge, victories could first be achieved in one province or several provinces.

Secondly, the idea of surrounding the cities by dividing the rural areas into different zones, enhancing the work in the cities, and finally completing the first victory in one or several provinces through urban uprisings was put forward. After the failure of the Guangzhou Uprising, the CPC Central Committee emphasized in its instructions to various regions that "occupying large cities is the final move when the struggle of the worker-peasant has matured in vast areas". Before this, while enhancing the struggle in central cities, the rural areas need to be divided into separate zones to create a separatist situation, "until the rural separatism is complete and the urban struggle reaches a climax, then a general uprising centered around the city can be initiated to fulfill the task of taking over the region".

Thus, the revolution mode of surrounding cities by partitioning rural areas into different zones, enhancing urban work, and finally accomplishing the first victory in one or multiple provinces through urban uprisings, has replaced the revolution mode of starting an uprising in cities then pushing to rural areas and taking the capital with "one strike". This represents the first step the CPC Central Committee has taken from the practical reality of China towards breaking away from the constraints of urban centralist theory. This has made an important contribution in enlightening the Party to explore and eventually accept the revolutionary path of rural areas surrounding the cities.

However, the CPC Central Committee's understanding of the uneven socio-political and economic development of China, especially the imbalance between urban and rural political and economic development is not profound, thus cannot genuinely break free from the constraints of urban centralism. At the same time, the goal of achieving "first victory in one or several provinces" does not truly reflect the uneven development law of Chinese revolution. The shortcomings inherent in it, under specific conditions, can still bring losses to the Chinese revolution.




In the exploration of the path of Chinese revolution, the truly significant ideological sprout is the proposal of the "Up the Mountain" thought within the Communist Party of China. The "Up the Mountain" thought is the initial form of the "Armed Struggle of Workers and Peasants" thought. 

Around the time of the 87th Meeting, the Communist Party of China Central Committee discussed the direction of the peasants' movement and armed peasants several times. At this time, Mao Zedong proposed the idea of "going up the mountain". In June 1927, Mao Zedong convened a meeting in Hankou with comrades from Hunan who had fled after the "May Day Mutiny". At this meeting, he called on everyone to return to their hometowns, proposed going to the mountains and going aboard ships on the lakesides, to resolutely struggle against the enemy and advocate for the armed defense of the revolution. 

He then returned to Hunan to serve as the provincial secretary, responsible for the work of the Hunan Provincial Committee, making the arrangements for members of the Peasants' Association and the Peasants' Self-Defense Army to "go up the mountain" and "into the lake", preserving the revolutionary strength and waiting for the right opportunity. On July 4, Mao Zedong proposed at an enlarged meeting of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee: "The armed peasants can go up the mountain or join the army connected to the party", he clearly pointed out: "If we do not preserve the armed force, we will have no way to cope once an incident occurs." 

He believed that: The peasant army could go up the mountain, and predicted that "going up the mountain could form the basis of military power". On the 13th, the Communist Party of China Central Committee announced that it is now in "the critical moment of the revolution's survival". The Central Committee decided to launch a peasant autumn harvest uprising in four provinces — Hunan, Hubei, Jiangxi, and Guangdong — to advance the implementation of the land revolution. 

At the end of July, Mao Zedong was actively preparing for the Autumn Harvest Uprising and drafted the "Outline on the Hunan Movement" (hereinafter referred to as the "Outline") to report to the Central Committee. The "Outline" reflected Mao Zedong's thoughts on starting a military uprising, establishing a party-led army, forming an armed enclave, establishing a revolutionary government, and advancing the land revolution. On August 7, the Communist Party of China Central Committee secretly convened an emergency meeting in Hankou. Mao Zedong summarized the four lessons from the failure of the Great Revolution at the meeting: completely abandoning the independent political stance of the Communist Party, not paying attention to military issues, not raising a revolutionary program to solve the peasants' land issues and the party's separation from the masses. He emphasized that in the future they need to pay much attention to the military, knowing that political power is obtained from the barrel of a gun. 

At the 87th meeting, Mao Zedong was elected as a candidate member of the Temporary Political Bureau of the Central Committee. Cai Hesen suggested that Mao Zedong stay in central work while Qu Qiubai wanted Mao Zedong to go to Shanghai Central. Mao Zedong disagreed, he said: "I want to go out and carry out an armed uprising, I don’t want to live in high-rise buildings with you, I want to make friends with the green forest friends in the mountains." 

On August 9, Mao Zedong attended a meeting of the Temporary Central Political Bureau. He criticized the wrong proposition of the Hunan organization following the Nanchang Uprising troops to Guangdong, he believed: "Hunan's mass organization is even larger than Guangdong, what is lacking is arms." He clearly proposed: "We need to form a division of armed forces in Hunan, occupy five or six counties, form a political base, and develop land revolution throughout the province." He believed that even if the autumn harvest uprising fails, there is no need to go to Guangdong, they should go to the mountains. 

In mid-August, Mao Zedong was sent to Hunan as a special representative of the Communist Party of China Central Committee to lead the Autumn Harvest Uprising. On August 18, Mao Zedong, at the provincial committee meeting in Changsha, expressed important views on the issues of uprising and land. He advocated: the development of the Autumn Harvest Uprising in Hunan is the solution to the land issue of the peasants.



He pointed out: to start a rebellion, the power of the peasants alone is not enough, there must be military assistance. The development of the rebellion is to seize political power. Our party's previous mistake was ignoring the military. Now we should focus 60% of our energy on military activities, seizing power on the basis of the gun's barrel and establishing government. He believed: to fully grasp the peasants, we must confiscate the landlord's land and give it to the peasants. On September 9, Mao Zedong launched the Autumn Harvest Uprising in Hunan. The obvious characteristic of this uprising was: a large number of workers and peasant armed forces participated; publicly raised the banner of the Workers' and Peasants' Revolutionary Army. The initial goal of the uprising was still to seize the central city of Changsha. When the plans of various rebel forces to attack Changsha were frustrated, Mao Zedong showed his ability to learn lessons from practice in a timely manner, decisively changed the original deployment at the Wen's city meeting, decided to "transfer troops", led the rebel forces "up the mountains", and sought foothold in the weakly defended mountainous areas under enemy control. So, the Autumn Harvest Uprising forces retreated towards Pingxiang, south along the Luoxiao Mountains. After the "Three Bays restructuring", by the end of October, Mao Zedong led the forces to Ziping, Jinggangshan. After getting up the mountain, under the leadership of the former committee headed by Mao Zedong, the troops deeply mobilized the masses, helped the locals recover, rectify and establish party organizations, carried out land reforms, established the Red Guards and the Workers' and Peasants' Revolutionary Government, widely launched guerrilla warfare, vigorously strengthened the Red Army construction, Jinggangshan became the first peasant revolutionary base in the country, sparking the sparks of "armed occupation of workers and peasants" in practice.

However, the revolutionary practice of establishing peasant revolutionary bases represented by Mao Zedong was not accepted by the whole party at that time and could not be accepted by the Comintern. Many people in the party doubted whether a small or several revolutionary bases could exist for a long time. Dogmatists denounced this great creation as "peasant consciousness". The Comintern believed that "the Workers and Peasants' Revolution is moving towards a new climax". The policy line of the Communist Party of China is to prepare for a new revolutionary climax, whose main task is to prepare for a "wide mobilization" between cities and towns and neighboring provinces and regions. Therefore, we must oppose the "disorderly, unconnected, doomed to fail guerrilla warfare". In response to the instructions of the Comintern on the adaptation between city and countryside, and neighboring provinces and regions, the CPC Central Committee made specific arrangements for Hunan Province, from Pingyue along the border of Xianggan to the main road to Xiangyue as the main line of rebellion, to complete the total rebellion of the province. They placed the armed forces of the revolutionary base of Jinggangshan in the middle section of the Luoxiao Mountains, built by Mao Zedong, under the total rebellion of the province, and ordered Mao Zedong to lead the troops to attack Xiangnan, to "expand" the base, and to unite with Xiangnan and Yuebei. At that time, Mao Zedong also thought that establishing bases in the countryside was to coincide with the uprising in the central city, what was different was that he could determine the work guidelines based on the specific situation at that time. Mao Zedong had different views from the instructions of the CPC Central Committee and the Hunan Provincial Committee. Mao Zedong believed that in periods when the ruling class's rule is temporarily stable, we should not adopt the policy of spreading troops to expand, but only adopt the policy of consolidation. Mao Zedong summarized the experience and lessons of armed uprisings all over the country since the "Eight Seven" meeting, listed six reasons to explain why the Red Fourth Army should not go to Hunan to "expand" the base, but should first consolidate the revolutionary base in the middle section of the Luoxiao Mountains, with which to "carry on a long-term struggle with the enemy". Mao Zedong emphasized the significance of consolidating the revolutionary base. He said: "This argument is by no means a conservative idea. In the past, the national rebellion, at one time was thriving, but as soon as the enemy counterattacked, it was like washing away water, and it was completely defeated. This is because it does not seek to consolidate the foundation for a while, but only seeks great momentum. At this moment we will correct this disease, on the one hand, establishing a base for the military, and on the other hand, establish a consolidated foundation for the future of the rebellion in Hunan and Jiangxi provinces.



"However, Mao Zedong's correct opinion was not accepted, resulting in the "August Failure" in southern Hunan. After the failure in southern Hunan, the “Left” doctrinaire, who has always considered himself correct, still criticised Mao Zedong, stating that his idea of consolidating base areas was a conservative concept, arguing that the Red Army could only find a way out by actively expanding outward and expanding the Soviet regime, and so on.



Contrary to the "Left" doctrinaire who were eager to seize power through uprisings in central cities, a right-wing pessimistic view emerged within the base areas. Some Communist Party members overestimated the enemy's strength, couldn't perceive the contradictions within the enemy's camp, especially when they were defeated or surrounded from all sides, or pursued by a strong enemy, they saw these local setbacks and difficulties as overall and fundamental ones, prompting them to ask, "How long can the Red flag last?" Mao Zedong stated that this was a fundamental question, and without addressing whether the base areas of the Chinese revolution and the Chinese Red Army could exist and develop, we cannot move forward. Mao Zedong used the basic principles of Marxist violent revolution, summarized the experiences of building rural revolutionary bases in Jinggangshan and other places, wrote "Why can the Chinese Red Regime Exist?" and "The Struggle of Jinggangshan", and proposed the idea of "armed independence of workers and peasants".

Firstly, Mao Zedong discussed the reasons and conditions for the existence and development of the Red regime. He said: "In one country, the long-term existence of one small or several small areas of Red regime within the surrounding of White regime, is something that has never happened in any other country in the world. The occurrence of this wonder has its unique reasons. And its existence and development also require appropriate conditions."

First, the political and economic development of China is unbalanced. China is a semi-colonial and semi-feudal country with unbalanced political and economic development. The power of the ruling class is mainly concentrated in the cities, while the rural areas are much weaker. As a semi-feudal country, the local self-sufficient agricultural economy gives China's rural areas a relative independence. The rural areas have less dependence on the city, providing the proletariat with the economic conditions to mobilize the peasants, carry out armed struggle, and establish a Red regime in the countryside. As a semi-colonial country, many imperialists compete and partition their spheres of influence in China, manifested as continuous division and conflict among warlords. The proletariat can use the contradictions, divisions, and wars among the warlords to establish and develop revolutionary bases, enabling the Red regime to emerge and persist surrounded on all sides by the White regime. Mao Zedong pointed out: “We only need to know that the division and war of China's White regime continues without interruption, then there is no doubt that the Red regime's occurrence, existence, and gradual development.” At the same time, because China is a large country, there is room for the revolutionary forces to maneuver; suitable for establishing the Red regime, suitable for the Red Army to fight in favorable terrain. Mao Zedong chose to establish a base in the central section of the Luoxiao Mountains because of its good terrain."



Secondly, there is a solid mass foundation. The first occurrence and the ability to persist for a long period of the Red regime are in those places that have been influenced by the first Civil Revolutionary War and had experienced a surge of mass revolutionary movements. Such areas (such as Hunan, Jiangxi, Hubei, Guangdong, etc.) were major areas where the Northern Expedition had been, had party organizations, and the party had considerable influence among the masses. Trade unions and peasant associations were organized, and the working and peasant masses had struggled against the comprador landlord class. In such places, both the people and the army have received political training from the democratic revolution, therefore, the Red regime easily occurred and persisted here for a long term.

Thirdly, a progressing revolutionary situation. Whether small local people's governments can persist for a long period depends on whether the national revolutionary situation is progressing. Mao Zedong believed that if the national revolutionary situation is progressing, then the development and long-term existence of small-scale red regimes is unquestionable. On the contrary, it would be impossible. Then is China's revolutionary situation developing or not? Mao Zedong believed that after the failure of the Great Revolution, none of the basic contradictions that led to the Chinese revolution were resolved. Therefore, "the current situation of the Chinese revolution continues to develop with the ongoing sectarianism and war of the domestic comprador bourgeoisie and the international bourgeoisie." So, the red areas will also continue to develop, gradually approaching the acquisition of national power.

Fourthly, the presence of a sizeable formal Red Army. Mao Zedong believed that the existence of a sizeable formal Red Army is a necessary condition for the existence of the Red regime. If there is only the Red Guards without the formal Red Army, it cannot deal with the reactionary armed forces, it cannot create a separatist situation, and even if it does separate, it will not be long-term and increasingly developmental separations. He emphasized that "the thought of 'workers and peasants armed secession' is an important idea that the Communist Party and the working and peasant masses in the divided areas must fully possess."

Fifthly, the correct leadership of the Communist Party. The "Workers and Peasants Armed Division" is a division under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party. The correct leadership of the Communist Party is a key factor in the existence and development of the Red regime. The border committee of the Hunan-Jiangxi border under the secretariat of Mao Zedong and the military commission under the secretariat of Chen Yi implemented the correct border policies, resolutely struggled against the enemy, created a government in the middle section of the Luoxiao Mountains, opposed escapism; carried out a deep land revolution in the separated areas; the party in the army helped the local party to develop, and the armed forces of the army helped the local armed development; took a defensive position against Hunan where the ruling power is relatively strong, took an offensive position against Jiangxi where the ruling power is relatively weak; used great efforts to construct Yongxin, created mass division, arranged for long-term struggle; concentrated the Red Army to counter possible enemies, opposed disbandment of troops, avoided being defeated one by one by the enemy; the expansion of the separated areas adopted a wave-like policy, opposed the policy of rash advance. In this way, there were various military victories from April to July in the base area of Jinggangshan. However, the blind directives from "left" dogmatists led to the "August Failure" in southern Hunan.



Among the five conditions, the first condition is the most important. It is precisely because of the semi-colonial and semi-feudal social nature of China that led to the imbalance in China's political and economic development, which provided the possibility of establishing a red regime. And it was based on the characteristics of China's social nature that Mao Zedong proposed a correct analysis of the reasons for the existence and development of the Red regime.

Secondly, Mao Zedong proposed the basic content of "armed worker-peasant separatism". What is "armed worker-peasant separatism"?
