It is the construction of a rural revolutionary base or a red regime with the principal content of land revolution under the leadership of the proletariat, with armed struggle as the main form, relying mainly on the revolutionary base, and land revolution as the main content.

Armed struggle is the main form of struggle in "armed worker-peasant separatism". Mao Zedong pointed out profoundly that China is a semi-colonial and semi-feudal country, without a democratic system internally, oppressed by the feudal system; without national independence externally, oppressed by imperialism. The enemies of the Chinese people - warlords, gentry, imperialism, all hold knives in their hands, ready to kill. In the face of such enemies, the main form of China's revolution must be armed. The revolution in China, which predominantly economic is agriculture, took the form of military development and uprising, which is a characteristic. Because without the armed forces, there can be no support for this separatism in the encirclement of the white regime from all sides. Mao Zedong stressed: The struggle at the border is entirely a military one, so both the party and the masses have to militarize. How to deal with the enemy? How to fight? Became the central issue in daily life. The so-called separatism must be armed. If there is no armed force in a place, or the armed force is not enough, or the strategy to deal with the enemy is wrong, the place will immediately be taken over by the enemy. Without armed struggle, there can be no existence of revolutionary base areas, no people's status, and there is no talk of the development of other tasks of the party. The party can only ensure the continuation of the farmer's land revolution, expand the separatist areas, construct and develop rural revolutionary bases by deeply mobilize the peasant masses and extensively carry out armed struggles.

The land revolution is the core content of "armed worker-peasant separatism". To carry out an anti-imperialist and anti-feudal democrat revolution, we must mobilize peasants to deeply initiate a land revolution, since the exploitation and oppression of the Chinese people by imperialism largely relies on the backward feudal relationships in the countryside. The destruction of the feudal system is a fatal blow to imperialist rule in China..



Mao Zedong pointed out clearly when he attended a meeting in Changsha, Hunan Province, to discuss and formulate the plan for the autumn harvest uprising: The purpose of the autumn harvest uprising was to thoroughly implement the land reform and solve the peasants' land problems with guns. After the situation of "armed rural areas by workers and peasants" was created in the Jinggang Mountains, land reform became a major part of the work in the areas. When the Red Army first arrived at the Jinggang Mountains, Mao Zedong primarily led the Red Army to mobilize the peasant masses, beat up the local tyrants, distributed their wealth, abolished debts and voided contracts, in preparation for land distribution. By May 20, 1928, when Mao Zedong chaired the first representative meeting of the Party at the Hunan-Jiangxi border, he proposed the task of vigorously carrying out land reform. After the conference, under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party's special committee and the border workers' and peasants' government, land reform committees were universally established at the county, district, and township levels, and policies for land distribution per capita at the township level were formulated. Thus, the land reform in the revolutionary bases of the Jinggang Mountains was vigorously carried out.

The land reform liberated the productivity of the countryside, greatly stimulated the enthusiasm for revolution and production among the vast number of peasants. It not only provided a source for the replenishment of the Red Army but also created material conditions for supporting the war of the Red Army, further strengthening and developing the situation of armed separations in rural areas at the Hunan-Jiangxi border.

The rural revolutionary base is the basic position of "armed separation of workers and peasants," it is the foothold and starting point for the victorious development of the revolution and the implementation of land reform. The fundamental problem of the revolution is the problem of power. The Party, in accordance with the national conditions of China, shifted the emphasis of its work from the urban areas to the rural areas and amassed and developed its forces there. The issues of opening up and establishing peasant revolutionary bases are essentially ones of seizing power, first in the countryside and then in the cities, first seizing local power and then seizing national power.

Mao Zedong attached great importance to the construction of revolutionary bases. He believed that such consolidations and developments of Red power, not only are conducive to land reform and armed struggle, but they can also create a group of talents for our Party. Mao Zedong was strongly opposed to the "fluid guerrilla warfare" that discarded the revolutionary bases. In his letter criticizing Lin Biao's wrongful views, he pointed out: Judging by the fact that in a period when the revolutionary climax is still far away, doing such hard work of establishing power seems to be in vain, and they prefer to use the relatively convenient method of fluid guerilla warfare to expand political influence, waiting until the work of mobilizing the masses nationwide is done well, or has reached a certain level, and then start a nationwide armed uprising. 

In conclusion, the thought of "armed separation of workers and peasants" articulated by Mao Zedong calls for under the leadership of the proletariat, primarily using armed struggle, taking land reform as the basic content, using the revolutionary base areas as strategic positions, and starting from this point, to achieve the fundamental goal of seizing national power. The armed struggle, land reform, and base area construction guided by the thought of the "armed separation of workers and peasants" are organically integrated and interconnected.



Without the armed struggle under the leadership of the proletariat, it is impossible to carry out effective land revolution, nor can we establish and develop revolutionary bases; without carrying out the land revolution, we cannot fully mobilize the vast peasants, and the armed struggle cannot obtain the support of millions of masses, and the base cannot be consolidated and developed; without the revolutionary base, the armed struggle will lose its foothold and fall into failure, and the achievements of the land revolution cannot be maintained. The thought of "The worker-peasant armed secession" incorporates these three inseparable aspects, including the basic content of Chinese democratic revolution, and also reflects the main form and fundamental purpose of Chinese democratic revolution. It is an extremely correct revolutionary thought guiding China's revolution to continue forward after the failure of the Great Revolution.

Mao Zedong's discussion on the conditions for the existence of the Red regime, the proposition of the concept of "worker-peasant armed secession", and the specific explanation of secession policy, have important theoretical and practical guiding significance. Mao Zedong scientifically answered the question "How long can the red flag be fought" raised in the base area; he succinctly summarized the main ways and methods of the party to lead the revolutionary struggle and accumulate and develop revolutionary forces at the time - relying on workers and peasants (mainly peasants), through armed struggle, to establish and develop rural revolutionary bases, as a formula. This is not only a summary of the results of the party's exploration of revolutionary roads in the previous stage but also laid the foundation for the later complete formation of the "encirclement of the city by the countryside" theory; the specific policy provisions provided reference for the development and consolidation of other revolutionary bases. In April 1929, Mao Zedong drafted a letter to the center for the Red Fourth Army's front committee, proposing a plan to win the whole of Jiangxi through quadrilateral secession. The deployment is: under the revolutionary forces in northern, western, southern, and eastern Jiangxi has "created a situation of encircling Nanchang", "decide in the early stages of the Kuomintang's melee, with more than 20 counties in western Fujian and southern Jiangxi as the scope, and use guerrilla tactics to mobilize the masses, so that the masses openly secession, deeply into the land revolution, establish the government of the workers and peasants, from this secession and Hunan Jiangxi border secession connection, form a strong force, as the foundation for forward", and then strive for the whole Jiangxi, while including west Fujian, west Zhejiang, time for a year. In September, the first representative meeting of the Communist Party of Western Fujian made a plan for the future of "the worker-peasant armed secession" in Western Fujian. Among them, for the "party and government and mass development methods", the following three points have been strongly put forward: First, "establish a central work area", "as the base for the development of the whole Western Fujian", "a county should also have a central work area, as a county development's base" Second, eliminate the gap between the red areas, so that they "mutually belong" . Third, "rely on the existing work place like a wave forward, do not be unrelated to the advance". The above two documents specifically plan how to implement the "worker-peasant armed secession" in one region and one province. The principles put forward by the two documents that need to be noted, such as establishing a solid "central area" as a base for continuing to advance, the development of the base must "rely on" the existing areas and gradually connect the neighboring areas of secession, and the provisions on the content of the struggle in the secession area, are all a summary of practical struggle experience and enrich the thought of "worker-peasant armed secession".



The worker-peasant armed secession is an important content of the road to encircling the cities from the countryside, but its implementation does not mean the complete formation of the revolutionary road to encircling the cities from the countryside. Because there are two problems to be solved: First, where should the focus of the party's work be? Is it to promote the national revolutionary climax and seize the national power with the city struggle as the main? Or is it to take the rural worker-peasant armed secession as the main and take the road of encircling the cities from the countryside? Second, how should the role of the rural base in seizing the national power be estimated, is it considered as a decisive factor, or just as an auxiliary factor? Without resolving these two problems, the persistence and development of the new road are impossible.



The development of the revolutionary situation promoted the progressive understanding of the Chinese revolutionary path by the Chinese Communists, represented by Mao Zedong. The Sixth National Congress of the Party affirmed Mao Zedong's practice of establishing bases. Later, in September 1929, Zhou Enlai, on behalf of the Central Committee, issued an instruction letter to the Red Fourth Army Forward Committee, hereafter referred to as the "September Letter." The letter affirmed Mao Zedong’s notion of the "armed segregation of workers and farmers." It pointed out, "First there was the Red Army, then urban political power. This is a characteristic of the Chinese revolution and a product of China's economic foundation." 

The letter supported Mao Zedong's strategy for Red Army operations, strengthening the construction of the Red Army, correcting non-proletarian thinking within the party, and advocating for establishing a strong people's army under the leadership of the Communist Party. In accordance with the spirit of the "September Letter" from the Party Central Committee, the Red Fourth Army convened the Gutian Conference in Shanghang, Fujian in December 1929, outlining a clear direction for army and party construction. During the process of moving to bases in southern Jiangxi and western Fujian, situations and experiences from other rural bases, such as those led by Fang Zhimin in the Min Zhe Gan region and He Long in the Western Hunan-Hubei region, were continuously conveyed to the Red Fourth Army. These experiences greatly broadened Mao Zedong's Vision, and made a new leap in his understanding of the Chinese revolutionary path, further strengthening his view that the Chinese revolution must take the path of encircling the city from the countryside. 

However, at that time, there was a wrong tendency in the party to dogmatize Marxism-Leninism and sanctify the instructions of the Communist International. They lacked an understanding of China's revolutionary path of encircling cities from the countryside. For a while, some leaders of the Communist International and the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China had a rather pessimistic mood about the revolutionary situation at that time, which was reflected in the Central Committee's February letter. They believe that the climax of the revolution would not come, and the Red Army should be divided into small groups, scattered among the rural areas, with Zhu De and Mao Zedong leaving the troops and hiding the greater goals. 

This pessimistic thinking also had an impact on the Red Fourth Army. Lin Biao, who was the commander of the column at the time, was one of the representatives. His mood was quite apparent at the Ruijin Conference on May 18, 1929. Lin Biao believed that the revolutionary situation was "not optimistic," the future was "very vague," and the current work of establishing Red political power in the countryside, and carrying out the land revolution in-depth, was "in vain". He proposed to replace the establishment of revolutionary bases with a "mobile guerrilla" campaign to influence the masses. When the mobilization of the masses reached a certain level, a national armed uprising would occur, and revolution would be victorious. This shows that there was still a lack of correct understanding of the strategic development situation and path to victory of the Chinese revolution within the Party and the Army. 

To answer these concerns, Mao Zedong wrote a long letter to Lin Biao in January 1930, which is the article "A Single Spark Can Start a Prairie Fire." The article systematically expounds the strategic significance of establishing rural bases for the Chinese revolution. The main content and significance of the article are as follows: 

It clearly states that, according to China's national conditions, the path of launching a national armed uprising with the city as the center is not suitable for China, and China must find its own path. At the beginning of the article, Mao Zedong states that, "Regarding the estimation of the current situation and the accompanying questions of our actions, there is still a lack of correct understanding among some comrades in our party." They do not believe that the climax of the revolution can come quickly and lack the profound idea of establishing Red Power in guerilla zones to promote the arrival of the national revolution. They seem to think that it is futile to do the arduous task of establishing political power during the period when the critical point of the revolution is still far away, and they hope to use relatively easy mobile guerilla tactics to expand political influence. When the work of winning over the masses throughout the country is done, or reaches a certain point, a national armed uprising can then be launched. At that time, the power of the Red Army will be added to achieve a major revolution on a national scale.

The theory of first winning over the masses and then establishing political power, which involves all places nationwide, is not suitable for the actual situation of the Chinese revolution.



"Mao Zedong analyzed the origins of this theory, mainly because he did not clearly understand China's national conditions, and did not consider issues from the perspective of China's national conditions. Further, he argued the necessity to establish and develop revolutionary bases and red power, and proposed a rural-focused ideology. Mao Zedong analyzed China as a semi-colonial and semi-feudal country struggle over by various imperialist countries, and pointed out that this created a scenario of constant warfare among China's ruling classes. This, in turn, created opportunities to establish revolutionary bases in the vast rural areas, enabling the Red Army and revolutionary power to exist and grow for extended periods. Mao Zedong emphasized the need and significance of establishing bases and systematically building power, implementing thorough land reform, and expanding the armed forces of workers and peasants. He argued that this last aspect represented the highest form of peasant struggle in semi-colonial China under the leadership of the proletariat, and an inevitable development of the peasant struggle in semi-colonial China; and unequivocally represents the most important factor promoting the climax of the nationwide revolution. Only in this way can the faith of the masses be established in the revolution, as seen in the Soviet Union. Only in this manner can there be tremendous difficulties for the ruling classes, shake their foundations, and promote their decomposition. This is also necessary to truly create the Red Army, becoming the main tool for the future grand revolution. In summary, it is essential to promote the climax of the revolution. This is because peasants represent over 80% of the national population and are the main force in China's revolution. The Chinese proletariat, aiming to achieve an anti-imperialist and anti-feudalism mission, need to solve the central issue of democratic revolution, which is the peasants' land issue. They must rely on peasants, organize the peasants, and elevate peasants' struggle to the highest form of violent seizure of power. The revolutionary war led by the Chinese proletariat is effectively a war with peasants as the main body. Mao Zedong's proposition of 'the most important factor' and the four 'must do such' has clarifies the relationship between the armed establishment of workers and peasants and the success of the national revolution. As Zhou Enlai mentioned in his research on 'the sixth', Mao Zedong's ideas advocate for focusing on rural areas and require the party to shift their focus from the cities to the countryside, becoming a new starting point for the grand revolution. This is followed by analyses of a series of contradictions in China at the time, demonstrating that the trend of 'A Single Spark Can Start a Prairie Fire' during the Chinese revolution is inevitable.

Mao Zedong pointed out that when evaluating the political situation in China, there's a need to analyze in view of the comprehensive, interconnected development. Things must be looked at their essence, not to be confused by the phenomena. He analyzed the subjective forces and the anti-revolutionary forces of the Chinese revolution specifically, stating that in contemporary China, while the subjective forces of the revolution may be weaker, the anti-revolutionary forces based on China’s feeble socio-economic organization are also relatively weak. Therefore, the climax of China's revolution will undoubtedly be faster than that in Western Europe. And we must look at its essence when viewing things. As long as a detailed inspection of the various contradictions leading to the climax of the Chinese revolution and their forward development is made, one will understand that the arrival of the climax of the Chinese revolution is inevitable and will not be confused by surface phenomena. Mao Zedong critically analyzed the contradictions between the people and imperialism and feudalism after the failure of the revolution in 1927, which none of those were resolved, and the contradictions among rulers could not be reconciled. The vast majority of workers, peasants, petty bourgeoisie, and student youths yearned for revolution, including mutiny from soldiers in the reactionary army of the Kuomintang. China was filled with kindling on a national scale, which would soon ignite a raging fire. The trend of 'A Single Spark Can Start a Prairie Fire' is unstoppable. The time from 'A Single Spark Can Start a Prairie Fire' is undoubtedly near. Mao Zedong criticized the pessimistic outlook of the Red Army and the Party, including a pessimistic letter from the Central Committee in February, as they failed to grasp the essence of the political situation. At the same time, he pointed out that Marxists are not fortunetellers. Future development and changes should only provide a broad direction. It should never mechanically dictate the time and day."



But the approaching climax of the Chinese revolution is indeed like standing at the summit of a mountain, looking far into the east to see the radiant and burgeoning dawn. It's not hard to see that Mao Zedong in "A Single Spark Can Start a Prairie Fire," for the characteristics of Chinese society, the characteristics of the Chinese revolution and its laws, has made a new leap in understanding. He not only further answered the possibility of the existence and development of the Chinese Red Regime but also revealed the necessity of the existence and development of the Chinese Red Regime. He proposed from both positive and negative aspects that when the Chinese revolution was defeated by powerful enemies in the city and could not win the national revolution with the city as the center, the focus of party work must be on the countryside rather than the city, marking the beginning of Mao Zedong's theory of rural encirclement of cities.

Secondly, a comprehensive exposition of the theory of rural encapsulation of cities. In May 1930, Mao Zedong's article "Against Bookism" further answered the Marxist debate on the Chinese revolution's path within the Party from an elevated ideological line. He exposed and criticized the mistakes of the "left" doctrinaires who dogmatized and sacralized the road of urban armed uprising in the October Revolution in Russia and opposed this with the rural road encircling the cities. He explicitly put forward the theoretical basis for the road around the city. The article pointed out: "The victory of the Chinese revolutionary struggle depends on the Chinese comrades' understanding of the Chinese situation," "Without investigation, there is no right to speak." He criticized the bad style of theory being divorced from practice and "blind talking" within the party.

After initially confirming that the focus of party work is on rural areas, establishing rural revolutionary bases, and conducting thorough land reforms within rural revolutionary bases, Mao Zedong summarized his experience in party building, state-building, and army building and proposed a series of new policies and guidelines. This constitutes the main content of the comprehensive theory of rural encirclement of cities. In January 1935, the Zunyi Conference confirmed Mao Zedong's correct leadership, opening up a new situation for the Chinese revolution. In December 1936, Mao Zedong wrote "Problems of Strategy in China's Revolutionary War," which comprehensively discussed the characteristics of China's revolutionary war, explained the uneven law of political and economic development in semi-colonial China, and concluded that China's revolutionary war is possible to develop and win. It determined a whole set of military strategies and tactics for rural areas to surround the cities, such as active defense, anti-encirclement preparations, strategic retreat, strategic counterattack, concentration of forces, mobile warfare, fast warfare, annihilation warfare, etc. Mao Zedong, in his book, reiterated the objective and subjective conditions for the existence and development of China's rural revolutionary bases from a new perspective: "China is a large country — 'the East is not bright and the West is bright, it is dark in the South and there is the North,' there is no shortage of room for maneuver," which is an important geographical condition. The implementation of land reform and equality between officers and soldiers can gain farmers' support and the support of the Red Army, which is an important basis for popular support. The Communist Party adopted correct strategic tactics, which is a fundamental guarantee for exerting subjective initiative and achieving revolutionary victory. Mao Zedong's discussion also constitutes an important part of the theory of rural encirclement of cities in China. In July 1937, Mao Zedong wrote "On Practice," and in August he completed "On Contradiction" which clarified the dependency of theory on practice from the epistemological height, and the correct methods of analyzing and solving problems, deeply exposing the ideological roots of dogmatism and the serious harm it does to the revolutionary cause, laying a philosophical foundation for the theory of rural encirclement of cities. By this point, Mao Zedong's systematic and complete explanation of the theory of rural encirclement of cities marked the complete formation of the theory of rural encirclement of cities.

After the outbreak of the Anti-Japanese War, during the Anti-Japanese War and the Liberation War, Mao Zedong's theory of the revolutionary road of rural encirclement of cities has greatly developed.



In response to the new situation of the Anti-Japanese War, in late August 1937, the LuoChuan Conference of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China correctly formulated the principles of independent guerrilla warfare in the mountains, deciding to vigorously organize guerrilla warfare behind enemy lines, mobilize the masses, and widely establish rural anti-Japanese bases behind enemy lines. The Central Committee of the Party, represented by Mao Zedong, resisted the tendency of Wang Ming to shift the focus of the party's work back to cities and other right-wing errors, consciously placing the party's focus in the vast rural areas based on the actual situation of the Anti-Japanese War. 

In May 1938, Mao Zedong emphasized the issue of establishing the base area of ​​anti-Japanese guerrilla warfare in "Strategic Issues of Anti-Japanese Guerrilla Warfare". He pointed out the necessity and importance of setting up bases for anti-Japanese guerrilla warfare: due to the long and brutal nature of the Anti-Japanese War, it would be impossible to maintain guerrilla warfare behind enemy lines without a base. The base of guerrilla warfare is the strategic base for fulfilling its strategic mission, achieving the goals of preserving and developing itself, and eliminating and driving out the enemy. Without such a strategic base, the execution of all strategic tasks and the realization of the war goals would lose their foundation. Therefore, completely overcoming banditry from the minds of guerrilla warfare leaders is a prerequisite for establishing the policy of building base areas. He proposed that temporary bases should be established in mountainous, flat, and river port areas where enemy rule is weak, and these bases could become more stable over time. 

In October of the same year, Mao Zedong specifically analyzed the conditions of the trinity in China in "New Stage": First, the semi-colonial cities could not completely rule the countryside; second, China is a large country with a wide area for guerrilla activities; third, there are people's armies and crowds led by the Communist Party. These three conditions, with the wide and protracted war that we organized and persisted, can resist the enemy occupying the city, with a crisscross war that will surround and isolate the city, grow our strength gradually from long-term warfare, change the enemy's situation, and then coordinate with changes in the world to drive the enemy out and restore the city. Mao Zedong also pointed out that due to these three conditions, the countryside will definitely defeat the city.

China's armed struggle must follow the path of rural areas surrounding cities, which is a characteristic of the Chinese revolution and is determined by China's economic base. China's economic base is different from that of capitalist countries. The economic base of capitalist countries is dominated by the capitalist mode of production, and the center of the economic base is in the cities; China's economic base is mainly the backward feudal mode of production scattered in the countryside. After the failure of the Great Revolution, due to the more brutal rule of the new warlords of the Kuomintang, the revolutionary forces in the cities were repeatedly severely damaged. Therefore, the weak revolutionary forces in the city cannot make armed uprisings and final battles with the enemy who has an absolute advantage. The main target of the proletarian revolution in capitalist countries is the bourgeoisie concentrated in the cities, and the main driving force of the revolution is the working class concentrated in the cities; one of the main targets of the Chinese revolution is the feudal landlord class scattered in the countryside, and the main driving force of the revolution is the peasantry under the leadership of the working class. This has determined that China's revolution is first composed of the Red Army in rural areas, and later the city authority. Therefore, Mao Zedong made a clearer summary of the issue of the Chinese revolution in "War and Strategy Issues" in November 1938. He pointed out: In capitalist countries, the proletarian party can win over the masses through a long period of legal struggle. When the time comes for uprising and war, they firstly occupy the big cities and then attack the countryside. China is different in this regard.



The characteristics of China are: it is not an independent democratic country, but a semi-colonial and semi-feudal country; it does not have a democratic system internally and is oppressed by the feudal system; it lacks national independence externally and is oppressed by imperialism. Therefore, there is no parliament to exploit, and there is no legal right for workers to organize strikes. Here, the task of the Communist Party is essentially not to enter into an uprising and war through a long-term legal struggle, nor to take the cities before taking the villages, but to go the opposite way. In December 1939, Mao Zedong continued to elucidate the issue of China's revolutionary road in "The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party". He pointed out: the ranks of the Chinese revolution must prepare, accumulate and temper their strengths and avoid decisive battles with powerful enemies when their strength is insufficient, "it is necessary to transform the backward rural areas into advanced and solid bases, and create great revolutionary positions militarily, politically, economically, and culturally to oppose the vicious enemies who use cities to attack rural areas, and gradually strive for complete revolutionary victory in prolonged battles." He also pointed out: "Due to the uneven development of China's economy (not a unified capitalist economy), the vastness of China's land (there is room for the revolution to maneuver), the lack of unity within the anti-revolutionary camps in China and various contradictions, and because the main force of the Chinese revolution, the peasantry, is led by the Communist Party, the proletariat's political party, this has resulted in prospects of initial success in rural areas for the Chinese revolution on the one hand, and on the other hand, it results in the uneven development of the revolution, which brings long-term and arduous tasks to achieve complete revolutionary victory. It can therefore be understood that the prolonged revolutionary struggle taking place in these revolutionary bases consists primarily of guerrilla warfare led by the Chinese Communist Party among the peasants. Therefore, neglecting the standpoint of establishing rural areas as revolutionary bases, the standpoint of hard work among the peasants, and the standpoint of guerrilla warfare are all incorrect." However, emphasizing the work in rural areas does not mean that the work in cities and other rural areas under enemy control can be abandoned. On the contrary, without work in cities and other rural areas, the rural bases would be isolated and the revolution would fail. Furthermore, the ultimate goal of the revolution is to seize the cities, which are the main bases of the enemy, and without sufficient work in the cities, this goal cannot be achieved. These arguments enrich Mao Zedong's theory of the countryside surrounding the city. The path of armed seizure of power by surrounding the city with the countryside, created by the Chinese Communists, represented by Mao Zedong, had been widely spread across many parts of the country by the time of the Anti-Japanese War, and it became the only correct path towards final victory in the Anti-Japanese War. The theory of the countryside surrounding the city and armed seizure of power also received a comprehensive explanation. Its main content is: firstly, China's national conditions determine that China's revolution must take the path of the countryside surrounding the city and armed seizure of power. Mao pointed out that the central task and highest form of the revolution is the armed seizure of power and resolution of issues through war, which is universally correct as a principle of Marxist-Leninist revolution. In capitalist countries, there is no internal feudal system, but a bourgeois democratic system; there is no foreign national oppression, but oppression of other nations by their own. Based on these characteristics, the task of the proletariat's political parties in capitalist countries is to educate workers through long-term legal struggles, breed strength, and prepare to finally overthrow capitalism. However, China is not an independent democratic country but a semi-colonial and semi-feudal country; it is oppressed by imperialism internally and does not have a democratic system. There is no parliament to exploit, and there is no legal right for workers to organize strikes.



Therefore, in China, the primary form of struggle is war, and the principal form of organization is the army. The task of the Communist Party is not essentially to enter insurrection and war through prolonged legal struggle, nor is it to take the cities before the countryside but to take the opposite path. The focus must be on the rural areas, accumulating and developing strength in the vast rural regions where enemy rule is weak, and preparing to seize power through armed struggle in the end.

Secondly, to follow the path of encircling the cities from the countryside and seize power with armed forces, we must establish solid rural bases. Mao Zedong pointed out that if the revolutionary forces are unwilling to compromise with imperialism and its running dogs, and instead, insist on struggling hard; if they want to accumulate and hone their strength and avoid decisive battles with powerful enemies when they are not strong enough, they must turn the backward rural areas into advanced solid bases—great revolutionary positions in military, political, economic, and cultural aspects—to fight against the brutal enemy who uses cities to attack rural areas and gradually achieve complete revolutionary victory in long-term battles.

Thirdly, the relationship between rural struggle and urban struggle must be handled correctly. Mao Zedong pointed out that focusing on the rural struggle does not mean ignoring the urban struggle, nor does it mean rejecting other forms of struggle beyond armed struggle. Without the coordination of various forms of struggle beyond armed struggle, the armed struggle cannot succeed. Similarly, without city work and other works, the rural base would be isolated, and the revolution would fail. The relationship between rural struggle and urban struggle is that the former is primary, and the latter is secondary. The city's struggle should assist the rural struggle. The party's city struggle should be defensive, making maximum use of legal means to organize the masses and carry out the struggle. The guideline for the party's work in the white area is "to hide excellence, dwell in the long-term, accumulate strength, and wait for the right opportunity."

In the later stage of the Liberation War, the People's War of Liberation entered the stage of strategic decisive battle. According to Mao Zedong's concept of encircling the cities from the countryside and finally seizing the cities, the Chinese People's Liberation Army gradually completed the task of encircling and seizing the cities in blocks and fragments all over the country. In practice, according to Mao Zedong's idea, first seize the small cities occupied by the enemy, then the medium cities occupied by the enemy, and finally the big cities occupied by the enemy. In the seizure of cities, the Communist Party and the People's Liberation Army also created two ways in Tianjin and Beiping, namely, armed seizure and peaceful liberation. Mao Zedong's great strategic thinking and revolutionary practice during the Liberation War further enriched and developed the idea of encircling the cities from the countryside and finally seizing the cities.

Represented by Mao Zedong, the Chinese Communists, starting from the actual conditions of China as a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, pragmatically broke the shackles of dogmatism. They creatively formed a relatively complete theory about agricultural and peasant armed separatism, the establishment of red power, the formation of the Party and the army in rural areas, the implementation of land revolution and the strategy and tactics to be adopted, on the basis of theory and practice. This theory revealed the objective law of the development of China's revolution, opened up a new path to seize power by arms, ensured the victory of China's New Democratic Revolution, and embodied the first historical leap in the integration of Marxism-Leninism with Chinese revolutionary practice during the period of Democratic Revolution. The path of encircling the cities from the countryside and seizing national power by armed forces is a path never mentioned in the classic works of Marx, Engels, Lenin, and others, and it is also a new path in the history of the proletarian revolution.



It is a glorious exemplification of the unique combination of the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism, such as the proletarian violent revolution, state power, alliance of workers and peasants, and the uneven political and economic development of imperialist states, with the specific practice of the Chinese revolution. It is another great feat in the proletarian revolutionary movement following the October Revolution in Russia. The theory of rural areas surrounding the cities and armed seizures of national power occupies an extremely significant position in the history of Mao Zedong's thought development.



After the failure of the Great Revolution in 1927, the focus of the work of the Communist Party of China shifted from cities to rural areas, and the armed separatism of the base areas began. Represented by Mao Zedong, the Communists of China began their arduous practice and theoretical analysis of base area construction after they opened up the first revolutionary base in Jinggangshan, putting forward a series of unique insights in the construction of political power, economy, and culture. They formed a relatively correct theory of base area construction.

Thoughts on the Construction of Political Power

After the Autumn Harvest Uprising troops arrived in the Jinggangshan area, they began the work of constructing political power. On November 28th, 1927, the Tea Ling County Worker-Peasant-Soldier Government was established, with Tan Zhenlin as the chairman. The Sui Dynasty County Worker-Peasant-Soldier Government was established in January 1928. In February, the Ninggang County Worker-Peasant-Soldier Government was established. Subsequently, the worker-peasant-soldier governments in Yongxin and Lianhua counties were also established in succession. People's political power was established in the townships of all counties. In May, on the basis of the various Worker-Peasant-Soldier Governments, the Xianggan Border Worker-Peasant-Soldier Soviet government was established. On November 25th, Mao Zedong concentrated collective wisdom and summarized the experience of building political power over the past year in a report to the CCP Central Committee titled "The Struggle in Jinggangshan," where he elucidated the following basic ideas:



Mao Zedong pointed out: the political power of the people in all levels of counties, districts and towns is organized universally, but it is only nominal. Many places do not hold workers, peasants, and soldiers' congresses. District and county levels, and especially the executive committees of the government, are all elected in a mass meeting manner. A hastily convened mass meeting cannot discuss problems and cannot give the masses political training. On the other hand, it is most convenient for opportunists to manipulate. Although some places have convened representative meetings, after the elections, all powers are concentrated in the committee, and the representative meeting is not mentioned again. He said the reason for this is the lack of propaganda and education about this new political system. Feudal dictatorship deeply ingrained in the minds of the masses and even ordinary party members has not been completely eradicated. When encountering problems, they seek convenience and dislike cumbersome democracy.




To this end, Mao Zedong proposed that the democratic system must be implemented, and a detailed organizational law for representatives at all levels should be formulated. This is the earliest idea of Mao Zedong to implement the people's congress system.

Mao Zedong pointed out that the democracy of the working people's dictatorship, "is the people's own power, it relies directly on the people, its relationship with the people must be kept highly engaged", and "its power also relies entirely on the people". At that time, the system of democratic centralism was not only in the Representative Assembly, but also in the Executive Committee, that is, "it was not used to it in government work". Mao Zedong emphasized: "The system of democratic centralism must show its effect in the revolutionary struggle so that the masses understand that it is the most able to mobilize the power of the masses and is most conducive to the struggle. Only then can it be truly and widely applied to mass organizations." He summed up the experience of the revolutionary base areas in carrying out the democratic centralist system over the past few years, especially the full development of people's democracy experience, affirmed the effective methods of developing people's democracy in the base areas over the years. He emphasized the importance of adhering to the principle of democratic centralism in the construction of base area political power.

In the construction of political power in Jinggangshan area, the prestige of the Communist Party of China is relatively high, and the functions of the government are not well played, which has resulted in the phenomenon of party replacing government; at the same time, there are no organizations of the Communist Party in the political organs of some places. To overcome these two phenomena, Mao Zedong pointed out: "In the future, the party should undertake the task of leading the government; the party's claims and methods, except for propaganda, must be implemented through government organizations." The All-China Soviet of Workers and Peasants' Deputies, held in Ruijin, Jiangxi Province in November 1931, established a Workers' and Peasants' Democratic Regime - the Provisional Central Government of the Republic of China, elected a Central Executive Committee and the People's Commissariat with Mao Zedong as Chairman and passed the first constitution in the history of revolutionary base areas—The Outline of Constitution of the Republic of China. The Constitution stipulates: "All Soviet power belongs to the workers, peasants, Red Army soldiers and all working people", the constitution also does not recognize all political and economic privileges of imperialism in China, abolition of all unequal treaties. All properties of imperialism in China are "owned by the state". The National Soviet of Workers and Peasants is the highest centralized authority of Soviet power. During the closing of the conference, the Esczecutive Committee of the Soviet Central is the supreme authority. The Executive Committee organizes the People's Commissariat to handle daily affairs. In January 1934, the Second National Delegates Congress of the Chinese Soviet was held in Jiangxi province. Mao Zedong made a report to the congress on "Care for the Masses' Life, Concentrate on the Work Method" and passed "The Outline of the Constitution of the Republic of China", reelected the Executive Committee of the Soviet Government of China. Mao Zedong still served as chairman. Mao Zedong, during his chairmanship of the government, emphasized the following thoughts on the construction of political power:
First, the idea of combining democracy and dictatorship.

Mao Zedong pointed out that the broadest democracy of the Soviets is firstly manifested in its elections. The Soviets extended full voting and candidacy rights to all formerly exploited and oppressed nationalities, establishing equal rights for women and men. Secondly, Soviet democracy is seen in urban and rural representative assemblies: the urban and rural assembly system is the foundation of the Soviets, serving as a mechanism to closely connect the Soviets with the general public. Moreover, Soviet democracy offers all revolutionary public complete freedom to assemble, associate, express, and publish, as well as to strike, and encourages extensive public supervision and criticism of their work. Mao particularly emphasized the role of the People's Congress, enabling the people to fully exercise their power as masters of their own homes. In general, he believed that the Soviet system embodies a very broad revolutionary democracy for the general public, but within this democracy, the vast majority of its power consists of millions of proletarian believers who are conscious of their needs. The Soviets used this power to establish their dictatorship, organize revolutionary wars, organize Soviet courts, launch fierce attacks on class enemies from all sides, and the Soviet courts played a significant role in cracking down on counter-revolutionary activities within the Soviet territory.

Secondly, the thought of caring about the public's life. Mao Zedong pointed out that our current central task is to mobilize the broad masses to participate in revolutionary struggle, to overthrow imperialism and the Kuomintang with revolutionary warfare, to extend the revolution nationwide, and to oust imperialism from China. Therefore, it is crucial to gain the endorsement and support of the majority of the public. He said: to win over the public's endorsement? To get the public to lend their full strength to the front lines? In that case, we must be with the people, we need to arouse the initiative of the people, we need to care about the people's concerns and needs; we need to genuinely seek benefits for the people and solve people's production and life issues: the issue of salt, rice, housing, clothing, bringing up children, etc., to solve all the problems of the people. If we do so, the broad mass will surely endorse us, treat the revolution as their life and take the revolution as their most glorious flag. Mao Zedong also said: what is the real copper wall and iron bulwark? It is the masses, millions of people wholeheartedly endorsing the revolution. This real copper wall and iron bulwark, no force can ever break through, absolutely impervious. The counterrevolutionaries cannot break us, but we must break the counter-revolutionaries. Mao Zedong confidently stated: unite millions of masses around the revolutionary government, develop our revolutionary war, and we can eliminate all counter-revolutions, we can take over all of China.

Thirdly, the thought of paying attention to work methods. Mao Zedong pointed out that we are the leaders and organizers of the revolutionary war, and we are also the leaders and organizers of the public life. Here the issue of working methods is seriously posed to us. Therefore, "not only do we have to propose tasks, but we have to solve the problem of methods to accomplish tasks". "Without solving the method problem, it’s just empty talk. Without paying attention to the leadership of expanding the Red Army, and without a scrupulous method of expanding the Red Army, even if you chant the expansion of the Red Army a thousand times, the result will still be unsuccessful". Mao Zedong also proposed a method of work where the advanced lead the latecomers. He said: "In all the places we lead, there is undoubtedly a good number of active cadres, and many good working comrades have emerged from the masses..."



These comrades bear a responsibility, that is, they should help those places where work is weak and assist those who are still not good at their jobs. "We must use practical methods to improve our work. Advanced places should move further ahead, and backward places should catch up with advanced ones. Only in this way can we crush the enemy's "siege" and overthrow the rule of imperialism and the Kuomintang throughout the country.



Economic construction is the main task of building revolutionary bases. Mao Zedong, starting from the actual situation of production conditions, production level, and economic structure of rural revolutionary bases, and considering the needs of the revolutionary war, summarized the experience of economic construction in revolutionary bases while building the political power, and put forward some valuable thoughts on the economic construction of revolutionary bases. In October 1928, the second representative conference of the Party in the Hunan-Jiangxi border area adopted the resolution drafted by Mao Zedong. The first part of the resolution is "Why can the Red Political Power in China Exist?", which brought up the experience issue of revolutionary bases under the siege of white forces "worth the attention of every party member". At that time, the shortage of daily necessities and cash in the revolutionary base "has become a big problem". He emphasized: "If the border area party does not have a suitable method for economic problems and the enemy's power is still stable for a relatively long period, separatism will encounter great difficulties. The considerable solution to this economic problem is really worth the attention of every party member." During his leadership of the work of the Interim Central Government of the Chinese Soviet Republic, Mao Zedong led the economic construction of the central base, summarized the experience of economic construction work, and published important works such as "We Must Pay Attention to Economic Work" and "Our Economic Policy", elaborating on the thoughts on the economic construction of revolutionary bases.

First, he expounded on the importance of economic construction in revolutionary bases and criticized the wrong views on economic construction. Mao Zedong pointed out: “The intense development of the revolutionary war requires us to mobilize the masses to immediately carry out economic movements on the economic front and undertake necessary and possible economic construction projects. Why? All our work now should be for the victory of the revolutionary war, first of all for the complete victory of the war to smash the enemy's fifth 'siege'; for the struggle for material conditions to guarantee the supply and supply of the Red Army; for improving the lives of the masses, thereby further arousing the enthusiasm of the masses to participate in the revolutionary war; for organizing the vast masses of people on the economic front and educating them to gain new mass strength for the war; for consolidating the alliance of workers and peasants from economic construction, to strengthen the dictatorship of the proletariat and peasants, to strengthen the leadership of the proletariat. For all this, it is necessary to carry out construction work in the economic field.” For this reason, Mao Zedong criticized two kinds of wrong views on economic construction: one view "believes that economic construction should not be carried out in the environment of the revolutionary war, which is extremely wrong". He pointed out that if they do not understand, if they do not carry out economic construction, the material conditions of the revolutionary war cannot be guaranteed, the people will feel fatigue in the protracted war, it will not break the enemy's economic blockade of our base, the people's life will not improve, and thus, the revolutionary war cannot proceed smoothly, and the alliance between workers and peasants will be affected. Another viewpoint “believes that economic construction has become the center of all tasks at the moment, neglecting the revolutionary war and undertaking economic construction away from the revolutionary war, which is also wrong.” Mao Zedong pointed out: “At the current stage, economic construction must revolve around the central task of the revolutionary war. The revolutionary war is the central task at present, and economic construction is for it, revolves around it, and is subordinate to it." "Only after the end of the civil war can it be said, and it should be said, that economic construction is the center of all tasks." Mao Zedong clearly explained the dialectical relationship between economic construction and revolutionary war here.



Secondly, it correctly stipulates the economic policy and principles of the revolutionary base. After 1931, the labor and taxation policies implemented by the "left" adventurists represented by Wang Ming caused great damage to the industry and commerce within the rural revolutionary base, causing serious difficulties for military and civilian supplies. This aroused doubt and dissatisfaction among many party members. In 1933, Zhang Wentian, Chen Yun and others published articles criticizing this "leftist" mistake. They pointed out that if the current policy of "eating up capital first" is adopted, the Soviet economy will inevitably wither, workers will become unemployed, and the lives of workers will deteriorate. This policy essentially represents the small bourgeoisie consciousness of a part of backward workers and the narrow trade unionist interests of some workers. In January 1934, Mao Zedong made a report at the Second National Delegates of Workers and Peasants, and further pointed out when discussing the economic policy of the rural revolutionary base: "Our current state-owned economy consists of state-owned enterprises, cooperative enterprises, and private enterprises." " We not only do not stop but also encourage and reward private economy as long as it does not exceed the scope of government law. Because the development of private economy at present is needed for the interests of the state and the people. Undoubtedly, the private economy is currently absolutely dominant and will remain dominant for a considerable period of time." "The development of state-owned economy as much as possible and the large-scale development of cooperative economy should be carried out simultaneously with the encouragement of private economy." " When the cooperative economy and the state-owned economy work together, they will become a great economic force after a long period of effort." "The principle of our economic policy is to carry out all possible and necessary economic constructions, concentrate economic power for war, and strive to improve the lives of the masses, consolidate the economic union of workers and peasants, ensure the proletariat's leadership over farmers, and strive for state-owned economy's leadership over private economy, creating the prerequisites for future development into socialism." It can be said that Mao Zedong has already proposed the ideas of the relationship between the three major components of the New Democratic economy (state-owned economy, cooperative economy, private economy). These economic policy ideas have been guiding the economic construction of the base later.
Thirdly, it expounds the center of economic construction of the revolutionary base and the position of agricultural production. China is one of the earliest developed countries in the world and has the most developed rural natural economy. In China's more than two thousand year feudal society, the main economic form has always been the natural economy combined with agriculture and family handicrafts. Its production is not for exchange, but for the needs of producers or production units. This economic form has continued into modern China. Therefore, Mao Zedong pointed out: "The center of our economic construction is to develop agricultural production, develop industrial production, develop foreign trade and develop cooperatives." He especially emphasized: "Under the current conditions, agricultural production is the first place in our economic work.



"Since ancient times, China has established its nation based on agriculture. Our location is mainly rural and focused on agricultural production, which not only helps to solve our crucial problem of food shortage but also provides materials for industrial and craft productions such as hemp, cotton, sugar cane, and bamboo which are used for making daily goods like clothes, sugar, and paper. Therefore, we must strive to lead the farmers to solve issues related to labor force, farming cattle, fertilizers, seeds, and water resources. It is pointed out that mobilizing women to participate in production, organizing mutual labor assistance, and organizing cattle cooperative are important measures to solve these problems. In particular, it was proposed that water resources are the lifeblood of agriculture.
Fourth, it outlines the basic policy guidelines for the financial base of the revolutionary base. The purpose of the Soviet finance is to ensure the provisioning and supplying of the revolutionary war, to bear all the expenses of the Soviet revolution. Though at that time, the Soviet Republic was only in a relatively small part within the total range of the country, they were economically backward areas that implemented policies favorable to public tax collection based on the principles of the class and revolution. Therefore, the sources of the Soviet's finance are: ① confiscating and levying all feudal exploiters; ② taxation; and ③ the development of the national economic undertakings. Mao Zedong pointed out: "The basic policy of our financial policy is to increase our fiscal revenue from developing the national economy." We need the financial work to serve the development of production, therefore "the issuance of banknotes by the state bank should basically base on the needs of the national economic development, and the needs of pure finance should only be put in a secondary position". At the same time, he pointed out: "Fiscal expenditure should be based on the principle of saving." "It's a principle of our accounting system to save every penny for war and revolutionary causes, and for our economic construction." Every government worker should understand that "corruption and waste are grave crimes". Therefore, the campaign against corruption and waste must be launched.
Under the guidance of Mao Zedong's economic construction thoughts, the economic construction work of various revolutionary bases has developed production vigorously through the hard work of the Soviet government, which not only supported the revolutionary war but also improved the lives of the people in the revolutionary bases. Regarding the thoughts on cultural constructions
China is a country with a very backward culture, and under the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang, illiterates account for 80% of the total population, leading to the ignorance of the people. In response to this, Mao Zedong pointed out: For the victory of the revolutionary war, for the consolidation and development of the Soviet power, for the mobilization of all the people's forces, to join the great revolutionary struggle, in order to create a new era of revolution, the Soviets must carry out cultural education reform, to remove the shackles placed on the minds of the working masses by the reactionary ruling class, and to create a new culture of workers and peasants. Since the establishment of the revolutionary base, great attention has been paid to cultural construction. Elementary schools were established throughout the revolutionary base, allowing the children of the working masses to attend school and study. At the same time, efforts were expanded to eliminate illiteracy, organize various forms of night schools and study classes, and carry out literacy campaigns. The government also developed the publishing industry, published various newspapers and books, mass revolutionary arts also developed, and great achievements were made in physical education and sanitation work. Mao Zedong summarized the experience of cultural and educational work in the revolutionary base, and proposed two basic contents of the thought of cultural and educational construction: First, he proposed the policy of cultural and educational. Mao Zedong pointed out: Our policy of cultural education "is to educate the vast laboring masses in the spirit of communism, to make cultural education serve the revolutionary war and class struggle, to link education with labor, and to make the vast Chinese people all enjoy the happiness of civilization".
Secondly, it proposed the central task of cultural and educational construction.



Mao Zedong pointed out that the central task of the cultural education in the revolutionary base is "to strenuously carry out all compulsory education, to develop extensive social education, to strive to eliminate illiteracy, and to train a large number of senior cadres who lead the revolutionary struggle". For the existing intellectuals, they should serve the people, help train revolutionary intellectuals, and contribute to the development of cultural education.


After the outbreak of the anti-Japanese war, the people's army led by the Chinese Communist Party advanced into the enemy's rear, initiated an independent anti-Japanese guerrilla war, tried to mobilize the masses, and established an anti-Japanese base. With the development of anti-Japanese guerrilla warfare, the anti-Japanese democratic base became increasingly solid and expanded. The anti-Japanese democratic base is an advanced front for implementing and realizing the new democratic theory of the Communist Party of China. The unified front regime led by the Communist Party established in each base, and the various new democratic policies implemented, fully demonstrated that the base had begun to change the semi-colonial and semi-feudal social nature and gradually became a prototype of the new democratic society. The people in the base are truly leading a new life. The people are full of spirit, united under the leadership of the Communist Party of China, striving to defeat the Japanese invaders and achieve a better future. The Party's base construction thought has also been fully developed. In the construction of the anti-Japanese democratic base, the construction of political power is the central link. The basic guiding ideology of the construction of political power in the anti-Japanese democratic base is the "Ten Major Programs of Anti-Japanese National Salvation" formulated by the Chinese Communist Party in the early stage of the Anti-Japanese War and the political program of the new democratic revolution expounded by Mao Zedong in "On New Democracy". Its specific contents are as follows:. On the construction of political power

First, the "three thirds" principle of political power construction has been universally implemented and executed. The political power of the anti-Japanese democratic base is a national unity front. In the construction of political power, the Party conscientiously implements the "three thirds" principle, which is a practice and a system of political democracy by the Party. On March 6, 1940, in the instructions on the issue of political power in the anti-Japanese base issued by the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, it was clearly stipulated that in the various anti-Japanese bases, in all levels of public opinion agencies or political power agencies, "Communist Party members constitute one third, non-party leftist progressives constitute one third, and those who are neither left nor right constitute one third." On March 11, at a meeting of senior cadres in Yan'an, Mao Zedong reiterated, "the distribution of personnel in terms of political power should be: Communist Party members constitute one third, representing the proletariat and the poor peasants; leftist progressives constitute one third, representing the petite bourgeoisie; moderates and others constitute one third, representing the middle bourgeoisie and enlightened gentlemen, only traitors and anti-communists do not have the right to participate in this political power". On December 25, 1940, the Central Committee's instructions to the Party, drafted by Mao Zedong, formally proposed the name "three thirds” for the first time. On May 1, 1941, the Central Bureau of the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia Border Region of the Communist Party of China proposed that the "Program for the Administration of the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia Border Region" approved by the Political Bureau of the Central Committee stipulated: "In the list of candidates, Communist Party members only constitute one third, so that people of all parties and no party can participate in the activities of the institutions of public opinion and the administration of the border region." On November 21, 1941, in his speech to the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia Border Region Consultative Council, Mao Zedong once again expounded the important significance of implementing the "three thirds" to the Party and the public, and educated Party members that "national affairs are the public affairs of the nation, not the private affairs of a party, therefore Communist Party members only have the obligation to cooperate with non-Party personnel, and they do not have the right to monopolize everything and exclude others". He also made a solemn statement to the non-party personnel: "The principle of democratic cooperation between the Communist Party and the non-party personnel is unchangeable and will never change." He hoped that this cooperation "will now be put into practice at the meeting". The "three thirds" principle of political power construction is an effective democratic system explored by the Party in the construction of political power in the anti-Japanese base, and Deng Xiaoping pointed out in the "Party Life" publication of the Northern Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on April 15, 1941: "The essence of the 'three thirds' political power is the issue of democracy..."



"The firm implementation of this extensive democratic system is, on the one hand, due to the need for all societies to unite against common enemies; on the other hand, because each class can represent significant power, they check and balance each other. If there is no unified government that allows all parties, factions, and classes to have a voice, there can be no victory for the entire nation. After the "Tripartite System" policy was proposed, some Communist Party members doubted whether this would weaken the party's leadership. However, this policy precisely ensures the leadership position of the Chinese Communist Party in political power, and firmly unites the petty bourgeoisie masses; on the other hand, it brings all the forces that can be united, such as the enlightened people in the middle bourgeoisie and the landlord class, to the people's side, thereby consolidating the anti-Japanese national united front led by the party, consolidating the anti-Japanese base, and showing the extraordinary leadership ability and superb organizational art of the Chinese Communist Party represented by Mao Zedong. The "Tripartite System" is a specific policy for the construction of political power in the anti-Japanese democratic base, a special form under the specific historical conditions at the time, with distinctive characteristics of the times, but in terms of its basic spirit, it requires the party to unite the masses outside the party in leading state affairs and to implement democratic cooperation with non-party individuals.

Secondly, fully guarantee the democratic rights of the base people. Once the organizing principles are established, whether these principles can be implemented depends on whether our party has extraordinary magnanimity and a serious spirit. During the Anti-Japanese War, the masses of people in all anti-Japanese bases could participate in electoral activities universally, truly exercising their most sacred democratic rights, establishing governments co-operated by communists and individuals from various anti-Japanese parties and non-affiliated individuals, and electing trusted, capable, experienced, people-oriented individuals to leadership positions at all levels. This is an important symbol of practicing democratic politics. The heads of the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border region and other anti-Japanese bases were all from the masses. Article 2 of the electoral regulations of the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border region council at all levels stipulates: "Universal, direct, equal, anonymous voting is adopted." Article 3 stipulates: "All people living in the border region, aged 18 and over, without distinction of class, party, occupation, gender, religion, ethnicity, wealth, and educational level, have the right to vote and be voted for. Only traitors, those who have been found guilty by the court and deprived of their citizen rights, and mental patients, do not have the right to vote nor to be voted for. Accordingly, all anti-Japanese classes, whether peasants, workers, landlords, or capitalists; all anti-Japanese parties, whether the Communist Party, the Kuomintang, or other parties; and all ethnicities, whether Han, Manchu, Mongol, Hui, or Tibetan... as long as they are upright, physically healthy, mentally normal, they all have the right to vote, to be voted for, to recall, and to participate in all political activities in the anti-Japanese bases. During the elections, all parties, groups or individuals are free to express their campaign and campaign programs and engage in campaign activities. Not only the working masses actively participate in the election, landlords and rich peasants also enthusiastically participate in the election activities. To embody the national equality of the anti-Japanese National United Front, the anti-Japanese democratic regime has clear provisions for the election rights of ethnic minorities. Ethnic groups that have reached the legal number of members for the council elections can hold their elections separately; ethnic groups that do not meet the legal number but reach one-fifth of the legal number for town elections, county city elections, and border region elections can also hold elections separately, electing one council member of that level. Looking at the proportion of voters in the elections, the principle of democratic equality of the anti-Japanese democratic regime is also demonstrated. Taking the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border region as an example, there were three democratic elections from 1937 to 1946. In the first election from May to November 1937, the voters who participated accounted for more than 70% of the total electorate; in the second election in 1941, the participants accounted for more than 80% of the total electorate; from March 1945 to March 1946, in the third election, the average voter turnout was 82.5%, reaching a high of 96%. The same was true in other anti-Japanese bases."



In the 1940 elections in the seven counties of the Jin-Cha-Ji base area, the male and female citizens participating in the county election accounted for 78.3% of the total number of citizens, those participating in the district election accounted for 81.4% of the total number of citizens, and those participating in the village election accounted for 83.9% of the total number of citizens. Even in some guerrilla zones where the enemy was "sweeping", the people's elections were not interrupted. If it could not be conducted during the day, it was conducted at night; if a large meeting could not be organized, it was conducted in small groups. In short, every effort was made to achieve the goal. The participation of women in politics is a measure of social progress. In the elections in the anti-Japanese base areas, the proportion of women participating in the elections was also very large, generally reaching about 80%, and the highest reached 90%.

The election activities in the anti-Japanese base areas truly embodied the principles of universality, directness, and equality, ensuring that representatives at all levels have a broad representation. It perfected and consolidated the power at all levels, further strengthening the anti-Japanese unity of all classes, factions, and ethnic groups in the anti-Japanese base areas, promoting the democratization process of the anti-Japanese base areas, and promoting the development of the War of Resistance.

Third, implementing a lean administration. From 1941 to 1943, the Anti-Japanese base areas led by the Chinese Communist Party entered the most difficult stage. The area of the base was halved, the population of the base area dropped from 100 million to less than 50 million, the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army reduced from 500,000 to 300,000, and there were extreme difficulties. Under such severe circumstances, the Party began to implement the policy of "lean military and administration." In November 1941, Mr. Li Dingming proposed the idea of "lean military and administration" at the Second Congress in Shaanxi, Gansu and Ningxia. He pointed out: "In today's difficult situation, the government should come up with a unified economic plan based on the current economic base; third, within the scope of financial and economic capabilities and without hindering the conditions of the war, the principle of lean soldiers should be implemented for the military; fourth, the provision conditions should be specified to avoid unnecessary supply and consumption; fifth, advocate thrift and clean style, and avoid unnecessary waste". Mao Zedong added a note to this proposal: "This is a good method, which is exactly the medicine for our bureaucracy, formalism, and institutionalism." Subsequently, the Party Central Committee issued instructions on lean military and administration to the anti-Japanese democratic base areas in December 1941. Mao Zedong pointed out, “This time the lean military and administration must be strict, thorough, and universal, not superficial, painless, or partial. In this lean military and administration, we must achieve lean, unified, efficient, economical, and oppose bureaucracy.” Starting from the winter of 1941, various anti-Japanese base areas began to implement "lean military and administration". The Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border area simplified three times in a row. The internal agencies of all bureaus, offices, and courts were cut by a quarter, and their affiliated agencies were reorganized from the original 1140 people to 991 people. The directly affiliated agencies of the border area were reduced from 35 to 22, and the staff were reduced from 469 to 279. After the second reorganization, the total number of county (city) governments and county councils in the whole region reduced from the original 1189 people to 397 people, which was 33% of the original number. The original staff of the various district offices was 1250 and was reduced to 955, accounting for 75.6% of the original number.



All other bases were streamlined three to four times as well. The policy of streamlining and efficiency began at the end of 1941 and basically ended at the end of 1943. The anti-Japanese democratic bases claimed significant achievements, and the personnel cut down were returned to the frontline of production. Through this work, old formalized tendencies in the system were corrected, thus establishing a unified leadership structure, opposing bureaucratic tendencies in work, and improving work efficiency. The streamlining had a positive effect, reduced the number of idle personnel, and significantly saved costs. As a result of the lower costs, the number of public debts levied in various bases was accordingly reduced by a third, greatly reducing the burden on the people, improving the credibility of the anti-Japanese democratic government led by the party in the face of severe difficulties, strengthening the bond between the party and the masses, consolidating the united anti-Japanese national front, and creating favorable social conditions and material bases for the victory of the revolution. The War of Resistance against Japan was an important period for our party's ideological theory, policy strategy towards maturity. During this period, the party central committee formulated a series of correct economic policies, accumulating rich experience in guiding economic construction.

Firstly, we established "developing the economy and guaranteeing supply" as the general guideline for financial and economic work. At the beginning of the war of resistance against Japan, in order to make up for the shortfalls in finance and economy and improve the living conditions of the military and civilians, the party led the people in the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border area to carry out the production movement first and achieved considerable success, which allowed us to relatively smoothly navigate through the most difficult period. However, there was still a difference in understanding within the party about how to fundamentally solve the financial supply problem in the border areas. Some people, restricted by the outdated and conservative view of finance, forgot to develop the economy and source of wealth, and just circled around on the issue of financial income and expenditure, attempting to solve the financial problem by shrinking necessary financial expenditures. Some people, while advocating production development, put forward many adventurous but impractical big plans, such as the construction of heavy industry, development of large salt industry, and military industry, etc. In order to correctly guide the economic construction in the border area, Mao Zedong made an important report in December 1942 at the Northwest Bureau Conference on the "Economic and Financial Issues during the War of Resistance".
