He correctly summarized the experiences and lessons of financial and economic work in the border area, criticized the above two wrong tendencies, and proposed the general guideline for financial and economic work of "developing the economy, ensuring supply". Mao Zedong said: The quality of financial policy can certainly influence the economy, but it is the economy that determines finance. There is no way to solve financial problems without an economic basis or to enrich finance without economic development. Financial difficulties can only be solved through realistic and effective economic development. It is impossible to solve any problems if you forget to develop the economy and the source of wealth and attempt to solve financial problems by shrinking necessary financial expenses. Here, Mao Zedong clearly pointed out that the fundamental way to solve financial and economic difficulties is to develop the economy, source the wealth, and increase income. Based on this, the party highly emphasized the development of production in the border areas and the actual benefits of production, pointing out that all institutions, schools, and troops must carry out vegetable cultivation, grain cultivation, pig farming, charcoal burning, handicraft industry development, and partial grain cultivation under the condition of war. All factories should depend on their own economic profit and loss for the rise and fall of their business. The common goal of the party branch, administrative leadership, and trade union in the factory is to manufacture as much and as good products as possible with the most economical cost and sell them under the fastest and most favorable conditions. This is to say how to measure the economic construction in the base is not only to see how much wasteland has been reclaimed, how much land has been cultivated, how many factories have been created, but also to see how much social needed products have been produced, and to organically combine individual and unit production with social needs.

The general guideline for financial work proposed by Mao Zedong also clearly pointed out the fundamental purpose of developing the economy in the base. That is to ensure the supply of funds for the war of resistance, to meet the living expenses and business expenses of party, government, and military personnel, and to improve the living conditions of the people.



The overall guideline profoundly elaborates the fundamental guiding principles of the establishment of the base area economy from both the means and the purpose. 

Secondly, focusing on agriculture while also developing other productions is a strategic guideline proposed by the Party for the development of the base area economy. What should be emphasized in developing the rural base area economy? This is a major issue concerning the overall situation, which was initially not very clear to the whole Party. In the first stage of the production movement in the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border area, the military, government agencies, and schools focused on agricultural production, with agriculture as the primary focus, and achieved good results. In the second stage, to quickly solve the urgent issue of self-sufficiency, many military units, government agencies and schools paid attention to commerce while overlooking agricultural production. The government's production investment also favored industry and commerce over agriculture. This bias of emphasizing commerce while underestimating agriculture was detrimental to the overall economic development of the border region, and it had to be corrected. Therefore, Mao Zedong proposed that for the development of various economic undertakings in the border regions, "agriculture should be given the first place, industry, handicraft, transportation, and animal husbandry the second place, and commerce the third place," thus clarifying the focus and direction of the base area's economic development. To vigorously develop the agriculture of the base area, Mao Zedong, from a practical perspective, also proposed a series of vital economic and technological measures. These mainly are: ① reduce rents and lower interests, alleviate the feudal exploitation of peasants by landlords, and stimulate the interest in production among the peasants; ② organize and establish various forms of agricultural labor assistance organizations, carry out collective production, and increase labor productivity; ③ reward production, launch a labor model movement, reward labor heroes, and advocate laboring for wealth; ④ conform to local conditions, take practical actions, and realistically determine measures to increase production; and improve and upgrade agricultural technology, such as water conservancy projects, and promote fine varieties. All the above measures have played an important role in the development of the base area's agricultural production.

Thirdly, the strategy of "both public and private" or "military and civilian" is an important guideline proposed by the Party to properly handle economic relationships of different natures in the base area. During the Anti-Japanese War, the rural base area economy, generally speaking, had two different forms of economic components: the public economy and the people's economy (i.e., the private economy). The public economy refers to agriculture, industry, and commerce operated by the government, military, offices, and schools; the people's economy refers to all private-sector agriculture, industry, and commerce. How to properly handle the relationship between these two different types of economies in the course of developing the base area economy is a vital issue. At the beginning of the Anti-Japanese War, the Party adopted a policy of "seeking foreign aid, and recuperating the people's strength" in the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border area. On the one hand, it organized and assisted the people in developing production, on the other hand, it strove to lighten the burden on the people, which resulted in significant recovery and development in the people's economy. Speaking of agriculture, from 1937 to 1940, the cultivated land area increased by about one-third in three years, and the grain output grew by about 45%. However, later due to serious financial and economic difficulties and the implementation of self-sufficiency tasks, especially more attention was paid to the establishment and development of public economy in 1941-1942, neglecting the development of the people's economy. The government's investment in the economy also went primarily to public enterprises, very little went to private enterprises, and the people's burden was excessively increased, which caused widespread dissatisfaction among the people. In order to mobilize both the public and private sectors' enthusiasm for co-developing the base area economy, Mao Zedong proposed the guideline of "both public and private" or "both military and civilian", that is, on the one hand, develop the public economy, and on the other hand, develop the people's economy, implement the co-progress of public and private.



The implementation of the "balance between public and private" or "balance between military and civilian" policy correctly handled the relationship between public and private economies at that time, greatly mobilized the enthusiasm of both the public and private sectors to develop the base economy, and enabled both the public and private economies to achieve relatively good development. The base was also gradually able to provide for themselves and meet their own needs through the joint development of the public and private economies.

Fourthly, "Unified leadership and decentralized operation" is an important principle proposed by the party for organizing and leading the economic life of the base area. The public economy is an important component and leading force of the new democratic economy of the base area. Its establishment and development have a decisive impact on the development of the base economy. In order to organize and lead the development of the public economy in the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border area, the party Central Committee put forward the principle of "Centralized leadership and decentralized operation" in 1942, distributed some production costs to various units, and asked each unit to operate independently and self-supply. However, this principle was not fully implemented at the time and for some time afterwards. There was too much decentralized operation and not enough centralized leadership, or even no centralized leadership at all, which brought great chaos to the economic life of the border area. People valued businesses that could make quick profits, but neglected agricultural production. There was serious speculation in business, and some even smuggled arms and evaded taxes. Industrial construction rushed ahead regardless of conditions, resulting in some factories being unable to start production or ending shortly after starting. Each unit kept its own profits, leading to uneven distribution of hardships and joys. Those who made money had food and clothing, while those who couldn't, each cadre only received two pounds of cotton to make clothes. This situation was incompatible with the Party's general policy of "developing the economy and ensuring supplies". Therefore, Mao Zedong emphasized in his report on "Economic Problems and Financial Problems" that: "The development of the public economy must implement the principle of 'centralized leadership, decentralized operation'. Not only is industry like this, but so is agriculture and commerce." Mao Zedong further generalized this principle as "unified leadership, decentralized operation". The development of the public economy in the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border area has fully implemented this principle since 1943: it has unified the operating direction of enterprises by system and level, adjusted the mutual relations between enterprises, and under the condition of allowing a considerable part of the income to be retained by the production units, it has unified the distribution of production profits and let all sides solve problems according to the unified plan, policies and policies. The chaotic situation in the past was quickly reversed, the border area economy achieved relatively smooth development, and the uneven living conditions of personnel in various aspects were overcome. Therefore, Mao Zedong said: "'Unified leadership, decentralized operation' principle, has been proven to be the right principle for our liberation areas to organize all economic life under current conditions." In terms of cultural construction, the Chinese Communist Party, as the leader of base area construction, also directly bears the leadership responsibility for cultural construction. What principles should be followed in cultural construction, what tasks should be completed, what methods should be adopted and what direction should be developed in the process of base area construction, not only are theoretical problems, but have also become practical problems. For this reason, the Chinese Communist Party has undertaken extensive explorations and formulated a more complete set of guidelines and policies.

Firstly, it emphasizes that the basic principle of cultural construction in the base area revolves around the War of Resistance against Japan. At the beginning of the War of Resistance, Mao Zedong proposed in "Guidelines, Methods and Prospects for Resisting Japanese Aggression" that the past educational guidelines and the educational system should be fundamentally reformed. All urgent and irrational methods should be discarded. Newspaper, publication, film, theater, literature, arts, everything needs to be in the interest of national defense. After entering the stalemate stage of the War of Resistance, in October 1938, Mao Zedong further pointed out in his political report "On the New Stage" at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China: "Under the principle of everything for the war, all cultural and educational undertakings should be adapted to the needs of the war..."


Therefore, it is necessary to implement the following cultural education policies: First, revise the educational system, abolish urgent and unnecessary courses, change the management system, and base on the principle of teaching courses required for war and promoting students' learning enthusiasm. Second, establish and expand various cadre schools, training a large number of cadres for resisting Japan. Third, extensively develop popular education, organize various remedial schools, literacy movements, theater movements, choral movements, sports movements, establish various local newspapers in front of and behind the enemy, and improve the people's national culture and national awareness. Fourth, implement compulsory primary education, with the aim of educating new generations in the national spirit. The above-mentioned guidelines and policies highlight a basic principle, that is, cultural construction must be closely centered around the war against Japan and serve the comprehensive and long-lasting war against Japan.

Second, it proposed the basic direction of cultural development. In January 1940, Mao Zedong gave a speech at the first representative meeting of the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia Border Region Cultural Association, entitled "The Politics and Culture of New Democracy" (that is, "On New Democracy"), which systematically discussed the historical process and characteristics of China's modern cultural revolution. He proposed the task of "transforming a China that is ignorant and backward under the rule of old culture into a China that is civilized and advanced under the rule of a new culture". This "new culture" is "the national, scientific, and popular culture, that is, the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal culture of the masses". This has actually pointed the way for the development of a new democratic culture, which has immeasurable guiding significance. After the Rectification Movement began, in May 1942, Mao Zedong delivered a speech at the Yan'an Talks on Literature and Art, elaborating on the relationship between literature and art, politics, and the entire revolutionary cause, not only clearly proposing that literature and art must serve the workers, peasants and soldiers, but also further discussing the question of how literature and art serve the workers, peasants and soldiers. These will inevitably have a significant impact on the cultural construction of the base areas of the Anti-Japanese War, and they will become a powerful driving force to promote the cultural and artistic movement in the Anti-Japanese War base areas.

Third, the key to the cultural construction of the base of the Anti-Japanese War is to have a large number of intellectuals and fully play their role. With the consolidation and expansion of the base areas of the Anti-Japanese War, the tasks of propaganda, organization, and arming the masses are extremely difficult, and a large number of cadres and soldiers sacrificed and decreased in the cruel struggle against the enemy, all of which urgently need to absorb a large number of intellectuals to join the party and the army. In this respect, the Chinese Communists represented by Mao Zedong have a very clear understanding. In December 1939, Mao Zedong pointed out in "Absorbing Intellectuals in Large Quantities" that "in the long-term and cruel national liberation war, in the great struggle to establish a new China, the Communist Party must be good at absorbing intellectuals, in order to organize great resistance forces, organize millions of peasant masses, develop revolutionary cultural movement and the united front movement. Without the participation of intellectuals, the victory of the revolution is impossible." In December 1940, Mao Zedong drafted a directive for the central committee of the Communist Party of China, "On Policy," which proposed that "liberal educators, cultural figures, journalists, scholars, and technicians should be allowed to come to the base areas and cooperate with us in running schools, newspapers, and doing things. All intellectuals who are more active in resisting Japan should be absorbed into our schools for short-term training, so that they can join the military, government, and social work." During the Anti-Japanese War, the anti-Japanese base areas centered on Yanan were able to attract a large number of patriotic intellectuals, young students, and elites from the cultural sector, attracting them to come all the way despite the hardships, which cannot be separated from the correct policies of the Communist Party of China.

Fourth, specific policies and regulations suitable for the cultural construction needs of the base areas were formulated. With the gradual implementation of these guidelines and policies, and the continuous expansion and consolidation of the base areas, cultural propaganda activities in the base areas are increasingly active, and cultural associations are established one after another.


The Central Committee of the Party regards cultural propaganda as an important weapon for educating the masses, organizing the masses, and attacking enemies. The cultural undertakings in the Anti-Japanese base areas have become a "necessary and important front in the overall revolutionary front". The party has cultural management departments in its own organization, and there are also cultural management institutions in the government, using various means to promote the development of cultural undertakings. In September 1940, to carry out the cultural movement of the Anti-Japanese War, the CPC Central Committee specifically issued the "Central Directive on Developing a Cultural Movement", which demanded all party organizations and armies in the base areas to "plan and carry out all propaganda activities, educational activities, and publishing activities in an organized manner, in order to popularize and improve the theoretical and political levels of party members, and to popularize and raise the political level of the Anti-Japanese army and the Anti-Japanese people. The theoretical, political, and cultural levels of all members of the base area, the army, and the people should be higher and more extensive than in other parts of the country... The transportation of cultural grain should be regarded as more important than the transportation of clothing and ammunition." In January 1938, the Jinchaji Border Area Military and Civilian Representative Congress passed the "Cultural Education Resolution", which specified the basic principles of cultural education: demonstrating a high spirit of nationalism, strengthening the Anti-Japanese forces; training sound military and political cadres, Leading the Anti-Japanese war; creating specialized technical talents, establishing all kinds of undertakings during the Anti-Japanese war; cultivating passionate new youth, expanding the foundation of the national revolution; improving the cultural level of the general public and promoting their health. In January 1939, the First Senate of the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia Border Region passed the "Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia Border Region Anti-Japanese War Program", which fully discussed the cultural education and cultural construction policy in the border region; in November of the same year, the Second Congress of the CPC Shaan-Gan-Ning Border Region Resolution on cultural and educational work in the border area: "Cultural education in the border area must strive to remove the cultural backwardness left by the old regime before the revolution to the masses - illiteracy, superstition, and unsanitary conditions; it must be based on progressive scientific theory and fight for the establishment of a new culture of the Chinese nation."


The theory and strategy of the party's united front originate from the revolutionary strategy principles of the proletariat of Marxism, and have gone through a logical development process in the specific environment of the Chinese revolution. Its first ideological and practical result in the Chinese revolution is the proposal of the party's democratic united front thought and the realization of the first cooperation between the KMT and the Communists.
At that time, the united front objects understood by the Communists were very broad. In January 1923, "Guide" pointed out in its article that "whether a class or a party is revolutionary is not fixed. Under certain historical conditions, the proletariat "can cooperate with the revolutionary actions of any party...any soldier." But such a union can only be a "revolutionary union", not a "compromise union". Specifically, among the various classes in Chinese society, Communists believe that the national bourgeoisie is one of the driving forces of the democratic revolution during the stage of the democratic revolution. The petty bourgeoisie is the basic force of the revolution. The comprador class is fundamentally counter-revolutionary, but because the comprador class is the agent of different imperialists, there are conflicts and conflicts between the interests of different compradors, and therefore, "The Japanese comprador Anfu faction can agree with the anti-British movement in the national revolution", and the "research faction" “Often opposed to the Fengtian warlords". The proletariat "should make the greatest use" of this "internal contradiction conflict" to weaken the "power of the enemy".
Based on the above principles, Communists analyzed the state of China's various political forces around the Second National Congress of the CCP and believed that "the Kuomintang is relatively a revolutionary democratic party and is truly a democratic party". Therefore, the "Resolution on the" Democratic United Front "of the Second National Congress of the Communist Party of China" proposed to "first invite the Kuomintang and the Socialist Youth League to hold a representative meeting at the appropriate place, to discuss how to invite other reform groups and how to carry out" united front work ". This shows that the party at that time not only wanted to ally primarily with the Kuomintang but also to unite with other "reform groups" to form a broad democratic united front.



At that time, given that Wu Peifu showed some support for the people's movement, the Communists believed that it was meaningful to ally with Wu Peifu in "eradicating the Red Beards" ("Red Beards" refers to Zhang Zuolin — note from the translator). Therefore, while the revolutionary party fundamentally advocated "uniting with the people", it did not rule out some "meaningful unilateral alliance" with Wu Peifu. In 1923, after Wu Peifu cause the February 27th tragedy, Chinese Communists immediately adopted the stance of determinedly overthrowing the warlord of the Beiyang Army. Later, with the help of the Communist International, the Party achieved cooperation with the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) at the beginning of 1924. However, the party's alliance target at this time was still not singular. In October 1924, after Feng Yuxiang launched a coup in Beijing, the Communists, after a period of observation, adopted a policy of allying with Feng Yuxiang and the National Army. After the outbreak of the Anti-Feng War, the democratic tendency of Feng Yuxiang's National Army became clearer, and various political forces also advocated for democratic politics. Under this special situation, Chinese Communists proposed "everyone unite", including the Guangzhou National Government, National Army, all sectors of workers, farmers, businessmen, and students, nationalist faction, the right-wing of the Kuomintang, the left-wing of the Kuomintang, and the communist faction, to jointly promote the National Assembly and create a "real republic". However, due to the rapid reversal of the anti-Feng War situation, the aforementioned proposals of the Chinese Communists could not be realized. But the National Army became the second most important ally after the Kuomintang. The party's theories and policies reflected the basic principles of exploiting contradictions, striving for the majority, and allying with all possible forces under specific historical conditions to fight against the primary enemy.

Among the two main allies at the time, Communists believed that Feng's National Army represented the "anti-comprador rural bourgeoisie". However, the understanding of the class content of the Kuomintang was complex. When the topic of democratic revolution was put on the party's agenda, Communists pointed out that the democratic faction led by the Kuomintang represented the "bourgeoisie". But at that time, the so-called bourgeoisie did not have a definite content. According to the analysis of the Second National Congress of the Communist Party of China's Manifesto, the "bourgeoisie" included the "commercial and industrial bourgeoisie" and the "petty bourgeoisie", but in discussing the alliance of the proletariat with the bourgeoisie, it only mentioned the establishment of a "democratic united front with the petty bourgeoisie". It seems that the so-called democratic bourgeoisie represented by groups such as the Kuomintang specifically refers to the petty bourgeoisie.

The first to point out that the Kuomintang was a multi-class party was the representative of the Comintern, Maring. In July 1922, in his report to the Executive Committee of the Comintern, he pointed out that the Kuomintang was composed of "intellectuals", "overseas Chinese", "soldiers", and "workers". "Overseas Chinese" was the "capitalist factor" in the Kuomintang. In January of the following year, the Executive Committee of the Comintern's "Resolution on the Relationship Between the Chinese Communist Party and the Kuomintang" further pointed out that the class basis of the Kuomintang included "liberal bourgeoisie", "petty bourgeoisie", "intellectuals and workers". Chinese Communists quickly accepted the Comintern's view that the Kuomintang was a temporary alliance of four classes, and pointed out that the interests of the bourgeoisie in this temporary alliance fundamentally conflict with the interests of the workers and peasants.



In May 1924, the Party's Third Plenary Session of the Third Committee analyzed this objective fact and began to divide the Kuomintang into left and right factions. However, it did not yet specify the specific class content of the left and right factions. In the second half of 1924, communists further divided the Kuomintang into left, middle, and right factions. There was no unified view on the class content of these three factions at that time. In July 1926, the Third Plenary Session of the Fourth Committee of the Party further divided the Kuomintang into four forces, namely: the warlords, compradors, bureaucrats and other semi-feudal forces, represented by the right faction. The representatives of the workers and peasants were the Communist faction. The representatives of the petty bourgeoisie were the left faction. The representatives of the national bourgeoisie were the new right or middle faction. This basically clarified the class content of various factions within the Kuomintang. On this basis, the plenary proposed the strategy of "uniting the left and middle factions and attacking the reactionary right faction." The main united front targets of the party were clearly identified as the petty bourgeoisie represented by the left faction of the Kuomintang and the national bourgeoisie represented by the middle faction.

Among the two classes that could be united, communists believed that the petty bourgeoisie was a reliable force for the revolution, while the national bourgeoisie held a "contradictory" attitude towards the revolution and held a unique position in the revolution. Before and after the Second and Third Party Congresses, communists pointed out that the power of the Chinese bourgeoisie was still very "immature", it could not become an "independent class force", and it had a tendency to "compromise" and a mentality of "muddling through" in the revolution. However, at that time, the communists still believed that the bourgeoisie should play a central role in the democratic revolution. "The democratic revolution is indeed in the interests of the bourgeoisie." The assessment of the bourgeoisie's role and status was obviously too high. In May 1924, after the Third Plenary Session of the Third Committee of the Party, communists further pointed out that the revolutionary nature of the bourgeoisie is "always intermittent", and "the higher the bourgeoisie, the more willing they are to compromise". Their participation in the revolution is bound to "not persist to the end". However, the communists overly overlooked the reality of the national bourgeoisie's power, believing that it was in the transition from the comprador class to the national industrial bourgeoisie and could not participate in the revolution. It also had no ambition to seize the leadership of the revolution. This perception existed for a considerable period of time and was the theoretical foundation of the party's inability to address the issue of competing with the bourgeoisie for leadership for a significant period of time. Not until the first half of 1926, Mao Zedong in his article "The Cause of the Split of the Kuomintang Rightist Faction and Its Impact on the Course of the Revolution", truly pointed out that the Chinese bourgeoisie had the intention and action to monopolize the leadership of the revolution and realize the capitalist future. In July of the same year, the Third Plenary Session of the Fourth Committee of the Party also pointed out that "China's bourgeoisie has gradually become an important component of the national movement and has a tendency to lead this movement," and its armed forces are gradually "forming" .


However, its "compromise nature" remains very serious, "once there is a slight victory", it will "betray the revolution and cooperate with the enemy". Therefore, on the one hand, the party should "promote the bourgeois revolution" and see it as a "friendly force". On the other hand, it must prevent future dangers and strive to compete with the bourgeoisie for the leadership of the revolutionary movement. It determined that the national bourgeoisie always has a dual nature during the democratic revolutionary stage. Its weakness does not lie in lack of desire to take leadership, but in guiding the revolution towards failure according to the weak will of this class. It pointed out that the proletariat needs to unite with the national bourgeoisie, be vigilant about its betrayal, and strive to compete with it for leadership of the revolution. This is theoretically completely correct. However, the third plenary session of the Fourth Congress, in correcting the mistake of neglecting the existence of bourgeois forces, also stated that they are forces that the revolution cannot leave at any moment. The unique role of China's national bourgeoisie has not been fully recognized.

From the above analysis, the Chinese Communists basically clarified the proletariat's correct attitude towards alliance partners during the Great Revolution. But it was severely affected by the "typological" error of Comintern in determining the political representation of the united class. At the time, the Communists regarded the left, middle, and right factions of the Kuomintang as primarily the political representatives of the petty bourgeoisie, the national bourgeoisie, and the landlord and comprador classes, which was relatively reasonable, but still somewhat oversimplified and absolutized. The mistake is then definitively seeing Chiang Kai-shek's group as the core of the middle faction, and Wang Jingwei as the representative of the "left" faction. If the boundaries between various parts of the bourgeoisie and the boundaries between them and the imperialist and feudal forces in semi-colonial and semi-feudal China are not fully defined, then the various factions of the Kuomintang representing different levels of the bourgeoisie and their representatives cannot have absolutely different positions. They did not see the complexity of political figures such as Chiang Kai-shek and Wang Jingwei, which emerged from complex Chinese society, and their complex relationship with the landlord comprador class, so they could not understand the complexity and variability of their class attributes. Therefore, before 412, the Party Central Committee chaired by Chen Duxiu, especially the Comintern, always made concessions to Chiang Kai-shek. After 412, the Communists generally accepted the Comintern's "three stages" of revolution, regarded Chiang Kai-shek's betrayal as a sign of the entire national bourgeoisie turning to reactionism, raised the slogan of "opposing the bourgeoisie", and obliterated the dual nature of the national bourgeoisie. And fundamentally limited the target of subsequent unity to the so-called left faction of the Kuomintang centered on the Wang Jingwei group, with unrealistic hopes for it.
Second, the issue of "leadership" and "independence" in the united front were initially raised.
In the stage of democratic revolution, the basic principle of the proletariat's alliance with the democratic bourgeoisie, Marxism-Leninism believes, includes two aspects: one is that the proletariat must grasp the leadership in the alliance; the other is that the proletariat must maintain complete independence. The understanding and recognition of these two principles by the Chinese Communists during the initial establishment of the united front experienced a complex process.
The second congress of the Communist Party of China provided the following provisions for the principle of unity: The proletariat's alliance with the democrats is just to "help the democratic revolution", "not to surrender to the democrats representing the bourgeoisie to be their appendages". At the same time they unite, they gather under the "banner of the Communist Party, independently carrying out their own class movement".



Here, the proletariat's independent thought in the revolutionary united front is clear. However, the communists did not point out the reality of the proletariat's leadership at the meeting, instead interpreting independence as the proletariat being unable to achieve complete liberation in a democratic revolution, and therefore needing to engage in independent class struggle. They are not the ones in command in the absence of alliances, but merely assisting to gain some immediate benefits. In August 1922, with the help of the Communist International, the party established a policy of a united front for cooperation within the KMT and the Communist Party. By the end of the same year, a spokesperson for the party pointed out at the Fourth Congress of the Communist International that when the Chinese Communist Party cooperates with the KMT, it must "compete with the KMT" in terms of organizing and educating the masses, and "divide the KMT". This shows that at the beginning of determining the cooperation within the KMT and the Communist Party, the party had thought of striving for the dominant position in the cooperation.

However, the Fourth Congress of the Communist International negated this principle and made a resolution for cooperation between the KMT and the Communist Party on this basis. Therefore, at the third party congress, there was a heated debate among Communist Party members about the principles of cooperation between the KMT and the Communist Party. Some people, such as Chen Duxiu, fully accepted the resolution of the Communist International, advocating that all members of the Communist Party and industrial workers also join the KMT, and "all work goes to the KMT." This opinion takes a positive attitude towards the issue of cooperation, but mistakenly believes that the party's independence is "not a problem" in the future, and tends to neglect the party's independence. Another group of leaders, like Cai Hesen, believed that it was necessary to "maintain the party's independence" completely after joining the KMT. But they interpreted independence as not all members of the Communist Party joining the KMT, and industrial workers "should not join the KMT." Their idea of "independence" still has the drawbacks of being simplified and superficial.

The above two opinions were unified in the decision of the third congress. The principles of cooperation between the KMT and the Communist Party reflected in the documents of the third congress are: ① Political independence, i.e., maintaining the proletariat party's uncompromising, thoroughly revolutionary political profile with "any imperialist or any warlord". ② Organizational independence, i.e., maintaining the party's "organization" even when joining the KMT, and further "expanding" the party's organization while "strictly" observing party discipline. ③ Independent working class movement, i.e., carrying out the special task of the Communist Party, which is to independently launch trade union movements and class struggles of the working class, while not giving up engaging in the Nationalist Revolution. ④ The need to resist the KMT's erroneous policies and actions.



The leader of the National Revolution is the Kuomintang. These principles, except for the fifth one, which is relatively complex in comprehension, the first four are essentially correct in theory. The shortcomings are: The third item only emphasizes the independence of the workers' movement, but does not point out that the Party should also maintain the right to independent activities in the mass movements of peasants and the petty bourgeoisie, etc. At the same time, the content of independence is just the Party maintains independence in organization, propaganda, and mass movement, without involving the issue of independently carrying out political and military work. The principle of "cooperation" is still very one-sided. In November 923, the first plenary session of the Third Session of the CCP made some new decisions on the principle of cooperation. It requires Communist Party members and Youth League members to "strive to stand in the central position within the KMT". This involves in theory the Communist Party's principle of striving for full control within the united front. However, this idea could not be persisted in and developed, and even the Party's independence of organization and mass movement proposed by the third National Congress of the Communist Party was not implemented in the specific work after the establishment of the KMT-CPC cooperation, resulting in the mistake of taking all the work to the KMT. The third session of the Third National Congress of the Party initially corrected this error, and the Fourth Congress of the CPC summed up the practical experience of KMT-CPC cooperation in earnest, adding the following new content to the cooperation principle: ① Recognized the leading position of the proletariat in the democratic revolution. ② More clearly emphasized that the independent development of the "industrial workers' movement is the" fundamental work of the proletarian party. ③ Proposed the principle that industrial workers "must have work needs to join the KMT". ④ Initially proposed the task of organizing the peasant movement independently. The fourth CCP National Agricultural Resolution pointed out that in the peasant movement, the Communist Party "must independently carry out... public propaganda and branch work outside the KMT".
The proposal of the above principles shows that communists have a further understanding of the special position of the proletarian party in cooperation. However, these principles have not yet turned into correct practical policies. The leadership of the proletariat is still the leadership of the mass movement by the proletarian party, and "independence" remains merely to carry out the labor and peasant movement independently. It further requires the whole party in the labor and peasant movement, especially in the industrial workers' movement, to maintain a certain distance from allies, implement the policy of industrial workers "joining the KMT as needed". There is a lack of independent conduct and leadership of political and military work to change the balance of power in cooperation, ensure the united front plays its role according to the will of the proletariat and its party, and transform the victory of the democratic revolution into the victory of the proletariat and realize the content of the socialist prospect.
The new rightists of the KMT could not tolerate the very limited independent activities of the CCP either. The occurrence of incidents such as the Zhongshan Warship Incident and the Party Affairs Sorting Case indicates that the rightists have begun to gradually restrict and cancel the CCP's independent activities.



After the establishment of the High Command of the Northern Expedition, Chiang Kai-shek further openly used the Northern Expedition as an excuse, and issued a series of laws restricting the independent struggle of workers and peasants. In view of the above situation, the Chinese Communists once proposed the idea of "withdrawing from the Kuomintang" and "preparing independent military forces" to confront Chiang Kai-shek. However, the Communist International neither supported the Chinese Communist Party's independent military activities nor "firmly opposed the demand for withdrawing from the Kuomintang" and didn't allow “the standpoint that essentially led to the withdrawal from the Kuomintang" to exist. It also explicitly pointed out that this understanding of the "independence of the Chinese Communist Party" was not permissible. In July 1926, the 3rd Executive Committee of the Fourth Communist Party proposed the issue of the struggle for leadership between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie, pointing out that the party needed to "show more self-independence in politics" and "establish its own influence among workers and the majority of peasants". This shows that the entire party was increasingly aware of the significance of the proletariat gaining revolutionary leadership and maintaining independence amid a series of betrayals by Chiang Kai-shek. The issue remains, however, that neither "leadership" nor "independence" was directly connected with the issue of arms and political power. It was also made clear that the role was only to assist the left wing, not "replace the left wing". This proposition was almost an identical copy of the Communist International’s directive "not to attempt to lead with Communists replacing the 'left wing'”. Its incorrect direct origin is obviously the Communist International.

As the Northern Expedition War moved into the Yangtze River region, the Kuomintang right wing's anti-labor and peasant activities became more obvious, and communists saw even more the seriousness of Chiang Kai-shek's expanding power. The Central Bureau of the Party's report pointed out that after the Zhongshan Warship incident, Chiang Kai-shek’s group gradually squeezed out the Communist Party and the left wing of the Kuomintang, forming a "loud and noisy alien domination". Some left-wing leaders "were fundamentally shaken". Under these circumstances, communists further believed that they could not replace the left wing as leaders, but help the left wing gain the "masses" and "take responsibility for themselves". The Hankou Special Meeting in December 1926 (also known as the December Special Meeting) further pointed out that the Party could not monopolize all popular movements such as "workers, farmers, merchants, students" and "political struggle". It also clarified that the Party's independence only refers to the independence of "political propaganda and party organization". The previously emphasized independence of the worker-peasant movement was also abandoned. Of course, changes made by the Hankou Special Meeting emphasized cooperation with the left wing in the workers and peasants movement and political struggle, to avoid "full conflict with the Kuomintang", which was not unreasonable. The problem is that the conference did not propose specific measures for the Party to take full control of the Democratic Revolution by expanding the left wing, but instead believed that the party should give up some power to the left wing, thereby distancing itself from the Democratic faction, which led to a reduction in the principle of "cooperation". In spring 1927, after the resolution of the 7th expanded Executive Committee of the International reached China, and especially after Chiang Kai-shek's betrayal of the revolution, Chinese Communists accepted the International's revolutionary "three stages" theory, believing that the Chinese revolution had entered a period of alliance of the three classes of workers, peasants, and the petty bourgeoisie, and that cooperation between the two parties had already become the task of jointly establishing and leading the democratic dictatorship of the workers, peasants, and the petty bourgeoisie, with cooperation being "even closer". But in fact, this was not the case. The closer it got to the late stages of the Great Revolution, the so-called left wing represented by Wang Jingwei quickly transformed into a representative of the landlord and comprador classes, with betrayal becoming increasingly evident and the situation becoming more serious. Despite the fact that the communists and representatives of the Communist International theoretically thought that "cooperation" had become even closer, they also saw the seriousness of this situation from a realistic point of view.


However, they did not provide a practical answer to how to maintain the independence of the proletariat under these conditions. The international representative, Luo Yi, made a special report on "The Relationship between the Chinese Communist Party and the Kuomintang and the Independence of the Communist Party" in the Political Bureau of the CCP Central Committee, emphasizing that after Chiang Kai-shek's betrayal, the Communist Party must still maintain "independence" within the Kuomintang. However, when it came to specific ways to maintain independence, he merely repeated the three principles of "developing the land revolution, strengthening the worker's movement, and winning over the petty bourgeoisie," without any specific methods. Later, Luo Yi proposed to overthrow the Kuomintang Central Committee through a coup, thus changing the content of cooperation and maintaining the independence of the Communist Party. This is obviously unrealistic. The Communist International only sent a "May Directive" after some delay, proposing to establish "eight divisions or ten divisions with reliable commanders" and to set up a "Revolutionary Military Tribunal" to punish reactionary officers. From a basic theoretical point of view, this directive is obviously correct. But under the conditions at the time, this path was also clearly unworkable.

Meanwhile, the CCP's principle of united front also underwent changes. In leading the Shanghai workers' armed uprising, the Party explicitly put forward the principle of the workers leading the armed uprising, seizing power, calling a meeting of representatives from all walks of life to establish a civilian democratic regime, and partly made this principle a reality. Here, "leadership" and "independence" were linked for the first time with issues of arms and power. However, the method of seizing power in Shanghai was not suitable for the objective reality of Chinese society, and the struggle to establish a democratic regime also failed due to a dramatic imbalance of power. At the same time, the Communist International also disapproved of the method of seizing power through the armed uprising of Shanghai workers, advocating for Communists to participate in the Wuhan Kuomintang government. The Chinese Communists accepted the opinion of the Communist International, decided to participate in the Wuhan government and the local governments of the Kuomintang at all levels, and transformed them into a democratic dictatorship of workers, peasants and the petty bourgeoisie. There was still the content of independently carrying out political power activities in theory. However, because the Communists did not propose fundamentally effective measures to transform the army as a pillar of power, the aim of reforming the Kuomintang's power was not achieved, the Party's independent activities were increasingly threatened, and ultimately lost its independence and leadership.

Third, establishing the form of cooperation within the party

At the beginning of the issue of establishing a united front, there was a significant disagreement between the Chinese Communists and the Communist International on the form of "cooperation", until the Xihu Conference in August 1922 preliminarily determined the form of cooperation within the Guomindang and Communist parties. Looking at the activities of the Party at the First National Congress of the KMT and afterwards, the form of cooperation between the KMT and the Communist Party as understood by the Communist International and Chinese Communists at that time included three aspects.

First, members of the Chinese Communist Party joined the KMT in their personal capacity. In the history of the international communist movement, the form of communist joining democratic parties in a union style was precedent to follow.



Marx and Engels led members of the Communist League to participate in democratic groups like the bourgeoisie-styled Cologne Democratic Association in Germany during the European Revolution in 1848. In 1917, Marin advised members of the Indonesian Social Democratic League to join the bourgeoisie's Islamic League. The first cooperation between the Chinese Communist Party and the Chinese Nationalist Party (Kuomintang) drew directly from the latter. Nonetheless, these two instances of cooperation had very little in common. Indonesia, although a backward Asian colonial country, had a political environment characterized by many Western features. Therefore, even though the Indonesian revolution was a national one, it could adopt the methods of Western democratic revolutions to a considerable extent. China, as a semi-colonial and semi-feudal country without a democratic tradition and without a bourgeoisie democracy to leverage, required that the cooperation between the Communist Party of China (CPC) and the Chinese Nationalist Party be implemented in a peculiar Chinese way. Communist International, under whose guidance CPC members joined the Nationalist Party as individuals, helped the Nationalist Party build according to the Soviet model, and later assisted to establish a powerful government. This move, unprecedented in the history of international communism, was necessary given China's unique national conditions.

Since the cooperation between the CPC and the KMT took a peculiar form, it required a corresponding strategy to ensure success. Under the then prevailing conditions in China, a party with strict organizational discipline, a powerful armed force, and a regime combined with such a party and army, if under the control of the proletariat, would become a potent weapon for the people's liberation struggle and the exercise of people's rights. If combined with dictatorial forces, it would easily become a tool for individual fascist dictatorship. Sun Yat-sen was a loyal democratic warrior who saw this unity in terms of republican weaponry. However, the KMT was not just Sun's party; within it, a mixture of representatives from all classes congregated. Anti-Communist and anti-Soviet forces manifested from the beginning; the elements establishing a personal fascist dictatorship using the KMT's party, government, and military organizations were evident and gradually evolved.

Given the CPC, especially the designers of the CPC-KMT cooperation in the Communist International, was helping a non-proletariat party establish a rigid organization, powerful military, and a manageable government, they needed to ensure from the beginning that the political entity they helped to build would not become an alien force. 

However, when defining the internal cooperation between the CPC and the KMT, the Communist International did not do this. The CPC's strategy also had a flaw. As mentioned before, the party had formed the basic understanding since the Second National Congress of the CPC: once the democratic revolution succeeds, the proletariat could not be thoroughly liberated; a second revolution against the bourgeoisie was necessary. Hence, the proletariat party's cooperation with the democratic KMT was a temporary strategy. The proletariat's participation in the democratic revolution was seen as aiding the democrats, a notion that persisted for a long time. The Fourth National Congress of the CPC suggested the working class to join the KMT as necessary and not to expand the organization for the KMT unnecessarily. It restricted the scope of this "aid," essentially suggesting maintaining a certain distance from democrats. The Communist International regarded this change in cooperation principles at the Fourth National Congress of the CPC as a transition from a "close alliance" to a "political union" between the two parties. This statement was vague, leaving the exact meaning and specific form of "political union" undefined and failing to point out the specific difference between a "political alliance" and a "close alliance."

Due to the lack of special strategies by the Communist International and the Chinese Communists in implementing cooperation within the united front of the Kuomintang and the Communist Party, and the failure to formulate specific guidelines to firmly grasp the direction of cooperative development, the leadership of the cooperation gradually began to transform into a tool of dictatorship after the death of Sun Yat-sen. Following Sun Yat-sen's death, the "Western Hills Faction" took up the banner to oppose the "Three Policies". Chiang Kai-shek took advantage of these anti-Communist forces to gradually unfold his dictatorial conspiracies, seizing the opportunity of the Northern Expedition to completely take control of the machinery of the Kuomintang and begun restricting the independent activities of workers and peasants. Faced with the increasingly clear sign of new warlord's dictatorship, the Communist International had still not reminded and warned the Chinese Communists to take effective measures to prevent this dangerous development, and their strategy remained blind. The Chinese Communists, on the other hand, saw this danger clearly and clearly raised the slogan of opposing both the Beiyang military dictatorship and the new military dictatorship.

In response to the development trend of military dictatorship of the new right-wing of the Kuomintang, the Communists also proposed changing the form of cooperation: after the Zhongshan Warship Incident, the Communists proposed to "withdraw from the Kuomintang", which in fact was to completely change the internal party cooperation to external union. This opinion was negated by the Communist International. After that, the party proposed partial modification to the form of cooperation at the Third Executive Meeting of the Fourth Session, and pointed out in its resolution: "The Kuomintang's organization should not be an autocratic party in the form of one class, with severe discipline and regulations, but it now needs to bring many petty bourgeois revolutionary masses into the Kuomintang, so the party's organization form can be more flexible... It needs to have the nature of a political club." Tan Pingshan, representing the CPC Central Committee, submitted a written report to the 7th Executive Committee of the Communist International, further pointing out: "The organizational rules of the Kuomintang are almost as strict as those of the Communist Party, which does not meet the needs of China's situation. These stringent rules are not only unhelpful, but even harmful." The Communist International only formally recognized this viewpoint of the Chinese communists in May 1927. The resolution of the Eighth Executive Committee of the Communist International on Chinese issues stated: "The tasks facing the Kuomintang require corresponding changes in its organizational form. It must be reorganized as soon as possible based on the approach that strongly supports masses... The working, farmer, soldier organizations and craftsmen organizations must be collectively accepted... to join the Kuomintang." This proposed a reorganization plan for the Kuomintang, which was exactly the opposite of that in 1924, but these plans were not implemented and there was no possibility of implementation.

Faced with this severe situation, the Chinese Communists and the Communist International did not take effective measures to reverse the transformation of the united front organs into tools of dictatorship. After the Zhongshan Warship Incident, the party central committee, presided over by Chen Duxiu, adopted a policy of retreat. During the Northern Expedition, the party central committee put forward the concept of resisting the tendency of dictatorship through a wide National Assembly Movement, and stirred up the "Party Power Movement" and "Welcoming Wang Jingwei's return to office" movement within the Kuomintang, as well as balancing power among various military factions, attempting to stop Chiang Kai-shek's dictatorial process through these means, without proposing truly effective measures. The Communist International, on the other hand, advocated eradicating the dictatorship tendency by having large masses of revolutionaries swiftly join the Kuomintang. At the Seventh Enlarged Executive Committee meeting, the Communist International proposed allowing Communist Party members to participate in the Nationalist government, thereby expanding the scope of "internal party cooperation" from within the party and the military to within the government. This marked a major evolution in the form of first cooperation between the KMT and the CPC. The Eighth Executive Committee meeting further emphasized this principle and proposed the task of the Communist Party to take over the leadership within the Kuomintang. However, this was not meant to change the balance of power within the united front, thereby ensuring the smooth transition from the democratic revolution to the socialist revolution.



Stalin, based on the experience of the "October Revolution," asserted that it was impossible to transition from a democratic revolution to a socialist revolution by transforming the Kuomintang government into a dictatorship of the working classes, small farmers, and petty bourgeoisie. He believed that eventually, like the October Revolution, the transitional regime established in the democratic revolution could only be overthrown by armed conflict to achieve the conversion of the two-step revolution. However, the Comintern still did not propose a clear guideline for the Communist Party to independently arm itself, and its strategy was contradictory. With Chen Duxiu presiding over the party central, under the direction of this blind policy and in the context of fierce conflict, it would be even less likely to take immediate, strong measures to salvage the dangerous situation.

History has proven that in semi-colonial and semi-feudal China, it was correct and of tremendous historical significance for the Communists to establish a revolutionary united front in the form of cooperation within the Communist Party, helping the Kuomintang to rebuild a centralized and unified party, a powerful armed force, and an effective government, following the template of the USSR. However, the Comintern and the CCP center under Chen Duxiu's leadership focused only on the independence of the Party's organization and mass movement, failed to seize comprehensive leadership within the united front, and failed to adopt a strategy surpassing allies in overall strength ratio, causing a sharp contradiction between content and form. Unquestionably, this was one of the major reasons for the loss of the great revolution.

During the great revolution, the Chinese Communist Party was in its infancy. The whole party, including Mao Zedong's theoretical strategy, inevitably carried the characteristics of this youthful period. Therefore, at that time, it was impossible for the party to solve all the theoretical and strategic problems of the united front correctly. It was not until the new period of the Anti-Japanese War that, under the leadership of Mao Zedong, the wisdom and experience of the entire party were greatly developed and enriched, resulting in a broader Anti-Japanese National United Front, symbolized by second KMT-CCP Cooperation, which played a substantial role in winning the Anti-Japanese War.

Section II: The Thought and Policy Strategy of Establishing the Anti-Japanese National United Front

1. Establishment of the Principle of Independence and Autonomy in the Anti-Japanese National United Front

The Anti-Japanese National United Front, advocated by the Chinese Communist Party, is a broad alliance based on the cooperation of the KMT and the Communist Party, including all anti-Japanese classes, strata, political parties, groups, patriots, ethnic minorities, compatriots in Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan, and overseas Chinese. During this period of the Anti-Japanese War, it mobilized the national army and the common people to the greatest extent, became the most effective organizational form of national resistance, and was a decisive factor in defeating the Japanese invaders. The formation and application of the thought and policy strategy of the Anti-Japanese National United Front is a great achievement of the Chinese Communist Party in combining the strategic thought of the proletarian revolution with the concrete practice of leading the Anti-Japanese War.

The principle of "independence and autonomy in the Anti-Japanese National United Front" of the Chinese Communist Party means maintaining the political, ideological, and organizational independence of the Communist Party in the Anti-Japanese National United Front while also promoting unity. This principle, in essence, insists on the leadership of the Communist Party in the Anti-Japanese National United Front and the Anti-Japanese War.


From December 1935 to July 1937. During this stage, the CPC Central Committee and Mao Zedong proposed the policy of establishing the Anti-Japanese National United Front while emphasizing the Communist Party's leadership in the United Front. This prepared for the "independence and autonomy within the Anti-Japanese National United Front" principle. In late December 1935, the CPC Central Committee held a Politburo meeting in Wayaobao, Shaanxi. On December 25, the meeting passed the "Resolution on the Current Political Situation and the Party's Tasks" (hereinafter referred to as the "Resolution"). The "Resolution" proposed that the party's line is to "mobilize, unite and organize all revolutionary forces of the whole Chinese nation" and establish "the broadest Anti-Japanese National United Front." While emphasizing the establishment of the Anti-Japanese National United Front, the "Resolution" also stressed the Communist Party's leadership in the united front. The "Resolution" pointed out that the Communist Party "should unswervingly fight against all tendencies of wavering, compromise, surrendering and betrayal within the Anti-Japanese United Front," and "strive for their leadership in the Anti-Japanese front with their thoroughly correct words and actions against Japan and traitors." "Only under the leadership of the Communist Party can the Anti-Japanese movement achieve complete victory." After the meeting, Mao Zedong made a report on the "Strategy Against Japanese Imperialism" at the Party Activists' Meeting, systematically clarifying the issue of the party's leadership in the Anti-Japanese National United Front. Mao Zedong pointed out, "The Communist Party and the Red Army are not only initiating the Anti-Japanese National United Front, but they will also inevitably become a strong pillar in the future Anti-Japanese government and the Anti-Japanese military." "As long as the Communist Party and the Red Army exist and develop, then the Anti-Japanese National United Front will also exist and develop. This is the leadership role of the Communist Party and the Red Army in the National United Front." Mao Zedong also took the failure of the 1927 Revolution as an example to emphasize the importance of the party's leadership in the united front. On April 20, 1936, Zhang Wentian emphasized in the article "Several Questions on the Anti-Japanese People's United Front" that, "the Communist Party, the Soviet Union and the Red Army must become the strong core of the united front," and "the Communist Party, the Soviet Union and the Red Army are to promote, create and expand the Anti-Japanese People's United Front through actions and struggles. We are the locomotive and propeller of the Anti-Japanese People's United Front." On September 1, 1936, the CPC Central Committee pointed out in the "Instructions on Forcing Chiang Kai-shek to Fight Against Japan" that "our overall policy should be to force Chiang to fight against Japan," and at the same time emphasize that we "are the organizers and leaders of the Anti-Japanese United Front of all parties and factions (including Chiang Kai-shek's Kuomintang)." In the first half of May 1937, the CPC Central Committee held a national representative meeting of the party in Yan'an. Mao Zedong made the "Tasks of the Chinese Communist Party in the Anti-Japanese Period" report and the conclusion of "Struggling to Mobilize Millions of Masses into the Anti-Japanese National United Front" at the meeting. Mao Zedong pointed out, "Is the proletariat following the bourgeoisie, or is the bourgeoisie following the proletariat? This issue of the leadership responsibility of the Chinese revolution is the key to the success or failure of the revolution." "Today, the bourgeoisie represented by the Kuomintang still has a lot of passivity and conservatism," "This situation has increased the political leadership responsibility of the proletariat and its party." Mao Zedong pointed out, "How does the proletariat realize its political leadership to all revolutionary classes through its party? First, it is to propose basic political slogans according to the historical development process, and mobilize slogans for each development stage and major event," "as the concrete goals of the unified actions of the people across the country." "Second, when acting across the country according to these concrete goals, the proletariat, especially its vanguard Communist Party, should bring up their unlimited enthusiasm and loyalty and become the model to achieve these concrete goals." "Third, on the principle of not losing the confirmed political goal, establish a proper relationship with allies, develop and consolidate this alliance...



"Fourthly, the development of the Communist Party, the unity of thought, and the strictness of discipline." Mao Zedong also used the lesson of Chen Duxiu's right-leaning capitulationism "lowering the party's stance, blurring the party image, and sacrificing the interests of workers and farmers" leading to the failure of the revolution to illustrate the importance of adhering to the leadership of the proletariat in the united front.
From August 1937 to November 1937. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and Mao Zedong clearly put forward the principle of self-reliance in the united front, and initially expounded this principle. After the start of the National Anti-Japanese War in July 1937, representatives of the Communist Party of China such as Zhou Enlai, Qin Bangxian, Lin Boqu and others continued to negotiate with representatives of the Kuomintang on issues such as the cooperation between the Nationalists and the Communists and the reorganisation of the Red Army. On August 1, Mao Zedong and Zhang Wentian pointed out in a telegram to Zhou Enlai, Qin Bangxian, and Lin Boqu that after the Red Army was reorganised, it should "carry out guerrilla warfare independently under the whole strategic guideline," "not be bound in tactical warfare," and "only in this way can the strengths of the Red Army be exerted and a substantial blow given to the Japanese invaders." On August 4, Mao Zedong and Zhang Wentian telegraphed Zhou Enlai, Zhu De, and Ye Jianying, asking them to propose at the Nanjing Defense Conference that "regular warfare and guerrilla warfare should be combined, and guerrilla warfare should be carried out by the Red Army and other suitable units under the overall strategic deployment, given independent command." In late August 1937, the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China held an expanded meeting in Luochuan, Shaanxi. The meeting decided that: the leadership of proletariat must be adhered to in the united front; to carry out independent guerrilla warfare in the mountains behind the enemy lines, open up battlefields behind the enemy lines, and establish Anti-Japanese bases behind enemy lines; to start Anti-Japanese mass movements in the Kuomintang-ruled areas, fight for the political and economic rights the people should have; and to reduce rent and interest as the basic policy to solve the peasant problem during the Anti-Japanese War period. In October 1937, Mao Zedong once again explained in a conversation with British reporter Betrand: "The method of warfare currently used by the Eight Route Army is what we call independent guerrilla warfare and mobile warfare." Obviously, from the beginning of August 1937 to October, the Party Central Committee and Mao Zedong have clearly put forward the "independent and self-reliant" principle, but this "independent and self-reliant" mainly refers to military independence. On November 12, 1937, Mao Zedong emphasized at a meeting of the party's activists in Yan'an that "the principle of independence and self-reliance must be closely linked to all united front work" in response to the trend of class capitulationism within the party and the trend of national capitulationism within the Kuomintang group. He pointed out that “the explanation, practice and adherence to the principle of independence and self-reliance within the united front is the central link in leading the Anti-Japanese National Revolutionary War to victory." In this way, the principle of independence and self-reliance in the Anti-Japanese National United Front was clearly and comprehensively put forward.

From November 1937 to November 1938, the Party Central Committee represented by Mao Zedong struggled against Wang Ming's right-leaning errors, establishing the principle of independence and self-reliance in the Anti-Japanese National United Front throughout the party. At the end of November 1937, Wang Ming, a representative of the Communist Party to the Comintern, a member of the Executive Committee of the Comintern, and a member of the Presidium, returned from the Soviet Union. He proposed that the emphasis on independence and democracy in the Luochuan meeting was wrong. He opposed the principle of independence and self-reliance in the party's united front, emphasized that "everything should go through the united front" and "everything should obey the united front", and put forward a relatively systematic right-leaning error. Wang Ming's erroneous views had a certain impact within the party, preventing the principle of independence and self-reliance in the Anti-Japanese National United Front from being fully implemented, and causing certain damage to the party's work. The Party Central Committee represented by Mao Zedong conducted necessary struggles against Wang Ming's right-leaning errors, preventing his erroneous views from being formed into resolutions. The Party Central Committee and Mao Zedong continued to uphold the principle of independence and self-reliance in the united front in their actual leadership work, pushing the party's work forward continuously. From the end of September to early November 1938, the Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China was held in Yan'an.



The conference passed the "Expanded Political Resolution of the Sixth Plenary Session of the CCP," approving the line of the Central Political Bureau represented by Mao Zedong. The conference criticized conciliationism on the issue of the united front, and basically overcame Wang Ming's right deviation error. In the conclusion made at the conference, Mao Zedong specially emphasized and elaborated on the issue of independence and self-reliance within the united front. He pointed out: "In short, we must never break the united front, but we must not bind ourselves." "Our principle is the independence and self-reliance within the united front, both united and independent." The political resolution passed by the plenary meeting also emphasized that "we should insist on ensuring the independence of the Communist Party in politics and organization". Thus, the principle of independence and self-reliance in the Anti-Japanese National United Front was established throughout the party.

Second, the establishment of the Anti-Japanese National United Front is a broad alliance based on the cooperation between the Kuomintang and the Communist Party

On the issue of the composition of the Anti-Japanese National United Front, Mao Zedong pointed out: "Our task is to merge the activities of the Red Army with those of the workers, peasants, students, petty bourgeoisie, and national bourgeoisie, into a unified national revolutionary front." To accomplish this task, considering the specific circumstances of the Anti-Japanese war period, it is necessary to extensively carry out the work of the upper-level united front.

Firstly, the party will strive to unite patriotic leaders of all parties and groups as a breakthrough in carrying out upper-level united front work. Mao Zedong, on behalf of the Party Central Committee, once wrote letters to Shen Junru, Zou Taofen, Tao Xingzhi, Zhang Naiqi, Song Qingling, and Cai Yuanpei, expressing enthusiastic support for their Anti-Japanese patriotic claims and activities. This publicity of the political propositions of the Chinese Communist Party for Anti-Japanese salvation gained positive responses from patriotic democrats. Among them, people like Lu Xun, Mao Dun, Song Qingling had written letters to the Party Central Committee expressing their support for the Chinese Communist Party's Anti-Japanese union.

Secondly, the work to strive for local power holders to join the Anti-Japanese National United Front is the central link in the upper-level united front work. Mao Zedong, Zhou Enlai, Zhu De and other central leaders carried out the united front work actively for Zhang Xueliang and Yang Hucheng in Shaanxi; Yan Xishan in Shanxi; Chen Jitang, Li Zongren, Bai Chongxi in Guangdong and Guangxi; Liu Xiang, Liu Wenhui in Sichuan; Long Yun in Yunnan; Feng Yuxiang, Song Zheyuan, Fu Zuoyi in North China, through letters or public talks. They especially strengthened the effort to win over the Northeast Army under Zhang Xueliang in Shaanxi and the Seventeenth Army under Yang Hucheng. In November 1935, Mao Zedong wrote a letter to Dong Yingbin, the commander of the 57th Army of the Northeast Army, explaining the Anti-Japanese united front policy of the Communist Party. On January 25, 1936, Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai, as leaders of the Red Army, issued a "Letter to the Soldiers of the Northeast Army" pointing out that the enemies of the Northeast Army are Japanese imperialism and the traitor Chiang Kai-shek, and the only way out for the Northeast Army is to fight against Japan and Chiang Kai-shek. Also, they clearly expressed that the Red Army is willing to unite with the Northeast Army to fight against Japan first, and they hope to send representatives to negotiate jointly. Through the hard work of our party, the majority of the officers and soldiers of the Northeast Army were the first to accept the proposal of a united anti-Japanese war. As a result of talks between Zhou Enlai, Li Kenong and Zhang Xueliang, Zhang Xueliang was on the path to fight against Japan in alliance with the communists.



Meanwhile, considering Yang Hucheng's good relationship with the Chinese Communist Party during the Great Revolution and afterwards, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) immediately sent Wang Feng with a handwritten letter from Mao Zedong to meet Yang Hucheng, and also dispatched party cadres such as Wang Bingnan to the 17th Route Army to work with Yang Hucheng, which quickly led to an agreement between Yang Hucheng and the Red Army to cease civil war and resist Japan together. Thus, the policy of the national united front against Japan implemented by the Communist Party of China achieved a significant victory in the northwest region first.

Thirdly, the CPC dealt with the Chiang Kai-shek group. In the winter of 1935, the Chinese Communist Party sent representatives to negotiate with the Kuomintang in Nanjing on establishing the Anti-Japanese National United Front, which was first proposed by the Kuomintang. The negotiations were carried out under extremely confidential circumstances. The main issues of the negotiation were ending the civil war, establishing a national defense government, forming an anti-Japanese alliance, restructuring the Red Army, establishing southern guerrilla forces, opening up anti-Japanese public sentiment, releasing political prisoners, and halting land reform. The negotiations lasted until the Xi'an Incident, and no specific agreement had been reached, as the Chiang Kai-shek group showed no sincerity. However, Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Party made great efforts to achieve the second cooperation between Kuomintang and the communist party for a common resistance against Japan. On April 25, 1936, the CPC Central Committee issued a declaration for the creation of a united front among all parties and classes against Japan, for the first time openly including the Kuomintang in the united front.

In dealing with Chiang Kai-shek's group, the Chinese Communist Party made a strategic shift from "anti-Chiang" to "pressuring Chiang to resist Japan". After the shocking "Xi'an Incident", the national situation became extremely complex and Mao Zedong's party central committee astutely proposed a peaceful solution based on the interests of the Chinese nation. This, along with the efforts of a delegation led by Zhou Enlai, forced Chiang Kai-shek to accept a six-point plan including cessation of civil war and a united resistance against Japan. This essentially put an end to the ten years of civil war and laid the groundwork for a united front against Japan.

Thirdly, a comprehensive explanation of the strategic principles and basic policies of the Anti-Japanese National United Front.

Several key issues were correctly resolved in the strategic thinking of the Communist Party of China on the Anti-Japanese National United Front. These involved properly managing the relationship between national struggle and class struggle within the united front. Mao Zedong firmly grasped the primary contradiction between China and Japan, and conducted a detailed analysis of the unique contradictions within the national united front.



He wrote, "War is first analyzed for its characteristics, and so is the united front - the contradiction between China and Japan and the contradictions within the country."
