He used the regularity and characteristics of the anti-Japanese national united front as the basis for formulating strategies. In the fight against Japan, there is both a national struggle and an internal class struggle, which generalizes as the national struggle, subordinating the class struggle to the anti-Japanese national struggle, which is the fundamental principle of the anti-Japanese united front. He emphasized the consistency of the two, pointing out: "In the national struggle, the class struggle appears in the form of the national struggle, which shows the consistency of the two. On the one hand, the political-economic demands of the class require non-break cooperation within a certain historical period; on the other hand, all demands of class struggle should start from the needs of national struggle (for anti-Japanese). Thus, the unity and independence, national struggle and class struggle, anti-Japanese and democracy are combined in the united front, essentially also the relationship between national struggle and class struggle, striving for democracy for the anti-Japanese, the government granting the necessary democracy and political freedom to the people, especially the freedom to organize, train, and arm for self-defense, which can achieve comprehensive anti-Japanese. However, there is also appropriate class struggle in the national struggle, such as preserving the independence of parties and classes, insisting on the limited rights of parties and classes, freedom of criticism, improvement of people's political and economic conditions, etc., which are beneficial to united anti-Japanese struggles and should be preserved by the Communist Party and the masses it leads. In the anti-Japanese struggle, those struggles are to be and should be stopped, which is not conducive to united anti-Japanese, such as civil war, party hostility, local separatism, and on the one hand feudal political-economic oppression, and on the other, insurgent policies and overly high economic demands detrimental to anti-Japanese. Accordingly, the Central Party proposed: First, to distinguish between the big landlords and capitalists who advocate anti-Japanese but are wavering, and advocate unity but are anti-communist, and the nationalist bourgeoisie, small landlords, enlightened gentlemen, who have less duality. When the Kuomintang launched the first anti-communist climax, what attitude the nationalist bourgeoisie took, whether it was different from the big bourgeoisie, was not verified, through the first anti-communist climax, it proved that the attitude of the nationalist bourgeoisie was indeed different from that of the big landlords and big bourgeoisie. Thus, Mao Zedong made important revisions to the article "Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party." He wrote that the national bourgeoisie "not only differs from the surrender faction of the big landlords and big bourgeoisie, but also differs from the stubborn faction of the big bourgeoisie, and they are still our better allies. Therefore, it is absolutely necessary to adopt a cautious policy towards the national bourgeoisie."
Secondly, to distinguish between the anti-Japanese pro-Japanese capitalist class and the pro-Japanese British-American big landlord capitalist class. "The pro-Japanese big capitalist (surrender faction) has already surrendered or is preparing to surrender. The European and American capitalist class (stubborn faction) is very shaky though still in the anti-Japanese camp, they are two-faced characters who fight Japan on one hand and are anti-communist on the other, our policy towards the surrender faction of the big bourgeoisie is to treat them as enemies, decisively overthrow them. As for the diehard faction of the big bourgeoisie, we would adopt a two-faced revolutionary policy towards them, namely: on the one hand to unite with them, because they are still anti-Japanese and we should leverage their contradictions with Japanese imperialism, and on the other to fight them decisively, because they are implementing a high-pressure policy against the Communist Party and the people that undermines the anti-Japanese and unity, without struggle, it would cause harm to the anti-Japanese and unity. "
Furthermore, to distinguish between the different factions within the Kuomintang, which is primarily composed of pro-British and American big capitalists. The Kuomintang is a party made up of complex elements, which include the stubborn faction, the middle faction, and the progressive faction. Due to their different positions, interests, various relationships, and historical situations, their attitudes towards anti-Japanese and unification with communists are different and change according to the time and place.



Therefore, we should also make distinctions among them. On July 6, 1940, Mao Zedong pointed out in his report at a cadre meeting: In fact, only a minority in the Kuomintang are truly diehard factions. On April 12 of the same year, the central secretariat and the military commission also pointed out that only a portion of officers at all levels of the central army and the political training system were diehard factions, the majority were moderates, and some were progressives. It is by no means that all of the central army are diehards. On November 16 of the same year, Mao Zedong, Wang Jiaxiang, and Zhu De, and other central leaders again pointed out: It is wrong and harmful for our party and our army to perceive the Whampoa graduates as a general anti-communist group. Under the current serious situation, it is urgent to correct this perception, take any opportunity to unite with Whampoa soldiers, and not antagonize them, but move them with a national-first mindset. On April 23, 1941, the Central Military Commission issued a "Directive on Distinctly Treating Various KMT Army to Achieve Majority", in which the Kuomintang army was divided into four categories: those who have already colluded with Japanese invaders and are resolutely anti-communist (hidden traitors); those who have not colluded with the Japanese but are also resolutely anti-communist (true diehards); those who are neutral during anti-communist periods and sympathetic to us. It pointed out that our policy is: unite with sympathizers, win over neutrals, weaken diehards, eliminate hidden traitors, in order to strive for the majority and insist in resisting Japan till the end.
   
Finally, distinction should be made between two-faced characters among Japanese-collaborating traitors and determined traitors such as Wang Jingwei, Wang Yitang, and Shi Yousan.  Mao Zedong pointed out, "Even among the Japanese-collaborating traitors, there are two-faced characters, and we should also treat them with a two-faced revolutionary policy. That is, on the side that collaborates with the Japanese, we adopt a policy of attack and isolation, and on the side that wavers, we adopt a policy of pull and win. Make a distinction between such two-faced characters and determined traitors, like Wang Jingwei, Wang Yitang, Shi Yousan, etc.” Unity is achieved through struggle and vice versa. Mao Zedong said in explaining the policy of the Anti-Japanese National United Front: "The current policy of the Anti-Japanese National United Front is neither all unity denying struggle, nor all struggle denying unity, but a comprehensive policy combining unity and struggle. Unity and struggle is a fundamental strategic principle of the Chinese Communist Party towards the bourgeoisie, as well as the general policy of the Anti-Japanese National United Front. The success and failure of our party and the revolution are closely related to this principle.

The unity and struggle in the Anti-Japanese National United Front are dialectical relationships: the two are relative, not absolute. Mao Zedong said in his speech at the meeting of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee on September 24, 1938: “In the United Front, unity is the basic principle, which should be implemented in all places and all work, and we can never forget unity and cannot but assist with the principle of struggle, because struggle is for unity, without struggle, we cannot develop and consolidate the United Front, and necessary struggles that suit the situation are needed". He also said in the "Anti-Surrender Outline": "Never forget struggle while uniting, never forget uniting while struggling, neither of the two can be neglected, but unity is the main, 'grind but do not break'”.  Mao Zedong summed up the relationship between unity (unification, solidarity) and struggle as: "Struggle is the means of unity, and unity is the purpose of struggle. Seeking unity through struggle results in the preservation of unity, seeking unity through concession leads to the demise of unity." In July 1940, Mao Zedong provided the following summary in the conclusion of a discussion meeting of senior cadres in Yan'an: 
① We have always emphasized unity, and the same goes for the future-for all anti-Japan factions. 
② We have always emphasized struggle, and the same goes for the future-to deal with all surrender factions. 
③ We emphasize both unity and struggle-to deal with all die-hard factions who are both anti-Japanese and anti-communist.



④ Sometimes emphasizing unity, sometimes emphasizing struggle - it depends on whether the stubborn faction's attitude is primarily about unity or anti-communism. ⑤ Struggle is for unity - to prolong cooperation time. ⑥ No matter which aspect (political, military, cultural) unity is the main theme for the current period, but no matter which aspect, there is also struggle. This is because the anti-communist policy of the Kuomintang's stubborn faction has not changed. The correct handling of the relationship between unity and struggle is a very complex and difficult issue to grasp. Whether this relationship can be handled correctly has become a dividing line between the correct policy and the wrong policy in the history of the Communist Party of China.
During the Anti-Japanese War, the Communist Party of China, having grown from a young party into a mature party in thought and politics, and mastered the art of leadership of Marxism, not only made an in-depth analysis of the national bourgeoisie, especially the big landlords and bourgeoisie, and formulated a strategy of both unity and struggle, but also successfully implemented this strategy in practice. In the Anti-Japanese United Front, the Chinese Communist Party adopted a strategy of both unity and struggle against the big landlords and the bourgeoisie. This not only defended against attacks from the stubborn faction, protected the progressive forces from loss, and ensured their continued development, but also extended their anti-Japanese war time, maintained cooperation between the CCP and them, and avoided a large-scale civil war. Therefore, Mao Zedong said: "If there is no struggle, the progressive forces would be eliminated by the stubborn forces, the united front would no longer exist, the stubborn faction would surrender to the enemy without resistance, and a civil war would erupt." The main reason why the Anti-Japanese National United Front could stick to victory was that the Communist Party of China adhered to the overall policy of both unity and struggle in the United Front. Developing progressive forces, winning over middle forces, and isolating stubborn forces, the United Front is bound to be a coalition of several classes or political groups. Because the interests and positions of the various classes and political groups participating in the United Front are different, they will inevitably be divided into three forces: left, center, and right. Mao Zedong said: "The basic condition for the victory of the Anti-Japanese War is the expansion and consolidation of the Anti-Japanese United Front. To achieve this goal, we must adopt the strategy of developing progressive forces, winning over middle forces, and opposing stubborn forces. This is an inseparable trio, and the means to achieve unity with all anti-Japanese forces is through struggle." Developing progressive forces, winning over middle forces, and isolating stubborn forces is not only a basic strategic principle of the CPC in the Anti-Japanese National United Front but also the political line of the CPC during the Anti-Japanese War.
Firstly, developing progressive forces. At this time, the following seven forces need to be developed: develop the proletariat, the peasant class, and the strength of the urban small bourgeoisie, freely expand the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army, widely create anti-Japanese bases, develop the Communist Party's organization throughout the country, develop nationwide workers, peasants, youths, women, children democratic constitutional movement among the broad masses of the people, this is the central link in the three strategic principles, the basic link.
"Only by gradually developing progressive forces can we prevent the reversal of the situation, prevent surrender and division, and establish an unyielding foundation for victory in the anti-Japanese war."


Next, we strive to win over the moderate forces. "It must be known that Chinese society is a society with a large middle and small ends. The Communist Party, if it cannot win the masses of the middle class and satisfy them according to their situation, cannot solve the China problem." "In China, such moderate forces have a great power and are often the decisive factor in our struggle against the stubborn faction, so we must take a very cautious attitude towards them." The characteristic of the moderate forces is that they are politically wavering. Therefore, under certain conditions, it is possible for us to win them over. To strive for the moderate forces, specifically, is to strive for the following seven types of people: the national bourgeoisie, the enlightened gentry, the miscellaneous military, the moderate faction within the Kuomintang (referring to those factions and individuals who are not very active against communism or adopt a neutral attitude within the Kuomintang), the moderate faction of the Central Army (although the Central Army is the direct line of troops of Chiang Kai-shek, there are some armies or individual troops that are not very active against communism, or adopt a neutral attitude during the anti-Japanese period), the upper-small bourgeoisie and various small parties. We have done a great deal of work to win over these seven types of people during the Anti-Japanese War and achieved significant results, not only engaging most of them in the Anti-Japanese War, but also joining us in the struggle for democracy. 

Finally, we isolate the stubborn forces. The stubborn faction refers to the anti-Japanese faction of the large landlords and large bourgeoisie, i.e. the Chiang Kai-shek group of the Kuomintang. They adopted a two-faced policy during the Anti-Japanese War: advocating anti-Japanese actions while implementing extremely reactionary policies to crush progressive forces. Isolating the stubborn forces, as we say, is applying the two-faced policy of the revolution to the two-faced policy of the stubborn ones: on the one hand, we strive to keep them in the Anti-Japanese United Front for as long as possible; on the other hand, we are determined to struggle against their passive anti-war and active anti-communist policies. This is a policy of fighting for unity, or of both unity and struggle, a combination of attacking and pulling.

How do we struggle against the stubborn faction? Mao Zedong proposed the principles of reason, benefit, and measure. The principle of reason, also known as the principle of self-defense, means if someone does not offend me, I do not offend him, but if someone offends me, I must hit back. The principle of benefit, also known as the victory principle, means that if you do not fight, then stop, but if you do fight, you must win and absolutely cannot conduct a struggle without planning, preparation, or certainty. The measure principle or the truce principle, means to stop the struggle at the right moment. Successful application of these three principles achieves the goal of isolating the stubborn forces. Use contradictions, strive for the majority, oppose the minority, defeat them one by one

Among the imperialist countries, among the various exploiting classes, groups, and factions, they inevitably collude with each other to exploit and oppress the people on one hand; on the other hand, due to different interests among them, they are competing and full of contradictions, especially with the changing revolutionary situation and the increasing development of the people's revolutionary power, their internal contradictions will sharpen. The contradictions within the exploiting class and its continuous expansion are beneficial for the proletarian-led people's revolutionary struggle. Mao Zedong, in his book, "On the Strategy Against Japanese Imperialism," proposed the strategic viewpoint that "we must collect all the fights, gaps, and contradictions in the enemy's camp for use against the main enemy." Later, he summarized it into a sixteen-word strategic guideline of "using contradictions, striving for the majority, opposing the minority, defeating them one by one", and the CCP leadership successfully applied this strategic guideline. First of all, the establishment of the second KMT-CCP cooperation and the formation of the Anti-Japanese National United Front, is the result of the Chinese Communist Party successfully using the contradiction between the British and American faction of the Chinese big bourgeoisie and Japanese imperialism.



In 1956, Mao Zedong explained to foreign friends the experiences of our country's successful democratic revolution. He said, "The comprador bourgeoisie in the past were pro-Britain, pro-America, and pro-Japan. During the Anti-Japanese War, we took advantage of the conflicts between Britain, the US, and Japan, and first fought against the Japanese invaders and the puppet group attached to them. Then, we opposed the invasion of the US and Britain and overthrew their puppet groups. "Secondly, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) exploited the conflicts between local warlords and the Chiang Kai-shek group, gaining the support of local powers, isolating the Chiang Kai-shek group, and forcing them to join the Anti-Japanese war in cooperation with our party. Next, the CCP, in its struggle against the capitulation and anti-communist activities of the Kuomintang Chiang Kai-shek group, also fully exploited the conflicts among various groups and factions within the Kuomintang, winning the majority, isolating the minority, and achieving victory in the struggle. During the Anti-Japanese War, in many places, the people's revolutionary forces were at a disadvantage compared to the Kuomintang, yet the CCP was able to achieve victory in the anti-reactionary struggle due to the Party's political advantage and appropriate application of strategy. Finally, our party also exploited the contradictions between the national bourgeoisie and the large landlords and the big bourgeoisie, uniting the national bourgeoisie and isolating the large landlords and the big bourgeoisie.

Section Three: The Thought and Policy of the People's Democratic United Front 

I. The Proposal of the Concept of the "People's Democratic United Front"

The period of the Liberation War was the final decisive stage of the Chinese democratic revolution and one of the most spectacular chapters in the history of the Chinese revolution. The Chinese revolutionary united front, formed against the backdrop of the decisive battle between two different destinies and futures of China, has its own characteristics. It is based on the common political foundation of striving for people's democracy and achieving domestic peace; the guidelines and policies are completely independently decided and implemented by the CCP; it has a complete organizational form - the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference; and so on. However, the most prominent feature of the united front during the Liberation War is its large scale and profound foundation, beyond any previous time. Mao Zedong repeatedly mentioned the grand scale and deep foundation of the united front at that time during the Liberation War. In February 1947, he said in a party directive drafted for the Central Committee of the CCP: "This is a very broad united front of the entire nation. Compared with the united front during the Anti-Japanese War, it is not only of the same grand scale but also has a more profound foundation." Here, he already mentioned that the foundation of the united front is more profound than during the Anti-Japanese War. At the end of 1947, based on the development of the practice of the united front, Mao Zedong drew a new conclusion, further stating: "Our united front of the new democratic revolution is now broader and more solid than at any previous time." He specifically explained: "At first glance, it seems that compared with the Anti-Japanese War, our national united front of the revolution has shrunk. But in reality, only in the current period, only after Chiang Kai-shek sold out the national interests to American imperialism and launched a nationwide civil war against the people, only after the crimes of American imperialism and the reactionary rule of Chiang Kai-shek were completely exposed in front of the Chinese people, did our national united front truly expand." Here, Mao Zedong clearly affirmed that the scale and the profound basis of the united front during the Liberation War surpassed any previous time, especially surpassing the Anti-Japanese National United Front - the only comparable united front in terms of scale, scope, and influence. 

The concept of the "People's Democratic United Front" appeared in the later stage of the Liberation War, and was first proposed by the democrat Zhu Xuefan.


In January 1948, Zhu Xuefan, the chairman of the Chinese Labor Association in London, accepted the invitation of the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee. Before leaving for the liberated areas within the country, he issued a declaration to workers around the world. The declaration stated that he fully accepted the claims of the Chinese Communist Party, supported the democratic revolution movement, supported land reform, supported all political forces struggling for democracy, and formed a People's Democratic United Front. On July 1, 1949, the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party issued a slogan to commemorate the 12th anniversary of the "July 7" Anti-Japanese War, proposing to "consolidate the People's Democratic United Front". This is the earliest mention of the concept of the "People's Democratic United Front" by the Chinese Communist Party.

1. Systematically clarified the main targets of the revolution under the new situation:
The successful united front policy of the Chinese Communist Party has promoted the formation of the People's Democratic United Front thought and strategy with its own characteristics. In order to make the entire party and the people of the whole country further understand the current direction of struggle, Mao Zedong in April 1947 more clearly put the opposition to bureaucratic capitalism in parallel with the opposition to imperialism and feudalism as the three major tasks of the New Democratic Revolution. In December 1947, Mao Zedong, in his report on the current situation and our tasks, analyzed the economic reality of the bureaucratic monopoly capital class accumulating social wealth and monopolizing the national economic lifeline, pointed out: "This monopoly capital, coupled with the state power, becomes the state monopoly capitalism. This monopoly capitalism is closely combined with foreign imperialism, the landlord class in the country and old-style rich peasants, to form a comprador feudal state monopoly capitalism. This is the economic basis of the reactionary regime of Chiang Kai-shek. Therefore, the task of the New Democratic Revolution, in addition to cancelling the privileges of imperialism in China, is domestically to eliminate the exploitation and oppression of the landlord class and the bureaucrat bourgeoisie (big bourgeoisie), to change the comprador feudal productive relations, and to liberate the restrained productive forces. Because the bureaucratic monopoly bourgeoisie controls large state-owned enterprises that control the national economic lifeline and possess a huge amount of social wealth, "it prepares sufficient material conditions for the New Democratic Revolution." Mao Zedong clearly put "confiscating the monopoly capital of Chiang Kai-shek, Soong Tse-ven, Kong Xiangxi, and Chen Lifu as the property of the New Democratic State", along with "confiscating the land of the feudal class as the property of the peasants" and "protecting the national industry and commerce" as the three major economic programs of the New Democratic Revolution. This is Mao Zedong's further development of the tasks and program of the New Democratic Revolution under the new political and economic environment after the victory of the Anti-Japanese War.

During the Anti-Japanese War, Mao Zedong had pointed out: "The big bourgeoisie with a comprador nature has never been the driving force of the Chinese revolution, but the object of the Chinese revolution." But during the Anti-Japanese War, our party did not directly propose the slogans of confiscating bureaucratic capital and eliminating the bureaucratic bourgeoisie. The reason for this was firstly that the bureaucratic bourgeoisie was still within the anti-Japanese camp at the time, and we needed to adopt the unified front strategy of both unity and struggle against them in order to concentrate our forces to deal with the main enemy, Japanese imperialism. Therefore, confiscating bureaucratic capital and eliminating the bureaucratic bourgeoisie could not and should not have been the action program for that period. Secondly, the monopoly groups of big bankers and big compradors gradually formed before the Anti-Japanese War. During the Anti-Japanese War, they were in the stage of expanding their monopoly power into other economic sectors and accelerating capital concentration. After the victory of the Anti-Japanese War, the bureaucratic capital developed to its peak, bringing unparalleled disasters to the Chinese people. Its feudal, comprador, military, and state monopoly reactionary nature was thoroughly exposed before the people. As Mao Zedong pointed out: "Based on the Sino-US Commercial Agreement, the exclusive capital of the United States and Chiang Kai-shek's bureaucratic comprador capital are closely combined together, controlling the country's economic life. As a result, there is extreme inflation, unprecedentedly high prices, increasing bankruptcy of the national industry and commerce, and the worsening of the living conditions of laborers and public service personnel.



This situation forces people of all classes to unite for the struggle to save the dying. "In short, there is a gradual process of exposure to the law of the generation, development, and demise of bureaucratic capital and its reactionary nature. The people of China's understanding and struggle against it also correspondingly go through a gradual process of development. After the People's Liberation Army of China moved into strategic attack in 1947, the Chinese Communist Party timely put forth the slogan of confiscating the bureaucratic capital of the four big families, which naturally instantly received the heartfelt support of the broadest masses of the people across the country. 

Mao Zedong has incisively pointed out: "A revolution led by the proletariat, of the masses of people, against imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucratic capitalism, is the New Democratic Revolution of China, which is the overall line and policy of the Chinese Communist Party at the current historical stage. Considering the concentrated representation of the three big enemies: imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucratic capitalism, as being the reactionary ruling group of Chiang Kai-shek, Mao Zedong has distinctly proposed the political slogan of "toppling Chiang Kai-shek, liberating the whole of China". This slogan encapsulates the entire revolutionary program of the Chinese Communist Party at the time and presents a clear goal of struggle and political direction for the whole Party, army, and the people of the country. It has extremely significant implications for isolating a handful of enemies to the greatest extent and uniting the vast majority of people, especially in winning over the middle-of-the-roaders. 

At different stages of the revolutionary development, Mao Zedong always paid attention to accurately identifying the main enemies of the revolution by considering changes in the objective situation and accordingly setting out specific programs and policies. On this premise, Mao Zedong also always underscored the importance of exploiting the contradictions among factions within the reactionary ruling group to divide and disintegrate the enemy, emphasizing "collecting all the disputes, loopholes, and contradictions within the enemy camp for use against the current main enemy". At the start of the liberation war, Mao Zedong pointed out: to crush Chiang Kai-shek's attack, "we should seek all those within the Nationalist Party's army who might oppose the civil war, and isolate the warmongers". "On one hand, our army should conduct broad and open political propaganda and assaults against the KMT's war army to demoralize its will to fight the civil war. On the other hand, preparations for and organization of rebellions should be initiated from within the KMT army. Embark on the Gao Shuxun campaign so that a large number of Nationalist forces will follow the example of Gao at critical junctures of the war and stand on the people's side." To this end, the central government established specialized departments and assigned specialized cadres to carry out the work of dividing the enemy army. After the People's Liberation Army moved into strategic attack, the continual military failures of Chiang Kai-shek induced an extremely serious crisis in the enemy camp. The contradictions between various factions within the KMT and between Chiang's direct-line troops and local military groups become increasingly sharp. The central committee of the party further pointed out: "When dealing with contradictions within the enemy, if they remain as opposition factions within the reactionary rule and local power factions against Chiang, we can only consider them as indirect allies. But when they change their stance, endorse our action program, and openly oppose Americo-Chiang, we must welcome them, urge them to transform themselves through actions, and prove their direct alliance." Under this correct policy, our party has done a lot of patient, meticulous work to win over the anti-Chiang factions within the KMT, accelerating the disintegration of the enemy camp. Influenced by the Chinese Communist Party, the anti-Chiang factions within the KMT united in January 1948 to establish the Nationalist Party Revolutionary Committee, with Li Jishen, Feng Yuxiang, and others as its leaders, openly declaring their participation in the struggle to overthrow Chiang Kai-shek's treasonous dictatorship. At the same time, the People's Liberation Army, under the favorable conditions of the KMT's settled defeat and the rapid expansion of all contradictions within the enemy, carried out the policy of closely integrating military attack and political persuasion and launched a massive political offensive on all fronts.



This not only prompted many armies of the Kuomintang to announce uprisings or surrender their cities en masse, but also won over General Fu Zuoyi, who was entrusted by Chiang Kai-shek to command over 600,000 troops, to accept peaceful reorganization. During our great advancement of a million soldiers across the Yangtze River and directly into Nanjing, even Zhang Zhizhong, the chief representative sent by the Kuomintang government for negotiations, was won over to the side of the people's revolution, and joined the ranks of the people's democratic united front.

III. Strategies and thoughts on consolidating and expanding the worker-peasant alliance

The feudal landlord class has always been one of the main targets of the Chinese democratic revolution. During the War of Resistance Against Japan, our party, in order to establish a broad united front against Japan, proactively changed the policy of confiscating landlord's land after 1927 to a policy of rental and interest reduction, in order to win over landlords to join the resistance. After the end of the War of Resistance Against Japan, the national contradictions between China and Japan eased, and the contradictions between the peasant masses and the feudal landlord class became increasingly acute. 

In Shanxi, Hebei, Shandong and other liberated areas in central China, there were broad mass movements in which, through struggles against traitors, liquidation, rent reduction, and interest reduction, land was taken directly from landlords, thus achieving "the tiller to own their land". Some collaborators, bullies, and landlord elements fled to the cities, cursing the peasant movement in the liberated areas. Influenced by the reactionaries, some intermediaries were skeptical of the farmers' struggle, and a few people within the party felt that the peasant movement was "overreacting". 

In response to this situation, Mao Zedong and Liu Shaoqi clearly pointed out at the time: "Now, as in the time of the Great Revolution, the peasants reach out for the land, and whether the Communist Party approves, we should have a firm and clear stance.” 

After the outbreak of the full-scale civil war, Chiang Kai-shek's large-scale attack on the liberated areas boosted the reactionary momentum of the landlord class, who pinned their hopes on the victory of the Chiang Kai-shek government. Landlords and bullies who had fled to Chiang's jurisdiction organized "returning home groups" one after another, attacking the liberated areas with Chiang Kai-shek's troops, recklessly counter-attacking the masses of peasants, stubbornly opposing the land reform movement led by our party and at the same time, the rich peasants also adopted a hostile attitude towards land reform. 

In essence, one of the important purposes of the Chiang Kai-shek group's launching of the counter-revolutionary civil war was also to preserve the feudal land system and the feudal privileges of the landlord class in order to maintain their reactionary economic foundation. Therefore, our party convened the National Land Conference from July to September 1947 and formulated the "Outline of Chinese Land Law".



On October 10th, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) solemnly pointed out when announcing this outline: "The land system in China is extremely unreasonable. Generally speaking, the landlords and wealthy peasants, who make up less than 10% of the rural population, own about 70% to 80% of the land and cruelly exploit peasants. However, hired workers, poor peasants, middle peasants, and other people, who account for more than 90% of the rural population, only own about 20% to 30% of the land in total, laboring year-round without sufficient food or clothing. This severe situation is the root cause of our nation being invaded, oppressed, impoverished, and backward, and it is the basic obstacle to the democratization, industrialization, independence, unification, and prosperity of our country." In order to change this severe situation, the "Outline of Chinese Land Law" (hereinafter referred to as the "Outline") developed the revolutionary spirit of the May 4th directives, specifically declaring: "Abolish the land system of feudal and semi-feudal exploitation, and implement the land system where the cultivators have their own fields." The "Outline" explicitly stipulates policies to confiscate all land property of landlords and expropriate excess land property of wealthy peasants, and proposes "to deduct more and supplement less in terms of land quantity, and to deduct fertile and supplement lean" in terms of quality, detailing the methods of distributing land according to the average population in rural areas. In accordance with the provisions of the "Outline of Chinese Land Law," a land reform movement began in the liberated areas to completely destroy the feudal and semi-feudal exploitation system and eliminate the landlord class on an unprecedented large scale.

Since the Central Committee issued the "May 4th Directive", the land reform movement carried out in the liberated areas has been overly lenient towards the wealthy peasants and some landlords, with some regions seldom daring to mobilize the masses or fulfilling the poor peasants' demands for land, thus showing a right-leaning tendency. After the National Land Conference formulated a thorough land policy, the liberated areas overcame this right-oriented trend and vigorously promoted land reform. However, some over-"left" tendencies occurred, such as some areas failing to properly classify class elements, misclassifying the identities of landlords and wealthy peasants, blurring the boundaries between enemies and us; some infringing on the interests of middle peasants, damaging national industries and commerce; some overly emphasizing detaining the assets of landlords and wealthy peasants, using the same method to struggle with wealthy peasants and landlords, and even uniformly adopting the method of "sweeping them away", failing to provide them with a way out, leading to chaotic beatings and killings; and so forth. Faced with this, the CPC Central Committee led by Mao Zedong attached great importance to it, and further elaborated the basic principles of land reform and a series of specific policies around the Central Committee's December meeting in 1947, resolutely rectifying the above-mentioned "left" leaning errors. At the end of November 1947, the CPC Central Committee reissued Mao Zedong's "How to divide the rural classes" and "Decisions on some issues in the land struggle" written in 1933, as the standards for classifying classes and the basis for executing policies. The release and implementation of these two documents corrected the tendency of the "left" leaning policy in the land reform that misclassified some people as landlords and wealthy peasants. At the Central Committee's December meeting, Mao Zedong pointed out: "In order to vigorously and thoroughly proceed with land reform, not only must we organize the most extensive mass peasant associations in rural areas, including hired workers, poor peasants, and middle peasants, and their elected committees, but we must also first organize poor peasant groups, including poor and hired worker masses, and their elected committees, as the legitimate bodies for implementing land reform, and the poor peasant groups should become the leadership backbone of all rural struggles. Our policy is to rely on the poor peasants, consolidate the alliance with middle peasants, and eliminate the feudal and semi-feudal exploitation system of the landlord class and the old-style wealthy peasants. The land and property that the landlords and wealthy peasants should get cannot exceed the peasant masses. However, the so-called 'left'-leaning erroneous policy that was implemented during 1931-1934, namely 'the landlords do not get land, the wealthy peasants get bad land', should not be repeated."



To get more than 90% of people in the countryside to participate in the unified front of land reform, Mao Zedong pointed out two basic principles that must be followed: "First, the demands of the poor and hired peasants must be met. This is the most basic task of land reform. Second, it is necessary to firmly unite the middle peasants and not harm their interests." 

In order to fulfill the strategic task of consolidating the union of middle peasants, Mao Zedong made specific rules for middle peasant policies: "In the process of confiscating the land property of the feudal class and dividing the land, the opinions of the middle peasants must be respected, some needs of the middle peasants (such as allowing some middle peasants to retain a higher amount of land than the average level of the poor peasants) must be taken into account. The active workers in the farming community and the local democratic government must take in middle peasants, do not make mistakes in driving people of middle peasant origin into the rich peasant circles, but also reasonably and fairly make middle peasants bear the burden of land taxes and support the war." 

Due to the implementation of the above two basic principles, the worker and peasant alliance led by the working class (through the Communist Party) has been consolidated and developed as never before, enabling the role of the peasant main force to be fully utilized.

During the land reform movement, the Party Central Committee, led by Mao Zedong, not only focused mainly on relying on poor and hired peasants and uniting middle peasants, but also focused on winning over all classes and strata that could be united. To isolate and attack the most stubborn enemies in the feudal class, Mao Zedong, in line with China's actual feudal relations in rural areas, proposed policies that would create distinctions between landlords and wealthy peasants, large, medium, and small landlords, bullies and non-bullies among landlords and wealthy peasants, and that he would not harm policies for non-feudal forms of exploitation such as landlords and wealthy peasants investing in industry and commerce. In the struggle to overthrow the feudal system, the Central Committee and Mao Zedong made special efforts to win over enlightened gentry who had split from the feudal class. 

The Central Committee, in reasserting its strategic principle of "winning over the majority, opposing the minority, using contradictions, and breaking them down one by one," emphasized that "it is important to understand that the 'majority' should include a minority of enlightened elements in the enemy camp (i.e., enlightened gentry and patriots in the feudal comprador class)." In this regard, Mao Zedong provided a profound explanation: "The enlightened gentry are individual people in the landlord and wealthy peasant class who have democratic tendencies. These people have contradictions not only with bureaucratic capitalism and imperialism but also with feudal landlords and wealthy peasants. During the War of Resistance against Japan and in the difficult period after the war, they gave us considerable help, and when we implemented land reform, they did not impede or oppose it. Therefore, a policy of unity should still be adopted towards them.” 

As China's intellectuals mostly come from landlord and wealthy peasant families, the country's national bourgeoisie mostly has ties with the land, and there are hundreds of thousands of enlightened gentry across the country, if we unreservedly unite all enlightened gentry who support the opposition to America and Chiang Kai-shek, who support democracy (not anti-Communist), and who support land reform, and also educate them in the process, then it will be beneficial for winning over the nation's intellectuals, the national bourgeoisie, the enlightened gentry, and for isolating the main enemy of the Chinese Revolution, the Chiang Kai-shek reactionaries. 

Based on the above-guiding principles, our party consolidated and won over a large number of enlightened gentry and patriots during land reform, making large landlords, bullies, and wealthy rural families in the feudal class extremely isolated. Through our party's unity and education, many representative figures among the enlightened gentry have successively sided with the people's revolution, participating in the struggle against the American and Chiang reactionaries, and playing a certain role in the People's Democratic United Front.


In January 1948, after thorough investigation and research, Ren Bishi, entrusted by the Central Committee of the Party, delivered a speech on "Several Issues in Land Reform", correctly expounding on subjects such as "standards for class division in rural areas", "the need for a solid unity of all middle peasants", "methods of struggle against landlords and rich peasants", "policies for industry and commerce", "issues related to intellectuals and enlightened gentry", and "resolutely opposing random beatings and killings". This important speech by Ren Bishi more specifically clarified the principles and policies of land reform proposed by Mao Zedong and played a positive role in rectifying the "leftist" tendency.

In summary, the Central Committee led by Mao Zedong drew upon the lessons learned from the Land Revolution War, timely correcting the rightist and "leftist" tendencies in the land reform movement since the "May 4th Directive", and formulated policies and guidelines in accordance with the actual situation of the rural areas. The implementation of these policies galvanized the broad mass of poor peasants, solidified the unity of all middle peasants, won over the enlightened gentry and other patriots, and not only did not diminish the ranks of the people's democratic united front against feudalism in the countryside, but further strengthened and expanded it.

As the People's Liberation Army advanced into the regions controlled by the Kuomintang, newly liberated areas increased rapidly. Given that remnants of the enemies in these regions had not been completely eradicated and the consciousness of the masses was generally low, different from the older liberated areas and semi-old liberated areas, Mao Zedong proposed different strategies for implementing land laws in different areas in February 1948. In the older liberated areas, the land issues had been largely resolved and only a part of the land needed to be adjusted, so the focus should be on rectifying the Party's ranks and resolving conflicts between the Party and the masses; in the semi-old liberated areas, the land issue had not yet been thoroughly resolved, so land distribution should be widespread and thorough; in the newly liberated areas, the land law should be implemented in two stages: the first stage should neutralize the rich peasants, attack the landlords, especially large landlords, distribute their land and property, and then enter the second stage to distribute the surplus land and property of the rich peasants. Soon after, based on the actual conditions of the rural work in the newly liberated areas, Mao Zedong made new provisions. He pointed out: "If the land is divided too early, it will be welcomed by only a few courageous individuals, the basic masses will not get their share and will express dissatisfaction. Moreover, the rapid dispersion of social wealth is also detrimental to the army. If the land is distributed too early, the burden of military needs will fall prematurely on peasants, not landlords and rich peasants." Therefore, it is necessary to first widely implement rent reduction and interest alleviation, as well as corresponding social and financial policies, to ensure that "social wealth does not disperse, social order is relatively stable, conducive to concentrating all efforts to eliminate the reactionary Kuomintang". The aforementioned strategic approach proposed by Mao Zedong, facilitated land reform to be carried out in liberated areas of different types, according to the strength of feudal forces, the level of mass consciousness and organization, differentiating, step by step, in stages, thus making our party's land reform policy increasingly complete. In April 1948, Mao Zedong highly encapsulated the basic principles and policies of land reform into the general line of land reform, namely, "relying on poor peasants, uniting middle peasants, eliminating feudal exploitation in stages and differently, and promoting agricultural production". Since then, the large-scale land reform movement has developed healthily along the correct track of this general line. More than a year after the announcement of the "Chinese Land Law Outline", our party has thoroughly solved the land problem in vast areas with a population of more than 100 million. The land of the feudal class was roughly evenly distributed among the rural people, especially the poor and hired peasants, greatly stimulating the revolutionary passion and production enthusiasm of the peasants, the main allies of the proletariat.



In both economic and political terms, the vast number of peasants who had gained emancipation strove to produce, eagerly joined the army, actively supported the front lines, and provided a solid and inexhaustible reserve force for the national liberation war. They played an unprecedentedly significant role, whether in supplying troops, providing for the army, or transporting war supplies. The land reform movement, carried out thoroughly and universally, but also step by step and differently, mobilized the enthusiasm of hundreds of millions of peasants, won all the force that could be won, and provided our party with the fundamental conditions to defeat all enemies, consolidating and expanding the people's democratic united front.

Four, Promoting the Formation and Development of the Second Front

After the outbreak of the all-out civil war, under the heroic fight and firm resistance of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, the KMT army shifted from an all-out attack to a key attack, and the KMT government suffered a heavy blow militarily. At the same time, the KMT government also fell into a severe crisis economically and politically. Economically, the U.S. and Chiang signed a series of treaties and agreements. The American troops rampaged arbitrarily in China and committed wrongdoings. According to incomplete statistics from Shanghai, Nanjing, Beiping, and Tianjin, from August 1945 to the end of 1946, there were at least 3,800 instances of American troops' atrocities, causing over 300 casualties among our troops and civilians, raping more than 300 women, and further colonizing the region ruled by the KMT. KMT extensively plundered the people, recklessly issued banknotes, causing severe inflation, skyrocketing prices, and the people struggled to get by. Politically, the KMT unilaterally convened a divisive National Congress, sabotaged the Nanjing negotiations, and forced the CCP representatives to withdraw from the KMT-controlled area, fully exposing their true face of fake peace. The vast majority of the people and democratic parties became educated from the KMT's perverse behavior, became increasingly dissatisfied with the KMT, and pinned their hopes on the Communist Party of China. Mao Zedong pointed out: "On the basis of the Sino-US commercial agreement, the monopoly capital of the United States and Chiang Kai-shek's bureaucratic comprador capital are closely combined, controlling the country's economic life. The result was extreme inflation, unprecedentedly high prices, the increasing bankruptcy of national industry and commerce, and the worsening livelihood of laboring masses and public servants. This situation forced people from all walks of life to unite and struggle for survival."

The CCP Central Committee correctly analyzed the situation at the time and believed that a new climax of the nationwide people's revolution was about to come. To this end, Mao Zedong drafted a directive for the party central committee on February 1, 1947, stating: "The current situation in various aspects suggests that China's political situation will develop to a new stage. This new stage is the stage of the development of the nationwide anti-imperialist and anti-feudal struggle to the new people's great revolution. Now it is its eve. The task of our party is to struggle for the arrival and success of this climax." On February 28, 1947, Zhou Enlai drafted the "Strategy against the KMT in the White Areas" for the central committee, which was sent to Dong Biwu, Liu Xiao, Qian Ying, Wu Yuzhang, Fang Fang, and others. The directive stated: "The struggle of the masses in the Jiangnan region will inevitably go through some twists and turns, but the overall trend will inevitably continue to rise. Facing the current suppression policy of Jiang, we should expand propaganda, avoid hard collisions, win over middle people, use legal forms, and strive to establish a broad front against treason, civil war, dictatorship, and anti-secret terror based on the struggle for survival."



The directive emphasizes, "In the struggle, we need to link up, and sometimes shift to economic struggle, to mobilize a larger crowd to join. It is also easy to gain a legitimate form. With a broad foundation of economic struggle, it is also easy to link to the anti-espionage and anti-civil war struggle." On May 5, Zhou Enlai drafted another directive for the Central Committee, sending it to Liu Xiao, Liu Changsheng, Qian Ying, and others. In response to the Kuomintang government's fabrication of the so-called CCP underground struggle line program, attempting to suppress the people's movement in the KMT-ruled area with an excuse, the directive states: in the Kuomintang-ruled areas, the party's work policy "is to protect the party and progressive forces, to continue strengthening the people’s movement," and "for this purpose, we need to be firm and brave as well as alert and cautious." We must adhere to the party's principle of mobilizing the masses to carry out anti-American and anti-Chiang policies, conducting "legal and illegal struggles."

The directive stresses: "Work in the city under the Jiang administration, everything should be planned for a long-term existence, to promote mass struggle, carry out a united front, and in this way, can help the liberation area victory, the advent of a new national climax." The people in the Kuomintang-ruled areas, under the specific leadership and guideline of the united front of the Communist Party, started a patriotic and democratic movement against the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang in the cities and rural areas.

The US and Chiang Kai-shek adopted the policy of turning China into a US colony, starting a civil war, and strengthening fascist dictatorial rule, thereby declaring themselves enemies of the people. They put the people of all classes on the line of hunger and death, forcing all the people to unite and struggle against the KMT government. There is no other way out. Mao Zedong pointed out: "The Chinese people of all classes who are oppressed and united by the reactionary policies of the Chiang Kai-shek government, including workers, peasants, urban petite bourgeoisie, national bourgeoisie, enlightened gentry, other patriots, minorities, and overseas Chinese. This is a very wide national united front." On May 30, 1947, Mao Zedong pointed out: "There are already two front lines in China. The war between Chiang Kai-shek's invading army and the People's Liberation Army is the first front line. Now the second front line has appeared, which is the sharp struggle between the great just student movement and Chiang Kai-shek's reactionary government." The second front line is led by the student movement, including all classes of democratic movements under KMT rule and oppression.

The starting point of the second front line was the student protest against American brutality in Peking in December 1946. On the evening of December 24, 1946, Shen Chong, a female student at Peking University, was raped by US troops. After the news came out, it aroused great outrage among the people of Peiping, especially students. The underground party organization believed that this was a good opportunity to launch a mass struggle, and immediately decided: through the Shen Chong incident, to raise the banner of maintaining national dignity, to ignite the national righteous indignation of the masses, and to initiate a protest against American brutality among Peiping students. The party decided to unite a larger group of students and launched a school strike throughout the city. The KMT authorities tried to undermine the student movement, hoping to use "legal solutions" to blur the political nature of the struggle. Aiming at the conspiracy of the US-Chiang reactionaries, the Communist Party organization proposed to adhere to the center slogan of "American troops out of China". This slogan has a clear political nature of struggle, which is easy to unite the masses and expand the patriotic united front.



On December 29th, the underground party school committee of Beiping decided to take to the streets for a procession. On December 30th, students from Beiping marched on the streets, chanting slogans like "American soldiers, get out of China." The movement rapidly expanded nationwide with 500,000 students participating. The movement was aimed directly at the American and Kuomintang reactionary factions, marking a new high in the struggle of the people in the Nationalist-controlled areas and becoming the starting point for the formation of the second front. Thereafter, the Chinese Communist Party's underground organization took the initiative to unite the masses and lead the people in the Kuomintang-controlled areas in numerous anti-American and anti-Kuomintang struggles. The May Fourth Movement of 1947 signified the formation of the second front. After the resistance movement, the Nationalist government intensified its economic reign and political oppression, causing people's struggles to erupt in succession and the patriotic democratic united front continued to expand. In response to this situation, the Shanghai Regional Committee of the CCP made a report to the CPC Central Committee on April 28, 1947, noting that "the mass movement in the Chiang-controlled areas, following the resistance movement, is about to reach another new high which may begin in the month of Chen (May)." The Shanghai Regional Committee decided to initiate mass movements, starting from the continuous development of livelihood struggles and gradually progressing to political opposition against the Kuomintang's "foreign borrowing and domestic war," focusing on "organizing several central movements as the mainstream activities when the backbone of the movement converges." On May 5th, Zhou Enlai drafted a telegram for the CPC Central Committee to Liu Xiao and others, emphasizing the "protection of our party and progressive democratic forces, to continue to strengthen and carry out the people's movement," encouraging mass mobilization and the expansion of the united front in the anti-Kuomintang and anti-American struggles. Following the instructions from the central leadership, the Shanghai Bureau decided that students from universities in the north and south of the Kuomintang-controlled area would initiate various activities commemorating the May Fourth Movement starting from early May 1947. Thus began the prologue to the second front's struggle.

The Shanghai Regional Committee of the CCP believed that Nanjing, being the "capital" of the Kuomintang with significant political influence, was the place to breakthrough, launching an impressive anti-civil war and anti-famine movement that would shock both domestic and international observers. Under the leadership of the Shanghai Bureau, on May 20th, representatives from universities in Shanghai, Hangzhou, Suzhou, and other places went to Nanjing, joining more than six thousand students from Nanjing University to initiate a massive anti-famine and anti-civil war protest. The march faced suppression by the Kuomintang military, police, and secret service; this is known as the May 20th Incident. The movement was notable for two main features: it evolved from economic to political struggles, and from scattered protests, it gradually converged into a unified national movement. The patriotic and democratic student movement received support from the entire nation, which swiftly expanded the anti-American and anti-Kuomintang struggle to over sixty major cities across the country, creating an enormous tide of opposition.

During the struggle, the Communist Party paid great attention to the strategy of the united front, emphasizing mass mobilization, unity among the majority, exploiting the enemy's contradictions, disintegrating reactionary forces, and adhering to the principles of being justifiable, advantageous, and restrained. At that time, within the ruling group of the Kuomintang, there were disagreements on how to handle the student movement. Members of the Kuomintang Legislative Yuan, Shanghai Mayor Wu Guozhen, and some university presidents feared that the Kuomintang military, police, and secret service's brutality would escalate the situation and become unmanageable, advocating for a resolution through mediation or negotiation.



The Shanghai Bureau guided the masses to call for the release of all arrested students, to punish the perpetrators, and to focus their accusations on the persecution by the Kuomintang's military, police, and special forces. At the same time, in order to reduce the persecution by the Kuomintang's military and police, on May 23, Zhou Enlai pointed out in the "Instructions of the CPC Central Committee on Working with the Youth Army and Police in Student Movements" drafted for the Central Committee: "In order to avoid an antagonism with the youth army and police, and to win their sympathy for the student movement, you should immediately work with the soldiers of the youth army and police through various organizations and activists..." At that time, some schools, in accordance with the instructions of the party Central Committee, organized faculty and students to fellowship with the youth army. During a march in Shanghai, when the marchers were blocked by the military and police, they appealed to them, pointing out their own low wages and the need to act conscientiously. As a result, the antagonistic sentiment of the other party was reduced to a certain extent. At the same time, the Shanghai Bureau also clearly pointed out that when the masses were mobilized and the struggle had achieved certain results, it should be stopped at the right time. Active participants were persuaded to abandon excessive demands for indefinite strikes, in order to prevent them from distancing themselves from the vast majority of the masses. Thus, a strategy of temporarily stopping the strike, resuming classes on one hand and struggling on the other, was timely proposed, which won wide sympathy from students and society.

To promote a nationwide student federation and prepare for new battles, the National Student Federation was established in mid-June 1947. The federation issued a call to all students across the country: unite under the slogans of anti-hunger, anti-civil war, and anti-persecution, regardless of party affiliation, faith, and region. Form a solid united front to fight domestic reactionary forces to the end.

The struggle on the second front directly coordinated with the military operations on the front line of the People's Liberation Army. It disrupted the Kuomintang's rear areas, tied down and weakened Chiang Kai-shek's forces, and accelerated the progress of the people's revolution victory. The student movement aroused widespread sympathy in society. Workers, peasants, urban petty bourgeoisie, national bourgeoisie, enlightened gentry, and patriotic overseas Chinese all stood on the side of the Communist Party and actively supported and participated in the patriotic democratic movement. Chiang Kai-shek of the Kuomintang's ferocious face was fully exposed, completely isolated, surrounded by the whole nation, the people's democratic united front is constantly consolidating and expanding, the Chinese people will achieve victory nationwide.

V. A New Form of United Front Organization Under the People's Democratic Dictatorship

As early as the Anti-Japanese War, in view of the long-term nature of the Anti-Japanese War, and in response to the dictatorships of the Kuomintang's "melting together", "limiting", and "anti-communism" propositions, the Chinese Communist Party proposed long-term cooperation between various parties in the Anti-Japanese War while maintaining their independence. In the practice of leading the anti-Japanese base areas, the Chinese Communist Party also established a "three-thirds" government where CPC members, left-wing progressives, middle-of-the-roaders, and others each accounted for one third. After the victory of the Anti-Japanese War, where should China go? What kind of government should be established? Various classes and groups formed political parties and groups to state their opinions and demands. For a time, a multi-party coexistence situation appeared on the political stage of China. After the full-scale outbreak of the War of Liberation, the Communist Party of China regarded dealing correctly with the relationship with various parties as one of the major issues in establishing, consolidating, and developing the people's democratic united front, and put forward the policy of dealing correctly with the relationship with various democratic parties, thus fully forming a multi-party cooperation relationship led by the Communist Party of China, and initially establishing a system of multi-party cooperation and political consultation led by the Communist Party of China.



To correctly handle inter-party relationships, the first step is to scientifically analyze the nature of all parties. Mao Zedong and other Chinese Communists have conducted serious studies on all the democratic parties that were active on the Chinese political stage at the time, scientifically analyzing their organizational components and political tendencies, providing theoretical basis for properly handling the relationship with democratic parties. Zhou Enlai pointed out in his "Opinions on Current Work of Democratic Parties" that although the composition of the democratic parties is relatively complex, ranging from opposition factions within the ruling class to progressive members, they were mainly political representatives of the upper petite bourgeoisie, the national bourgeoisie, and their intellectuals. They opposed the one-party dictatorship of the Kuomintang, and the democratic parties and democrats associated with them were an important force on China's political stage that could not be ignored. Zhou Enlai also conducted an analysis of non-partisan democrats, believing that although non-partisan democrats did not form a party formally, they essentially have partisan traits. Their long-term participation in democratic political movement and strong involvement in fights against imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat-capitalism were all inherently partisan. They were simply some democrats that lacked party organization, and thus are non-partisan democrats with partisan tendencies, with political leanings largely in line with those of the various democratic parties.

Based on the analysis of the democratic party and democrats, the Communist Party of China proposed to unite with them during the liberation war period, to collaborate with them in the long term and jointly build New China. At the same time, the leadership position of the proletariat and its party must be held while long-term cooperation is underway, and the shortcomings and errors of the other party should be criticized or fought against. Before the outbreak of the full-scale civil war, the Communist Party actively sought joint action with all democratic parties during the political struggles in negotiations with the Kuomintang. After the outbreak of the full-scale civil war, the Chinese Communist Party formulated and implemented a series of correct policies in order to further cooperate with the democratic party and democrats. Politically, they absorbed a large number of people outside the party to participate in political work and social affairs, and often communicated and coordinated with them on major issues such as land reform, and negotiations between the Communist Party and the Kuomintang. In terms of economy, they firmly implemented policies to protect national industry and commerce, took care of their livelihoods, and were responsible for their safety and health. The Chinese Communist Party also carried out in-depth and meticulous work through extensive contacts and cooperation with democratic parties and democrats, helped them raise their understanding of the essence of American imperialism and the Kuomintang, clarified the trends and directions of the development of the Chinese revolution, and gradually embarked on the path of the New Democracy revolution.

The Chinese Communist Party's policy of cooperation and education with the democratic party was correct and successful. When the People's Liberation Army launched a strategic counterattack and was in an obvious advantage, the call of the Chinese Communist Party to establish a democratic united government received a positive response from democrats from all walks of life. On April 30, 1948, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued a "May Day Labor Day Slogan", calling for "all the national laborers to unite, join with national intellectuals, liberal bourgeoisie, all democratic parties, social sages and other patriots, to consolidate and expand the united front against imperialism, feudalism, bureaucrat-capitalism, and to jointly struggle to overthrow Jiang Jieshi and establish New China." "All democratic parties, people's organizations, and social sages quickly convened a political consultation meeting, discussed and implemented the convocation of the People's Congress, and established a democratic united government." The Chinese Communist Party's call received a positive response from the democratic parties and democrats.



Li Jishen and He Xiangning of the Revolutionary Committee of the Chinese Nationalist Party, Shen Junru and Zhang Bojun of the China Democratic League, Ma Xulun and Wang Shaoao of the China Democratic National Construction Association, Chen Qiyu of the China Public Interest Party, Peng Zemin of the China Peasants and Workers Democratic Party, Li Zhangda of the Chinese People's Federation for Salavtion, Cai Tinggui of the Democratic Promotion Association of the Chinese Nationalist Party, Tan Pingshan of the Alliance of the Three Principles of the People, and Guo Moruo, a non-partisan democrat, jointly telegraphed Mao Zedong in response to the call of "May 1" by the Communist Party of China. They expressed their belief that the May Day slogan "meets the needs of the people's situation" and is in line with their principles. They also pledged to join forces with the Chinese Communist Party to strive for the completion of a great cause. Subsequently, in response to the invitation of the Chinese Communist Party, leaders of various democratic parties and non-partisan democrats entered the liberated areas in batches to prepare for the convening of a new political consultative conference. On January 22, 1949, 55 leaders of various democratic parties and non-partisan democrats who had arrived in the liberated areas, including Li Jishen and Shen Junru, jointly published "Our Views on the Current Situation", expressing their willingness to follow the leadership of the Communist Party of China and "Consider thoroughly", while also recognizing that "there is no possibility of compromise and reconciliation between revolution and counterrevolution", "within the People's Democratic Front, there is absolutely no place for reactionaries to stand, nor can there be so-called middle lines". 
The support and response of various democrats to the "May 1" call not only confirmed the leading position of the Chinese Communist Party in the cooperation of various democratic parties, it also symbolized the initial formation of the multi-party cooperation situation led by the Chinese Communist Party and that the People's Democratic United Front has entered a new historical stage.
Various democrats acknowledging the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party and after entering the liberated areas, the CPC Central Committee further clarified the principles and guidelines for handling relations with the democratic parties. On January 22, 1949, the CPC Central Committee issued "Directions on How to Treat Democrats", which states that the party should thoroughly honestly and sincerely explain political and party policy issues to Democrats, educate and win them over with positivity, provide straight answers on policy issues and handle policy implementation truthfully. The methods used can be based on their suggestions, such as presentations by the heads of various departments of the Communist Party of China, discussions, organized tours, or regular contact and conversations with party members. As for how to treat the local organizations and organizational development issues of various democratic parties and groups, the CPC Central Committee also issued clear instructions. In February 1949, in the "Instructions on How to Treat Local Organizations of Various Democratic Parties and Groups", the CPC Central Committee pointed out that all democratic parties that were established before the "May 1" call of our Central Committee and contributed to the common struggle against imperialism, feudalism, bureaucrat-capitalism, and the reactionary rule of the KMT in the areas liberated by the people's liberation army, should be recognized as having legal status after being proven by the party headquarters and are permitted to conduct activities in the name of the party and expand party members or associates. These principles and guidelines for handling partisan relations laid the foundations for the Communist Party's post-establishment principle of "long-term coexistence, mutual supervision". As the initial formation of a multi-party cooperation situation under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party requires the establishment of a united front organization to negotiate, handle disagreements among them, etc.



After the call for "quickly convening a political consultative conference" was proposed in the 1948 "May Day" slogan, the Communist Party of China and various democratic parties actively prepared for the convening of the political consultative conference, which gradually evolved into a broad united front organization led by the Communist Party of China, with representatives from various democratic parties, people's organizations, democratic figures from all walks of life, domestic ethnic minorities, and overseas Chinese participating.

The term "Political Consultative Conference" had already existed before the "May Day" call. In January 1946, under the pressure of the national people's demand for peace and democracy, the Kuomintang government convened a political consultative conference, and finally passed five resolutions beneficial to democracy, peace, unity, and solidarity under the consultation efforts of the Communist Party. However, the Kuomintang government quickly tore up the CPPCC resolution and launched a comprehensive civil war. However, the form of democratic consultation of the Political Consultative Conference left a very good impression on the national people. As Mao Zedong pointed out in the opening speech of the first session of the People's Political Consultative Conference: "Our conference is called the Political Consultative Conference because we held a Political Consultative Conference with Chiang Kai-shek's Kuomintang three years ago. The result of that meeting was destroyed by Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Party and its accomplices, but it has left an indelible impression on the people.

In order to distinguish from the Political Consultative Conference convened in January 1946, after discussion between the Communist representative and the democratic personage representative in November 1948, it was decided to call the political consultative conference of 1946 the "old CPPCC" and the conference currently being prepared as the "new CPPCC". On September 17, 1949, at the second meeting of the new CPPCC preparatory committee, it was decided to rename the "new political consultative conference" to the "Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference", referred to as the "CPPCC". The lineup of the new CPPCC was very strong, and the determination of the units and the representative quota and list that agreed to participate in the new CPPCC went through many consultations, repeatedly deliberated, and took several months to finalize. The representatives of the new CPPCC were divided into five categories: party representatives, regional representatives, military representatives, group representatives, and special invited representatives. 

The lineup of the new CPPCC has three outstanding features compared to the old CPPCC: First, the representatives are broad, including representatives from various democratic parties, people's organizations, various regions, the People's Liberation Army, ethnic minorities, overseas Chinese and the religious world, fully reflecting the great unity of all ethnic groups, democratic classes and all patriotic democratic forces in the Chinese New Democratic Revolution; at the same time, it includes well-known figures and representative figures who have made contributions to the people's cause in various historical periods of the Chinese national democratic revolution. Representative figures from various revolutionary periods such as the Xinhai Revolution, the Northern Expedition, the May Fourth Movement, the Anti-Japanese War, and the Liberation War have all been included, and even people with a certain reputation in the late Qing Dynasty and the Beiyang government and those who sympathized with the revolution later and did good things for the people have also been included.

Second, the seriousness of political standards. Although the lineup of the new CPPCC is extremely large and includes everything, it is also based on the seriousness of politics and distinguishes between the enemy, us, and friends. According to the regulations of the preparatory committee organization, for those who do not meet or do not fully meet the standards to participate in the new CPPCC, they will not be invited as party or group units, and they will be advised to dissolve or stop activities; while paying attention to the broadness of unity, they will invite these organizations with a history of democratic movement and actual performance in the Liberation War and with certain representative democrats to participate in the new CPPCC or in the united government after their political organizations or groups declare to end.

Third, it ensures the leadership of the Communist Party and reflects the unity and cooperation between the Communist Party and non party people. The leadership of the Communist Party is not simply to overwhelm the minority with the majority, but to sincerely cooperate with democrats with an equal attitude and adopt a method of democratic consultation to reach political consensus. As a party unit, the number of representatives of the Communist Party is equal to the number of representatives of the Min Revolution and the Min Alliance, and if the party members in the representatives of the liberated areas, various regions, and basic mass units such as workers, farmers, youth, and women are added, they will still be the majority.
