In this way, the new CPPCC not only reflected the leadership of the proletariat and the dominance of the worker-peasant alliance, but also included a substantial number of non-party figures, emphasizing the breadth of unity. In September 1949, the first session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) was solemnly held in Beijing. The conference passed the Organizational Law and Common Program of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. It stipulated that the CPPCC, composed of representatives from the Chinese Communist Party, various democratic parties, people's groups, various regions, People's Liberation Army, various ethnic minorities, overseas Chinese, and other patriotic democrats, is the organizational form of the people's democratic united front. This form of organization will exist for a long time and, before the convening of the universal suffrage-based National People's Congress, performs the powers of the National People's Congress. After the convening of the National People's Congress with universal suffrage, it will propose suggestions to the National People's Congress or the Central People's Government about essential national construction matters and other important measures, playing a consultative, advisory, and promotional role. The Organizational Law of the CPPCC stipulates that the purpose of the CPPCC is to unite all democratic classes and ethnic groups in China through the unity of democratic parties and people's groups, to implement New Democracy, to oppose imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucratic capitalism, to overthrow the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang, to eliminate open and hidden remnants of counter-revolutionary forces, to heal war wounds, to restore and develop the people's economy, culture and education, to consolidate national defense, and to unite all nations and countries in the world that treat us equally to establish and consolidate the independence, democracy, peace, unity, wealth, and strength of the People's Republic of China led by the working class, based on the worker-peasant alliance. The Organizational Law of the CPPCC also stipulates its organizational structure: the National Committee is elected by the plenary session, and local committees are established in central cities, important regions, and provincial capitals, all of which implement high-level democracy.

The common program of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference plays the role of a transitional constitution. Its formulation and approval legally verify the party system and political system of multi-party cooperation led by the Chinese Communist Party. It confirms that the CPPCC is the organization form of the people's democratic united front. This is not only a historical fruit of China's New Democratic Revolution but also an inevitable product of the revolutionary united front led by the Chinese Communist Party, creating a new form of united front organization with Chinese characteristics under the people's democratic dictatorship.

Sixth, the thought of dealing with the relationship between leaders and the led

During the national liberation war, an important reason why the people's democratic united front, led by the working class (through the Chinese Communist Party) and based on the worker-peasant alliance, could be consolidated and expanded unprecedentedly was that the relationship between leaders and the led was properly handled. In January 1948, Mao Zedong profoundly summarized the historical experience of our party in achieving the leadership of the proletariat over the united front, putting forward two conditions that the working class and the Chinese Communist Party must meet to achieve leadership over the led classes, strata, political parties, and people's groups: "(a) Lead the led (allies) to fight resolutely against the common enemy and achieve victory; (b) Provide material benefits to the led, at least not harm their interests, and give them political education at the same time. Without these two conditions or lacking one of them, leadership cannot be achieved." Mao Zedong also specifically pointed out, "The Communist Party must lead the middle peasants to make a resolute struggle against the feudal class with them and achieve victory (eliminate armed forces of the landlords and divide the land of the landlords). If there is no resolute struggle, or if there is a struggle but no victory, the middle peasants will waver. Furthermore, part of the land and property of the landlords must be allocated to the poorer members of the middle peasants, while the interests of the richer middle peasants should not be harmed." At the same time, certain political rights should also be given to the middle peasants, along with education. Similarly, "In the city, the working class and the Communist Party should implement leadership over the middle class, democratic parties, and people's groups oppressed and harmed by reactionary forces in the same way."



This means that, on the one hand, we should strongly guide them to join the ranks of workers, farmers, and the urban petit bourgeois in their struggle against the United States and Jiang, or at least remain neutral; constantly affirm their revolutionary nature with the victories of the people's revolution in various aspects, and overcome their tendencies to compromise or waver. On the other hand, we should propose economic programs and policies aimed at protecting national industry and commerce to ensure that their material interests are not harmed; and educate them to continually enhance their understanding of the New Democratic Revolution's program. In such way, our party has equipped with the basic conditions to lead the national bourgeoisie and their political parties.

Mao Zedong further pointed out: "In Chiang Kai-shek's ruled area, among the upper petite bourgeoisie and middle bourgeoisie, there is a small portion, namely the right-wing members of these classes, who possess reactionary political leanings. They spread illusions on behalf of American imperialism and the reactionary group of Chiang Kai-shek, and they are against the People's Democratic Revolution. When their reactionary tendencies still have influence over the masses, we should expose them to the affected masses, weaken their political influence among the masses, so that the masses can liberate themselves from their influence." However, the historical lessons from 1927 to 1931 tell us that when the right wing of the upper petite bourgeoisie and the middle bourgeoisie echoed the Chiang’s group against the revolution, our party appropriately combatted their reactionary tendencies politically, often wiping them out economically, which once caused serious losses to the revolution. Therefore, Mao Zedong lucidly pointed out in 1947: "Political struggle and economic elimination are two different things, if we mix these two, we will make a mistake." Due to China's economic backwardness, the capitalist economy represented by the upper petite bourgeoisie and middle bourgeoisie must be allowed to exist for a long time even if the revolution emerged all over China. And, according to the division of labor of the national economy, those parts of them that are beneficial to the national economy need to be developed. Therefore, the economic position of the national bourgeoisie represented by the upper petite bourgeoisie and middle bourgeoisie must be handled cautiously, and a policy of protection must be adopted in principle.

Based on the above-mentioned thoughts of Mao Zedong, our party has developed an industry and commerce policy of "developing production, prosperity of the economy, balancing public and private interests, and mutual benefit of labor and capital," to "protect property of industrialists and businessmen, and their legal operations, from being infringed," and be able to develop economically. However, during the implementation of this policy, there are still incidents of undermining the industry and commerce in certain areas, primarily expressed as: one-sided emphasis on workers' immediate welfare in the labor movement, infringing on the interests of the national bourgeoisie; infringing on landlords and wealthy farmers' operated industry and commerce in land reform; exceeding the scope in cracking down economic counter-revolutionaries; striking industrialists and businessmen in tax policy; etc. Mao Zedong pointed out that the organizational levels of the party in leading principles "should prevent beforehand the errors of applying the method of struggle against landlords and wealthy farmers, eliminating feudal forces in the countryside, in cities, and strictly distinguish between eliminating the feudal exploitation of landlords and wealthy farmers and protecting their operated industry and commerce, and strictly distinguish the correct policy of developing production, prosperity of the economy, balancing public and private interests, and mutual benefit of labor and capital from the one-sided, narrow, and actually destruction of industrial and commercial industries, and the harmful so-called worker welfare relief principle". Establish our policy based on these distinctions, and eliminate the doubts of national bourgeoisie about the New Democratic Revolution agenda, causing them to gradually get closer to the political level and policy level required by the current revolutionary struggle, preferably against the same enemy with workers, farmers, urban petite bourgeoisie, or remain neutral. As the People's Revolution nears victory, our party carries out deeper political education to help democratic parties break away from their neutral position and raise them to the level of accepting the New Democratic Revolution agenda.


In summary, after the bureaucratic bourgeoisie represented by the Chiang Kai-shek group broke the united front, the Party Central Committee and Mao Zedong continued to implement the theory and practice of uniting and struggling with the national bourgeoisie, which created favorable conditions for the national bourgeoisie to finally accept the leadership of the working class.
In conclusion, during the period of the National Liberation War, the Party Central Committee, led by Mao Zedong, initiated a land reform movement on an unprecedented scale, further consolidating the worker-peasant alliance. Meanwhile, based on the worker-peasant alliance led by the working class, it united and won over all those who could be united and won over, including not only the national bourgeoisie but also patriots who had split from the ruling group of the Kuomintang and enlightened gentry who had split from the feudal landlord class. This made the people's democratic united front unprecedentedly consolidated and expanded, leaving the Chiang Kai-shek group completely isolated and helpless. In April 1948, our Party proposed to convene a political consultative conference without the participation of reactionaries and to discuss the establishment of a democratic coalition government. The call was warmly responded to by various democratic parties, people's organizations, and non-party democrats. They sent representatives to enter the liberated areas one after another, and worked together with our Party to prepare for the new Political Consultative Conference. In the climax of the strategic victory of the People's Liberation Army, various democratic parties announced their agreement with our Party's policy on industry and commerce and land reform; they recognized that the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang was the root of the counter-revolutionary civil war and the fundamental obstacle to domestic peace and democracy; they pointed out that American imperialism was the enemy of the Chinese people. They issued a joint statement, publicly declaring their abandonment of the middle road and accepting the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party. This is a major victory in our Party's correct handling of relations with the bourgeoisie.
Section One: Armed Struggle is the Main Form of Struggle in China's Democratic Revolution
First, The Proposal and Establishment of the Chinese Communist Party's Thought on Armed Struggle
The doctrine of armed struggle is an important part of the ideology and theory of the Chinese Communist Party and one of the three magic weapons for the victory of the Chinese revolution. The Chinese Communists, based on China's specific environment and conditions, gradually enriched and developed the Marx-Lenin doctrine of armed struggle in the process of revolution.
In the period after the founding of our party, the understanding of the extreme importance of armed struggle was insufficient. As Mao Zedong correctly pointed out when summarizing this experience, "On this point, our party was insufficient in understanding from its establishment in 1921 until its participation in the Northern Expedition in 1926. It did not understand the extreme importance of armed struggle in China at that time, it did not seriously prepare for war and organize the army, it did not pay attention to the study of military strategy and tactics." Of course, this is not to say that all members of the Party were completely ignorant of the importance of armed struggle in the Chinese Revolution. In fact, some Party members had many outstanding views.
Zhou Enlai had a certain understanding of the importance of armed struggle early on. In his article "A Review of Hu Shi's 'Effort'", published on December 15, 1922, during his time in Europe, he pointed out that "A real revolution requires a very strong and organized revolutionary army. Without a revolutionary army, the warlords cannot be defeated." This is the initial thought of seizing power by armed force. In early 1925, Zhou Enlai actively participated in and commanded the Eastern Expedition of the Huangpu student army, crushing the main force of the reactionary warlord Chen Jiongming with armed forces. Afterwards, in his report to the Huangpu student army on "The Political Work of the Army", he emphasized that "The workers and peasants, having been oppressed too much, will inevitably awaken and use armed force to resist the oppressors." He inspired everyone with the example of the victory of the October Revolution, explaining that it was "The workers and peasants used armed force to overthrow the Tsarist nobility of Russia."



"Likewise, the oppressed people of China and their oppressed ethnic minorities, when they become aware of the oppression by imperialists and warlords, will create a force from within themselves to overthrow imperialism and warlords." Clearly, Zhou Enlai made significant contributions to the issue of armed struggle both in theory and practice. 
Deng Zhongxia also said in January 1924: When the revolutionary thoughts and actions of the national masses have reached a fierce and tumultuous stage, military activities should not only not be abolished, but they are one of the important tasks. Xie Daiying also said at the time: Revolution cannot absolutely separate from the means of armed combat. These insights are extremely valuable. 
Especially Qu Qiubai, he has many insightful thoughts on the issue of armed struggle and he is a leader who understood the importance of armed struggle for our Party in the early days. After the May 30th movement in 1925, he discussed the importance of armed struggle in a series of articles he published. He said: "Civilians should have the right to armed self-defense." In October 1925, Qu Qiubai pointed out in response to the anti-Feng war at that time, that: "If the people were to arm themselves and wage an anti-Feng war, this would naturally be the beginning of a national revolution, the advent of a new era in the national revolutionary movement." He saw the armed struggle as a symbol of a new phase of the revolution, without the people's armed struggle, there can be no genuine revolution. This is a significant contribution of Qu Qiubai. He also pointed out the correct attitude of a revolutionary towards armed struggle is: "Not to fear armed riots", but to "actively ally with all forces in conflict with warlords and imperialism and wage a revolutionary war," "prepare for the armed revolutionary war of the masses" to achieve "the establishment of the people's central government." Qu Qiubai has already linked armed struggle with the seizure of power. On the eve of the Northern Expedition, Qu Qiubai’s theory on armed struggle had reached a new height. In addition to repeatedly emphasizing: to counter imperialism’s attack with "war by the revolutionary army and armed uprising by the people," "to wipe out all counter-revolutionary warlords," he particularly highlighted that armed struggle is the main form of struggle in the Chinese revolution. He said: "The central issue of the present revolutionary movement is preparing for a revolutionary war."
Due to the development of the situation, the Party's understanding of the armed struggle on the eve of the Northern Expedition heightened. In February 1926, at a special meeting convened by the Party Central Committee in Beijing, it confirmed that the Party's main current task was to prepare the Guangdong government's Northern Expedition from all aspects, to overthrow the rule of imperialism and warlords with a revolutionary war. In May 1926, the Ye Ting Independent Regiment led by the Party as an advance unit of the Northern Expedition first entered Hunan, setting the stage for the Northern Expedition. To closely coordinate with the progress of the Northern Expedition, in July 1926, the Party held the third expanded executive committee of the Central Committee. The "Resolution on Military Movement" passed at the meeting clearly pointed out: "Our Party is a revolutionary party of the proletariat, always ready to launch armed uprisings. It should participate in the work of the armed struggle in the process of national revolution and foster progressive military forces. At the same time, this work is to enable the Party to gain orderly experience in preparing for armed uprisings. By bringing up the Party-led armed uprising in the important agenda, the meeting shows that the Party's recognition of the importance of armed struggle has made a new leap.



The resolution then reminded the whole party: "Recently, our comrades in the party have paid attention to military movements," which is a significant improvement over the previous "our comrades not paying attention to military movements," but it must be pointed out that this progress is still limited, mainly manifested in "failing to understand the current military responsibilities of our party, and the significance of obtaining organized preparation for the experience of armed uprising."

Under the guidance of the ideology in this resolution, the party led the Shanghai working class to launch three armed uprisings in October 1926 and February-March 1927. The first two uprisings failed under the enemy's frenzied suppression, but the third uprising learned from the failures of the previous two and achieved a brilliant victory under the leadership of Zhou Enlai, Luo Yinong, and Zhao Shiyan, marking an important practice of the party leading armed uprisings. Zhao Shiyan made a high appraisal of this armed uprising of the Shanghai working class in the article "The March Uprising of Shanghai Workers" written in April 1927. He believed: "After the Russian October Revolution, the proletarian revolutionary achievements have added a new historical record for the March uproar of the Shanghai workers. In the history of China's revolution, the meritorious battles of the working class are affirmed through the March uprising of Shanghai workers, which secures the position of the working class in the revolution. The place of the March uprising in the history of the world revolution is written on the first page after the October Revolution. The place of the March uprising in the history of the Chinese revolution defines the nature of the Chinese revolution, ensures the victory of the Chinese revolution, and draws a new chapter in the history of the Chinese revolution." He also stressed that: "The uprising of the proletariat is the most serious lesson in the teachings of Marxism-Leninism." Zhao Shiyan clearly expressed the important idea that violent revolution is one of the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism, which is very creative. In the summer of 1927, the domestic political situation underwent a drastic change, and Chiang Kai-shek launched a counter-revolutionary coup on April 12. In mid to late May, reactionary military officers Xia Douyin and Xu Kexiang launched attacks on the revolution one after another. Faced with serious dangers, Mao Zedong and Cai Hesen proposed many correct emergency measures. Cai Hesen repeatedly suggested to the Central Committee to take resolute counterattacks, proposing that "only by attacking can we deal with attacks, only by uprisings can we deal with uprisings." On June 25, in a letter to the members of the Central Standing Committee, he urgently called out: If we sit here waiting for others to deal with us, it is no different from fish swimming at the bottom of the pot! He demanded that "the Central Committee and the army should immediately check their own strength and make a military plan in case of emergency." However, all correct opinions were rejected by Chen Duxiu, which ultimately led to the failure of the Northern Expedition.

After the failure of the Northern Expedition, our party learned a painful lesson and took a big step forward in understanding armed struggle. The party's "August 7th" meeting in 1927 critiqued Chen Duxiu's right-opportunism mistakes and established the general guidelines for the land revolution and armed resistance against the Kuomintang's reactionary slaughter, which was a decision of epoch-making significance. Around this time, the party led a series of armed uprisings, marking a new stage for the party to create its own armed forces and lead large-scale armed struggles.

II. The Basic Content of the Armed Struggle Theory of the Chinese Communist Party
The central task and highest form of revolution is the armed seizure of power
First, the characteristics of Chinese society determine that the Chinese revolution is armed struggle from the start.
Any social revolution is the result of class struggle under certain historical conditions, and is connected to a specific social-political environment. Its forms of struggle and organization must adapt to the characteristics of this society.


In his article "War and Strategic Issues", Mao Zedong conducted an exhaustive and profound analysis of the differences between capitalist countries and Chinese society, and the differing forms of revolutionary struggle that arise as a result.
In capitalist countries, violent revolution is the ultimate form of struggle under certain historical conditions based on long-term legal struggle. Capitalist countries no longer have feudal systems or oppression from foreign nations, and have established a bourgeois democratic system. The proletariat has a certain freedom of speech, association, and assembly, with the right to organize unions, carry out political and economic strikes, and use parliamentary platforms to advocate for political and economic benefits for the working class. Therefore, as long as there is no fascist war, the task of the proletarian parties is mainly to organize the worker masses to carry out non-violent legal struggles, and, through this, educate workers, gather strength, and overthrow capitalism after a long period of preparation. On the issue of war, Communist parties there oppose their country's imperialist wars. The only war they want is a civil war. "However, this kind of war should not be launched until the bourgeoisie is truly incapacitated, until the majority of the proletariat is determined to arm themselves and wage war, and until the peasant masses are willing to assist the proletariat."

When analyzing the characteristics of China’s political environment, Mao Zedong pointed out that China is different from capitalist countries. China is not a democratic country but a semi-colonial, semi-feudal country. It suffers from feudal suppression internally, lacking a democratic system, and imperialistic oppression externally, lacking national independence. There is no parliament to utilize, no right for workers to organize legal strikes. Moreover, there exist warlord rule states in the country, where both big and small warlords, landlords, and local bullies all have their own armies. The power is determined by the size of one's military, and the proletariat and working people are subjected to bloody repression and slaughter policies. In such a political environment, the task of the Communist Party, "is essentially not to proceed with uprisings and wars through long-term legal battles". The main and almost immediate task is to unite with as many allies as possible, organize armed struggles, and fight against the armed anti-revolution within or outside the country according to the situation, to strive for national and social liberation.
Based on the aforestated differences between China and capitalist countries, when Mao Zedong expounded on the basic principle that "the central task and ultimate form of revolution is to seize power through armed forces", he persistently held on to the view that "in China, the main form of struggle is war, and the main organisational form is the army". 
Secondly, the Chinese Revolution, in any period and under any circumstances, must prioritize armed struggle and persist in solving problems through war. 
At each historical stage of the development of the Chinese Revolution, Mao Zedong consistently emphasized that armed struggle is the primary form of the Chinese revolution and gradually developed a comprehensive theoretical system.
During the period of the Great Revolution, Mao proposed that the Communist Party should have its own independent armed forces and should assist in establishing peasant armed forces. On July 4, 1927, he pointed out at a meeting of the central committee discussing the situation and the party's policy, that peasant self-defense forces must be preserved and, if necessary, they can retreat to the mountains and prepare for waging war. Later, when summarizing the lessons from the failure of the first cooperation between the Nationalist Party and the Communist Party, he pointed out that our party lacked understanding of armed struggle from 1921 to 1926 when it participated in the Northern Expedition. "At the time, we did not understand the extreme importance of armed struggle in China, we did not seriously prepare for war and organize the army, and we did not focus on the research of military strategy and tactics. During the Northern Expedition, we neglected the recruitment of the army and overemphasized the mass movement. As a result, when the Nationalist Party began its reactionary path, all mass movements collapsed instantly."



During the period of the land revolution war, Mao Zedong, in the process of creating revolutionary armed forces and revolutionary bases, addressed for a period of time (mainly before the central organs of the Party moved to the base) the problem of the Party's work center not yet focused on armed struggle. He responded to the loss of faith and misperception of the form of armed struggle from a portion of people within the Party and the Army who doubted "how long the red flag could last". Mao authored a series of works, focusing on the necessity of the farmer-worker armed separatism, its feasibility, and its significant meaning to seize national power. He believed that the land revolution must be combined with armed struggle, and armed struggle must be combined with the establishment of worker-farmer authority and revolutionary bases. "The establishment and development of the Red Army, guerrilla teams, and red zones, is the highest form of peasant struggle under the leadership of the proletariat in semi-colonial China, and the inevitable result of the development of the semi-colonial peasant struggle; undoubtedly, it is the most important factor promoting the national revolutionary climax." This conclusion reinforced the Party's understanding of adhering to armed struggle, shifting the Party's work focus to leading the revolution, playing a decisive role. In 1936, Mao Zedong wrote "On the Strategic Problems of the Chinese Revolutionary War", using the Marxist perspective on war, he summarized the experiences of the land revolution war, systematically expounded on the Communist Party's fundamental views and attitudes towards war, analyzed in-depth the characteristics and laws of the Chinese revolutionary war and the correct guidelines. This further emphasized the importance of the Party studying revolutionary war, leading revolutionary war, and insisting on using revolutionary war to deal with counter-revolutionary war. This is a significant marker of the maturity of our Party's armed struggle theory.

During the Anti-Japanese War period, Mao Zedong pointed out that when facing foreign imperialistic invasion, us uniting all possible forces to carry out a national war does not mean giving up the principle of armed seizure of power, but a step in realizing this principle, and thus part of the armed seizure of power. He brilliantly discussed the relationship between the two major tasks of overthrowing imperialism and feudalism, pointing out that they are interconnected. "If the rule of imperialism is not overthrown, the rule of the feudal landlord class cannot be eliminated, because imperialism is the main supporter of the feudal landlord class. Conversely, because the feudal landlord class is the main social foundation for imperialism ruling China, and peasants are the main force in the Chinese revolution, if we do not help peasants overthrow the feudal landlord class, we cannot form a strong team for the Chinese revolution and overthrow the rule of imperialism." Mao Zedong, on one hand, insists on opposing national surrenderism, and sequentially published a number of brilliant works such as "Against Japanese Aggression: Policy, Methods, and Prospects", "On Protracted War", explaining the theory of comprehensive resistance and protracted war, providing a powerful ideological and theoretical weapon for forming a national war situation and winning the anti-Japanese war. On the other hand, he opposes class surrenderism and adheres to the principle of independence and self-reliance of our Party in the united front, criticizing and overcoming the right-leaning errors committed by representatives like Wang Ming. He pointed out that only by maintaining independence can the original position be maintained, especially to develop new positions. This is the central link to direct the Anti-Japanese National Revolutionary War towards victory. In response to the anti-communist wave initiated by the die-hard faction of the Kuomintang, Mao Zedong proposed the three principles of reason, advantage, and restraint. That is, the first is the principle of self-defense, if others do not offend me, I will not offend others, if others offend me, I will certainly offend others; against the military offensive of the die-hard faction, it must be resolutely, thoroughly, cleanly, all eliminated. The second is the principle of victory, if you don't fight, it's already, if you fight, you must win. The third is the principle of a truce, after repelling the hard-liners for a period of time, we should stop when it's appropriate, thereby ensuring the development and growth of the Chinese People's Liberation Army in the Anti-Japanese War, winning the Anti-Japanese War and preparing a strong force for overthrowing the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang.



As soon as the War of Resistance against Japan ended, on August 13, 1945, Mao Zedong delivered a speech at the Yan'an Cadres Meeting, titled "The Situation After the Victory of the Anti-Japanese War and Our Guidelines." He profoundly analyzed the basic political situation in China after the Anti-Japanese War, pointing out that Chiang Kai-shek intended to seize the fruits of victory of the Anti-Japanese War, launch an anti-people civil war, and inevitably move towards massacring the people nationwide. Chiang Kai-shek was sharpening his knives, and we must also sharpen ours. As Chiang sought to snatch every bit of power and gain every bit of advantage, our policy was to not yield an inch and to contest every inch of ground. Rights gained by the people must not be allowed to be lost easily; they must be defended through struggle. In the subsequent period, there emerged an unprecedented trend towards peace and democracy internationally, and domestically, there appeared certain signs of peaceful coexistence between the Nationalist and Communist parties. Some Communist Party members were too optimistic about the prospects for peace, believing that parliamentary struggle would become the main form of struggle. In response to this tendency, Mao Zedong reiterated that the Chinese revolution must take the path of armed seizure of power, stating: "The principle of the reactionary forces towards the people's democratic forces is to eradicate those that can be eradicated and prepare to eradicate those that cannot be eradicated for the time being. In light of this, the people's democratic forces should adopt the same principle towards the reactionary forces." Before heading to Chongqing for negotiations, Mao once again pointed out to the Party that we must not rely on negotiations, must not hope that the Kuomintang would have a change of heart, and must rely on our own strength. During the Chongqing negotiations, he instructed the entire army to resolutely counterattack the Kuomintang aggression, believing that the more victories we win, the more proactive and secure our negotiations would be. After the Chongqing negotiations, when talking about strategies regarding the reduction of troops, Mao emphasized: "The people's armaments, every gun, every bullet, must be preserved and not given up." After the People's Liberation Army achieved decisive victories in the three major battles, the Nationalist ruling group, with the support and planning of the U.S. Ambassador to China, John Leighton Stuart, launched a peace offensive in an attempt to use peace negotiations to achieve "ruling by dividing the river," so as to buy time to breathe, maintain the remaining reactionary forces, and then wait for an opportunity to make a comeback. In the face of this situation, Mao Zedong issued the great call to "carry the revolution through to the end" to the entire Party, army, and nation, pointing out that the enemy will not eliminate themselves. Whether it is the reactionary forces in China or the imperialist aggression of the United States in China, none will withdraw from the historical stage on their own. We must use revolutionary means to resolve, resolutely and thoroughly and cleanly annihilate all reactionary forces, overthrow the reactionary rule of the Kuomintang nationwide, and establish a republic with a people's democratic dictatorship led by the proletariat and based on an alliance of workers and peasants. The Communist Party of China, guided by Mao Zedong's theory of armed struggle, insisted on making armed struggle the priority at all times and under all circumstances, thereby achieving the victory of the Chinese revolution.

Third, all non-armed organizations and forms of struggle must complement and serve the armed struggle.

While emphasizing that armed struggle is the primary form of the Chinese revolution, Mao Zedong pointed out: "Everything else, such as the organization and struggles of the masses, are extremely important, indispensable, and must not be neglected, but all are for the sake of warfare." He emphasized that this cooperation and service are pervasive throughout the entire process and all aspects of the revolution.

The so-called entire process means that, whether before the outbreak of war or during the war, all of the Party's organizations and forms of struggle must serve the Party and the revolutionary war. Before the outbreak of the war, all organizations and struggles must revolve around preparing for war, mobilizing for war, in order to clear away various obstacles affecting the revolutionary war, mobilizing all forces to participate in the war, such as the nationwide Anti-Japanese Salvation Movement, Anti-Civil War Movement, and the December 9th Student Movement launched by the Party before the Anti-Japanese War. It was these movements that drove the surge of the national patriotic fervor against Japan, leading to the Xi'an Incident and its peaceful resolution.


After the outbreak of war, all organizations and forms of struggle must either directly or indirectly cooperate with revolutionary warfare. For example, during the Anti-Japanese War, movements such as the rectification campaign within the Communist Party and military, the mass production movement in the liberated areas, and the mass movements in the Kuomintang-ruled areas were all undertaken for the victory of the anti-war effort.
The so-called "all-round" means that, regardless of the front or rear, liberated or enemy-occupied areas, cities or rural areas, political-cultural centers or remote areas, the party's organizational work and mass movements within most of China's territory are directly related to armed struggle and can only and should only comply with the requirements of the frontline. Armed struggle is a characteristic and strength of the Chinese revolution.
In the article "On the Prospects for the Chinese Revolution," Stalin pointed out: "In China, it is armed revolution against armed counterrevolution. This is one of the characteristics and advantages of the Chinese revolution." Mao Zedong fully affirmed the correctness of this judgment. In his concluding report at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Party in November 1938, he analyzed the common characteristics of the nature and various stages of the Chinese revolution since the Northern Expedition. He pointed out that Stalin's view is perfectly applicable to the actual situation of the Chinese revolution. China's problems cannot be solved without armed struggle, and any revolutionary tasks cannot be accomplished without armed struggle. In his preface to the inaugural issue of the "Communist" in 1939, he brought forward armed struggle and the united front as two basic characteristics of the Chinese revolution, and described armed struggle, united front, and party-building as the three magic weapons of the Chinese revolution. He further emphasized that the primary form of the Chinese revolution is armed struggle.
Firstly, the nature and tasks of the Chinese revolution are closely related to armed struggle.
When analyzing the characteristics of the Chinese revolution, Mao Zedong pointed out: "Because China is a semi-colonial, semi-feudal country with an unbalanced development in various aspects such as politics, economy, and culture, and it is a country where the semi-feudal economy dominates and the land is vast, it not only establishes that the nature of the current stage of the Chinese revolution is of the bourgeois-democratic character and the main objects of the revolution are imperialism and feudalism, and the basic forces of revolution are the proletariat, the peasant class and the urban petty bourgeoisie, and, to a certain stage and to a certain extent, the participation of the national bourgeoisie, but it also establishes that the main form of struggle in the Chinese revolution is armed struggle." He believes that armed revolution against armed counterrevolution, a characteristic of semi-colonial China, is not found in the revolutionary history led by the Communist Party in any capitalist country.
The enemies of the Chinese revolution, that is, the objects of the Chinese revolution - feudalism, imperialism, and bureaucratic comprador capitalism - all have powerful counter-revolutionary armaments and rely on force to rule and reach their political goals with counter-revolutionary wars. The proletariat and the broad oppressed and exploited laboring masses in order to achieve liberation, to overthrow these well-armed enemies, must also engage in armed struggle. From the birth of the Chinese Communist Party to the establishment of the People's Republic of China, the Chinese revolution has gone through four historical stages, namely the Northern Expedition, the Land Revolution War, the Anti-Japanese War and the Liberation War. The objects of these wars are all armed counterrevolution, and the main participants in the wars are the armed revolutionary people. "The only difference is that either it is a civil war or a national war; or it is a war conducted solely by the Communist Party or a war conducted jointly by the Nationalist and Communist Parties...... However, they are all armed revolutions against armed counterrevolution, all revolutionary wars, and they all reflect the characteristics and strengths of the Chinese revolution." The history of the Chinese revolution fully proves that: without armed struggle in China, there would be no position for the proletariat, no position for the people, no position for the Communist Party, and no victory for the revolution.
Secondly, the growth and development of the Chinese Communist Party are linked to armed struggle.


A notable distinction between the Communist Party of China (CPC) and proletarian parties in capitalist countries is that the CPC developed amidst armed struggle, while proletarian parties in capitalist countries grew through lengthy legal struggles. Armed uprisings result from the growth of proletarian parties in capitalist countries, they are not the means or reason for the party's growth. The CPC, however, was different. Before the CPC came to power, its history was essentially one of armed struggle. Mao Zedong clearly stated:

"Our party's development, consolidation, and Bolshevization took place in the course of revolutionary war. Without armed struggles, there would be no Communist Party today."

During the period of the great revolution, even though our Party had started to recognize the importance of armed struggle, it hadn't fully understood its significance. We hadn't realized that armed struggle was the primary form of conflict in the Chinese revolution, and we hadn't concentrated on building revolutionary armed forces. As a result, when Chiang Kai-shek betrayed the revolution, a large number of communists were brutally killed, seriously impairing the party's construction and its cause. During the agrarian revolutionary war, our Party had established independent armed units, created revolutionary bases of armed separatism, and significantly expanded the party's forces. The party explicitly promoted the mission of using the army to aid local party development. However, due to Wang Ming and Li Lisan's lack of understanding of the characteristics and laws of Chinese armed struggle, they committed "leftist" errors, which resulted in serious losses to our party's cause. The Zunyi Conference established Mao Zedong's leadership of the party and the Red Army. The entire party learned the art of commanding warfare, thus enabling the party's construction and force to be revived.

In the Anti-Japanese War, our Party had gained a deep understanding of armed struggle. With the development of the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army led by the Party, the Party’s construction had undergone unprecedented development. As Mao Zedong pointed out: "A party can indeed be formed with guns. The Eighth Route Army in North China created a large party." "The Party's organization has stepped out of its small circle and become a national party. …… The Party's influence among the people of the whole country has further expanded. " In the War of Liberation, our understanding of the laws of armed struggle and our ability to control revolutionary warfare had reached a new stage. The number of the People's Liberation Army grew rapidly and its combat effectiveness improved greatly, eventually overthrowing the rule of feudalism, imperialism, and bureaucrat capitalism in mainland China, establishing the People's Republic of China, and the Communist Party of China becoming the ruling party that leads the country. Therefore, it can be said that our party's successes and setbacks, advances and retreats, are closely linked to armed struggle; our party's political line and its construction are also closely linked to armed struggle. Without armed struggle, without revolutionary war, "we cannot understand our political line, nor can we understand our Party’s construction. An important part of our political line is armed struggle."

Thirdly, the vast Chinese populace’s understanding and participation in the Chinese revolution are closely tied to armed struggle.

Any social revolution is based on the people’s full understanding and active participation. The way the people acquire this understanding and participation is a significant indication of the revolution’s characteristics, breadth, and depth. In the proletarian revolutionary struggle in capitalist countries, legal, nonviolent mass movements (primarily workers’ movements) are both the basic path to raising the class consciousness of the working masses and their main way of participating in revolutionary struggle. Armed struggle only happens when this legal struggle—the mass movement—reaches its broadest and deepest extent on a societal level.


In China, the masses have no democratic rights in politics, and 90% of the population are farmers living in a closed, scattered, and small-scale production state. Mobilizing and organizing the vast majority of the people in a legal and peaceful struggle to join the ranks of the revolution is impossible. In the Chinese Revolution, the people's understanding and participation in the revolution are primarily linked with armed struggle.

On the one hand, because the armed struggle is the main form of struggle in the Chinese Revolution, the people's mobilization for revolution is in fact the mobilization for war, and people's understanding of the revolution is initially linked with the violent means of the revolution. On the other hand, although the propaganda and mobilization work of the Chinese revolution is multi-channel and multi-faceted, it is mainly conducted through the army.

Mao Zedong always regarded the propaganda team (work team) as an important task of the People's Army. The vast majority of farmers in rural China get most of their understanding of the revolution from the Red Army, the Eighth Route Army, the New Fourth Army and the People's Liberation Army. Therefore, the degree of understanding and participation of the people in the revolution has always been directly proportional to the progress of the revolutionary war. When the revolutionary war advances and wins in a certain area, the people in that area will definitely be quickly mobilized and organized.

Mao Zedong compared the 25,000-mile Long March of the Red First Front Army to a propaganda team and a sowing machine in this sense. It is in the process of armed struggle that the masses realize their own interests, see their great power, understand that only the Communist Party can lead them to victory in the revolution, and thus bravely and actively engage in the revolutionary struggle. It was also the practice of revolutionary armed struggle that educated, tempered, and ultimately liberated the people. In essence, China's armed struggle is a peasant war led by the proletariat.

First, China is a country with farmers as the main population, accounting for 80% of the national population. Whether in terms of manpower or material resources, farmers are the most widespread and deep-rooted source of power for China's armed struggle. Farmers are the source of China's army, and soldiers are farmers in military uniforms.

Second, China's farmers are heavily oppressed by imperialism, feudalism and bureaucratic capitalism, without political rights, and economically distressed. They live in dire straits and therefore have a strong desire for revolution. They are the most reliable allies of the proletariat and the main force of the Chinese revolution.

Third, China is a country with a long history and glorious tradition of peasant uprisings and peasant wars. The Chinese Communist Party has summarized the experience and lessons of peasant revolutions in past generations, inherited and carried forward the glorious tradition of past peasant wars, and combined Marxist-Leninist doctrines concerning violent revolution with China's current reality and history, resulting in a new type of peasant revolutionary war with Chinese characteristics. "It's not to say that other forms of struggle can be abandoned, on the contrary. Without various forms of struggle outside of armed struggle to cooperate, armed struggle cannot succeed." However, other forms of struggle are for war and serve armed struggle. All organizations and struggles before the outbreak of war are for preparing for war.


Armed struggle and other forms of struggle are unified; armed struggle cannot be separated from other forms of struggle, and other forms of struggle must serve the armed struggle. Only by correctly understanding and dealing with the relationship between armed struggle and the struggles of workers, farmers, youth, women, the economic front, the counter-espionage front, and the ideological front can we facilitate the victory of the Chinese revolutionary war.

Section 2 The Military Dialectics Thought of the Communist Party of China

1. Establishing the Proletariat's View of War

Zhu De pointed out: "Comrade Mao Zedong systematically studied the laws of the Chinese revolutionary war. Particularly important is that Comrade Mao Zedong, in his military works, emphasized the theoretical foundation and methodology of Marxist-Leninist military science, that is, military dialectics." During the Agrarian Revolutionary War, the "leftist" adventurers caused disastrous consequences for the Chinese revolutionary war by studying and guiding the war in a dogmatic way. This situation prompted Chinese Communists represented by Mao Zedong to emphatically study the methodology of war in order to unify the military thinking of the entire party from a world view perspective. In 1936, Mao Zedong gave a lecture called "Military Dialectics" at the Shaanbei Red Army University. Most of the content of this lecture is included in the article "Strategic Problems in the Chinese Revolutionary War". Later, in works such as "On Protracted War", he discussed a series of important thoughts on military dialectics.

What is war?

The Chinese Communist Party views war from the perspective of class struggle. It is argued that all wars in human history recorded in writing originate from the emergence of private ownership and the struggle between classes. Mao Zedong studied the peasant wars in Chinese history and said: "The brutal economic exploitation and political oppression of peasants by the landlord class force peasants to rise up repeatedly to resist the rule of the landlord class... In Chinese feudal society, only this kind of peasant class struggle, peasant uprising and peasant war is the true driving force of historical development." He also looked at the national struggles of the world and said, "National struggle, in the final analysis, is a class struggle problem. In America, those who oppress black people are only the reactionary rule groups of the white race. They cannot represent the majority of workers, peasants, revolutionary intellectuals and other enlightened people within the white race." These are all adherents of the class struggle view. He also said: "Because of the emergence of the class, human life has been filled with wars for thousands of years. Every nation does not know how many wars they have fought, either within the ethnic group or between ethnic groups. By the imperialist era of capitalist society, wars were fought particularly widely and cruelly." It can be seen that war is a social phenomenon of class struggle. The forms of struggle between different classes in human class society are varied, including economic, ideological, cultural, diplomatic, etc. For the oppressed people and nations, the central task and highest form of the revolution is to seize political power through arms, and the war solves problems.


When economic, ideological, cultural, diplomatic, and other peaceful forms of struggle fail to resolve conflicts, recourse to force becomes inevitable, and war is used to address the issues. Thus, war has become the ultimate form for resolving class struggles, and this is an inevitable law. Mao Zedong profoundly revealed this law, asserting, "War—a form of struggle that has been ongoing since the existence of private property and classes, for resolving contradictions during certain developmental stages between classes, nations, states, and political groups—is the highest form of struggle." This is entirely scientific, accurately revealing the origins and nature of war, and clarifying that war is not a phenomenon above classes, but a deeply class-characterized social phenomenon.

The class nature of war is prominently reflected in the close relationship between war and politics. At the Gutian conference resolution, Mao Zedong criticized the erroneous concept of a purely military viewpoint and elucidated the relationship between the military and politics. In the article "On Protracted War," he further discussed the relationship between war and politics, while Lenin affirmed Clausewitz’s statement that war is the continuation of politics by other means. Accordingly, Mao Zedong emphasized: War is politics, and the act of war itself is political in nature. The occurrence and development of any war are closely related to the social politics that generate it; war is always conducted for specific political purposes. For example, China's War of Resistance Against Japan was fought to achieve the political goal of expelling Japanese imperialism and building a new China of equality and freedom and was closely tied to the consolidation and development of the united front against Japan. In summary, war is never detached from politics; it is subservient to and serves politics.

However, war is not equal to general politics; it is politics of bloodshed, a continuation of politics by special means. When political development reaches a certain stage and cannot progress as before, war breaks out to remove obstacles to political development. For instance, China's independent and semi-independent status was an obstacle to the political development of Japanese aggression. To remove this barrier, Japan launched the war of invasion against China. Similarly, Japanese aggression was a hindrance to the development of China's democratic revolution. To remove this barrier, the Chinese people initiated the War of Resistance Against Japan. Once Japan was expelled from China, the resistance war concluded. Thus, war and politics are essentially interconnected, both manifestations of class struggle, but there are differences between them. As Mao Zedong said, "Politics is war without bloodshed, while war is politics with bloodshed." The specificity of war gives rise to special organizations and methods for war, and the laws of war differ from the general laws of political struggle. Hence, the viewpoint that undervalues the military and neglects the study of war is also mistaken. Regarding the factors for victory in war, Mao Zedong's military thought is based on the principle that war is the highest form of class struggle and politics' continuation, considers the nature of war and its political foundations as the primary factors for victory. In 1946, Chiang Kai-shek, relying on his military forces bolstered by American aid, launched a comprehensive attack on the liberated areas. At that time, Chiang Kai-shek’s military advantage was just a temporary phenomenon and factor; US imperialist aid also played only a temporary role; while the anti-people nature of Chiang Kai-shek's war and the orientation of people’s hearts were factors that constantly played a role. In this respect, the People's Liberation Army had the advantage. The patriotic, righteous, and revolutionary nature of the People’s Liberation Army's war was bound to win the support of the entire nation.


This is the political foundation for defeating Chiang Kai-shek.
However, war is a competition of material power. The outcome of a war, in addition to being determined by its political basis, is mainly decided by military, economic, scientific, technological, and geographical conditions. All these factors are material conditions that cannot be ignored by the military strategists. They can't attempt to win a war outside the range of what these material conditions allow. Therefore, it is necessary to strive in creating conditions such as military, economic, scientific and technological, and natural environment that are advantageous to us and disadvantageous to the enemy, in order to lay the foundation for winning the war. Under certain material conditions, subjective leadership becomes the decisive factor in winning the war. The stage for military strategists is built on objective material conditions, yet with this stage, they can direct many powerful and magnificent dramas, using flexible and agile strategies and tactics to defeat the enemy and win the war.

Mao Zedong also pointed out: Weapons are an important factor in war, and China's weaponry is relatively backward, which is a major defect. There should be a way to improve it. However, weapons are not the decisive factor; the decisive factor is people, not things. In other words, among the two factors of people and weapons, people are in the first place, major, and play a guiding role. The comparison of strength, not only refers to military and economic strength, but also refers to human resources and public sentiment. Military and economic power are created and mastered by people. The practice of China's revolutionary war shows that the support of the people and the bravery and wisdom of the people and the army are decisive factors that often affect the outcome of the war. The revolutionary war in China, with inferior equipped weapons, defeated the enemy who had superior equipped weapons, mainly relying on the mobilization, arming, and fighting the people's war. This is the essence of Mao Zedong's military ideology of winning against the enemy. The way to eliminate the war

War is a unique phenomenon in class societies, when the class and the state are eliminated in human societies, war will also be eliminated, and the human society will enter an era of permanent peace. How can this goal be achieved? Mao Zedong pointed out: There is only one method, to eliminate war through war, to eliminate counter-revolutionary war using revolutionary war, and to eliminate unjust war using just war. Lenin once said: "The nature of war (counter-revolutionary or revolutionary) does not depend on who attacks, and 'enemies' are inside whose borders, but depends on which class is conducting the war, and the war is a continuation of what kind of politics." Based on the different class nature and political purposes of the war, historical wars can be divided into two major categories: just wars and unjust wars. Mao Zedong pointed out that a just war is an antidote, a bridge pushing world history into a new era, and without it, the leap in social development could not be realized; an unjust war hinders social development and progress. Therefore, Communists can neither simply support all wars nor simply oppose all wars, but should distinguish the nature of wars, support and participate in just wars, oppose the unjust wars. The bourgeoisie peacemakers, not distinguishing the justice and injustice of the war, oppose all wars; do not explore the social roots of war, unconditionally beg for peace from imperialism, they think that universal peace and lasting peace can be achieved under the rule of imperialism, this is completely unrealistic fantasy.


History has proven that within a country or globally, the eradication of all wars can only be achieved through the armed struggle of people from various countries, overthrowing imperialism and all exploitative systems, and establishing socialist and communist systems. As Mao Zedong said, "We are advocates of the abolition of war, we do not want war; but war can only be abolished through war, and in order to get rid of the gun, one must pick up the gun." We study the laws of war and wage revolutionary wars, entirely because we wish to eliminate all wars. This is the Communist Party's fundamental stance and attitude towards war. Economic situation is the material basis for war, and war cannot be separated from the economy, the economy is the material basis for war. Mao Zedong said: "War is not only a military and political competition but also an economic competition." "If economic construction is not carried out, the material conditions for the revolutionary war cannot be guaranteed." The Chinese Communist Party has always considered economic factors as a necessary condition for defeating the enemy during the leadership of the Chinese revolutionary war. 

Why was it possible for a small or several small red power regions to exist for a long time within a country and surrounded by the encirclement of white regimes during the initial period of the revolutionary war led by the Communist Party of China? Why did the revolutionary war promote the arrival of the climax of the Chinese revolution? Mao Zedong analyzed the unbalanced political and economic development in China at that time—the coexistence of weak capitalist economy and severe semi-feudal economy, several modern-style industrial and commercial cities and stagnant vast rural areas, several millions of industrial workers and tens of millions of farmers and handicraft workers under the dominance of the old system, the large warlords managing the central government and the small warlords managing each province, the reactionary armies affiliated to Chiang Kai-shek's so-called central army and the so-called miscellaneous armies affiliated to each provincial warlord, the existence of several railways, navigation routes, automobile routes and a single wheelbarrow route, only walking routes and walking paths that are not easy to walk. 

Based on such unbalanced economic and political development, there exists and develops contradictions of imperialist powers vying for China, contradictions between various military factions within China, many contradictions formed by the heavy taxes imposed by the reactionary government on workers, farmers, national industrial and commercial burdens, sharp contradictions between workers, peasants, intellectuals, urban poor and even soldiers of the reactionary army who are exploited and oppressed and reactionary rulers, landlords, and capitalists etc., just like the country is full of dry wood, which will soon turn into a fierce fire. This economic condition is the most fundamental reason for the existence and development of the Chinese revolutionary war at that time. Mao Zedong's military thought of analyzing the causes of war from an economic perspective is scientific and has guiding significance for any war. Why are there wars between countries of different nature or the same? As long as it is analyzed from an economic perspective, the main reasons are not difficult to find. 

The economy is the material basis for war. In China, a vast but poor and backward land, a protracted revolutionary war lasted 22 years and is due to active economic construction and development of productive forces and adjustment of production relations amid the war. Mao Zedong's military thought made an important contribution to the theory of the relationship between war and economy. Mao Zedong wrote many works, explaining the importance of the economy to war in different historical periods and setting the direction for economic work at the time.

He argued that war should be the focus during wartime, but economic construction is also a "great class struggle". Economic construction must revolve around war; cancelling economic construction is tantamount to weakening war. The party must represent the interests of the vast majority of peasants and workers, help them develop production, implement policies of rent and interest reduction, land reform, appropriately increase wages, give the masses tangible material benefits, stimulate their enthusiasm to support and participate in the revolutionary war, and oppose enemy attacks. Otherwise, the masses cannot distinguish between the Kuomintang and the Communist Party, which would create a situation that is unfavorable to us; having a lean and efficient military is an important policy to overcome difficulties. It makes our war apparatus suitable for wartime situations, we will become even stronger, not only will not be defeated by the enemy, but will eventually defeat the enemy. Just like Sun Wukong turning into a tiny insect and tunneling into the heart of Princess Iron Fan, defeating the colossal invader; rent reduction and production are two major tasks for defending the liberated areas. Whether the two major tasks of rent reduction and production can be completed will ultimately determine the outcome of the political and military struggles in the liberated areas, etc. These claims have been confirmed by war practice and are scientifically correct. As for peacetime, what is the relationship between economic construction and national defense construction? Mao Zedong said: "National defense is indispensable... The reliable method is to reduce military and political expenses to an appropriate proportion and increase economic construction expenses. Only when economic construction develops more quickly can national defense construction make greater progress." "Do you really want, really want atomic bombs, or do you just have a bit of desire and don't really want them? If yoU really want, really want, you should reduce the proportion of military and political expenses and increase economic construction. If you don't really want, really want, you should still go with the old charter." We should strengthen our national defense, therefore, we must first strengthen economic construction. This is a rule-based understanding of the relationship between economy and national defense in peacetime, and it is also an important guideline for national defense construction.

2. Understanding and Applying the Laws of War Realistically

War is an inevitable physical movement that can be understood. Starting from reality and aligning the subjective with the objective is a basic requirement of dialectical materialism. Mao Zedong applied dialectical materialism in military affairs and always believed that the war, like other social phenomena, is an inevitable physical movement with internal contradictions and inherent objective laws not dependent on human will. To study and guide warfare, we must start from reality and understand and apply the laws of warfare realistically - these are the fundamental characteristics and requirements of military practices. As for the question of whether wars and the laws of war can be understood by people, bourgeois military experts often exaggerate the unpredictability and uncertainty of war from an idealistic perspective and consider war as something elusive, attributing the outcome of wars to chance or "the will of God". This is the agnosticism of war issues. Mao Zedong, based on the principles of dialectical materialism and combined with the practical experience of China's revolutionary war, thoroughly denied the agnostic theory of war. He pointed out that although warfare has a greater degree of fluidity, there is relative stability in each specific phase within the fluid entirety of a long war. War's uncertainty also follows the same pattern. As both sides of the battle are armed living beings that keep secrets from each other and even create illusions to deceive the opponent, this leads to the characteristics of war's uncertainty. However, this does not negate the relative certainty of war...


One aspect of me is quite certain, while the other side of the enemy isn't very certain, but still have connections that can be found, clues that can be observed, and a series of past and present phenomena available for contemplation, which constitutes the so-called certain degree of relative certainty. In short, although war is greatly influenced by randomness, behind this randomness lies inevitability. People can see through the phenomena to perceive its underlying essence, comprehend and apply the laws of war through the manifestations of randomness. A comprehensive analysis of both enemy and our reality is crucial to mastering the laws guiding warfare.

How do we understand the laws of war? Mao Zedong, discussing "how to study warfare," pointed out: "There is a method to learn. One should use this method while learning and applying it. What is the method? That is to get a good understanding of all aspects of both the enemy and us, to identify the patterns of their actions, and to apply these patterns to our own actions." That is to say, guiding the war must follow the laws of war, and to understand these laws, we must conduct an objective, comprehensive analysis and comparison of all aspects of both the opposing sides, refine through the complex phenomena, and ponder over the essence. This is the fundamental approach to resolving the contradictions of subjective and objective factors in war. Because war is a bilateral activity of opposing parties, a competition of political, economic, military, geographical, subjective guiding ability, and other forces, the laws of war would come from these objective realities and inherent connections. Therefore, studying war must take both parties' subjective and objective conditions into account. Only by comprehensively analyzing both sides' subjective and objective conditions can we correctly understand the full picture of war and discover the guiding laws of war. Any one-sided and isolated emphasis on one point while ignoring others will not lead to a correct understanding of war and its laws. Mao Zedong said: “There are people who are clear on knowing ourselves but ignorant of knowing the enemy, and others who are clear on knowing the enemy but ignorant of knowing ourselves. Neither are able to solve the problem of learning and applying the laws of war". He emphasized the need to remember Sun Tzu's famous saying, "Knowing the enemy and knowing ourselves, in a hundred battles we will never be in peril". Historical experience has proven that Mao Zedong's remarks are completely correct. During the Second Domestic Revolutionary War, "left" adventurists or right opportunists either only saw the temporary victory of the Red Army and the temporary failure of the enemy, or only saw the strength of the enemy and the weakness of the Red Army, resulting in the mistakes of "left" adventurism or escapism. The proponent of the theory of national extinction and speedy victory during the anti-Japanese period did not comprehensively and objectively assess the situation of both the enemy and us. Those who believed in the theory of national extinction only see the enemy being strong and we are weak; those who believed in speedy victory only see our progress, the enemy's retreat, our many aids and the enemy's few aids, and denied the enemy's strength and our weakness. In contrast, Mao Zedong always comprehensively analyzed and compared the conditions of both the enemy and us. He not only saw the favourable conditions, but also the unfavourable conditions. He not only saw the domestic conditions, but also the international conditions. He not only looked at the present, but also at the developments, drawing out the fundamental laws of war from it. During the Land Revolution War, he comprehensively analyzed the condition of both the enemy and us, identified the four fundamental characteristics of the Chinese revolutionary war, revealed the fundamental laws governing the development of the Chinese revolutionary war, and formulated the strategies and tactics of the Chinese revolutionary war. During the Anti-Japanese War period, he also comprehensively analyzed the situation of both China and Japan, identified the four contradictions in the comparison of strength between China and Japan, and based on this, proved the fundamental law governing the development of the Anti-Japanese War, and formulated the strategic policy and strategic tactics of protracted war. To comprehensively and deeply understand the conditions of both the enemy and us, Mao Zedong systematically elaborated on the importance of understanding the dialectical development process of warfare and the importance of research and investigation. Mao Zedong applied the principles of dialectical materialism to the military, pointing out that the understanding process of commanders in each war or campaign includes two stages, namely the stage from perceptual knowledge to rational knowledge, and from knowledge to practice.


The primary content of the first phase is to form correct judgments and battle plans through research and investigation. Here, the key is research and investigation. Mao Zedong said: "The commander’s correct deployment comes from the correct determination, the correct determination comes from the correct judgment, and the correct judgment comes from thorough and necessary reconnaissance, and from the continuous contemplation of various reconnaissance materials." Mao Zedong pointed out: Not only is research and investigation extremely important in the first stage of cognition, but it is also extremely important in the second stage. Because whether the understanding obtained in the first stage conforms to reality needs to be reverified in the second stage. If the situation does not match or most of it does not match, the planned plan must be revised to adapt to the new situation. This is from the point of view of the cognitive process of the law of a battle. If you want to explore the universal laws of war, you must deepen your cognition through multiple repetitions from practice to cognition, and from cognition to practice. Focusing on the characteristics and development of war, emphasizing the study of the special laws of war, research and guidance of war, not only should we pay attention to the comprehensive analysis of both the enemy and our situation, oppose idealism in the war issue, but also need to focus on its characteristics and development, oppose mechanical theory in war issues; not only should we pay attention to the study of the general laws of war, but also emphasize the study of the special laws of revolution and the even more special laws of the Chinese Revolutionary War. This is a fundamental methodological principle proposed by Mao Zedong in applying the principle of general and special, universal and individual, to war.

First, from the perspective of the nature of war, revolutionary war is different from counter-revolutionary war. The nature of war is different, and its guiding laws are also different, and cannot be mechanically applied. At the beginning of the land revolution, some people in the army blindly plagiarized the bourgeois military affair, opposing the party's absolute leadership over the army, opposing the Red Army's implementation of the three major tasks, opposing democracy in the army, etc., the root cause lies in not seeing the fundamental difference between the Chinese Revolutionary War and the counter-revolutionary War, between the proletarian army and the bourgeois army.

Second, from the perspective of the war region, each country and each nation, especially the big countries and big nations, have their characteristics, so the war guidance laws also have their features. The Chinese Revolutionary War and the Russian Revolutionary War are the same in nature, but the two countries' situation is different, and the national characteristics are different, so the war's guiding laws are also very different. The dogmatists disregard these differences, rigidly apply the experience of the Russian Revolutionary War to China, blindly demand that everything be "normalized", and oppose so-called "guerrillaism", resulting in severe setbacks to the Land Revolution.

Third, from the perspective of time conditions, as the time conditions of war change, objective situations and tasks also change accordingly, so the war's guiding laws have their characteristics at different historical stages. Compared with the hot-cold weapon era, the methods and guidance laws of war are very different. The Chinese Revolutionary War, due to different stages of war development, also has different guiding laws. For example, the People's Liberation Army mainly focused on mobile warfare in the later stages of the Land Revolution; during the Anti-Japanese War, due to changes in the enemy's situation and tasks, the People's Liberation Army switched to guerrilla warfare as the main form of warfare; during the Liberation War, due to the change in the war situation, the People's Liberation Army again achieved a military strategy. In any case, the war situation is developing and changing, and the guiding laws of war should also change with it. Therefore, Mao Zedong has always emphasized the need to be good at flexibly applying the guiding laws of war according to changes in the war situation.

Section 3 Thoughts on the Construction of the People's Army

I. The Only Purpose of the People's Army



The ideological construction of the People's Army is a new type of People's Army construction thought and theoretical principles that embody Chinese characteristics, which the Chinese Communist Party creatively proposed by combining the principle of Marxist army construction with the actual conditions of the Chinese revolution, in the course of long-term revolutionary warfare and army building practice. Wholeheartedly serving the people is the sole purpose of our army.

As early as November 1927, in the "Current Situation in China and the Task Case of the Communist Party" formulated by the CCP Central Committee, the party identified the working and peasant revolutionary army, which was being formed, as completely different from the mercenary army. The so-called workers and peasant's revolutionary army is actually corresponding to the National Revolutionary Army. It excluded the bourgeois class that had defected after the revolution from the revolutionary camp, thereby declaring its proletarian nature and the purpose of serving the working people. In early 1929, while Mao Zedong and Zhu De were leading the Red Fourth Army to south Jiangxi and west Fujian, they proposed the idea of "the purpose of the Red Army is the revolution of civil rights” through the "Declaration of the Red Fourth Army Command". This was the first time that our army used the concept of "purpose" and demonstrated its location. Putting civil rights acquisition as the purpose of the Red Army appears to be adopting Sun Yat-sen's army-building advocacy, but as the "people" in the Red Army was defined as "workers and peasants and all oppressed classes", it's not the "national" sense originally meant by Sun Yat-sen, hence the "civil rights revolution" put forward by the Red Army essentially aims at the liberation of the working people.
