Purpose education is the central content of Red Army political education, and the outstanding achievement of Red Army political education lies in cultivating the spirit of self-sacrifice for soldiers and officers to fight for the interests of workers and peasants.

Entering the Sino-Japanese War, the purpose education of our army faced severe challenges due to the changes in the tasks and environment it undertook. On the one hand, the purpose statement during the Red Army period was obviously not fully adaptable to the new situation of the anti-Japanese national united front; on the other hand, our army relieved from the isolation of the civil war, was at risk of being eroded by various non-proletarian thoughts and lost the fundamental revolutionary direction. In this case, our army invested more energy in purpose education. Mao Zedong and others began to explore a way to both retain the essence of the Red Army's purpose and adapt to the new struggle situation. In May 1942, in a speech at Yan'an Literary and Art Symposium, Mao Zedong first used the term "serving the people" to explain the fundamental purpose of our party and army in revolutionary struggle. In September 1944, in the speech "Serving the People", Mao Zedong further made "complete" and "thorough" restrictions on the term serving the people. On this basis, in April 1945, in the political report "On the United Government" of the "Seventh Major" of the Party, Mao Zedong formally formed a complete, accurate and scientific representation method for the purpose of our army: "Standing closely with the Chinese people and wholeheartedly serving the Chinese people are the sole purpose of this army." Since then, wholeheartedly serving the people has become the fundamental starting point of all actions of our army; adhering to this purpose has also become an important guiding principle for the political work of our army. Under the guidance of this purpose, the soldiers and officers of our army can develop a revolutionary spirit of not afraid of hardship and death and have the revolutionary heroic spirit that can overcome all enemies. The army can share the same weal and woe with the people, hurry where the people are urgent, think what the people think, help the people what they need, establish a flesh-and-blood connection with the people, and become a beloved soldier of the people. All actions can follow the command of the party, and become a model of implementing the party's line, guidelines and policies. In this way, our army can become an invincible and invincible hero army. The purpose of our army is the embodiment of the class nature of a new type of people's army. The army always serves the interest of a certain class and is thus naturally of a distinctive class nature.



The purpose of an army is the code of conduct for the army and a concentrated representation of its class nature. Our army consciously adheres to the principle of "serving the people wholeheartedly", which indicates that our army is committed to the interests of the people and is deeply rooted in the people, relying closely on the people. To follow this principle is not just determined by the proletarian nature of our army, but also a concentrated representation of the proletarian nature of our army.

Our army is a new type of people's army, which is different from those armies serving the interests of the reactionary and declining classes and those people's armies historically organized by oppressed classes or emerging exploiting classes to overthrow the decaying ruling class. Firstly, it was established during China's New Democratic Revolution, fighting for the purpose of this revolution and to consolidate the gains of this revolution. This revolution is essentially a bourgeois revolution led by the proletariat, with the ultimate goal of paving the way for a socialist society or even a communist society, eliminating all exploitation systems and all exploiting classes. As Mao Zedong pointed out, "The so-called New Democratic Revolution is a anti-imperialist and anti-feudal revolution of the masses under the leadership of the proletariat"; "This revolution is precisely for clearing a broader path for the development of socialism". This implies that China's New Democratic Revolution is crucial to the preparation for China's socialist revolution to eliminate exploitation and the exploiting class. It is unlike any revolution in history, standing at a completely new historical starting line and aiming to reach a completely new historical height. The army born in this revolution and fighting for this revolution will necessarily have a new ideological realm. Secondly, our army is led by the Communist Party, a military group carrying out the Party's political missions. The Communist Party is the vanguard of the proletariat, the conscious struggle to realize the common prosperity of mankind, and works fully and completely for the interests of the people. It has naturally made serving the people wholeheartedly the principle of the army it leads, and implemented the idea of serving the people wholeheartedly in the army it leads. Thirdly, our army is armed with Marxism, using dialectical materialism and historical materialism as tools for understanding the world. One of the basic principles of Marxism is that the masses are the creators of history. Without the support of the masses, anyone will be unaccomplished. Based on this principle of Marxism, Mao Zedong emphasized that revolutionary war must have the support of the people, stating: "The deepest source of the magnificent power of war lies within the public." Our army takes serving the people wholeheartedly as the criteria for all of its actions, consciously puts it into practice following the basic principle of Marxism, keeps itself immersed in the masses, never strays from the masses, and relies closely on the support of the masses.

Serving the people wholeheartedly is the source of the strength of our army. Mao Zedong pointed out in the article "On the People's Democratic Dictatorship" that the reason our army is powerful is its conscious discipline and the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly.


Due to adhering to this principle, our army possesses a fearless spirit, determined to defeat all enemies, and never succumb to them; due to adhering to this principle, our army maintains unity and consistency between officers and soldiers, superiors and subordinates, and military work, political work and logistical work internally, as well as unity between the military and civilians, military and government, and our allies externally.  Due to adhering to this principle, our army has a correct policy for winning over enemy officers and soldiers and handling prisoners of war; due to adhering to this principle, our army has formed a series of strategies and tactics required for people's war; due to adhering to this principle, our army has formed revolutionary political work necessary for people's war; due to adhering to this principle, our army consciously performs the tasks of the production team. 
Under the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly, the officers and soldiers of our army clearly know that they are fighting for the people's interests, which include their own, and that their cause is great and noble, thus obtaining a strong psychological pillar. Therefore, they have a conscious and heroic spirit of self-sacrifice, willing to sacrifice their lives to defeat the enemy, even if it means fighting to the last man, they will never surrender. It is such a spirit that makes our army an invincible and fearless military.

Under the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly, our army has a good tradition of internal and external unity. Internally, whether they are officers, soldiers or even cooks, they are all from all over the country, all serving the people, all class brothers, and only on this basis of common class interests can a new relationship between officers and soldiers be formed. Externally, the army and the people form a close relationship. The army places the interests of the people above all else, always protecting the people's interests; the people regard this army as their own children and provide continuous support in terms of manpower, material resources, and spiritual support. They support the army at all costs and provide support for the army's survival and development, setting up posts, keeping vigil, leading the way, delivering food and ammunition, hiding wounded soldiers, cooperating in operations, and many models of supporting the army are emerging. The respect and love between officers, soldiers, and citizens is the source of the invincible strength of our army.

Under the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly, our army can effectively disintegrate the enemy army. Because our army can correctly distinguish between the upper and lower levels of the enemy army and carry out targeted work. Especially for the lower-level officers and soldiers of the enemy army, our army, with its actions of serving the people wholeheartedly, makes them understand that the war our army is engaged in is in line with their interests. Once they understand this, they will leave their old camps and join our army. In addition, under the guidance of the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly, our army follows a humanitarian policy towards prisoners, treats the injured, respects their dignity, welcomes those who wish to stay, and sends off those who wish to leave... This series of correct prisoner policies effectively disintegrates the morale of the enemy.

Under the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly, our army has formed strategies and tactics unique to the people's war. This strategy and tactics are based on the support of the people; and this strategy and tactics can only work with the support of the people.

Under the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly, the political work of our army is unified among officers and soldiers, the army and the people, and disintegrating the enemy army. The political work carried out according to this series of principles fundamentally mobilizes the intelligence and courage of our vast number of officers and soldiers, ensures good internal and external relations of our army, and effectively disintegrates the enemy army.


Under the principle of serving the people wholeheartedly, our army starts from the principle of reducing the burden on the people and actively undertakes production activities in the intervals of combat or training. The implementation of this activity not only greatly improved the living conditions of our military officers and soldiers but also won the support of the masses, making the masses truly regard this army as their own. 

Insisting on serving the people with all one's heart and soul gives our army powerful spiritual strength and the sincere support of the masses. This is the true strength of our army. As Zhu De once pointed out: "Our army is the product of the Chinese people's revolution. It is as loyal to the people as a son is to his mother, so the people love and support it, help it overcome difficulties, and continuously consolidate and grow under extremely harsh conditions."

The three major tasks of our army, as the main instrument of war, are naturally to fight. But as a people's army founded by the Chinese Communist Party, its duties are not only to fight. Since its inception, it has been carrying out the triadic tasks of fighting, doing mass work, and raising funds. In September 1929, the "Instruction Letter from the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China to the Fourth Army of the Red Army" stated that the basic tasks of the Red Army were: "First, to launch mass struggles, carry out land revolutions, and establish Soviet power; second, to carry out guerrilla warfare, arm the peasants, and expand its organization; third, to expand the guerrilla areas and political influence to the whole country." The letter said: "If the Red Army cannot carry out the above three tasks, it is no different from a regular army." The Gutian Conference Resolution, drafted by Mao Zedong, further pointed out based on the spirit of the letter: The Red Army is "an armed group that carries out revolutionary political tasks," "In addition to fighting to eliminate enemy military forces, it also bears major tasks such as propaganda to the masses, organizing the masses, arming the masses, helping the masses establish revolutionary power, and establishing Communist Party organizations." If these are forgotten, "it is to lose the meaning of fighting and the reason for the existence of the Red Army."

During the Anti-Japanese War, the task of raising funds was changed to "production," i.e., "making use of the intervals of combat and training to engage in the production of food and daily necessities, reaching the goal of self-supply, half self-supply or partial self-supply by the army." Mao Zedong once wrote about the great significance of the army's self-supply at that time. He pointed out: "The army's self-supply, under our conditions, is seemingly backward and regressive in form, but in substance, it is progressive and of significant historical meaning." "It allows our army to overcome difficulties in living materials, improve living conditions, and lighten the tax burden on the people in the difficult situation, thus winning the support of the people, sufficient to support a long-term war, and sufficient to expand the army, thereby expanding the liberated areas and shrinking the occupied areas, achieving the final goal of eliminating the invaders and liberifying the whole of China. Is this historical significance not great?" He said: "As long as every one of us brave and good at fighting Eighth Route Army and New Fourth Army, everyone is not only good at fighting, doing mass work, but also producing, we are not afraid of any difficulties, we will be what Mengzi said: 'Invincible'.

Before and after the victory of the liberation war, the three major tasks of our army were popularly summarized as a combat team, a work team, and a production team. In 1949, when the national liberation was about to come, a large number of cadres were urgently needed to carry out work in the vast new areas. Faced with this situation, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China decided to transform all 2.1 million field armies into work teams. In his report at the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee, Mao Zedong pointed out: "The People's Liberation Army is always a combat team. Even after the nationwide victory, during the historical period when the class has not been eliminated in the country and the imperialist system exists in the world, our army is still a combat team." "The People's Liberation Army is also a work team... With the gradual reduction of fights, the role of the work team has increased.



"After the founding of the People's Republic of China, the party faced the arduous task of reviving the national economy. The Military Commission of the Central People's Government pointed out in the “Directive on the Participation of the Army in Production and Construction in 1950”, "The People's Liberation Army is not only a defense army, but also a production army." This led to the formation of combat teams, work teams, and production teams. 
The fundamental purpose of building the People's Army is to serve the people, the army will do what the people need, and the interests of the Chinese people are the highest criterion to determine the tasks of our army at various times. Without this, the basic premise is lost. At the same time, the functions of the army are linked to its tasks. There are military, political, and economic tasks, long-term and current tasks, as well as basic and auxiliary tasks, etc. Our army is the part of the people that is the most organized, the most conscious, and the most combative. It can use military means to eliminate the enemy; it can serve as a propagator and organizer for the masses; it can also carry out agricultural and military production, reduce the burden on the people, support local construction, and even rescue the people from natural disasters, integrating multiple tasks in one, serving the people in all aspects. Of course, the People's Army's execution of the three major tasks has priorities. The People's Army, as a tool of the proletariat revolution and dictatorship, its fundamental task is combat. At different historical periods, the party has repeatedly emphasized that the People's Army can only complete other tasks without hindering its fundamental tasks. If it denies this basic task and does other work, it is putting the cart before the horse. It fails to accomplish the special tasks entrusted to our army by the people and fundamentally harms the interests of the people.

II. Adhere to the Party's Absolute Leadership over the Army
Formation of the Party's Ideology of Absolute Leadership over the Army
From the day the Communist Party of China had its own armed forces, it attached great importance to the issue of leadership over the army. In October 1927, on the way to the Jinggang Mountains leading the Autumn Harvest Uprising troops, Mao Zedong carried out the famous "Three Bays Reform", deciding to establish party organizations at all levels within the army under the leadership of the party's pre-enemy committee. "Party branches are built at the company level", party groups are established at the squad and platoon levels, party committees are established at the battalion and regiment levels, and party representatives are set at levels above the company. These important principles and systems have laid an important organizational foundation for the realization of party leadership over the military. In July 1928, in Zhou Enlai's military report at the Sixth Congress of the Party, when discussing the establishment of the Red Army and the militarization of party members, it was explicitly proposed that "the party should play a central role and a leading role." The "Resolution on Military Work" passed by the Sixth Congress of the Party further pointed out that "all military work of the Communist Party of China should be concentrated in the Central Military Department of the Communist Party of China." In December 1929, the Red Fourth Army held the Ninth Congress of the Party, and the famous Gutian Conference Resolution drafted by Mao Zedong pointed out against the purely military point of view that was detached from the leadership of the Party, clearly proposed that "China's Red Army is an armed group that performs revolutionary political tasks", and the ruling organs of the party in the army should become "the central leadership"; it stipulated that "all work, after the discussion and resolution of the party, should be carried out by the masses", important issues after the party committee meeting discussion, "once a resolution is made, it must be resolutely implemented". This established a set of principles and measures to realize the party's leadership over the army politically, ideologically, and organizationally, fundamentally distinguishing the proletariat army from all old armies and established the red army completely on the foundation of Marxism, thus strengthening the party's leadership over the army. In June 1930, the pre-enemy committee of the CPC issued the "Outline of Political Work at All Levels of the Fourth Army of the Red Army" prepared by the Red Fourth Army, as well as the "Provisional Regulations on the Political Work of the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army (Draft)" promulgated by the central government in the winter of 1930, both formally stipulated the party's leadership over the army. Since then, adhering to the fundamental principle of the party's absolute leadership over the army, has appeared in many of our party and army's formal documents, and has also been stipulated in military political work regulations promulgated over the years."



The principle of the Party's absolute leadership over the military, not only gradually formed and established with the founding of our army, but is also deeply rooted on the basis of Marxist theory. 

Marxism tells us that the army is the product of class struggle and is the tool for a certain class and its party to achieve political purposes. It is subordinate to a certain class and its party and serves the interests of a certain class and its party. There is no supra-class army or supra-party army in the world. Since modern times, the ruling class usually leads the state through its own party, and also controls the army through its own party. Of course, there are various forms for the ruling class to control the military. For example, in capitalist countries, some control state power and the military through one party, some through the rotation of two or multiple parties. However, regardless of the form, it cannot change the essence of executing the ruling class's will and cannot cover up the fact that it is the party, state, and army of the ruling class. The bourgeoisie's rule cannot allow the proletariat to take control of their political power, their military. Similarly, the Communist Party as the vanguard of the proletariat must firmly hold the leadership of the proletariat's army in its own hands and never share it with any other party.

In the long-term revolutionary struggle, the Chinese Communists have greatly enriched and developed Marxist theory by combining the basic principles of Marxism with the specific practice of the Chinese revolution, in many fields, including classes, parties, states, and armies. Mao Zedong once pointed out: "The party is the vanguard of the proletariat and the highest form of proletarian organization, and it should lead all other organizations, such as the army, government, and people's groups." He also said: "In these seven aspects of industry, agriculture, commerce, education, military, politics, and the party, the party leads everything." The Communist Party absolutely leads the army, which is Mao Zedong's consistent thought and proposition. As early as the land revolution, Mao Zedong explicitly stated: "Only the Communist Party leads this revolutionary war, and the Communist Party has formed an absolute leadership over the revolutionary war. The absolute leadership of the Communist Party is the most important condition for the revolutionary war to persist to the end. Without this absolute leadership by the Communist Party, it cannot be imagined that the revolutionary war could be so persistent." After the outbreak of the Anti-Japanese War, in order to strengthen the party's absolute leadership over the army, Mao Zedong further emphasized in the article "The Situation and Task of the Anti-Japanese War after the Fall of Shanghai and Taiyuan" that the Chinese Communist Party insists on its independent and self-determined guidelines in the Anti-Japanese National United Front, clearly stating: we "rejected the Nationalist Party's request to send their party members as Eighth Route Army cadres and adhere to the principle that the Communist Party absolutely commands the Eighth Route Army." In November 1938, when he summarized the experience of the party adhering to the principle of independence and autonomy in the united front since the outbreak of the war and talked about the lesson of Zhang Guozhu's own military power at the sixth plenary session of the sixth party, he further emphasized: "Communist Party members do not fight for personal military power (we must not fight, and never learn from Zhang Guozhu again), but fight for the party's military power, and fight for people's military power." "Our principle is that the party commands the gun, and the gun never commands the party. This is the most vivid summary of Mao Zedong's principle of absolute leadership of the party over the army. In October 1947, he reiterated in the "Declaration of the Chinese People's Liberation Army" that “all our soldiers must always remember that we are the magnificent People's Liberation Army, led by the great Chinese Communist Party. As long as we always adhere to the Party's instructions, we will surely win. The fact is indeed so.


For several decades, the reason why our army has been able to grow from small to large, from weak to strong, and move from victory to victory, the most important reason is that our army has always been under the absolute leadership of the Communist Party of China. The necessity of adhering to the Party's absolute leadership over the military. First of all, the Party's absolute leadership over the military is the fundamental guarantee of the proletariat nature of our military. In the specific environment of the Chinese revolution, emphasizing the Party's absolute leadership over the military can effectively turn the military, which is mainly composed of peasants, into a military of proletariat nature. The Chinese revolutionary war that took place in the semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, in essence, is a peasant war led by the proletariat, and the main component of the revolutionary army is inevitably peasants. As the oppressed, especially those deeply pressed under the three big mountains, Chinese peasants have a strong revolutionism. They strongly desire to overthrow the society that makes them suffer. However, as small producers, they are often influenced by the petty-bourgeois worldview, narrow-minded, lack of foresight, free and loose, and easy to go to extremes. In order to make an army that is mainly composed of peasants into a true proletarian revolutionary army, it is necessary to transform this army with the proletarian worldview and restrain this army with the proletarian revolutionary discipline. All of this can only be realized under the leadership of the Communist Party. Only the Communist Party can implement the proletarian revolutionary worldview in the army, establish proletarian revolutionary discipline in the army, thereby effectively overcome all kinds of petty-bourgeois worldview influences brought to this army due to peasant components, and make this army fully and thoroughly fight for the people's benefits. As pointed out in a paragraph added by Mao Zedong in the "Report on Military Political Work Issue of the Rearguard Corps Political Department at the Northwest Bureau Cadre Meeting", "It is unimaginable if our army does not have the leadership of the Communist Party and does not have the revolutionary military and political work led by the Communist Party. Without the leadership of the Communist Party, there would be no military and political work that thoroughly supports the interests of the people, and if there is no such army with military and political work, it would not be an army that thoroughly supports the interests of the people."

Second, only by adhering to the absolute leadership of the Communist Party of China can our army complete the historical tasks of the Chinese revolution. This is determined by the absolute leadership of the Chinese Communist Party over the revolutionary war. The practice of the Chinese revolution proves that only the proletariat and the Communist Party of China can overcome the narrowness of the peasant class, the petty bourgeoisie, and the national bourgeoisie, lead the revolution and war to the path of victory. The Party’s leadership over the entire war determines its leadership over the military. The Communist Party represents the interests of the broad masses of the people, thus being able to widely mobilize the masses to participate in and support its own army, allowing the war to acquire a deep pool of human and material resources. The Communist Party educates the army with the proletarian worldview, allowing the entire army and soldiers to deeply understand the laws of social development, hate all forms of exploitation, establish the lofty ideals of fighting for communism and serving the people wholeheartedly, thereby giving the army a high level of political consciousness, excellent internal and external unity, a total spirit of revolution, an unconquerable spirit, and an indomitable fight. Therefore, in the revolutionary war, they can be invincible and victorious in all battles; the Communist Party with its tight organization, discipline, and exemplary role makes its organizations at all levels the core of the unified leadership and unity of the military, making the army an unbreakable, unwavering fighting collective, an iron Great Wall that cannot be shaken by any individual ambitious schemers; the Communist Party uses Marxism's scientific theory as a guide, pointing out the correct political direction for the army in a timely manner, and formulating flexible and mobile strategies and tactics.



The Chinese Revolutionary War was long and complex. The People's Army often found itself in difficult positions, but due to the correct political and military leadership of the Party, it was finally able to grow from weak to strong, defeating all powerful enemies at home and abroad. 
In the end, the absolute leadership of the Party over the army is the fundamental guarantee for the growth and continuous victories of our army. The People's Liberation Army was born on August 1, 1927, was known as the Red Army of workers and peasants during the Land Revolution War, was reorganized into the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army during the Anti-Japanese War, and was named the People's Liberation Army during the Liberation War. The growth of the army from scratch, from small to large, and from weak to strong, are all results of the correct leadership and command of the Party. The third erroneous "leftist" dogmatic leadership and Zhang Guozhu's right opportunist anti-party activities lost the Red Army and its base areas nine-tenths. The Party and Mao Zedong resolutely opposed these "leftist" and rightist opportunisms, upheld the correct Marxist-Leninist guidance of the army, insisted on the correct military line, and ensured the growth and development of our army and achieved one victory after another. In particular, the Zunyi Conference established Mao Zedong's leadership position in the Red Army and the Party Central Committee, saved the Party in a critical moment, and also saved the Red Army. Thereafter, under the correct leadership of the Party, the Red Army shattered the enemy's encirclement and blockade, overcame rare difficulties and obstacles, successfully completed the 25,000-mile Long March, and created a miracle in human history. During the Anti-Japanese War, the strength comparison between the enemy and us was extremely disparate and the struggle environment was extremely difficult. Our Party, however, formulated the policy and strategy of conducting an independent and autonomous guerrilla war against Japan, leading our army to march deep into the enemy's rear, liberate the masses, and conduct a protracted people's war, finally shattering the myth of the invincibility of Japanese imperialism. After defeating the Japanese invaders, the Party Central Committee and Mao Zedong commanded our army to carry out the unprecedented scale of the Liberation War with the Kuomintang army, and in just over three years eliminated the Kuomintang's eight million reactionary troops, achieving the victory of liberating the whole of China. The facts eloquently prove that the establishment and growth of the Chinese People's Liberation Army is entirely attributable to the Chinese Communist Party, which founded, nurtured, and commanded the army. The Party's absolute control over the army must be realized through politics, ideology, organization, and systems. In the long-term practice of revolutionary struggle, our Party, in order to strengthen absolute command over the army, has gradually formed a set of fundamentally effective systems and measures to lead the army. This is the crystallization of the scientific experience of our Party's leadership of the army, which must be seriously upheld. 
Politically, the absolute leadership of the Party over the army is realized through the leadership of the Party's program, policies, and guidelines. The army is a tool for realizing the political program and policies of the Party. Only by resolutely implementing the Party's policies can the correct direction of army building be maintained, the thoughts and actions of the entire army be united, the relationship between army building and the Party's central task be properly handled, and the army truly become an armed group that obeys and serves the Party's program and policies and serves the realization of the Party's political tasks better. Therefore, the Party stipulates that in the army, only the Party's program, policies, and guidelines can be propagated, and the vast majority of officers and soldiers should be mobilized and organized to strive for the realization of the Party's program, policies, and guidelines. If various political assertions were allowed to be propagated freely within the army, it would cause confusion in the army, or even lose its direction and break away from the leadership of the Party.


In order to realize the political leadership of the military, the Party has formulated a series of military building principles, such as adhering to the purpose of serving the people wholeheartedly, adhering to the principle of the Party controlling the gun; adhering to educating the troops with Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought, and the Party's line, guidelines, and policies; carrying out the three major tasks of combat, working, and production teams; implementing the three major disciplines and eight points of attention; implementing the three major democracies in politics, military, and economy; implementing the three major principles of unity between officers and soldiers, unity between the military and the people, and disintegration of the enemy's army; observing the three major disciplines and eight points of attention; selecting and appointing cadres according to the principle of both moral integrity and professional competence; strengthening the construction of Party organizations in the military, exerting the core leadership role of the Party Committee; combat fort role of the Party branch and the vanguard model role of the Communist Party members; establishing a system of political work, etc. In the long-term revolutionary struggle, it is precisely by adhering to this set of military building principles that the Party has made the military always an armed group carrying out the Party's political tasks.
In terms of thought, the Party's absolute leadership over the military is realized through the insistence on the leadership of Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought. Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought is the only guiding ideology of our Party, country, and military, and is the ideological and theoretical basis for the Party to realize its absolute leadership over the military. This is because the Party's program, line, guideline, policy, and the series of military building principles formulated by the Party for the military, are all products of the combination of Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought, and the actual conditions of the country and military. Only by arming the military with Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought can the military and the Party have a common ideological basis, all actions follow the command of the Party, and can improve the ability of the majority of officers and soldiers to identify and resist various non-proletarian ideological erosions, maintain the purity of military thought. To realize the leadership of the army in ideology, the Party has established a complete set of ideological and political work of the Party in the army and carried out various forms of political education in due course according to the development and changes of the situation and the actual situation of the army. Through this education, the Party truly realizes the ideological leadership of the army.
In terms of organization, the Party achieves its absolute leadership of the military by establishing Party organizations at all levels of the military under the centralized and unified leadership of the Party Central Committee and the Central Military Commission, serving as the unified leadership and unity core of the troops, and making the highest leadership and command right of the military be concentrated in the Party Central Committee and the Central Military Commission, thereby realizing the Party’s absolute leadership of the military. The Regulations on Political Work of Our Army stipulate: “The People’s Liberation Army of China must be placed under the absolute leadership of the Communist Party of China. The highest leadership and command of the army belong to the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the Central Military Commission.” According to this organizational principle, in the army, only the Communist Party and its assistant—the Communist Youth League, can establish Party and League organizations, develop Party and League members, and carry out work; only Party organizations can appoint leaders at all levels of the army. Without the approval of the corresponding political organs, members of the military are not allowed to join other parties and religious organizations, establish various groups and organizations outside the regulations, or join local mass organizations on their own. The Party's organizational leadership of the military is the organizational guarantee for the Party's leadership of the military. In order to realize the Party's organizational leadership of the military, the Party has taken a series of organizational measures. Through these organizational measures, the goal of the Party's absolute organizational leadership of the military is achieved.
In terms of systems, it is to adhere to the commander-in-chief responsibility system under the unified collective leadership of the Party committee. This is a fundamental system to adhere to the Party’s absolute leadership over the army. The unified leadership of the Party committee, the collective leadership of the Party committee, and the commander in charge of divided work are three inseparable organic components, none of which can be lacking. This system of commander-in-chief responsibility under the collective leadership of the Party committee combines the wisdom of the collective with the initiative and creativity of individuals, which can both avoid the one-sidedness and possible mistakes of individual decision-making and prevent the phenomenon of relying on the collective for everything and no one taking responsibility.


This ensures the implementation of the party's instructions and resolutions, and the completion of various tasks entrusted by the party.
Third, the guiding principles of political work
The military building thought of the Communist Party of China not only emphasizes the importance of political work, but also summarizes the experiences of our army's political work, systematically presenting the guiding principles of our army's political work. About the basic principle of our army's political work, Mao Zedong said: "On the basis of the people's war, with the unity of the army and the people, the commander and the combatants, and the disintegration of the enemy army, the People's Liberation Army has established its own powerful revolutionary political work."

The basic content and requirements of the three principles were initially proposed during the Sanwan reorganization and the Jinggangshan struggle period. In September 1927, when Mao Zedong led the Autumn Harvest Uprising to carry out the Sanwan reorganization of the Workers and Peasants Revolutionary Army, he proposed to eliminate the management of feudal mercenary armies and warlord style, and implement democratic systems. It was specified that officers were not allowed to beat and scold soldiers, the soldiers had the freedom to speak at meetings, and the Soldiers' Committee was established at the company level and above to supervise expenditure and to criticize and supervise cadres. This democracy, based on complete political equality between officers and soldiers, became the initial content of the principle of unity between our army officers and soldiers. In October 1927, when Mao Zedong led the Workers and Peasants Revolutionary Army to Jinggangshan, he successively put forward the Three Main Rules of Discipline and Six Points for Attention, proposed that the army should undertake tasks of fighting, doing mass work and raising funds, and required our army to respect the interests of the masses and obey the discipline of the masses under the principle of seeking benefits for the people, in order to achieve the goal of unity and common struggle between the army and the people. This is the initial requirement of the principle of unity between the army and the people in our army. After the Revolutionary Army of Workers and Peasants established the revolutionary base in Jinggangshan, the enemy armies in Hunan and Jiangxi provinces organized suppression operations from time to time.

On how to handle prisoners of war in the battle between the Revolutionary Army of Workers and Peasants and the enemy army, the understanding and recognition of our army by the officers and soldiers of the enemy army affected how our army could ultimately defeat the enemy. In February 1928, Mao Zedong set out three policies for dealing with prisoners of war: no beating, scolding, killing, mistreatment, discrimination, or searching of prisoners of war, prisoners of war were to enjoy the same political and living treatment as our soldiers; implemented the principle of letting prisoners of war decide their own lives - those who wanted to stay were welcome, those who wanted to leave were given travel expenses; and treatment was given to wounded and sick prisoners of war. These three policies became the basic points of our army’s prisoner of war policy. And leniency towards prisoners of war is our army's main way to disintegrate the enemy army. The basic content and requirements for the above-mentioned three aspects were further confirmed at the Gutian Conference. The resolution required the Red Army to establish new relations between officers and soldiers, the military and the people, and correctly implement a policy on prisoners of war. Abolish the management system and method of leading the old army, and gradually improve the principle of political work. On October 25, 1937, in a conversation with the British journalist Bette, Mao Zedong officially summarized the unity of officers and soldiers, the unity of the military and the people, and the disintegration of the enemy army as the three basic principles of our army's political work.

About the principle of unity of officers and soldiers, Mao Zedong pointed out: "This is to eliminate feudalism in the army, abolish the system of beating and scolding, establish self-disciplined discipline, and lead a life of sharing weal and woe, so the whole army is united." The unity of officers and soldiers is the solid base for our army to overcome all kinds of difficulties and powerful enemies. Sticking to this principle can help our army thoroughly eliminate the residual thoughts of feudalism, mercenarism, and warlordism, and practice political equality, fraternal unity, shared happiness and hardship, and joint struggle between superiors and subordinates, and between cadres and soldiers. The meaning of the relationship between officers and soldiers is broad, not only including the main relationship between officers and soldiers but also relationships between superiors and subordinates, units, and departments. Since the relationship between officers and soldiers is the most fundamental relationship in the army, the principle of unity of officers and soldiers as the representative has become the basic rule for dealing with various relationships within the army. In this relationship, soldiers are the basis and cadres are the guide.



The education of leaders must first care for and love the soldiers, treating the soldiers as class brothers, and fully bringing into play their initiative and creativity. At the same time, it is also necessary to educate the soldiers to respect and cherish their leaders, willingly obey management and command, and help leaders correct their shortcomings and mistakes from a caring perspective, promoting internal unity and forming a strong cohesion. Mao Zedong pointed out, "Establishing conscious discipline and sharing life's joys and sorrows; hence, the whole army is united."

The unanimously principle of the people's army is not just a good wish and slogan, but is ensured by the democratic system. This democratic system has produced powerful forces. During the Jinggangshan period, the material life of the Red Army was extremely hard, and the battles were very frequent, but still maintained unchanging. Apart from the role of the party, this was relying on the implementation of democracy within the army. The officers don't beat and scold the soldiers. The treatment of the officers and soldiers is equal. The soldiers have the freedom to speak at meetings, abolished cumbersome etiquette, and made finances public. Those new captive soldiers felt that the Kuomintang army and the Red Army were two worlds, although the Red Army's material life was not as good as the White Army, but their spirit was liberated. Therefore, the same soldier, who was a cowardly enemy yesterday, is a brave Red Army today. Based on this, Mao Zedong pointed out, "Not only do the Chinese people need democracy, but the army also needs democracy. The democratic system within the army will be an important weapon to undermine the feudal mercenaries." He also said that the army "implementing a certain degree of democratization" "would drastically increase its combat power, and it would not fear that it could not sustain a long and cruel war". During the liberation war, the democratic system of the People's Army further developed into three major democracies of politics, economy, and military. Political democracy means enabling soldiers to exercise their democratic rights to achieve high political unity. Economic democracy is for soldiers to select representatives, who has the right to assist (not exceed) the company leader in managing the company's supplies and food, in order to improve the way of life. Military democracy is to teach each other between officers and soldiers, and soldiers during training; during combat, under the guidance of the company leader, mobilize soldiers to discuss combat methods, utilize the wisdom of the officers and soldiers, in order to improve technical tactics. The implementation of three major democracies has better implemented the principle of unity between officers and soldiers of the People's Liberation Army, which strongly guaranteed the victory of the war.

Regarding the principle of unity between the army and the people, Mao Zedong pointed out: "The relationship between cadres and soldiers should be close and united. The relationship between the army and the people and local party and government organizations should also be close". "The army must unite with the people, so that the army is viewed as their own in the eyes of the people, and this army will be invincible in the world". Emphasizing the principle of unity between the army and the people requires political work to ensure the unity of the army and the government and the army and the people. Under the guidance of this principle, the army always respects the people's government, cares for the people's interests, strictly enforces mass discipline, reduces the economic burden on the people, supports the people, abides by local policies and laws, respects local cadres, strengthens the unity of the army and the people, and jointly strikes against the enemy. The adherence to political work of this basic principle of correctly handling military-civilian relations can ensure the symbiotic relationship between the army and the people, gain the support and support of the people and the local government, and achieve victory in people's wars.


During the initial establishment of our military, we implemented the three major tasks and the three disciplines and six attentions, as specific actions to enforce the unity of the military and the civilians. On October 1, 1943, the CPC Central Committee issued a directive, demanding the People's Army to launch a large-scale "pro-governance and love the people" movement in the next January. To make a match, the anti-Japanese bases' governments and people of are required to launch a large-scale "support the army and prefer the anti-Japanese" movement, and a system needs to be established. During this movement, civilians and military both established and revised their own pro-government civilian conventions and support the army conventions, held celebration meetings, and consciously checked and criticized their own shortcomings. This is a new creation that implements the principle of unity between the military and the civilian society, and it serves as a good method to handle disagreements between the two in a correct manner. It brought the military and civilians in the anti-Japanese bases closer. Today, the annual pro-governance, love of the people, support for the army, and preference for the people activities before and after the Lunar New Year remain an institutional tradition in our country.

As for the principle of disintegrating the enemy army and treating prisoners with leniency, Mao Zedong pointed out, "Our victory not only relies on our army's operations but also depends on the disintegration of the enemy's army." Therefore, the People's Army has a correct policy for winning over the enemy's officers and men and treating prisoners. Anyone from the enemy who defects, repents, or is willing to fight against the common enemy after laying down their arms is welcomed and is provided appropriate education. Everyone, who becomes a prisoner of war, is treated kindly, without being killed, humiliated, or insulted."

This principle requires our army to carry out political propaganda and organizational disintegration of the enemy army politically, ideologically, organizationally, and psychologically while fighting. Various forms, such as battlefield shouting, distribution of propaganda materials, and infiltration into the enemy, are used to carry out political offensives that shake the morale and weaken the fighting strength of the enemy army. Implementing a good policy for prisoners of war, respecting the dignity of those surrendering, repenting, and laying down their arms, treating them leniently and without humiliation, and welcoming those who join our army, help weaken the enemy's strength and enhance our own to the greatest extent.

First established in the Jinggang Mountain period, the Red Army laid down four regulations for treating prisoners of war with leniency: first, don't beat, scold, kill, or torture prisoners of war. Second, don't search the prisoners' waist packs. Third, provide treatment to the injured. Fourth, release prisoners of war with freedom to stay or go; those who stay are welcomed and can join the workers and peasants revolutionary army, who will treat everyone equally, while those who leave will be given travel expenses. 

In all wars, our army used various propaganda tools to carry out a strong political offensive against the enemy army to support the military offensive. Due to the serious implementation of the principle of disintegrating the enemy army, the enemy's combat effectiveness was effectively weakened. During the Red Army period, from the first to the fourth anti-"siege" in the central revolutionary base area, 514,000 enemies were annihilated, among them, 198,000 were captured, accounting for 38.5%. During the Anti-Japanese War, Japanese soldiers influenced strongly by the militaristic education and the spirit of Bushido were also captured by the people's army. Under the inspiration of the policy of treating the prisoners of war with leniency, they joined the fight against the war of aggression. They formed anti-war and revolutionary organizations such as the "Anti-War Alliance" and "Awakening Alliance" and fought against the Japanese invaders shoulder to shoulder with the Chinese people. 

In the Liberation War, our army annihilated more than 8 million Kuomintang troops. Among them, the number of prisoners of war, defectors, rebels, and reorganized people totaled 6.36 million, accounting for 79% of the total number of enemies annihilated. These facts vividly illustrate the importance of the principle of disintegrating the enemy army.

The People's Army regards the unity of officers and soldiers, the unity of the military and civilians, and the disintegration of the enemy army as basic principles of political work also based on the purpose of the People's Army. First of all, the People's Army comes from the people and for the people. It does not have its own special interests. There is a common political base composed of shared interests between the army and the civilians. The officers and soldiers are all together for a common goal. Therefore, it is feasible and necessary for the People's Army's relationship between officers and soldiers and the people to be unanimous.



Next, the victory in the revolutionary war mainly depends on the masses of the people and soldiers. Therefore, it does not allow its own troops to stand above the people, and it does not allow officers to stand above soldiers. Instead, it must implement unity between the military and the people as well as unity between officers and soldiers. The principles of disintegrating the enemy forces and lenient treatment of prisoners of war are also inseparable from the class nature of the people's army. The people's army is fighting a just war against an unjust war, and it firmly believes that truth can persuade people, and the counter-revolutionary army can be disintegrated. The enemy soldiers who work for the reactionary class are mostly the coerced working masses, so the people's army should not torture and kill the enemy officers and soldiers who have dropped their weapons, but should practice revolutionary humanitarianism, show magnanimity, and strive to have them join the side of the just war. This not only will lead to the disintegration of the enemy's army and leniency towards prisoners of war, but it will also prompt the enemy's internal officers and soldiers to realize the unjust nature of the war. 

Mao Zedong pointed out: If the relationship between the military and the people, as well as the relationship between officers and soldiers is not handled well, this is not a matter of methods, but of fundamental attitudes or principles; the three major principles of respect for soldiers, respect for the people, and respect for captured enemy soldiers who have laid down their arms, all have to come from a fundamental attitude of respect for their human dignity. This democratic spirit is unique to the proletarian revolutionary army. All reactionary armies have no common interests with the masses and there exists contradictions of confrontation. Therefore, they are in opposition to the military and the people, and opposition between officers and soldiers. They cannot take a democratic attitude towards soldiers and the people, only use deceit and coercion; and for enemy prisoners of war, they often torture and massacre. All of this is inseparable from the class nature of these reactionary armies. Without doing so, the majority of their officers and soldiers from working-class backgrounds would not be able to act against the people, their army would not become the tool of the reactionary class.

The three principles of democracy are a vivid manifestation of the mass line in the construction of the army. Since the establishment of our army, Mao Zedong has emphasized the need to implement the mass line and develop democracy within the army. He pointed out that democracy is needed not only by the people but also by the army. The democratic system within the army will be an important weapon to destroy feudal mercenary armies. He personally established the Soldiers' Committee, implemented equality between officers and soldiers in politics and economics, and established a new democratic unity relationship within the people's army. In the resolution of the Gutian meeting, he also clearly stipulated the principle of "strict central guidance-based democratic life in the organization". During the Anti-Japanese War, he further stated that internal democracy in the army is an important factor in sustaining a prolonged war. Due to the establishment of a democratic system within the army, the aim of unity between officers and soldiers has been achieved, and the army has greatly increased its fighting capacity, and the long-term brutal war can be sustained. During the liberation war, he further summarized the experience of our army, wrote the article "Democracy Movement in the Army", and made a profound discussion on the purpose and method of internal democracy in the army. He pointed out: "The policy of internal political work in the army is to mobilize soldiers, masses, commanders, and all workers to achieve three major goals through the democratic movement under centralized leadership: high political unity, improvement of living conditions, and improvement of technical and tactical skills. "Political democracy means parity and unity between officers and soldiers and unity between superiors and subordinates. Through criticism and self-criticism, a high degree of political unity is achieved. Economic democracy is where representatives elected by soldiers have the right to assist (not surpass) the company leader in managing the company's food supply, implementing economic openness, and achieving the goal of improving life. Military democracy is the mass line of military work. During military training, there is mutual teaching between officers and soldiers and between soldiers. During combat, under the guidance of the company leader, soldiers are mobilized to discuss tactical and technical issues. Hence, the three principles of democracy are a vivid manifestation of the mass line in the construction of our army.


Implementing democracy within the military, we must properly handle the relationship between democracy and centralism. Our army is a highly centralized and unified combat collective, which not only needs to have democracy, but also needs to have a high level of centralization. Mao Zedong pointed out: These are two contradictory aspects of a unity, they are contradictory and unified, we should not emphasize one aspect while denying the other. We must both promote democracy in the military and prevent extreme democratization and anarchy; we must emphasize centralization and oppose militarism and commandism. In short, the democracy we implement in the military is democracy under centralized guidance, which is fundamentally different from bourgeois democracy. The three main disciplines and eight points of attention are important guarantees for our army's unity and combat. Discipline is the guarantee of implementing the line. The strict discipline of the People's Army is based on the political consistency and high consciousness of all officers and soldiers, and is a revolutionary discipline that serves the fundamental interests of the people. There is a fundamental difference from the old army discipline. The Three Rules and Eight Points set by Mao Zedong for the army are the basic guidelines for the entire army's actions, fully demonstrating the essence of the People's Army's conscious maintenance of the masses' interests.

When the party establishes military discipline, there are two fundamental starting points: one is to safeguard the interests of the people; the other is to consolidate and enhance the combat effectiveness of the troops.

As early as after the Autumn Harvest Uprising in the Hunan-Jiangxi border area in September 1927, Mao Zedong demanded that the officers and soldiers of the Autumn Harvest Uprising treat the people with politeness, fairness in buying and selling, not to exploit labor, not to beat people, and not to scold others. In October, Mao Zedong, in view of some problems in the implementation of discipline by the then uprising troops, announced three disciplines to the troops: ①Obey orders in all actions; ②Don’t take a single sweet potato from the masses; ③The confiscation from landlords should be turned over to the state. The implementation of these three disciplines effectively enhanced the unity within the army and between the military and civilians. After the troops entered Jinggangshan, because of continuous marching and fighting and scattered activities, there were instances of indiscipline. In early January 1928, after the Red Army occupied the county seat of Suichuan, Mao Zedong promptly summarized the experience of doing mass work, and then proposed six precautions: ①Close the door; ②Tie the straw; ③Speak politely; ④Buy and sell fairly; ⑤Return borrowed goods; ⑥Compensate for damaged things. In April 1928, after the uprising troops arrived in Shatian Village, Guidong County, Hunan Province, Mao Zedong formally announced the three major disciplines and six points of attention to all officers and soldiers. "Don't take a sweet potato from the masses" was changed to "Don't take anything from the workers and farmers." In 1929, when Mao Zedong was leading the Fourth Red Army to march to southern Jiangxi and western Fujian, he again changed the six attitudes into eight points of attention, adding "Bathing to avoid women", "Do not search the pockets of prisoners of war". Later, according to the development of the situation and the practical experience of the troops, "Do not take anything from the workers and farmers" was changed to "Do not take a single needle or thread from the masses"; "The confiscation from landlords should be turned over to the state" was changed to "Do not beat or scold people", "Do not damage crops"; "Bathing to avoid women" was changed to "Do not harass women"; "Do not search the pockets of prisoners of war" was changed to "Do not abuse prisoners of war". In October 1947, when the War of Liberation entered a critical period of strategic counter-offensive, in order to strengthen discipline and win the nationwide victory, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and Mao Zedong collected opinions from various troops, revised and standardized the content of the "Three Main Rules and Eight Points of Attention", and the Headquarters of the Chinese People's Liberation Army issued the "Instructions on Re-Issuing the Three Main Rules and Eight Points of Attention" drafted by Mao Zedong in Jia County, Shaanxi, to the entire army, requiring the entire army to "educate deeply" and "implement sternly". 

The "Three Main Rules and Eight Points of Attention" mainly manifests in its regulation of the political discipline, military discipline, and mass discipline of the People's Army, reflecting the disciplinary features of the People's Army.

Political discipline is the standard for military personnel's political behavior and speech, and is an important guarantee in adjusting the relationship between the army and the class and its party, standardizing for which class and its party the army serves, and which class and its party lead the army. "Obey orders in all actions" is the most important part of political discipline.



When Mao Zedong led the Autumn Harvest Uprising troops to conduct the Sanwan Reorganization, he began to establish the Party's organizations and representative systems in the army, and established the principle of "building branches at the company level." A month later, he proposed three disciplines, the first of which was obedience in all actions. Despite numerous modifications to the "Three Major Disciplines and Eight Points of Attention," this principle has always been preserved, and is listed as the first of the "Three Major Disciplines and Eight Points of Attention." It vividly reflects the nature of the People's Army and its dedication to serving the people wholeheartedly, embodying the principle that the Party commands the gun, never allowing the gun to command the Party. "Obedience in all actions," primarily means that the army must obey the command of the Party and submit to the leadership of the Party. The People's Liberation Army of China is the army of the people, established and led by the Communist Party of China, and its leaders at all levels carry out their duties and complete tasks under the leadership of the Party's organizations at the same level. Thus, obeying the Party's command and obeying the command of administrative leaders is consistent.

The three major disciplines constitute the system of disciplinary content of the People's Liberation Army, providing a standard for military action and an important guarantee for the army to complete training, duty, combat readiness, and other tasks in peacetime, and combat tasks in wartime. Strengthening and enhancing combat power is the starting point and ending point of all work in the People's Army; therefore, the army must have the strictest military discipline and must reinforce military discipline. "Obedience in all actions," "all captured materials must be turned in," "no mistreatment of prisoners," implementing these disciplines earnestly will play a significant role in cultivating the army's organizational discipline, implementing prisoner policies, and disintegrating enemy armies. As revolutionary soldiers, one must be loyal to their position, dedicate themselves to the defense of the nation, and consciously cultivate their professional discipline, that is military discipline.

Mass discipline is the standard for adjusting military-civilian relationship behaviors. The People's Liberation Army of China is the People's Army dedicated to serving the people wholeheartedly. The nature and purpose of the People's Army require it to be deeply rooted among the people, sharing weal and woe, blending like milk and water, depending on each other like fish and water, and closely connected in mind. The mass discipline of not offending even the slightest hair is the invaluable heritage that guarantees the People's Army is invincible in battle.

The "Three Major Disciplines and Eight Points of Attention" contain a total of eleven items, eight of which are regulations concerning mass discipline. For example, "do not take a single needle or thread from the masses," "speak politely," "trade fairly," "return borrowed items," "compensate for damages," "do not hit or swear at people," "do not damage crops," "do not harass women," and so on, highlight the People's Army's fundamental stance and attitude of serving the people, loving the people, and respecting the people.

Political discipline, military discipline, and mass discipline are all important components of the "Three Major Disciplines and Eight Points of Attention", and form an interconnected whole. Political discipline plays a leading role, providing fundamentals and direction, constraining and influencing the implementation of other disciplines; military discipline is the main body of army discipline; mass discipline is determined by the nature of the People's Army.

Chapter 4: Thoughts on People's War

I. Soldiers and Civilians are the foundation of victory


The People's War ideology of the Communist Party of China is based on the firm belief that the people are the decisive force in a revolutionary war, representing the fundamental interests of the majority of the people. It is a product of the basic principles of dialectical materialism and historical materialism, combined with China's war practices, and is the fullest embodiment of the Party's mass line in the revolutionary war. 
Historical materialism believes that the people are the creators of world history and the decisive force in human social activities, development, and change. Any major societal activity cannot be separated from the participation of the people, and its ultimate outcome is also determined by the will and power of the people. Mao Zedong summarized this idea succinctly, "The people, and only the people, are the driving force in the making of world history." He creatively applied this idea to the field of war, laying a solid foundation for the theory of the People's War. As early as the period of the land revolution war, Mao Zedong pointed out: "What is the real iron wall? It is the masses, the millions who truly support the revolution. This is the real iron wall, which cannot be broken by any power, completely unbreakable. The reactionaries cannot break us, but we can break the reactionaries. By uniting millions around the revolutionary government, developing our revolutionary war, we can defeat all reactionaries and win over the whole of China." During the Anti-Japanese War, in the face of the outrageous aggression by Japanese imperialism, Mao Zedong, as a proletarian revolutionary, insightfully pointed out: "The deepest source of the power of war lies in the people. The main reason why Japan dares to bully us lies in the unorganised state of the Chinese people. Once we overcome this defect and place Japanese invaders in front of our tens of millions of people who have stood up, we will frighten this wild bull into a big jump at our call, and this wild bull must be burned to death. With the beginning of the liberation war, Mao Zedong clearly pointed out: the people determine the victory or defeat of the war.
The reason why the masses are the source of war power is that war, as a special process of human social activity, ultimately depends on the participation of the people.
The masses are the source of manpower in war. Manpower is the foundation of military power. A key condition for the strength of military power is the numerical superiority of the army. War history shows that when the quality of the warring parties is equal, whoever has the numerical advantage is more likely to win. The people are the source of soldiers, without the people, the army is not strong. To establish a numerically superior army, the masses are the source of troop strength. The reason why our army was able to win in various revolutionary wars was mainly due to the fact that the people were able to continuously deliver new forces to the troops. In the Liaoshen Campaign, farmers in the northeast enthusiastically joined the army and fought, forming 80 second-line corps, about 300,000 people, continuously replenishing our army. In the Huaihai Campaign, the Communist Party of China mobilized 168,000 people to join the army, ensuring the victory of the decisive battle. Marshal Chen Yi passionately sang about the great power of the people, writing in "Remembering the Front Line of Huaihai" the verse "Hundreds of thousands of civilian workers walk impassably, war-horses and high carts carry grain, rotate with the army from west to east, strive to stand on the front line." General Su Yu praised the people as the "inexhaustible source" of the People's Army defeating the enemy.


The people are the source of material power for war. War is a competition of material strength; without certain material conditions, a war cannot be waged, and the most substantial source of material power for war comes from the people. The people are the producers of war supplies. This special social activity of war objectively requires people to invest their labor and materials in the production needed to wage war. With the development of the war, the demand for supplies continues to increase. In a certain sense, whoever can produce more advanced weapons and equipment, whoever can store more war supplies, can support a longer war time and win the victory of the war. The considerable demand for supplies in war cannot be separated from the production of the people. The people are not only the producers of war materials, but also the ones who deliver these supplies to the frontlines. During the three major battles fought by our army in Liaoshen, Huaihai, and Pingjin, more than 5 million civilian workers were mobilized. They used backward transportation means to overcome various difficulties and send a large amount of combat supplies to the frontlines, meeting the needs of the war. Mao Zedong once lamented that our victory in the War of Liberation was mainly due to the support of the 160 million people in the north. "As long as we rely on the people, firmly believe that the creativity of the masses is timely and reliable, and thus trust the people and integrate with the people, then we can overcome any difficulty, and no enemy can overwhelm us, but will be overwhelmed by us".

The great power of war also lies in the people's support or opposition. The outcome of a war certainly depends on the support of human and material resources, but it is even more dependent on the stance of the people. Regardless of whether it is a just war or an unjust war, it is closely related to the interests of the people. The different purposes of war determine the people's attitude towards war. How the people treat a war determines the amount of manpower and material resources invested in the war, determines the degree of proactive ability of the people in the war, determines the ability to overcome the difficulties of war and persist in combat, and ultimately determines the outcome of the war. Mao Zedong once clearly pointed out: Chiang Kai-shek's military advantage is only a temporary phenomenon, only a temporary factor; American imperialist assistance is also only a temporary factor; Chiang Kai-shek’s anti-people nature of the war and the direction of public sentiment, on the other hand, is a constant factor; and in this respect, the People's Liberation Army has the advantage. The patriotic and just revolutionary nature of the People's Liberation Army's war is bound to gain the support of the people of the whole country. This is the political foundation for defeating Chiang Kai-shek. Mao Zedong revealed the law of war development from the perspective that the justice of a war determines the public sentiment, and the public sentiment is a constantly effective factor in war. Zhu De, in his article "How the Chinese People Defeated American Imperialism's Armed Chiang Kai-shek Reactionary", also affirmed this from the perspective of summarizing historical experience. He pointed out: Chiang Kai-shek, the running dog of American imperialism, so rapidly and tragically perished, it is not an accident. This is the inevitable ending of the reactionaries who ignore the will of the people and the power of the people. This is Chiang's inevitable ending - as an adventurer who looked at only his temporary surface strength in the military but did not see his political isolation, carried out actions against the people. This is the historical judgement that should have been made by Chiang Kai-shek's bloody reactionary rule in China for 22 years and by the imperialists in China for more than a hundred years. The Revolutionary War in China was able to receive the active support of the masses because the purpose of the Revolutionary War fundamentally conforms to the interests of the masses. The direction of public sentiment is invincible.

Second, The rural revolutionary base is the strategic base for persisting in a protracted people's war.
Establishing a rural revolutionary base is an important part of Mao Zedong's People's War Theory...



During the Land Revolution War period, he repeatedly emphasized the importance of implementing "armed separatism of workers and peasants", and criticized the roving rebel thought. Later, in the article "Strategic Issues of Anti-Japanese Guerrilla War", he systematically discussed the idea of establishing bases. He pointed out: Rural revolutionary bases are the strategic base for people's war to carry out strategic tasks and achieve the goal of preserving and developing themselves and eliminating and expelling enemies. Without such a strategic base, the implementation of all strategic tasks and the realization of war goals would lose their support. During the Liberation War, when our army had shifted from strategic defense to strategic offense, Mao Zedong still instructed our troops advancing into the enemy-occupied areas to establish solid revolutionary bases in the deep behind enemy lines. Why is it necessary to establish a base in a people's war?

Firstly, fundamentally, this is determined by the long-term and brutal characteristics of China's revolutionary war. Mao Zedong pointed out: "The enemy of China's revolution is extraordinarily strong. Not only does it have powerful imperialism, but also powerful feudal forces, and there are reactionary elements of the bourgeoisie who collude with imperialism and feudal forces and oppose the people for a certain period." They hold political, economic, and military power, and use naked violence to oppress, exploit Chinese people and suppress revolutionaries and the revolutionary masses. The revolutionary forces are quite weak. Chinese people do not have any political freedom or economic strength. It is difficult to fight decisively against the enemy militarily for a while. Precisely because the enemy is extraordinarily strong, the power of the Chinese revolution cannot become a force to finally defeat the enemy without a long period of accumulation and training. Also, because the enemy's suppression of the Chinese revolution is extraordinarily brutal, the revolutionary forces cannot maintain their positions and capture the enemy’s positions without a long period of training to demonstrate their tenacity. The long-term nature and brutality of the Chinese revolution have determined that the focus of the revolutionary struggle should not be placed in cities heavily guarded by the enemy, but should be in rural areas where enemy forces are relatively weak.  

Secondly, the revolution war in our country is essentially a peasant war under the leadership of the proletariat. To carry out people's war, it is necessary to mobilize and rely on peasants. Only by establishing a base in rural areas, can we lead farmers to carry out a deep land revolution, so that farmers can address their immediate interests through land struggle, recognize the leadership of the Communist Party, trust the revolution, and establish a solid alliance between workers and peasants. In this way, we can fully mobilize farmers to join the people's war. While emphasizing that China's proletariat is the leader and the most fundamental driving force of the Chinese revolution, Mao Zedong also pointed out that the Chinese proletariat also has its own inevitable weaknesses, such as fewer numbers, younger ages, and the power of urban proletariat alone cannot win the victory of the Chinese revolution. The Chinese proletariat must rely on their most staunch ally-the peasant class to fulfill its historical mission.



More than 90% are poor peasants and middle peasants, of which the poor hired peasants account for 70%. They suffer from the oppression and exploitation of feudalism and imperialism. Especially the poor hired peasants who make up 70% of the total number of peasants, who basically have no land or insufficient land, are the semi-proletariat in the countryside, are the broadest driving force of the Chinese revolution, are the natural and most reliable allies of the proletariat, and are the main force of the Chinese revolutionary team.
