As early as March 1927, he put forward the seriousness of the peasant problem as the first question in his "Investigation Report on Peasant Movement in Hunan". In 1928, in "Why Can China's Red Power Exist?" and "The Struggle of Jinggangshan", he proposed that the Chinese revolution must combine armed struggle with land revolution and must establish revolutionary bases in the countryside. In 1930, in "A Spark Can Start a Prairie Fire", he further pointed out that the establishment and development of the Red Army guerrillas and the red areas are the most important form and inevitable result of the peasant struggle under the leadership of the proletariat in semi-colonial and semi-feudal China. He criticized the view that opposes the leadership of the proletariat and the role of the peasants as the main force of the revolution, and pointed out that in the semi-colonial Chinese revolution, only when the peasant struggle has not been led by workers can it fail, and that the peasant struggle does not exceed the influence of workers and is not detrimental to the revolution itself. Therefore, the armed struggle of the Chinese Communist Party is a peasant war under the leadership of the proletariat, which determines that the vast rural areas where the peasants are located should become the starting points and footholds for the victory of the Chinese democratic revolution. The rural encirclement of cities is the inevitable trend and result of this peasant revolutionary war.
Thirdly, the revolutionary army, in order to defeat the enemy and avoid decisive battles with powerful enemies when power is insufficient, must consolidate and develop strategic bases, accumulate and strengthen revolutionary forces, so as to create conditions for the final attainment of the entire victory of the revolutionary war in a long-term battle.
Mao Zedong pointed out: "What is the base of guerrilla warfare? It is the strategic base on which guerrilla warfare relies to accomplish its strategic tasks, to achieve the goal of preserving and developing itself, eliminating and driving away the enemy. Without such a strategic base, the execution of all strategic tasks and the realization of the purposes of war will lose their support. No rear action is the characteristic of guerrilla warfare in the rear of the enemy, because it is separated from the total rear of the country. However, without a base, guerrilla warfare cannot survive and develop for a long time, and this base is also the rear of guerrilla warfare." He pointed out that due to the large number of roaming elements in the Red Army and the existence of large roaming masses in the country, especially in the southern provinces, the political thought of brigandage was produced in the Red Army. This kind of thought is manifested in: ① unwilling to do hard work to establish a base, to establish the power of the people, and to expand political influence from this, but only to expand political influence by the method of mobile guerrilla warfare. ② To expand the Red Army, it is necessary to take a route of "recruiting soldiers and buying horses" and "recruiting surrender and admitting betrayal", not to go by the route of expanding local red guards and local red armies to expand the main red army. They are impatient to struggle hard with the masses, only hoping to go to big cities to have a big meal and drink. All these manifestations of brigandage thinking greatly hinder the Red Army from carrying out its correct tasks, so it is an important goal to clear up brigandage thinking in the ideological struggle within the Red Army party. It should be recognized that the brigandage of Huang Chao and Li Zicheng in history is not allowed by today's environment. He later pointed out: "Although the base is small, it has great political power, standing against the huge Kuomintang regime, giving a great difficulty to the Kuomintang's offensive militarily, because we have the support of peasants." Therefore, Mao Zedong pointed out the correct method to solve the problem of the strategic base of the people's guerrilla warfare, which is to establish the revolutionary base in the countryside.
The revolutionary base in the countryside is a great creation of the Chinese Communist Party in the revolutionary war.



"Within a country, amidst the encirclement of white regimes, one or several small pockets of red political power emerge – this is unique to China in the current world." It is determined by the specific rules of the Chinese revolutionary war and is a significant development in the Marxist ideology of people's war. With a revolutionary base, the basic conditions for self-preservation, self-development, and enemy elimination exist; a guaranteed human and material support will be available for long-term warfare. The small Red Army will have a relatively stable environment for training and enhancing its combat effectiveness, and can choose favorable battlefields to attack and annihilate the enemy with various forms of struggle, with the cooperation of local masses.

III. Structure of Armed Forces in People's War

Relying on the masses for the people's war, great efforts must be made to organize and arm the masses, and to mobilize their participation in the war to the greatest extent. Our Party, during the war years with armed struggle at the core, through hard practice, formed a unique system of three methods of armed forces in the people's war. Combining regular armies and mass armed organizations, major corps, and local corps, and armed and non-armed masses. These three combinations not only solved the problem of mutual cooperation in combat and the coordination of front and rear, but also solved the problem of development and strengthening of the people's army and the consolidation and construction of revolutionary bases.

First, the combination of regular army and mass armed organizations.

A regular army refers to the troops included in the formal establishment of the people's army in various historical periods, with a unified command system and uniform. Mass armed forces primarily refer to guerrilla teams, militias, and other armed organizations. Guerrilla teams and militias are irregular armed organizations that strike at the enemy in enemy-occupied areas, in a dispersed, mobile, and raiding manner. They are characterized by compact personnel, simple organization, light equipment, and flexible action. The combination of a regular army and guerrilla teams is determined by the fact that the Chinese revolutionary war is largely a guerrilla war, and is also required to unleash the power of the armed masses in the war.

Mao Zedong believed that for a people's war, there must be a strong army, and at the same time, a wide variety of people's armed organizations must be established, combining the regular army with the mass armed. He pointed out that "this army is powerful also because it has such a massive organization of people's self-defense forces and militia to cooperate with it in combat," "without the cooperation of these mass armed forces, it is impossible to defeat the enemy." This shows that the people's army and the mass armed are like a car's two wheels, indispensable. The people's army is the backbone of the people's war, and the mass armed organizations are its broad basis.

With this understanding, the Chinese Communists have always, on the one hand, made great efforts to create and expand the people's army, and on the other hand, stressed the establishment and development of armed mass organizations during the organization and leadership of the revolutionary war. During the Red Army period, every revolutionary base organized the Red Guards. During the land revolution war, Mao Zedong stressed the development and expansion of mass armed forces and advocated for the militarization of the countryside. He pointed out that the Red Army should help the Red Guards and workers and farmers' rebel squads with weapons, and as much as possible, help the people to arm themselves without weakening the Red Army's fighting strength. Before the first counter-encirclement campaign, under Mao Zedong's deployment, the Red Guards, Young Pioneers, Chastising Squads, and Red Army Reserve Teams were widely established in the base areas, and the unified command institutions of the people's armed forces as well as the stretcher, transport, traffic, and other war service organizations were established. After the victory of the first counter-encirclement campaign, to prepare for the enemy's another encirclement, Mao Zedong not only corrected the erroneous practice of the then left-wing leaders to "concentrate all guns in the Red Army," restored the local troops but also vigorously expanded the mass armed forces.



Red guerrilla forces were established in the white area, and red guard camps (companies), independent camps, etc., were established in counties and districts along the border. Detailed discussions and regulations were made on the mission, organization, training, and tactics of these armed forces, which further improved their military and political quality, thus strongly cooperating with the Red Army to crush the enemy's subsequent several "sieges". Therefore, Mao Zedong pointed out: People's guerrilla warfare and the main Red Army complement each other like left and right hands. "Without the people's guerrilla warfare, the main Red Army is like a one-armed general. In terms of the people's conditions in the base area, specifically, especially for combat, this means the people who are armed. The enemy regards it as a fear, mainly on this point." During the Anti-Japanese War, all young people who met the conditions in each anti-Japanese base joined the mass armed organization voluntarily and without leaving their posts. By the later stages of the Anti-Japanese War, the militia in the liberated areas had grown to 2.2 million people, and the People's Self-Defense Army had grown to nearly 10 million people. By the time of the Liberation War, the militia organizations in the liberated areas had grown to 5.5 million. Zhu De, in discussing the huge role of mass armament in people's war, pointed out: The huge militia force in the liberated area is unprecedented in the history of our army. We have learned to organize the militia, which is of great importance. Once the militia is organized, it either works with the regular army or fights independently. The production movement of the people in the liberated areas, the defense of the militia has contributed greatly, many enemy bases behind the enemy have been recovered, the militia's encirclement has played a great role. At the same time, the People's Self-Defense Militia also generally undertakes production tasks, which combines fighting with production, force with labour, and if such tasks are implemented, many old forms in the countryside have been transformed.

Second, the combination of main forces and local forces.
The people's army, in accordance with the needs of the struggle, divides itself into the main force and the local force. Mao Zedong pointed out that this division is also a factor in the strength of the people's army.
The main force has high centralization and strong organizational discipline, and has good weapons and equipment. It is not restricted by a fixed area, and can carry out strategic tasks across regions at any time according to the needs of the national strategy, conduct large-scale campaigns and even strategic decisive battles with the cooperation of local forces and militias, and annihilate large enemy groups. The local forces are units operating within a certain range in the country. It cooperates with the militia to defend the local area and strike at local enemies. The local army is an important link between the main force and mass armed organizations, and is an important arm for the development of our army, the strengthening of people's strength, and the implementation of people's war. In combat, it can undertake important tasks with the main force and play a pillar role in the local people's struggle against the enemy. In terms of connecting with the masses, the majority of the soldiers are locally born and raised, familiar with the local geographical environment and folk customs, conducive to merging with the local masses, conducive to taking root among the people, so they can more effectively mobilize and organize the masses to participate in and support the people's war. In terms of expanding the army, it is more convenient to locally organize and recruit militia and masses to join the army and participate in the war. When necessary, it can be transformed into the main force.
The tasks borne by the main and local forces are each emphasized, but their combat objectives are the same. Only by closely combining the two can we strike the enemy more effectively.



Mao Zedong has always attached great importance to the construction and combination of the main force corps and the local force corps. He pointed out: "The reason why this army is powerful is because it divides itself into the main force corps and the local force corps. The former can execute super-local combat missions at any time, and the duties of the latter are fixed in coordination with the militia, self-defence forces defending the local area and attacking the local enemy. This division has won the sincere support of the people. Without this correct division, for example, if only the role of the main force corps is paid attention to and the role of the local force corps is neglected, then under the conditions of the Chinese liberation areas, it would be impossible to defeat the enemy." During the period of the Agrarian Revolutionary War, some people only valued the development of the red army's main force corps and did not value the building of local armed forces. Mao Zedong criticised this erroneous thinking. He first affirmed the importance of building the main force corps of the red army, pointing out that "if there are only local red guards and no formal red army, then they can only deal with door-to-door gangs and cannot deal with the formal white army. Therefore, even if there are good workers and peasants, if there is no formal armed force of considerable strength, it is absolutely impossible to create a situation of separatism, let alone a long-term and increasingly developing separatist situation." At the same time, Mao Zedong attaches great importance to the construction of local armed forces, and clearly stipulated that assisting the development of local armed forces is one of the major tasks of the Red Army. Mao Zedong believed that with the combined cooperation of the Red Army and local armed forces, it could better strike at the enemy and achieve victory. When summing up the experience of the Jinggangshan struggle, he said: "After more than a year, we have created local armed forces with rich combat experience, which is very rare; this local armed force, plus the strength of the Fourth Army of the Red Army, is invincible to any enemy." During the Anti-Japanese War, Mao Zedong further expounded on this view, requiring the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army to immediately help the local people organise local troops and local corps led by local cadre whenever they arrived at a place. Then, it can produce main forces and main corps led by local people. In terms of the construction of local corps, in order to adapt to the needs of the struggle against the enemy, he also required the organisation of well-trained armed work teams, which are relatively healthy in military, political, and civil work, to go deep into the enemy's rear and strike at the enemy, mobilise the people's anti-Japanese struggle, and effectively cooperate with the front-line combat of all anti-Japanese bases. In order to strengthen the local armed forces, during the Anti-Japanese War, the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army even adopted the method of localisation of the main force units in some areas. During the most difficult period of the Anti-Japanese War, the Eighth Route Army and the New Fourth Army, in accordance with the spirit of the instructions of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, streamlined the main force and let at least one-third of the main force down to various military divisions, independent regiments, and guerrilla generals. In such a way, the military and political quality of the local army was improved and the construction of the base area was consolidated. In the later stages of the Anti-Japanese War, some local forces were assembled under certain conditions and transformed into the main force corps to complete large-scale regular combat missions. During the Liberation War, the method of timely upgrading of local troops was adopted, which quickly expanded the main force corps of the People's Liberation Army to one million people, creating important conditions for quickly winning the war.

Thirdly, the combination of armed masses and unarmed masses.
To bring out the power of the people's war, it is necessary to arm the masses and create conditions for direct participation of the people in the war. However, it is not enough to have only armed masses because they cannot be the whole or even the majority of the people. Most people are not armed, and it is equally important to be able to organize their power indirectly into the war. Only by combining armed and unarmed masses can we truly form a people's war in which everyone participates. Therefore, the combination of armed masses and unarmed masses refers to the overall combination of the people's war.


The establishment of mass armed organizations and non-armed mass groups, involving all the people in organizations associated with the cause of people's war, is the key link to closely combine the two. That is to say, on the one hand, we must establish mass armaments such as militias and self-defense teams, and at the same time widely establish mass groups such as trade unions, farmer's associations, student unions, women's associations, and children's groups, mobilizing all non-armed masses to show their strength under the leadership of the party and the revolutionary government for the victory of people's war. 

The combination of armed and non-armed masses is largely demonstrated through the combination of armed and non-armed struggles. Armed masses have certain military qualities, control weapons, and can fully bring into play the role of weapons. Therefore, they are the basic force of the people's war. The role of unarmed masses in supporting the front line and long-term revolutionary warfare cannot be ignored. They are an indispensable force in the revolutionary war. First, non-armed masses can "enthusiastically undertake various tasks to support the army", that is, the work of supporting the front line usually mentioned. They support the regular army by mobilizing people to join the army, transporting food for the army, providing favorable treatment to soldiers' families, and helping the army solve material difficulties, etc. They also support the militias and guerrilla forces, for instance, mobilizing the masses to participate in these forces, assisting them in launching attacks, reconnaissance, eliminating spies, guarding, transporting and protecting the injured, etc., all of which belong to the direct assistance to the military operations. During the three major battles of the Liberation War, under the slogan "Fully support the frontline, everything for victory", more than five million civilian workers were recruited nationwide, and the ratio of our army to civilians reached one soldier per civilian, one soldier per two civilians, or even one soldier per three civilians. This true people's war is rare in world war history. Besides, non-armed masses can also "enthusiastically engage in political, economic, cultural, and health construction works", which refers to various construction works in base areas. Without the mass construction in politics, economy, culture, education, and health in the base areas, there would be no basis for the people's war.

In the people's war, on the one hand, the army supports various struggles of the people through operations, and on the other hand, the people cooperate with the army in various struggles (political, economic, cultural, traffic, and military). Without this cooperation, victory in the revolutionary war cannot be achieved. It should be emphasized here that mobilizing the masses to join the war is not only an organizational and military issue but also requires corresponding political and economic policies to ensure that the people can control politics and gain actual economic benefits. Zhu De, in his "Discussion on the Battlefield in the Liberated Area", pointed out when implementing the above two correct policies in the liberated areas: "Military is related to politics and economy. The basic content of people's war is mass war, and all the above political and economic things are needed to carry out this kind of mass war. "

In summary, the armed force system of the people's war is an important part of the people's war ideology. It not only provides a solid foundation for the people's army to replenish and ensure the quality of soldiers, but also allows the main force to receive strong support from various forms of armament in the battle, forming the ever-reaching net of the people's war. The reason why our army is powerful is that the three-in-one armed force system is a very important factor.



Section 5: The Strategy and Tactics of People's War
I. The Strategic Thinking of Active Defense 
The strategy and tactics of the People's War of the Communist Party of China were born and developed in the practice of the Chinese Revolutionary War. For a long period of the Chinese Revolutionary War, we were in a weaker position facing a stronger enemy. Whether the enemy was the reactionary faction of the Kuomintang or the Imperial Japan or U.S imperialism, their military power and economic power far surpassed ours. However, we held an absolute advantage in terms of politics. Under the leadership of the Communist Party, our war was a progressive and just revolutionary war, while the enemy's war was regressive, unjust, and reactionary. Our soldiers were widely supported by the people and were in high spirits. The basic starting point of the party's strategic and tactical thinking is to fully exert subjectivity, guide the war in a profitable and harmless way based on the material conditions, and aim to defeat a superiorly-equipped enemy with inferior equipment. Starting from this basic idea, a series of military strategies and tactics were formed by our army. 

The Party advocates active defense and opposes passive defense, implements protracted defensive warfare in the strategy, and quick offensive warfare in battles and campaigns. This is the policy of active defense proposed by the party according to the practice of the Chinese Revolutionary War. 

What is active defense, and what is passive defense? Mao Zedong pointed out: "Active defense, also known as offensive defense, is also called decisive defense. Passive defense, also known as pure defense, is actually a false defense. Only active defense is the real defense, which is the defense for counterattack and offense." He believed that active defense is a mutual application of defense and offense in combat, preserve strength through defense, waiting for the opportunity to break the enemy. It is a means to assist the offense or prepare for the transition to offense; whereas passive defense is not for counterattack and offense, in terms of combat form, it only adopts pure defense rather than offensive means.

The strategic thinking of active defense is specifically manifested in protracted defensive warfare in strategic terms and quick offensive warfare in battles and campaigns. Inner and outer lines refer to the scope of the front; protracted and quick refer to the time of combat; defense and offense refer to the form of war. Strategically, on the whole, given the situation of the strong enemy and weak us, our army is forced to carry out long-term defensive warfare on the inner line, in a passive and disadvantageous position. Mao Zedong believed that in order to seize the initiative of the war, to annihilate the enemy's forces, in battles and campaigns, in local circumstances, our army must reverse the situation, and carry out a quick offensive warfare on the outer line. Because only an attack can annihilate a large amount of enemy forces and gradually change the balance of power between the enemy and us. Being quick enables our army to avoid enemy reinforcements and avoid being encircled by the enemy; Being in the outer line allows us to surround the enemy from all directions, achieving the aim to annihilate the defending enemy. In short, only by carrying out quick offensive warfare on the outer line in battles and campaigns can our army shift from strategically passive to actively aggressive in actual combat, gradually annihilating the enemy's forces while preserving ours, and crushing the enemy's repeated "sieges" against our army. How can our army transition from long-lasting defensive warfare on the strategic inner line to quick offensive warfare on the outer line? The key is to adopt the strategy of "Luring the enemy in deep". This is a necessary step taken to preserve strength and wait for the opportunity to break the enemy under the situation of a strong enemy and a weak us.



The necessity and benefits of doing this are: Firstly, "luring the enemy deeper" can enable our army to avoid unfavorable decisive battles with the enemy, and to wait until the situation is favorable before engaging in a decisive battle with the enemy. Secondly, "luring the enemy deeper" allows our army to shrink and concentrate its forces, transforming the strategic weakness of the enemy into our strength in battle, thereby making rapid decisive attacks possible. Thirdly, "luring the enemy deeper" leads the enemy deep into our natural strongholds, like a blind man riding a blind horse, struggling to advance. As a result, the fat are drained to thin, the thin to death, greatly reducing their advantage, while our army is free to move around it like a fish in water, becoming the dominant force strategically and able to seek favorable opportunities for swift attacks. 

These proactive defense strategies derive from the practical experience of the Chinese revolution. During the period of the Land Revolution War, the small Red Army was always faced with powerful attacks from the enemy. Our main task then was to figure out how to breach the enemy's blockade. Hence, the main task of active defense was to conserve power, wait for the right moment to break the enemy line, and to disrupt each of the enemy's blockade attempts, in order to survive and ultimately triumph. 

The basic principles of guerrilla warfare, "retreat when the enemy advances, harass when the enemy camps, attack when the enemy is weary, and pursue when the enemy retreats," also known as the "sixteen-character formula," is the original form of proactive defense strategy. 

These principles were concretized in November 1930, just before the first counter-blockade operation in the Central Soviet Area, with the proposal of the strategy of "luring the enemy deeper." During the Long March, after the convergence of the First and Fourth Red Armies in 1935, the strategic guideline of "concentrating the main force to advance northward, annihilating the enemy in large numbers in mobile warfare, and gaining the southern part of Gansu first to create a base in the Shaanxi-Sichuan-Gansu-Soviet Area" was established. 

During the Anti-Japanese War, Mao Zedong profoundly elucidated the temporal characteristics of the Sino-Japanese War, analyzed the fundamental factors of the contradictions between the two sides and revealed the basic law that the Anti-Japanese War was a protracted one, with the final victory belonging to China. Mao envisioned that the Anti-Japanese War would go through three phases: strategic defense, strategic stalemate, and strategic counter-offensive. 

The general strategic guideline of the Anti-Japanese War should be a protracted war. In the first and second phases, the specific strategic guideline is to carry out persistent defensive battles strategically and swift offensive battles tactically; the third phase should be a strategic counter-offensive. Mao pointed out that, when our army is scattered among the enemy in an intricate web and various encirclements, fighting multiple enemy attacks, the main task of active defense is to systematically break up the enemy's encirclement and "clean-up" operations, strengthening military force continually while promoting the expansion and development of our strongholds, thus accumulating strength for a strategic counteroffensive. 

In the early stages of the Liberation War, when the enemy was strong and we were weak, and when the enemy was on strategic offensive while we were on strategic defense, the main task of proactive defense was to avoid the enemy’s vital force, undergo mobile warfare, with the main goal to annihilate as many enemy troops as possible. Mao pointed out that we are capable of defeating Chiang Kai-shek, and the whole party should be fully confident in this. Generally speaking, our method of defeating Chiang Kai-shek lies in mobile warfare. Therefore, the temporary abandonment of certain areas and cities is not only inevitable but necessary. Temporarily giving up certain places and cities is for the purpose of annihilating a large amount of enemy forces, altering the enemy's advantage, and achieving final victory.


He clearly proposed the strategic policy of "Annihilating the enemy's vital forces as the main objective, not taking or keeping territory as the main objective," and put forward the principle and method of operation of "Concentrating superior forces to annihilate the enemy one by one." After the People's Liberation Army gradually gained the strategic initiative and the strategic strength reached a relative balance with the enemy, he proposed to timely turn strategic defense into strategic counterattacks and strategic attacks, and put forward the famous "Ten Military Principles" centered on annihilation warfare. When the conditions for a strategic decisive battle matured, Mao Zedong correctly chose the timing of the decisive battle, determined the direction of the decisive battle, formulated the operational policy of the three major battles of Liaoshen, Huaihai, and Pingjin, and combined large-scale mobile warfare and large-scale positional warfare to annihilate a large number of enemies. In strategic pursuit, he also put forward the principle of operation of implementing large-scale encirclement and circuitous, and the overall strategic guideline of active defense was comprehensively used and developed. In summary, these specific strategic policies and principles of operation proposed by Mao Zedong in various revolutionary wars are the specific implementation and reflection of the overall strategic guideline of active defense in different periods or stages of war. It can be seen that how to implement the overall strategic guideline of active defense does not have a fixed mode, but is constantly developing with the changes in the war situation.

II. Creative use and development of forms of warfare

"The essence of war is the purpose of war, to preserve oneself and annihilate the enemy. However, the forms of war to achieve this goal are mobile warfare, positional warfare, and guerrilla warfare." Adapting to the development and changes of the war situation, based on the growing and declining forces of the enemy and us, and the evolution of the war situation, it is necessary to timely carry out the military strategic transformation centered on changing the main form of operation under the overall goal of preserving oneself and annihilating the enemy. Establishing strategic guidelines that conform to objective reality, selecting appropriate methods of operation, flexibly using various forms of operation, and integrating them closely with each other are important manifestations of Mao Zedong's superb war command art. 

Mobile warfare, positional warfare, and guerrilla warfare, these three forms of warfare, the first two belong to regular warfare, and the latter is irregular warfare. Mobile warfare is the form of offensive operation in which regular troops fight on long battle lines and large battle zones. Positional warfare is defensive operations on fortified positions or field positions, as well as offensive operations against enemies defending fortified positions or field positions. Guerrilla warfare is a dispersed and mobile form of operation, and it is also a form of mass armed struggle. The three have their own characteristics and functions. The characteristic of mobile warfare is to concentrate the superior forces of regular troops, campaigns, and battles. It is offensive and mobile, and plays a main role in annihilating the enemy's vital force, changing the war situation, and finally resolving the fate of the war. The characteristics of positional warfare are that it has ample preparation time, perfect organization work, and long-lasting operations, which play an important role in resisting powerful enemy invasions and attacking enemies in fortified areas. The characteristics of guerrilla warfare are more initiative, flexibility, offensive, quick decision-making, and mobility than mobile warfare, which play a crucial role in cooperating with regular operations and the survival and development of weak forces. 

In the practice of leading China's revolutionary war, the Party conducted in-depth research on the issue of the close integration of the three forms of warfare: guerrilla warfare, mobile warfare, and positional warfare, developed theories about the issue of forms of warfare, and creatively and flexibly used these three forms of warfare. In the long-term practice of the People's Army in China's revolutionary war for more than 20 years, different forms of operation were flexibly used at different historical periods according to different historical conditions and war situations.



In the first three years of the Land Revolution War and during the entire Anti-Japanese War period, guerrilla warfare was the main form of combat; in the later years of the Land Revolution War and during the entire Liberation War period, mobile warfare became the main form of combat; positional warfare became an important form of combat in the later stages of the Liberation War, and the main form of combat in the later stages of the Korean War. According to the development and changes of war situation, the main form of combat was timely switched and the three forms of combat were closely combined to complement each other, and applied flexibly, which gave the powerful force of the people's war the most effective play in war practice. Mao Zedong pointed out as early as in 1938 that "someone says that we only advocate guerrilla warfare, which is nonsense. We have always advocated the combination of mobile warfare, positional warfare, and guerrilla warfare." "According to the experience of fighting for the past seven months, in military terms, if we can use mobile warfare, positional warfare, and guerrilla warfare in a coordinated manner, we can put the enemy army in a very difficult position." During the period when guerrilla warfare was the main form of combat, the People's Army did not reject regular warfare at all. The guiding principle formulated by Mao Zedong for the Eighth Route Army in the Anti-Japanese War was "guerrilla warfare as the basis, but do not slacken the mobile warfare under favorable conditions". In battlefield combat, there is positional warfare in mobile warfare, and mobile warfare in positional warfare. As for the transformation of mobile warfare into positional warfare, or positional warfare into mobile warfare, it is a common occurrence. In the Chinese revolutionary war, our army flexibly applied various forms of combat and organically combined them to create a miracle in the history of human warfare.

III. Formation of combat methods with Chinese revolutionary characteristics

The main goal of our army's combat is to annihilate the enemy's live forces. Concentrating superior forces to annihilate the enemy one by one is our main method of combat. The effect of this tactic is: to annihilate all, and to make a quick decision. Therefore, it is also the basic principle of all our combat principles. The concentration of superior forces and the annihilation of the enemy one by one are dialectically unified. Only by concentrating the superior forces can we achieve the goal of annihilating the enemy one by one; only by annihilating the enemy one by one can we form and maintain the advantage of troops better.

The Chinese revolutionary war was carried out under the condition that the enemy was strong and we were weak, and the enemy was large and we were small, and we were also in a defensive position in the strategic interior for a long period. Therefore, how to concentrate superior forces became more difficult and important. For this reason, starting from the Jiangxi struggle, Mao Zedong has always emphasized concentrating forces and made profound and comprehensive discussions on this. In 1928, he proposed: "Our experience is that almost every time we divide our troops, we fail, but when we concentrate our forces to fight an enemy that is smaller than us, equal to us, or slightly larger than us, we often win." In 1936, when he summed up our army's ten years of land revolution war experience, he made a special topic discussion on the issue of concentrating forces, clearly pointing out: "The basic way to achieve victory in strategic defense is to concentrate forces." Mao Zedong here mainly refers to our army, which is strategically weaker, only when we are good at concentrating superior forces in campaigns and battles, can we change the comparison of enemy and we in the local area and make me change from weak to strong; and also change from strategic defense to campaign and battle offense; at the same time also change from strategic interior line to campaign and battle exterior line; thus gaining local superiority and initiative, one by one annihilating the enemy. After winning many victories, the overall situation has also turned to our advantage and initiative. This is: "With less to defeat more, with disadvantage to defeat advantage and win. All start with our own local advantage and initiative, aim at the enemy's local disadvantage and passivity, win one battle, then defeat the rest one by one, the overall situation has turned to our advantage and initiative." During the Liberation War, Mao Zedong further elaborated on the idea of concentrating superior forces and drafted the combat instructions for the Central Military Commission-"Concentrate superior forces and annihilate the enemy one by one", pointing out "This is the main method to defeat Chiang Kai-shek's attack.


"Implementing this method will lead to victory. Violating this method will lead to failure." He further emphasized in his famous "Ten Military Principles": "Concentration of absolute superiority in forces in each battle (two times, three times, four times, sometimes even five times or six times the enemy's forces), encapsulating the enemy from all sides, striving to annihilate them completely, and leaving no escape." He pointed out profoundly, our army’s fight "aims mainly at annihilating enemy's living forces, and not principally at preserving or seizing cities and territories." Because only by annihilating the enemy's living forces can we finally preserve and seize cities and territories. Under the situation where the enemy is strong and we are weak, only in this way can we avoid disadvantageous decisive battles with the enemy and engage in beneficial decisive battles. "The temporary abandonment of some places and cities is not only inevitable but also necessary. Temporarily giving up some places and cities is for the ultimate victory, otherwise, the ultimate victory cannot be achieved." Mao Zedong pointed out: "For people, injuring ten fingers is not as good as chopping off one, and for the enemy, defeating ten of their divisions is not as good as annihilating one." Because when you annihilate the enemies in their established formations, the enemy has difficulty in replenishing, and for every one you annihilate, one less remains. Moreover, such annihilation wars will give the enemy a major psychological blow, discouraging their morale and shaking their military spirit. For us, it can greatly boost the morale of our army and people, and it can replenish our army in terms of manpower, equipment, and supplies. Defeat and exhaustion cannot achieve the aforementioned goals. Of course, this does not deny the significance of defeat and exhaustion under certain conditions. Mao Zedong pointed out: "Generally speaking, moving warfare performs annihilation tasks, trench warfare performs exhaustion tasks, and guerrilla warfare performs both exhaustion and annihilation tasks."

How exactly should we concentrate our forces? How many forces should be concentrated to form an advantage against the enemy? Based on our army's combat experience, the main points are as follows: First, concentrate the main force on the main direction of the battle, try to save forces on the secondary direction, and oppose military egalitarianism. The People's Army has long been in a besieged environment, facing strong and numerous enemies. It must concentrate its main force on the main direction of the battle, and it must not attack in all directions or divide its forces into mouths. Mao Zedong said: "Under conditions where there are strong enemy forces, no matter how many troops there are, there should only be one main use direction at a time, and there should not be two." The so-called concentration of superior forces is to concentrate superior forces on the main direction of the battle at the decisive moment. And on the secondary direction, only a part of the force is contained. Only in this way can a fist be formed, an advantage be created, and victory be ensured. Liu Bocheng pointed out: "For each offensive battle, the main direction of attack must be determined, and the main force must be assembled to strive for victory in the decisive battle. But at the same time, for the secondary direction, another part must contain the enemy, attract their attention and follow-up echelons, thereby ensuring the success of our main force's assault. In other words, we can use one person to twist and fight three enemies in the secondary direction, so that we can withdraw three people in the main direction to beat a single enemy, and strive for overall victory. The party, based on the lessons learned from the People's Army's years of warfare, emphasized during the Liberation War that from campaign deployment to tactical deployment, the principle of concentrating forces to annihilate the enemy one by one must be implemented, and military egalitarianism must be opposed. Mao Zedong pointed out: In terms of campaign deployment, when the enemy uses many brigades (or regiments) to advance in several routes, our army must concentrate absolute superiority in forces, at the right time, first surround and annihilate a brigade (or Regiment) of the enemy's army, with a small number of troops to contain the remaining brigades (or regiments) of the enemy, so that they cannot quickly reinforce the brigade (or regiment) that is being attacked by our army, so that our army can first annihilate this brigade (or regiment), and then, depending up on the situation after the victory, annihilate one to several brigades of the enemy's army, or to retreat and prepare for the next battle. Absolutely do not underestimate the enemy, and therefore evenly divide the troops to deal with the enemy on all sides, so as to be unable to annihilate any side and put oneself in a passive position.



Similarly, in terms of tactical deployment, when our army has already gathered absolute superior forces to surround one of the enemy's routes (a brigade or a battalion), the troops (or units) that our army is responsible for attacking should not attempt to annihilate the surrounded enemy all at once, which would result in evenly distributing forces, attacking everywhere and gaining no significant ground, prolonging time and being ineffective. Instead, our army should concentrate superior forces to choose and fiercely attack one weaker point (not two) from among the enemy's positions, strive for victory, and swiftly expand the result after succeeding, annihilating the enemy one after another.

Secondly, attack the weaker enemy first and appropriately determine the degree of force concentration according to the target of annihilation. Mao Zedong, when discussing about the deployment of concentrating forces to annihilate the enemy one by one, required that the target chosen first in a campaign should "be the weaker among the enemy brigades, or those with less assistance, or those whose geographic location and public sentiment are most advantageous to us and disadvantageous to the enemy". In tactics, it should be to "choose weaker point from among the enemy’s positions (not two)" \Thus, the People's Army is in a stronger position by having more troops confronting the weaker enemy. "First pick up the weak ones to hit", then it is easy to form an advantage, and after defeating the weak enemy, the strong ones also become weak.

In the Chinese revolutionary war, the party always emphasized the implementation of the tactical idea of "first choosing the weak ones to hit" closely related to the degree of concentration of forces. The basic requirement of concentrating superior forces is to be able to "surround the enemy on all sides, strive to annihilate all of them, and not let anyone slip through". Being able to meet this requirement constitutes an advantage. Mao Zedong said: "The concentration of forces we advocate is based on the principle of ensuring absolute or relative superiority in battlefield operations. Against a strong enemy, or in battles of great importance, we should face them with absolutely superior forces”, “against a weak enemy or in battles of less importance, it would be enough to face them with relatively superior forces". This points out that the degree of force concentration should be confident in annihilating the enemy. Among this, you should consider not only forces but also firepower; not only quantity but also quality; both material and psychological factors should be calculated. Besides, there are conditions such as time and place. Only comprehensive consideration would not exaggerate the advantage of one aspect into an overall advantage, so as to achieve the purpose of annihilating the enemy. For example, when fighting a strong enemy, the degree of force concentration should be higher, and when fighting a weak enemy, it could be lower; if our attacking force is weaker, the degree of concentration should be higher;

Thirdly, adopt the strategy of encirclement. The purpose of concentrating forces is to fight annihilation battles, thus, Mao Zedong pointed out: "Annihilation battles and the concentration of superior forces and the strategy of envelopment, are one and the same thing. Without the latter, there would not be the former." Without superior forces, it is difficult to wage annihilation battles. Without envelopment and flanking maneuvers, even an absolutely superior force would still not result in successful annihilation battles. Encirclement and flanking are fundamental principles of annihilation deployment which can make the enemy become completely isolated and unable to escape. Of course, depending on the actual situation of combat, sometimes adopting a three-sided encirclement or two-sided attacks is also permissible. In terms of tactical methods, it is required to adopt actions like outflanking, infiltrating, dividing, and interpenetrating, in order to divide and annihilate the enemy separately.




The application of the principle of annihilating the enemy by concentrating superior forces involves many aspects, such as actively creating and seizing opportunities, meticulously organizing preparations, flexibly applying offensive styles, and the tenacious fighting spirit of the troops. All of these play a significant role in the application of this principle, and should not be neglected at any cost.
IV. Thoughts on Strategic Offense
Strategic offense is one of the basic forms of warfare, which is a full-scale offensive against a strategic defensive enemy. The basic tasks of a strategic offense are to annihilate a large number of enemy troops, occupy strategic areas within enemy territory, and achieve victory in the war. The strategic decisive battle is the climax of the strategic offense, the basic means of implementing the fundamental transformation of war forces, and the operation in which both sides use their main forces to determine the outcome of the war. The strategic offense of the Chinese revolutionary war developed from strategic defense and is usually connected with the strategic counterattack. During the early stage of the Agrarian Revolutionary War and the later stage of the Liberation War, our army went through two strategic offensives that differed in scale and form. One was the strategic offensive implemented by the Red Army towards the peripheries after breaking down the enemy's "surround and annihilate" strategy during the time of the Agrarian Revolutionary War when the enemy was stronger and we were weaker. The purpose was mainly to establish and expand revolutionary bases. This strategic offensive was smaller in scale, limited in purpose, regional in nature, and was conducted repeatedly. The other was the nationwide strategic offensive carried out during the Liberation War which was held when the war situation underwent fundamental changes. Its purpose was to annihilate the enemy's heavy troop groups, overthrow the reactionary rule of imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat-capitalism, and liberate the whole of China. When our army switched to the strategic offense, Mao Zedong once said that the revolutionary war of the Chinese people has now reached a turning point. This is the turning point in history where the People's Liberation Army has repelled the offensive of Chiang Kai-shek's reactionary army, backed by the United States, and carried out its offensive, marking the turning point where the rule of imperialism in China has declined and eliminated for over a hundred years.

Looking at the entire conceptual framework, the thinking on strategic offense includes three parts: strategic offense, strategic decisive battle, and strategic pursuit. Regarding the strategic offense, it is usually implemented according to the general laws of war, i.e., when the offensive side becomes disadvantaged and the defensive side becomes advantaged or when the defensive side completely crushes the attack of the other side, which is the turning point into strategic defense. However, the strategic offensive in our army during the period of the Liberation War breaks the normally seen and thought patterns. The strategic offensive was not launched when the comparative strength of the enemy and our troops was roughly balanced or when all of the enemy's offensives were crushed and turned into strategic defense. It is initiated when the enemy still has a great numerical advantage and is still implementing a major offensive, leaving part of the forces to continue defensive measures, while the main force switches to offensive. The main direction of the strategic offensive is not directed toward the main group of the enemy's major offensive, but toward its strategically empty depth and central regions of enemy ruling forces; it is not a typical front-on offensive but a method of launching a long-range attack directly into the enemy's depth.

In the first year of the Liberation War, our army implemented a strategy of inner line operations and achieved great victories in annihilating a large number of enemy regular troops and gained initiative on several battlefields, which significantly altered the war situation in favor of the people. Nonetheless, in this process, we paid a price in casualties and lost large areas of land occupied. At that time, the Kuomintang controlled most of the country's area and population and received full support from American imperialism. Under such circumstances, changing the balance of advantages and disadvantages between the enemy and us by relying solely on the manpower and materials of the liberated areas to annihilate the enemies in the inner line would be extremely difficult.


The strategy adopted by the Kuomintang was precisely to continue to bring the war to the liberated areas, further damaging and consuming the human and material resources of the liberated areas, preventing a long-lasting counter-revolutionary strategy. The CPC central committee judged the situation and based on the victory of the year, determined that the basic task of the following year was to "launch a national counterattack, to hit the main force to the front line, bring the war to the Kuomintang regions, and annihilate the enemy in large numbers on the frontline". To this end, the Central Military Commission formulated the plan of "strike out and strategize the Central Plains", instructing Liu Bocheng and Deng Xiaoping's Jin-Jilu-Yu Field Army of 120,000 people, the first step to attack the enemy in Hebei-Shandong-Henan area and Henan-Anhui-Jiangsu region, the second step to advance towards the Central Plains. According to this overall intention, on the night of June 30, 1947, Liu and Deng's army forced their way across the Yellow River, heralding the beginning of strategic offense. At the same time, the Central Military Commission also made "coordinated operations of the three armies, and restraint of the two wings". Besides Liu and Deng's main force conducting a central breakthrough to Dabie Mountains, the East China Field Army led by Chen Yi and Su Yu was the left rear army moving into Shandong-Henan-Anhui region; the Taiyue Corps led by Chen Mi and others was the right rear army advancing into west Henan. The three powerful forces played a tactical role in the Jiang-Huai-He-Han region, hunting down their enemies. At the same time, our forces in Northwest Shaanxi launched an offensive in Yulin, mobilizing the Kuomintang's Hu Zongnan group to move northward, Shandong's forces launched an offensive in Jiaodong, continuing to lure the enemy in Shandong towards the coast, so as to facilitate the movement of the three armies. Liu and Deng's main force crossed the Longhai Line in early August 1947, reached Dabie Mountains in late August, Chen-Su army moved into southwest Shandong in early August, and Chen's division crossed the Yellow River to enter west Henan in late August. By the end of October, the three main forces had essentially completed their strategic deployment in the Central Plains, pushing the main battlefield of the southern front to the enemy-occupied areas, coordinating with all other battlefields, and reversing the overall war situation. About the strategic final battle, it is the operation where both sides use their main force to determine the outcome of the war. "Only the final battle can resolve who wins and who loses between the two armies". The strategic final battle is the climax of the strategic offensive, "the most intense, complex, changeable, and difficult period of the entire war or campaign; in terms of command, it is the most difficult time". The strategic final battle of the Chinese Revolutionary War began after our army turned to strategic offensive. A year after our army transitioned to a strategic offensive, from September 1948 to January 1949, in just 4 months plus 19 days, through the three major campaigns of Liaoshen, Huaihai, and Pingjin, decisive battles were successfully waged against the enemy. The three major campaigns annihilated a total of 144 divisions (brigades) of regular enemy troops and 29 divisions (equivalent brigades) of irregular troops, with a total of 1.54 million people. The victories in the three major campaigns wiped out Chiang Kai-shek's old base for civil war.
During the strategic final battle, our army accurately seized the timing of the decisive battle. Mao Zedong said that if the time for a final battle has not come, and there is no force for a final battle, one should not recklessly go to battle. Otherwise, victory will definitely not be achieved. On the contrary, if it is too late and the enemy implements a strategic retreat, the decisive battle may not happen. In March 1948, Mao Zedong analyzed in "A Report on the Situation" that of the 250 brigades nominally owned by the enemy in the two lines of north and south, only 180 brigades had not suffered from our army's annihilating attacks, including some new recruits undergoing secondary-line training and some were upgraded or organized from local troops and puppet troops, with weak combat capabilities. The average number of enemy troops per brigade had also dropped from around 8,000 to around 6,500. It's apparent that both the quantity and quality of the enemy's troops were falling sharply. Politically, the Chiang regime was very isolated, and its economy was on the verge of collapse. As for our army, both the quantity and quality had further developed and improved, weapons and equipment had improved, and combat experience had become richer.



In the northeastern region, the Kuomintang army was 550,000 strong, and was besieged in three areas of Changchun, Shenyang, and Jinzhou. Our army, however, reached 700,000 in number, not only surpassing the enemy team, but also possessing a significantly advantageous position. It can be said we had the advantages in both number and strategic placement. The highest command of the Kuomintang army was undecided about whether to retreat or defend in the northeast. All this indicates that the opportunity to initiate a strategic decisive battle in the Northeast battlefront was ripe. If we do not act, the enemy's indecision in withdrawing its troops from the northeast to the interior or the south of the Yangtze River will greatly increase our difficulties in the subsequent battles. The victory in the Liaoshen campaign decimated 470,000 enemy combatants, giving the People's Liberation Army a numerical advantage, and liberating the whole Northeast region, laying the foundation for the liberation of Beijing, Tianjin, and North China. From then, the national battle situation was rapidly declining. The victories in subsequent Huaihai and Pingjin campaigns greatly shortened the original plan of defeating Chiang Kai-shek within five years.

In the strategic decisive battles, our army established different campaign guidelines for different decisive battle targets. The operational guidelines for the Liaoshen campaign were to surround the enemy, seal off the Northeast Kuomintang army, and eliminate them one by one. As soon as the campaign began, Mao Zedong instructed the main force of the Northeast Field Army to focus on controlling the Beining Line, to first take Jinzhou, a strategic point linking the Northeast and North China. It’s the throat of the passage to the interior and "As long as Jinzhou is captured, you will have the initiative, which will be a great victory." The main attack direction of the Liaoshen campaign was directly towards the Beining Line, with the primary focus on the capturing of Jinzhou. Once this strategic intention was realized, the enemy retreat to the mainland from the northeast would be completely sealed off.

The central party proposed different strategic guidelines, for instance, during the Huaihai campaign, where the enemy forces were isolated, the party emphasized the importance of seizing the key points of the enemy's supply lines, effectively cutting off their routes of retreat. Similarly, in the Pingjin Campaign, the party emphasized on surrounding and cutting off key areas, further weakening the enemy's forces.

About strategic pursuits, strategic decisive battles basically determined the fate of the war, but to achieve a complete victory in the war, it is necessary to timely attack the enemy's strategic depth, implement strategic pursuits promptly, and decisively, cleanly, and completely annihilate the enemy, to achieve a complete victory in the war. 

The strategic pursuit in the War of Liberation needed to address two issues: firstly, how to expose the enemy's conspiracy to block the progress of the revolution with deceitful peace talks, and inspire the whole party, the whole army, and all the people to carry on the war of revolution; secondly, what kind of operational policy to adopt, to crossing the Yangtze River, and completely annihilate the remaining military forces of the Kuomintang within the mainland, and not to allow them to stubbornly resist or flee overseas, leaving behind troubles. The former is a political aspect, and the latter is a military aspect, but the two are closely linked. If the former is not done well, it will be detrimental to military victories, and if the latter is not tackled correctly, it will be difficult to end the war swiftly and decisively. The Central Military Commission, led by Mao Zedong, wisely solved these two problems.


After the three major battles of Liaoshen, Huaihai, and Pingjin, the Central Committee of the Party promptly issued the great call to "carry the revolution through to the end" to the entire Party and army, and with both hands of revolution, shattered the enemy's counter-revolutionary forces, timely issued the "order to advance to the whole country", calling for the whole army to bravely advance, to annihilate completely all reactionaries within China who dare to resist, thus liberating all of China. 
Under the command of the Party Central Committee, the People's Army timely disclosed the enemy's false "peace talk" plot, expanded their offensive into the strategic depth of the enemy, carried out the crossing the river campaign, liberated major cities such as Nanjing, Shanghai, Hangzhou, Wuhan, and a large area of Jiangnan, and destroyed the enemy's reactionary ruling center in one fell swoop. After the victory of the crossing the river campaign, Mao Zedong encouraged the entire army to "use their remaining courage to chase the poor enemy, and not to seek fame and become a bully." Subsequently, our army launched an unprecedented strategic chase in the east, south, west, and north. In order to capture the fleeing enemy, Mao Zedong also timely instructed: "Take a great detour, insert yourself behind the enemy, first complete the encirclement, and then fight back." According to this strategy, our army, in a proactive and courageous action, annihilated a large number of enemies in their chase in the south and southwest, thoroughly shattered Chiang Kai-shek's plot to rely on the southwest and plan for a comeback. In the strategic pursuit, some local forces, colluding with Chiang Kai-shek's defeated troops, attempted to take up a favorable position and resist to the end, the army adopted the policy of annihilating them on the spot. The Central Military Commission required the troops to hit hard, divide, surround, and annihilate them one by one. Like our Northwestern Field Army, after annihilating Hu Zongnan's main force, they quickly annihilated local forces such as Ma Bufang and Ma Hongkui, advanced to Xinjiang, and liberated the great Northwest. In the strategic pursuit, I fully exploit the power of political offensive, prompting the enemy to revolt, surrender, or reorganize peacefully, Mao Zedong timely proposed the "three ways" to disarm the enemy, namely the "Tianjin Way", "Beijing Way", and "Suiyuan Way". The "Tianjin Way" is to use combat to deal with the enemy, and relentlessly annihilate all enemies who dare to resist to the end. The "Beijing Way" is to force the enemy to accept a peaceful reorganization under our strong military strike and tight encirclement. The "Suiyuan Way" is to deliberately leave a part of the Kuomintang army intact or largely intact so that our army can concentrate on dealing with the main part of the enemy and then reorganize them at an appropriate time. In my advancement to the southwest and northwest, about 800,000 enemy troops were persuaded to rise up and forced to surrender. This is a great victory of the Party Central Committee's struggle strategy.

The first section: The construction of the party is a great project
I. The construction thought of the Communist Party of China is the inheritance and development of Marxist-Leninist party-building theory
Marx and Engels were the first to propose the theory of establishing a proletarian revolutionary party. Marx pointed out: Only when the working class organizes itself into an independent party opposing all the old parties established by the bourgeoisie can it act as a class. Such party organization by the working class is necessary to ensure the victory of the social revolution and the ultimate goal of this revolution — the elimination of classes. Marx and Engels, in order to guide the revolutionary struggle of the proletariat, established a scientific and complete system of communist thought, and guided the establishment of proletarian revolutionary organizations such as the "Communist League", "First International", and the German Social Democratic Labour Party, initiating a new stage in the revolutionary struggle of the world proletariat and working people, which is their great historical contribution.
However, the era that Marx and Engels were in was a time when the proletariat had already set foot on the historical stage but the revolutionary task of the proletariat was not yet fully mature. After the failure of the revolutions in various Western European countries in 1848, capitalism entered a period of peaceful development.


The Paris Commune uprising in 1871 was the proletariat's first heroic attempt to seize political power. However, the practice of the struggle showed that the objective conditions for seizing political power were not sufficient. The world's first batch of proletarian parties in Europe and America, which were established one after another, become "bankrupt" after various deformities and deteriorations due to the relatively "peaceful" nature of this period that provided nourishment for opportunism. Therefore, at the beginning of the 20th century, history posed the task of creating a new type of proletarian revolutionary party to deal with the matured revolutionary crisis and the leadership of the revolution. It was under these historical conditions that Lenin established a completely new type of proletarian revolutionary party - the Russian Bolshevik Party, and "even created a complete theory on the construction of the proletarian revolutionary party”.

Lenin proposed the task of establishing a new type of proletarian revolutionary party. Lenin pointed out: What we need is a new type of party, a party of another nature. He also said: To transform the old type of party of European parliamentaryism and reformationism, which is merely lightly coated with a layer of revolutionary color, into a truly revolutionary and truly communist new type of party. Lenin emphasized that the party must be new, that is, it must be fundamentally different from the parliamentary and reformist parties of the Second International. 

Although the parties of the Second International were proletarian parties when they were first established, after the death of Engels, they degenerated and became appendages of bourgeois parliamentary groups, thus losing their revolutionary nature and combat effectiveness. They are no longer proletarian revolutionary parties, but reformist parties, old type of parties. Lenin believed that at the beginning of the 20th century it was necessary to establish a new type of proletarian party. This kind of party should be a highly class-conscious, combat-oriented, mass-connected, and disciplined revolutionary party. Only by establishing such a revolutionary party can we meet the needs of history during the era of imperialism, and accomplish the revolutionary task of the proletariat.

Lenin elaborated that the ideological basis of the proletarian revolutionary party must be Marxism and must put principles into practice during construction. When Lenin founded the Bolshevik Party, he wrote works such as "Where to Begin" and "What is to be Done," firmly opposed the opportunism of worker spontaneity, and drafted a line for founding the party, namely establishing an all-Russian political newspaper and advocating Marxism to unify ideological cognition. Lenin said: "We base itself fully on the theory of Marx because for the first time it transformed socialism from utopia into science and laid a solid foundation for this science". 

Lenin clearly stipulated the relationship between the Party and the proletariat and proposed the principle that the ideological unity of the Party must be consolidated by the material unity of the Party's organization. Lenin pointed out that the Party is the advanced detachment of the proletariat, the organized detachment, the highest form of organization of the proletariat. The Party must be composed of the most conscious advanced elements among the proletariat. Party members can only be a minority in the proletariat, never all. The party is organized according to the principle of democratic centralism. Party members must obey unified discipline, maintain party unity, and never allow factional activities. The Party must lead all other organizations of the proletariat. Lenin said: "The proletariat has no other weapon in the struggle for power except organization… The proletariat can and will necessarily become an invincible force because its ideological unity formed on the basis of Marxist principles is consolidated by the material unity of the organization."



The above three points are the main contents of Lenin's party-building theory. They provide the most basic direction for the construction of the proletarian revolutionary party and have universal significance. The Communist Party of China was also founded and developed under the guidance of Lenin's principles of party building.

However, like many universal principles of Marxism-Leninism, the principles of Marxism-Leninism about certain things only reflect the most general rules of development of these things, and they can never encompass all the complexities and diversities of these things in phenomena. Lenin’s party-building thought reflects the most general rules of the development of the proletarian party, but it does not and cannot encompass all the characteristics of the development of the proletariat parties in various countries. Due to the differences in historical conditions in various countries, the establishment and development of the proletarian parties in all countries inevitably have their own characteristics and special laws. Therefore, the theory of party building in Marxism-Leninism is always being enriched and developed with the construction of proletarian parties in various countries. The thoughts and experiences of the Communist Party of China on the construction of the Communist Party of China under the historical conditions of semi-colonial and semi-feudal China are an example of adhering to the universal truth of Marxism-Leninism and the combination, enrichment, and development of the specific practice of the Chinese revolution.

The Communist Party of China was born in the semi-colonial and semi-feudal old China. On one hand, the severity and cruelty of the exploitation and oppression suffered by the Chinese working class are rare in the world, they are the most thorough in revolution and the strongest in combat, providing an excellent class basis for the establishment and development of the party. As Liu Shaoqi said, our party has a clear class consciousness from the moment it was born, and it is leading the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution from the position of the proletariat, combining the universal truth of Marxism-Leninism with the specific practice of the Chinese labor movement and the Chinese revolution. This renewal provides the Chinese revolution with all the excellent styles of the advanced party of the proletariat. But on the other hand, our party has been established in an eastern big country where the economy and culture are backward and the peasants and petty bourgeoisie make up the majority of the population. Our party is not only surrounded by the petty-bourgeoisie from outside the party, but also the majority of the members inside are of petty-bourgeois background. In addition, under the economic conditions in China, even the working masses and party members are easily influenced by petty-bourgeois thoughts. Therefore, petty-bourgeois ideas are often reflected in various ways in our party. This is inevitable and not surprising. For this reason, the contradiction between the thoughts of the proletarian inside the party and various non-proletarian thoughts, especially petty-bourgeois thoughts, has become the main contradiction within the party. The process of building the Communist Party of China is a process of continuously transforming the petty bourgeois elements within the party and overcoming various non-proletarian thoughts with proletarian ideas.

If we say that before the 1930s, such a situation in the construction of the Communist Party of China was not very prominent because the party was mostly active in cities, then this issue became particularly prominent after the party's focus shifted to rural areas.

After the failure of the Great Revolution, the Communists of China, represented by Mao Zedong, began to go deep into the rural areas to explore a revolutionary path suitable for China's national conditions after the failure of armed uprising in various places. On September 9, 1927, Mao Zedong launched the Autumn Harvest Uprising, and then the team went into the Jinggang Mountains. During the construction of the Jinggangshan Revolutionary Base, Mao Zedong explored the revolutionary path of surrounding cities from the countryside and seizing power by armed force. Mao Zedong pointed out that the Communist Party of China needs to take the path of surrounding cities from the countryside and seizing power by armed force.



He believes that 90% of China's economy is agricultural production, and capitalist commodity production only accounts for a minority and is concentrated in large cities. Agricultural production is made up of dispersed small producers, maintaining a strong independence and can be self-sufficient; In politics, the ruling class is strong in the cities, but weak in the countryside. This imbalance in economic and political power allows our party to lead the peasants in armed struggles in the countryside for a long time, establishing revolutionary bases. In the 1930s, Mao Zedong's idea of encircling the cities from the countryside and seizing political power by armed force was basically formed, and the focus of the Party's work had in fact been shifted from the cities to the countryside. With the Jinggangshan revolutionary base as a representative, revolutionary armed forces were established one after another, and the land revolution was fully carried out, opening a new situation.

The shift of the party's work focus to the countryside makes the task of party building even heavier. This is because with the shift of the party's work focus to the countryside, there has been a great change in the organizational composition of the party. As of March 1927, the total number of party members was 57,967, of which 53.8% were workers and 18.7% were peasants. However, during the period of the land revolutionary war in 1928, out of 130,194 party members, 10.9% were workers and 76.6% were peasants. In 1929, the number of worker party members dropped to 7.5%, and in July 1930, it dropped to 5.5%, and by！In September, it dropped to 1.6%. Is our party a peasant party when the peasant component is in the majority? The view of the Comintern at the time was that the cadres of the Chinese party were not from the working class, which resulted in the failure of the great revolution. They only emphasize party members from the working class, believing that non-worker cadres should be replaced by worker cadres in the party's organization, and the Red Army should also include people from the working class. At the time of the Sixth Party Congress, due to the emphasis of the Comintern on worker representation, out of 75 representatives, 41 were workers, and when electing Central Committee members, only worker components were emphasized, and 21 out of 36 Central Committee members were workers. However, most of these elected central committee members had not directly participated in actual revolutionary struggles.

As for how to build a party in a rural environment, the Communist Party of China proposed a different line from that of the Third International. First, the Party recognized the seriousness of the problem. In the course of establishing revolutionary bases, Mao Zedong felt that "the issue of leadership by proletarian ideology is a very important issue. The party in each county on the border is almost entirely composed of peasants. If it is not led by proletarian thinking, its tendency will be erroneous." Secondly, Mao Zedong analyzed the reasons for the emergence of erroneous views such as the purely military point of view, extreme democratization, non-organizational point of view, absolute egalitarianism, subjectivism, individualism, bandit mentality, and the remnants of impulsivism, pointing out that the source of these incorrect thoughts within the Party is naturally that the largest part of the Party's organizational foundation is made up of peasants and other small and medium-sized proprietors; however, the Party leadership failed to wage a consistent and determined struggle against these incorrect ideologies and educate Party members along the correct line, which is another important reason for the existence and development of these incorrect ideologies. Finally, what Mao Zedong emphasized was not the method of organizational elimination, but the method of strengthening ideological education within the Party and raising the Party's theoretical level. Mao Zedong further elaborated on this issue in articles such as "Against Book Worship," "On Practice," "On Contradiction," "The Announcement of 'The Communist'," etc., creating a path for building a vanguard of the proletariat under conditions where peasants account for a majority of the population and the petty bourgeoisie within the Party has a powerful influence.
II. The Party Building Theory of the Communist Party of China is Formed and Developed in Practice
Represented by Mao Zedong, the communists of the Communist Party of China enriched and developed the Marxist-Leninist theory of party building with original theories in the long-term revolutionary struggle and party building. 
The formation and development of the Party-building theory of the Communist Party of China is consistent with the formation and development of Mao Zedong Thought, and it is based on the development of China's revolutionary history and the Party's revolutionary activities at different historical stages.
