It is the correct theory of party building principles and the summary of experiences proven by the construction practice of the Communist Party of China. It is the crystallization of the collective wisdom of the Communist Party of China. From 1920 to 1927, Chinese Communists explored the valuable challenges of how to establish a new type of proletarian party in China. During this period, influenced by the October Revolution in Russia and the May Fourth Movement in China, and with the help of the Communist International led by Lenin, Chinese Communists began to establish the nature of the party, the party's basic program, and organizational principles. The program passed by the First Congress of the Party established the dictatorship of the proletariat as the party’s struggle goal. The Second National Congress clearly proposed the party’s democratic revolution program against imperialism and feudalism. Soon after the party was established, it led vigorous revolutionary struggles, and the vast majority of party members performed very well in the struggle. The party's organization also developed significantly. During this period, our party began to realize the importance of strengthening its own construction. At the Second National Congress of the Party in 1922, it proposed to strengthen the training of party members in ideology, politics, and organization, and pointed out that it must maintain its independence when uniting with the bourgeois democrats. At the First Executive Committee of the Third Session held in November 1923, it proposed to educate party members and the public with a dialectical materialist worldview and a collective life outlook, emphasizing opposition to individualism. This proves that at the beginning of the party, our party paid attention to the transformation of the ideological consciousness of party members. 

Subsequently, almost every time at the Congress or the Executive Committee expansion meeting, corresponding resolutions were made on internal organization and propaganda education issues. In the "Resolution on the Third Revision of the Constitution of the Communist Party of China" passed in June 1927, "Party Building" was clearly discussed in a separate chapter. But during this period, the party was still an immature party. Due to the limited understanding of Marxism-Leninism, insufficient theoretical preparation, the party just established and plunged into mass struggles, understanding little about the realities of the Chinese revolution, and lacking experience in party building; especially there is not yet a conscious understanding of the combination of Marxism-Leninism party building doctrine and the construction practice of the Chinese Communist Party. 

From the "August 7th Conference" in 1927 to the Zunyi Conference in 1935, the Communist Party of China began to explore how to build the party in the Red Army, how to build the party in armed struggles, and how to build the party in rural revolution bases. This created many new experiences and solved many major theoretical and practical problems that Marx, Engels, and Lenin did not encounter or mentioned, and initially formed a party building path with Chinese characteristics. The starting point of this path is: firstly, establishing the principle of emphasizing ideological party building and proposing to overcome all kinds of non-proletarian thoughts with proletarian thoughts. In response to the situation where a large number of peasant revolutionaries rushed into the party, and the serious existence of petite bourgeoisie thoughts within the party, the "Gutian Conference Resolution" (hereinafter referred to as the "Resolution"), it points out that party members must establish the outlook on life of proletarian revolution. It must overcome various non-proletarian thoughts within the party, especially various petite bourgeoisie thoughts, to ensure the ruling position of proletarian thoughts in the party. It must carry out serious criticism and self-criticism and actively conduct correct internal party struggles. This is the basic way to strengthen proletarian thoughts and eliminate all non-proletarian thoughts. The aforementioned principles and methods have initially formed the basic principles of emphasizing ideological party building, laying a foundation for future strengthening of the party's ideological construction.

Secondly, it proposed the scientific concept of the party's organizational line, emphasizing strengthening the construction of party members and grassroots organizations.



The "Resolution" proposes the scientific concept of "the organizational line of the Party" and elaborates on the issue of organizational construction under the guidance of the Party's organizational line. The "Resolution" first proposes to strengthen the grassroots organizations of the Party. Grassroots organizations live and fight among the vast number of soldiers and are the bridge and bond connecting the Party with the masses. Therefore, the "Resolution" reasserts that "each company builds a branch, and each squad builds a group; this is one of the important principles of the Party's organization in the Army." "Building a branch at the company level" is an important measure to strengthen the Party's leadership in the Army and make the branch a bulwark of grassroots organizations.

To improve the combat effectiveness of the Party organization, it is necessary to strengthen the construction of the Party membership. This is the primary concern in organizational construction. Mao Zedong defined the correct path for the development of Party members for the Red Army, emphasizing "the path of Party member development, with fighters as the main target." He also proposed that in the work of developing Party members, strict Party membership qualifications and procedures must be observed, as only in this way can the purity and fighting power of the Party membership be ensured.

The issue of democratic life within the Party is the core content of the Party's organizational construction. Democratic centralism is the fundamental organizational principle of the Communist Party of China, as well as the fundamental norm for doing well in democratic life within the Party. The "Resolution," addressing the trend towards extreme democratization appearing within the Red Army Party, emphasizes that in the life of the Party, it is necessary to insist on democratic life under centralized guidance. Any so-called democracy that strays from the Party's line and policy, away from the Party's leadership, is not true democracy for the proletariat, but extreme democratization of the petty bourgeoisie, which must be opposed.

Thirdly, it put forward the valuable idea of the Party's political construction, emphasizing that the Party's construction must be combined with the construction of the red power. Mao Zedong, in his articles "The Struggle in the Jinggang Mountains" and "Why Can the Red Power Exist?," pointed out that both the strength of the Communist Party's organization and the correctness of its political line are fundamental conditions for the long-term existence of the red power, and also emphasized the need to strengthen the Party's own construction and expand the Party's organization to make the Communist Party truly the strong core of the red power during the process of establishing the red power. This indicates that while the law of building the Party around the political line had not yet been fully developed, its basic ideas had already been formulated.

Fourthly, the scientific concepts and basic ideas of the Party's ideological line and mass line were proposed. Mao Zedong put forward the scientific concept and basic ideas of the ideological line in his fight against "left" dogmatism and in the article "Against Book Worship," and also proposed the scientific concept and basic ideas of the "mass line" in the Gutian Conference Resolution and the articles "Concern for the Masses' Life, Pay Attention to Work Methods" and so on.

In addition, during this period, our Party also created valuable experiences in conducting correct inner-Party struggles and established the principle of the Party's absolute leadership over the Red Army, among others. During this period, the Party focused on solving the problem of how to build the Party in terms of ideology and politics, with the goal of ensuring the vanguard nature of the party, to realize strong party leadership. Although the series of Party building principles proposed at that time were not yet mature and complete, the basic points on how to maintain the vanguard nature of the party in terms of ideology, politics, and organization under the conditions of the rural base areas and armed struggle, and how to realize Party leadership, had been proposed, and began to form an organic theoretical system. This is a result of creatively combining Marxist-Leninist party theory with the construction practice of the Communist Party of China represented by Mao Zedong, and it marked the initial formation of the Party building path with Chinese characteristics during this period. The Zunyi Meeting held in 1935 established Mao Zedong's leadership position in the Red Army and the whole party, providing extremely important political conditions for the further promotion and application of Mao Zedong's party building line across the party, and for its maturation and completion during the Yan'an Rectification Movement.



From the Zunyi Conference in 1935 to the Seventh National Congress of the Party in 1945. This period was an important time when our party transitioned from setbacks to successive victories and rapid development and growth of the Party's organization. It was also a period when the Party's construction path with Chinese characteristics matured. During this stage, led by Mao Zedong, the Party Central Committee proposed the grand task of building a broad, more Bolshevik Marxist party. In the process of realizing this task, Comrade Mao Zedong and others profoundly summarized the experiences and lessons of the Party's construction since its establishment, made many reports on Party building, wrote a large number of treatises on Party building, drafted many important documents, and led the whole Party in carrying out the famous Yan'an Rectification Movement, creating effective methods for Party style construction, and exploring the issue of Party construction in the combination of theory and practice, further developed and perfected the Party building ideas from the Red Army creation period, and gradually formed a complete theoretical system of Mao Zedong's Party construction ideas and the path of Party building.

In the early stage of this period, Mao Zedong wrote "On Practice" and "On Contradiction", two works that heavily critiqued dogmatism, systematically expounded the Party's dialectical materialist ideological line and scientific worldview, and laid the philosophical foundation for the Party's ideological construction. Following this, Mao Zedong discussed the importance of studying Marxism and enhancing theoretical level at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Party. On October 20, 1939, the CPC Central Committee founded the "Communist" magazine in Yan'an. Mao Zedong wrote the preface for the magazine, proposing the "task of building a nationwide, broad, and fully consolidated Bolshevik Chinese Communist Party in terms of thought, politics, and organization", and likening the construction of such a party to a "great project", he also summarized the Party's building experience over the past 18 years. From 1939 to the period before the Yan'an Rectification Movement, Mao Zedong also published works such as "On the Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party", "Absorb a Large Number of Intellectuals", "On Policy", etc. During this period, Liu Shaoqi wrote works such as "On the Cultivation of Communist Party Members", "On Struggle within the Party", "Being a Good Party Member, Building a Good Party"; Chen Yun published articles such as "On Cadre Policy", "How to be a Communist Party Member", "Several Issues on Cadre Team Building"; Zhang Wentian published articles such as "Organizational Work Should be Sinicized", "Briefly Discussing the Relationship between Party and Non-Party Masses", "Advocating Simplicity and Practical Work Style", etc. These publications on Party building further enriched the theory of the "great project", further perfecting the Chinese Communist Party's thoughts on Party building.

At the same time, the preliminary ideas on the Party's political construction also saw further development. The main points on the Party's political construction by Mao Zedong and other Communists during this period were as follows: The Party's construction must be combined with the Party's political line and political strategy, and the Party must formulate a correct political line and policy strategy. It stressed the need to enhance the political awareness of the whole Party in the process of implementing the political line, and develop and strengthen the Party's organization. The Party's construction must also be combined with the united front and armed struggle. The construction of the Party is decisive for the success or failure of the Chinese revolution. The united front and armed struggle are two fundamental weapons for defeating the enemy, and the Party's organization is the brave soldier charging and breaking through the enemy's lines with these two weapons. If the Party's construction is done well, the Party will be better able to grasp and use the united front and armed struggle, these two weapons, correctly lead the Chinese revolution, and lead it towards victory.

While setting about solving the Party's ideological and political lines, Mao Zedong and other Communist party members also effectively addressed a series of organizational construction issues. Mao Zedong, in "The Position of the Chinese Communist Party in the National War", comprehensively and systematically expounded on the Party's organizational line and construction issues, focusing on discussing the "moral and intellectual integrity" standard for the selection of cadres and the "selecting on the basis of their virtue" line for using cadres, emphasizing the need to care for and love cadres, unite cadres fully and correctly, and handle cadres who make mistakes, etc.



The basic principles for correctly conducting a two-front struggle has been proposed. Additionally, systematic discussions on various issues related to the construction of the party's organizations such as democratic centralism have been made in reports and other articles by Mao Zedong and other party members, hence forming a complete system of theories on party organization construction.

After resolving the political-thinking and organization direction of the party, starting from 1942, the Chinese Communist Party launched the famous Yan'an Rectification Movement. Through the rectification movement, the Communist Party systematically summarized and constantly improved the party construction, especially a complete set of theoretical principles and policy guidelines for the construction of the party's style.

We strengthen the party's construction with the aim to realize the correct leadership of the party over the Chinese revolutionary cause. On the principles of party leadership, at the onset of the Anti-Japanese War, Mao Zedong and other party members further expounded on the historical inevitability of realizing party leadership. The basic conditions, principles, paths, and methods were proposed, forming a preliminary theoretical system on party leadership. During the Yan'an Rectification period, Mao Zedong and other party members further discussed how to realize the principles, paths, and methods of party leadership, making the principles of party leadership more complete.

In these ten years, our party has become more mature in thought and politics and more solid in organization. Mao Zedong and others have formed a complete set of theoretical principles on what kind of party should be established, how to build this party from ideological, political, organizational, and style aspects, and how to correctly carry out the struggle between the two lines within the party. Liu Shaoqi made a high summary of our party's theoretical system at the Seventh National Congress of the party, explicitly proposing the scientific concept of "Mao Zedong's Theory of Party Construction" and "Mao Zedong's Line of Party Construction". This indicates that the theoretical system of Mao Zedong's Theory of Party Construction has been fully formed, and the path of party construction with Chinese characteristics has matured.

From the victory in the Anti-Japanese War to the eve of the establishment of New China, the party's organization and membership further expanded, the principles of party's democratic centralism and collective leadership system further improved, and the party's thought on party construction, especially on organizational construction, further developed.

First, from the victory in the Anti-Japanese War to the National Land Conference in July 1947. To adapt to the situation of large-scale war, the party central committee took measures such as cadre mobilization and organizational adjustment in a timely manner. While strengthening the leadership of the party in various regions, a large number of party members were absorbed to strengthen the party's power.

Second, from the National Land Conference to the Second Plenum of the Seventh Central Committee in March 1949. In order to support the strategic counter-offensive and strategic decisive battle of the People's Liberation Army, the party central committee conducted rectification in various liberated areas combined with land reform. It successively made instructions and decisions on enhancing the party's policy concept, strengthening discipline, consolidating the party's democratic centralism and collective leadership system. It promptly corrected the "left-leaning" tendency appeared in land reform and rectification, overcome some lack of organization and discipline among party members, ensured unified central leadership and implementation of various guidelines and policies, and strongly supported the war.

Lastly, from the Second Plenum of the Seventh Central Committee to September 1949. With the revolution about to achieve victory nationwide, the focus of the party's work began to shift from rural areas to urban areas, the party's activities changed from being secretive to open, and the party's position shifted from an oppressed, illegally functioning organization to a ruling party. The party central committee promptly formulated measures to prevent the infringement of bourgeois ideology, prohibit praising individuals, called on the whole party to continue to maintain a modest, cautious, unpretentious, and hard-working style, proposed principles of openly building the party, and prepared for ruling party construction, ideologically and politically.



During this period, due to the rapid expansion of the party's organization and membership, the rapid growth of revolutionary forces, and the war forms of large-scale mobile warfare and positional warfare, it was even more necessary to strengthen the coordination and unified action of the party's organizations at all levels. Therefore, the Party Central Committee emphasized the principles of centralized and unified leadership and collective leadership, consolidated the unity and unity of the party, and provided an important guarantee for winning the national victory. 
Third, the basic characteristics of party building during the New Democratic Revolution
The special conditions and circumstances experienced by the Communist Party of China during the New Democratic Revolution are the basic starting points for the construction and development of the Communist Party. Chinese Communists represented by Mao Zedong, in the process of constantly understanding and mastering these basic features, successfully solved the problem of building a mass, Marxist proletariat party, and created a theory of party building that conforms to the development law of our party. The basic characteristics of the construction of the Communist Party of China during the New Democratic Revolution are manifested in the following aspects:
First, the establishment of the Chinese Communist Party was after the October Revolution, based on the Chinese labor movement, with Lenin's Bolshevik Party as the model, and established according to Marxist-Leninist revolutionary theory and revolutionary style. From the beginning, our party was not influenced by the Second International of the Social Democratic Party in thought and organization. China does not have a period of capitalist "peaceful” development like Europe, which allows the working class to fight in peaceful parliamentary struggles, and there are no worker aristocrats like in Europe. Therefore, our party was a worker's revolutionary party armed with Marxism-Leninism from the beginning, without the reformist tradition of the Social Democratic Party.
Second, the construction and development of the Chinese Communist Party is closely related to the guidance of the Comintern. From July 1922 when our party's second congress announced to join the Comintern, to May 1943 when the Comintern was disbanded, the Chinese Communist Party was a branch under the leadership of the Comintern. In the long-term struggle of the Chinese revolution, on the one hand, the Comintern did play a positive role in helping the construction and development of the Chinese Communist Party. Our party's program and the formulation of the united front policy, the Northern Expedition, the Land Revolution War, the Anti-Japanese War, etc., have all received the support and voice of the Comintern and Stalin. On the other hand, the Comintern and Stalin also made mistakes in guidance and interference, and even almost caused the Chinese Communist Party and the Chinese Revolution to fall into a dilemma. Chen Duxiu's right-leaning errors and Wang Ming's "left" leaning errors are directly related to blindly following the wrong instructions of the Comintern and Stalin's wrong opinions. It should be said that the construction of our party, the advancement and retreat of the party, and the victories and failures are inseparable from the guidance of the Comintern.
Third, within the Chinese Communist Party, the components of the peasants and petty bourgeoisie account for a considerable proportion, which is the social basis for the "left" and right deviations in our party. China's semi-colonial and semi-feudal society is a society with a large middle and small ends, that is, the working class and landlords, bourgeoisie, are the minority, and the vast majority are peasants, urban petty bourgeoisie, and other middle classes. Our party is growing in the revolutionary alliance of Chinese peasants and other petite bourgeoisie. China has not formed a powerful petite bourgeoisie party, so it is inevitable for a large number of revolutionaries from the petite bourgeoisie to join the working-class revolutionary party. But this makes the components of the peasants and petty bourgeoisie in our party account for a considerable proportion. The opposition and struggle between the working-class thought and petty-bourgeois thought has been the most essential contradiction in the party for a long time. Under this circumstance, how to build a proletarian revolutionary party becomes a major issue facing our party.
Fourth, the Communist Party of China is honed in both alliance and struggle with the bourgeoisie. During the New Democratic Revolution, our party has established a revolutionary united front with the bourgeoisie many times. After this united front broke down, we have also had intense armed struggles with the bourgeoisie and its allies.


Generally speaking, during the process of the new democratic revolution, when our party forms a united front with the bourgeoisie, the party is prone to leaning to the right; whereas when our party splits with the bourgeoisie, the party is prone to a "left" inclination. Therefore, correctly handling our party's relationship with the bourgeoisie is another major issue in our party's construction.

Fifth, the Chinese Communist Party was formed through lengthy armed struggles. Armed struggles are the characteristics and advantages of the Chinese new democratic revolution, and they are the main form of China's revolutionary struggle. Our party has conducted lengthy domestic revolutionary wars and wars of national liberation during the democratic revolution. Vast party members and cadres have lived a collective military life for a long time, undergoing severe exercises mentally, organizationally, and in life, and have established intimate relationships with the masses who share life and death. Therefore, the party's construction is closely related to the correct handling of the issue of armed struggle. How to build and develop the party in armed struggles is another important issue in party building.

Sixth, the Chinese Communist Party has grown and strengthened in the long-term construction and struggle of rural revolutionary bases. Since 1927, our party has pioneered the road to surround the cities from the countryside and ultimately take the cities by armed forces. The revolutionary forces, in order to accumulate and exercise their strength, have long penetrated into the countryside and transformed the backward rural areas into advanced solid bases, forming great revolutionary positions in military, political, economic, and cultural aspects, gradually seizing the total victory of the revolution. In rural areas, the party, in addition to focusing on its own construction, must also lead the people to carry out power construction, economic construction, and cultural construction, learning a full set of skills to govern and secure a country peacefully. Therefore, how to build in the rural bases divided by the enemy, persist in guerrilla warfare, the scattered individual economy, a worker class revolutionary party that is armed with Marxism-Leninism theory, strictly disciplines, centralized and unified, is a new subject without precedent in the history of the international communist movement encountered by the Communist Party of China.

Looking at the above, one can see that the Communist Party of China's surrounding historical conditions, social environment, class relations, its experienced revolutionary path, form of struggle all have supreme particularities, which demand the members of the Communist Party of China to exhibit extreme originality, combining Marxist-Leninist party construction principles with the Communist Party of China's practical experience. Mao Zedong's party construction theory was formed and developed in the process of the party leading the people to carry out revolution and construction, and it adapts to these historical demands.

Section 2 Party Ideological Construction
1. Building the party from an ideological perspective is a significant feature of the Communist Party of China
Building the party from an ideological perspective, is the notable feature and central link of the construction theory of the Chinese Communist Party, and it is the outstanding contribution of the CPC people, represented by Mao Zedong, to the doctrine of the Marxist-Leninist party. It has played a decisive role in the establishment, consolidation, and development of the Chinese Communist Party, and in adhering to the party's vanguard nature and leadership status of the working class.
Building the party from an ideological perspective is an important principle of Marxist-Leninist party construction ideology
The founding fathers of the doctrine of the proletariat party, Marx and Engels, from the birth of the party, paid great attention to the important role of revolutionary theory and the ideological construction of the party, advocating the combination of scientific socialist theory with the worker movement, and using this theory to educate the entire party. Marx pointed out in the introduction to "A Critique of Hegel's Philosophy of Law" that “the weapon of criticism certainly cannot replace the criticism of weapons, material force must only be overthrown by material force; but once the masses grasp the theory, it would also become material force." In the "Communist Manifesto" published by Marx and Engels in 1848, they further clarified: "In practice, the communists are the most resolute parts of the political parties in each country, always pushing the movement forward; theoretically, their superiority over the rest of the working class crowds lies in their understanding of the conditions, progress and general results of the working class movement..."


Later, Engels, in summing up the experience of party building, said: "Our party has a great advantage: it has a new scientific worldview as the theoretical foundation." This scientific worldview is the Marxist view of Dialectical Materialism and Historical Materialism, which is the greatest ideological weapon for Communists to understand and transform the world. With the development of the proletarian revolutionary movement, the expansion of the party team, and the theoretical victory of Marxism, not only the awakened workers demanded to join the party organization, but also other people from non-proletarian backgrounds flocked to the proletarian party team. This will inevitably cause the proletarian party to be influenced by various non-proletarian ideological consciousness. Therefore, Marx and Engels not only emphasized the class nature of the party, pointed out that the party was composed of advanced members of the working class and was always pushing the movement forward, but also emphasized the advancement of the party, pointed out that the party must have a new scientific worldview as the theoretical foundation, and put forward specific requirements for strengthening the party's construction in thought: "If such people from other classes join the proletarian movement, they are first required not to bring any remnants of prejudices from the bourgeoisie, petty bourgeoisie, etc., and to unconditionally master the proletarian worldview." It emphasizes the need for "the most thorough break with traditional property relations" and "the most thorough break with traditional notions." In order to maintain the advanced nature of the proletarian party, Marx and Engels proposed strict ideological requirements for non-proletarian members who joined the party: "First, these people must bring real enlightenment; second, if such people from other classes join the proletarian movement, they must first demand that they do not bring any remnants of prejudice from the bourgeoisie, petty bourgeoisie, etc., and must unconditionally grasp the proletarian worldview." Marx and Engels' important thoughts outlined the direction of ideological construction for the proletarian party and laid a theoretical foundation.
Leninism is Marxism in the era of imperialism and proletarian revolution. Lenin not only founded the new type of proletarian party in Russia - the Bolshevik Party, but also inherited, defended and developed Marxism's doctrine on party. When Lenin founded the party, he was facing the situation of the Second International's comprehensive betrayal of Marxism and the denial of the role of revolutionary theory by the Russian economic school. Therefore, from the very beginning of establishing a party in Russia, Lenin paid great attention to the significant role of revolutionary theory in the construction of a new type of proletarian party. Lenin particularly pointed out that instilling socialist ideas into the working class is a regular and basic task of the party. He criticized spontaneity and stressed the "instilling" theory from the very beginning of the party's establishment. He pointed out: "Without revolutionary theory, there will be no strong socialist party." "Only a party guided by advanced theory can play the role of advanced fighters." He also sharply pointed out: "Without a theory, the revolutionary faction will lose the right to survive, and is bound to be politically bankrupt sooner or later." In Lenin's view, "whether a party is a real workers' party or not relies not only on whether it is composed of workers, but also on who leads it, its actions and its political strategy. Only based on the latter, can it be determined whether the party is a real proletarian party." Here, Lenin has regarded the fundamental condition that determines the nature of the proletarian party as which thought holds the dominant position within the party. "If the thought of revisionists really prevails within the party, then it is not the socialist party of the working class." Lenin's important discussions have enriched the theory of Marxist party building.
As can be seen, without revolutionary theory, there will not be a strong proletarian party. The nature of the party does not depend on the origin of the party members, but on the guiding ideology and political line of the party. This is the theoretical basis for emphasizing the construction of the party in thought. Building the party in terms of thought is determined by the national conditions of China.



The Communist Party of China is a proletariat political party established according to the revolutionary theories and revolutionary style of Marxism-Leninism. Marx and Lenin, when discussing the conditions for the establishment of the party, believed that only when there are class conditions and theoretical conditions, and the two are combined, can the establishment of the proletariat political party become a reality. In China, by the time of the May Fourth Movement, the establishment of the Communist Party of China already had both class conditions and theoretical conditions. At that time, industrial workers had increased to two million people, and they stepped onto the political stage independently. They held strike struggles in many central cities, displaying the incomparable revolutionary firmness and thoroughness of the Chinese proletariat and their immense fighting power. A batch of advanced intellectuals with the preliminary idea of communism recognized the strength of the working class and decided to carry out Marxist-Leninist propaganda education and organizing work among the worker masses, which furthered the combination of Marxism-Leninism and the Chinese workers' movement. The great anti-imperialist and anti-feudal May Fourth Movement achieved this combination. After the May Fourth Movement, early Communist Party organizations centered on urban areas were established successively in Shanghai, Beijing, Changsha, Wuhan, Shandong, and other places, as well as among Chinese students in Japan and France, and carried out extensive activities among the worker masses. The Chinese workers' movement found its spiritual weapon from Marxism, and Marxism found its material force in the Chinese workers' movement. The combination of Marxism-Leninism and the Chinese workers' movement produced the Communist Party of China. After the establishment of the Party, it first established and developed in the city and among the working-class masses, and it carried out vigorous strike struggles. However, the revolutionary practice of the Chinese Communist Party showed that the social environment in which the Party was located, the class relations, and the revolutionary road to be taken, compared with the Communist Parties of various European countries, have a significant difference. Therefore, the Chinese Communist Party encountered major issues in its self-building that European parties had never encountered before. The Old China is a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, the collusion between imperialism and feudal forces caused serious national oppression and class oppression, the feudal exploitation system was clearly advantageous in social and economic life, although national capitalism had some development, its strength was weak, and this caused China to form a society with a small top and bottom, and a large middle. The landlord, the bourgeoisie, and the working class only accounted for a minority of the population, while most of the population are peasants and other petty bourgeois. This basic characteristic of Chinese society determines that if the Chinese Communist Party wants to become strong and take on the heavy responsibility of the revolution of saving the country and the people, relying solely on the strength of its class is far from enough, it must absorb the enthusiastic participants of the majority of peasants and other petty bourgeois who are "sincerely revolutionary, believers in the revolutionary doctrine, endorse the party's policies, and willing to follow discipline and work hard", making the party become a great mass party. Also, because the city is the enemy's stronghold, while the countryside is where the rule of imperialism and feudal forces is weaker. Therefore, the party organization that only exists in the city is difficult to survive and develop. It must develop and grow in the countryside, and lead the workers and peasants to create an armed enclave there. After the failure of the great revolution in 1927, the focus of the party's work gradually shifted from the city to the countryside, and the party moved away from the central cities and its class masses. Since then, the party has existed and developed in the countryside. On the one hand, the party lives in the countryside, surrounded by a vast sea of peasant petty bourgeois; on the other hand, the party mainly recruits its members from the petty bourgeois masses. Under these special social conditions, building a truly Marxist, highly pure proletariat political party is undoubtedly a formidable task. As Mao Zedong said, "The organization of the party in villages, due to living conditions, many are branches composed of members of the same surname, and the branch meetings are almost at the same time family meetings. Under such circumstances, the construction of 'the Bolshevik Party of Struggle' is extremely difficult.



"The difficulty lies in the various non-proletarian ideologies dominated by petty-bourgeois thought, which constantly attack the Communist Party from all directions, and the petty-bourgeois thought within the party that has not yet been overcome occasionally causes trouble. In this situation, it is both critical and extremely difficult to maintain the proletarian nature of the party and the purity of communism. Represented by Mao Zedong, the Chinese Communists, guided by the Marxist-Leninist doctrine of party-building, specifically analyzed the characteristics of China that differ from other European countries in the establishment of the proletarian party, pointing out that "the issue of proletarian ideological leadership is a very important issue. If the party in the border counties, which is almost entirely composed of peasants, is not given proletarian ideological leadership, its tendency can be erroneous". Emphasizing the importance of party building in terms of thought, and putting ideological construction at the forefront of party building, it successfully solved the major task of how to build the party into a proletarian revolutionary party under the social conditions in China where the working class is small in number but strong in fighting power, and peasants and other petty bourgeoisie constitute the majority of the population. The ideological construction of the party is the premise and foundation of all aspects of party building. The ideological and theoretical construction is the central link in the party's construction. It pervades all aspects of the party's construction and is the premise and foundation of all other aspects of the party's construction. 

The party's ideological construction is an important premise of the party's political construction. In the party's political construction, the determination of the party's political line, the formulation of the party's strategies and policies, and the determination of the political tasks of the party at various historical stages all require correct and scientific theoretical guidance and must be based on the ideological line. The correctness of the ideological line directly determines the correctness of the political line. For the party's political construction, the role of the party's theoretical construction is mainly manifested in the following points: firstly, the party can only correctly observe and analyze the situation, propose correct political tasks, and formulate correct political lines and policies if it is correct in its ideological and theoretical interpretation, especially if it has a Marxist ideological line. Secondly, the correctness of the ideological line determines whether the party's political line and policies can be correctly implemented. If the party's thoughts are not unified, even a correct political line cannot be realized. Thirdly, overcoming and correcting the wrong tendencies within the party, especially the overall wrong tendencies, must start with correcting the root causes in thoughts and improving the Marxist theoretical level of the entire party. During the period of the Great Revolution, Chen Duxiu erroneously exaggerated the power of the reactionaries, renounced the leadership of the proletariat, and his right opportunist errors led to the failure of the great revolution. The "Left" deviation during the period of the Land Revolution war copied the Russian revolution, without studying the national conditions and actual situation of the Chinese revolution, which violated the line of seeking truth from facts, and resulted in serious setbacks for the party and the revolution. Mao Zedong adhered to the principle of seeking truth from facts, combined the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism with the specific realities of the Chinese revolution, and found a correct path of revolution in which the countryside surrounds the city and armed power is seized, leading the Chinese revolution to continuous victories after the Zunyi Conference ended the rule of "Left" deviationist leaders in the party central leadership. Historical facts have proven that deviation from or deviation from the Marxist-Leninist ideological line in ideology will inevitably lead to errors in political lines. Therefore, the success or failure of the party's ideological construction is related to the success or failure of the party's political construction.

The party's ideological construction is the ideological foundation of the party's organizational construction. In the party's organizational construction, whether the principle of democratic centralism can be implemented and the unity of the party can be maintained to make the party the strong core leading the Chinese revolution and construction is inseparable from the party's ideological construction. The unity and unity of the party is the life of the party and one of the basic requirements that the party's construction is to achieve. So, how to make the party organization a solid and unified whole? Fundamentally speaking, only when all party members common have the same faith and the same ideal, that is, only when there is ideological unanimity throughout the party, can there be organizational unity and political unity. Lenin once pointed out that without ideological unity, organizational unity is meaningless; we have never sought such organizational unity and it is impossible to seek it.."



Due to ideological differences, there is a lack of genuine unity among people, making it impossible for an organization to be uniform. The Chinese Communist Party has become a strong fortress leading the people's revolution because every party member shares a common belief and communist ideals. Throughout the revolutionary practice, Mao Zedong always emphasized that the whole party should study Marxism-Leninism seriously, forming ideological consensus first, and then forming political and organizational unity. In the process of its organizational construction, our party has always based on ideological construction. Ideological construction is the ideological guarantee for strengthening the party's work style. The party's style is the style of the party organization and its members in politics, thinking, organization, work, and life, it is a specific manifestation of the nature of the working-class vanguard. A person's behavior comes from thought, and thought determines a person's words and deeds. To maintain and develop the fine traditions and style of the party, it is necessary to continuously strengthen the ideological education of party members, enhance the party spirit of each party member, and establish a communist worldview and outlook on life. In the Yan'an Rectification Movement, Mao Zedong required the majority of party members to study Marxist-Leninist theory seriously, check their words and deeds, and rectify the "three styles", that is, party style, academic style, and literary style. After the Yan'an Rectification Movement, not only has the whole party's level of Marxist-Leninist theory improved, but it has also formed the fine work style of our party. If there are still non-proletarian thoughts in his mind, he often makes mistakes of subjectivism, sectarianism, bureaucracy, and individualism in his work. That's because non-proletarian thoughts are the roots of these errors. If the roots are not eliminated, errors will inevitably be made in the work. And the way and means to eliminate non-proletarian thought is to carry out Marxist-Leninist ideological and theoretical education. The style of our party is seeking truth from facts, doing everything from reality, combining theory with reality, believing in the masses, relying on the masses, "coming from the masses and going to the masses", maintaining close ties with the masses, and taking the mass line; being brave to criticize and self-criticize, adhering to the truth, correcting mistakes, distinguishing right from wrong, uniting comrades; daring to take responsibility, ignoring personal gain or loss; striving hard, selflessly serving the public; being frugal and plain, frugal and economical; not arrogant or rash, and not discouraged. In order to build the party's style, we must first attach importance to ideological education and solve ideological problems, and make the party's ideological education regular and systematic. Therefore, giving the party members correct ideological education is the foundation of correcting the party members' style of work. 

II. Main Contents of Ideological Construction

To strengthen the ideological construction of the party, it is necessary to clarify what the content of ideological construction is. The main content of the party's ideological construction is based on the party's proletarian worldview and methodology, guided by Marxist dialectical materialism and historical materialism, and arms the whole party with advanced revolutionary theory, educates the majority of party members to raise their awareness, correct their thinking, and transform their worldview. Not only should we join the party in organization, but also in ideology.

Marxism–Leninism arms the whole party with the task of ideological construction

Mao Zedong believed that arming the whole party with Marxism-Leninism theory is the main task of the party's ideological construction. Marxism-Leninism is the soul, motivation, and direction of the Communist Party, which is a universal rule for the development of proletarian parties in various countries worldwide. The Chinese Communist Party is no exception. However, our party has its own particularity, which is that it grew and developed in a country where the petty bourgeoisie is extremely broad and semi-colonial and semi-feudal. Due to the profound influence of feudal petty bourgeoisie ideology, and because "the preparation in thought and theoretical training were inadequate" when we founded the party, the contradiction between proletarian thinking and non-proletarian thinking within our party is very prominent. Therefore, it is even more necessary to emphasize the need to regularly educate our party members through Marxist-Leninist ideology.



Mao Zedong pointed out: "Generally speaking, all Communist Party members with considerable research capabilities need to study the theories of Marx, Engels, Lenin, and Stalin. They should study the history of our nation and analyze the current movements, their conditions, and trends. They are also responsible for educating those party members with a lower cultural level." Liu Shaoqi further emphasized: "The most important issue in building our party is firstly, the construction of thinking, which involves educating and transforming our party members with the scientific ideas of Marxism-Leninism, the proletariat thought…"

The greatest contribution Mao Zedong made for our party and the Chinese people was to complete the great task of Sinicization of Marxism, i.e., the Chinese Communist Party members, represented by him, created the great Mao Zedong Thought. The new party chapter stipulates: "The Chinese Communist Party takes Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought as its own guide to action." This requires the whole party to arm their minds with Marxism-Leninism, educate party members and cadres with Mao Zedong Thought, and apply it to guide their own practice. Overcoming non-proletarian thoughts with proletarian thoughts is key to ideological construction.

Instilling communist ideology throughout the party, using the worldview of Marxism-Leninism to transform and overcome various non-proletarian thoughts within the party is crucial. It requires each party member to join the party not only organizationally but also ideologically. Early in the Jinggangshan struggle period, Mao Zedong noticed the seriousness of this issue. As the land revolution war deepened, the importance of ideological education was increasingly emphasized on the party's agenda. Zhou Enlai, who was then serving as the Minister of Organization of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, also pointed out: "In order to bolshevize the party, firstly it's necessary to strengthen the proletariat foundation, while continuously reforming the party's organization and resolutely opposing the consciousness of the petty bourgeoisie."

In the Chinese Communist Party, the contradiction between proletarian thought and petty-bourgeois thought is the main and essential contradiction. Therefore, the main issue that ideological construction needs to solve is this contradiction. In the Red Army's Fourth Army, there exist various non-proletarian thoughts, which greatly hinder the implementation of the party's correct route. He believes that "The most urgent issue in the Red Army party is the education problem." The petty bourgeois mentality mainly manifests itself in three aspects: subjectivity, narrowing down desires to actuality, and considering local issues as the whole. They often forget themselves in success or victory, and become pessimistic, even betraying the revolution and the party, in failure or setback.



Many of their representatives hope for an immediate success of the revolution to change their class status, thereby lacking patience for the longevity and difficulty of the revolution, but are greatly interested in the revolutionary phrases and slogans of the "left". The errors of "left" bias that are repeatedly committed are directly related to these issues. Some others find the various temptations of the bourgeoisie most appealing to their tastes, and politically, they tend to follow the right-wing sentiments and notions of the bourgeoisie. Generally speaking, "leftist" errors are more likely to occur within the party during splits between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie, whereas right-wing errors are more likely to occur when the proletariat and bourgeoisie unite. In organizational life, due to the limitations of the lifestyle and thought methods of the petty bourgeoisie, and especially due to the social impact of China's backward, scattered feudal family and guilds, the petty bourgeoisie tends to exhibit individualistic and factional errors in organizational matters. Such erroneous tendencies are even more likely to arise during protracted rural guerrilla warfare. Those with such erroneous thoughts do not dedicate themselves to the liberation of the party and the people, but instead exploit the strength of the party and the people, even at the expense of damaging their interests, to achieve personal and factional goals. They often undermine the flesh-and-blood ties between the party and the masses and the intimate unity within the party by bureaucratic bureaucracy, paternalistic system, punishment-based system, individual heroism, anarchism, liberalism, hilltopism, independence, factional disputes and even hooligan tactics, etc. In view of these detestable manifestations of petty bourgeois thought, Mao Zedong emphasized that party members should study the theories of Marx, Engels, Lenin, and Stalin, study our nation's history, and study the current situation and trends of movement, so as to promote our scientific understanding of the world, understanding the relationship between individuals and the masses, individuals and collectives, individuals and organizations, and individuals and the party, bringing our ideological line, political line and organizational line to the correct track of Marxism-Leninism, excluding all kinds of "left" or right interferences; everything starts from reality, everything is for the benefit of the people, everything is for the party's political tasks and struggle goals. Overcome the non-righteous wind of viewing Marxism-Leninism in a dogmatic way, copying and copying foreign experiences, divorcing from Chinese reality, and standing above the masses, overcoming idealistic subjectivism and thinking style and methods. Therefore, the task of researching the theory of Marxism-Leninism extensively and deeply is a major problem that urgently needs to be solved and must be dedicated to solving.①  We should take the study of Marxism-Leninism theory as a regular activity of the party. We should establish and improve dedicated ideological and political work systems, and combine mass self-education and remodeling with dedicated ideological and political work. Only in this way can we continuously advance the consciousness and theoretical level of all party members, and build the party into a vanguard of the proletariat that aims at Marxism-Leninism, consists of highly aware, disciplined, and self-sacrificing party members, represents the interests of the broad masses of people, and marches forward along with the broad masses of people. Engaging in party struggle actively and correctly is an important method of ideological party-building, and carrying out party struggle actively and correctly is the fundamental method to resolve contradictions within the party. Mao Zedong mentioned in the resolution on the Border Party: "In the remodeling of the party, we should completely stand from the viewpoint of the proletariat...fight resolutely against the past party's petite bourgeois liberalism, independence, romanticism, and hesitant thoughts." Intra-party criticism is a weapon for strengthening the party organization and reinforcing its combat effectiveness. To make criticism function as a combat weapon, as early as during the land revolution war, Mao Zedong proposed that criticism should be carried out in such a way as to make party members understand that the purpose of criticism is to strengthen the combat effectiveness of the party in order to achieve the victory of class struggle.


Criticism should not be used as a tool to attack others. It is essential to distinguish between criticism within the party and outside the party. Criticism should focus on the broader aspects, prevent subjectivity, arbitrariness and vulgarization. The discussion should be evidence-based, and political aspects should be considered in the critique. During the Anti-Japanese War, to resolve the thoughts of party members regarding joining the party and enhancing their quality, Mao Zedong developed criticism and self-criticism into a rectification movement for conducting Marxist ideological education, using the proletarian world view to unify the whole party. This gave the theory of Marxist criticism fresh content and was a great invention in the history of the Communist movement's party-building.

Firstly, it combines learning theory with practice. 
During the Rectification Movement, Mao, on the one hand, called on all party members and cadres to seriously study Marxist theory and grasp the spirit of Marxism; on the other hand, he guided the whole party to connect individual thoughts and actual work, link up with the reality of China's revolutionary history and reality, using Marxist-Leninist positions, views, and methods to study while rectifying, self-examining and introspecting. This led to cadres recognizing the pros and cons of the party line in history and understanding the essence of Marxism from their hands-on practical experience. They effectively overcame the subjectivist learning style within the party, freed many comrades from dogmatic ignorance. To oppose subjectivism that separates theory from practice, we must promote the spirit of seeking truth from facts in Marxism. In the article "Reforming our learning", it pointed out that "seeking truth from facts" is the sharpest and most effective weapon in the hands of a Communist Party member. 

Secondly, it combines criticism with self-criticism.
The fundamental purpose of carrying out the Rectification Movement is to "stick to the truth, correct mistakes," "clarify ideas, and unite comrades," improve the level of Marxist-Leninist theory and policy thinking of the whole party.
To properly implement criticism and self-criticism, Mao profoundly summarized the lessons and experiences from the party's internal struggles. He proposed "punishing the past and refining the future, curing diseases and saving people" as two main principles to adhere to during rectification in response to the "uncompromising struggle, relentless blow" erroneous guideline touted by "leftist" dogmatists. During the course of guiding the rectification study, the Central Committee repeatedly stressed that criticism and self-criticism should be fact-based, state the facts, make sense, convince others with reason, overcome wrong ideas with the right ones, win over people, and clear up right from wrong from a reasoned perspective, to reach genuine consensus in understanding. Some comrades, including their own mistakes, may not understand some issues for a while and should be allowed time to wait, and even repeats. They oppose the practice of coercion and they are not allowed to treat internal problems as antagonistic contradictions.

Approach human matters with caution, without indifference or injury to comrades. 
During the Yan’an Rectification, leaders lead by example, sincerely conducting criticism and self-criticism, playing a leading role, dispelling general cadre’s concerns, and promoting a good atmosphere of criticism and self-criticism.
Chapter 9: The Party's Construction Thought. It both accounted for irregularities within the party and promoted democratic style; clarified thoughts and unifying comrades, achieving unprecedented unity and unity in thought within the party. Criticism and self-criticism also became the basic method for the whole Party to solve ideological contradictions within the Party and to properly handle contradictions among the people. 

Third, the combination of leadership and the masses.
The process of the Yan’an Rectification Movement fully embodies the process of combining leadership and the masses. In May 1941, the rectification study was first carried out among the central senior cadres, criticizing the subjective style, summarizing the party's historical experience, on the basis of basically consistent understanding, in February 1942 the rectification was extended to the entire party, carrying out Marxist educational activities, achieving unprecedented unity and unity in the entire party. In October 1943, it returned to the central senior cadres to continue the rectification study, distinguishing the political route, summarizing experiences, until the party's Sixth Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee in April 1945 adopted the "Resolution on Several Historical Issues", the whole party, especially the party's senior cadres, reached unity on the basis of Marxism-Leninism. This educational principle and method from the leadership to the masses, and from the masses to the leadership, extended to other work in the party, this is the working method of combining leadership and the masses. This working method was summarized and promoted by Mao Zedong. On June 1, 1943, Mao Zedong summarized the experience since the rectification and drafted a decision on several issues on leadership methods for the central government. In this decision, a theoretical summary was made on the scientific method of realizing party leadership, clearly putting forward the principle of "combining leadership and the masses". Mao Zedong believed that to complete a task, it is necessary to both give full play to the enthusiasm of leading cadres and mobilize the enthusiasm of the masses. 

"In all practical work of our Party, correct leadership must come from the masses and go to the masses." The leadership method and working method of combining leadership and the masses not only reflects the idea of democratic centralism, but also reflects the spirit of the mass line, the content is very rich. Of course, the formation and application of this method did not start from the rectification movement, but the promotion and advocacy of this method, as an effective working method and tradition for the entire party, is one of the achievements of the rectification movement.
The Rectification Movement is a great initiative in the ideological construction of the Communist Party of China, it provides experience for how to ideologically construct the party, sets an example, establishes several fundamental principles for ideological construction (these principles, Mao later elevated them to the three main styles of the party), gives a clear path to the ideological construction of the party, and cultivates a large number of outstanding cadres for the Chinese revolution.

Under the new historical conditions of the Liberation War, the "three investigations" (investigating class, investigating thought, investigating style) and "three rectifications" (rectifying organization, rectifying thought, rectifying style) were carried out as the basic content of the party rectification movement.
The historical experience of the Communist Party of China proves that the method of rectification is effective in resolving contradictions within the party, rectifying the party's line, changing the party's style, enhancing the party's unity, consolidating the party's organization, strengthening the party's leadership, and maintaining the advanced nature of the proletariat. It is a big magic weapon in the ideological construction of the Communist Party of China, an important way for Mao Zedong to emphasize the construction of the party from the ideological point of view, and a development of Mao Zedong's Marxist theory of party building.
Third, adhering to the ideological line of seeking truth from facts is the fundamental way to strengthen the ideological construction of the party.


Strengthening the Party's ideological line and arming the entire Party with Marxist theory primarily involves adhering to the Party's pragmatic and realistic ideological line. The pragmatic and realistic ideological line established by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) is a product of applying dialectical materialism, i.e., the world outlook and the theory of cognition of Marxism-Leninism, to solve practical problems of the Chinese revolution. Furthermore, it has been honed through constant summations of experience and lessons learned in fighting against various incorrect ideologies. This ideological line has been proven to be completely correct through the Party’s long-term practical struggle, possessing rigorous scientific nature and unparalleled combat power, making it the lifeline of the CCP. 

The concept of pragmatism and realism as an ideological line of the Party emerged during the Great Revolution period. Mao Zedong's analysis of the classes in Chinese society and his exposition on the peasant problem, as well as his views on China's revolutionary path reflected in his articles "Analysis of the Classes in Chinese Society" and "Report on an Investigation of the Peasant Movement in Hunan," embody the spirit of pragmatism and realism.

The ideological line of pragmatism and realism gradually took shape during the period of the Agrarian Revolutionary War. In 1929, Mao Zedong contrasted subjectivism with Marxism, treating subjectivism as a wrong guiding principle, its outcome will either be "opportunism or impetuousness." He called on Party members to use the method of investigation and research to replace the method of subjectivism. In May 1930, Mao wrote "Oppose Book Worship," using the concept of "ideological line" for the first time, explicitly proposing the principle of combining theory and practice. He pointed out, "We should learn Marx's 'book,' but it must be combined with our country's actual situation. We need 'book,' but we must correct the de facto 'bookist' that is out of touch with reality." To achieve the combination of the universal principles of Marxism with China's reality requires conducting investigations and research among the masses, "without investigation, there is no right to speak." During this period, although the scientific concept of pragmatism and realism had not yet emerged, Mao had already proposed the basic principle of the ideological line of pragmatism and realism — the combination of theory and practice, laying the foundation for the formation of the ideological line.

The ideological line of pragmatism and realism was formally established during the Yan'an Rectification Movement. During this period, Mao wrote "Reform Our Study", "Rectify the Party's Style of Work," and other works. In these writings, he explicitly proposed the concept of pragmatism and realism, scientifically defined its meaning, and expounded the ideological line of starting from actuality, seeking truth from facts, and linking theory with practice from the perspective of its cognitive substance.

The formation of the ideological line of seeking truth from facts has its theoretical basis and historical conditions:

Firstly, it is the inevitable result of the development of the philosophical thoughts of the Chinese Communist Party. "On Practice" and "On Contradiction" (referred to as the "Two Treatises") provides philosophical proof for the Party's ideological line. It primarily embodies the historical experience of the combination of the universal principles of Marxism and the concrete practice of the Chinese revolution summarized philosophically in the "Two Treatises." "On Practice," based on scientific social practice, clarifies the principle of the historical unity of subjective and objective, theory and practice, providing philosophical proof for the ideological line of seeking truth from facts from the perspective of epistemology; "On Contradiction" clarifies the principle of the unity of universality and particularity of contradictions and their dialectical relationship based on the particularity of contradictions, providing philosophical proof for the ideological line of seeking truth from facts from the perspective of dialectics.

The perceptions in "On Practice" about practice being the basis of cognition, and the priority of practice; the perceptions in "On Contradiction" about the particularity of contradictions being the basis of cognition and the importance of specific analysis of specific conditions collectively verifies one issue: all starts from actuality, seeking rules from "facts."


Because of the practical activities that people themselves engage in, the reality and facts that people face in their own practical activities directly manifest as specific and particular. In the "On Practice," the idea of the two leaps in the process of cognition (from practice to cognition, and then from cognition to practice) is discussed. Moreover, in "On Contradiction," the basic order of cognitive process (from individual to general, and then from general to individual) is examined. Both ideas are proving the same point: the regular knowledge we seek from "facts" must serve as the guide to action, in other words, be combined with practice, serve practice, and be tested and developed in practice.

The general law of the development of cognition in the "On Practice," which is the idea of "practice, cognition, practice again, cognition again" cycling to infinity, and the idea of the cyclic process from individual to general, then from general to individual in "On Contradiction," both argue that seeking truth from facts is a gradually deepening and never-ending process. That is, even the correct cognition reflecting the universality of contradiction proven by practice must return to practice and combine with new, concrete reality (practice), guiding new practice and continuing to be tested and developed during the process of serving the new practice. This process never ends.

The "Two Treatises" provide another important demonstration of the philosophical evidence for the Party's ideological line, summarizing the historical lessons from the combination of Marxist universal principles and China's specific revolutionary practice. "On Practice" digs deep into the epistemological roots of "

On the other hand, it is the product of the long-term opposition to subjectivism by the Communist Party of China. Subjectivism is a thought method that exaggerates subjective force while ignoring objective reality. Subjectivism has caused great harm. In the history of the Chinese Communist Party, every time subjectivism was rampant, the revolutionary cause suffered serious setbacks or even failure. In particular, Wang Ming's "leftist" dogmatism has ruled the party for the longest time, with the most significant harm and worst influence, becoming the fundamental ideological obstacle for the Chinese Communist Party to implement the correct line. Aware of this profound historical lesson, Mao Zedong always highlighted the issue of ideological method and ideological line to the whole party in each historical period, especially at the significant historical turning point of the revolution, treating the fight against subjectivism as a matter of first importance. 

Mao Zedong's exposition of the idea of seeking truth from facts contains the following three theoretical aspects:
Firstly, everything starts from reality...



Mao Zedong creatively applied the philosophical path of materialism to practical work, proposing the perspective of starting from the reality. The so-called reality refers to everything objectively existing, "Everything outside of our minds is objectively real... only our minds (thoughts) are the subjects of study." Starting from reality means starting from the characteristics of moving objective things. Firstly, we should start from the specific characteristics of different things. For the practical activities of the proletariat party, it is the most important and fundamental to start from the national conditions of one's own country. Understanding the nature of Chinese society and the national conditions of China is the basic basis for solving all the problems of the Chinese revolution. The Chinese Communists recognized the nature of old China as a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, and from this fundamental national condition, they found the unique path for the Chinese revolution. Secondly, we need to start from the changing and developing objective situations. Thirdly, we need to start from the sum and connection of things.

Second, linking theory and practice. Mao Zedong made incisive explanations on how to link theory and practice, pointing out: "Chinese Communists can only link theory and practice when they are adept at applying Marxist-Leninist position, viewpoint, methods and Lenin-Stalin's doctrine on Chinese revolution, further from serious research in Chinese historical and practical realities, and make theoretical creations needed by China on all fronts." Firstly, theory should be applied to practice. Mao Zedong emphasized that learning Marxist theory must pay attention to its application. He said: “With regard to the theory of Marxism, it is important to master it and apply it because the purpose of mastering it is entirely for application.” He used the idiom "shoot the arrow with a target in mind" to illustrate the relationship between Marxist theory and the Chinese revolution, "The arrow of Marxism-Leninism must be used to shoot at the target of the Chinese revolution". Second, practice should be guided by theory. Practice without theoretical guidance is blind practice, this is the principle of Marxism-Leninism reiterated by Mao Zedong. He pointed out that not only should we understand the conclusions of Marx, Engels, Lenin, and Stalin about general laws, but we should also learn their positions and methods for observing and solving problems. Not only should we study the general theory of Marxism, but we should also study China's history and current situation, deduce the regularities from it, and transform Marxism into a Chinese form.

Third, demonstrating conscious initiative and mastering objective laws. Firstly, research is necessary. Research is the prerequisite for understanding objective laws. Research has a particularly important meaning for Chinese Communists. Because the Chinese Revolution does not have existing experiences to draw from, only through research can we understand China's unique national conditions and find the unique path for the Chinese Revolution. Based on the extensive research experience during the period of Land Revolution War, Mao Zedong summarized two points on how to conduct good research: One is "to keep eyes groundward and not just look up into the sky. Without the interest and determination to look down, one will never truly understand the matters of China in his lifetime."; the other is to hold research meetings, not to rush through or merely listen to the reports of a few grassroots leaders, but to squat down, hold various types of discussions among the masses, and conduct in-depth investigations. Mao Zedong emphasized the mass point of view on how to conduct a good research meeting, "Without fervor, determination to look down, desire for knowledge, and the spirit to put down one's airs and willingly be a student, one can never do it well. It must be understood that the masses are the real heroes, and we often seem naive and ridiculous, without understanding this, we cannot gain basic knowledge." 。



Secondly, it is necessary to find out the laws of things. The perceptual materials obtained through investigation are still semi-finished products. It is necessary to fully play the role of the brain as a processing factory, find out the internal connections of things, and form concepts and laws. Mao Zedong summarized this manufacturing process as a process of refining the rough, keeping the true, going from one to the other, and going from the surface to the inside.
The ideological line of seeking truth from facts formed during the Yan'an Rectification Movement became a theoretical weapon for unifying the party's ideological understanding, and promoted the unity and unity of our party under the banner of Mao Zedong Thought.
Section Three The Construction of Party Organizations
1. Democratic centralism is the fundamental organizational principle of the proletarian party
The construction of party organizations is an important part of Marxist party-building doctrine. Lenin pointed out: "The reason why the proletariat can become and must become an invincible force is because the ideological unity formed by it according to Marxist principles is consolidated by the material unity of the organization, which unites millions of workers into a large army of the working class." Only by going through the organization, the correct theory, program and line of the party can be transformed into a huge material force, and the role of the command center of the proletarian political party can be maximized.
The proletarian party is the vanguard of the working class and the leading core and command center of the entire class. The nature and mission of the party determine that it must take democratic centralism as its organizational principle. This is because: as a political party that is the leading core of the entire class, it must possess the leadership force to seize political power, build socialism, and achieve the great goal of communism. In this, not only must there be a correct theory, program and line, but also rely on its solid organization and unanimity, to maintain the unity of thought and politics and unity of organization and action of the entire party. Only by using the organizational principle of democratic centralism can we mobilize the enthusiasm of all members to the greatest extent, unify the will and action of the entire party, and win the victory of the proletarian revolutionary cause.
The emergence and development of democratic centralism has gone through a long historical process.
Marx and Engels attached great importance to the construction of the party in the struggle to establish the proletarian political party. The Communist League’s charter and the draft of the International Workers’ Association's common charter and organizational regulations approved by the summer committee in 1872, which they presided over, are important documents reflecting the doctrine and organizational principles of the Marxist party. Although Marx and Engels did not use the concept of democratic centralism in these documents, they always embodied the principle of unity of democracy and centralism. From Marx and Engels' thoughts and practices, their main contents about the party's organizational principles are as follows: the organizational structure of the party reflects the union and international both have relatively complete organizational systems that unify democracy and centralism. At the first congress of the Communist League held in June 1847, the organization of the alliance was determined to be composed of branches, districts, general districts, central committees, and congresses. The charter of the alliance stipulates that the highest leadership body of the alliance is the central committee as the executive body of power. The organizational system of the first international is more complete than the Communist League. The highest authority of the First International is the International Congress.



During the closing of the Congress, the General Committee elected by the Congress executes the resolutions of the congress. Within the General Committee, there is a core organization, the Standing Committee. The Standing Committee is composed of the Chairman of the General Committee, the General Secretary, and the communicative secretaries of various countries.
