The organizations of various national associations are called Joint Committees. Underneath the Joint Committees are local groups, branches, and small groups. From this, it can be seen that the international organizational structure is actually the prototype of the organizational structure of modern communist and workers' parties in various countries.

Regarding the bottom-up electoral system, the alliance implements a bottom-up electoral system. The draft of the statutes passed at the first congress of the Communist League states that each branch elects its own leader, and the responsibilities are chosen from the committee's leaders. The Central Committee is elected by the district committee where the Central Committee is located. Public officeholders are elected regularly every year, and if their work is unsatisfactory, they can be dismissed at any time. The draft also stipulates that each member of the International Workers' Association has the right to elect and to be elected, and all elected leaders have to report their work to their electorate and can be dismissed at any time.

Regarding party organization life, members (or international members) of the Communist League are all equal within the organization. As Engels pointed out, there is only one type of member in the International, and this member has equal rights and obligations, and there are no special members. The international organization life always insists on the principles of democracy and concentration where minorities obey the majority. Marx is a model for adhering to this principle.

For example, at the Basel Congress, the Bakunin faction called for a discussion on inheritance rights. Marx himself disagreed with Bakunin's view that abolition of inheritance was the starting point of the social revolution, but agreed to discuss this issue at the congress. Marx drafted a report on the inheritance issue for the General Committee, and together with Bakunin's proposal, it was discussed at the conference. The discussion resulted in neither proposal gaining a majority. In this situation, Marx did not use the authority of the General Committee to force others to accept his views, but recognized the status quo, and actively worked to let people understand this issue through practical struggle.

Regarding the principle of party activity, Marx always insisted on collective leadership in the International General Assembly. Marx was the actual leader of the International and had high prestige. However, it was not Marx who had the final say in the General Committee, but a collective discussion. Any proposal is only effective after majority approval. When the General Committee discusses issues, each member has full speaking rights, can speak freely, express their own opinions, but each person's speech must not exceed five minutes. On Marx's proposal, the Executive Chairman of the General Committee's weekly meeting was to take turns serving.

On relations between leaders and the masses, Marx and Engels always treated this issue with democratic and equal principles, and set a brilliant example for the organization construction of the proletarian party.


Marx and Engels are recognized as the leaders of the international communist movement and activists of socialist parties in Europe and America, who continue to consult with them on theories and strategies for revolution. However, they always treat everyone equally, offering advice and discussing matters as regular soldiers. They oppose worship from others and strictly prohibit others from praising themselves. Marx once pointed out that he and Engels "both regard fame as worthless" and "because of my disgust with all personal worship, while the International was in existence, I never allowed the publication of the many praises from various countries that disgusted me. I never even responded to them, and when I did, it was to reprimand. The terms Engels and I had in mind when we first joined the Communist secret society were to abandon everything conducive to superstition of authority in the statutes." Regarding the party's organizational discipline, the Charter of the Communist League specifies that all members must maintain political consistency with the league, their "ways of life and activities must be in line with the purpose of the League"; they must "not join any anti-Communist (political or ethnic) groups"; they must "obey all resolutions by the League", etc. If these conditions are not complied with, they will be deemed as a "betrayal of the League" and depending on the severity, they may be suspended or expelled from the league. Marx believed that strict discipline is necessary for the victory of the proletariat. He pointed out: "We must now uphold the discipline of the party absolutely, otherwise everything will come to nothing."

At the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century, as capitalism developed into imperialism and the revolutionary struggle of the proletariat entered a special stage of seizing power, Lenin timely formulated special organizational principles—centralism—for the Russian Social Democratic Labor Party. From 1899 to 1904, Lenin emphasized repeatedly the need to build the party according to the principle of centralism. In 1899, he explicitly proposed the principle of centralism in his article "Our Current Task" for the first time. Lenin believed that the new type of proletariat party established according to the principle of centralism has two main characteristics: first, the party's local activities must be completely free, while also setting up a unified and therefore centralized party; second, the party should strive to become a revolutionary party with the main goal of fighting for political freedom, and at the same time resolutely not plan political conspiracies. The two aspects put forward by Lenin have three important significances: first, it is not only a profound summary of the historical experience of the international communist movement, but also a political remedy for opposing and overcoming the group habits that were widely prevalent when the Russian Social Democratic Labor Party was established; second, it not only clearly proposed the principle concept of centralism but also made it one of the main characteristics of the new type of proletariat party, which distinguishes it from other worker parties; third, it proposed opposing a small group of conspiratorial organizations, which not only distinguishes the centralism of the new proletariat party from the different types of centralism that have appeared in history, but also made an unconscious theoretical preparation for the later proposal of the democratic centralism principle.

However, at the time, the biggest obstacle to implementing centralism was Economism. Economism believed that implementing centralism violated the principle of democracy. Lenin pointed out in his book "What is to be Done?" that the necessary conditions for implementing democratic principles are complete openness, election system, and general supervision. But under the Tsarist autocracy, implementing such a democracy is like a group of peasants taking wooden sticks to fight against the Tsar's spies, detectives, and gendarmerie who have all the best equipment, often resulting in immediate failure at the start of the action. Therefore, the party can only implement centralism. Not only that, Lenin made an unprecedented systematic elaboration of the principle of centralism, and further formulated specific implementation details, thereby developing the centralism idea into an actionable and more complete organizational system. In 1903, at the Second Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party, the party split into Bolshevik and Menshevik factions. This one-party two-faction situation continued for nearly a decade.




The struggle between two factions around organizational issues, whether in terms of time, scale, or intensity, far exceeded that with the economic faction. The Mensheviks fiercely criticized the principle of centralization in order to replace it with self-government, claiming that centralization was a "bureaucratic" centralization, accusing Lenin of wanting to turn the party into a "large factory" with the Central Committee acting as the factory director, implementing "serfdom" within the party, and turning party members into "small wheels" and "small screws". They believed that the party should be the sum of all autonomous committees, and that each part of the party should not be subject to the whole, but should have autonomy over the whole. To counteract the Mensheviks, Lenin published the famous book "One Step Forward, Two Steps Back" in 1904, which profoundly criticized the Mensheviks' absurd views on organizational issues, highly praised the idea of centralization, and comprehensively explained the organizational principles of centralization. In the book, Lenin repeatedly emphasized that the principle of centralism was the most basic and principled idea in the plans to establish the Iskra group. With centralization, the intellectual authority of the party would become the authority of power. "The idea of centralization is the principle method of resolving all local and detailed organizational issues," "it is the only principled idea". Following this, Lenin further proposed the principle of implementing centralization. He believed that for the party to carry out its work correctly, it needed to have the principles of the minority obeying the majority, individuals obeying the organization, lower levels obeying higher levels, and local areas obeying central command. If "there is no principle of the minority obeying the majority, no principle of parts obeying the whole, then it is simply unimaginable". Lenin proposed that the principle of centralization must be reflected in the party's organizational charter. Because "the charter is the formal expression of organization". Forming a good charter is the fundamental organizational measure to ensure the implementation of the principle of centralization. Only by strictly adhering to this charter can we rid ourselves of the stubborn self-willedness of groups, the arbitrary mess caused by groups, and the pointless squabbles of groups. Therefore, the principle of centralization, "should run through the entire party charter". As such, the idea of centralization has transformed from theory into practice, turned into the party's law, transformed into the will of the entire party, thus transforming into the material weapon for destroying the despotic system of the exploiting class.

II. The Chinese Communist Party's Continuation and Development of the Proletarian Organizational Principle

Democratic centralism is our party's fundamental organizational principle and a core tenet of Mao Zedong's party building theory. In the long-term practice of revolutionary struggle, Chinese Communists, represented by Mao Zedong, continuously developed and perfected the principle of democratic centralism, greatly enriching and developing the theory of Marxist-Leninist democratic centralism.

Before the founding of the Chinese Communist Party, Mao Zedong discussed and studied the issue of party building according to what organizational principles, with Chinese revolutionary intellectuals who initially embraced communist ideas, represented by the likes of Li Dazhao, Chen Duxiu, Cai Hesen and Zhou Enlai. On August 13th and September 16th of 1920, Cai Hesen wrote two long letters to Mao Zedong from Germany, introducing Lenin's party building theory and also elaborating his basic views on the party's organizational issues. Regarding the party's organizational principles, Cai Hesen stated: "The Bolshevik Party is organized as a highly centralized organization, the party discipline is as strong as iron, it can only be so to nurture a minority of highly conscious organized members, suitable for wartime and for taking on the enormous task of transformation". Cai Hesen also proposed: "The supreme organ of the party is the Central Committee. All sorts of activities and parts of the party, including newspapers, parliaments, groups and various movements, must be absolutely subject to the command and supervision of the Central Committee." In his reply, Mao Zedong stated: "Your letter is very insightful, there is not a word I disagree with." Under their advocacy, our party was established from the beginning according to the principle of democratic centralism. The principles of democratic centralism were already embodied in the program passed by the first party congress, and the party constitution from the second, third and fourth party congresses.



In June 1927, the Central Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China, by the delegation of the fifth party congress, explicitly proposed and affirmed the principle of democratic centralism in the "Party Construction" chapter of the "Resolution on the Third Amendment to the Constitution of the Communist Party of China", marking its first appearance in the Chinese Communist Party Charter. The party Charter approved at the sixth party congress in July 1928, preliminarily elucidated the content of democratic centralism. In December 1929, in the Gutian Conference Resolution drafted by Chairman Mao, C. Mao argued for closely integrating ideological construction with organizational building based on the democratic centralism, advocating eradication of extreme democracy and correction of non-organizational viewpoints, and emphasized that minority must obey majority under centralized guidance and democratic lifestyle.

In 1937, China was facing the severe situation of imminent fully-fledged invasion by Japanese imperialism. To rally the masses to join the Anti-Japanese United Front and jointly strive to defeat Japanese imperialism, Chairman Mao, in the summary of the National Representative Conference of the Communist Party of China held in Yan'an in May 1937, not only elevated democracy to the level of "guarantee against Japanese", but also asserted to achieve the goal of overthrowing Japanese imperialism, the party must have power. How could the party gain power? Chairman Mao advocated that to empower the party, it depended on the practice of the party's democratic centralism to mobilize the full enthusiasm of the entire party. In times of reactionary and civil wars, centralism was more prominent. In the new era, centralism should be closely associated with democracy. The practice of democracy allows for full activation of party-wide enthusiasm. By fully activating party-wide enthusiasm, a large number of cadre can be trained, remnants of sectarianism can be purged, and party-wide unity can be achieved as strong as steel.

In October 1938, on the eve of shifting from strategic defense to strategic stalemate in the Anti-Japanese War, Japan shifted its main forces to the battlefields behind the enemy lines, and the KMT adopted the policy of passive resistance. Meanwhile, the Wang Ming rightism mistake of abandoning party leadership emerged within CCP. At the same time, because "our country is dominated by economies of small production and patriarchal system, and there is still no democratic life on a national scale. This situation was reflected in our party, resulting in a lack of democratic life. This phenomenon hinders the full development of the party-wide enthusiasm". In response to this situation, Mao, in the political report of the Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Communist Party, made clear demands on how to mobilize the entire party's enthusiasm in the Anti-Japanese War by relying on democratic centralism. He said: "The Chinese Communist Party facing the great struggle demands the entire party leadership, all party members and cadre, to highly mobilize its enthusiasm for victory. The so-called enthusiasm must be concretely manifested local.creation capabilities, sense of responsibility, vitality of work, daring and good at raising questions, expressing opinions, criticizing shortcomings, and supervising leadership organs and leading cadre with a caring perspective. Without these, the so-called enthusiasm is void. The manifestation of this enthusiasm relies on the democratization of life within the party. Without democratic life within the party, the purpose of enthusiasm cannot be achieved. The creation of a large number of competent talents can only be possible in a democratic life. " In order to enhance the party's fighting capacity and break through the difficulties of war, Chairman Mao emphasized in this political report: "Expanding democracy within the party should be regarded as a necessary step to consolidate and develop the party, and an important weapon for the party to be lively and capable in the great struggle, gladly assume duties, grow new forces, and break through the difficulties of war.". He emphasized both the importance of expanding internal party democracy and the strict adherence to the discipline of "four obediences", i.e., individual obedience to organization, minority obedience to majority, lower-level obedience to a higher level, and the entire party obedience to the central. In 1945, with the victory of the Anti-Japanese War imminent, the seventh party congress was convened on the basis of rectification in Yan'an. The seventh party congress raised the understanding and argumentation of democratic centralism to the level of organizational law.


In his report on amending the Party Constitution, Liu Shaoqi pointed out: "Our party is not a simple sum of the number of party members, but a unified organism organized by all party members according to certain rules. It is a combination of party leaders and those being led; it is a unity formed by the party leaders, various levels of party organizations, and a large number of party members according to certain rules. This rule is the inner-party democratic centralism."
The Party Constitution passed by the 7th National Congress of the Party describes democratic centralism as "concentration based on democracy and democracy under centralized guidance." For the first time, it accurately expresses the dialectical relationship between democracy and centralism in a concise language. Regarding democracy under centralized guidance, there are now some criticisms, some people even think that this is the theoretical basis for bureaucratic centralism. In fact, Liu Shaoqi explained its meaning very clearly in "On the Party": Democracy under centralized guidance means that all party meetings are convened by the party's leadership; elections and resolutions within the party must be adequately prepared, carefully considered, and follow certain procedures; all party members must abide by the party constitution and uniform discipline, must obey the overall situation, obey the collective, and firmly oppose extreme democratization and anarchistic tendencies. All of these are precisely to promote democracy fully through normal procedures and channels. In specific work, some people understand democracy under centralized guidance as conducting elections and voting according to the intentions of the party leadership, which weakens and undermines inner-party democracy. This is indeed a serious problem that needs attention in party life. But it is a misunderstanding of democracy under the guidance of centralization, and democracy should not be separated from the guidance of centralization.
After the 7th congress of the party, Mao Zedong's thoughts on democratic centralism have further developed. During the liberation war period, in September 1948, Mao Zedong summarized the experience of collective leadership and drafted the resolution of "On Improving the Party Committee System" for the Central Committee, pointing out that the party committee system is an important mechanism to ensure collective leadership and prevent individual dictation. During the second plenary session of the 7th Party Congress in March 1949, Mao Zedong emphasized the working methods of the party committee, which enriched and developed the thoughts of democratic centralism, and prepared for the arrival of a new stage of party construction in organization.
Third, the basic content of party organization building
Party organization building is one of the main contents of party building, which mainly includes tasks such as the construction of the party's cadre corps, the party member corps, and democratic centralism. The building of the party's cadre corps occupies a central position in the party's organizational construction. The construction of party members is the foundation of party organization construction. The construction of democratic centralism is an important task for party organization construction. The cadre corps promotes the function and power of the party's organization. Party cadres are the backbone of party organizations, the main implementers of the party's line, guidelines, and policies, and the decisive force in realizing party leadership.
(1) "After the political line is determined, the cadres become the deciding factor.
The Chinese Communist Party has always believed that the reason why the cadre issue is important is firstly that the great revolutionary struggle requires a large number of cadres to organize and lead.


"The Communist Party of China is the party leading the great revolutionary struggle among a large nation of several hundred million people, and without a majority of leaders with both morals and talent, it cannot complete its historical mission." The correct political line must be ensured by the correct organizational line. The cadres of the party at all levels are the planners and organizers of the revolutionary cause. 

The vast majority of cadres bear the heavy responsibility of implementing and executing the party's line, guidelines, and policies, organizing and leading the masses to implement the basic line of the party at each historical stage. Only through their "leading sheep" role among the masses can the party's overall line and overall policy be transformed into the conscious action of hundreds of millions of masses, and the success of the party's cause can be achieved. Mao Zedong believed that the cadres, as a guarantee of success for all the party's undertakings, hold this importance not only for the party's overall line and overall task, but also for the specific work and tasks of a particular region or unit. In view of certain places and units where the situation cannot be improved, work cannot be advanced, and public opinion is significant, Mao Zedong pointed out: "The basic reason why many places and many organizations cannot advance their work is the lack of such a united, normal, and healthy leadership backbone. For instance, a school of a hundred people will not succeed without a few to a dozen of the most active, decent, and innovative leaders formed from teachers, staff, and students according to actuality (not forcibly gathered)."

Cadres are the bridge of the party to the masses. The party is the faithful representative of the interests of the hundreds of millions of the masses and the fighting force committed to the interests of the people. The cause of the party is the cause of the masses, and the guidelines and policies formulated by the party need to be implemented by the masses. However, for the masses to wholeheartedly follow the party, unite around the party, and engage in various undertakings under the leadership of the party, one important link is to rely on our cadres to propagate to the masses, mobilize the masses, and organize the masses. Without a large number of cadres working closely with the masses, the party cannot survive. When creating the Jinggangshan base, Mao Zedong emphasized that the cadres should "organize, train, and send the masses to the battlefield of economic construction. They are the commanders on the economic front, and the masses are the fighters." Later, Mao Zedong also considered maintaining close contact with the masses as one of the three major styles of the party. Through cadres of all levels and types, the party maintains contact with the masses, relies on them to strengthen the leadership over the masses, and completes various tasks. In this way, the party will not lose touch with the masses, and the cause of the party will be invincible.

(2) The cadre line of "employing people for their talents" and the employment standard of "both morals and talent." "On the issue of using cadres, there have always been two opposing lines in our ethnic history: one is 'employing people for their talents,' and the other is 'employing people for nepotism.' The former is the correct line, and the latter is not." The selfless nature of the proletariat determines that the Communist Party's line for employing people is "employing people for their talents." When criticizing Zhang Guozhu's line of "employing people for nepotism," Mao Zedong emphasized the need to "adhere to a fair and correct style in the cadre issue in order to consolidate the unity of the party, which is the important responsibility of the central and local leaders." Mao Zedong insisted on "five lakes and four seas," opposed factionalism and cliqueism. He once said that anyone who asked him for a job was firmly rejected. He would not introduce, recommend, speak, or write letters. This "four no's" basic point of his was a counter to nepotism.



Adhering to the cadre policy of appointing people on their merits, that is, adhering to the cadre standards of both morality and ability. “Merit" here refers to a combination of morality and ability. The Communist Party of China, based on the Marxist line of cadres, has drawn inspiration from the standards of employing talents in ancient Chinese politics, and creatively proposed the specific contents of the Party's cadre "morality" and "ability". It includes: "Understand Marxism-Leninism, have political foresight, have the ability to work, be willing to make sacrifices, be able to solve problems independently, be unshakable in difficulties, and work faithfully for the nation, for the class, and for the party." Mao Zedong summarized the standards of morality and ability as "resolutely implementing the party's line, obeying the party's discipline, having close ties with the masses, having independent working ability, being active and diligent, and not seeking personal gain."

After the cadre standards of possessing both morality and ability were established, how to identify and select talents to leadership positions at all levels is a critical issue. Regarding the inspection and recognition of cadres, Mao Zedong believed that the first step is to broaden one’s horizon and improve one’s thinking. Some comrades agree to select cadres who possess both morality and ability, but they feel that talents are hard to find. This involves not only a problem in thinking but also a lack of broader perspective. During the Land Revolution War, Mao Zedong pointed out sharply in response to individuals who frequently lamented the lack of cadres: "Are there really no cadres? Countless cadres have emerged from the land struggle, economic struggle, and revolutionary war. How can we say that there are no cadres? If we abandon the wrong view, the cadres will stand before us." Furthermore, Mao Zedong proposed the main methods to identify cadres, that is, "not only to look at the cadre's momentary actions, but also to look at the cadre's entire history and entire work." This way, mistakes in employing people can be avoided. In addition, Mao Zedong stressed that cadres should be identified, selected, and trained in the practice of revolutionary struggle and mass struggle. "Those who are truly united and connected with the masses must be gradually formed from the mass struggle, and cannot be formed apart from the mass struggle." "We must continuously promote active individuals who have emerged from struggle to replace those who are minor or corrupted in the original backbone."

(3) Cadre training and cadre education.
The proletariat revolution requires thousands of excellent cadres. To ensure successors to the revolution, The Communist Party of China pays great attention to cadre training and education. Firstly, it’s necessary to "guide them". Mao Zedong believed that cadres should be given responsibilities and let them work freely, so that they can grow their abilities in practice. In this process, it is also important to provide timely guidance. Leadership experience can only be gained after taking up leadership positions, and never before that. "To be a really capable high-level commander is not something that can be achieved by just starting out or merely talking about army matters on paper. It must be learned in war." In war, "often it is not learning first and then doing, but starting to work and then learning, doing is learning." Only in this way can one become a mature leader and make a significant contribution to the party's cause.



Secondly, to “improve them", "this refers to providing opportunities for learning, educating them, and uplifting their abilities in theory and work." Improving the quality of officials, the most important principle is to enhance Marxist theoretical knowledge among the majority of officials. Mao Zedong said: "Our vision is not enough; we should resort to telescopes and microscopes. Marx's method is the political and military equivalent of telescopes and microscopes." However, studying theory isn't about solely memorizing maxims and conclusions from revolutionary leaders. Mao Zedong repeatedly emphasized the learning method of combining theory with practice, stating that “The great power of Marxism-Leninism lies in its connection with the specific revolutionary practices of each country. For the Chinese Communist Party, it means learning to apply Marxism-Leninism theory to the specific conditions of the Chinese revolution." "Discussing Marxism without considering Chinese characteristics is simply abstract and hollow Marxism.” Mao Zedong further summarized the guideline of theoretical learning and research, which is to "establish studying the specific issues of Chinese revolution as central, with the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism as guidance", indicating the direction for officials' theoretical study.

Finally, we should care for them. The method of caring for officials is, first, to “inspect their work, help them summarize experiences, affirm their achievements, and correct mistakes." This can help them make fewer or no mistakes. "Assigning tasks without follow-up, only paying attention when serious mistakes are made, is not the way to care for officials.” The second is to properly treat officials who have made mistakes, “for those who have made mistakes, we should generally adopt persuasion methods and help them correct their mistakes." The third is "to take care of their difficulties.", "For officials who have illness, life, family and other difficulties, we must take care of them as much as possible". Cultivating new officials, especially young new officials, is of strategic significance. Some communists are not enthusiastic about selecting new officials, especially young officials, because they don't trust young officials and worry that they can't lead effectively. This is political short-sightedness. Mao Zedong believed that the tasks of Chinese revolution and construction always need young people to take over and emphasized "If our party does not have a large number of new officials working in cooperation with old officials, our cause will be interrupted." And the entire party is required to plan and cultivate a large number of new officials as a combat mission.

(4) Proper treatment of officials who have made mistakes.
In the practice of reforming society and the world, officials will inevitably make mistakes; there is no person who does not make mistakes. The Chinese Communist Party has a series of correct policies and theoretical thoughts on how to properly treat officials who have made mistakes.


Firstly, it is important to understand the root causes of mistakes, which means "focusing on the analysis of the circumstances at that time, the content of the errors, and the societal, historical, and ideological origins of the errors". Mao Zedong believed that without a concrete analysis of the causes of errors, and "overemphasizing individual responsibility", we cannot unite more people to work together, which is detrimental to the Party's cause. Secondly, there should be a correct policy for dealing with cadres who make mistakes. In response to Wang Ming and other "leftist" opportunists' policy of "brutal struggle", "ruthless blow", and "killing with one stick" towards cadres who make mistakes, Mao Zedong emphasized: "The purpose of us exposing errors and critiquing shortcomings is completely to help people, not to kill them. Treatment of ideological and political problems must not be taken recklessly, and should adopt 'cure the disease and save people', which is the correct and effective method." Mao Zedong further specified this policy of punishing the past and healing the people into the formula of "unity—critique—unity", which starts from the desire for unity, resolves contradictions through criticism or struggle, and achieves new unity on a new basis. The Chinese Communist Party was able to keep the majority of cadres closely united under the Party's banner and achieve one great victory after another precisely because it adhered to this correct policy. Finally, cadres who make mistakes should have a correct attitude towards their own mistakes. Any shortcomings and errors can cause harm to the party and the people. This requires leaders at all levels of the party to adopt a serious attitude in the face of mistakes, humbly accept the criticism and help of others, carefully summarize experiences and lessons and do a better job in the future. Mao Zedong has always advocated allowing others to make mistakes and to correct them. However, he is against concealing faults and persisting in mistakes, which not only "harms the group, but also harms the individual".

The construction of democratic centralism: The construction of democratic centralism is an important task in the party's organizational construction. Only by implementing democratic centralism can we establish a complete and strict organizational system of the party, and unite all party members and various organizations of the party into a unified whole. This can then correctly handle the relationship between party leaders and those being led, higher-level organizations with lower-level ones, individual party members with the party organization, realize normalization of internal political life in the party, and enhance the initiative of the entire party. This in turn can establish a scientific leadership system and work system, thereby formulating and implementing correct lines, principles, and policies, and realizing the correct leadership of the party.

As for the basic connotation of democratic centralism, the Party believes that democratic centralism combines democracy and leadership, and is the application of Marxist epistemology and the mass line in the party's life and organizational construction. This summary reflects the essential features of democratic centralism and clarifies the interrelation between democracy and centralism. In democratic centralism, democracy and centralism, as categories of party organization principles, are interdependent, mutually restrictive, and dialectically unified. Mao Zedong said, "Democratic centralism is democratic, and it is also centralized. It unifies two seemingly conflicting things in a certain form", "There is no impassable gorge between democracy and centralism". This dialectical relationship between democracy and centralism is specifically manifested in: on the one hand, democracy is the basis and premise of centralism. Without widespread democracy as the foundation, correct opinions cannot be centralized, and the enthusiasm of party members and the masses cannot be aroused. Such centralism can only be empty and false. Only centralism based on full democracy is correct and has authority. On the other hand, democracy is restricted by centralization and carried out under centralized guidance. Centralization is a requirement of democracy itself. Because only under centralized guidance can democracy have the correct direction, and the organization of the party and the initiative and creativity of the party can be better exerted. Without centralization, it is impossible to form a unified opinion, and it is difficult to get anything done, and democracy cannot be realized.



Therefore, when we emphasize the promotion of democracy, we must pay attention to maintaining the central unity of the party; when we emphasize centralization, we must also pay attention to taking democracy as the foundation. We cannot one-sidedly emphasize democracy or one-sidedly emphasize centralization. To adhere to the democratic centralism, we must oppose the two erroneous tendencies of personal arbitrary rule, patriarchal system, extreme democratization, and anarchism, and we must overcome the problems of insufficient democracy and insufficient centralization.

After the democratic centralism was written into the constitution as a guiding principle, our party's understanding of this principle is a continuous development process. Since 1927, looking at the party's history of building the party, we are certainly using democratic centralism to guide the party's organizational activities. However, there are not only extremely rich experiences but also profound lessons. In the party's historical documents, in the reports and works of Mao Zedong, Liu Shaoqi, Zhou Enlai, Deng Xiaoping, and others, a summary of the experiences and lessons has been theoretically summarized and concluded, gradually forming some basic viewpoints on this system that have been popular in the party for a long time.

First, democracy and centralization must be carried out simultaneously, and neither side can be neglected. This is the most basic viewpoint our party adopts in implementing the principle of democratic centralism. The Resolution of the Gutian Conference proposed the principle of strict democratic life under centralized guidance in the organization. This has organically unified democracy and centralization, showing the dialectical relationship between the two. By the Yan'an Rectification period, after learning Marxist-Leninist party-building theory and a deep summary of historical experience, we realized that "democratic centralism means both democracy and centralization. Without the leadership at the top and democracy at the bottom, anarchy will result, and no tasks will be well accomplished. On the contrary, if there is only leadership at the top but no democracy at the bottom, shortcomings cannot be exposed, and work cannot be improved".  Mao Zedong and Liu Shaoqi used the same two phrases-worded differently in the reports made by the Seventh National Congress of the Party, "Centralization based on democracy, and democracy under central guidance" to summarize the content of democratic centralism and explain the dialectical relationship between democracy and centralization. At the same time, they also pointed out that although the emphasis on democracy and centralization can vary in practice due to different conditions, neither can be neglected. Both the tendency towards extreme democratization and the tendency towards bureaucratic centralization are unacceptable. Since then, the party has established a party committee system during the war of liberation, established a system of reporting for approval, and improved the working methods of the party committee. All of these were made under the guidance of the aforementioned basic viewpoint.

Secondly, the "Four Subordinations" is an important principle of democratic centralism, and it is also our disciplinary principle and party spirit manifestation. The "Four Subordinations" is, in general, an important manifestation of the party's centralization, while "minority subordination to the majority" is also a reflection of the party's democratic system. In October 1938, Mao Zedong summarized historical experiences in his report at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Party, and concisely summarized party discipline as: individuals are subordinate to the organization; the minority is subordinate to the majority; lower levels are subordinate to higher levels; the party is subordinate to the central committee. At the same time, he pointed out that these "Four Subordinations" are also important principles of democratic centralism. The Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee of the Party accepted Mao Zedong's opinions and wrote them into the political resolution. In 1940, the Central Committee issued a "Decision on Enhanced Party Spirit," treating the "Four Subordinations" as an important manifestation of the party spirit, and called on the entire party to use it for self-checks and to correct violations of the "Four Subordinations." Hence, the viewpoint that the "Four Subordinations" is both a principle of democratic centrality and a discipline principle and party spirit manifestation was established in the entire party..


Starting from the seventh party congress, subsequent party constitutions have explicitly stipulated this.
Thirdly, we should pay more attention to the construction of inner-party democracy. Just as our party's strength was like "sparks of stars" in 1929, Chen Duxiu seized the fact that inner-party democracy was normally shrinking, and attacked and even slandered the Central Committee of the party by saying that it had completely abolished "minimal democracy"! At this time, the Central Committee rightly responded that the extent of party democratization is determined by objective and subjective conditions. If the objective white terror is extremely severe, and demands for democratization beyond what is possible, it is just a method for "helping Russian Tsar's constitutional police" (as Lenin once said). With the great improvement of the revolutionary situation, the fundamental change in objective conditions, Mao Zedong pointed out at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Party Congress in 1938: "Expanding inner-party democracy should be seen as a necessary step to consolidate and develop the party, and to make the party lively and active in the great struggle, fulfilling the task joyfully, creating new power, and breaking through the difficulties of war as a key weapon." By 1945, our party's view on promoting inner-party democracy as much as possible based on conditional permission had matured even more. At that time, Liu Shaoqi, based on the objective conditions in Yan’an and various liberated areas, stated in his report at the Seventh Congress of the Party: "Now it is necessary to let go and expand our party’s democratic life. We must implement high levels of inner-party democracy, and at the same time implement the party's leadership in highly centralized basis."

Based on the above fundamental views, the party emphasizes the necessity to handle the following relationships in implementing the principle of democratic centralism.
(1) The relationship between democracy and centralization.
The relationship between democracy and centralization in democratic centralism is a dialectical and unified relationship. They are two contradictory aspects of the same unity, they are contradictory, and they are also unified. Their contradiction lies in: democracy emphasizes the full free expression of individual will (before centralization), while centralization emphasizes the constraint of individual will by the will of the majority gathering together, emphasizing the individual will obedience. Their unity lies in: democracy is the method, foundation, and process of centralization, while centralization is the destination, result, and process of democracy. A correct concentration is inseparable from democracy, and true democracy cannot be without concentration. Concentration without democracy is a tree without roots, and democracy without concentration is a flower without fruit, both can't truly achieve unification of will and action.
Concentration without democracy is despotism. Despotism and arbitrariness, because they lack a democratic foundation and mass foundation, inevitably lead to individualism and anarchy in execution. Democracy without concentration is extreme democratization, which directly leads to anarchy. It can be seen that concentration without democracy and democracy without concentration, although different in approach, ultimately lead to anarchy.
In the process of the party's implementation of democratic centralism, there has been a tendency to split the two or even juxtapose them against each other, each emphasizing one aspect while denying the other, holding to one end.



Under normal circumstances, the emphasis on democracy by the public, individuals, and team members, and the emphasis on centralization by leaders, organizations, and secretaries are all aspects of one-sidedness. Some practice pragmatism in implementing the democratic centralism system, emphasizing democracy to superiors and centralization to subordinates. Some only pay attention to the unity of the form of democracy and centralization, and sever the content of the two. Formally, democracy is followed by centralization, the masses are democratic, the leadership is centralized, the members are democratic, the secretaries are centralized, but the will of centralization is not the will of the majority of people in the democratic process, but the personal will of the leaders. This form of democratic centralism also violates the democratic centralism, and it is impossible to really unify the will.

(2) The relationship between individuals and organizations.
The individual members of the party are subject to the party's organization, which is an important principle of party life. The individual party member is an element that constitutes the organization, and the organization is the sum of individual party members, but it is not as simple as simple addition. Party members obey the party's organization to achieve unity of will and consistency of action. Only when each party member's will is fully expressed and the initiative, positivity, and creativity are fully exploited, can the organization have vitality and achieve the real unity of will and action. Therefore, the submission of party members to the organization should be based on democracy. Democratic decision-making, unified action, this is an accurate summary of the relationship between individual party members and the party's organization. In dealing with the relationship between individuals and organizations, there are problems with some party members not obeying the organization's decisions and not implementing resolutions. There are also situations where some party members are unable to fully express their will and blindly obey. In the life of the party, ordinary party members often take a negative attitude towards the decisions of the organization, and cadre party members often consider themselves special members, refusing to execute or even arbitrarily changing organizational resolutions. This is not permitted by the principle of organization and organizational discipline.

(3) The relationship between the minority and the majority.
The minority obeys the majority, which is the most basic principle of the democratic centralism system. Implementing the principle of democratic centralism requires thorough adherence to the principle of minority obeying the majority, which can prevent authoritative decision-making, power decision-making, and arbitrariness. But because humans' understanding of truth is not linear but curved, truth is often first discovered by a few. Therefore, the minority and the majority are mutually transformable. Therefore, in implementing democratic centralism and handling the relationship between the minority and the majority, the correct principle is to obey the majority and respect the minority.
In the life of the party and leadership work, violating the principle of minority obedience to the majority, ordinary party members and a few members often fail to obey the decisions made by the organization according to the will of the majority during the process of implementing decisions, and party member cadres and secretaries often make major issues personal. The principle of obeying the majority is violated. To strictly implement the principle of minority obeying majority, it is very important to implement a voting system for major issues on the basis of full democratic discussion.



(4) Relationship between lower-level and higher-level organizations.
Lower-level organizations obey the higher-level organizations, which is an important organizational principle of the party. However, such obedience is not blind. Before making decisions about the lower-level organizations, higher-level organizations should fully listen to the opinions of the lower-level organizations and try to achieve consistency between the two levels. During implementation, if the lower-level organizations have different opinions, the higher-level organizations should listen humbly and make appropriate adjustments or handle ideological and political work. Therefore, the correct way to handle the relationship between the two is to obey the higher-level organization while respecting the lower-level organization, so that they can coordinate and be consistent. In the party life and leadership work, there are frequent cases where higher-level organizations disrespect lower-level organizations, and lower-level organizations do not obey higher-level organizations. Certain higher-level organizations, when making decisions on major issues, neither investigate nor listen to the opinions of the lower-level organizations. This decision-making approach, characterized by subjectivism, bureaucracy, condescension, and arbitrary commands, does not conform to reality and causes resistance in the lower-level organizations, rendering the resolutions unenforceable. Some lower-level organizations do not understand the overall requirements, some even act based on local interests, adopting a pragmatic attitude towards the decisions of the higher-level organization - implementing advantageous policies and refusing to implement disadvantageous ones with the excuse that they do not conform to reality, or arbitrarily changing the decisions of the higher-level organization. These do not comply with the party's organizational principles.

(5) Relationship between all party organizations and the central committee.
All party organizations obey the central committee, which is the most important principle in the basic principles of democratic centralism. In this relationship, the central committee respects the innovative spirit of all party organizations and actively solicits their opinions and suggestions. All organizations must strictly obey the central committee and, under the premise of conscientiously implementing the central committee's line, guiding principles, policies, and resolutions, execute them creatively in accordance with the reality of their unit, department, or region. In the party life and leadership work, some party organizations refuse to execute the central committee's policies and decisions based on their local interests. Some even brazenly defy the central committee's decisions under the banner of "grounded in reality and executing creatively," which is not permitted by the party's political discipline.

(6) Relationship between collective leadership and individual division of responsibility.
The system of collective leadership and individual division of responsibility is an important system of democratic centralism and an important leadership system of the party. Collective leadership and individual division of responsibility are both indispensable. The principle of collective leadership is the work system of the party committee.



In the leadership work of the Party, all major matters related to the Party's line, principles, and policies, the deployment of major tasks, the appointment, dismissal, mobilization and handling of cadres, and major issues related to the interests of the masses must be collectively discussed and decided by the Party committee, and must not be arbitrarily determined by individuals or a minority. In the execution of decisions and in the daily work of the Party, the system of individual division of labor and responsibility must be implemented. For decisions made collectively, responsibility and authority should be allocated, tasks should be carried out separately, and everyone should be responsible for their own tasks. Those who neglect their duty should be held accountable. 

Without collective leadership, the scientific and authoritative nature of decisions cannot be guaranteed, and even because of the lack of restriction by the collective, there could be personal arbitrariness, and personal gains can be sought in the decision-making of major issues. Without the system of individual division of labor and responsibility, the collective decision could be shelved due to unclear responsibilities, and no one would be accountable, making it impossible to implement. Mao Zedong made a succinct summary of collective leadership and personal division of responsibility: "Great powers are centralized, small powers are decentralized; Party committees decide, all sides go to work, they have decisions in their work, they don't deviate from the principles, check the work, and the Party committees are responsible." This has important guiding significance in handling the relationship between collective leadership and individual division of responsibility by the Party committee.

In dealing with the relationship between collective leadership and individual responsibility, there are often major problems and it is difficult to distinguish them from daily work, resulting in issues that should have been collectively decided not being decided collectively, which weakens collective leadership, affects the decision-making level, and results in decision-making errors. Problems that should not be collectively decided are collectively decided, which causes inefficiency in work operation. Both of these situations should be avoided as much as possible.

The responsibilities of the Party committee's collective leadership can be summarized according to the principle of scientific leadership: defining goals, establishing norms, delegating authority, supervising and inspecting, responding to randomness, solving difficulties, conducting research, and creating conditions. This should be the focus of collective leadership.

On the basis of correctly handling the above relationships, the Party has proposed the following basic ideas and approaches to adhering to and improving democratic centralism in practice: (1) Strengthening the education on the Party's democratic centralism and enhancing the consciousness of implementing democratic centralism.

In the construction of the Party's democratic centralism, some Party members and Party organizations have weak perceptions about the Party, the concept of Party spirit, and the idea of the Party's organizational discipline, which is an important ideological cause for the weak implementation of democratic centralism. Therefore, it is necessary to strengthen the education on the Party's democratic centralism, with a focus on educating Party members and cadres on the Party's concept, the concept of Party spirit, and the concept of the Party's organizational discipline, so as to enhance the consciousness of implementing democratic centralism.

In the education on the Party's concept, Party members and cadres should clearly understand the core leadership status and key role of the Party. The Party has a core leadership status in its relationship with other organizations. The Party plays a key role in the progress and development of the revolutionary cause. This status and role of the Party determine the extreme importance of adhering to democratic centralism, realizing the unity of the Party's organization, will, and action. It should be made clear that only Party members and cadres who recognize the Party's core leadership and key role can consciously implement the principles of democratic centralism.

In the education of the Party spirit, Party members and cadres should understand: The Party takes the working class and the broad masses of the people as its own class basis, represents the interests of the majority of the people, strives for the interests of the majority, sacrifices their personal interests for the benefits of the majority, and sacrifices local interests for the overall interests. This is the purpose of the Party and the embodiment of Party spirit.


Only with a clear sense of the Party's mission, and Party members and cadres who possess a high level of Party consciousness, can we conscientiously adhere to the four obediences within the organization and not distort these relationships due to personal or local interests. In terms of education on Party organizational discipline, it is necessary to help Party members and cadres to correctly understand the four obediences. Even when their ideological consciousness and Party awareness have not yet reached a conscious level, they still need to follow organizational principles and accept the constraints of organizational discipline.

(2) Effectively strengthen the construction of the democratic centralism system. 
In the construction of the Party's democratic centralism, system construction is another weak link. Due to the lack of detailed system, standards and procedures for democratic centralism basic principles and fundaments in the Party's life and leadership work, it is inconvenient for Party members and cadres to follow, and also inconvenient for the organization to operate and supervise. Therefore, it's important to establish a set of clear, comprehensive systems, standards and procedures to provide reliable institutional guarantees for democratic centralism. This includes specification of the election system, rules, and procedures, and maintaining and implementing the election rights of party members, the democratic rights of party members, etc. The work decision-making system includes collective leadership system, important issue deliberation system, decision-making process, voting system, and so on. The supervision and inspection system includes the reporting system for major issues and the supervision and inspection system for decision execution, among others.

(3) A working adjustment mechanism must be established to implement the principles of democratic centralism.
In decision-making implementation, it is necessary to both prevent distortion and ensure creativity instead of mechanical implementation. To achieve this, a working adjustment mechanism must be established. Without a sound work adjustment mechanism, some party members and lower-level organizations may interpret and innovate according to their own understanding, which can have considerable arbitrariness and sometimes lead to inaccurate judgments affecting the correct execution of decisions. Therefore, to organically combine implementation with creativity in the implementation of democratic centralism, a work adjustment mechanism must be established.

(4) Improve the oversight and restraint mechanisms, and strictly enforce organizational discipline.



Supervision and discipline enforcement is the ultimate safeguard mechanism of democratic centralism. Only by integrating the principle of democratic centralism into effective supervision and by reprimanding and punishing those who violate democratic centralism can the other conditions for the implementation of democratic centralism play an effective role and form a guiding mechanism. Supervision and discipline enforcement are not only the guarantee conditions for the implementation of democratic centralism but also are powerful means and safeguard mechanisms for leadership and management. The Central Party Committee requires that every leader and manager learn to use this mechanism to implement leadership and management work, and promote the development of various undertakings. Building of Party Members
The building of party members is the foundation of party organization construction. The party is made up of party members, who are the basis of the party and the main body to implement the party's line. Strengthening the building of party members has significant importance for consolidating the party organization, maintaining the vanguard nature of the party's working-class, enhancing the relationship between the party and the masses, and fully realizing the leading role of the party. Therefore, in the construction of the party organization, the building of party members occupies a very important position.
From the establishment of the Communist Party of China in 1921 to the failure of the Great Revolution in 1927, it was the initial stage of the construction of the party members and the birth period of the theory of party members' construction. At the time of the first national congress of the Chinese Communist Party, there were only over 50 members. With the need for anti-imperialist and anti-feudal revolutionary struggles, the party seized the opportunity to expand party members and establish party organizations, constantly expanding the team of party members. By September 1927, the number had grown to 57,967, giving the team of party members an initial scale. However, due to the infancy period of our party, it showed its immaturity in terms of party members' construction. This mainly manifested in: firstly, the unbalanced development of party members. Judging from the distribution of party members in April 1927, most were concentrated in the southern provinces such as Hubei, Hunan, Zhejiang, and Guangdong, and there were fewer party members in the northern provinces. The proportion of workers was more, and there were fewer party members from other labor classes. There were more male members and fewer female members. Secondly, the discussion on the theory of party members' construction was limited to the development of party members and the education of party members, and overlooked the importance of developing party members among farmers and soldiers. Thirdly, Chen Duxiu believed that "the increase in the number of party members is the first important issue". If "we don't rush to increase the number of party members, it is negligence of the party, and it is a reactionary act". This wrong guiding ideology led to the blind pursuit of quantity over quality in the development of party members. This is an important lesson from the construction of party members during this period. After the failure of the Great Revolution in 1927, the party suffered a terribly heavy defeat. Many Communist Party members and revolutionary masses were brutally killed, and the number of party members dropped from over 57,000 to about 10,000. The revolution was in extreme danger. At the critical juncture of the Chinese Revolution, the party held the August 7 Conference, corrected Chen Duxiu's right-leaning mistakes, and established the overall policy of land revolution and armed resistance to the reactionary Kuomintang. Subsequently, rural revolutionary bases were established, opening the road to surround the cities from the countryside and to seize power by force, and the focus of party work shifted from cities to rural areas. Building the party in rural areas and the Red Army were new problems encountered in the history of Marxist party building. Representatives of the Chinese Communist Party, led by Mao Zedong, with an extraordinary pioneering spirit, successfully solved the problem of party member construction in theory and practice. However, during this period, "a part of the party's leadership did not manage to hold the correct political line and organizational line throughout this stage", and the party suffered the damage of "left- leaning" mistakes. Especially Wang Ming's "left-" leaning mistakes almost destroyed the Chinese revolution.


In terms of the party member team construction, the main manifestations of Wang Ming's "leftist" mistakes were: the development of party members' "only factor theory"; the indexation and rush of party member collection; in the party life, he practiced patriarchy and implemented "brutal struggle" and "relentless attack" from inside the party. Due to Wang Ming's "left" error, the party suffered severe losses.
Therefore, from the party's 1921 Eighth Seventh Conference to the 1935 Zunyi Conference, it was a period of tortuous development of the Communist Party of China’s member team, and also a period when the theoretical formation of the party member team construction. The Zunyi Conference, held in 935, ended the "left" erroneous rule of Wang Ming in the CPC Central Committee and established the correct leadership of the new Central represented by Mao Zedong, thus enabling the construction of the CPC member team to get on the right track. The Sixth Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee, held in 1938, established the party's Marxist organizational line, and changes to the party's organization, marked the completion of the party's organizational work transition since the Zunyi Conference, especially since the outbreak of the Anti-Japanese War. After the war of resistance entered the stalemate stage, by 1941, the construction work of the CPC member team was widely deployed, and the theory of party member team construction was further enriched and developed. From the preparation of the Yan'an Rectification Movement in May 1941 to the Seventh Plenary Session of the Sixth Central Committee in 1944, the construction of the party member team is closely linked with the Rectification Movement, indicating the deep development of the CPC party member team construction. After the successful convening of the Seventh Party Congress in April 1945, the construction of the CPC party member team formed a complete theoretical system. 
From the victory of the Anti-Japanese War in August 1945 to the establishment of the People's Republic of China on October 1, 1949, this period was an unprecedented period of grand development of the CPC party member team, as well as a period when the theoretical perfection of the party member team construction. During this period, the party, in order to win the victory of the Chinese People's War of Liberation, made some major decisions on the construction of the party members team, thereby strengthening the party's organization and enhancing the party's combat effectiveness. 
The basic experience of party member team construction in the New Democratic Revolution period is: First, the construction of the party member team must be carried out under the condition of adhering to the vanguard nature of the proletariat. In China, where there are a very small number of the proletariat and the peasants and other petty bourgeoisie make up the vast majority of the population, the construction of a mass proletarian party is a very difficult task. The Chinese Communist Party, represented by Mao Zedong, has put forward a party building line suitable to China's condition: "Firstly, it emphasizes ideological and political construction, while also focusing on organizational construction." That is to say, the construction of the party is not purely concerned with the class component of the party members, but with the proletarian transformation in the ideology of the party members and overcoming various non-proletarian ideologies. Under the guidance of this correct party building line, during the Democratic Revolution, the party overcame the non-proletarian ideology existing among party members through strengthen ideological construction. The large number of party members are trained to be strong proletarian vanguard soldiers, and the party is built into a mass, strong proletarian party.
Second, in the work of attracting party members, it is necessary to properly handle the relationship between quantity and quality. In the work of developing party members, quantity and quality are two contradictory aspects, and they are dialectically unified. On the one hand, the work of developing party members cannot go without a certain number and rules. The arduous task of the Chinese revolution requires the Chinese Communist Party to have enough strength to undertake the important task of leading the Chinese revolution. Therefore, the party must continually add fresh blood, and conscientiously and prudently incorporating outstanding elements who meet the conditions into the party's organization. On the other hand, the work of developing party members should also pay attention to quality.



Because the quality of party members directly affects the nature of the party, which is directly related to the implementation of the party's line, principles, and policies and the play of its leading role. Therefore, the quality issue is the core of the development of party member work and cannot talk about the growth in the number of party members without considering the quality. During the democratic revolution, the successful experience of our party was: to develop quantity based on ensuring the quality of party members, never pursue quantity one-sidedly and neglect quality.

Third, the development of the party's organization must follow the correct guidelines. During the democratic revolution, there were two error tendencies concerning the development of party members: one is laissez-faire and disregard for quality; the other is separatism, rejecting people who apply for party membership and meet the conditions of becoming party members. These two tendencies have hindered the normal development of the party. In the struggle against these two tendencies, our party proposed the correct guideline of "boldly develop and don't let a bad element in", which both overcame separatism and greatly developed the party's organization while maintaining the purity of the party. 

Fourth, to improve the party's combat effectiveness, it is necessary to seriously carry out party member education. Through education, party members are expected: In terms of thought, to strengthen party spirit, firmly establish a revolutionary worldview; politically, to be loyal to the party, firm in stance, willing to sacrifice everything personally and never betray the party; organizationally, to enhance party consciousness, perform party member duties, maintain party unity, strictly observe party discipline; in work, to be proficient in business, work actively, and dedicate to serving the people. Party member education runs through the entire history of the party, must submit to and serve the party's line and central work, must be based on helping party members establish a proletarian worldview, and must strengthen education at historical turning points. The guideline, way, and method of education are to adhere to the principle of linking theory with practice, layering education, self-direction, tightening the party's organizational life, and collectively carrying out party rectification, etc.

The rich experience accumulated over a long period of revolutionary struggle, enrich and improve the theory and policy of the party's team building.

Firstly, the correct guideline for party member team building has been formulated. That is, the guideline of "boldly develop and not let a bad person in". Overcoming the "separatist tendency", and to improve the "vigilance against spies and opportunists taking the opportunity to infiltrate". The long-term guiding principle of party member team building, is what Mao Zedong proposed, "The Communist Party should display its high positivity in the national war; and this positivity, should be specifically displayed in all aspects, that is, it should play a pioneering and exemplary role in all aspects." Communist Party members should be "models of bravery, command execution, discipline adherence, political work, and internal unity"; models of extreme honesty, non-use of private, more work, less reward; models of seeking truth from facts, far-sighted models, learning models. Only when Communist party members "highly play their pioneering and exemplary role, can mobilize all the vitality of the nation, and struggle to overcome difficulties, defeat enemies, and build New China".

Secondly, the standard for Communist Party members has been specifically and accurately proposed. That is, fight for communism all the life; the interests of the revolution are above all else; abide by party rules, strictly serve party secrets; perseverance in implementing decisions; role model for the masses; learning. Chen Yun believes that only those who meet the above six conditions are worthy of being a good Communist Party member and will not tarnish the great and glorious title of party members.



Thirdly, the issue of "party members" was comprehensively and scientifically elaborated. In the Party Constitution adopted at the Seventh Congress of the Party, the "party member" section consists of 13 articles, including the basic conditions for party membership, the obligations of party members, the rights of party members, the development of party members, and issues related to party members leaving or withdrawing from the party. Among them, the obligations and rights of party members are stipulated for the first time. The Party Constitution stipulates that the obligations of party members are: ① to strive to improve their consciousness and understanding of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought; ② to strictly abide by party discipline, actively participate in the political life within the party and the revolutionary movement within the country, implement the policies and resolutions of the Party and its organizations in practice, and struggle against all phenomena that harm the interests of the Party both inside and outside the Party; ③ to serve the people, consolidate the connection between the Party and the people, understand and timely reflect the needs of the people, and explain the policies of the Party to the people; ④ to model adherence to the discipline of the revolutionary government and revolutionary organizations, master their own businesses, and play a model role in various revolutionary professions. The rights of party members are: ① to participate in free and practical discussions on the implementation of party policies at party meetings or in party publications; ② the right to vote and be elected within the party; ③ to propose suggestions and statements to any organ of the party up to the central level; ④ to criticize any staff of the party at party meetings. The above provisions not only show that the Party's requirements for party members are higher and the democracy within the Party is more abundant, but also show the maturity of the Party.
 
Fourthly, the theory of Party member cultivation was established. During this period, Liu Shaoqi, combining the actual situation of the Chinese Communist Party leading the revolutionary struggle, carried out a long-term and fruitful study and exploration of the issue of Party member cultivation, and formed a complete and systematic theory unique to the Chinese Communist Party on Party member cultivation. He proposed the necessity of Party members' Party spirit cultivation; the content of Party spirit cultivation and the basic ways of Party spirit cultivation and so on. 

Fifth, the problem of party member education was successfully solved. ① The main content of education within the party: one is to carry out education on Marxism-Leninism, class and party within the party, so that party members can understand the correct relationship between Marxism-Leninism and Three Principles of the People (San Min Zhu Yi), the unified national front and class struggle, and the national and class positions. The second is to carry out education in historical materialism, so that party members can truly understand "the laws of human social historical development and the inevitable future of communist society", understand "the historical position and role of the proletariat in society, understand the interests of the proletariat and its great cause of liberating all mankind, and foresee the current tasks and fundamental goals of the Communist Party and its members". The third is to carry on education that revolution interests are above all else, to make party members actually "put the interests of the revolutionary party first, and handle all personal issues with the principle of prioritizing the revolution and party interests". The fourth is party discipline education, which makes party members "strictly abide by the basic principles where individuals obey the organization, minorities obey the majority, lower levels obey higher ones, and the whole party obeys the center". Five is education for party cadres at all levels, mainly "to effectively improve cadres' political level and work competence." ② Forms of Marxist ideological education. The Central Committee believes that the Rectification Movement is a good form for carrying out Marxist ideological education. On the one hand, it involves the serious study of Marxist writings and the files of the Central Committee, constantly improving the theoretical level of party members and achieving ideological unity; on the other hand, it involves linking theory with practice, carrying out serious criticism and self-criticism, overcoming various non-proletarian ideologies, and establishing a proletarian worldview. ③ The standardization of party school education problem. The Central Committee believes that party schools are important positions for cultivating party leaders and theoretical cadres at all levels. On this, the Central Committee stipulates: The basic task of party schools at all levels is "to educate cadres with the theory and practice of Marxism-Leninism"; teaching methods "should be from less to more, from simple to complex, from China to foreign countries, from concrete to abstract principles, in order to achieve the purpose that students can truly understand what they have learned". Learning methods should adopt the principle of mainly individual study guided by instructors, supplemented by collective study in groups.



The Sixth, the issue of the working attitude of party members and party cadres. In October 1945, Mao Zedong clarified the correct attitude that party members and party cadres should have towards work regarding the issue of a large number of party members and cadres in Yan'an heading to the front line. He pointed out, "What is work, work is struggle. Where there are difficulties, problems, we need to go and solve them. We are fighting to solve the difficulties. The more difficult places require more attention, that's what a good comrade would do." He called on party members and cadres to "enjoy giving to others, pick the heavier burdens, endure hardships before others, and enjoy after others." He required all party members going to the front line to be mentally prepared, ready to "root and blossom among the people," "establish good relationships with the masses, care for them, and help them solve their difficulties." At the same time, "tell the people, tell comrades, the road is tortuous," "prepare for a tortuous path," "we face many difficulties ahead, we cannot ignore them," and "overcome all difficulties to reach the goal of victory."
