The fourth is to define it from the perspective of the history of the Party's internal line struggle, pointing out that Mao Zedong Thought is not only formed and developed in the struggle against enemies at home and abroad, but also in the principle struggle against various erroneous opportunistic thoughts within the Party, "It is the only correct guiding thought of our Party, the only correct general line". Liu Shaoqi also pointed out: "There have been countless historical facts in the past to prove that when the revolution is guided by Comrade Mao Zedong and his thought, the revolution will be victorious and progressive; while when the revolution departs from the guidance of Comrade Mao Zedong and his thought, the revolution will fail and regress." Liu Shaoqi's comments, which conform to the objective laws of the formation and development of Mao Zedong Thought, correctly explain the relationship between Mao Zedong Thought and Marxism in terms of individuality and commonality, between learning and application and innovative development, and between its advancement and regression, success and failure in the Chinese revolutionary struggle, and therefore also provide proof of the necessity and need to establish the guiding position of Mao Zedong Thought.



Thirdly, the report outlines the main content of the thought system of Mao Zedong. Liu Shaoqi pointed out that Mao's thought, as the complete revolutionary and nation-building theory of the Chinese people, "is manifested in various works of Comrade Mao Zedong and many party documents. This includes Comrade Mao Zedong's analysis on the modern world situation and China's national conditions, his theories and policies on New Democracy, on liberating peasants, on the united front of revolution, on revolutionary wars, on revolutionary base areas, on building the New Democratic Republic, on party building, and on culture, etc." These theories and policies, are the "greatest expression of Chinese national wisdom and the highest abstraction in theory." The report summarized nine aspects of Mao's thought, which constitute the New Democratic theory system with Chinese characteristics, answering questions such as what kind of revolution China will carry out, how to carry out this revolution, and what kind of country to establish after the revolution. This is the main achievement of the first historical leap of Sinicization of Marxism.

Fourthly, the report calls for "launching a movement to study Mao's thought within the party", to welcome the "climax of Marxist culture". This is a call to push forward the cause of Sinicization of Marxism. 

Liu Shaoqi's scientific exposition of Mao's thought is an important milestone in the history of the Chinese Communist Party's understanding of Marxist theory and Mao's thought. If the establishment of Mao's thought reached the highest level of Sinicized Marxism of that time, then Liu Shaoqi's scientific explication of Mao's thought also reached the highest level of the Party's understanding of Mao's thought at that time. Despite some discrepancies in statements, terminology, and even analysis, its profoundly logical analysis and argumentation have made irreplaceable unique contributions to establishing the guiding position of Mao's thought in the Party and promoting the better understanding and grasping of this theoretical system by the whole party.

The preamble of the Constitution of the Communist Party of China adopted by the Seventh Party Congress clearly states: "The Communist Party of China, with the ideation of the unity of Marxist-Leninist theory and the practice of Chinese revolution - Mao Zedong Thought, takes it as the pointer of all its work and opposes any dogmatic or empiricist tendencies." This historic decision is the most authoritative confirmation of the great achievements of the first historic leap in the Sinicization of Marxism.

It should be noted that the naming of the party's guiding thought after Mao Zedong's name is mainly due to the needs of the party and is closely related to the understanding of the relationship between "Mao Zedong Thought" and "Comrade Mao Zedong's thought". At the time, throughout the party, including Liu Shaoqi's report, there was no distinction between the two, that is, there was no special attention to the relationship between personal creation and collective wisdom, and "Mao Zedong Thought" was equated with "Comrade Mao Zedong's thought". However, it should be pointed out that Mao Zedong himself did not consider Mao Zedong Thought to be solely his personal creation. He explicitly expressed this understanding at the Seventh Central Committee of the Sixth Party Congress and the Preparatory Meeting of the Seventh Party Congress. At the Seventh Plenary Session of the Party, when explaining the draft of the Historical Resolution, he stated: "The resolution credits me with many good deeds, I don’t oppose it, but it doesn’t deny that I have shortcomings and mistakes. They just aren't mentioned for the benefit of the party." In his speech on the guidelines for the conference work at the preparatory meeting of the Seventh Party Congress, he said, “All the good deeds are credited to me in the resolution, so I want to express my opinion on this. If it’s written as representatives, that’s acceptable. If it’s only me, that won't represent the party.” Not only that, he also did not advocate equating himself with the founders of Marxism-Leninism.



In the process of formulating the concept of "Mao Zedong Thought," Mao Zedong stated in a letter to He Kaifeng, the acting Minister of the Propaganda Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China: "My thought (Marxist-Leninist) is not yet mature, it is still in its learning phase, not at its propagandizing stage. If propagandizing has to be done, it should be about certain sections (such as a few from the rectification documents), and not be propagandized as a system, because my system has not yet matured." In August 1948, Wu Yuzhang, president of North China University, sent a telegram to the central government, suggesting that at the school's opening ceremony, he would propose "mainly learning Mao Zedong-ism," and "changing Mao Zedong Thought to Mao Zedong-ism." Mao Zedong replied that "Such a statement is highly inappropriate. There is no Mao Zedong-ism for now; so one cannot talk about Mao Zedong-ism. It is not mainly about 'studying Mao Zedong-ism,' but rather, we must call on students to study Marxist-Leninist theories and China's revolutionary experiences. The so-called 'Chinese revolutionary experiences' include some pamphlets written by Chinese communists (including Mao Zedong) based on Marxist-Leninist theories and the party's central policies and directives. Furthermore, some comrades have erroneously placed my name alongside Marx and Lenin, saying 'Marx, Engels, Lenin, Stalin, Mao.' This is incorrect. Both your statement and the later one are not in line with reality, and are unbeneficial and harmful, and must be firmly opposed." At the Second Plenary Session of the 7th Central Committee in March 1949, Mao Zedong again emphasized that "the Chinese Communist Party members should not be listed alongside Marx, Engels, Lenin, and Stalin." All these show that Mao Zedong himself had a clear understanding of the term "Mao Zedong Thought."

Around the time of the Party's 7th National Congress, to cater to the needs of the whole party to study Mao Zedong Thought, various volumes of the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" were published successively in Anti-Japanese Base Areas and Liberated Areas. Before that, from 1927 to 1943, multiple individual versions of Mao Zedong's writings, thematic collections, and dissertations were published, and some of his works were included in the party's documentary collections "After the Sixth Congress," "Before the Sixth Congress," and "The Two Routes." This facilitated the compilation of Mao Zedong's selected works. The first edition of the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" was compiled and published by the Shanxi-Chahar-Hebei Daily in 1944, divided into 5 volumes, over 400,000 words, including 29 written pieces by Mao Zedong, primarily writings from the period of the Anti-Japanese War. The objective of publishing this book, as stated by the Shanxi-Chahar-Hebei Daily, was "to implement Mao Zedong Thought throughout the party in the border areas." Only with the guidance of Mao Zedong Thought can the Chinese revolution achieve victory, so it is necessary for both party insiders and outsiders to deeply study Mao Zedong Thought. Based on this collection, Dalian Mass Bookstore slightly modified it and published a five-volume set of the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" in 1946; the Central Bureau of Shanxi-Chahar-Hebei revised and published a six-volume edition of the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" and a sequel in 1947. Later, the Northeast Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China published a six-volume set of the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" (hardcover edition was six combined volumes)under the name of the Northeast Bookstore in 1948. This is another significant collection of Mao Zedong's writings, which includes 50 articles by Mao Zedong from March 1927 to December 1947, totaling more than 800,000 words. Besides the above works, on the eve of the victory of the War of Resistance in 1945, the Subei Publishing House published a selection entitled the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong." The collection started with eight pieces discussing Mao Zedong thought by Zhu De, Zhou Enlai, Liu Shaoqi, and others. Titled "On Mao Zedong Thought," it served as the preface of the collection. In 1948, the Shanxi-Hebei-Henan-Shandong Central Bureau of the Communist Party of China compiled and published the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" as an "internal party document," which included 61 articles by Mao Zedong split into two volumes. Arranged by the "Period of the Great Revolution," the "Period of the Civil War," and "Since the War of Resistance," totaling more than 900,000 words, it was the most substantial and richest of all the selections of Mao Zedong's works published before the founding of the People's Republic of China. The publication of various versions of the "Selected Works of Mao Zedong" served as the textbook for the whole party to study Mao Zedong Thought, and played an active role in promoting the study and propagation of Mao Zedong Thought in all base areas and liberated areas.



Section 2: Strategic Thinking on the Transition from Rural to Urban Areas
I. The Historical Conditions for the Proposal of Strategic Thinking on Transitioning from Rural to Urban

China's societal and historical conditions determined that the new democratic revolution had to follow the path of rural areas surrounding cities. The timely realization of the transition from rural to urban areas is a fundamental guarantee for carrying out the revolution to the end and seizing and consolidating nationwide victory. In the second half of 1947, the Chinese People's Liberation War reached a turning point, and the People's Liberation Army entered a nationwide scale attack, disrupting Chiang Kai-shek's plan to continue the war towards the liberated areas and attempt to thoroughly destroy the liberated areas. Mao Zedong noted this as a critical turning point in history; it marked a transition from the development to elimination of Chiang Kai-shek's twenty-year anti-revolutionary rule and the hundred year long period of imperialistic rule in China. This was a major event. In October 1947, in the "Declaration of the Chinese People's Liberation Army," Mao Zedong solemnly issued the great call to "Defeat Chiang Kai-shek and liberate all of China" and deeply pointed out: "We now bear the most important and glorious task in the history of our country's revolution. We should actively strive to complete our task." It was under these historical conditions that the Party Central Committee promptly proposed to pay attention to and strengthen urban work, start the issues of political and strategic transformation, and urban work became one of the important agenda items of the Party Central Committee. In February 1948, the Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee requested to "not focus the Party’s attention on war and rural work, but guide it to urban work." In September, the enlarged meeting of the Central Political Bureau explicitly proposed to "strengthen the management of cities and industries, and gradually shift the focus of party work from rural to urban." From the end of 1948 to the beginning of 1949, the CPC Central Committee issued many specific instructions on policy issues such as military control, organization of city representatives, disposal of urban real estate, wages, prices, factory resumption, and reception of cultural and educational institutions, indicating that the focus of the party's work had begun to shift from rural to urban. In March 1949, the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee of the CPC pointed out more explicitly: "From 1927 till now, the emphasis of our work has been in rural areas, gathering strength in rural areas, using rural areas to surround cities, and then gaining cities. The era adopting this approach is now over. Starting from now, we are entering the period from city to rural and city-led rural...The focus of the party's work must be in cities. We must make great efforts to learn how to manage and construct cities."

In the face of the glorious historical task, the Communist Party of China once again demonstrated great theoretical courage and fearless revolutionary mettle, promoting and developing the theory and practice of New Democracy, forming and developing a strategic thinking on the transition from rural to urban.

II. The Timely Establishment of the View that Urban Work is the Center of the Party's Work

Given that cities have always been the focus of imperialism and reactionary rule in China, the reluctant to admit defeat enemy would surely fight us hard with various means, Mao Zedong specifically pointed out: after we enter the cities, we must learn to wage political, economic, and cultural struggles against imperialists, the KMT, and the bourgeoisie in these cities, and conduct diplomatic struggles against imperialists. In these urban struggles, we must fully rely on the working class, unite other laboring masses, win over intellectuals, strive to have as many nationalist capitalists as possible who can cooperate with us and their representatives on our side, or make them remain neutral, so as to defeat the enemy step by step. At the same time, Mao Zedong emphasized: we must make great efforts to learn how to manage and build cities.

From the first day we took over the city, our eyes have been directed towards the restoration and development of the city's production industry; all other work in the city is centered around and serves this core work of production construction. Similarly, in all old liberated areas, the central task of the party is "to mobilize all forces to restore and develop the production industry, and this is where the focus of all work lies".

Under the guidance of the above strategies and policies, the Communist Party of China has extensively articulated strategic thoughts on leading urban work. In the process of taking over cities, Liu Shaoqi pointed out the need for a perspective that unifies both urban and rural areas. In the past we only had rural areas, now with the addition of cities, i.e., the addition of large industries, state-owned enterprises (of a socialist nature), state capitalism, urban-rural relations, and other new issues. If we want to direct the party's work as a whole with city work at the center, we need to think about and cater to these problems. The 'single-minded' approach must change, otherwise mistakes will be made. He believes that there are two issues that need to be resolved regarding the takeover of cities: one is the resumption of work in private enterprises, and the other is the rapid arrangement after takeover of enterprises, handing them over to appropriate authorities for normal production operations. The issue of city management post-takeover has not been fundamentally resolved yet. After the second plenary session of the Communist Party, everyone should try hard to learn how to solve this. In addition to receiving well, managing well, and transforming are also necessary. Some old things need to be discarded, but not too much, and new things need to grow. To build up the city, develop production, is to manage well. That makes workers and peasants approach each other. The power to rely on for urban work is the working class, Liu Shaoqi emphasized. In regard to the issue of city management, Chairman Mao put forward the question of who to rely on and what to do. Chairman Mao's answer was to rely on workers, to develop production. The workers are must to rely on. But, are workers reliable? Marxism believes that the working class is the most reliable. This is generally speaking. Specifically speaking, there are also issues. Therefore, we must strive to make the working class fully reliable. If we neglect and rely on workers without doing work, it is not reliable. Our party had a strong connection with workers in the past but was forced to move to the countryside later. The Kuomintang has been active among workers for so many years and has spread influence, it has complicated the inner side of workers; and our connection with workers has weakened, and we are unfamiliar with the workers' looks. So we must strive to learn, always pay attention to Chairman Mao's directives about relying on workers, strengthen the worker's work, and make workers fully reliable. There are three main methods: Try our best to guarantee the living standard of workers and not let it be too low; widely and deeply educate workers; organize workers. Deng Zihui pointed out the trend towards certain mistakes that appeared during the early phase of entering the city: It is very necessary for Chairman Mao to clearly affirm that the focus of future work will shift to the city, rely on the working class after entering the city, and urgently restore and develop production.



Who to rely on after entering the city and being vague in thought, Zhengzhou and Kaifeng first target the poor and hard labourers, forgetting industrial workers. This is a common phenomenon, and the idea of relying on the working class is unclear. The focus of urban work is to resume production, which I did not understand in the past and thought that production should be handled after the workers are mobilized; if the life issues of the workers are not addressed, how can you do a labour movement?

The most essential requirement of urban work is to promote the industrialization of China. Ren Bishi believes that: the focus of the whole party's work shifts from the countryside to the city, which is a "historically significant issue". The so-called emphasis on the city basically means relying on the working class to restore and develop industrial production, including light industries, heavy industries, and transportation, and organizing trade; everything else in the city, such as municipal construction, public movement, finance, culture education, and party construction should serve the development of the industry. In short, it is about starting industrialization, which is the most fundamental issue in urban work. He explained the importance of realizing industrialization from three aspects: 

(1) It is necessary to implement the policy of self-reliance. We have achieved self-reliance in politics and military, which is no longer an issue, but we must also achieve economic self-reliance to be completely independent. In other words, except for what we do not have in terms of resources in China, we can completely solve it by ourselves. We need to have a strong machinery manufacturing industry, as well as a military manufacturing industry, capable of producing aircraft, tanks, ships, etc. This is how we can be completely independent in terms of national defense. 

(2) The needs of the revolutionary cause to shift to socialism. If there are only military and political conditions, without economic conditions, without industrial development, it is impossible to turn to socialism, the past "left" leaning errors were here too. In the old China's national economy, the proportion of industry only accounted for about 10%, Ren Bishi believed that New China should gradually shift to socialism, the proportion of industry should reach at least 30%, so after the national revolution victory, we still need two to three Five-Year Plans, to transition to socialism. 

(3) The need to consolidate the worker-peasant alliance. The worker-peasant alliance, now and in the past, is mainly manifested in giving land to the peasants, emancipating the peasants from the feudal system, and realizing the alliance. In the future, agriculture needs to develop and farmers' lives need to improve, which means providing cheap industrial goods; at the same time, farmers supply the city with their products, promote industrial development, improve workers' lives, and this is what can consolidate the worker-peasant alliance. In the future industrial development, it still has to provide tractors, combine harvesters, etc. to assist agriculture towards collectivization, and agriculture has to support industry with a large amount of food and raw materials, surplus agricultural products, and labor, develop foreign trade, balance exports and imports, we must recognize this kind of mutually promoting relationship between industry and agriculture. 

In order to train a large number of urban work cadres and achieve the transition from rural to urban, there was a very prominent issue at the time, where did a large number of cadres come from? Mao Zedong has always attached importance to the cadre issue. Since the beginning of 1948, he has repeatedly proposed to attach importance to intellectual cadres and to absorb intellectuals, especially engineers, technicians, and staff with knowledge and experience, to join the revolutionary ranks. In the notice of the September meeting, he proposed that preparing cadres should not only rely on the old liberated areas, but also pay attention to absorbing cadres from the big cities under the rule of the Nationalist Party, where many workers and intellectuals can participate in our work. At the second plenary session of the 7th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, he also proposed "We must prepare to turn the entire 2.1 million field army into a work team... We must regard the 2.1 million field army as a huge cadre school". Zhu De also emphasized: In the past, from city to rural was a big change, now from rural to city is again a big change. Our work needs to adapt to this big change. The army needs to gradually metamorphose into a work team from a combat team, which is also a big change.



Our army is a school, a school that is tasked with raising people who are capable of taking action. They will be responsible for managing and carrying out production in the future. 
Section three: Presenting the mission of "Two Musts"
Facing the change from rural to urban areas, and the test of holding national power, the Chinese Communist Party has put forward a series of guidelines and policies to strengthen the building of the party. This includes strengthening discipline, perfecting the system of democratic life within the party. The Communist Party of China is founded on the basis of Marxist revolutionary theory and democratic centralism, and since its inception has maintained strict organisational discipline. During the long period when the Communist Party of China and the People's Liberation Army it led were divided by enemies and in a guerrilla warfare environment, certain local party organisations and military authorities were allowed to maintain significant autonomy. This proved to be positive for activating local party organisations and armies, and overcoming long-term difficulties. However, it also led to some situations of indiscipline and anarchism, localism and guerrilla-ism, which worsened compared to the period of Anti-Japanese War, and damaged the revolutionary cause. This kind of situation was not fundamentally suitable for fully holding political power. Therefore, the September conference in 1948 profoundly emphasised the importance of strengthening the party within the new historical conditions.

The September conference believed that in order to adapt to the needs of the current revolutionary situation and ensure full unity in the execution of various policies by the party and army, as well as the full implementation of military plans, the entire party must make its greatest efforts to overcome these erroneous tendencies, and centralise all possible and necessary power into the hands of the central and representative bodies. Deng Xiaoping said in his speech: "The army moves forward, production grows a little, and discipline is strengthened". Of these three guidelines, strengthening discipline is extremely important as it is an essential part of ensuring revolutionary victory; furthermore, strengthening discipline is also linked with developing democracy within the party. The key to solving this issue lies with the higher authorities, the regional party committees, and the senior party cadres. Bo Yibo believed that strengthening discipline is a strategic issue, and the whole party should fully recognise its importance and far-reaching significance. Mao Zedong suggested that the central comrades should put their full efforts into this matter, so that the whole party and army could overcome these erroneous tendencies within the third year of the war, unite the people of the whole country, rapidly expel the invading forces of US Imperialism from China, and overthrow the reactionary rule of the Nationalist Party. The conference also pointed out that, within our party, due to the war environment or other underground situations, the normal democratic life within the party has not been well developed; even after the Party's Seventh National Congress mandated the holding of representative conferences at all levels, this situation remained largely unchanged. At the same time, to adapt to the special environment of the past and the needs of the struggle, the normal democratic life within the party could not but be limited. Some serious bureaucratic phenomena detached from the masses emerged in party organisations and government bodies; certain erroneous propositions, unorthodox sectarian style, and situations of indiscipline were allowed to secretly propagate and grow within the party, causing numerous losses to the party and the people's cause. The conference believed that the revolution will soon achieve national victory, and both the situation and conditions necessitate and allow for improving the insufficiency of the democratic life within the Party in the past period, so as to enhance the political quality of the Party and strengthen its fighting capacity.

Mao Zedong pointed out in his report: The way to implement democratic life within the Party is to implement the system of representative meetings and conferences. There is democracy within our Party, but it is insufficient or lacking, and now it needs to be increased. The method is to replace cadre meetings with representative meetings and conferences. The advantages of cadre meetings are speed, convenience, and ease of convening, and these advantages should be retained in representative conferences without making them too cumbersome. The theoretical level of our party must be acknowledged as still low, and must be improved.



Such a large party is either ignorant or not consolidated on many basic theoretical issues, which is exemplified by our party's low theoretical level. There are many new intellectuals and worker-peasant cadres in the party who don't know many basic viewpoints and can't explain many problems. There are millions of students and professors nationwide, as well as many theatre troupes. If you cannot put forward a coherent argument, you will have to listen to them. We need to improve our theory and also popularize it. Central Committee members and Politburo members should regard this as a political task to pay attention to, otherwise, they won't convince those comrades who make mistakes.

Ren Bishi said that during the war, especially in direct combat areas, centralization was required. The emphasis on a single lead was correct. "The liberation area in North China now has relative peace, both inside and outside the party should emphasize democracy, establish a democratic system, and the system must be implemented." He pointed out: "There are still phenomena of suppressing democracy within the party, which is caused by the conditions of the Chinese party and applying the management methods of the army to the party". Considering the existing phenomenon that party members dare not cross levels to reflect opinions on direct leadership, and the phenomenon of "small broadcast" appearing in the masses, Ren Bishi pointed out: "The main thing is the lack of criticism and self-criticism, and real ones, there is no small broadcast". He believed that holding delegate meetings and elections were forms of promoting democracy, but the essence was criticism and self-criticism. "If there are only delegate meetings and the words of small broadcasts cannot be openly spoken at the meetings, then it is only a form of democracy and no substance of democracy." The function of democracy requires long-term cultivation, "there must be democracy within the party first, then the people's democracy can truly be established. Ren Bishi emphasized that strengthening discipline is the objective need for the regularization of the army, the concentration of forces for combat, and the development of production after regional unification, more importantly, "as we move from rural to urban areas, we emphasize unity and discipline more, so as to avoid problems like Zhang Guozhu. And the more we move forward and win, the more these problems and this bad tendency are likely to grow"; "Otherwise, we will not be able to defeat the influence of the international and national bourgeoisie." He clearly pointed out that enforcing discipline is unconditional, but forming discipline is conditional. "Strengthening discipline has two conditions: First, the whole party should have 500 cadres who understand Marxism-Leninism. If cadres master Marxism-Leninism, they can ensure the uniform implementation of policies. Many issues have already been decided, and the Sixth Party Congress resolution has talked about it, but it hasn't been resolved well. If every county committee could have one person who firmly grasps the policy, the situation would be quite different. One must read those five works of Marxism-Leninism, busy can be used as an excuse to squeeze out others". "The second condition is to establish a system, enact laws, such as the regulations on deserter management, people’s court regulations, etc.", "We need big laws, as well as small laws, big laws govern small laws, and we can also allow the people to enact several conventions, but we need a unified law. There must also be a system in the military and government agencies, once the system is set up it must be followed." Will obeying discipline, emphasizing centralization and unification weaken local enthusiasm and creativity? Ren Bishi replied: "Strengthening discipline is not about reducing the enthusiasm of local areas, but eliminating blind enthusiasm and promoting systematic and organized enthusiasm."



For this reason, the meeting specifically discussed and passed the "Resolution of the Central Government on the Reporting System for Central Bureaus, Sub-Bureaus, Military Regions, Military Commission Branches and Preparatory Committees to Central Government", and the "Resolution of the Communist Party of China Central Committee on Convening Party Representatives at All Levels and Representative Meetings". After the meeting, Mao Zedong drafted a decision on "Strengthening the Party Committee System" for the CPC Central Committee. Facing great victory, we must adhere to the "two musts". At the January Political Bureau meeting, Mao Zedong proposed not to let victory dazzle our minds. He said, if the victory dazzles the mind, it is more likely today. The greater the victory, the heavier the burden, the easier it is to unite during critical and difficult times. We must be vigilant about this, educate our cadres, and first of all, we need to make our senior cadres understand that after the war is over, the real work begins. At that time, it might feel easier to fight battles.

At the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee of the Party, Mao Zedong warned the entire party again. Because of victory, the sentiments within the party of pride, self-proclaimed heroes, pausing progress, and pursuing enjoyment and unwilling to live a hard life may grow. Because of victory, the people thank us, and the bourgeoisie will also join in the praise. The enemy's force cannot conquer us, that has been proven. The bourgeoisie's boast may conquer the weak-willed in our ranks. Some Communists may never have been conquered by the weaponized enemy, they are worthy of the title of hero in front of these enemies; but they cannot withstand the attacks of bullets wrapped in sugar coatings, they will lose to sugar bullets. We must prevent this situation.

Mao Zedong further pointed out: "Capturing national victory is only the first step in the long march. If this first step is prideful, it is relatively small, and the prouder ones are still coming. After decades, people's feelings about the victory of the Chinese People's Democratic Revolution will feel as if it was just a short prelude to a long play. The play must start from the prelude, but the prelude is not the climax. China's revolution is great, but the journey after the revolution is longer, the work is greater, and more difficult. It is now necessary to make this clear to the party and ensure that comrades continue to maintain a style of modesty, prudence and not being arrogant or impetuous, and must ensure that comrades continue to maintain a hardworking style."

In the conclusion of the meeting, Mao Zedong clearly proposed not to celebrate the birthdays of party leaders, not to name locations, streets and businesses after party leaders, to maintain a hard-working style, and to stop praising deeds. The task of strengthening the construction of the ruling party was proposed. Ren Bishi, during his speech at the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee, proposed that with the shift in work focus, party construction must also adapt. He believes that after the failure of the Great Revolution, the Chinese Communist Party has been fighting in the countryside for a long time, and now 85% to 90% of party members are peasants, "this is very natural, but it is also a weakness, that is, it is prone to tendencies of laxity and lack of discipline”. After entering the city, "if we don't have a party base among the workers and can't establish a close connection with the working class, we can't really rely on the working class". Therefore, the main development object of the party in the city is industrial workers, followed by handicraft workers and shop assistants; if the development speed is too slow, it will compromise the work.



How to ensure the quality of party members? He pointed out: firstly, strict examination is necessary, new party members need to hold a joining ceremony, which "is educational for party members." Secondly, education needs to be strengthened, and organizational life improved. Thirdly, we need to regularly check the work of party members, carry out criticism and self-criticism, and strictly enforce discipline.
Ren Bishi warned the party's leadership and organization department at all levels: there must be strong cadres who regularly attend to party work. This includes branch building, the party's leadership style, working style, the thought trends of party members, etc. "Being busy with various economic construction and administrative affairs, neglect of the party's construction, forgetting about party work, that is very dangerous", this "is especially important for our Party when it is about to become the ruling party nationally."
Fourth, Develop production and unify financial work.
Regarding the economic work, the September meeting stressed the issue of production development and financial unification. 
The phrase "grow production by one inch" has been discussed at the enlarged meeting of the CPC Central Secretariat in Chengnan Village, and it was raised again at this meeting. 
The meeting believed that the restoration and development of industrial and agricultural production in the liberated areas is an important link in supporting the war and defeating the Kuomintang reactionaries. On one hand, the People's Liberation Army must advance a victorious offensive towards regions of the Kuomintang, obtaining a large amount of human and material resources required for the war from the Kuomintang and its regions. On the other hand, they must make every effort to restore and develop industrial and agricultural production in the old liberated areas, achieving a certain increase compared to the current level. Only when both of these tasks are completed can it be guaranteed to overthrow the Kuomintang's reactionary rule, otherwise it would be impossible. 
Mao Zedong said, "As the army advances, production must grow an inch, otherwise there's no food to eat." Ren Bishi said: "Now the economic burden of the people in the old liberated areas is very heavy, and coupled with labour burden, this makes people's burden even greater, especially on the Pingchuan Avenue. According to financial researchers, the burden should not exceed 20% of the income (excluding indirect burdens), otherwise problem arises in growing production by an inch."
To ensure the advancement of the army, Ren Bishi proposed that the old liberated areas should improve production, "make a bit more effort and put in a little more capital without hurting the vitality too much". "In the Central Plains, mobilize the masses to widely reduce rents and interest, in order to support troops advancing to the South during the fourth and fifth years of the war, and become their rear."
The meeting believed that in order to restore and develop production, it is necessary to have better organizational work, effectively lead the domestic market in the liberated areas and regulate foreign trade, solve some problems of machine and raw material shortages, focusing first on solving transportation and repairing railways, highways, and river channels.



Waste must be opposed, and frugality must be practiced deliberately: On the frontline, we should focus on confiscation for public use, care for our live forces, cherish our weapons, save ammunition, and protect prisoners; in the rear, we should reduce the expenses of state institutions, reduce the mobilization of non-urgent manpower and animal power, reduce the meeting time, pay attention to the agricultural seasons, abide by the farming season, save the cost of industrial production, improve labor productivity, mobilize the whole party to study and manage industrial production, agricultural production and business, as far as possible to organize the economy of each liberated area appropriately, overcome the blindness in the market, and fight against all speculators if necessary.

Mao Zedong raised the issue of financial unity in his report. He stated: "The Finance Committee of the North China People's Government will unite the economic, financial, trading, financial, transportation and military industrial potential, and necessary construction work and administrative work in North China, East China, and Northwest China. It is not everything that is united, but what is possible and necessary is united, what is possible but not necessary is not united, and what is necessary but not possible is temporarily not united. Such as agriculture, small handicraft industry, etc. are temporarily not united, while financial work, currency issuance must be unified first. Administrative unity means that the orders are issued by the Finance Committee of North China, and the party, government, and military of the three regions must guarantee the execution of the unified orders of the Finance Committee of North China."

Section III: Efforts to Uphold the Vision of a New Democratic Society  
1. The exposition of the thought of a new democratic society 
Ever since the Chinese Communist Party proposed the basic idea of New Democracy, with the victorious development of the democratic revolution and the deepening understanding of the issue by the Chinese Communist Party, the theory of the New Democratic Society was further enriched and developed in the late 1940s and early 1950s. This theory, combined with the theory of New Democracy revolution, forms a complete system of New Democracy theory. In 1925, the Fourth Plenum of the CCP pointed out: "After the victory of the national revolution, whether it is followed by the proletarian revolution, whether it is necessary to go through the bourgeois democratic system, the degree of the revolution of its own class in the national revolution and the social objective conditions at that time must be determined by the proletarian class.” In 1926, Stalin discussed this issue a bit in his speech at the Chinese Committee of the Communist International. He believed that the future revolutionary regime in China is a "regime of proletarian and peasant democratic dictatorship", "This will be the transitional regime for China towards non-capitalist development, or more precisely, towards socialist development, which is the direction the Chinese revolution should go.” Here, Stalin clearly proposed that the transition from democratic revolution to socialism in China needs a transitional regime. However, he did not specify how this transitional regime will realize this change. Two years later, Cai Hesen also wrote an article emphasizing the "Soviet power of the dictatorship of workers and peasants" as an important factor for the future revolutionary transition. He called the power of workers and peasants the "crane of transition". He said that after the victory of the Democratic Revolution, the Soviet government of workers and peasants should "confiscate all large enterprises of foreign countries and then confiscate all large enterprises of local capitalists, organize and direct the economic life of the whole country", and "quickly prepare for the transition to the socialist revolution, i.e., eliminate the capitalist market economy and replace it with the collective rural economy under the domination of organized state-owned city industry". When history develops to this moment, it is the "beginning of socialism". From Cai Hesen's statement, the process of transition from democratic revolution to socialism is not only the process of eliminating capitalist economy, but also the process of forming a collective rural economy under the leadership of state-owned industry. In this statement, Cai Hesen made the main task in the transition process very clear. But he is more about expounding Marxist theory, and his understanding of the actual process of future changes in the Chinese revolution is not clear enough. Because the Chinese Communist Party was in its infancy at that time, the understanding of many issues came from the guidance of the Communist International. Furthermore, the New Democratic Revolution had just started, and the Chinese Communists lacked the practice and experience of revolution. Therefore, it is impossible to have a full understanding of how to transition.


After the failure of the Great Revolution, members of the Communist Party of China began to shift their focus to rural areas, further integrating China's revolution with its national conditions, making the vision of change increasingly clear in this process. In the 1930s, with the deepening of the Chinese Revolution, the workers' and peasants' Soviet regime was established in various bases, and its economy was mainly composed of "state-owned enterprises, cooperative enterprises, and private enterprises". The principle of economic policy at that time was, "to concentrate economic power for the war, while striving hard to improve the living conditions of the masses, consolidate the economic union of workers and peasants, ensure the leadership of the proletariat over the peasants, compete for the leadership of state-owned economy over private economy, and create the premise for future development towards socialism". In December 1935, in the report he made at the Wayaobao conference, Mao Zedong proposed to change the Workers' and Peasants' Republic into the People's Republic to unite more people. He pointed out: "The government of the People's Republic is mainly composed of workers and peasants, while accommodating other classes of anti-imperialist and anti-feudalist forces." And he particularly proposed to protect the development of national capital industry and commerce. These ideas generated in the practice of the Chinese revolution became an important basis for the later concept of a new democratic society. In May 1939, in the article "May 4th Movement", Mao Zedong also argued that: "This kind of democratic revolution is to establish a social system that has never existed in Chinese history, that is, a democratic social system. The predecessor of this society was a feudal society (which has been semi-colonial and semi-feudal in recent centuries), and its successor is a socialist society. If one asks a communist why he should first struggle for the realization of the social system of bourgeois democracy and then for the realization of the social system of socialism, the reply is: this is the necessary course of history." Here, Mao Zedong explicitly pointed out that there is a transitional society in the process of transition from a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society to a socialist society. Although the term "New Democracy" was not directly mentioned in the text, its meaning is clear. After further theoretical exploration, in January 1940, in the "On New Democracy", Mao Zedong first proposed the concept of "New Democratic Society". He pointed out: the first step and stage of China's revolution is to "establish a new democratic society based on the union of all revolutionary classes in China led by the Chinese proletariat" and "then develop it to a second stage to establish a socialist society in China". He believed that in a new democratic society, the policy to be adopted is: politically, to implement a democratic republic of workers and peasants' union, based on the proletarian leadership, which unites anti-imperialist and anti-feudal forces, with the People's Congress system as a form of state power and implements democratic centralism. Economically, to take over large banks, industries, and businesses into state ownership, allow the existence of small and medium-sized capitalist industries and businesses, confiscate landowners' lands for peasant ownership, implement "the land to the tiller". In terms of culture, it promotes anti-imperialist and anti-feudal popular culture. In Mao Zedong's words, this is, "The entire result of the Chinese revolution is: on the one hand there is the development of capitalist elements, and on the other hand there is the development of socialist elements." After discussing the political, economic, and cultural forms of new democratic society, Mao said that the integration of politics, economy, and culture of new democracy is the new democratic society. In April 1945, Mao Zedong further argued in his report to the 7th Party Congress the historical inevitability and necessity of first establishing a new democracy and then socialism. He pointed out: we are going to push China towards a socialist society and communist society in the future. But, "only through democracy can socialism be reached, which is the inherent truth of Marxism". And in China, the fight for new democratic politics, economy, and culture is still going to be a long-term process. Otherwise, "to build socialism on the ruins of a colonial, semi-colonial, and semi-feudal society is just a complete fantasy".



The reason is nothing other than that "Our capitalism is too little". As such, in the New Democratic society, besides the state-owned economy, the individual economy of the laboring people, and the cooperative economy, private capitalism must be allowed to develop within the range where it cannot manipulate the country's economics and the people's livelihood. This "is not only a progress but also an inevitable process".

In the second plenary session of the seventh Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party held in March 1949, although the development direction from the new democratic society to socialist society was mentioned, it was only proposed as a future development rather than an urgent current task. At this meeting, it was still noted that after the revolution victory, a new democratic country needs to be established. The policies proposed after analyzing the economic conditions in China are still new democratic policies. Mao Zedong pointed out at the meeting: "For a considerable period after the victory of the revolution, it is still necessary to make use of the enthusiasm for urban and rural capitalism as much as possible to promote the development of the national economy. During this period, all urban and rural capitalist elements that are not harmful but beneficial to the national economy should be allowed to exist and develop. This is not only inevitable but also economically necessary. It is just that we need to "adopt appropriate and flexible restriction policies" in various aspects. It was also pointed out that in such a new democratic country, there will be socialist state-owned economic sectors, semi-socialist cooperative economic sectors, private capitalist economic sectors, individual economic sectors, and state and private cooperative national capitalist economic sectors as main economic elements. These economic elements constitute the economic form of new democracy. In June of the same year, Mao Zedong further emphasized in the article "On People's Democratic Dictatorship" that all elements of urban and rural capitalism beneficial to the national economy must be utilized, "Our current policy is to restrict capitalism, not to eliminate it". Liu Shaoqi also had a lot to say about this before and after the founding of New China. On May 29, 1949, Liu Shaoqi told a cadre meeting in Beijing that because our country's production is underdeveloped, mainly due to too little capitalism, after the victory of the democratic revolution it was inevitable to develop capitalism but this had to be restricted while gradually developing. The transition to socialism would happen decades later, which is difficult to be specific about right now, but the time will be quite long and not very short. On the eve of the founding of New China, during a discussion on the "Common Programme of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (Draft)", some democratic people proposed to include China's future socialist objective. Liu Shaoqi, on behalf of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, responded: "We think this is still improper because it is still a long time in the future to take serious socialist steps in China. If you write this goal into the common programme, it is easy to confuse the practical steps we need to take today". Zhou Enlai, in his report on drafting the common programme and its features, also explained the reason for not including the future of socialism into the common programme. On June 23, 1950, Mao Zedong said in his closing speech at the second meeting of the National Political Consultative Conference that the implementation of private sector nationalization and agricultural socialization "still lies far in the future". "Our country is moving forward steadily in this manner, going through war, through new democratic reforms, and in the future, after the national economic and cultural undertakings have greatly thrived, after all conditions are met, and after the entire people have thought it over and everyone agrees, we can calmly and properly enter the new period of socialism". Here, what exactly is meant by "far in the future" was not explicitly defined by the central government at the time.

At the Politburo meeting in September 1948, Mao Zedong predicted that once the democratic revolution was victorious nationwide, it might be possible to start a full-scale attack on socialism within fifteen years. Ren Bishi stated at the second plenary session of the seventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of China: "After the national revolution victory, we will still need two or three five-year plans before we can transition to socialism."



During his visit to the Soviet Union in 1949, Liu Shaoqi wrote in a letter: "It will take about fifteen years to build socialism." At a meeting of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference in September that year, Mao Zedong was asked when the socialism would be reached, he replied: "Probably twenty or thirty years!" In April 1950, Zhou Enlai told the Party leadership and cadres attending the United Front conference: "It will take approximately fifteen years to build socialism." This shows that the New Democratic society established after the victory of the New Democratic Revolution, as a stage of Chinese society, would not exist for only a few years. Rather, it was seen as a relatively long period of preparing for socialism. This was a consensus within the Party, with Liu Shaoqi referring to this period as the "stage of New Democratic construction.”

On March 28, 1951, Liu Shaoqi gave a report at the first national organization work conference of the Chinese Communist Party, stated clearly: "The ultimate goal of the Chinese Communist Party is to realize the communist system in China. It is now struggling to consolidate the new democratic system, and in the future it will struggle to transition to the socialist system, and finally strive to achieve the communist system.” On September 9th of the same year, the resolution about rectifying the grassroots organizations of the Party passed at the Party's first national organization work conference stipulated the standards for party members (the eight conditions for Party members). The second one is: "The ultimate goal of the Chinese Communist Party is to realize the communist system in China. It is now struggling to consolidate the new democratic system, and in the future it will struggle for the nationalization of industry, and the collectivization of agriculture, that is, for the transition to the socialist system."

The scientific concept of the Chinese Communist Party is: after the victory of the New Democratic Revolution, a New Democratic society is established. The New Democratic society includes the stage of New Democratic construction and the transitional period. After the establishment of the New Democratic society, the construction of New Democracy begins. When the construction of New Democracy has achieved considerable results, and all the material and mental conditions for transition to socialism are fully met, the transitional period starts, with the initiation of the socialist revolution. After entering the transitional period, it remains a New Democratic society, still with co-existing components of multiple economies. But at this time, the capitalist economy has gone from "allowed to develop" to "accepted for transformation", the economic policy towards capitalism is no longer one of utilization and limitation, but of transformation and elimination; guiding farmers and craftsmen towards collectivization. When these tasks are completed, the socialist society is birthed.

The theory of the New Democracy society is a crystallization of the struggle experience of the Chinese Communist Party and the Chinese people, it is a great creation by Mao Zedong and other leaders of the Communist Party of China. This theory, along with the theory of the New Democracy Revolution, together constitute the complete system of the New Democratic theory.

Second, the Construction of the Theory of People's Democratic Dictatorship.

Political platforms generally include the state system and the form of state power, that is, the two aspects of state nature and political structure. In political science, "state nature" refers to the class nature of the state, and the central issue is the position of various classes in the state.



The term "political system" refers to the form of organization of state power, that is, which form is chosen and adopted by the ruling class to organize the organs of power, and to implement its rule and management. The national system determines the political system, and is reflected through the political system. The political system is compatible with the national system. Different classes' dictatorships form different national systems, and due to different historical conditions and traditions in each country, political systems also differ. Even countries with the same national system can adopt different political systems.
New Democracy politics mainly includes the social foundation of New Democracy state power and the content of the national system and political system of New Democracy state.
Regarding the issue of the social foundation of New Democracy state power, Mao Zedong pointed out in "On New Democracy" that the Chinese proletariat, peasants, intellectuals and other petty bourgeoisie are the basic forces determining the fate of the state. These classes, either already awakened or waking up, are bound to become the fundamental components of the state construction and power structure of the Republic of China, with the proletariat being the leading force. The Republic of China that needs to be established today can only be a Democratic Republic of all anti-imperialist and anti-feudal people under the leadership of the proletariat. This is the Republic of New Democracy. This New Democratic Republic is distinguished from the old forms of Western-style, bourgeois dictatorship, and capitalist republic, which is the republic of Old Democracy, which is outdated. On the other hand, it is also different from the Soviet-style, proletariat dictatorship, and socialist republic. That kind of socialist republic has flourished in the Soviet Union and is about to be established in all capitalist countries. Without a doubt, it will become the ruling form of state construction and political power structure in all industrially advanced countries. However, such a republic is not suitable for the revolution of colonial and semi-colonial countries in a certain historical period. Therefore, the form of state adopted by the revolution of all colonial and semi-colonial countries during a certain historical period can only be the third form, which is the so-called New Democratic Republic. This is a form of a certain historical period, so it is a transitional form, but it is an indispensable necessary form. Mao Zedong pointed out that among the various state systems worldwide, classified by the class nature of their power, there are fundamentally no more than three types: 1) Republic under bourgeois dictatorship; 2) Republic under proletariat dictatorship; 3) Republic under joint dictatorship of several revolutionary classes. The first is the state of Old Democracy. Today, after the outbreak of the second imperialist war, many capitalist countries have lost their democratic breath and have transformed or are about to transform into bloody military dictatorship of bourgeoisie. Some countries under joint dictatorship of landowners and bourgeoisie can be attached to this category. The second one, except for the Soviet Union, is brewing in various capitalist countries. It will become the world ruling form in a certain period. The third one is the transitional form of state adopted by the revolution of colonial and semi-colonial countries. The revolution in each colonial and semi-colonial country will inevitably have some different characteristics, but these are minor differences within a great similarity. As long as it is a revolution in a colony or a semi-colony, its state construction and political power structure will fundamentally be the same, that is, a New Democratic state where several classes opposing imperialism unite to jointly rule. In today's China, this form of New Democracy is the form of the Anti-Japanese United Front. It is anti-Japanese, opposing imperialism; it is also a coalition of several revolutionary classes, a united front.


To further clarify the connotation of new democratic politics, Mao Zedong discussed the so-called issue of the state system. He said, this issue of the state system has been a matter of contention since the late Qing Dynasty, and it has still not been fully understood after decades of dispute. In fact, it only refers to one question, which is the status of various social classes in the country. The bourgeoisie always conceals this class status, using the term "national" to achieve its actual one-class dictatorship. This kind of concealment is of no benefit to the revolutionary people and should be clearly pointed out. The word "national" can be used, but national does not include counter-revolutionaries and traitors. The dictatorship of all revolutionary classes over counter-revolutionary traitors, that is the state we want now. "The so-called civil rights system in modern countries is often monopolized by the bourgeoisie, and it becomes a tool for oppressing the people. If it is the civil rights of the Kuomintang, it is shared by ordinary people, and it is not a privilege of the few." Moreover, there is the so-called issue of political system, which refers to the form of the composition of political power, and it refers to the form of a certain social class to organize the political power organ that opposes the enemy and protects itself. Without the appropriate form of political power organ, it cannot represent the country. China can now adopt a system of the National People’s Congress, Provincial People’s Congress, County People’s Congress, District People’s Congress, and Town People’s Congress, with governments elected by representatives from all levels. But one must implement a truly universal equal electoral system that has no differences in sex, belief, property, education, and so on, to suit the positions of all revolutionary classes in the country, suit the expression of public opinion and command of revolutionary struggle, and suit the spirit of new democracy. This system is the democratic centralism. Only a government of democratic centralism can fully carry out the will of all revolutionary people and can most powerfully oppose the enemies of the revolution. "The spirit of not being a private possession of a few" must be reflected in the composition of the government and the army, and without a real democratic system, this goal cannot be achieved, which is called incompatibility of political system and state system. Mao Zedong pointed out clearly that the state system refers to the dictatorship of all revolutionary classes; the political system refers to democratic centralism. This is the politics of new democracy, this is the republic of new democracy, this is the republic of the Anti-Japanese United Front, this is the republic of the new Three People's Principles of the three major policies, this is the truly deserving "Republic of China". We now have the name "Republic of China", but not the reality of the "Republic of China". We should honor the name by instilling the reality, this is the work of today. This is the internal political relationship that revolutionary China and anti-Japanese China should and must establish, this is the only correct direction for today's nation-building work. At the Seventh Congress of the Party in 1945, Mao Zedong further elaborated on the politics of new democracy. He said: We advocate the establishment of a state system of democratic alliance of the united front under the leadership of the working class based on the vast majority of the people in the country after thoroughly defeating the Japanese aggressors, that is, the state system of new democracy. The political power organization of new democracy should adopt the democratic centralism, with major policy guidelines determined by the people's representatives at all levels, and the government elected.



This is a national system that truly suits the majority of China's population. In this country, contradictions still exist among different classes, each with some different demands, such as the contradiction between labor and capital, being a prominent one. However, these contradictions and different demands can be adjusted and should not and will not be allowed to exceed the common requirements during the entire stage of New Democracy. In December 1947, Mao Zedong explicitly proposed the political program of New Democracy. He said: "'To unite all oppressed classes, people's organizations, democratic parties, minorities, overseas Chinese in various places, and other patriots to form a national united front, overthrow Chiang Kai-shek's dictatorship, and establish a democratic united government.' This is the most basic political program of the People's Liberation Army and the Chinese Communist Party." In September 1948, Mao Zedong explicitly proposed in the report of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee to "establish a people's democratic dictatorship based on the alliance of workers and peasants led by the proletariat" in the future, and said, "The class nature of our power is such: it's led by the proletariat, based on the alliance of workers and peasants, and not only includes the workers and peasants, but also the participation of democratic capitalists in the people's democratic dictatorship." Soon after that, he called for the revolution to be carried out to the end, clearly stating that after the victory of the revolution, a People's Democratic Republic led by the proletariat and mainly composed of the alliance of workers and peasants should be established nationwide. On June 30, 1949, in the article "On the People's Democratic Dictatorship," Mao Zedong established the historical inevitability of establishing a people's democratic dictatorship in China. He clarified the basic tasks of the people's democratic dictatorship, the relationship between democracy and dictatorship, and positions of each class in the people's democratic dictatorship, thus forming a complete theory of the people's democratic dictatorship.

Mao Zedong profoundly elucidated the historical inevitability of establishing the people's democratic dictatorship in China. The article summarized the historical experience of both positive and negative aspects in China for over a hundred years, depicting the path that Chinese progressives have taken in seeking revolutionary truths since the Opium War, clarifying that Marxism-Leninism is the guiding light of the Chinese revolution; only by implementing the people's democratic dictatorship can the Chinese people overthrow the 'three mountains' and take the only path to socialism. Mao Zedong criticized various plans for bourgeois republics advocated by bourgeois representatives and pointed out: "There have been bourgeois republics in foreign countries, but China cannot have one, because China is a country oppressed by imperialism." "Summarizing our experience, concentrated in one point, it is the people's democratic dictatorship based on the alliance of workers and peasants led by the working class (through the Communist Party). This dictatorship must unite with the international revolutionary forces. This is our formula, this is our main experience, this is our main program." He made clear the nature of the new China and the positions and relationships of each class in the state power. Mao Zedong pointed out that the imminent People's Republic of China would be a state of people's democratic dictatorship with the working class as the leadership, and the alliance of workers and peasants as the base. 

In China, at the current stage, the people include the working class, the peasant class, the urban petty bourgeoisie, and the national bourgeoisie. Among them, the working class is the leading force of the people's democratic dictatorship. Because only the working class has the most foresight, is the most selfless, and is the most thorough in revolution. History has proven that there is no revolution without the leadership of the working class, while there is victory in the revolution with the leadership of the working class. The basis of the people's democratic dictatorship is the alliance of the working class, the peasant class, and the urban petty bourgeoisie, mainly the alliance of workers and peasants. Because these two classes account for 80% to 90% of China's population, the forces to overthrow imperialism and the Kuomintang reactionaries mainly come from these two classes. The transition to socialism must rely on this alliance. In addition, the people's democratic dictatorship also includes a special alliance between the proletariat and the national bourgeoisie. Mao Zedong pointed out that "in order to cope with the oppression of imperialism and to upgrade the backward economic status, China must take advantage of all capitalism factors beneficial to the national economy and people's livelihood in both urban and rural areas, and unite with the national bourgeoisie to strive."


"Our current policy is to control capitalism, not to eliminate capitalism." However, the national bourgeoisie cannot act as the leader of the revolution and should not hold a dominant position in the state power. Highlighting the content of the people's democratic dictatorship and the relationship between democracy and dictatorship, Mao Zedong pointed out: "The combination of the democratic aspect within the people and the dictatorship aspect against the reactionaries constitutes the people's democratic dictatorship." This statement not only directly indicates the content of the people's democracy and the dictatorship against the enemies, in substance but also in form.

To implement democracy for the people is to ensure that the broad masses of working people are the masters of their own affairs, fully enjoying various freedoms and democratic rights. In particular, the rights of workers to manage the state, various enterprises, and cultural education should be guaranteed. Address internal contradictions among the people in accordance with the principles of democracy, implementing democratic centralism. The contradictions among the people can only be resolved democratically, educating and transforming ourselves. Only in this way can we fully reflect the will, interests, and needs of the people, enhance the sense of responsibility of the broad masses, and ensure the smooth progress of our cause.

To practice dictatorship against the enemy means to suppress and oppress these antagonists, only allowing them to abide by the rules and not allowing them to speak or act recklessly. If they want to speak and act arbitrarily, they will be immediately banned and sanctioned. "If not so, the revolution will fail, the people will suffer, the country will perish." Of course, dictating against the enemy does not mean suppressing them ruthlessly or exterminating them physically. Only after their political power has been overthrown, they are provided with land and work, allowing them to transform themselves into new people through labor.

Mao Zedong pointed out that the relationship between democracy and dictatorship is a combination, interaction, and indivisible. Historical experience shows that without people's democracy, there would be no dictatorship against the enemy; without dictatorship against the enemy, people's democracy could not be guaranteed. He proposed the basic tasks of the people's democratic dictatorship.

First, we must strengthen the state apparatus, namely, strengthen the people's army, the people's police, and the people's courts, in order to consolidate national defense and protect the interests of the people. Suppress the resistance of the reactionary classes domestically and resist the aggression and subversion of imperialism abroad. Second, we must progressively solve the problem of national industrialization.



Carrying out economic work and undertaking serious economic construction tasks. Third, reforming non-socialist economy, educating and reforming the national bourgeoisie, so that in the future, privatization of private enterprises can be realized. Educate and reform small production, "the serious problem is to educate the peasants," use long-term and careful work, implement the socialization of agriculture, so that China gradually moves from an agricultural country to an industrial country. Fourth, fight against all old thoughts in political thought, use democratic methods, educate and reform oneself, reform one's bad habits and ideas from the old society, and move towards socialism and communism.

The People's Democratic Dictatorship is a new form of dictatorship created by the Chinese Communist Party based on Marxist state theory, combined with Chinese reality, with national characteristics, and suitable for China's national conditions. Compared with the dictatorship of the proletariat, there are both similarities and significant differences. The similarities are first, both are led by the proletariat and its party; second, both are based on the worker-peasant alliance; third, both provide political guarantees for the development of socialism. The differences are first, the scope of people's democracy is different. Under the dictatorship of the proletariat, the people do not include the bourgeoisie; under the rule of the People's Democratic Dictatorship, the people not only include the working class, peasant class, petty bourgeoisie, but also include the national bourgeoisie. Second, the target of the dictatorship is different. Under the dictatorship of the proletariat, the bourgeoisie is the target of dictatorship; under the rule of the People's Democratic Dictatorship, the national bourgeoisie is not the target of dictatorship, and the target of dictatorship is reactionaries or enemies. In 1956, the socialist reform was fundamentally completed, the bourgeoisie and the capitalist exploitation system no longer existed, the socialist system was fully established, and our country’s People’s Democratic Dictatorship was essentially a dictatorship of the proletariat.

The theory of the people's democratic dictatorship is a product of the combination of Marxist-Leninist theories of proletarian revolution and dictatorship with Chinese reality, and a great creation of the Chinese Communist Party leading the people in long-term revolution and construction practice. It is the highest stage of development of new democratic political theory and program. Our country's People’s Democratic Dictatorship has gone through three stages of development: During the period of the New Democratic Revolution, the People’s Democratic Dictatorship established in the revolutionary base areas was just a local, not a national power. This rule, under the leadership of the workers’ party—the Communist Party, was a joint dictatorship of all revolutionary classes. Its task was to overthrow the reactionary rule of imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucratic capitalism and to resolve the tasks of the democratic revolution. Since the founding of the People's Republic of China, our country's People’s Democratic Dictatorship has gone through two stages of development: the transition period from New Democracy to socialism, and the socialist era. Our Party and Mao Zedong have pointed out many times that the People’s Democratic Dictatorship in these two stages was essentially a dictatorship of the proletariat. Therefore, for a long period of time in our country, the two terms People’s Democratic Dictatorship and proletarian dictatorship coexisted and were interchangeable. This is because both are the same in the fundamental aspects of the workers' class and its party leading the state, the worker-peasant alliance as the class basis of state power, the historical mission of eliminating classes and realizing communism, and the state functions of new democracy and new dictatorship. Lenin once said: “All nations will inevitably move towards socialism, but all nations will not move in the exact same way, in this or that form of democracy, in this or that type of proletarian dictatorship, and in the speed of socialist transformation in all aspects of social life, each nation will have its own characteristics." Our country's People’s Democratic Dictatorship is a type of proletarian dictatorship that is suitable for China's national conditions and revolutionary traditions. Connected with the above characteristics of the theory of people's democratic dictatorship is the theory of the transition from a new democratic society to a socialist society, which further enriches and perfects the party's new democratic political theory and makes this theory a more complete system.


The theory of the Party's revolutionary transition includes the following aspects: First, after the victory of the democratic revolution in China, it is necessary to immediately transition to the socialist revolution. Mao Zedong pointed out, "The Chinese revolution includes two different stages: the bourgeois democratic nature of the revolution (i.e., the New Democratic Revolution) and the proletarian socialist nature of the revolution. The former stage is the necessary preparation for the latter stage, and the latter stage is the development result of the former stage. "The socialist revolution is the inevitable trend of the democratic revolution." After the conclusion of the New Democratic Revolution, it is necessary to immediately transition to the socialist revolution without pause. This is the development law of the Chinese revolution. Mao Zedong also believed that the New Democratic country already possesses favorable factors for future development to socialism. These are: the leadership of the proletariat and its Chinese Communist Party in the New Democratic society, the People's Democracy based on the alliance of workers and peasants including various democratic classes, the state-owned economy of socialist nature and the cooperative economy of half-socialist nature, plus the formation of the socialist camp. This favorable international environment makes the final result of China's bourgeois democratic revolution avoid the prospect of capitalism and realize the prospect of socialism. This idea of revolutionary transformation fully embodies Marx's theory of "continuous revolution." It not only clarifies the goal of the current revolutionary struggle but also mentally prepares for socialism in the future.

Second, the transition from semi-colonial and semi-feudal society to socialist society in China cannot be conducted directly. It must go through a transitional period, which is the New Democratic society. The state it intends to establish is the New Democratic state.
