Mao Zedong said: The stage of China's New Democratic Revolution is "a transitional stage to end semi-colonial, semi-feudal society and establish a socialist society." The state to be established in this transitional stage can only be a New Democratic Republic. This New Democratic Republic is "an unalterable requisite form" of transition taken by all "semi-colonial countries' revolutions". As long as it is the revolution of a semi-colonial country, the state established after the revolution can only adopt the form of a New Democratic Republic. Although the New Democratic Republic is only a historical form for a certain period, it is the "necessary form" for the transition to a socialist society. Mao Zedong also pointed out that the transitional period for China to transition to a socialist society will be a relatively long historical stage. How long this stage will be in time, Mao Zedong did not make it clear, but from Mao Zedong’s conclusions, it can be seen that it is not a short time. He stated: China's revolution "the first step is New Democracy," and "the time for this first step is quite long and cannot be achieved overnight." Therefore, during the transition period, a new state form and political form of alliance of several democratic classes will emerge politically for a quite long period. In terms of economics, after the victory of the revolution for a quite long time, it is necessary to as much as possible utilize the enthusiasm of urban and rural private capitalism to facilitate the forward development of the national economy. Liu Shaoqi also once said, "The time required for this transition will be much longer than in the Eastern European and Central European People's Democratic countries." Based on the understanding of the long-term nature of the transitional period, Mao Zedong also specifically emphasized the need to consolidate the New Democratic country and the arduousness and long-term nature jobs of consolidating the New Democratic country.


Thirdly, the new democratic state plays a very important role in the process of revolutionary transformation. Mao Zedong publicly stated: After the Chinese Communist Party has "completed the revolution of Chinese bourgeois democracy", it is prepared to "transform it to the stage of socialism when all necessary conditions are met". What are the conditions for this transformation? Mao Zedong believed that the new democratic state would play a very important role in this transformation process. He said: In China, "without a unified new democratic state, without the development of a new democratic national economy, without the development of private capitalist economy and cooperative economy, without the development of national, scientific, popular culture, i.e., new democratic culture, without the liberation and development of tens of millions of people's individualities, in short, without a thorough bourgeois democratic revolution led by the Communist Party, it would be a complete illusion to want to establish a socialist society on the ruins of a colonial, semi-colonial, semi-feudal society". Here, Mao Zedong put forward the conditions for the revolutionary transformation: ① there is a new democratic state power led by the proletariat, including various democratic classes; ② the full development of the new democratic economy; ③ the full development of new democratic cultural undertakings; ④ other necessary material preparations; and so on. And these conditions can only gradually form in the new democratic state, which shows the important role and position of the new democratic state in the revolutionary transformation.

The new democratic political doctrine laid the political foundation of the People's Republic of China. At the first plenary session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference held in September 1949, the delegates, guided by new democratic political doctrine, formulated the Common Programme, which served as a temporary constitution. The Common Programme specifies that the nature of the People's Republic of China is "a state of new democracy or people's democracy", and it "practices the dictatorship of the people's democracy led by the working class, based on the alliance of workers and peasants, and uniting all democratic classes and all ethnic groups in the country". It has also stipulated a form of state power organization that is consistent with the people's democratic dictatorship, namely, the people's congress system based on the principle of democratic centralism. "The state power of the People's Republic of China belongs to the people. The organs for the people to exercise state power are the people's congresses and people's governments at all levels," and the state "implements democratic centralism in all organs of state power". It has also stipulated the forms of ownership of the new democratic state, "The People's Republic of China must abolish all the privileges of imperialist states in China, confiscate bureaucratic capital for the state ownership of the people, gradually change the feudal and semi-feudal land ownership into peasant land ownership, protect the public property of the state and the property of cooperatives, protect the economic interests and private property of workers, peasants, petty bourgeoisie and national bourgeoisie, develop the people's economy of new democracy, and steadily transform an agricultural country into an industrial country". In addition, it has also made provisions in military, diplomatic and other fields. The above stipulations about the specific content of the new democratic state are all reflections of the new democratic political doctrine.

Third, the understanding and application of new democratic economic thought

During the new democratic revolution, the Chinese Communists combined Marxist economic theory with the practice of Chinese revolution, revealed the historical characteristics of the economic system of Chinese semi-colonial and semi-feudal society, proposed the need to develop Chinese economy through new democratic forms, and formed the basic program of new democracy with Chinese characteristics and a relatively complete theoretical form. After the 840s, China gradually fell from a completely feudal society to a semi-feudal and semi-colonial society. Mao Zedong analysed that the result of imperialist aggression in China "on the one hand promoted the disintegration of Chinese feudal society, generated capitalist elements in China, and transformed a feudal society into a semi-feudal society; on the other hand, they brutally ruled China and transformed an independent China into a semi-colony and colony of China". Here, Mao Zedong correctly pointed out that China's semi-feudal and semi-colonial economic form was formed under imperialist aggression.



Due to the invasion of capitalist imperialism, China’s socio-economic form has undergone significant changes: on the one hand, in rural areas, the feudal economic form where landlords own most of the land is still maintained, but for China as a whole, the natural economy has disintegrated, turning a feudal society into a “semi-feudal” society. That is to say, another “half” appeared in the semi-feudal society, which is the emergence of capitalist production relations. By the 1920s, capitalist production relations developed into the dominant economic relations in the national economy. This is the economic basis of the New Democratic Revolution of a proletarian-led but bourgeois democratic nature. On the other hand, the so-called semi-colony is foreign invaders forcing the Chinese government to cede territory, pay indemnities, and lose part of its sovereignty politically through war. More importantly, economically forcing the Chinese government to raise foreign debts and use tariffs, salt taxes, lijin, etc. as collateral, thereby losing tariff autonomy, and adopting various means such as opening mines, building railways, building factories, and running banks in China to control China’s economic lifeline and make China a semi-colonial economic status. Faced with this social form, based on deep practical exploration and theoretical explanation, the Communist Party of China believes that the characteristics of the socio-economic form of a semi-feudal and semi-colonial society are as follows.
In terms of production relations, the natural economic foundation of self-sufficiency during the feudal era has been destroyed, but the basis of the feudal exploitation system-landlord class’s exploitation of farmers, not only maintains but also combines with comprador capital and usury capital, The advantage in the socio-economic life of old China is obvious. Capitalism has developed and played a significant role in China's political and cultural life, but its power is weak. Imperialism manipulated China’s finances and economic lifelines. Under the dual oppression of imperialism and feudalism, China’s vast people, especially farmers, are increasingly impoverished and bankrupt, and they are living in a life of extreme poverty and no political rights.
From the perspective of the level and distribution characteristics of productive forces, the productive forces of old Chinese society are very backward, and the structure presents a multi-level state. The output value of modern industry only accounts for about 10% of the total output value of the national economy. Among them, state monopoly capital (commonly known as bureaucracy capital) accounts for about 80% of the fixed assets of the country’s industry and transportation. Private capitalist industry ranks second in modern industry, and it is a force that cannot be ignored. Industrial workers only account for 0.6% of the population, about 3 million people, about 90% are scattered, individual agricultural economy and handicraft industry economy, this part is backward and there is not much difference from the ancient economy. Mao Zedong said that this productive situation is "the result of the oppression of the imperialism system and the feudalism system in China. This is the expression of the economic nature of old China's semi-colonial and semi-feudal society". The basic characteristics of the industrial distribution are concentrated in the northeast and the six coastal provinces. In these two regions, the land area accounts for 18% of the country, the population accounts for 42%, and the industrial output value accounts for about 80% of the country. Only Shanghai's industrial output value accounts for more than 25% of the country's total industrial output value. Mao Zedong pointed out: "Our country's industry was concentrated in coastal areas in the past... All of our country's light and heavy industries, about 70% are along the coast, and only 30% are inland. This is an unreasonable situation formed in history." The economic development is extremely unbalanced, "The weak capitalist economy and the severe semi-feudal economy coexist, several modern industries and a stagnant vast rural area coexist, millions of industrial workers and hundreds of millions of farmers and handicraft workers under the old system coexist... Some railways, air routes, motor vehicle roads and generally wheelbarrow roads, roads that can only be walked on foot, and roads that are not easy to walk, all coexist". The Communist Party of China's analysis of China's half-feudal and half-colonial economic form is the basis of the formation of the economic thought of New Democracy. The practice of the economy of New Democracy began during the period of the land revolution war, and after the Anti-Japanese War, it has been fully elaborated and practiced.



During the period of the Land Revolution War, the Party recognized the extreme importance of economic construction, and clearly pointed out that the economic construction of the base area is to serve the revolutionary war. It cannot be separated from the war to engage in economic work alone, but to ensure the material needs of the war, to ensure an adequate supply of soldiers, we cannot be separated from economic construction. In this regard, the Party began to form a series of distinctive economic policy principles.
The Party pointed out that our national economy is now composed of military camp industries, cooperative businesses, and private business. At present, state-owned economic enterprises are limited to possible and necessary parts. State-owned industries and commerce are also beginning to develop, although they currently hold a small proportion, but the future is limitless. As for private economies, as long as they do not fall outside the scope of government laws, they should not only be not obstructed, but should also be promoted and rewarded, because the development of private economies is needed for national interests, even though they currently have the absolute advantage, they will still dominate for a considerable time. For this reason, the Party has established the principle of the Party's economic policy, which is to carry out all possible and necessary construction on the economic side, to concentrate efforts to supply the war, while striving to improve the people's living conditions, to consolidate the alliance of workers and peasants on the economic side, to ensure the proletariat's leadership over the peasants, to strive for the state-owned economy's leadership over the private economy, and to create the premise for future development into socialism. This was in line with the demands of the level of production development and the transformation of production relationships in the base areas at that time. In 1935, the international and domestic situation changed, in order to get more people to join the national democratic revolutionary united front, Mao Zedong further required the whole Party to clarify its economic policy on capitalism. He pointed out in the "Strategy Against Japanese Imperialism" that "The People's Republic does not abolish non-imperialism and non-feudal private property during the bourgeois democratic revolution, nor does it confiscate the industry and commerce of the national bourgeoisie, but it encourages these industries and commerce. "In the stage of democratic revolution, the struggle between labor and capital is limited." The labour law of the People's Republic protects the interests of workers, but it does not oppose native capitalists making money, and it does not oppose the development of native industry and commerce, because such development is detrimental to imperialism and beneficial to the Chinese people. The implementation of this economic policy can cause political changes, expand the united front, and better complete the political tasks.
Under the guidance of the above economic policy principles, the Party pointed out that the central task of economic construction in the base areas is to develop agricultural production, promote industrial production, develop foreign trade, and develop cooperatives. Based on this standpoint, the Party proposed specific measures for economic construction. To develop agricultural production, the land issue must be solved, the feudal exploitation system and the solid foundation of production relations must be disintegrated, the peasants' land ownership rights must be established, and with the policy of encouraging agricultural production, the peasants' enthusiasm for production can be improved. On this basis, help farmers organize labor mutual assistance societies, farming teams, ploughing cattle cooperatives, to solve the problems of inadequate labor, livestock, and so on. Mao Zedong emphasized that, under current conditions, agricultural production is the first place in our economic construction work. At the same time, he criticized the previous overly "left" policy of complete confiscation and thorough distribution of land, arguing that this hurt the middle class in rural areas and was not conducive to the development of our Party's struggle in rural areas. For the development of industrial production, Mao Zedong emphasized planned development of handicraft industries and some industries, one is for self-sufficiency, and the other is for export. It requires efforts to develop foreign trade, open up markets inside and outside the Red Zone, adjust the surplus and deficiency. The party also attaches great importance to the development of the cooperative economy, thinking that the cooperative economy is the best economic form under the current level of productivity, it cooperates with the state-owned economy, and through long-term development it will become a huge economic force, gradually dominate private economy and obtain a leading position. 
Of course, during this period, the Party's exploration of the concept of New Democratic economy was preliminary, and the theory was not mature and complete, it did not use the scientific concept of "New Democratic economy", and it did not clarify the internal logical connection between the national economy and the unique historical stage of New Democracy.



The leap in understanding of the New Democracy economy occurred after the onset of the Anti-Japanese War. During the Anti-Japanese War era, Mao Zedong lucidly expounded the idea of the New Democracy economy in texts such as “The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party”, “New Democracy”, “Economic and Financial Issues During the Anti-Japanese Era”, and “On the Joint Government”, marking the completion and structuring of the Party’s New Democracy economic theory.

Firstly, the concept of the "New Democracy Economy" was proposed. After systematically analyzing the characteristics of China's semi-feudal and semi-colonial society, the Party reaffirmed that the nature of the Chinese revolution at the current stage is still a bourgeois democratic revolution. But the bourgeois democratic revolution in China now is not an old-style generic bourgeois democratic revolution, but a new-style special bourgeois democratic revolution, that is, the New Democratic Revolution. This revolution requires establishing new democratic politics, economy, and culture. Mao Zedong stated: The Chinese Communist Party has been fighting for many years for the political, economic, and cultural revolution of China. The aim is to build a new society and a new nation of the Chinese people, and "to establish such a republic in China, it must be new democratic in politics and also new democratic in economics." This is because economic issues manifest themselves in political and cultural aspects. What is the content of the New Democracy economic revolution then? It is "to nationalize the big capital and big enterprises of imperialists and traitor reactionaries, to distribute the land of the landlord class to the farmers, to preserve ordinary private capitalist enterprises, and not to abolish the economy of the rich."

Secondly, the construction of the New Democracy economy must take the path of "capital restraint" and "equal land rights." The construction of the New Democracy economy must formulate guidelines and policies according to China's historical characteristics and economic conditions, and explore the correct path of development. China should neither blindly copy the Soviet model of economic development nor be identical to the capitalist economies of Europe and America, but should establish a new type of economic relationship. After emphasizing that large banks, large industries, and large commerce belong to the New Democratic country, Mao Zedong quoted the content related to the Nationalist Party's First Congress declaration, that is, "All domestic and foreign enterprises, either monopolistic in nature or too large to be operated by private forces, such as banks, railways, and water routes, should be managed by the state, so that the private capital system cannot manipulate the people's livelihood. This is the essence of capital regulation." He believed that this was the correct guideline for the economic composition of the New Democracy Republic. Regarding the policy towards capitalist economy, Mao Zedong clearly stated: After the victory of the New Democratic Revolution, it can be envisaged, and it is not surprising that the capitalist economy will develop to a considerable extent in Chinese society because the obstacles on the path of capitalist development have been cleared away. This is because the Chinese economy is still very backward. Therefore, the standard for confiscating capital is whether it can manipulate national economic and social welfare. At the same time, the development of state-owned economy and cooperative economy should be encouraged, gradually increasing their proportions, to provide economic guarantees to avoid the future development of capitalism. In rural areas, confiscate the landlords' land and distribute it to farmers with little or no land, implementing the principle of "those who work the land should own it", eliminating feudal relationships in rural areas, but allowing the existence of the rich peasant economy, which is the "equal land rights" policy. During the era of New Democracy, generally agriculture was not socialist, but various cooperative economies that developed on the basis of those who work the land owning it also had elements of socialism. The new production relationships established based on the principles of capital regulation and equal land rights were consistent with the development level of social productivity at the time, and this was also a concentrated expression of the consistency between Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and the Chinese Communist Party's New Democracy program.



Thirdly, the basic policy and correct approach to developing a New Democratic economy are discussed. The New Democratic economy consists of the state economy, the private economy, and the cooperative economy. Without the coordinated development of these three types of economies, it would be impossible for the Chinese people to build a socialist economy on a semi-feudal and semi-colonial foundation. Consequently, the Party has formulated several specific policies to develop the economy. In terms of labor policy, it employs a dual approach of modestly improving workers’ living conditions and not hindering the legitimate development of the capitalist economy, in order to balance labor-capital relationships and promote economic development. The land policy continues to adjust based on changes in the Party's central tasks at different times. From the "confiscation of all land" in the ten years of civil war, it transitioned to a dual policy during the war of resistance demanding landlords to reduce rents and interest, which positively united landlords and rich peasants to join the war of resistance against Japan. Regarding the policy towards private capitalism, Mao Zedong pointed out that while state and cooperative economies should be developed, in the current rural base areas, the main component of the economy is not state-owned, but privately owned. It gives free capitalist economies a chance to thrive in order to oppose Japanese imperialism and the semi-feudal system, which is currently the most revolutionary policy. He openly declared that Communists have a unique viewpoint on economic revolution: "Some people don't understand why Communists are not afraid of capitalism, but advocate its development under certain conditions. Our answer is simple: replace foreign imperialism and feudal oppression with a certain development of capitalism. It not only benefits the bourgeoisie but also the proletariat. Right now, China has one more foreign imperialist and one more feudal system, not one more native capitalist; on the contrary, we need more capitalism." Under China's unique historical conditions and the system of New Democracy, the general abolition of private property is not the aim, but rather the general protection of private property. Opposing capitalist thought within the Party while not opposing the capitalist elements in socio-economic contexts is paramount. After 1940, the War of Resistance bases and the Shaanxi-Gansu-Ningxia border area entered the most difficult times. To overcome these hardships, Mao Zedong prioritized economic development in the construction of border regions and base areas, believing that the War of Resistance was not only a political and military competition but more importantly an economic one. He proposed: "Develop the economy, ensure supplies, is our overall guideline for economic and financial work." Carry out large-scale civilian production initiatives, implement self-dependency, and abundant food and clothing. The correct way to develop the economy was proposed to be overcoming individual decentralized management and achieving collectivization, and the only way to achieve collectivization was through cooperatives as a form of production organization. It emphasized the need to develop heavy and light industries to create conditions for the transformation from an agricultural country to an industrial one. Especially the proposal of the standard of social productivity shows its theoretical depth and outstanding wisdom. He said, "The quality and magnitude of the role of the policies and practices of all parties in China among the Chinese people, ultimately, depend on whether they help the development of the productive forces of the Chinese people and the amount of help, whether they are shackling productivity or liberating productivity."

With the smooth progress of the Liberation War, the victory of the Chinese democratic revolution was only a matter of time. The Party deeply and systematically reflected on how to develop a New Democratic economy after the victory of the revolution, and fully elaborated on the economic program of New Democracy.

After long-term revolutionary struggles and constant summarization of experiences and lessons, Mao Zedong clearly put forward the three major economic programs of New Democracy in "The Current Situation and Our Tasks" in 1947, namely: "The confiscation of the land of the feudal class belongs to the peasants, the confiscation of the monopoly capital headed by Chiang Kai-shek, Soong Ziwen, Kong Xiangxi, and Chen Lifu belongs to the New Democratic state, and the protection of national industry and commerce."



"
Firstly, the confiscation of the landlords' lands to be owned by the peasants is the central content of the New Democratic Revolution and one of the basic economic programs of New Democracy. The peasant problem is the fundamental problem of the Chinese revolution and also the central issue for the proletariat to achieve leadership. The peasant problem, first and foremost, is the land problem. In semi-colonial and semi-feudal China, the feudal land system, where the landlord class cruelly exploited the peasants by occupying land, seriously hindered the development of rural productivity and was one of the root causes of China's poverty and backwardness. Therefore, launching land reform among the poor peasants, eliminating the feudal exploitation of the land system, and implementing "land to the tiller" was a major task of the New Democratic Revolution.
When a new historical stage arrived, the Party highly affirmed the land policy and land distribution methods, which were formulated according to reality during the land revolution period, that is: relying on poor and hired peasants, uniting middle peasants, restricting rich peasants, protecting small and medium-sized industrial and commercial entrepreneurs, eliminating the landlord class, and turning feudal land ownership into peasant land ownership; distributing land equally on a per capita basis at the village level, based on the original farmland, with more being subtracted from more abundant and less fertile land being compensated for. The Party also believed that during the Anti-Japanese War, to meet the requirements of uniting against Japan, the Chinese Communist Party's policy of confiscating the landlord class's lands and allocating them to peasants was changed to a policy of rent and interest reduction, which also made the Party's land policy conducive to actual development. Based on the rich practice and ideological accumulation of these two historical stages, on May 4, 1946, the CPC Central Committee issued "Instructions on the Land Issue," or the "May Fourth Instructions," changing the rent and interest reduction policy of the Anti-Japanese War period back to confiscating the landlord class's lands and allocating them to peasants, and implementing land reform in the liberated areas. The National Land Conference in 1947 formulated the first relatively complete New Democratic land program in the history of the Communist Party of China— "Outline of China's Land Law," which clearly stipulates that "the exploitative land system of feudalism and semi-feudalism should be abolished, and the land system of 'land to the tiller' should be implemented." At the Party's December Conference the same year, Mao Zedong summed up the experience of land reform, pointing out that the guideline for land reform was: "Rely on poor peasants, solidly unite middle peasants, and eliminate the feudal and semi-feudal exploitation system of the landlord class and the old-type rich peasants." Meanwhile, he emphasized the two basic principles that must be paid attention to in land reform: "First, the demands of poor peasants and hired peasants must be met; this is the most basic task of land reform; second, firm unity with middle peasants must be maintained; their interests should not be harmed."
In his speech at the expansion meeting of the Northwestern Field Army Front Committee in January 1948, Mao Zedong asked various local democratic governments to pay attention to the fact that in the process of land reform, landlords as a class should be eliminated, but as individuals, they should be protected. "The abolition of the private ownership of the landlord class does not mean that we do not need them as individuals. Landlords and old-type rich peasants constitute one-tenth of the rural population, a total of 36 million people nationwide. This is a labor force in society and a form of wealth. If we distribute a share of land and property to them and let them participate in productive labor, they can carry a litter, produce food, and pay public grain, which is beneficial to the state." Mao Zedong also pointed out that the purpose of defeating Chiang Kai-shek and eliminating the landlord class is "to economically destroy the feudal comprador production relations and liberate the shackled productive forces. In the countryside, it is to liberate the peasants, break the feudal land ownership system, implement thorough land equalization, transfer land ownership to the peasants, and enable the peasants to feel at ease to produce, and improve farming methods”."



In April of the same year, Mao Zedong, in his speech at the Jin-Sui Cadre Conference, clearly and completely defined the party's overall route and overall policy for land reform, which is “rely on the poor peasants, unite with middle peasants, gradually and differentially eliminate the feudal exploitation system, and develop agricultural production”. This line, guideline, and policy, maximally united and strived for all the forces that could be united in the countryside, represented the interests of the broadest masses in China's rural areas, ensured the smooth progress of land reform, liberated and developed rural productivity, consolidated the worker-peasant alliance, and laid the foundation and conditions for the victory of China's revolution and the realization of national industrialization.

Second, the confiscation of bureaucratic monopolistic capital for the ownership of the new democratic state is another important content in the economic program of the new democracy. Bureaucratic capital, represented by the four major families of Jiang, Song, Ji I, and Chen, formed in the later stage of the land revolution, and reached its peak during the Anti-Japanese War. The KMT's bureaucratic capital includes two parts: one is the state monopoly capital, which is all the capital of the country owned by the big landlords and the bourgeoisie represented by the four major families; the other is the private capital owned by the four major families and other bureaucrats and warlords. These two parts of capital monopolize the economic lifeline of the country, represent reactionary production relations, and are serious obstacles to China's economic and social development. To confiscate bureaucratic capital is to confiscate these two parts of capital.

The confiscation of bureaucratic capital has a dual revolutionary nature: on the one hand, bureaucratic capital is the feudal and comprador state monopoly capitalism, which is the economic foundation of the Kuomintang rule. Opposing bureaucratic capital is to oppose feudal and comprador capital, which has the nature of a new democratic revolution; on the other hand, to oppose bureaucratic capital is to oppose the big bourgeoisie, and to concentrate this immense power that controls the national economic lifeline into the hands of the new democratic state, become the main source of the state-owned economy of socialist nature, and create conditions for the socialist transformation. Therefore, the confiscation of bureaucratic capital also has the nature of a socialist revolution.

During the Liberation War, the Communist Party of China began to confiscate bureaucratic capital from the cities in the liberated northeastern region; after the three major battles, it basically confiscated the bureaucratic capital enterprises north of the Yangtze River; by the end of 1949, except for Taiwan, all the bureaucratic capital enterprises on the mainland had been taken over by the people's government, owned by the people's state. Completing the revolutionary task of confiscating bureaucratic capital has important significance: firstly, confiscating the bureaucratic capital in a dominant position allows the new democratic state to control the country's economic lifeline, making the state-owned economy the leading position in the national economy; secondly, the proletariat can use the economic power transformed from bureaucratic capital to consolidate the newly born People's Republic; finally, it laid the foundation for the transition to socialism by establishing a new democratic society and corresponding economic system.

Third, the protection of national industries and commerce is a very characteristic content in the economic program of the new democracy. As mentioned before, the Communist Party of China divides Chinese capitalism into bureaucratic capitalism and national capitalism, and adopts completely different policies. A protectionist policy is implemented for national capitalism, that is, under the conditions of new democracy, they allow the capitalist economy that does not manipulate the national economy and people's livelihood to develop.

Because we completed the transformation from new democracy to socialism too early in our actual work, and finished the transformation of national capitalism too early, and massively criticized capitalism after the mid-1960s, "cut off the tail of capitalism", and made a series of "leftist" errors, some people thought Mao Zedong has always been a "populist", a "utopian" .



However, in the process of the New Democratic Revolution, especially in the dispute over the "founding of the nation in 1949" after the Anti-Japanese War, only the Chinese Communists represented by Mao Zedong repeatedly declared that in the new democratic society, not only should we not be afraid of capitalism, but under certain conditions, we should advocate its development. All kinds of bourgeoisie dare not propose the development of capitalism. Only the Communist Party of China puts the protection of national industry and commerce and the development of capitalism beneficial to the national economy and the people's livelihood as its own economic program. It has conducted a profound analysis and criticism of the populist ideology within the party from the combination of theory and practice.

Mao Zedong pointed out: First, socialism must have socialized large-scale production as its solid material base. Whether or not to have this base "is where Marxism differs from populism". Second, the agricultural socialist thought advocating absolute egalitarianism on the issue of land distribution, which destroys industry and commerce, namely the so-called socialism based on small rural production advocated by populists, is "reactionary, backward, and retrogressive in nature. We must criticize this kind of thought". Third, this type of socialism not only protects backward small-scale production, but also inevitably defends feudalism and alienates socialism into despotism suppressing individual liberation. "If the bound personality is not liberated, there is neither democracy nor socialism". In short, the socialism advocated by populists is against the law of social development and is an utopian, reactionary thought.

Why should we protect national industry and commerce and allow the capitalist economy that does not manipulate the national economy and the people's livelihood to develop? Mao Zedong pointed out: First, "to replace the oppression of foreign imperialism and domestic feudalism with a certain development of capitalism, is not only a progress but also an inevitable process". Second, under certain conditions, the development of capitalism "is beneficial not only to the bourgeoisie but also to the proletariat, or even more beneficial to the proletariat. The present China has one more foreign imperialism and one more domestic feudalism, not one more domestic capitalism. On the contrary, our capitalism is too little". In summary, the development of capitalism under the new democratic regime is beneficial and harmless. "What we advocate is the capitalism of new democracy, which has its vitality and is still revolutionary", "Its nature is to help socialism, it is revolutionary, useful, and beneficial to the development of socialism".

The conception of a new democratic economic structure is the core of the new democratic economic theory and an important part of the party's new democratic social thought.

With the successive victories of the New Democratic Revolution and the implementation of the three major economic programs, the conception of the New Democratic economic structure gradually took shape. Mao Zedong's "On New Democracy" mentioned the economic structure of New Democratic society, pointing out: "The large banks, corporations, and businesses belong to the state of this republic... The state-run economy of the New Democratic Republic under the leadership of the proletariat is of a socialist nature and is the leading force in the entire national economy." "It does not confiscate other capitalists’ private property, and does not prohibit the development of capitalist production that cannot manipulate the national economy and the people's livelihood. This is due to the fact that China's economy is still very backward.” “Confiscate the land of the landlords... Transform the land into the private property of the peasants", "At this stage, in general, it is not about establishing socialist agriculture yet, but the various cooperative economies that develop on the basis of 'the tiller has its field' also have socialist elements".
"The richer economy of the rural areas is also allowed to exist". It is not hard to see that in the new democratic economic structure envisaged by Mao Zedong at the time, there were five economic components, namely the state-run economy, cooperative economy, private capitalist economy, individual economy, and the richer economy. This idea was further refined a few years later. In December 1947, Mao Zedong further clarified the economic components of New Democracy in his paper "The Current Situation and Our Tasks": "1) state-run economy, which is the leading component; 2) the agricultural economy gradually moving towards the direction of collectivization from the individual; 3) the economy of independent small industrial and commercial operators and small and medium-sized private capital economy.



"These are the entirety of the New Democracy's national economy." This division combines the individual economy and the rich peasant economy into the agricultural economy. Though it is simpler and more scientific than the classification in the "On New Democracy," it only includes the three economic components of the state-owned economy, private capitalist economy, and agricultural economy. This is obviously incomplete, and therefore, this theory still needs further development. The person to complete this development was Zhang Wentian. In July 1948, at a joint meeting of county organization department secretaries and propaganda department secretaries called by the Northeast Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee, Zhang Wentian summarized his years of research and proposed the idea of six components of the new democratic economy: ① State-owned economy or public economy; ② State capitalism; ③ Private capitalism; ④ Petty commodity economy, primarily the peasant economy; ⑤ Co-operative economy; ⑥ Nomadic economy. This formulation, though not perfect and its exposition not thorough enough, nonetheless established a complete framework for the last proposal of the New Democracy economic structure. 

Two months later, based on his report at the Urban Work Conference of the Northeast Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee, Zhang Wentian wrote a report to the central government titled, "Outline on the Composition and Basic Policy of Northeast Economy," explicitly proposing five components of the new democratic economy, namely "state-owned economy, co-operative economy, state capitalism, private capitalism, petty commodity economy (a small part of the natural economy is not significant, hence omitted)." This is the earliest and most complete exposition of the new democratic economy's composition. 

Zhang Wentian also fully discussed the nature, status, development direction, and interrelationships of these 5 types of economies: ① The state-owned economy is a socialist economy that holds a leading position in the national economy. ② The cooperative economy is of socialist qualities in varying degrees and is a reliable and powerful assistant to the state-owned economy. Only through a cooperative economy can agricultural collectivization be realized, enabling farmers to move from new democracy to socialism. ③ State capitalism, or capitalism "managed and supervised" by the new democratic state, is the form of private capitalism most advantageous to the development of new democracy. Therefore, we should consciously acknowledge the economic category of "state capitalism" and consciously promote and organize it. ④ Private capitalism is a capitalist economy. Given the backwardness of our national economy, the development of private capitalism is inevitable and necessary to a certain extent. However, it should not be allowed to develop unchecked, but must be managed and supervised within certain limits. ⑤ Petty commodity economy stands at a crossroads between capitalism and socialism. After a long period of education and struggle, under New Democracy led by the proletariat, it will develop towards socialism, but this requires "a longer transition period than Eastern European countries." Zhang Wentian believed: "Only by correctly understanding the nature, position, development direction and interrelationship of these five economies can we determine the starting point and basis for the economic policy in the Northeast. Only in this way can we grasp the correct line on the economic front and realize the correct leadership of the proletariat in the construction of the social economy." Zhang Wentian's scientific argument marked the real maturity of the new democratic economic structure and made its final formation possible a year later. 


The formal formation of this concept is marked by two important documents: Mao Zedong's report at the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, and the Common Program of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (hereinafter referred to as the "Common Program") on the new democratic economic structure. 

Mao Zedong first discussed the extreme importance of making the state-owned economy the leading component of the entire national economy, then pointed out: "China's private capitalist industry...is a force that cannot be ignored... During this period, all urban and rural capitalist elements that are not harmful to the national economy but beneficial should be allowed to exist and develop..."


"This is not only inevitable, but also economically necessary." Regarding the dispersed individual economy, Mao Zedong believed that "it is possible and necessary to guide them cautiously, gradually and actively towards modernization and collectivization. The laissez-faire view is wrong." Mao Zedong also recognized the importance of the cooperative economy, saying: "Only the state-owned economy without the cooperative economy, we will not be able to guide the individual economy of the working people towards collectivization step by step, it will not be possible to develop from a new democratic society to a socialist society, and it will not be possible to solidify the leadership of the proletariat in state power." Finally, he summed up: "The state-owned economy is of a socialist nature, the cooperative economy is semi-socialist, plus the private capitalist economy, the individual economy, and the state-capitalist economy cooperated by the state and private individuals, these are the main economic components of the People's Republic. These constitute the new democratic economic form."

The "Common Program", which once played the temporary role of the constitution, undoubtedly has authoritative and legal validity in determining the economic structure of new democracy. The provisions about the economic structure of new democracy have put a successful end to the decades-long development process of this concept. The "Common Program" discusses the nature, role, status, and prospects of the five types of economic components allowed in the new democratic society, generally follows Mao Zedong's approach, and ultimately stipulates: The fundamental guideline for the economic construction of the People's Republic of China is to consider both public and private sectors, benefit both labor and capital, foster mutual aid between urban and rural areas, and promote domestic and international exchange. The goal is to enhance productivity and boost the economy. The state should adjust the state-owned economy, cooperative economy, individual economy of farmers and craftsmen, private capitalist economy, and state capitalist economy in terms of business scope, raw material supply, market sales, working conditions, technical equipment, fiscal policy, financial policy, etc., and let various social economic components cooperate under the leadership of the state-owned economy, each playing its part to stimulate the overall socio-economic development. This guideline and policy conform to the social realities created by China's history and revolution, help exploit the advantages of various economic components, and foster rapid socio-economic development.

Fourth, building a national, scientific, and popular new culture.

During the Anti-Japanese War, Mao Zedong successively published "New Democracy", "Reform Our Study", "On the Yan'an Forum on Literature and Art", "Art Workers Must Combine with Workers, Peasants and Soldiers", "The United Front in Cultural Work", "On the Coalition Government" and other articles. These articles expressed the Chinese Communist Party's understanding of cultural issues, systematically constructed the cultural thoughts of New Democracy, and formed the cultural program of New Democracy.

The Chinese Communist Party scientifically explains the historical inevitability of the emergence of New Democratic culture from the dialectical relationship between culture and politics and the economy. The Chinese Communist Party reveals the historical inevitability of the emergence of New Democratic culture from the background of the changes in social structure and cultural structure in China since the Opium War. Mao Zedong believed, starting from the Opium War in 1840, China gradually declined from an independent and complete feudal society to a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society. Changes in the social, political, and economic structure would inevitably lead to changes in culture and cultural structure. Prior to the Opium War, Chinese culture was a single feudal culture; after the Opium War, in addition to feudal culture, there were also imperialist servile culture and the newly emerged democratic culture of the national bourgeoisie. In other words, after the Opium War, the nature of Chinese social culture has changed from single to diverse. At this time, on the one hand, the old culture of feudalism continued to control the spiritual life of the Chinese people deeply; on the other hand, feudal culture coexisted and fought with servile culture and democratic culture. The uniqueness of the modern social development in China and the complexity of the renewal of thoughts and culture determined the multiplicity of the nature of modern Chinese social culture, which belonged to a multi-track culture.




In the contradictory evolution of China's modern multi-track culture, bourgeois democratic culture is a powerful force on the frontline of China's modern culture. They serve the purpose of the Chinese democratic revolution by challenging China's feudal culture and represent the direction of societal evolution in China. During the Hundred Days' Reform and the Xinhai Revolution, progressive Chinese people actively studied and promoted Western democratic culture and tried to mimic it to establish democratic culture in China. They used bourgeois democratic culture as a weapon to start a war against feudal culture, aiming to awaken people to revolutionize and strengthen the nation. Since the bourgeois democratic culture in China is not derived from the soil of its own feudal culture but transplanted from Western culture, its class basis is very small. China's feudal culture has a long history and has formed a firm national cultural psychological structure through dynastic feudal systems. The slave culture supported by imperialism is colluding with it to form a cultural alliance against bourgeois democratic culture. Therefore, in the face of confrontation, the bourgeois democratic culture can only enter the battle for a few rounds before being repelled by this reactionary alliance. Mao Zedong pointed out: "The old bourgeois democratic culture, in the era of imperialism, has decayed and become powerless. Its failure is inevitable." The new democratic culture was born under such historical conditions. This means that the bankruptcy of the old democratic culture and the emergence of the new democratic culture in the imperial era are the inevitable results of modern historical development. After the May Fourth Movement in 1919, the advanced proletariat came to China's historical stage with its firm and uncompromising anti-imperialist and anti-feudal spirit, exhibiting new and powerful political power, thus adding fresh content to modern Chinese society. The new cultural movement after the "May Fourth" quickly developed into a Marxist ideological movement. So, in China's modern multi-track culture, a new cultural content was injected, causing a historical turning point in the direction of modern culture. On the one hand, China's old democratic culture is riddled with holes and has been defeated repeatedly in its struggle against imperialist slave culture and feudal culture, yet it retains its progressiveness. On the other hand, it is true that China's old democratic culture is incapable of overthrowing feudal and slave cultures. Only the advanced proletarian new democratic culture guided by Marxism can overthrow feudal and slave cultures. The proletarian new democratic culture has gradually become the main force of China's modern cultural revolution.
The Communist Party of China has made it clear that the new democratic culture is the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal culture led by the proletariat, which is the most salient historical feature of the new democratic culture. Mao Zedong pointed out that the cultural or ideological front in China has formed two different historical periods around the "May Fourth". Before the "May Fourth", the struggle on China's cultural front was the struggle between the bourgeois new culture and the feudal old culture. Before the "May Fourth", the conflicts between schools and imperial examinations, new learning and old learning, Western learning and Chinese learning, all had this characteristic. The so-called schools, new learning, and Western learning of that time were basically the natural sciences required by the representatives of the bourgeoisie and their social political theories (basically, there were still a lot of feudal remnants in China). He believed that this so-called new learning has a revolutionary role in the struggle against Chinese feudal thought and serves for the Chinese bourgeois democratic revolution of the old era. However, due to the weakness of the Chinese bourgeoisie and the world had already entered the imperialist era, this bourgeois thought could only enter the battlefield for a few rounds, then was repelled by the reactionary alliance of foreign imperialist enslaving thoughts and Chinese feudal retrogressive thoughts. This philosophical reactionary alliance, with only a slight counter-attack, confesses so-called new learning capitulation, retreats, loses its spirit, and only leaves its shell.


Therefore, he concluded that the old bourgeois democratic culture, in the era of imperialism, has decayed and become powerless, and its failure is inevitable. This is not the case after the "May Fourth Movement". After the "May Fourth Movement", China gave birth to an entirely new cultural force, which is the cultural thought of communism led by the Chinese communists, that is, the cosmic view of communism and the theory of social revolution. As the era was after the First World War and the October Revolution, i.e., when the national question and the colonial revolution had changed the face of the world, this made the Chinese revolution closely linked to the world revolution. With China's new political force, namely the Chinese proletariat and the Chinese Communist Party, taking to the stage of Chinese politics, this cultural force, armed with new costumes and new weapons, united all possible allies, arrayed itself and waged a valiant attack on imperialist culture and feudal culture. This new force has made great strides in the fields of social sciences and literature and art, whether in philosophy, economics, political science, military science, history, literature, or art (be it drama, film, music, sculpture, or painting). The edge of this new cultural army, from ideas to forms (such as text), has brought about a great revolution. Its momentum is so great and its power is so fierce that it is practically invincible. Its mobilization is wider than any historical era in China. Therefore, Mao Zedong emphasized that before the "May Fourth Movement", China’s new culture was of old democratic nature, a part of the capitalist cultural revolution of the world bourgeoisie; after the "May Fourth Movement", China's new culture is of new democratic nature, a part of the cultural revolution of the world proletariat's socialism. Before the "May Fourth Movement", China's new cultural movement, and China's cultural revolution were led by the bourgeoisie, and they still had a leading role; after the "May Fourth Movement", the cultural thoughts of this class are more backward than their political ones, and they have no leading role; at most, they play the role of an ally to a certain extent during the revolution, as for the role of an alliance leader, it had to fall on the shoulders of proletarian cultural thought. This is an iron fact that no one can deny. Accordingly, Mao Zedong reached the conclusion: the so-called new democratic culture is the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal culture of the people; today, it is the culture of the anti-Japanese united front. This culture can only be led by the proletarian cultural thoughts, i.e., communist thoughts, and any other class's cultural thoughts cannot lead it. The so-called new democratic culture, in a word, is the proletarian-led anti-imperialist and anti-feudal culture of the people.
New democratic culture is the antithesis of proletarian socialist cultural thought leading the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal new democracy of the masses, which is the fundamental attribute of new democratic culture. Mao Zedong first criticized the bourgeois reactionary culture that was prevalent at the time, pointing out that the bourgeois reactionaries, on the question of culture, were as completely wrong as they were on the question of power. They do not know the historical characteristics of China's new period, they do not recognize the new democratic culture of the people. Their starting point is bourgeois authoritarianism, culturally it is bourgeois cultural authoritarianism. A section of the so-called Western culture people, they had actually sponsored the Kuomintang government's cultural "annihilation of the Communists", and now seem to be sponsoring some kind of "limit the Communists", "dissolve the Communists" policy. They are unwilling to let workers and peasants stand up politically, nor do they want them to stand up culturally. The culture of the capitalist diehards, the path of cultural despotism, is not viable, like the question of power, it does not have domestic or international conditions. Therefore, this cultural despotism, is also best to be "withdrawn".



Next, he criticized the erroneous view that the leadership of the New Democratic Revolution simply belongs to the proletariat, and therefore, the New Democratic culture is also of a socialist nature. He pointed out: As a guideline for national culture, it is communist thought that occupies a guiding position, and we should strive to propagate socialism and communism among the working class, and step by step, appropriately, use socialist education for peasants and other masses. However, the whole national culture is not yet socialist. The politics, economy, and culture of the New Democracy, because they are led by the proletariat, all have socialist elements, and not just ordinary elements, but decisive factors. However, in terms of the overall political situation, the overall economic situation, and the overall cultural situation, they are not socialist, but New Democratic. This is because the main task of the current stage of revolution is to oppose foreign imperialism and domestic feudalism, it is a bourgeois democratic revolution, and it is not a socialist revolution aimed at overthrowing capitalism. In terms of national culture, if one thinks that the current national culture is or should be a socialist national culture, this is incorrect. This is the propagation of the communist ideological system, which has been regarded as the practice of the current action program; the observation of problems, research, handling of work, and training of cadres from the position and method of communism, as the guideline for the whole national education and national culture during the stage of the Chinese Democratic Revolution. A national culture with socialism as its content must reflect socialist politics and economy. We have socialist elements politically and economically, which are reflected in our national culture as well. But as a whole society, we have not yet formed such an overall socialist political and economic system, so we can't have such an overall socialist national culture. The current Chinese Revolution is part of the world proletariat socialist revolution, and therefore, the current new culture of China is also part of the new culture of world proletarian socialism, it is a great ally; this part, although it contains significant elements of socialist culture, but in terms of the entire national culture, it does not participate purely with the qualifications of socialist culture, but with the qualifications of the New Democratic culture of the people's anti-imperialist and anti-feudal revolution. Since the current Chinese Revolution cannot do without the leadership of the Chinese proletarian culture, the current new culture of China also cannot do without the leadership of Chinese proletarian cultural thought, that is, the leadership of communist thought. But this leadership, at the current stage, is leading the masses to carry out an anti-imperialist and anti-feudal political and cultural revolution, so the content of the new national culture as a whole is still New Democratic, not socialist. At present, unquestionably, we should expand the propaganda of communist thought, intensify the study of Marxism-Leninism, without this propaganda and study, not only can we not lead the Chinese revolution to the future stage of socialism, but we also cannot direct the current democratic revolution to victory. However, we should distinguish between the propaganda of the communist ideological system and the socialist system, and the practice of the New Democratic action program; and also distinguish between the communist theory and method for observing problems, studying academys, handling work, training cadres, and the New Democratic guideline for the entire national culture. It would be highly inappropriate to conflate the two.

Based on the above analysis, Mao Zedong pointed out that, at the current stage, the content of China's new national culture is neither bourgeois cultural authoritarianism nor purely proletarian socialism, but New Democracy of the People's Anti-imperialist and Anti-feudal Revolution led by proletarian socialist cultural thought.

Based on the status of China's social, political, and economic development, on the basis of building a New Democratic society, Mao Zedong proposed the basic content of building a New Democratic culture. 

Mao Zedong pointed out that the New Democratic culture is firstly national, "It is against imperialist oppression, advocates the dignity and independence of the Chinese nation. It belongs to our nation, with our national characteristics."


Mao Zedong has always emphasized that Chinese culture must have its own distinctive characteristics of the Chinese nation and should have its own form, which is the national form, because "it is of our nation". Mao advocated that Chinese culture should have a national form and a New Democratic content, but he did not simply "favor new and despise old", instead, he particularly emphasized that Chinese culture should have historical continuity, for he revered that the source and root of the national culture he favored lies in traditional Chinese culture. Emphasizing the independence of the Chinese nation in cultural development is based on emphasizing the themes of the imperialist and proletarian revolutionary era, it is also a full recognition of the political and cultural struggle against imperialism in China since modern times. At the same time, Mao believed that, in the sense of world revolution, emphasizing the national characteristics of cultural development does not imply establishing a narrow nationalist closed culture, on the contrary, the construction of the new culture of the Chinese nation should be open and unite with the socialist cultures and the new democratic cultures of other nations in the world to establish a mutually absorbing and mutually developing relationship, together forming the world's new culture, which is the revolutionary national culture.

Mao Zedong linked national culture with the development of world culture, this thought greatly strengthened the foundation and future of the development of China's New Democratic culture. In "The Position of the Communist Party of China in the National War", he criticises the practice of individuals who do not understand internationalism, who separate internationalist content and national form. He believes that Chinese culture should "unite with all other nations' socialist cultures and new democratic cultures to establish a mutually absorbing and mutually developing relationship, together forming the world's new culture." He advocates for "absorbing more fresh foreign things, not only absorbing their progressive reasonings, but also absorbing their new expressions." We should absorb what we need from foreign languages. Mao pointed out: "China should absorb a great deal of foreign progressive culture as raw material for its own cultural food; this work is not yet sufficient." Mao believes that not only current socialist and new democratic cultures, but also foreign ancient cultures, such as the culture of the enlightenment era of capitalist countries, anything that we need today, should be absorbed. He sees New Democratic culture as the result of absorbing the spiritual wealth of not only China but also all of humanity, Mao maintained the dialectical and synthetic cultural standpoint of early Chinese Marxists, and truly clarified in theory the exploration of the issue of Chinese cultural development started by people like Li Dazhao and Chen Duxiu, an important link in historical development was completed.

Here, Mao proposed a famous principle: "All foreign things, just like our food, must pass through our own mouth-chewing and gastrointestinal movement, mix into saliva gastric juice intestinal juice, decompose it into essence and chaff, and then excrete the chaff, absorb its essence, then it can be beneficial to our body, we must not swallow it live without any criticism." This is not only a historical summary of the experience of the Chinese revolution, but also a correct grasp of the direction of the new cultural movement since the May Fourth Movement. In the article "Against Party 'Eight-legged Essays'", Mao criticised the formalism of the May Fourth Movement. He pointed out that many leaders of the May Fourth Movement lacked the critical spirit of Marxism, and the methods they used were generally bourgeois methods, that is, formalistic methods. 

"They opposed the old 'eight-legged essays' and old dogmas, advocated science and democracy, which was very right. But in their views of the current situation, history, and foreign things, they lacked the critical spirit of historical materialism. What they called bad was absolutely bad, all was bad; what they called good was absolutely good, all was good. This formalistic way of seeing things affected the development of this movement." Dogmatism and "total westernization" are the "left" and "right" ends of this formalistic concept.


Mao Zedong specifically mentioned the detrimental effects of formalism on the Chinese Communist movement and propagation of Marxism. He pointed out that the fundamental principles of Marxism must be fully and appropriately unified with the concrete practice of the Chinese revolution, "that is to say, it would only be useful when combined with national characteristics and subject to specific national forms, rather than subjectively or formulaically applied". "Formulaic Marxism" is undoubtedly a subjective and dogmatic form of Marxism that commences from a "canonical" and "textual" standpoint, assuming a far "left" facade and inflicting tremendous losses on the Chinese revolution. Mao Zedong pointed out that not only should the Chinese Revolution oppose "formalistic Marxism", but Chinese culture should also have its own form, that is, a national form. "National form, content of new democracy - this is our new culture today."

Next, New Democratic Culture is scientific, "It opposes all feudal and superstitious thought, advocates seeking truth from facts, advocates objective truth, and advocates the consistency of theory and practice." 

Inheriting the spirit of promoting scientific rationality since the "May 4th" movement, Mao Zedong pointed out that in the cause of anti-imperialism and anti-feudal superstition, the scientific thinking of the Chinese proletariat can establish a united front with materialists and natural scientists from the still progressive bourgeoisie in China to complete the enlightenment work since the "May 4th" movement. Here, Mao Zedong proposed scientific methodological principles for treating historical cultural heritage. First, Mao Zedong made this judgment on the nature of Chinese historical culture: "China's long-term feudal society has created a brilliant ancient culture." Therefore, when clearing up the legacy of ancient culture, you have to "eliminate its feudal dross, absorb its democratic essence". This is a necessary condition for developing the new culture of the Chinese nation and enhancing national self-confidence. Second, this kind of cleaning work cannot be indiscriminately inclusive without criticism. It is necessary to distinguish between the decayed things of the ancient feudal ruling class and the excellent ancient people's culture that has a certain degree of democracy and revolutionary nature. Third, we cannot sever history, because China's new culture at present comes from the development of ancient culture, so we should respect our own history. "But this kind of respect, is to give history a scientific status, is to respect the development of dialectics of history, not to praise the past and not the present, not to praise any feudal poison." Applying Marxist standpoints, views, and methods, Mao Zedong has transcended the "May 4th" era's debate on the cultures of "both ancient and modern times and both Eastern and Western cultures", and solved the methodological principle of cultural inheritance. Undoubtedly, this principle is both the inevitable result of the dialectic integrated cultural stance held by Li Dazhao and other early Chinese Marxists and a summary of the regularity of Chinese cultural historical movement.

On creating a new culture, Mao Zedong believes that it can only be maintained by adhering to practicality. He pointed out in his December 1936 "On the Strategic Issues of the Chinese Revolutionary War": "Reading is learning, using is also learning, and it's even more important." This presents his methodology of learning from application. In the "Rectification of the Party's Style of Work", he called on the whole party to "learn to apply the standpoints, viewpoints and methods of Marxism-Leninism, study China's history earnestly, study China's economics, politics, military and culture". Because, "for the theory of Marxism, it must be proficient and applicable, and the aim of proficiency is entirely for the purpose of application."

To always maintain the progressiveness of new culture, Mao Zedong believes that the progressiveness of cultural effects is reflected in the fact that culture should represent the direction of social development, represent the interests of the advanced class, and should play a role in promoting the development and progress of society. He clearly stated in "On New Democracy": "To turn China, which has been dominated by old culture and therefore is backward and ignorant, into a China that is dominated by new culture and therefore is civilized and advanced." "Establish a new culture for the Chinese nation, that is our purpose in the field of culture." Because of this, he fully affirmed the great significance of the May Fourth New Culture Movement thoroughly and uncompromisingly opposing imperialism and feudalism, because it is in line with the tasks of the Chinese democratic revolution against imperialism and feudalism in modern times, and it heralds the prelude to the New Democratic Revolution in China.



Finally, the new democratic culture is a culture of the masses. Mao Zedong pointed out that it should serve the labouring masses who make up more than 90% of the whole nation and gradually become their culture. The knowledge of educating revolutionary cadres and the knowledge of educating the revolutionary masses should be distinguished and connected in terms of level, also improving and popularizing should be distinguished and connected. This is another vivid manifestation of the party's "seek truth from facts" ideological line. On the one hand, cultural construction should serve the fundamental purpose of the revolution, on the other hand, cultural construction has laid the ideological and cultural foundation for the revolution. In the direction of cultural construction, the party emphasized that democracy should be linked with cultural construction, thereby reversing the one-sidedness of the cultural movement, making it truly penetrate into society, into the workers and peasants, and become a bottom-up social cultural revolution. Therefore, the party pointed out that mass, democratic culture does not mean indiscriminate application of the same pattern, method, content for cultural education for all objects. Mao Zedong believed that two distinctions and connections should be noted: distinguishing and connecting the knowledge of educating revolutionary cadres and the knowledge of educating revolutionary masses in terms of degree; and distinguishing and connecting improvement and popularization. Mao Zedong's thoughts are clearly expounded in his "Talks at the Yan'an Forum on Literature and Art". He believes that the premises and foundations of popularization and improvement should all be the masses of workers and peasants, because "our art and literature are basically for the workers, peasants and soldiers, so what we call popularization is to popularize among the workers, peasants and soldiers, and what we call improvement is to improve from the workers, peasants and soldiers". He pointed out that popularization is the foundation, improvement is the development. "Improvement should be emphasized, but it is wrong to emphasize improvement to an inappropriate degree by focusing on it in a one-sided and isolated way." This wrong view neglected the actual ideological and cultural status of the Chinese working masses and failed to recognize the tasks faced by popularization and improvement. Because "what is popularized is relatively simple and easy to understand, it is therefore more easily accepted by the vast majority of people at present"."So under current conditions, the task of popularization is more urgent." Mao Zedong emphasized that popularization is more important and urgent, it does not mean the neglect of improvement, he believes the two cannot be completely separated. Because popularization needs development, popularization will also constantly improve the ideological culture of the masses of workers and peasants, and thus not satisfied with the simple popularization and demand improvement. For this reason, "popularization not only does not hinder improvement, but provides a basis for the current limited scope of improvement, and prepares necessary conditions for the future broad scope of improvement". Mao Zedong distinguished improvement into two types, one is the improvement for the masses; the other is the improvement for cadres. The connection of the two improvements is that they are both for the masses, and the distinction lies in the level of education, therefore he proposed that literature and art should "both have advanced art needed by the masses who have been elevated, or first needed by cadres in the masses, developed from the elementary artistic basis, and elementary art which is often most urgently needed by the greatest number of people today under the guidance of such advanced art". 
The mass new democratic culture, for the masses of the people, should also be a powerful weapon of revolution. The party pointed out that revolutionary culture, before the revolution, is the ideological preparation for revolution; during the revolution, it is a necessary and important front in the total front of the revolution. And the workers of revolutionary culture are the commanders at all levels on this cultural front. "Without revolutionary theory, there will be no revolutionary movement", it shows how important the revolutionary cultural movement is to the revolutionary practice movement. And this cultural movement and practice movement are both of the masses. Therefore, all progressive cultural workers, during the Anti-Japanese War, should have their own cultural army, and this army is the masses of the people. A revolutionary cultural person who does not get close to the people is a "commander without soldiers", whose firepower cannot defeat the enemy.


To achieve this goal, textual reform must be carried out under certain circumstances, and language must be brought closer to the people, for the people are the infinitely rich source of revolutionary culture. 
The establishment of the New Democratic Culture Program marks an important theoretical link in the process of sinicization of Marxism, finding the basic direction of Chinese cultural development in the historical thread of China's cultural revolution since modern times. It both opposes national nihilism and distinguishes from narrow nationalism, opposing the "left" and right-leaning erroneous tendencies, laying a theoretical foundation for the development of Chinese culture.
